headline: A Year Full of Missteps Is Finally Over
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Serviceman Held for Carrying Explosives Into Texas Airport
text: HOUSTON — A man preparing to board a flight at the airport in Midland, Tex., on Saturday morning was detained by the authorities after explosives in military-grade wrapping were discovered in his luggage, leading to an evacuation of the terminal building, law enforcement and city officials said.

headline: Picturing How Ryan Brothers Could Settle  Family Business
text: Yes, the Jets are a long shot to qualify for the playoffs Sunday. They need to beat Miami and hope for other outcomes to occur. Since we have exhausted every possible playoff scenario this week, and with the drama still to be played, I thought it might be fun to explore — Hollywood style — what could happen AFTER all N.F.L. games are concluded. Here is one possibility, with apologies to Francis Ford Coppola, that borrows heavily from a scene in “The Godfather,” when Michael Corleone, played by Al Pacino, settled all family business.

headline: Experts Weigh In on Outside Groups’ Pro-Gingrich Spots
text: DES MOINES — Can they do that?

headline: An Unlikely Group Rebels Against Preservation Districts
text: Susan Beckstead stepped out of her sky-blue, three-story classical revival Victorian on Pierce Street — the one with bay windows, dentil and egg-and-dart molding, a modillion cornice and balustrade-lined flat roof — to show a visitor around her 120-year-old neighborhood bordering Duboce Park in central San Francisco.

headline: Money Refused Could Become Money Owed
text: Juvenile offenders are often reminded that bad decisions have consequences. The juvenile justice systems in California counties are about to learn the same hard lesson.

headline: Simms Taback, Author of Wry Children’s Books, Dies at 79
text: Simms Taback, a children’s book illustrator and author who won the Caldecott Medal in 2000 for his adaptation of the nonsensical Yiddish folktale “Joseph Had a Little Overcoat,” died last Sunday at his home in Ventura, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Fancy Footwork for the Raiders and 49ers
text: This season, the Raiders and the 49ers have had standout performances by players who rarely get their hands on the ball. Meet the place-kickers and punters whose feet, though gnarled and sometime missing toenails, have helped carry their teams in the 2011 regular season.

headline: This Time, Wisconsin Is Ready
text: LOS ANGELES — Delayed by the filming of a car commercial on Figueroa Street, Wisconsin Coach Bret Bielema was about 10 minutes late for his scheduled Rose Bowl news conference Saturday morning. Upon his arrival, a grin and one of his standard wisecracks expressed the mantra the Badgers have been pushing since the moment they arrived in Southern California earlier this week.

headline: For a Second Night, Vehicles Are Set Ablaze in the Los Angeles Area
text: After a night when nearly 20 cars were set ablaze in Hollywood, in parking areas under apartment buildings or beside homes while people slept, area fire stations called in extra staff and increased patrols on Friday evening, awaiting a second strike, fire officials said.

headline: Girl in a Fishbowl
text: In a large fishbowl behind the bar at Bimbo’s 365 Club, it looks as if a small naked woman is swimming with the goldfish. This “girl in the fishbowl” has been part of the nightclub since it opened in 1931 at 365 Market Street. In 1951, Bimbo’s relocated to North Beach. Dolphina, as she is known, still lures patrons to the bar.

headline: If 2011 Was Any Indication, Hold On to Your Hats in 2012
text: Texans will close out 2011 with more questions than answers: How will Gov. Rick Perry’s presidential bid play out? How will lawmakers’ multibillion-dollar budget cuts affect education, Medicaid and health care? Will the courts ever decide on new State House, Senate and Congressional districts so Texas can hold elections?

headline: Norah Jones and the Music She Loves
text: It took Norah Jones precisely one year to become a household name. Her debut album, “Come Away With Me,” was released in February 2002, and by the following February it had sold four million copies and she had won five Grammys.

headline: Romney and Paul Ahead in New Iowa Poll
text: DES MOINES — The Des Moines Register poll — the final one before the Iowa caucuses on Tuesday — has Mitt Romney and Ron Paul virtually tied in the lead going into the final 72 hours before voting.

headline: Chief Justice Defends Peers’ Hearing Case on Health Law
text: In the face of a growing controversy over whether two Supreme Court justices should disqualify themselves from the challenge to the 2010 health care overhaul law, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on Saturday defended the court’s ethical standards.

text: The game welcomed back legendary players from the Rangers and Flyers, including Mark Messier, Bernie Parent, Eric Lindros, Brian Leetch, Bob Clarke and Adam Graves.

headline: Intervening After Robbery, an Off-Duty A.T.F. Agent Is Killed
text: An off-duty special agent for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives was fatally shot on Saturday afternoon when he, along with at least one other law enforcement officer and a retired officer, tried to stop a robber who had just held up a pharmacy on Long Island, the authorities said.

headline: Romney Says He Would Veto the Dream Act
text: LE MARS, Iowa — In Le Mars, Iowa, the self-proclaimed ice cream capital of the world, Mitt Romney ordered a scoop of rocky road before heading to his first campaign stop of the day, a crowded restaurant filled with more than 200 voters.

headline: Playing Five Minutes, Old Goalie Steals Show
text: PHILADELPHIA — Given the long, truculent history of the Flyers-Rangers rivalry, a lot of people expected at least a mock fight to break out Saturday at the Flyers-Rangers alumni game at Citizens Bank Park. Instead, the capacity crowd of 45,808 saw a display of good-natured class and surprising skill from players ranging in age from 28 to 68.

headline: Age 52, and Still Working the Streets
text: Barbara Terry, 52, raised four children and bought a house from the proceeds she earned working the streets of Hunts Point, in the Bronx.

headline: Amid Lead for Romney in Iowa Poll, Momentum for Santorum
text: The much-respected Des Moines Register poll was published on Saturday night and shows Mitt Romney in the lead in the Iowa caucuses, with 24 percent of the vote to 22 percent for Representative Ron Paul of Texas and 15 percent for Rick Santorum.

headline: Surging Back Into Zuccotti Park, Protesters Are Cleared by Police
text: 2:10 a.m. | Updated  More than 500 people associated with the Occupy Wall Street movement gathered in Zuccotti Park on Saturday and, in a return to scenes from earlier in the year, the evening began with the sound of drumming and calls of the now familiar slogan, “We are the 99 percent” — and it ended with torn-down barricades and a scuffle with police officers.

headline: Devils Rookie Henrique Settling In Between Two Stars
text: NEWARK — Adam Henrique, a 21-year-old center playing in only his 35th N.H.L. game, hopped over the boards with two other Devils forwards 45 seconds into Saturday’s game, and the three quickly pushed the puck into the Pittsburgh Penguins’ zone.

headline: MSG Leaves Time Warner Systems
text: The MSG and MSG Plus networks were removed from Time Warner Cable’s New York metropolitan-area and Buffalo systems at midnight Eastern on Saturday, cutting off subscribers from Knicks, Rangers, Islanders, Devils and Buffalo Sabres games. In total, the dispute affects 1.7 million cable homes.

headline: For ‘Occupy the Caucus’ Protesters, a Successful Day of Arrests
text: DES MOINES — “How many people had fun today?” said David Goodner, a 30-year-old community organizer, to a bus full of Occupy the Caucus protesters on their way from Newt Gingrich’s local campaign headquarters to President Obama’s. The question was met with cheers, as the group considered the 18 arrests, including those of two local teenagers, that made today a sign of success.

headline: Lottery Numbers

Sandy Maisel, a friend of the couple and a professor of government at Colby College.

Zolkind and Dr. Neil A. Zolkind of Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. Rabbi Terry A. Bookman officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Coconut Grove in Miami. Cantor Rachelle Nelson assisted.

headline: Katherine Beirne and Brian Fallon
text: Katherine Noel Beirne and Brian Edward Fallon Jr. were married Saturday by the Rev. Robert T. Begin, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Colman Catholic Church in Cleveland.

headline: Does the F.A.’s Report Change Your Opinion on Suárez?
text: England’s Football Association on Saturday released the 115-page report compiled by an independent commission that suspended Liverpool striker Luis Suárez for eight games. The document lays out in painstaking detail the evidence that Suárez directed a racist insult at a black opponent during a Premier League game in October, as well as the methods it used to go about determining his punishment.

headline: Marnie Hanel, James Bordley V
text: Marnie Elizabeth Hanel and James Bordley V were married Saturday evening at Trinity Parish Church in Seattle. The Rev. Paul Collins, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

text: A look back at the big news stories of the year.

headline: The World This Week, Part 1

headline: South Korea Predicts Changes in Peninsula
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea vowed on Monday to “deal strongly with any provocations” from the North, predicting a “big change” on the divided Korean Peninsula following the death of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, and his young, untested son’s rise to power.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Joe Sacco, the well-known American cartoonist and journalist, uses his “comic journalism” lens on a rural district of Uttar Pradesh, India’s largest and one of its poorest states. Caravan magazine publishes a long piece by him in its latest issue, which also includes a long profile of Imran Khan, the Pakistani cricketer turned politician. Mr. Sacco and an Indian journalist who assisted him, Piyush Srivastava, travel to the district Kushinagar near the border between Uttar Pradesh and Bihar to meet with poor and lower caste families.

headline: Madrid to Celebrate Three Kings, and the Gift of Innocence
text: One of Spain’s most popular holiday events, the colorful Procession of the Three Kings, will proceed down the Paseo de la Castellana from Nuevos Ministerios to Plaza de Cibeles on Friday between 6:30 p.m. and 9 p.m. It features the elaborately dressed kings, their pages and helpers, who ride on floats distributing sweets to the children lining the route. There are at least 30 carriages, theatrical re-enactments, dancers, musicians, jugglers, street performers, royal pages, giant puppets and many other entertaining characters.According to the Bible, at this time of year, three wise and powerful kings brought gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh to the infant Jesus. To celebrate the occasion, on Jan. 5, children in Spain go to bed early, awaiting the morning, when they hope to find the presents that they requested of the three kings in letters written on Boxing Day, Dec. 26. They leave shoes on windowsills or balconies or under the Christmas tree to be filled with toys.

headline: The Year in Football Language

headline: Boom Year for Illicit Elephant Ivory
text: If you think you had a bad year, spare a thought for Africa’s elephants. They are being killed in ever greater numbers for their ivory, which is smuggled these days mostly to Asia. Rising wealth has led to a boom in demand there in recent years.

headline: Q. and A. With Ed Snider: Philadelphia Hockey’s Heart and Soul
text: Ed Snider co-founded the Philadelphia Flyers in 1967 and has owned or run the team ever since. Today, as chairman of Comcast Spectacor, the company that owns the Philadelphia Flyers, he is perhaps the most powerful man in the game, as outlined in this Dec. 31 New York Times article.

headline: New Year’s Revelry Hurts Hundreds in Philippines
text: MANILA — Officials in the Philippines mounted one of the most extensive campaigns in the country’s history to stem the annual tide of injuries caused by New Year’s Eve celebrations.

headline: Little Syria (Now Tiny Syria) Finds New Advocates
text: In 1891, Yusuf Sadallah arrived in Lower Manhattan from the town of Baskinta, in the part of the Ottoman Empire that is now Lebanon. Going by the name of Joseph Sadallah, he set up a trading shop on Washington Street, where other immigrants from the Levant — Syrians, Lebanese and Palestinians — had created a vibrant Arab quarter known as Little Syria.

headline: In Iowa, Rick Perry Is Stuck in the Second Tier
text: Every candidate has a lot on the line in the Iowa caucus on Tuesday, but perhaps none more than Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

headline: Not Too Close to the Critters, Little Lady

headline: Missing Chinese Lawyer Said to Be in Remote Prison
text: BEIJING — The brother of a prominent dissident rights lawyer who had been missing for 20 months said Sunday that the lawyer, Gao Zhisheng, was being held in a prison in the remote western region of Xinjiang.

headline: Romney Fights for First-Place Showing in Iowa Caucuses
text: DES MOINES — Mitt Romney sought to convert his tentative standing atop the polls into a first-place finish in the caucuses here, telling Iowans on Sunday that he had the “capability to go the full distance” against President Obama, as his rivals beseeched voters not to settle on a candidate lacking full commitment to their conservative values.

headline: Disruptions: Resolved in 2012: To Enjoy the View Without Help From an iPhone
text: Last week, I drove to Pacifica, a beach community just south of San Francisco, where I climbed a large rocky hill as the sun descended on the horizon. It painted a typically astounding California sunset across the Pacific Ocean. What did I do next?

headline: ‘New Year’s Rockin’ Eve’ Draws Strong Ratings
text: ABC extended “Dick Clark’s New Year’s Rockin’ Eve” on Saturday night, and it appeared to pay off, giving the network its best end-of-the-year prime-time ratings since 2000. The two new hours of New Year’s Eve merriment, from 8 to 10 p.m., drew about 8.3 million viewers, an unusually high number for a Saturday night. Repeats on the other networks drew between 1.5 million and 3 million viewers.

headline: Falling Forward (Without Falling Down)
text: Here’s a Twittter post for a new year in a century in which the things we don’t know are easily as important as those we do. In such an environment, what qualities can help individuals and communities avoid big missteps? I’d start with literacy, connectedness, empathy, engagement, enterprise and anthropophilia.

headline: Palestinians and Israelis Will Talk This Week
text: JERUSALEM — Palestinian and Israeli negotiators plan to meet for the first time in more than a year in Jordan on Tuesday, in an effort to revive moribund peace talks, although none of the sides involved suggested any reason to view the meeting as a sign of significant progress.

headline: Sad Things (Wonkish and Trivial)

headline: Bachmann Makes Final Pitch to Iowa Faithful
text: OSKALOOSA, Iowa – Representative Michele Bachmann took the pulpit at the Jubilee Family Church here during the morning worship service on Sunday and preached from Scripture, weaving her personal story with biblical parables about redemption — a message that seemed tailored to reassure undecided voters about the viability of her embattled campaign.

headline: A Nebraska Fan Faces the New Reality
text: I was walking through the office when a colleague stopped me. “Did I hear you say something about Nebraska football?” he asked, innocently, cheerfully, not realizing the twisted synapses that were about to fire in my brain. I frowned and shook my head over the idea of writing about the team. “My comments would be too blue,” I assured him glibly.

headline: As U.S. Agent Is Mourned, Officials Try to Figure Out Who Shot Him
text: On Sunday morning, James J. Capano stopped in front of the pharmacy where his son, an off-duty federal agent, had lost his life less than 24 hours earlier.

headline: Gilbert Puts His Stamp on a Lively Celebration
text: Alan Gilbert had an elegantly straightforward idea for the New York Philharmonic’s New Year’s Eve concert at Avery Fisher Hall (and on televisions everywhere, thanks to PBS). He set aside the orchestra’s long tradition of following the Central European model of offering either bubbly programs of Viennese waltzes or grandly serious works like Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony as well as recent alternatives, like presenting a pops concert featuring a Broadway singer or light classics that would not otherwise be heard in a Philharmonic program.

headline: Amid Impeccable Slams, a Revealing Bid Gives Away a King
text: The Goldman Pairs started in 1929. It was traditionally held during the Eastern States Regional over Memorial Day weekend. However, that event did not take place last May. So the event was moved to the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional, which ended on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: You Read It Here First: Plays’ Plans Still in Flux
text: The new play “Detroit” was a hit at Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago in 2010, so much so that the New York producer Jeffrey Richards announced last January that he would move the show to Broadway in the fall of 2011. But as summer passed, there was no word on a cast, a theater, an opening night. Asked for an update, Mr. Richards said his fall producing schedule was hectic — he had “Chinglish,” “Bonnie & Clyde” and “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” all coming to Broadway — so he was waiting until winter for “Detroit.”

headline: Tom Cruise Is Again a Box-Office Draw
text: LOS ANGELES — Tom Cruise appears to have left behind his weird period, at least at the North American box office.

headline: From City Park to Stadium: A Giant’s Unlikely Return
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — About five weeks ago, Chase Blackburn was living in a suburb of Columbus, Ohio. He lifted weights close to his home, at Dublin Community Recreation Center, and practiced punt coverage alone on a field at a nearby park.

headline: With ‘24/7,’ HBO Refines a Winning Formula
text: HBO’s “24/7” series has nearly perfected the documentary as a promotional vehicle.

headline: Occupy Protesters Aim Anger at Both G.O.P. and Democrats in Iowa
text: With the whole state of Iowa fixated on Republican presidential contenders just days before they go head to head in the caucuses, anger from Occupy protesters over what they see as the overwhelming influence of corporate greed in politics is spilling over to both sides of the political divide.

headline: Jets’ Chances End Early as Offense Fights Itself
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — The Jets filed out of their locker room and into the off-season. Some players wore headphones. Others fiddled with smartphones. Their faces showed disappointment and frustration, but also resignation, as if their tumble from playoff contention was expected. And in a way, it was.

headline: On Modern Time
text: We live in time. On days like this one, when we find ourselves carried without any effort or intent from the end of one calendar year to the next, this observation is perhaps especially clear.

headline: Reviving a Long-Lost Tale From Kurt Weill’s Archive
text: LONDON — A small girl and boy play with their toys before falling asleep, and when they have done so, the toys come to life. Adventures ensue as Evil is battled, with Good duly prevailing and the toys returning to their former inert state. This is not, as you might think, “Toy Story 17,” but a new children’s show at the Royal Opera House’s Linbury Studio Theater that boasts an almost-forgotten score by none other than Kurt Weill.

headline: Google Bases a Campaign on Emotions, Not Terms
text: Google, one of the biggest advertising companies in the world, has finally embraced advertising for itself.

headline: Gingrich to Take Aim at Romney in New Hampshire
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Newt Gingrich said on Sunday that he intended to campaign in New Hampshire, where polls show him running third, rather than move directly to South Carolina, where he is leading.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Treat
text: The author George R. R. Martin has given his fans a late Christmas gift in the form of a sample chapter from his forthcoming “Winds of Winter,” the sixth book in “A Song of Ice and Fire,” his popular fantasy series. Mr. Martin, who is also the executive producer of the HBO series “Game of Thrones,” which is adapted from his novels, posted a preview of his latest work on his Web site, georgerrmartin.com, last week. No publication date has been announced. The series’s fifth book, “A Dance With Dragons,” was published in July after a six-year wait; it sold more than 170,000 print copies on its first day. Mr. Martin also announced that the book’s paperback edition, to be released in July, would contain a different sample chapter from “Winds.”

headline: Schedule Announced for Scotland Week
text: 59E59 Theaters has announced that it will present the United States premiere of “A Slow Air,” a new play written and directed by David Harrower, beginning April 4 as part of Scotland Week, the annual celebration of all things Scottish. “A Slow Air” explores the impact of the 2007 terrorist attack on the Glasgow Airport from the perspective of a family in a nearby village. It had its premiere at the Traverse Theater during the 2011 Edinburgh Festival Fringe. “Blackbird,” a previous play from Mr. Harrower, had a well-received run at Manhattan Theater Club in 2007 and won the 2007 Olivier Award in London for best new play. 59E59 is also set to present the United States premiere of “Federer Versus Murray,” a dark comedy written and directed by Gerda Stevenson, on April 4.

headline: Footnotes
text: After 14 months of marriage, the comedian Russell Brand has filed for divorce from the pop star Katy Perry, citing “irreconcilable differences,” The Associated Press reported. The couple, above, met in 2009 at the MTV Video Music Awards, of which Mr. Brand was the host. They were married in October 2010. ... After being hospitalized on Dec. 21 for shortness of breath, the R&B singer Etta James — who has terminal leukemia — is now breathing on her own and has been taken off a respirator, The Associated Press reported on Saturday.

headline: Santorum Pushes Supporters to Keep His Surge Alive
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa – Emboldened by a late and unexpected rise in the polls, Rick Santorum came to this conservative corner of rural Iowa on Sunday and urged his supporters to redouble their efforts to help ensure a win in the state’s caucuses on Tuesday night.

headline: Shiny Bibelot From Shakespeare, Handel & Co.
text: Forget “Auld Lang Syne.” The best music to ring in a new year is “Now a bright new day is dawning,” the joyous chorus that ends “The Enchanted Island,” the inventive concoction that had its premiere on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera. The music for this finale is lifted from the “Hallelujah” chorus that concludes Handel’s oratorio “Judas Maccabaeus.” The new words are by the librettist Jeremy Sams, who devised the story and assembled this fanciful, clever and touching pastiche by selecting arias, ensembles, choruses and dances from works by Handel, Vivaldi, Rameau and lesser-known Baroque composers.

headline: In Flop of H.P. TouchPad, an Object Lesson for the Tech Sector
text: The TouchPad tablet from Hewlett-Packard was one of the most closely watched new gadgets of 2011 — and quickly turned out to be the year’s biggest flop. The TouchPad, which was supposed to be a rival to Apple’s iPad, lasted just seven weeks on the market before H.P. killed it, citing weak sales.

headline: Metropolitan Pastiche

headline: Monday: Unconventional and Then Some
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — You can’t tell from my head shot, but I wear glasses. Even so, it was a strain to make out exactly what Paula Gamache was trying to get across to us, because no matter how hard I peered OVER, AROUND, BEYOND and UNDER, her message went SIGHT UNSEEN.

headline: PBS Takes On the Premium Channels
text: In an effort to freshen its image and lift revenue, the Public Broadcasting Service is trying to be more like HBO — without the monthly cable bill.

headline: In Speaking for TLC, the Least Said Is Best

headline: A Fairy Tale Stoked by Childhood Dreams
text: We live in a golden age of children’s fiction, and in the most memorable moments of his staging of “The Nutcracker,” Alexei Ratmansky takes his place among the most imaginative children’s authors. The snow scene that ends Act I, with aspects of seduction, terror and vengefulness unlike in any other “Nutcracker,” has a dramatic urgency that recalls some of the classic works of Hans Christian Andersen. The time-traveling scenes whereby a pas de deux in each act shows us a Princess and Prince who are the adult alter egos of Clara and the Nutcracker Boy recall some of the finest parts of the “Harry Potter” and “His Dark Materials” series.

headline: Colts Gain From One Last Loss, Earning Top Pick
text: The Indianapolis Colts’ season ended several days before it began in September, when quarterback Peyton Manning had neck surgery that sent him to the bench, imperiled his career and put the Colts into a tailspin. But on the final Sunday of their miserable year, the Colts won big — by losing one last time.

text: Last year will be remembered as the moment when dance music slithered across the Atlantic and insinuated itself into American genres that have hitherto been immune to it. In mainstream pop, R&B, even hip-hop, tempos and ecstatic feeling were on the rise across the board.

headline: Barbara Lea, Cabaret Singer, Dies at 82
text: Barbara Lea, a jazz-influenced cabaret singer known for an intense fealty to words and music that resulted in interpretations of masterly subtlety, died last Monday in Raleigh, N.C. She was 82.

headline: Overdosing on Extremism
text: ACCORDING to a recent study by the Centers for Disease Control, drug overdoses have increased almost six-fold in the last 30 years. They now represent the leading cause of accidental death in the United States, having overtaken motor vehicle accidents for the first time on record.

headline: Live Coverage of Winter Classic on Monday
text: Slap Shot will provide live analysis of the Winter Classic game between the Rangers and the Flyers, beginning at 3 p.m. Monday. On Sunday, the N.H.L. moved the game’s start time from 1 to 3 p.m. in the hope of improving ice conditions. NBC’s coverage will still start at 1 p.m., the same time the gates open at Citizens Bank Park.

headline: Bring on a Playoff, but Save the Bowl System
text: By the time we arrived in Queens at the Comus Club’s 89th annual Christmas Ball, I’d already begun to reconsider my position that the minor bowl games that dot the college football landscape were irrelevant.

headline: The Danger of an Attack on Piracy Online
text: By invoking the acronym SOPA right at the get-go, I may be daring many of you to check the next column over for something a little less chewy. After all, SOPA, which stands for Stop Online Piracy Act, sounds like a piece of arcane Internet government regulation — legislation that entertainment companies desperately care about and that leaves Web nation and free-speech crusaders frothing at the mouth. The rest of us? What were we talking about again?

headline: Rangers and Flyers Bring Bare-Knuckle History to a Showcase
text: PHILADELPHIA — When the N.H.L. and NBC originally plotted the Winter Classic, the idea was to present two traditional rivals. It does not hurt that this year’s matchup — the Rangers and the Flyers — play in the first- and fourth-largest television markets in the country, but these clubs also have a venomous history that is hard to equal.

headline: Bulk’s Not Just in Bulkhead, So Coast Guard Steps In
text: SEATTLE — In this season of expanding waistlines, even the Coast Guard has been forced to monitor midsections: specifically, the drafts of passenger vessels burdened with transporting an increasingly heavy population.

headline: An Ad Blocker Opens the Gate, Ever So Slightly
text: ADBLOCK PLUS became the most popular piece of “add-on” software for the Firefox Web browser, in part, because it had a simple mission: see online ad, block online ad. The name said it all — and each day 10 million people or so surf the Internet with Adblock Plus installed, presumably never missing the advertising they were meant to see.

headline: Flyers Make Goalie Switch for Classic
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Flyers’ No. 1 goalie, Ilya Bryzgalov, has been a star of HBO’s “24/7” series, quirkily philosophizing about Russian literature, the cosmos and other subjects. But Bryzgalov is unlikely to be a marquee name when the Flyers take on the Rangers in the annual Winter Classic on Monday at Citizens Bank Park.

headline: Howard Halpern, Therapist and Self-Help Author, Dies at 82

headline: Top Social Topics in ’11: Bin Laden and Mubarak
text: Almost two-thirds of adults who used the Internet in 2011 also belonged to social networks, like Facebook and Twitter, according to the Pew Internet and American Life Project.

headline: Homeward Goes the Dust Bowl Balladeer
text: The news that Oklahoma is now ready to accept and celebrate Woody Guthrie, the seminal American folk singer who died in 1967, as a native son with an exhibition and a study center for his archives is welcome if long overdue. The state resisted honoring him for decades, because of his leftist politics. “I ain’t a Communist necessarily,” Guthrie said, “but I been in the red all my life.”

headline: Holmes Ends His Season on Sideline
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — A simmering season of discontent for wide receiver Santonio Holmes boiled to the surface Sunday, sending the Jets into the off-season as a splintered squad.

headline: Stigmatizing Food Stamps
text: Five years ago, New York State stopped requiring that all applicants for food stamps be electronically fingerprinted. Recently, California and Texas ended their requirement, leaving New York City and Arizona the only jurisdictions to continue the stigmatizing requirement.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes a regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Send in Questions for Melinda Gates
text: Melinda Gates will be traveling shortly to Bangladesh to look at maternal health, child health and women’s issues (including family planning and reproductive health) — and she has agreed to answer your questions about these topics while she’s there. So please post your questions for Melinda and me about these issues in the comments below, and we’ll choose some and give you our best answers.

headline: The Distorted View from Capitol Hill
text: Last week, both The Washington Post and The Times published illuminating stories on the growing affluence of members of Congress. Both stories — Peter Whoriskey’s in the Post and Eric Lichtblau’s in the Times — demonstrate how the economic fortunes of those elected to Congress have diverged radically from those of the men and women they represent.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week

headline: Nobody Understands Debt
text: In 2011, as in 2010, America was in a technical recovery but continued to suffer from disastrously high unemployment. And through most of 2011, as in 2010, almost all the conversation in Washington was about something else: the allegedly urgent issue of reducing the budget deficit.

headline: Obscuring a Muslim Name, and an American’s Sacrifice
text: He was buried after the Sept. 11 attacks with full honors from the New York Police Department, and proclaimed a hero by the city’s police commissioner. He is cited by name in the Patriot Act as an example of Muslim-American valor.

headline: ‘Essential Benefits’ and Health Reform
text: The Obama administration surprised supporters and critics when it decided to let states define the “essential health benefits” that must be provided to their citizens under health care reform. The move could lessen opposition in Republican-led states and increase the chances that they will move ahead on building new health insurance exchanges to comply with the reform law.

headline: Democrats Descend on Iowa to Hit Romney

headline: A Dilemma for Russian Leaders: To Suppress Protests or Not

headline: In Times Sq., Gross Reminders of Overindulgence

headline: Wearing Special Shoes on an Arduous Journey
text: Dmitriy Frenkel has only one pair of shoes. He wears them in August heat and through December snow. The shoes are brown and have thick soles; the right one is shaped differently from the left. They are not particularly stylish, but were specially molded to suit Mr. Frenkel’s disfigured right foot, affected by the polio that he contracted as a child.

headline: Israeli Protest’s Invocation of Holocaust Is Condemned

headline: Lottery Numbers
Cars Set on Fire, and Los Angeles Set on Edge

There are palm trees, year-round gardens and splendid weather — it was 81 degrees and sunny on Sunday — but there are also mudslides, gang shootings, wildfires and earthquakes.

headline: Political Bickering and Government Inaction Marked the Year in India

Ron Paul, Rick Perry, Ron Paul, Mitt Romney, Rick Santorum. RomneyRomneyGingrichSantorumSantorum.

headline: Disposal Halted at Well After New Quake in Ohio
text: An official in Ohio said on Sunday that the underground disposal of wastewater from natural-gas drilling operations would remain halted in the Youngstown area until scientists could analyze data from the most recent of a string of earthquakes there.

text: After his third deployment, Sgt. Matthew Pennington, 28, returned to his home in Dexter, Me., where he is recovering from both physical and psychological traumas.

headline: In Afghanistan, Poppy Growing Proves Resilient
text: NAKILABAD KALAY, Afghanistan — This stretch of the Helmand River Valley, the heart of the nation’s poppy-growing area, stands as a showcase for one of NATO’s most ambitious offensives against the Taliban and the drug trade. But now, the area is also becoming an object lesson in the resilience of militants and opium producers alike.

headline: After Three Decades, Tax Credit for Ethanol Expires

headline: Undercutting Vow of Softer Stance, Egypt Again Defends Office Raids
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-led government on Sunday justified its recent crackdown on human rights and democracy-building organizations as a defense against foreign interference in its politics, defying international pressure and contradicting reports from senior officials in Washington that Egypt’s military rulers had pledged to soften their stance.

headline: Embattled but Confident, Bachmann Says She Is the ‘Complete Package’

The message seemed tailored to convince skeptical and undecided voters of the viability of her embattled campaign.

headline: Giants Rout the Cowboys and Win the N.F.C. East
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The ending hung heavily over MetLife Stadium on Sunday evening, doomsday developments dangling from the floodlights. The Giants’ season had been reduced to the simplest of situations: If they beat the Dallas Cowboys, they would win the N.F.C. East and advance to the playoffs. If they lost, though, and collapsed for a third consecutive year, the ending — for underperforming players and besieged coordinators and maybe even the veteran coach — would topple upon their heads.

headline: Sudden Health of Defense Empowers the Pass Rush
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ defensive coordinator, Perry Fewell, has lamented not having a full complement of players at his disposal this season because of injuries in nearly every area: on the line, among the linebackers and in the secondary.

headline: In Defense of Brian Schottenheimer

The Jets’ problems pertain to player personnel. They’re constructed to run the ball and win with defense. That’s why they felt comfortable building around a quarterback that has limitations like Mark Sanchez.

text: A new Public Policy Polling survey in Iowa, conducted Saturday and Sunday, shows a virtual three-way tie in advance of the Iowa caucuses. Ron Paul has a nominal lead with 20 percent of the vote in the poll, followed by Mitt Romney at 19 percent and Rick Santorum at 18 percent.

headline: Image of the Day: January 2

headline: Reading Between Rex Ryan’s Lines

headline: What Tomlinson Said About Santonio Holmes
text: Wide receiver Santonio Holmes is coming under criticism from Jets teammates,  some of them speaking anonymously, for quitting on the team. (Holmes was benched for the final minutes of the Jets’ season-ending loss at Miami after arguing with teammates in the huddle).

headline: Los Angeles Police Arrest Suspect in Car Arsons
text: LOS ANGELES — A four-day storm of arsons that caused more than $3 million in damage to cars and apartment buildings across Los Angeles led to an arrest early Monday morning after a reserve sheriff’s deputy, on patrol in the midst of another chaotic night of serial fires, recognized a man from a video surveillance tape released this week.

headline: Braised Rabbit, a Warming Winter Meal
text: For a cold weather meal, a braised rabbit is a fine choice. The recipe in this week’s City Kitchen is for an oven-baked version of the classic hunter-style rabbit alla cacciatore. A touch of tomato, some crimini mushrooms and some dried porcini, garlic and rosemary are all you need, plus a splash of wine and chicken stock. The proportions are forgiving, so measurements need not be exact.

headline: Statistical Lows for Romo and Tebow
text: Anyone could see that Tim Tebow was having a bad day Sunday, and the numbers backed that up. He was 6 for 22 for 60 passing yards in a loss against Kansas City, and his rushing wasn’t anything special (six carries for 16 yards).

headline: Monday Reading: A Week at a Fat Camp for Grown-Ups
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Unconstitutional Constitution

headline: Hermetic Economic Cults (Wonkish)
text: Brad DeLong points to repeated quotes from Chicago economists asserting that any economist proposing fiscal stimulus – Christy, Larry, me – must be corrupt. And then they get all huffy about the way I insult them!

headline: Bachmann Returns to Iowa Airwaves
text: DES MOINES — Representative Michele Bachmann hasn’t been on the air in Iowa with a television commercial since August when she surprised the country by placing first in the state’s straw poll. But she reappeared on Monday with a 30-second spot that comes just in time for the caucuses on Tuesday.

headline: Gym-Pact Fines You for Not Exercising
text: With the start of a new year, many people resolve to shed their holiday paunch by hitting the gym more frequently. It’s easy to stay motivated for a few weeks, but then other things seem to take precedence — late nights at work, happy hour or the couch.

headline: Eric Lander
text: An interview with the mathematician and geneticist behind the Human Genome Project and the Broad Institute.

headline: Power in Numbers
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — His Ph.D. is in pure mathematics, in a subfield so esoteric and specialized that even if someone gets a great result, it can be appreciated by only a few dozen people in the entire world. But he left that world behind and, with no formal training, entered another: the world of molecular biology, medicine and genomics.

headline: New Year’s Resolutions to Parent By
text: Either you’re the kind of person who makes New Year’s resolutions or you’re not. I most emphatically am and a few of my resolutions are very specific to me as a parent. I’ve made the whole idea of “the parent we want to be” versus the “parent we actually are” something of a meme for Motherlode in part because for me, there’s often such a huge gap between the two.

headline: Paul Turns Ad Focus to New Hampshire
text: As Ron Paul tries to pull off a first-place finish in the Iowa caucuses on Tuesday, his campaign has turned its eyes to his next primary battle, releasing a new television ad in New Hampshire.

headline: Coursekit Raises $5 Million to Reinvent the Classroom
text: LinkedIn helps professionals connect around job opportunities; Facebook helps people unite around social experiences, like the birth of a baby or an approaching holiday party. But what about online hubs where students can gather to meet their fellow classmates, dish on assignments and trade study tips?

headline: On Our Radar: Oil Washes Ashore in Nigeria
text: Nigerian villagers and environmental groups say that oil washing up on the coast must be from the recent Royal Dutch Shell loading accident, which caused the biggest offshore spill in the country’s waters in 13 years. Shell denies that the oil is from the spill, saying its dispersal efforts prevented any of that crude from washing ashore. [Reuters]

headline: Genome Study Points to Adaptation in Early African-Americans
text: Researchers scanning the genomes of African-Americans say they see evidence of natural selection as their ancestors adapted to the harsh conditions of their new environment in America.

headline: Gingrich on the Culinary Trail in Iowa
text: INDEPENDENCE, Iowa — Is it a coincidence that Newt Gingrich’s long and winding bus tour has stopped at many food businesses?

headline: Russian Art Group Claims Attack on Police Van
text: MOSCOW — A spokesman for the radical art collective Voina on Monday announced that its members had broken into a St. Petersburg police station on New Year’s Eve and used gasoline bombs to incinerate a police vehicle used to transport prisoners as “a gift to all political prisoners of Russia.” Amateur video posted online showed a figure tossing lighted objects under a large vehicle, which was then engulfed in flames and spewed smoke into the night sky.

headline: Twisting Race Hits First Turn as Iowa Votes
text: DES MOINES — Mitt Romney has grown so confident of his Iowa prospects that on Monday night he dropped all humble pretense and proclaimed, “We’re going to win this thing.” At the same time, Rick Santorum insisted that his momentum carried its own whiff of victory.

headline: Turnips: Versatile and Nutritious in Any Season
text: Turnips are one vegetable you can count on during the winter months; like carrots, they store well. The root vegetables are members of the cruciferae family, the same family that brings you nutrient-rich vegetables like cabbage, kale and broccoli (genus Brassica). Turnips are rich in sulfuric compounds, particularly glucosinolates, that are believed to have antioxidant properties. They’re also a very good source of potassium. When you can get them with the greens attached, they’re a two-in-one crop, like beets, as their greens bring you a whole new set of nutrients – lots of calcium, vitamin K, vitamin A and beta carotene – and culinary possibilities. Turnip greens are similar in flavor to kale, perhaps a little more bitter, and with a more delicate texture.

headline: For Gajdosova, a Slow Australian Embrace
text: PERTH, Australia — Just like on the Australian flag, Australian tennis still has one star who considerably dwarfs the rest.

headline: Really? The Claim: Listening to Music Can Relieve Pain
text: THE FACTS

headline: Back in Iowa, With the Usual Fuss
text: DES MOINES — There is always something a little peculiar about coming to Iowa for its quadrennial day of fame, but this time it was particularly disconcerting for me to land in an otherwise unremarkable Midwestern city for its first-in-the-season presidential nominating contest.

headline: The Call of the Wild
text: Q. How do deer communicate? Do they have any ability to vocalize?

headline: A Medical Tell-All Can Be Found in Urine
text: I happen to love asparagus and eat it often. But an acquaintance once told me she carefully avoids this wholesome vegetable simply because it makes her urine smell bad.

headline: India on $1,000 a Day
text: City hopping by private jet, mingling with maharajas in their palaces, hanging out with world famous artists in their ateliers or being serenaded by a group of classical musicians in the middle of the desert – for a tiny, elite group, travel in India is far removed from the backpacker trail.

headline: Lunchtime Polling Update
text: Two polls straggle in late on Monday morning.

headline: The Caucus | Undecided in Iowa
text: The decision-making process so far for three Iowans who are still choosing among the presidential candidates ahead of Tuesday’s caucus.

headline: Push for Votes as Iowa Campaign Wraps Up
text: The six contenders in Iowa fanned out across the state looking for anyone to caucus for them Tuesday night.

headline: Iowa, the Early Decider, Still Hasn’t
text: DES MOINES — In an election in which waves of support have come and gone for candidates, one thing has remained near constant: the percentage of voters who have been undecided, or who have indicated that they could easily change their minds on Tuesday at the Iowa caucuses. According to recent polls, 41 percent of likely Republican caucusgoers considered themselves undecided just days before votes are to be counted.

headline: Two Point Guards Are Better Than One in Denver
text: When the Denver Nuggets traded Carmelo Anthony and Chauncey Billups to the Knicks last season, an opportunity arose for George Karl and his incredibly deep and highly unorthodox roster. There would be no more stifling isolations, no more breaks with the slow-footed Billups leading the way, no more indifferent defense from Anthony, nor any dropoff when the Nuggets’ stars went to the bench.

headline: Veteran Lobbyist to Advise Romney Campaign
text: 2:39 p.m. | Updated DES MOINES — Mitt Romney has added a veteran Washington lobbyist — Charlie Black, a top political aide to Senator John McCain‘s 2008 presidential campaign — to the circle of informal advisers who are trying to help to guide him to the White House.

headline: Animal Studies Cross Campus to Lecture Hall
text: Once, animals at the university were the province of science. Rats ran through mazes in the psychology lab, cows mooed in the veterinary barns, the monkeys of neuroscience chattered in their cages. And on the dissecting tables of undergraduates, preserved frogs kept a deathly silence.

headline: ‘Glee’ Star Gets His Broadway Turn
text: In a rehearsal studio off Times Square last week, Darren Criss — a breakout star of the Fox high school musical series “Glee” — was performing a bit too perfectly.

headline: One on One: Scott Harrison, Charity Water
text: Scott Harrison used to be a New York City club promoter, making a living from selling people $16 drinks and $300 bottles of vodka. Now he is the founder and chief executive of Charity Water, a nonprofit that focuses on the need for clean drinking water around the world.

headline: Johnny Wilson, N.H.L. Star, Dies at 82; Held Consecutive-Game Record
text: Johnny Wilson, an All-Star forward who set a National Hockey League record by appearing in 580 consecutive games, and who played on four Stanley Cup championship teams with the Detroit Red Wings in the 1950s, died on Dec. 27 in Livonia, Mich. He was 82.

headline: The Caucus | Obama’s Shadow Operation
text: Jeff Zeleny reports on President Obama’s robust campaign in Iowa. In spite of all the attention on the Republicans, Mr. Obama the most organized candidate in the state.

headline: Staal Returns With Light Day and Some Rust
text: PHILADELPHIA — At last year’s Winter Classic, the Penguins’ Sidney Crosby received the first of two hits to the head that would sideline him with a concussion for almost 11 months.

headline: Caucus Video: Obama’s Shadow Operation
text: Jeff Zeleny reports on President Obama’s robust campaign in Iowa. In spite of all the attention on the Republicans, Mr. Obama is the most organized candidate in the state.

headline: A Gathering Storm Over ‘Right to Work’ in Indiana
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Nearly a year after legislatures in Wisconsin and several other Republican-dominated states curbed the power of public sector unions, lawmakers are now turning their sights toward private sector unions, setting up what is sure to be another political storm.

headline: Science, Faith and Progress (With and Without a Capital ‘P’)
text: Thomas M. Lessl, a scholar at the University of Georgia who has long studied the rhetoric and societal relationships of both science and religion, is well positioned to add to the recent discussion here over whether confidence in science as a source of progress is based on faith or fact.

headline: Reaching Back 2,000 Years to Unravel a Curse
text: A vegetable seller named Babylas was the target of an alarming curse nearly 2,000 years ago. Written on a lead tablet found in Antioch, one of the largest cities in the Roman Empire, the curse calls on the gods to tie up the hapless greengrocer, then “drown and chill” his soul.

headline: NBC’s M.L.S. Promo
text: Pretty interesting NBC Sports Network promo of Major League Soccer. The new network was the Versus channel until 4 p.m. Eastern, Monday. M.L.S. will make its debut on NBC with the game between the Red Bulls and Dallas from Frisco, Tex., on Sunday, March 11 at 3 p.m. Eastern.

headline: Opposition Protests Constitution in Hungary
text: BUDAPEST — As the governing party celebrated its achievements inside, tens of thousands of Hungarians rallied outside the nation’s 19th-century opera house on Monday in a rare opposition protest of what critics see as a campaign by Prime Minister Viktor Orban to undermine democracy and consolidate his power.

headline: Reports Differ of Attack on an Iraqi Minister
text: BAGHDAD — As reports of violence in Iraq go, this one seemed straightforward, almost routine: A convoy carrying a leading Sunni politician was said to be hit by a roadside bomb north of Baghdad on Sunday night, wounding two bodyguards but leaving the official unscathed.

headline: New Reality on Fox: Hurry Up and Dance
text: The reality show “So You Think You Can Dance” is getting shorter. Weeks or maybe months before Fox would have announced the change, the program’s executive producer, Nigel Lythgoe, disclosed in a Twitter message on Sunday that the network had canceled the results show for the season scheduled to start in May. “I will have to change the format,” he added. Fox previously split the show into two nights, revealing the weekly results a day after the competitions. The eighth season, last year, lost ground to another summer competition, “America’s Got Talent” on NBC, but it remains an important piece of Fox’s schedule. A Fox scheduling executive said on Twitter on Monday that the reasons for the shortening would be explained “in due time.”

headline: Live Analysis: Rangers Win Winter Classic
text: Brad Richards, the Rangers’ prized off-season acquisition, scored early in the third period to lift the Rangers to a 3-2 victory against the Flyers in the Winter Classic at Citizens Bank Park on Monday.

headline: We’re Baa-ack, and the Academy Is, Too
text: The Bagger may have taken last week off, but the celebrity-industrial complex never rests. Meryl Streep earned kudos from the Kennedy Center and will receive an honorary Golden Bear from the Berlin Film Festival next month. The Palm Springs International Film Festival also announced yet more honorees – Charlize Theron, Jessica Chastain and Howard Shore join most of the season’s other lauded performers. And the Academy signaled once again that it is not trying to shake things up this year.

headline: Mistakes and How To Deal With Them
text: So Alex Tabarrok thinks he has a great gotcha in my warnings about deficits and interest rates from 2003. Except, I’ve already acknowledged that mistake:

headline: Lang Lang to Play at Sonoma State Opening
text: When the financier Sanford I. Weill wanted a sense of what the music hall being built at Sonoma State University would sound like, he asked a friend, the pianist Lang Lang, to stop by to play. Mr. Weill liked what he heard, so he and his wife, Joan, went on to donate $12 million toward the project’s $130 million cost.

headline: A Collaboration That Began With a Disastrous Lunch
text: In the annals of academic rivalries, perhaps none is fiercer than the crosstown one between Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: Gingrich Says He Is Unlikely to Win Iowa Caucus
text: WALFORD, Iowa — Newt Gingrich has dusted off an old theme song: “Eye of the Tiger,’’ whose lyric “just a man and his will to survive” pumped from speakers as his campaign bus rolled dramatically into the warehouse of an excavating company here.

headline: In Euro Zone’s Crisis, Technocrat in Paris Works Behind the Scenes
text: PARIS — With France widely expected to lose its vaunted AAA credit rating any day now, the government here is bracing for the fallout. But as President Nicolas Sarkozy heads into a tough re-election fight, for financial damage control he is increasingly reliant on a civil servant of whom few people outside France have ever heard: Ramon Fernandez.

headline: A Celebrity Chef Will Take to the Chicago Stage
text: The celebrity chef Rick Bayless will take to the Chicago stage this March. Collaborating with the Lookingglass Theater Company, Mr. Bayless will serve the audience a Mexican-influenced dinner with wine pairings as he tries to cook his way into the heart of an unhappy woman in “Cascabel.” Mr. Bayless created the show with Tony Hernandez and Heidi Stillman, who are directing it together. Promoted as “a theatrical feast,” the show will run from March 21 through April 22 at the Water Tower Pumping Station. Tickets — for $200 to $225 — include dinner.

headline: Two Choices for Best Bedside Read in the Hospital
text: What is the best reading material for a stay in the hospital: the book that will lift you far away from that miserable place, or the one that will plunge you deeper in, a kind of guidebook to clarify local customs and keep you out of trouble?

headline: An Innocent in America
text: Steven Spielberg’s new film “The Adventures of Tintin” took in roughly $12 million during the past holiday weekend. This is not tremendous box office (“Mission: Impossible — Ghost Protocol,” by contrast, exceeded $30 million), but it’s more than some skeptics had predicted for a movie about a cartoon character who, though beloved in most parts of the world, is practically unknown in the United States. Charles de Gaulle once declared that in terms of international fame, Tintin was his only rival. We, on the other hand, don’t even know how to say his name right. In the original cartoons Tintin, the creation of the Belgian artist Hergé, spoke French, and thus his name should be pronounced “Tanh-tanh,” and not, as the movie has it, to rhyme with “win win.”

headline: Watching Them Grow Up (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rape and Its Aftermath (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Oscar Ballot Doesn’t Add Up for Some Voters
text: The Oscar nomination ballots were mailed out last week – they are due back on Jan. 13 – and the new voting rules are already causing problems. It’s not quite a debacle on the order of hanging chads, but as Scott Feinberg writes at The Hollywood Reporter, some voters are perplexed about why the ballot only has five spaces for best picture, when there can be up to 10 nominees.

headline: Risks: Resting Heart Rate as Simple Biomarker
text: A large study has found that a rise in resting heart rate over a decade may indicate an increased risk of death from coronary artery disease.

headline: Patterns: Trace Elements and Pancreatic Cancer Risk
text: A new study has found that high bodily levels of the trace elements nickel and selenium may be associated with reduced risk for pancreatic cancer, and that high levels of arsenic, cadmium and lead may increase the risk.

headline: To Asia and Back, Sleep Not an Option
text: I’M a music guy who loves technology. My company develops things like text messaging platforms and mobile payment processing solutions. I used to work for Virgin Records, where there was a dedicated travel department that helped with everything. Now, I’m on my own.

headline: Nutrition: 4 Vitamins That Strengthen Older Brains
text: Higher blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin B, vitamin C, vitamin D and vitamin E are associated with better mental functioning in the elderly, a new study has found.

headline: Giants and Cowboys Lift NBC in Ratings
text: The combination of an N.F.L. division rivalry game between the Dallas Cowboys and the New York Giants with playoff implications for both teams and a lack of competition from other broadcast networks worked strongly in NBC’s favor on Sunday. Preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates suggest that the game — won by the Giants, 31-14 — was not only the highest-rated “Sunday Night Football” game since the program moved to NBC in 2006, but that it also had the best overnight rating of any Sunday prime-time N.F.L. broadcast in 13 years. It barely beat the ratings for this season’s Week 1 game between the Cowboys and the New York Jets.

headline: To Promote Brisk Tea, Pepsi Enlists Yoda
text: PEPSICO is piggybacking on the release next month of Lucasfilm’s “Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace 3D” to promote its Brisk iced tea and juice drinks.

headline: A Tasmanian Maginot Line for Two Millipede Species
text: On the Australian island of Tasmania, two species of millipedes maintain a mysterious standoff, according to a new study — separated by a 140-mile boundary they rarely cross.

headline: British Columbia: Aggressive Strategy Lowers the Number of New H.I.V. Cases and AIDS Deaths
text: New H.I.V. cases and AIDS deaths are both going steadily down in British Columbia, according to data released last week.

headline: Ron Paul Sounds Good at First, but Then Gets Pretty Scary
text: DES MOINES — They say that one of the great things about the current primary system in our country, which puts most of the power of picking in the hands of the least populated, least representative states, is that it promotes “retail politicking.” That means the candidates shake your hand, look you in the eye and lie to you directly.

headline: Cantor Defends House G.O.P. Stance on Tax Increases
text: During an interview with “60 Minutes,” Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia and the House majority leader, strongly defended his party’s dug-in opposition to tax increases last year, saying it reflected the party’s core values, but he seemed to stumble when recounting former President Ronald Reagan’s record on taxes.

headline: Tending to the Loyalists
text: With airplanes flying so full these days, it’s not easy to find a seat using frequent flier miles. But hotel loyalty programs are a different story.

headline: Gaza Premier in Turkey, in First Official Trip Abroad
text: ISTANBUL — Ismail Haniya, the Hamas prime minister of Gaza, who is making his first official trip abroad since his Islamist movement took over the Palestinian strip in 2007, sought Monday to strengthen ties with the Arab and Muslim world in the wake of regional uprisings that have produced a rise in Islamist political strength.

headline: Protocol to Treat Anorexia Is Faulted
text: When a malnourished teenager with anorexia nervosa is admitted to the hospital, weight gain is a top priority — and food is medicine. But doctors mete out meals with caution, providing fewer calories than needed at first because the patients may be so frail that major swings in diet can be life-threatening.

headline: Romney Sounds Increasingly Confident in Iowa
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Ann Romney fell on her bottom in Dubuque four years ago, and her husband can’t stop talking about it.

headline: How Conservatives Spin the Nation’s Predicament
text: “Pity the Billionaire,” by Thomas Frank, is a showcase example of the problems that can be created by the long lead time (six to nine months or more if a project has not been fast-tracked) involved in publishing a topical book in an age when news is instantaneous, and there is 24/7, wall-to-wall coverage of hot-button issues.

headline: Out of the Kitchen and Into a Bit of Trouble
text: Blame it on the chicken.

headline: A Public Policy Expert Looks at the Bird Flu Threat
text: Responding to experiments in the Netherlands and the United States in which scientists created a highly transmissible form of the potentially deadly H5N1 bird flu virus, the National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity urged scientific journals not to publish details of the work out of fear that the information could be used by terrorists. Laurie Garrett, senior fellow for global health at the Council on Foreign Relations and a recipient of a 1996 Pulitzer Prize for her coverage of an Ebola epidemic, responds to questions about the public policy implications of bird flu and bioterrorism. Her latest book, “I Heard the Sirens Scream,” offers a detailed account of the 2001 anthrax attacks and the bioterrorism policy actions that resulted.

headline: How Hard Would It Be for Avian Flu to Spread?
text: Recent reports that two teams of scientists had genetically altered a deadly flu virus to make it more contagious have provoked fear, even outrage, in some quarters.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 2
text: Oklahoma State beat Stanford, Oregon beat Wisconsin, and Houston beat Penn State as the college football bowl season continued.

headline: A Recipe for Simplifying Life: Ditch All the Recipes
text: What’s the first step toward cooking and eating better this year? Perhaps you should start by learning how to boil water.

headline: Sometimes You Have to Settle for Just Being There
text: In her latest blog post, Laura Klein writes: In the past, I dreamed of plucking my students from their miserable homes and finding solutions to their problems. I felt powerful and capable, as though I would be able to offer them something better. Now I know that the best I might do is to just be there when they return from their holiday break, offering them something steady and certain.

headline: In Classic vs. Modern Violins, Beauty Is in Ear of the Beholder
text: What gives a violin made by Stradivari or Guarneri del Gesù its remarkable sound? Researchers have examined the wood preservatives, varnish, even the effects of the Little Ice Age on the density of wood, for anything that might explain the instruments’ almost magical properties.

headline: Ancient Capital Wilted When Water Ran Low
text: Angkor, the ancient city in Cambodia that was the seat of the Khmer empire, flourished from the 9th to the 15th century. Today, tourists still appreciate the remnants of its architecture and sophisticated hydro-engineering systems, composed of canals, moats and large reservoirs known as barays.

headline: Triumph for Houston Comes at Penn State’s Expense
text: DALLAS — Quarterback Case Keenum joyously climbed into the stands and began directing the Houston band. He hugged everybody in his path. As the clock wound down in the Cougars’ 30-14 victory over Penn State, he made sure to give his coach, Tony Levine, a Gatorade bath.

headline: Herding Quail Like Sheep
text: Jennifer Gee, a biologist at the Claremont University Consortium and the University of California, Riverside, writes from the tropical dry forest near Álamos, Mexico, where she and Jennifer Calkins are studying Callipepla quail.

headline: Patti Smith Ends Bowery Residency
text: As 2011 recedes in the rear-view mirror and the weekend’s confetti is swept away, we note as well the passing of another tradition. On New Year’s Eve, Patti Smith announced from the stage at the Bowery Ballroom that the concert was her last — at the Bowery Ballroom.

headline: Jason Taylor on Being Carried Off the Field
text: No matter your rooting interest, it was nice to see teams that were already eliminated compete so fiercely in Week 17. The Dolphins, the Chargers and the Chiefs fought the good fight, and won. The league is smart to schedule divisional games on the final weekend.

headline: For Congo Children, Food Today Means None Tomorrow
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Today, the big children will eat, Cynthia, 15, and Guellor, 13. Tomorrow, it will be the turn of the little ones, Bénédicte, Josiane and Manassé, 3, 6, and 9.

headline: The Caucus Click: Aboard Romney’s Campaign Bus
text: An inside view of Mitt Romney’s campaign bus.

headline: Michigan’s Turnaround Forged by a Friendship
text: Minutes after Western Michigan named Jack Harbaugh its head football coach in 1982, a stranger knocked on his office door.

headline: Schottenheimer, Coughlin and Jaguars
text: The Jets’ offensive coordinator, Brian Schottenheimer, will interview for the head coaching job in Jacksonville.

headline: American Groups Rebut Egyptian Accusations
text: CAIRO — Two American democracy-building organizations accused Egypt’s military-led government of a campaign of false statements about their activities and history, ratcheting up a confrontation between Washington and Cairo over police raids that shut down the groups’ offices.

headline: 3 In-Laws of Afghan Girl, 15, Are Held in Her Torture
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan girl’s nails had been pulled out, her skin on her ear and nose had been twisted with pliers, and she had been kept in a dark, filthy basement bathroom without proper food or water for five months by her husband’s family for refusing to go into prostitution, Afghan government officials said.

headline: Pakistani Panel Begins Inquiry Into Memo
text: ISLAMABAD — A three-member Supreme Court panel opened an inquiry on Monday into a controversial memo suggestive of a civilian-military power struggle, seeking statements from the Pakistani spy chief and Pakistan’s recently resigned ambassador to United States, as well as a former American national security adviser, before adjourning to Jan. 9.

headline: Gingrich Sends an E-mail in Spanish, Asking for Support in Iowa
text: WALFORD, Iowa — Newt Gingrich promises to make English the official language of government, but on Monday he sent an e-mail appeal in Spanish asking for support at the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Owners Argue Merits of Firearms on Airplanes
text: TUCSON

headline: London Succumbs to the Spell of ‘The Nutcracker’
text: LONDON — That four productions of “The Nutcracker” have been running here over the holiday period may be little cause for surprise in the United States, where “Nutcracker” ubiquity is entirely accepted. But even as recently as last year, Britain, like the rest of Europe, didn’t seem to have succumbed to the dictate that “The Nutcracker” must dominate all dance stages from December to January.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: For 2012, Signs Point to Tepid Consumer Spending
text: American consumers are running out of tricks.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: After Setbacks, Perry Takes the Long View
text: CARROLL, Iowa—On his first campaign stop of the day on Monday, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas was introduced by a supporter as “the next governor of the United States.”

headline: World Markets Turn Higher
text: European stocks rallied on Monday, after manufacturing in Germany and China beat forecasts. French bonds fell before debt sales this week and the euro weakened.

headline: Here’s to Filene’s Basement
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Wall Street, Renewed Optimism for Deal-Making
text: Before Europe’s debt crisis flared anew last summer, rattling markets and choking off a revival in mergers and acquisitions, huge corporate cash piles and cheap debt had fostered hopes that deal-making would recover strongly last year.

headline: New Albums by Kevin Hufnagel, Jimmy Owens and Guided by Voices
text: GUIDED BY VOICES

headline: The Need for Vaccinations
text: To the Editor:

headline: Democrats Become Target of Occupy Protests
text: In what Occupy the Caucus members called a symbolic “die-in,” 12 protesters lay motionless on the lobby floor of the Renaissance Des Moines Savory Hotel Monday afternoon before getting arrested.

headline: A High School Naïf Doubles as a Competent Career Gal
text: In the 1980s the most dangerous place for a teenage American girl to be was in a horror movie. The wider the eyes and the rosier the cheeks, the more certain it was that she would meet a grisly fate.

headline: Europeans Planning for Less Unanimity
text: BRUSSELS — For decades, any European Union nation could block proposed laws in the most delicate policy areas, like taxation, consigning them to the scrap heap if they encroached too much on its power.

headline: Rick Santorum at the Pizza Ranch: Don’t Vote for That Other Guy
text: BOONE, Iowa — At a hot, crowded Pizza Ranch this afternoon, where journalists and locals jostled for sight lines and breathing space, Rick Santorum explained why Iowans shouldn’t just accept what seems like the inevitable, and settle for Mitt Romney.

headline: ‘Love Story, the Musical’ Heading to Philadelphia
text: The Walnut Street Theater in Philadelphia will present the American premiere of “Love Story, The Musical” in September. Based on Erich Segal’s novel and movie, the musical has a book and lyrics by Stephen Clark and music and additional lyrics by Howard Goodall. After a sold-out season at the Chichester Festival Theater in England, the show transferred in December 2010 to London’s West End, where it was nominated for three Olivier Awards.

headline: Ibsen ‘Fragments’ Under Scrutiny
text: In a case that has gripped Scandinavia, “lost fragments” of work by Henrik Ibsen, above, are suspected to have been forged. An economic crimes unit in Norway is looking for possessions and letters that supposedly relate to Ibsen, and to Knut Hamsun, a Nobel-winning novelist and Nazi sympathizer, The Observer of London has reported. Geir Ove Kvalheim, a Norwegian scriptwriter and actor, has been charged with forging more than a dozen documents and is scheduled for trial in April. The case began when Mr. Kvalheim said he had found fragments of a previously unknown Ibsen play, “The Sun God,” a discovery that would have changed literary history. News reports say that Mr. Kvalheim, who could face up to six years in prison if convicted of the offense, has refused to comment on the charges.

headline: Arts Education Center Names New Executive
text: Eric G. Pryor has been named the new executive director of the Center for Arts Education, the organization’s board announced on Monday. The center provides programs, professional development and advocacy for New York City’s public schools. Mr. Pryor previously served as executive director of the New Jersey State Museum and as president of the Visual Arts Center of New Jersey. He succeeds Richard Kessler, who became the dean of Mannes College the New School for Music in August.

headline: A Packed Schedule For Spoleto Festival
text: American premieres of the Philip Glass opera “Kepler” and of John Cage’s 1991 orchestral trilogy, “Twenty-six, Twenty-eight and Twenty-nine,” will be featured at the Spoleto Festival USA, which runs from May 25 through June 10 in Charleston, S.C. The festival’s schedule will also include Mike Daisey’s solo shows “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs” and “Teching in India”; Les 7 Doigts de la Main’s “Traces”; a production of Noël Coward’s “Hay Fever” by the Gate Theater of Dublin; and “Making Up the Truth” by Jack Hitt. In addition to Mr. Glass’s opera, directed by Sam Helfrich, Spoleto will offer the American premiere of “Feng Yi Ting,” a contemporary Chinese opera by the composer Guo Wenjing and directed by Atom Egoyan. Additional concerts will be given by K. D. Lang and Mavis Staples, and dance performances will include works from Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

headline: Storehouses for Solar Energy Can Step In When the Sun Goes Down
text: If solar energy is eventually going to matter — that is, generate a significant portion of the nation’s electricity — the industry must overcome a major stumbling block, experts say: finding a way to store it for use when the sun isn’t shining.

headline: Romney Confident of Winning — Something
text: MARION, Iowa — Mitt Romney told a Cedar Rapids crowd Monday that President Obama is great — at some things. “I watch a president who’s become the great divider, the great complainer, the great excuse-giver, the great blamer,” Mr. Romney said.

headline: Davenport Becomes a Magnet for Candidates
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa – It took Carolyn Barry nearly until the caucuses to make up her mind. But her flirtations with a series of other candidates seemed a thing of the past as she enthusiastically shook Mitt Romney’s hand while wearing a campaign button that spoke to suddenly solid support.

headline: In Nigeria, Boko Haram Is Not the Problem
text: GOVERNMENTS and newspapers around the world attributed the horrific Christmas Day bombings of churches in Nigeria to “Boko Haram” — a shadowy group that is routinely described as an extremist Islamist organization based in the northeast corner of Nigeria. Indeed, since the May inauguration of President Goodluck Jonathan, a Christian from the Niger Delta in the country’s south, Boko Haram has been blamed for virtually every outbreak of violence in Nigeria.

headline: Caterpillar Locks Out Workers in Canada
text: OTTAWA — A lockout late Sunday of about 465 workers at a Canadian locomotive factory owned by a Caterpillar unit has renewed debate in Canada about the labor impact of foreign ownership.

headline: Teva Names a New Chief Executive
text: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries of Israel named Jeremy Levin of Bristol-Myers Squibb as its next chief executive, replacing Shlomo Yanai. Mr. Levin, 58, a doctor educated at the University of Cambridge, worked at Bristol-Myers as senior vice president for strategy, alliances and transactions. He will take over as president and chief in May, Teva said in a statement, after Mr. Yanai, 59, retires. Teva’s shares plunged last year amid mounting competition for its No. 1 drug, a branded multiple sclerosis medicine called Copaxone. Mr. Yanai, a former Israeli army general with no previous pharmaceutical experience, spent $6.5 billion last year to buy the American biotechnology company Cephalon, then told investors in December that Teva might not able to meet its long-term target of $31 billion in sales by 2015.

headline: Chile’s President Defends His Response to Wildfires
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Wildfires swept through unseasonably hot, dry parts of southern Chile on Monday, as firefighters struggled to extinguish the blazes and as the government of Sebastián Piñera, Chile’s beleaguered billionaire president, defended its response.

headline: Queens Libraries Speak the Mother Tongue
text: The best-selling biography of Steve Jobs is flying off the shelves at libraries in Queens, which is not surprising. But in many of the borough’s 62 branches, the copies being borrowed are in Korean, Chinese or Spanish.

headline: The Slush Funds of Iowa
text: Turning on the television in Iowa recently has meant getting hit by an unrelenting arctic blast of campaign ads stunning in volume and ferocity. Residents here say they have never seen anything like the constant negativity in decades of witnessing the quadrennial combat of the state presidential caucuses. The ads have transformed the Republican race for a simple reason: a new landscape of unlimited contributions to “independent” groups that was created by the Supreme Court.

headline: In Greece’s Sour Economy, Some Shops Are Thriving

And, generally, one can expect the current prevailing sentiment about a coach’s performance — whatever that sentiment might be — to have all the staying power of rent money.

headline: Sam Oliver Gets Married
text: Sam Oliver was going to be married. The recently widowed lieutenant colonel, 35 years old, had proposed to a young lady back home in Massachusetts and she accepted. Now he just needed to get time off from his duties along the Virginia section of the Washington defenses. On New Year’s Day 1862, he applied by letter for a three-week furlough. He submitted it to his commanding colonel, William Greene, who was pleased to comply — not because he wanted Oliver’s happiness, but because he wanted to get rid of him.

Its mayor, who is the subject of a state police investigation, has been pushed aside in favor of a receiver, who has taken control of the city’s finances.

headline: Falling Behind
text: On Sunday, Washington became the first state to have a minimum wage above $9 an hour, $9.04 to be exact. headline: Keeping the Muse in Business
text: It’s nearly a century since the magazine Poetry was founded on uncertain prospects and an “open door” promise: “May the great poet we are looking for never find it shut.” Across the decades, the slim, challenging magazine has survived, publishing all manner of startling new poets, including T.S. Eliot, Langston Hughes, Wallace Stevens, Gwendolyn Brooks, Ezra Pound and Marianne Moore. Robert Frost happily celebrated its first decade in a subscription blurb urging readers to try Poetry as the “best boost” ever for struggling versifiers.

headline: Fighting Over Parsley

If the standoff had lasted longer than a few days, and if blood had actually been spilled, we might now know it as the Parsley War. But on July 18, they were overwhelmed and forcibly ejected by Equipo 31, a crack team of Spanish special forces soldiers. No shots were fired.

headline: Ohio: Sites of Two Earthquakes Nearly Identical
text: The 4.0 magnitude earthquake that struck Youngstown on Saturday occurred at an almost identical location to one a week before, a seismologist who studied the quakes said Monday. Both earthquakes occurred close to the bottom of a 9,200-foot-deep disposal well where for months, brine and other liquid waste from natural-gas wells had been injected under pressure. They were the 10th and 11th earthquakes to occur near the well since March, but the first to be precisely located. The finding provides further evidence to support what some scientists had suspected: that the waste, from the drilling process called hydraulic fracturing that is used to unlock natural gas from shale rock, might have migrated from the disposal well into deeper rock formations, allowing an ancient fault to slip. Similar links between hydraulic-fracturing disposal wells and earthquakes have been suspected in recent years in Texas and Arkansas. John Armbruster, a seismologist with Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, part of Columbia University, said that the epicenter of the quake Saturday was about 100 meters, or 110 yards, from that a 2.7-magnitude quake on Dec. 24. There were a few reports of minor damage from the earthquake on Saturday, but none from any of the earlier quakes. The Ohio Department of Natural Resources reached an agreement last week with the owner of the disposal well, D&L Energy, to halt operations indefinitely and issued a moratorium on further development of disposal wells in the area until the analysis of the 4.0 quake was completed.
