headline: Christmas Blues in Russia
text: MOSCOW — After New Year’s — the biggest traditional family holiday of the year — Russia descends into an odd, sleepy state for 10 days. Most businesses go on vacation, Moscow’s hellish traffic temporarily evaporates, and Russians spend their days in that hazy state between hangover and drink, either at their snowed-in dachas or on warmer shores. A couple of days after Orthodox Christmas on Jan. 7, they will emerge from hibernation and stumble into work, dazed by the prospect of three more months of winter.

headline: Taliban Opening Qatar Office, and Maybe Door to Talks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Giving a first major public sign that they may be ready for formal talks with the American-led coalition in Afghanistan, the Taliban announced Tuesday that they had struck a deal to open a political office in Qatar that could allow for direct negotiations over the endgame in the Afghan war.

headline: The Financial Lesson in Too Many Skis
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His new book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this week, and we’ll be running excerpts all week long. Meanwhile, his sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Condé Nast Traveler: In case you’re already planning that midwinter vacation to the Caribbean, here are some thoughts on where and how to dine on Barbados, Martinique and St. Lucia. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: 3M to Acquire a Unit of Avery Dennison
text: 3M, the maker of Post-it notes and Scotch Tape, has agreed to buy the office and consumer products business of the Avery Dennison Corporation for $550 million in cash.

headline: The Convoluted Economics of Storing Energy
text: As I reported in Tuesday’s paper, some companies think that one form of renewable energy is going to open a window for another — that solar photovoltaic panels, which convert sunlight directly into electricity, are going to increase the grid’s need for a type of solar energy that can be stored.

headline: The Colts Can’t Win for Losing
text: You have to hand it to the Indianapolis Colts because whatever they do, they do it big, all the way back to their moving-vans-rolling-out-of-Baltimore days. Now, after turning the platform of their almost-dynasty into a quadruple flip with three twists in the pike position (from 10-6 in 2010 to 2-14 in 2011, degree of difficulty: 8.9), they followed with the equally big response of canning the architect of the Peyton Manning Dynasty, Bill Polian, and his handpicked successor/offspring, Chris.

headline: Mississippi State Defensive Tackle Declares for N.F.L. Draft
text: Mississippi State defensive tackle Fletcher Cox is skipping his senior season and declaring for the N.F.L. draft. Cox is considered one of the country’s best defensive line prospects and is projected by N.F.L. evaluators as a second-round pick, though some analysts believe he could be selected late in the first round.

headline: Wisconsin Has More Than Bowl Loss to Worry About
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Wisconsin lost for the third time this season Monday evening. As painful as it was, it was equally fitting for a team that has now lost two consecutive Rose Bowls by a combined 9 points.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Jan. 3
text: Twitter users could experience Rupert Murdoch unfiltered this New Year’s weekend, as he joined the service and immediately began sharing his thoughts large and small. One post indicated support for Rick Santorum on the eve the Iowa caucuses, saying he was “Only candidate with genuine big vision for country.” In the past, Brian Stelter writes on The Caucus blog, Mr. Santorum has criticized Fox News as part of his broader complaint that the news media has ignored his candidacy, saying, “You know, Bill O’Reilly has refused to put me on his program.” On Monday night, Mr. O’Reilly acknowledged Mr. Santorum’s recent rise in the polls and said, “We have invited Rick Santorum to appear on Wednesday.”

headline: Feet in Iowa, Eye on Florida
text: 12:12 p.m. | Updated  DES MOINES — With the political world’s attention focused on Iowa, Mitt Romney’s campaign is looking several steps ahead and turning to Florida, where it is buying up time on broadcast television in that voter-rich primary state.

headline: Wild-Card Games: What the Film Says
text: Andy Benoit, who has been contributing weekly film reviews this season, trains his eye on the wild-card matchups:

headline: For Neck Pain, Chiropractic and Exercise Are Better Than Drugs
text: Seeing a chiropractor or engaging in light exercise relieves neck pain more effectively than relying on pain medication, new research shows.

headline: On Our Radar: Quakes and Fracking
text: A 4.0 magnitude earthquake that struck Youngstown on Saturday occurred at a site that was almost identical to one hit a week earlier, a seismologist says — close to the bottom of a 9,200-foot-deep disposal well where liquid waste from natural-gas wells had been injected under pressure. The finding provides further evidence that the waste from the fracking process may have migrated from the well into deeper rock formations. [The New York Times]

headline: Guilty Verdicts in 1993 Racial Murder Case That Changed Justice in Britain
text: LONDON — More than 18 years late by the reckoning of the victim’s family and many others across Britain, a jury at the Old Bailey on Tuesday found two white men guilty of the racially motivated stabbing and murder of a black youth named Stephen Lawrence on a south London street in April 1993.

headline: Wheelies: The Finish Line Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Frustrated Gingrich Looks Past Iowa and Lashes Back at Romney
text: BURLINGTON, Iowa — With his candidacy battered by negative campaign ads and a disappointing showing in the Iowa caucuses, Newt Gingrich is adjusting his strategy to rescue his ailing campaign, aggressively swatting back at Mitt Romney, whose supporters have painted him into the box of a Washington influence-peddler.

headline: The Strengths of Rick Santorum
text: The conventional wisdom holds that Rick Santorum’s last-minute bid to consolidate the not-Mitt Romney vote in Iowa is, like so many other developments in this election season, nothing but good news for Romney — because Santorum’s rise is preventing Rick Perry or Newt Gingrich from gaining ground instead, and in a drawn-out campaign Romney would ultimately “be more threatened by Gingrich or Perry” (as HotAir’s Ed Morrissey puts it) than by the former Pennsylvania senator. “On record, on economic conservative credibility, on ties to big donors,” Dave Weigel writes, “Santorum’s not the opponent Romney feared most.” “If Perry or Gingrich are in the top three, we have a real race headed into South Carolina,” Erick Erickson suggests. But if Santorum wins Iowa, “we might as well sit back and declare Mitt Romney the nominee.” (Judging by these quotes, the Romney camp seems to agree.)

headline: Jeremy Jordan On Verge of Joining Broadway Move of Disney’s ‘Newsies’
text: One of the major casting questions pending on Broadway is whether “Newsies,” this spring’s new Disney musical, will star Jeremy Jordan, whose performance as the newsboy Jack Kelly drew critical acclaim in the show’s premiere in New Jersey last year and helped persuade Disney Theatrical Productions to transfer it to New York. Now that Mr. Jordan is free from the Broadway musical “Bonnie & Clyde,” which closed on Friday, it’s a good bet that he’ll be hawking “papes” as Jack on Broadway.

headline: Iowa Caucuses Q. & A.
text: Updated | 4:12 p.m. As Iowans and voters around the country awaited the beginning of the 2012 Republican nomination contests on Tuesday night, Michael Shear, a Times political reporter and chief correspondent for The Caucus blog, hosted a live — and lively — discussion about the caucuses on The Times’s Facebook page. Below, a transcript of highlights from the chat.

headline: Should Lego Be Gender-Free — or Just Less Complicated?
text: I just saw my first commercial for those Lego Friends for girls I wrote about here before the holiday, and after my first glimpse of Heartlake City, the new Lego world, I wondered if I’d spoken too soon about my willingness to place my order now. As the new Ladyfig characters in their brightly colored cafe morphed, on screen, into animated creations that looked far more Polly Pocket than Lego Hermione Granger, I cringed a little. Then I took a closer look at the building, with its ice-cream cups, flowers and railings. And it occurred to me that maybe the real problem with Lego, for girls and boys, isn’t the gender specificity of the various building sets. It’s that there are so many sets for building so many specific things.

headline: ‘Ideas Do Have Consequences’: the Ron Paul Appeal
text: NEWTON, Iowa — A Ron Paul stump speech offers something for almost everyone. And that may help explain why Mr. Paul, a 76-year-old Texas congressman, is polling so well here.

headline: Jobless Rate in Germany Edges Lower, Hitting 6.8%
text: FRANKFURT — The German economy remained mostly immune to the malaise afflicting the rest of the euro zone in December, with data released Tuesday showing that unemployment fell slightly during the month and that the average number of jobless people for the full year was the lowest in two decades.

headline: Romney’s Stump Speech Evolved Over Time
text: BEDFORD, N.H. —Last month in New Hampshire, Mitt Romney delivered what his aides billed his “closing argument,” a final pitch to voters before the before the nominating contests begin.

headline: The Old Professor Brings Them to Their Feet
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — For Newt Gingrich, there are no shades of gray. He speaks declaratively and authoritatively. Everything he opposes is “fundamentally,” “profoundly,” even “grotesquely” wrong and is often cast in apocalyptic terms.

headline: Rice Noodles With Stir-Fried Chicken, Turnips and Carrots
text: Turnips are a perfect winter vegetable for a hearty stir-fry.

headline: Top Hip-Hop Agent Joins C.A.A.
text: 1:31 p.m. | Updated Cara Lewis, a top booking agent for hip-hop who last month left her longtime job at WME, the agency formerly known as William Morris Endeavor, has joined that company’s archrival, the Creative Artists Agency.

headline: From Pippen to Holmes: Is There a Penalty for Quitting on a Team?
text: When Santonio Holmes of the Jets appeared to quit on the team in a loss to the Dolphins Sunday, a number of teammates went public with their criticism. But it wasn’t the first time in recent sports history that a player was in the spotlight for not being a team-first guy. Jorge Posada of the Yankees took himself out of the lineup in May when Manager Joe Girardi tried to bat him ninth in the lineup against the Red Sox. And in 1994 Scottie Pippen of the Bulls refused to play when Coach Phil Jackson designed a scoring play for his teammate Toni Kukoc.

headline: Two Hours Later, the Audience Is Won Over
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Rick Santorum’s surge in the polls took many political watchers by surprise. But it shouldn’t have shocked anyone who has watched him preside over one of his nearly 400 town hall meetings in Iowa over the last year.

headline: Producers Guild Announces Its Nominations
text: The Producers Guild just released its nominations, and the top film contenders are:

headline: Shooting at Checkpoint Raises Tensions in a Disputed Region Claimed by Moldova
text: MOSCOW — Tension rose between Russia and Moldova, a former Soviet republic that recently celebrated 20 years of independence, after a Russian peacekeeper fatally shot a young Moldovan man as he sped through a checkpoint early on New Year’s Day.

headline: Van Halen, Stalwart Arena-Rock Band, to Play Intimate Set at Small Club
text: Van Halen has invited music writers and critics to an intimate concert at Cafe Wha? in Greenwich Village on Thursday night as a prelude to a tour with the band’s classic lineup later this year. Nothing official has been released, but journalists have been told the group will play a short set. The one-night performance in that 250-seat club on MacDougal Street in Manhattan marks the latest enigmatic hint that the band has sent about its plans for the year.

headline: Man Being Questioned in Firebombings
text: Updated 1:33 p.m. | The police are questioning a man who investigators believe may be responsible for four firebomb attacks in Queens over the weekend, the city’s police commissioner said on Tuesday.

headline: Training Program for Math Teachers Will Shift Its Focus
text: The Math for America program, which attracts and trains math teachers, is shifting its focus away from new recruits to teachers who are already in the classroom, and plans to more than double its presence in New York City in the next several years.

headline: Bull’s-Eye | Jason Wu for Target
text: “I can finally afford Jason Wu!” squealed a fan upon hearing about the forthcoming Jason Wu for Target collection, in stores Feb. 5. The capsule, Wu’s first in collaboration with a mass retailer, possesses a lot of the label’s familiar, feminine spirit but takes more direct inspiration from French New Wave films and the actress Jean Seberg. Pleated frocks with sailor-striped hemlines, dainty silk blouses with neck ties and collars, and sportier knits and tennis skirts stand out as some of the line’s most wearable pieces. “My goal was not to duplicate anything from my main collection,” Wu says. “Instead I designed completely new clothes and accessories that reflect my taste and have a voice of their own.” Friendly reminders of Wu’s work (like the touch of lace on a trench coat or T-shirt) are matched with a delightful dose of animal humor. (Meet Milu, a mischievous kitty and the collection’s mascot, who makes appearances as a print on a scarf and tee.) Here, a Riviera cotton striped A-line dress and canvas satchel explain why Wu calls the whole gamut “gamine chic.” It seems, as they say, les jeux sont faits.

headline: Beckham Appears Likely to Stay With Galaxy
text: David Beckham’s days in Major League Soccer are apparently not over after all.

headline: The Iowa Caucuses
text: The vote count remained too close to call into early Wednesday morning, when Mitt Romney was finally declared the winner by just eight votes.

headline: Dutch Firm’s Finance Officer Quits After Reorganization
text: A business executive who became the first woman to be appointed chief financial officer of a large Dutch company resigned on Tuesday, citing a dispute over a management reorganization at her employer, the phone operator KPN.

headline: Great for Hopping About
text: MARIJANA CONDIC and Lisa Leipziger, friends in Frankfurt, had a modest mission: to make espadrilles that were sturdier than the Spanish styles they love to wear. “I came back from holiday in Spain and told Marijana we have to do something special with espadrilles so they don’t fall apart after a month,” Ms. Leipziger said. Their label, Lika Mimika, is the happy result. The unisex styles, in soft lamb, goat and calfskin, are hand-stitched in Spain and come in a range of neutrals and Pop colors. Two new styles, lined with rabbit fur or curly lamb shearling, are a clever travel shoe: cozy for the flight and vacation-ready upon landing.

headline: Why We’re Trying Another Infomercial
text: We are about to take another shot at something that ended in failure five years ago. Yes, we are making another infomercial, but this time I think I know what I’m doing. Actually, that may be an exaggeration. This time, I at least have the experience of having gone through the process once before.

headline: ‘Bridesmaids,’ ‘Ides of March’ Get a Little Help From Producers Guild
text: Order another corsage for “Bridesmaids” because it’s going to the party. The Producers Guild chose the comedy as one of its 10 best films of the year, possibly advancing its standing with the Academy on the road to Oscar. “The Ides of March,” George Clooney’s political thriller, also got a nod, another boost following several Golden Globe nominations. “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” which so far has been a longer shot according to most Academy Awards watchers, made the list, too. The other films the Producers Guild chose are the expected bunch: “The Artist,” “The Descendants,” “The Help,” “Moneyball,” “Midnight in Paris,” “Hugo” and “War Horse.”

headline: When Romney’s Reach Exceeds His Grasp
text: DES MOINES – It is jarring, in an age of irony and nuance, to hear Mitt Romney conclude his stump speeches with a riff on the hymn, “America the Beautiful.” At an early-morning rally today, a few hours before the Iowa caucuses begin, he discussed his love for the patriotic song — probably the most beloved in the canon – and recited several of the song’s verses, strongly suggesting that its vision of the country differed from President Obama’s.

headline: Anatomy of a Stump Speech
text: A strong stump speech is one of the most important components of a presidential campaign. Times reporters following the candidates have deconstructed and annotated four candidates’ stump speeches, providing context and checking facts.

headline: Robert L. Carter, an Architect of School Desegregation, Dies at 94
text: Robert L. Carter, a former federal judge in New York who, as a lawyer, was a leading strategist and a persuasive voice in the legal assault on racial segregation in 20th-century America, died on Tuesday morning in Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: First Contest of the Year: Following the Iowa Caucuses
text: Overview | What are the Iowa caucuses? What role do they play in shaping American presidential elections? In this lesson, students create sketches and analyze visualizations of the Iowa caucuses, then conduct a scavenger hunt through The Times to find information about the 2012 Iowa caucuses and what they mean for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Karting at Daytona: Fun, but Not Play Time
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Late on the afternoon of Dec. 30, the bags were packed and trailers loaded. Daytona Kartweek was over, and by Saturday morning the historic speedway where it took place would be emptied of cars, 18-wheelers and tents.

headline: TimesCast | January 3, 2012
text: Republican candidates make their final pitches before the Iowa caucuses | It’s the season of the political tourist.

headline: Interactive Feature: Anatomy of a Stump Speech
text: A strong stump speech is one of the most important components of a presidential campaign. In an effective speech, a candidate can weave promises and attacks, lay out ambitious plans, and connect with voters on a personal level.

headline: Campaigning Across Iowa
text: A glimpse at the Republican candidates campaigning before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Red Bulls to Acquire Swedish Defender
text: According to reports out of Sweden, the Red Bulls have signed defender Markus Holgersson, 26, on a free transfer from Helsingborg, his hometown club.

headline: Dates Set for School Closing Hearings
text: The city's Department of Education has set hearing dates for the 25 schools that officials have recommended for closing or for the removal of  middle school grades. The Panel for Educational Policy will vote on the recommendations on  Feb. 9.

text: IF you want to have some fun, bring friends to Simpson Wong’s new restaurant on Cornelia Street and watch them taste the duck-fat ice cream in a dessert called duck a la plum.

headline: Wong Restaurant
text: Simpson Wong has a freewheeling palate and nuanced instincts for building contrasts.

headline: Gingrich Calls Romney a Liar
text: DES MOINES — Weeks of staying cheerily — and ineffectively — positive amid an onslaught of negativity appears to have finally gotten to Newt Gingrich.

headline: ‘War Horse’ Sound Tricks: Ice Skates for Bullets and Other Trade Secrets
text: 1:09 p.m. | Updated  Box office-wise, the surprise winner of the holiday season was “War Horse,” Steven Spielberg’s military epic. With an absence of recognizable stars -– save perhaps, for the horse -– the film’s appeal is in the very filmmaking: Mr. Spielberg’s own style, of course, and that of frequent collaborators like the Oscar-winning cinematographer Janusz Kaminski and the sound designer Gary Rydstrom, who has won Oscars for “Saving Private Ryan,” “Titanic,” “Jurassic Park” and more.

headline: It’s Organic, but Is It Natural?
text: My article over the weekend on Mexico’s booming market in organic tomatoes bound for the United States raises an important question: Do Americans really need to eat organic tomatoes in the winter, when they are hard to grow naturally here?

headline: Landmark on Twisting Path Toward Talks
text: The Taliban re-emerged three years after the American-led 2001 invasion, mounting a violent insurgency against Western forces and the Afghan government, during which repeated efforts to bring them to the negotiating table have faltered.

headline: Fed to Publish a Forecast of Rate Moves, Guiding Investors
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve will begin later this month to publish the predictions of its senior officials about their own decisions, hoping to increase its influence over economic activity by guiding investor expectations.

headline: $87 Million Later, Music Start-Up Closes Before Going to Market
text: Beyond Oblivion, a digital music start-up company that raised $87 million from blue-chip investors like News Corporation, closed its doors last week without ever introducing what was supposed to be its signature product, Boinc.

headline: Even Without James, Oregon Looks Strong for Next Season
text: PASADENA, Calif. — There was a moment, in the waning moments of the third quarter of what may have been his last game as an Oregon Duck, that perfectly encapsulated the spirit of LaMichael James.

headline: Caucusing at Home, and Ready for Crowds
text: Tonight will be the third time Sharon McNutt and her husband, Gary, will welcome caucus voters into their home in Silver City, Iowa, one of a handful of private locations that will bear witness to the first votes of the 2012 presidential election.

headline: The Outer Limits of Insider Trading
text: Most insider trading cases start out with suspicions about well-timed transactions that prove to be lucrative once information becomes public about a company. Bringing a successful enforcement action requires more than just suspicious trading, however, because the government must have evidence that a trader acted on material nonpublic information and not just that the person made a particularly prescient investment.

headline: Lobbyist Is Expected to Plead Guilty in Corruption Case
text: Richard J. Lipsky, a prominent New York lobbyist who was charged in the bribery conspiracy case that also ensnared State Senator Carl Kruger, is expected to plead guilty on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, a person briefed on the matter said Tuesday.

headline: From the Mail Bag: On Taking a Gap Year
text: Over the holidays, readers flooded The Choice’s mailbox with thoughtful comments and observations, including on the initial student postings to our first-person “Envelope, Please” series.

headline: Murdoch Tweet Hints at Chill Between Fox News and Glenn Beck
text: A Twitter message from Rupert Murdoch about the Fox News talk show “The Five” drew notice on Monday.

headline: Liverpool Won’t Appeal Suspension of Suárez
text: Liverpool has decided not to appeal the eight-game suspension given to striker Luis Suárez, who was found to have used racial insults against Manchester United defender Patrice Evra in December. But the club took a few parting shots at the findings of the commission that handed down the ban before announcing its decision not to appeal it.

headline: Bachmann Looks to an Election Night ‘Miracle’
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Representative Michele Bachmann made her longstanding pledge to repeal President Obama’s health care law the central focus of her last campaign stop in the Des Moines area before tonight’s caucuses.

headline: Quick Action in Kashmir After Death of Protester
text: NEW DELHI — A day after security forces shot and killed a teenager during protests over electricity shortages in Indian-administered Kashmir, regional authorities moved swiftly on Tuesday to keep the killing from setting off new rounds of demonstrations during what has been an unusually peaceful period in the region.

headline: Pass the Large Grain of Salt
text: “HERE’S a good example of what we’re talking about,” Simon Doonan said. My Cuban sandwich had just arrived, pressed flat and bulging with cheese. He was giving it a withering once-over.

headline: Simon Doonan Is Taking Reader Questions
text: Simon Doonan, the creative ambassador at large for Barneys New York and the author of the new book “Gay Men Don’t Get Fat,” will be responding to reader questions about porking out, slimming down, the perils of guacamole and chips, and whether or not certain foods can truly be categorized as “straight” or “gay.” Submit your question as a comment below or tweet us at @nytimesdining using the hashtag #asksimon, and he’ll answer on Diner’s Journal.

headline: Flavors of Peru, Recast
text: “LET’S go out for Peruvian!” doesn’t quite have the ring of a dinner invitation for Chinese or Italian. But as is increasingly clear, Peruvian cuisine — whose indigenous potatoes, chili peppers and seafood have been supplemented by ingredients and transformed by culinary techniques from many countries, China and Italy included — has much to offer beyond rotisserie chicken.

headline: Charters Don't Have to Pay Rent, for Now
text: A state Supreme Court judge has rejected a request by parents and advocacy organizations for an immediate order to require New York City to charge charter schools rent for the space they occupy inside public school buildings. He did not, however, address the legality of the city's free-rent practice.

headline: European Central Bank Picks Belgian as Top Economist
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank unexpectedly named Peter Praet, a Belgian, its de facto chief economist on Tuesday, breaking a tradition in which German hard-liners occupied that crucial policy-making post.

headline: Police Demographics Unit Casts Shadows From Past
text: Ethnic and racial profiling by the authorities. Concerns about the true loyalties of Americans whose roots are elsewhere. Tracking where New Yorkers of potentially suspect racial, ethnic or religious backgrounds live.

headline: Where the Producers Guild and the Academy Part Ways
text: LOS ANGELES — On close inspection the nominations for annual movie awards from the Producers Guild of America do less to clarify a confusing Oscars race than it might appear.

headline: Dancing Diplomacy: American Troupes to Tour Again for State Department
text: American dance companies are once again heading overseas to practice a kind of choreographed diplomacy as part of the second season of DanceMotion USA. The Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs of the State Department and the Brooklyn Academy of Music are to announce on Wednesday plans for the international tours of the four American dance companies taking part.

headline: College Stars Look to N.F.L. Draft
text: It’s not too early to be looking ahead to the N.F.L. draft, especially if you’re a promising underclassman wanting to turn pro. Baylor’s junior quarterback, Robert Griffin III, the recent Heisman Trophy winner, and Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck, who has a year of eligibility remaining, lead the crop of players who have declared for the draft. Also jumping early are the Oklahoma State junior receiver Justin Blackmon and the Rutgers junior receiver Mohamed Sanu.

headline: Trying Always to Please, Rarely to Challenge
text: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s annual five-week winter season at City Center is always a phenomenal draw. As with few or no other dance companies, all parts of that theater are thronged. The audience arrives in happy anticipation; then it greets everything with joy. Each section of Ailey’s “Revelations,” the hit of all hits, is not only followed but also actually preceded by applause.

headline: Alvin Ailey Dance at City Center

headline: Fewer Viewers Check Out ‘The Bachelor’ on ABC
text: Could the television broadcast audience be growing less susceptible to the charms of “The Bachelor” on ABC? The season premiere of the series averaged 7.7 million total viewers over a two-hour period on Monday night, according to Nielsen data, down from the 9 million viewers who watched the 15th-season premiere last January. There was also a 17 percent drop in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with last year. This placed ABC a distant second in the overall ratings among the broadcast networks, behind the CBS Monday comedy block. CBS finished No. 1 in all ratings categories in every prime-time half-hour.

headline: Resolution: Convert Paper Bonds to Electronic Versions

headline: Vain Glorious | Brushes With Greatness

To help identify the worthy investments from the rest, we’ve enlisted the expertise of five of the industry’s leading makeup artists. Here, they reveal the one tool they’re rarely without.

headline: Five Dishes at Wong
text: This week, I do my first pirouette as restaurant critic with a review of Wong, which opened on Cornelia Street in September. I don’t know why the restaurant didn’t make it on to more of those year’s best lists that everybody was publishing last month (Breaking: Gael Greene just placed it on hers), because the place offers some of the most original Asian cooking that New York has seen recently. Along with RedFarm, Kin Shop and Rouge et Blanc, Wong makes a compelling case that Asian fusion and pan-Asian cuisine are alive and kicking, even though those terms feel extremely last century at the moment.

headline: Words of Wisdom From the Candidates: End This, Repeal That
text: DES MOINES — When I was in high school, assemblies rarely deviated from the following pattern: No matter the speaker, the students would start out restless, and leave bored. But we never had Ron Paul as a closer.

headline: Multitasking Doctor Imperils Patient, Case Study Says

headline: Broadway Box Office Soars, With ‘Spider-Man’ Flying Highest Ever
text: Broadway producers and theater owners charged higher-than-usual prices for many seats last week to take advantage of tourists over the temperate New Year’s weekend, and the resulting profits were enormous. Eighteen of Broadway’s 34 shows earned more than $1 million, with “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” setting a record for the highest gross ever on Broadway — $2,941,794 for nine performances – according to data released by producers on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: A Portuguese University Town, Both Familiar and Foreign
text: Visiting a college town can sure bring back memories: dorm living, late night studying, partying to excess, roaming the campus dressed like vampires.

headline: Georgia’s Tough Campaign Against Childhood Obesity
text: The blogosphere hates Georgia’s tough new Strong4Life campaign against childhood obesity. Short ads or billboards, each featuring an obese child (the youngest looks to be about 9, the oldest a teenager), tell Georgia to “stop sugarcoating” the problem. “Fat kids become fat adults,” reads the slogan under what looks to be the youngest child, a little girl who can be seen in a brief video saying she hates to go to school, where kids make fun of her. Another ad, under a young boy, reads: “Big bones didn’t make me this way. Big meals did.”

headline: The Next War
text: As the new year begins, At War is taking a look at a series by our Washington correspondents dubbed “The Next War.” The articles examine the American military and the decisions confronting it in a new age of austerity, from the cuts to come, to the costs of technology and the vision of a newer, leaner fighting force.

headline: President's Loan Scandal Adds Pressure on Merkel
text: BERLIN — Just as Germany finds itself cast with the leading role in shepherding Europe out of economic crisis, the country’s top leadership appears to be faltering.

headline: She Wrote a Nation’s Welcome
text: Even if Emma Lazarus’s poem “The New Colossus” had not transformed the gargantuan Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor from an aggressive monument — “Liberty Enlightening the World” — into a welcoming “Mother of Exiles”; even if she had not provided that crowned goddess with a humane voice that still resonates (“Give me your tired, your poor”); even if she had not asserted a powerful connection between liberty and opportunity, the exhibition “Emma Lazarus: Poet of Exiles”  at the Museum of Jewish Heritage demonstrates that there would still be reasons to value her life and work.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: On Yacht, Murdoch Catches the Twitter Wave
text: Some people sunbathe and drink daiquiris on their Caribbean vacations. Rupert Murdoch, the chairman and chief executive of the News Corporation, joined Twitter.

headline: Big Bus Operator Files for Bankruptcy
text: Coach America, one of the country’s biggest bus operators, filed on Tuesday for bankruptcy protection to cut its debt load.

headline: How to Avoid Potholes on the Road to Politeness
text: Is it a breach of good manners to mislead folks just a little if you are going to show them a good time?

headline: Analysts See Performance Issues Behind RIM’s Delays
text: OTTAWA — When Research in Motion said in December that a new line of BlackBerry phones would not appear until the end of 2012, the announcement provoked equal parts of shock and disbelief from analysts.

headline: Peter Frampton Reunited With ‘Best Guitar’ After 31 Years
text: Peter Frampton has been reunited with the Gibson electric guitar he played on “Frampton Comes Alive,” three decades after it was presumed destroyed in a plane crash.

text: Pictures from Iraq, Pakistan, Cambodia and Egypt.

text: Photographs from Iraq, Pakistan, Cambodia and Egypt.

headline: Software Helps Identify Anonymous Writers or Helps Them Stay That Way
text: Your writing style is a little like your fingerprint. Your word choice, spelling, punctuation, sentence structure and syntax are all dead giveaways.

headline: Eric Asimov: How the View from the Critic’s Perch Has Changed
text: FOR the last three months, I’ve had the pleasure of returning to analytical eating as the interim restaurant critic. While my wife will say that I generally eat a little too critically all the time, it’s been my first sustained period reviewing restaurants since I began writing about wine full time in 2004.

headline: Anger and Hate Devour a Man and His Country
text: The clammy chill that pervades “The Hunter,” the fourth feature film by the Iranian director Rafi Pitts, seeps under your skin as you wait for its grim, taciturn protagonist to detonate.

headline: Steak ’N’ Bacon Cheddar Meatballs
text: Adapted from “The Meatball Shop Cookbook” by Daniel Holzman and Michael Chernow with Lauren Deen (Random House, 2011)

headline: Nobody Likes to Talk About It, but It’s There
text: DES MOINES — Talking about race in American politics is uncomfortable and awkward. But it has to be said: There has been a racist undertone to many of the Republican attacks leveled against President Obama for the last three years, and in this dawning presidential campaign.

headline: Unable to Raise Capital, Brokerage Firm Calls It Quits
text: WJB Capital, a tiny broker dealer that was pushing to expand in the shadows of large Wall Street banks, has decided to close up shop after being unable to raise money from investors in recent weeks.

headline: Puddin’ by Clio Opening in the Village
text: Clio Goodman grew up in a family of serious cooks, so it was only natural that she would try her hand at a culinary career. After graduating from the Culinary Institute of America, she worked at Danny Meyer’s restaurant group and for Daniel Boulud. Now she is pursuing her dream: desserts built around pudding. Let others have their macarons; Ms. Goodman has fine-tuned a classic stovetop pudding and makes it in eight flavors. On Friday, when she plans to open her little shop, Puddin’ by Clio, with its open kitchen and white oak trim, she will have parfaits layered with pudding, and cakes, like banana upside-down, with a pudding filling. She also makes pudding pies, including chocolate and Key lime; trifles layered with cake; and, to adorn plain pudding, about 18 sauces, crumbles, nuts and fruit.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Emoting Robots and the Stalin of Facebook
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors found on the Web. For more items, go to the full list in the right-hand column.

headline: Hamachi Now Available to Home Cooks
text: Hamachi, or yellowtail, a fish in the jack family, is so very familiar and yet so rare: well known in its raw state, as sushi, sashimi and tartare in restaurants, yet seldom sold in retail markets for the home cook.

headline: ‘Lysistrata Jones’ to Close
text: “Lysistrata Jones,” the new Broadway musical about a college basketball team that brought dribbling, passing, and hoop shots to the Walter Kerr Theater, will close after the Jan. 8 matinee performance, the producers announced on Tuesday, following two months of weak ticket sales. The show opened on Dec. 14 to a mix of positive and negative reviews from critics, and it failed to develop a following despite the relative lack of new original musicals on Broadway last fall, with some ticket sales agents saying that the title – a modern-day twist on the classic Greek play – was off-putting to some potential theatergoers and tourist groups. (The only other original musical to open on Broadway during the fall season, “Bonnie & Clyde,” received worse reviews and closed on Friday.)

headline: Why I’d Bet on Santorum (and Against My Model)
text: The official version of FiveThirtyEight’s polling-based forecasts project Rick Santorum to receive about 19 percent of the vote in the Iowa caucuses on Tuesday night. It translates this to an 18 percent chance of Mr. Santorum’s overcoming his slight deficit with Mitt Romney and Ron Paul and winning the caucuses outright.

headline: Lucky to Be a Leftover
text: HOLIDAY cooking is finally over, but many refrigerators are still in hangover mode: stuffed with the remains of Christmas beef, the country ham from New Year’s Day, the rest of that disappointing crown roast of pork or spectacular leg of lamb. The holidays generate a special genre of leftovers: too boring to eat, too expensive to toss.

headline: Oprah’s ‘Next Chapter’ Draws 1.1 Million Viewers
text: Oprah Winfrey is back on television with a new talk show. But some of her fans don’t seem to know.

headline: A Token of Peace as a Soothing Brew
text: Unlike the oil, fruit and wood of the olive tree, which have enriched the kitchen since ancient times, the leaves have been more symbolic, as tokens of peace. But the greenery also has a less familiar culinary application. Dried olive-leaf tea is a gently mellow herbal brew with a scintilla of bitterness that evokes a green olive. Some lemon or honey enhances the flavor; it’s excellent iced, and can be added to a marinade, especially for fish, or — released from its bag — used in a spice rub or to season a salad dressing. Few tea stores sell it, but Garden of Eden now carries Mysia brand olive-leaf tea bags from Turkey. The individual packets are labeled Zeytin Yapragi Cayi, which simply means olive leaf tea. The tea is also available online.

headline: Adblock and Wikipedia Look to Raise Money for ‘Free’ Software
text: On Monday, I wrote about how the lead developer of an open-source project – Adblock Plus – had created a start-up to manage the project. As part of a new business plan, the software, which has long been known for blocking ads, would no longer block what it calls “acceptable ads.” (These ads will not be flashy or slow down the browsing experience.)

headline: City Tells Struggling Schools to Carry On While Funds Are in Flux
text: Now that the state has suspended payments for improvements to the city's struggling schools, principals are wondering: What happens to the SmartBoards, teachers and programs they have purchased, with the expectation the money to pay for them was forthcoming?

headline: Live Blogging the Iowa Caucuses
text: Welcome to FiveThirtyEight’s live blog of the Iowa caucuses.

headline: The Caucus
text: Megan Liberman and Nate Silver talk about what we might expect to see and what unexpected outcomes to look for in the Iowa Caucus tonight.

headline: The Mendacity of Dopes
text: So Alex Tabarrok thinks I treat everyone who disagrees with me as mendacious idiots, and Tyler Cowen says that I always demonize my opponents.

headline: Bach Cantatas Adapted for One Baby’s Early Days
text: The presentations could hardly have been more disparate in scale, spirit and spectacle, or lack of it. Still, fresh memories of “The Enchanted Island,” the remarkable Baroque confection unveiled by the Metropolitan Opera on New Year’s Eve, crowded in on the experience of two Bach cantatas performed by the Trinity Choir and Trinity Baroque Orchestra on Monday afternoon as part of the Bach at One series at the intimate St. Paul’s Chapel in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Obama Looks for a Share of the Iowa Spotlight
text: The Republican caucus is clearly the big story Tuesday night, but that hasn’t stopped President Obama from trying to grab some of the spotlight in Iowa. The president is hosting a live video conference for Democrats attending precinct caucuses across Iowa, where he will try to get himself in shape to repeat his 2008 win in the state, while at the same time landing a punch or two against the Republicans.

headline: On This Rock ’n’ Roll Tour of the Heartland, a Sobering Survey of Old America
text: “The decay of America is original and massive in its scale,” reflects Kurt Markus, the esteemed photographer, who, with his son, Ian, filmed the small, pungent rock ’n’ roll tour documentary, “John Mellencamp: It’s About You.”

headline: Duct Tape Goes From Fix-It to Dress-Up
text: THERE was a time when Lady Gaga’s improvised pasties made out of duct tape might have been viewed as a creative, if painful, use of the handyman’s favorite fix-it. But a couple of strips of strategically placed tape is nothing compared to the elaborate ensembles do-it-yourselfers are making out of it these days.

headline: Leonardo Painting’s Restoration Bitterly Divides Art Experts
text: PARIS — Leonardo da Vinci’s “Virgin and Child With Saint Anne” does not enjoy the same star status as his Mona Lisa. But for the Louvre, it is an equally treasured masterpiece.

headline: Why January Is the Coolest Month Onstage
text: Here’s an exclamation you will probably never hear: “Great news — I just got tickets to see experimental theater!”

headline: These Actors Think You Can Probably Do It Better Than They Can
text: New Yorkers, are you ready for your close-ups?

headline: Legal Fight for Mother of Suspect in Arsons
text: LOS ANGELES — The mother of Harry Burkhart, the suspect arrested in connection with more than 50 fires that were set in the Los Angeles area, appeared in federal court Tuesday, fighting extradition to her native Germany, demanding to know where her son was and calling him mentally ill.

headline: Easing Gently Into a Noisy New Year
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Casino the State Saved
text: ATLANTIC CITY — The view from the 39th floor of the Revel resort and casino here is nearly as stunning as the fact that the $2.4 billion project is actually nearing completion after five years, including a stretch when construction halted for almost a year after financing evaporated.

headline: Harboring Jews in Tunisia: The View From Yad Vashem

text: To the Editor:

headline: One Search for a Body, Another for Meaning
text: A metaphysical road movie about life, death and the limits of knowledge, “Once Upon a Time in Anatolia” has arrived just in time to cure the adult filmgoer blues. It was directed by the Turkish filmmaker Nuri Bilge Ceylan, whose earlier movies include “Distant” and “Three Monkeys” and who in recent years has emerged as one of the consistently most exciting directors on the international scene. His latest, which shared the grand prize at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival, takes the unassuming form of a police investigation that, as miles and words mount, evolves into a plangent, visually stunning meditation on what it is to be human.

headline: With Ownership of Corporate Parent Reportedly in Flux, Lotus Cars Awaits a Resolution
text: The ambitions of Lotus Cars, which showed six concepts just over a year ago at the Paris auto show, are again the subject of rumors and speculation. The Malaysian government may follow the advice once given by Colin Chapman, the founder of Lotus, to “simplify and add lightness” by divesting itself of Proton Holdings, the corporate parent of the boutique British sports-car manufacturer.

headline: Santorum Delivers Harsh Critique of Obama and His Values
text: URBANDALE, Iowa – The students at Des Moines Christian Assembly found out Tuesday morning that class was being dismissed early so they could get a special civics lesson from a visiting former United States senator, Rick Santorum.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Are We Less Violent?
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Hezbollah TV, Syrians Who Support Assad Claim to Be the Victims
text: While supporters of the Syrian uprising have done a remarkable job of documenting the Arab League observer mission  filling YouTube channels with video of outraged citizens describing the violent crackdown on dissent by the Syrian government  viewers of one television station in neighboring Lebanon are getting a very different picture of events in Syria.

headline: Decoding the Iowa Caucus Coverage
text: The 2012 Iowa caucuses on Tuesday night offer a first judgement on the Republican presidential candidates. But with its changing cast of frontrunners, Web-paced reports of scandal and intrigue, and saturation TV coverage of rural campaign stops, the Iowa campaigning has provided enough spectacle to exhaust entire teams of reporters.

headline: Explaining Tonight’s Polls
text: Within an hour or so, we’ll be getting results about Iowa voters’ preferences from interviews that are known as “entrance polls” — similar to the exit polls conducted for primaries in other states. Edison Research of Somerville, N.J. stations interviewers at a random number of caucus sites, and they ask voters before they head inside to fill out questionnaires about their choices for a presidential candidate, and their positions on other issues.

headline: Iowa Tackle Will Enter Draft
text: The Iowa offensive tackle Riley Reiff told coach Kirk Ferentz today that he will skipping his senior year to declare for the N.F.L. Draft. Reiff is considered one of the top tackle prospects in the N.F.L. Draft; ESPN projects him as a Top 10 pick. Reiff is planning on leaving this weekend to train.

headline: Knicks Hope to Get Boost From Return of Rookie
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The most compelling action on the Knicks’ practice court Tuesday came 30 minutes after practice ended. There, in a spirited game of 3-on-3, Amar’e Stoudemire and Iman Shumpert traded passes and slick drives.

headline: Women of Steel
text: It had to happen. For female politicians, invoking the name of Margaret Thatcher at a crucial time in your campaign is one of the canniest, most clichéd and most predictable of tactics.

headline: Steeler’s Sickle Cell Trait and Denver Do Not Mix
text: PITTSBURGH —  Ryan Clark peeked in the window a few moments before Coach Mike Tomlin’s news conference began Tuesday, a smile creasing his face as he was about to become the most unusual entrant on the playoff injury report.

headline: For Wall Street Overseer, Progress Comes at a Crawl
text: Leading a new federal agency intended to help prevent another financial crisis may seem like a dream job for most economic gurus, but the government made a nomination only last month after a painfully slow search process.

headline: Clemson Fans Hold Fast to a Tradition Worth More Than the Paper It’s Printed On
text: ATLANTA — As far as ridiculous college football traditions go, stamping a $2 bill with an orange Clemson tiger paw is pretty benign.

headline: After 40-Year Battle, Train May Roll for Oahu
text: KAPOLEI, Hawaii — From the farmlands here on the western side of Oahu, the hotels of Honolulu and the bluffs of Diamond Head can be seen rising 20 miles in the distance. This is rural Hawaii: waves and coastline on one side, lush mountains on the other and barely a building or vehicle in sight.

headline: The Best Android Gaming Apps of 2011
text: Just as the 10 best Android apps can hold their own against the 10 best iPhone apps of 2011, so can the better Android games hold their own against their iPhone counterparts. Here are my picks for the best new Android games of the year.

headline: In Liguria’s Coastal Hills, a Storm’s Fury Brings a Struggle for Restoration
text: VERNAZZA, Italy — When Unesco added the Cinque Terre, five medieval coastal towns perched along the Ligurian Coast, to its World Heritage List in 1997, it cited “the harmonious interaction between people and nature to produce a landscape of exceptional scenic quality.”

headline: In Westchester County, the Platinum Mile Is Reinvented, Again
text: In its glory days from the late 1960s to the mid-1980s, the Platinum Mile, as a section of Interstate 287 in Westchester County, N.Y., is called, was what its name suggested: a prosperous stretch of gleaming office parks, home to Fortune 500 companies like I.B.M., Texaco and General Foods.

headline: New Hampshire Now Optional for Some
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Former Gov. John H. Sununu had come to join the phone banks at Mitt Romney’s campaign headquarters here on Monday night when a reporter asked him what effect Tuesday’s Republican caucuses in Iowa would have on New Hampshire.

headline: Let Noncitizens Contribute to U.S. Elections
text: Arlington, Va.

headline: Time, or Tolls? Doing the New Math for New Jersey Commuters
text: It sounds like a problem from a physics exam: Two drivers left a parking lot in East Brunswick, N.J., at the same moment on Tuesday morning. One swallowed hard and took the New Jersey Turnpike, paying tolls that had jumped 53 percent on New Year’s Day. The other took Routes 1 and 1/9, toll free.

headline: The Forgotten Wages of War
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: A Cuomo Microscope on Capitol Renovation
text: ALBANY — No one would accuse Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of lacking attention to detail. But in recent months, his passion for the restoration of the Capitol has amazed even his closest aides, as the state’s chief executive has seemed at times more like its chief historian — or, at other moments, its chief architect, interior decorator and custodian.

headline: There Is an ‘I’ in Quit
text: Of all the various sins committed by athletes on and off the field, the worst — or at least the one that brings the quickest, most fiery denunciations — is quitting. The boxer Roberto Duran will be forever remembered for the “no más” ending to his fight in 1980 against Sugar Ray Leonard. And all his N.B.A. rings will not erase Scottie Pippen’s petulant refusal to enter a 1994 playoff game because the final shot was drawn up for his Chicago Bulls teammate Toni Kukoc.

headline: Massachusetts: Police Say Lieutenant Governor Was Sleeping and Speeding Before Car Crash
text: Lt. Gov. Timothy Murray was driving at more than 100 miles per hour and showed behavior consistent with falling asleep at the wheel when his car flipped over early on Nov. 2, the Massachusetts State Police found in an investigation released on Tuesday. In a statement to the news media, Mr. Murray said he believed his falling asleep to be the cause of the accident, although he initially said the crash was caused by black ice. The car, a state-owned vehicle, was totaled in the accident, but Mr. Murray was uninjured. Mr. Murray will pay a $555 ticket; he is not expected to face additional charges.

headline: Numberplay: 2011 – The Year in Puzzles
text: Happy New Year to all Numberplay readers. The New Year is traditionally a time to look back nostalgically at the past year, and look forward with hope toward the coming year. Today, I want to do mostly the former, because puzzles are infinite and open-ended and not even the authors of Numberplay know what the future will bring! But looking back over 2011 there are plenty of treasures that we can revisit, savor and perhaps extend.

headline: Early Numbers From the Exit Polls
text: DES MOINES — Here’s some early numbers from the entrance polls, crunched by the crack New York Times polling unit:

headline: Gordon Hirabayashi, World War II Internment Opponent, Dies at 93
text: Gordon Hirabayashi, who was imprisoned for defying the federal government’s internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II but was vindicated four decades later when his conviction was overturned, died on Monday in Edmonton, Alberta. He was 93.

headline: Overtures to Egypt’s Islamists Reverse Longtime U.S. Policy
text: CAIRO — With the Muslim Brotherhood pulling within reach of an outright majority in Egypt’s new Parliament, the Obama administration has begun to reverse decades of mistrust and hostility as it seeks to forge closer ties with an organization once viewed as irreconcilably opposed to United States interests.

headline: Bring Back Boring Banks
text: Medford, Mass.

headline: Dempsey Raises the Bar for U.S. Stars in Europe
text: LONDON — American soccer’s biggest name has arrived in England, hoping to live up to the reputation he made for himself on his first visit. Landon Donovan is fresh from Los Angeles, so it was understandable when he noted that sequels sometimes do not live up to the original.

headline: So Much Fun. So Irrelevant.
text: Two things have struck me about the Republican presidential candidate debates leading up to the Iowa caucuses. One is how entertaining they were. The other is how disconnected they were from the biggest trends shaping the job market of the 21st century. What if the 2012 campaign were actually about the world in which we’re living and how we adapt to it? What would the candidates be talking about?

headline: Teachers Resist High-Tech Push in Idaho Schools
text: POST FALLS, Idaho — Ann Rosenbaum, a former military police officer in the Marines, does not shrink from a fight, having even survived a close encounter with a car bomb in Iraq. Her latest conflict is quite different: she is now a high school teacher, and she and many of her peers in Idaho are resisting a statewide plan that dictates how computers should be used in classrooms.

headline: Beyond Elections: People Power
text: The presidential election may be grabbing headlines, but the true rallying cry for 2012 is to struggle and organize around those issues that a president might take seriously, to stake out positions that would benefit what used to be called the working class (and now goes by “the 99 percent”) and to garner enough political will and power to pressure the president and Congress to move resolutely on the issues that matter.

headline: Louisiana: BP Cleanup Payments on Hold
text: The $20 billion fund created by BP to pay damages from the 2010 spill in the Gulf of Mexico has stopped making payments until the judge overseeing the sprawling federal court litigation clarifies a recent order. Judge Carl J. Barbier in New Orleans ruled on Dec. 29 that settlements reached since Nov. 7 must provide 6 percent of the “gross settlement amount” to an escrow account for certain litigation expenses of plaintiffs’ lawyers. In a letter to Judge Barbier, David Pitofsky, the lead counsel for the fund, asked the judge whether, among other questions, his ruling means that people who have already received money should be forced to give some of it back. “We feel compelled by the court’s order to freeze payments to eligible claimants until we get clarification from the court,” said Kenneth R. Feinberg, administrator of the fund.

headline: Yankees Are Saving Now for a Potential Splash Next Winter
text: The most telling moment of the Yankees’ off-season was when they simply said no to C. J. Wilson. Here was the No. 1 starter for the Texas Rangers, the two-time defending American League champions. He wanted to come to New York for a visit, and the Yankees would not even extend an invitation.

headline: Turning Tax Time Into Party Time
text: AS the holiday season ends, the tax season begins, giving some revelers little reason to celebrate. A new ad campaign for Jackson Hewitt Tax Service wants to change that by getting customers to focus more on refund checks than on the actual filing of their taxes.

headline: Fred Milano, an Original Member of Dion and the Belmonts, Dies at 72
text: Fred Milano, one of the original members of Dion and the Belmonts, who wove his backup tenor tones into the musically seamless harmonies of 1950s and ’60s hits like “A Teenager in Love” and “Where or When,” died on Sunday at a hospital on Long Island. He was 72 and lived in Massapequa, N.Y.

headline: Sanchez’s Chore: Cleaning Up the Mess
text: Whenever Mark Sanchez finishes distancing himself from the Jets’ underachieving season, he intends to jot down his emotions so “hopefully we’re not feeling this way next year.” In the meantime, we can only imagine what must be swirling inside his head.

headline: Romney Wins Iowa Caucus by 8 Votes
text: DES MOINES — Mitt Romney’s quest to swiftly lock down the Republican presidential nomination with a commanding finish in the Iowa caucuses was undercut on Tuesday night by the surging candidacy of Rick Santorum, who fought him to a draw on a shoestring budget by winning over conservatives who remain skeptical of Mr. Romney.

headline: Entrance Polls Show High Evangelical Turnout
text: DES MOINES — It looks like a similar proportion of evangelical voters is turning out for the caucuses this year, as compared to the four years ago.

headline: Firebomber Picked Targets to Settle Personal Scores, Police Say
text: Over the last few years, the list of grudges grew, each emanating from a perceived slight. There was the time he was not allowed to use a bathroom. And the time he was apparently dissatisfied after buying crack cocaine.

headline: The Frontier of Classroom Technology
text: Do social media, interactive whiteboards and other recent innovations benefit students? What are the downsides?

headline: Iowa Caucuses
text: The Iowa caucuses, in which a nation awaits the verdict of a handful of some of its least representative citizens, are not going to settle the race for the Republican nomination for president. But they did put on display the choice the Republicans present to voters: right, far right or the far, far right.

headline: Small and Light, Starbucks Bottles as Canisters for Bombs
text: Mason jelly jars, whiskey quarts, wine and beer bottles — all have been among history’s vessels of choice for a homemade gasoline bomb.

headline: Rangers See Conspiracies in Winter Classic Calls
text: Coaches can be paranoid. They have been known, as well, to pop off about the quality of refereeing after any particular game — usually, of course, after defeats.

headline: Reckless Disregard for Safety
text: The House showed its utter disregard for public safety in November when it approved the National Right-to-Carry Reciprocity Act, which would take away the authority of states to decide who is allowed to carry a concealed and loaded handgun within their borders.

headline: Fred J. Schmidt
text: Mr. Schmidt, 56, is president and chief operating officer of Coldwell Banker Commercial of Parsippany, N.J., which has about 200 affiliated brokerage companies nationwide and is a subsidiary of Realogy.

headline: ‘A Very Likely Miscarriage of Justice’
text: The power to pardon is an essential means of justice, allowing a governor to right what the law got wrong. Gov. Jerry Brown of California has been asked to commute to time served the sentence of Shirley Ree Smith, who was convicted in 1997 of killing her grandson and has already served 10 years of a 15-years-to-life sentence. We urge the governor to commute her sentence so she does not now have to return to prison as a result of a misguided Supreme Court ruling.

headline: Raising Standards for Head Start
text: The Head Start program, which prepares disadvantaged 3- and 4-year-olds for school, has served nearly 30 million children since it was created in 1965. While there is little doubt that the federal program is critically important for these children and their parents, quality varies widely among programs.

headline: No. 22 Harvard Visits Fordham and Leaves With a Loss
text: Chris Gaston, a 6-foot-7 junior forward who endured two seasons in which Fordham won a grand total of nine games, stalked into the locker room at halftime Tuesday, fed up. It was time for a change, he said to himself.

headline: Entrance Polls: Examining Romney’s Strength
text: Mitt Romney is getting the most support among Iowa caucus goers who say that defeating Mr. Obama was the most important quality in a candidate. Nearly half of voters who said defeating the president was the most important thing in a candidate said they were casting their support for Mr. Romney.

headline: Booking a Flight to Space, With Travel Insurance
text: To go to outer space, Catherine Culver went to a travel agent.

headline: History at the State Capitol
text: A collection of artifacts will be displayed around the Capitol complex in Albany in connection with renovations scheduled to be completed this year.

headline: Accusations of Bullying After Death of Teenager
text: Amanda Cummings was not shy about her interests: animals and poetry, shopping and Katy Perry music, summer afternoons by the swimming pool and excursions to Manhattan, where she hoped to live some day.

headline: The Month Ahead
text: A look at the schedule of primaries and caucuses through Feb. 4.

headline: Online Sales Buoy U.P.S. And FedEx
text: With sales rising to a record $35.3 billion in November and December — a 15 percent increase from a year ago, according to the research service comScore — online retailers are celebrating.

headline: Adrift in Coach’s Absence, St. John’s Founders Again
text: St. John’s was a force last season when it played at Madison Square Garden, where it upset elite teams like Duke, Connecticut and Pittsburgh. The building earned the nickname Lavinwood, in homage to Coach Steve Lavin and his California ties, from the rowdy crowd of St. John’s students.

headline: Oedipus Rex Complex
text: DES MOINES

headline: Obama Speaks to Caucusing Democrats in Iowa
text: President Obama, back in the capital after his holiday break, was making his own speech to Iowa voters on Tuesday night, telling caucusing Democrats that he has kept the promises he made to them four years ago when his win in the Democratic caucus there electrified the country and galvanized his run for the White House.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Wednesday: You Are Here
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Brendan BEHAN was a lot of things: most chiefly among them, he was a poet and a novelist, a volunteer with the Irish Republican Army and, by his own admission, a drunk. The first two made him famous, the last killed him. What came in between sent him to prison, but it richly informed his writing. It’s difficult to encapsulate a writer like Mr. Behan in one small paragraph, but I’d like to move on to Brendan Emmett Quigley’s puzzle.

headline: Sacrificing to Nurture Her Sons’ Academic Aspirations
text: Listening to Kevin Del Villar rattle off ideas for how to improve Sunset Park, near his Brooklyn home, one might think he has been an urban planner or architect for years.

headline: School Loses Bid to Halt Man’s Protest
text: Citing the First Amendment, a judge on Tuesday denied a request by a New York City private school to prohibit the son of a former headmaster from picketing in front of the school as students arrive for class each morning.

headline: Ronald Searle, Slyly Caustic Cartoonist, Dies at 91
text: Ronald Searle, the British cartoonist and caricaturist whose outlandishly witty illustrations for books, magazine covers, newspaper editorial pages and advertisements helped define postwar graphic humor, died on Friday in Draguignan, in southeastern France, where he lived. He was 91.

headline: Grants in Limbo, the City Tells Principals to Hold On
text: In the face of the state’s suspension last week of federal grants to help improve 33 of New York City’s most troubled schools, the city’s Education Department sent a reassuring message to its principals: stay the course.

headline: New Wrinkle for a Fixture of Gay Life
text: The last weekend of 2011 brought mild weather to the city, so on their way home from the movies on Friday night, Randy Bourscheidt and his partner decided to go for a nightcap at Julius’, a bar on West 10th Street in Greenwich Village.

headline: Town Breathes Easier as Frozen Dead Guy and His Festival Stay Put
text: DENVER — It was probably not, in the end, an idea with huge franchise potential or a killer smartphone app in its future. After all, a gleefully macabre weekend celebration built around a frozen corpse — complete with coffin races, tours of the shed where the body is kept on ice and, of course, lots of beer — just might not be as fun beyond the skewed sensibility of Colorado’s hippie-tinged mountain belt.

headline: Out of Santorum’s Lean Operation, a Muscular Result
text: DES MOINES — Former Senator Rick Santorum’s campaign in Iowa conducted no polls or focus groups, employed no speechwriter and had no security presence until a few days ago. “We don’t have a bunch of guys with earpieces running around doing nothing,” he would boast.

headline: Electability and Principles Split Iowa Votes, Poll Finds
text: DES MOINES — Republicans appeared sharply divided between those whose top priority is defeating President Obama and those seeking someone representing traditional conservative principles and religious values, according to a poll of voters entering the Iowa Republican caucuses on Tuesday.

headline: As Israelis and Palestinians Talk, the Rise of a Political Islam Alters the Equation
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli and Palestinian officials met in Amman, Jordan, on Tuesday, their first encounter in more than a year, and while little emerged, the meeting said a great deal about the crossroads facing the Palestinians — and the entire Middle East — as political Islam emerges as a potentially transformative force in the region.

headline: Backers Hope Paul’s Iowa Strategy Will Move His Message
text: ANKENY, Iowa — Before the voting began in Iowa, Ron Paul was asked by an ABC correspondent, “When you lay your head on your pillow at night, do you see yourself in the Oval Office?”

headline: Dispatch From Des Moines’ Precinct 73
text: DES MOINES–After reciting the Pledge of Allegiance, the Iowans of Precinct 73 and about a dozen reporters listened to short speeches about all the candidates except Michele Bachmann. No one present was willing to represent her.

headline: Iraq’s Factional Chaos Threatens to Disrupt a Kurdish Haven
text: ERBIL, Iraq — For the Kurds here in this ancient city, the rewards of war are numerous and obvious. Construction cranes rise from the cityscape. Highway medians are green with shrubbery. A glittering shopping mall with an indoor ice skating rink stands as a totem of American-style consumerism. The only blast walls in sight are those that protect the regional parliament, decorated by sunflowers painted in muted shades of yellow.

headline: Syria Killings Continue; Group to Add Observers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian activists reported that at least two people were killed on Tuesday in the restive city of Hama in central Syria, despite the presence of Arab League observers there.

headline: Singer Responds to ‘Patriotic Duty’ to Enter Senegal’s Presidential Race
text: Putting his lucrative recording and touring career on hold in response to what he called a “supreme patriotic duty,” the Senegalese singer-songwriter Youssou N’Dour announced late Monday that he was running for president of his country.

headline: Paul Concedes Top 2 Spots
text: DES MOINES — Representative Ron Paul claimed one of the three tickets out of Iowa after results showed him trailing the two leaders in the race, Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum.

headline: Corrections: January 4
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Governor Expected to Set Up Panel on Education Reform
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to announce Wednesday in his State of the State address that he will convene a statewide commission to address a wide range of education issues, including improving student performance and school accountability, according to people familiar with the plan.

headline: Iowa’s Decision Night Arrives With the Air Full of the Unknown
text: PELLA, Iowa — Under the glare of a giant backlighted cross, four volunteers for Ron Paul formed a human obstacle course in front of voters walking into Pella Christian High School here, about an hour’s drive east of Des Moines.

headline: ‘Lovin’ It’ at the Santorum Ballroom
text: JOHNSTON, Iowa — “I’m lovin’ it!” shouted Lynn Rodgers as she stood in front of a television tuned to Fox News.

headline: Gingrich Promises ‘Great Debate’ in N.H.
text: DES MOINES — Newt Gingrich promised that a “great debate” in the Republican party will begin tomorrow in New Hampshire as he lashed out at Mitt Romney as a “Massachusetts moderate” who would not fundamentally fix the country’s problems.

headline: Iowa Caucus Live Blog
text: Caucusgoers all over Iowa are gathering in their communities Tuesday night to pick a Republican nominee for president. The Times’s political unit is on the ground in the Hawkeye State — with the candidates and at the caucus sites — to provide live updates and analysis of the 2012 nominating contests. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@thecaucus), get real-time results and dig deeper into the numbers with FiveThirtyEight.

headline: A Long Wait for Equality in Parliament
text: The Indian Parliament will “remain a male bastion for the near future,” Nilanjana S. Roy writes in the International Herald Tribune. The lower house, “almost 90 percent male in its composition, had ensured that a bill intended to increase the number of female members would not be passed for at least another year,” she writes.

headline: Bachmann Stays in the Race
text: DES MOINES — Michele Bachmann declined to drop out of the Republican presidential contest despite having come in last in the Iowa caucus, receiving only about 5 percent of the vote.

headline: News Quiz | Jan. 4, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: 3 Arrested as Occupy Protesters March in Midtown
text: About 150 people associated with the Occupy Wall Street movement demonstrated on Tuesday at several Midtown locations, including Grand Central Terminal, where three people were arrested, the authorities said.

headline: Why Ice May Be Bad for Sore Muscles
text: Already, the benches in gym locker rooms and beside basketball courts are filling with 2012’s early casualties, those of us who, goaded by New Year’s resolutions, are exercising a bit too enthusiastically and developing sore muscles. Many of us will then drape ice packs over our aching muscles. But a new review article published this month in the journal Sports Medicine suggests that for sore muscles, ice is not always the panacea that most of us believe it to be and that, in some instances, it can be counterproductive.

headline: Real Estate Prices Are Steady in Manhattan, but Sales Fall
text: The Manhattan real estate market closed out 2011 with prices relatively flat, but sales volume for the fourth quarter was down by more than 12 percent from the previous year largely because of shrinking condominium inventory as fewer new developments came to market, according to reports that will be released by the city’s major brokerage firms on Wednesday.

headline: Word of the Day | regal
text: regal •\ˈre-gəl\• adjective

headline: Perry to Return to Texas to Assess Campaign
text: DES MOINES — Rick Perry said Tuesday night that he would return to Texas to “assess” whether there was a path for him to continue in the presidential campaign.

text: The candidate responds to his fourth place result in the Iowa caucuses. (Courtesy of NBC)

headline: Ron Paul | Iowa Caucus
text: The Republican candidate says the constitution is popular with voters in Iowa. (Courtesy of MSNBC).
