text: The candidate responds to her sixth place result in the Iowa caucuses. (Courtesy of NBC)

headline: Rick Perry | Iowa Caucus
text: The candidate decided to return to Texas to reassess his campaign. (Courtesy of MSNBC)

headline: A Conversation With: Air Pollution Expert Dr. Gunasekar
text: Dr. Arunachalam Gunasekar is a 30-year veteran of the Indian armed forces, where he was a public health professional and director of medical research. He joined the World Health Organization in 2008, where he currently specializes in environmental health issues including air pollution and associated health problems.

headline: Michigan Prevails in an Exciting Conclusion to an Uninspiring Game
text: NEW ORLEANS — Since the Bowl Championship Series went to its double-hosting format in 2006, the contest held before the national title game in the host city has been more relevant as a springboard to the next season.

headline: First Vote Reinforces G.O.P.’s Ideological Divide
text: DES MOINES — All year long the story of the Republican race for president was Mitt Romney and a rotating cast playing the role of Someone Else. On Tuesday night, Someone Else was played by two candidates: Rick Santorum, the longtime champion of social conservative issues that were supposedly taking a backseat in this jobs-centric presidential race, and Ron Paul, the noninterventionist Texan who represents an almost 180-degree turn from the Republican Party’s direction.

headline: NYT Front Page for 01/04/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 01/04/2012

headline: Rick Santorum | Iowa Caucus
text: The candidate speaks from the top of a race still too close to call. (Courtesy of MSNBC)

headline: In Praise of Iowa
text: It’s easy to complain about the Iowa caucuses – easy and completely justifiable. Iowa’s caucus-goers have given us the presidency of Jimmy Carter, lent credibility to Pat Robertson’s political ambitions and created a permanent constituency for ethanol subsidies among Democrats and Republicans alike. As friendly and civic-minded as Iowans may be, there’s no reason why a low-turnout contest in a small, rural state should play such an outsize role in every presidential nominating process.

headline: Donovan Returns for Everton
text: 3:35 p.m. | Updated Landon Donovan provided some wonderful highlights during his two-month, 13-game loan to Everton in 2010. Though credited with only two goals during his brief time with the Toffees, Donovan played extremely well: he injected speed on the wing, served up assists, took corner kicks and helped the squad earn victories over the likes of Manchester City, Manchester United and Chelsea. Named the club’s player of the month for January, he made a lasting impression with fans, teammates and Everton Manager David Moyes.

headline: Mitt Romney | Iowa Caucus
text: Romney speaks as he hangs on near the top of a close race.

headline: Tight Race Catches TV Anchors by Surprise
text: From their respective television studios in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday, the liberal MSNBC anchor Rachel Maddow and the conservative Fox News commentator Karl Rove looked to Iowa and saw the same thing: a Republican race that was “tight as a tick.”

headline: McCain Expected to Endorse Romney in New Hampshire
text: DES MOINES — Senator John McCain of Arizona is expected to endorse Mitt Romney on Wednesday in New Hampshire, giving the former Massachusetts governor a boost at a critical moment in the campaign.

headline: Jan. 4, 1965 | Lyndon Johnson Outlines ‘Great Society’ Plans
text: On Jan. 4, 1965, in his State of the Union address, President Lyndon B. Johnson outlined the goals of ”the Great Society,” a set of domestic programs designed to advance civil rights and aid those in poverty.

headline: ‘Today We Eat. Tomorrow We Don’t.’
text: WHO is president of the Democratic Republic of Congo?

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 4, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “Reframing the Debate Over Using Phones Behind the Wheel.”

headline: The Caucus | On to New Hampshire
text: Michael D. Shear reports from Des Moines on the virtual tie in Iowa between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum as the 2012 campaign moves to New Hampshire and South Carolina.

headline: Iconic Scenes, Revisited and Reimagined
text: An empty road during the Vietnam War. A hilltop landscape in Spain. A nondescript motel balcony in Memphis.

headline: The Other Reason Europe Is Going Broke
text: One great way to start a bar fight during an American Economic Association conference is to claim that the U.S. economy is preferable to Europe’s. Someone will undoubtedly start quarreling about how G.D.P. per capita doesn’t measure a person’s happiness. Someone else may point out that if you look at income inequality and entitlements, the average European is doing much better.

headline: Electoral Politics and Reality TV
text: Every election season, it starts earlier: a chorus of complaints about the election season having started earlier. The twist in the current version of the quadrennial exercise is the persistent meme that the Republican nomination process is mimicking the tropes of reality television. A notable guest on “The Tonight Show” alluded to this not long ago when asked about the primary drama: “I’m going to wait until everybody is voted off the island,” President Barack Obama demurred. “Once they narrow it down to one or two, I’ll start paying attention.”

headline: A Day With Stephen Colbert
text: Staff of 80, cast of one.

headline: How Many Stephen Colberts Are There?
text: There used to be just two Stephen Colberts, and they were hard enough to distinguish. The main difference was that one thought the other was an idiot. The idiot Colbert was the one who made a nice paycheck by appearing four times a week on “The Colbert Report” (pronounced in the French fashion, with both t’s silent), the extremely popular fake news show on Comedy Central. The other Colbert, the non-idiot, was the 47-year-old South Carolinian, a practicing Catholic, who lives with his wife and three children in suburban Montclair, N.J., where, according to one of his neighbors, he is “extremely normal.” One of the pleasures of attending a live taping of “The Colbert Report” is watching this Colbert transform himself into a Republican superhero.

headline: Do You Have a Signature Clothing Item?
text: While campaigning in Iowa, Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum started making a fashion statement by wearing V-neck sweater vests. Do you have a favorite fashion item or accessory that you wear or carry often? What do you think it says about you?

headline: Statistics That Drive Success in the Colonial
text: Field-goal percentage defense, assist-to-turnover ratio and rebounding margin:  a recent analysis on The Quad found that success in those three statistical categories to be most correlated with men’s college basketball teams reaching the Final Four. But are they also the best predictors for other levels of basketball success?

headline: With Unemployment Insurance, Is 99 Weeks the Magic Number?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Ennio Morricone’s Music Gets Comic Treatment in London
text: The wide appeal of the music of the Oscar-winning composer Ennio Morricone, who wrote for spaghetti western films such as “Fistful of Dollars,” Brian de Palma’s “The Untouchables” and hundreds of other films, is evidenced by the wide array of artists who pay homage to him. They range from the producer Danger Mouse, who with Daniele Luppi last year released an album influenced by Morricone, to Metallica, who contributed to a 2007 tribute album.

headline: Fighting on Many Fronts in Asian Foreign-Language Entries
text: 1:18 p.m. | Updated  One of the intriguing mysteries of the competition for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film is trying to figure out why certain groups of countries submit films that are so similar in subject matter. For example, this year, as in 2011, several European countries have chosen films about interactions between Europeans and immigrants from poor, ravaged nations seeking sanctuary in the West.

headline: When Mandela Goes
text: JOHANNESBURG — Last Friday, the holiday cheer of New Year celebrations was disrupted by news that Nelson Mandela had just been rushed to the hospital. A popular local D.J., Kaya FM’s Bob Mabena, saw a report on a local television news channel and tweeted about it, setting off a virtual panic.

headline: Jets Season, Foretold
text: It was Jets versus Dallas on a Sunday night at MetLife Stadium.

headline: In A Village, Private Schools Do More With Less
text: The phenomena of Indian parents sending their children to private school, no matter whether they are rich or poor, isn’t just happening in big cities. It has spread to towns and villages, as well.

headline: Reviewing What Worked and What Didn’t in 2011
text: The beginning of the year is a great time for reflection, revelation, resolution and even a little celebration. We did do some things right last year, and the results are starting to show. I also did some things wrong, which I intend to rectify in the near future. Move out of the way, 2011.

headline: Amid Dark Vents in the Depths, Something Stirs
text: Around 7,800 feet under the frigid Southern Ocean, the flash of a remotely operated underwater vehicle captured scenes from a distant undersea ecosystem. Slender chimneys belched plumes of boiling black smoke. A closer look at clusters of white pebbles revealed a writhing mass of countless yeti crabs — a new species. A pale, lone octopus skulked on the ocean floor.

headline: 2 Sentenced to Prison in Racial Killing That Scarred Britain
text: LONDON — More than 18 years late by the reckoning of the victim’s family and many others across Britain, a jury at the Old Bailey found two white men guilty of the racially motivated stabbing and murder of a black youth named Stephen Lawrence on a south London street in April 1993.

headline: Romney’s Ugly Win May Be a Charm
text: I don’t care if you call it a win or a tie. In Iowa on Tuesday, Mitt Romney had a performance that looks ugly on the stat sheet, but which accomplished quite a bit when you consider it in its broader context.

headline: Sex and Santorum
text: The race for the Republican presidential nomination has been an edifying spectacle. No, really: we are learning a lot of things that we might not have if it had been a simple Romney coronation. Until he rose in the polls, Ron Paul was seen by many liberals as an almost cuddly figure, a nice antiwar guy with some quirky ideas about gold; we’ve learned a bit since.

headline: Beautifying America
text: Andy Rosenthal, our editorial page editor, notes that Mitt Romney likes to quote from “America the Beautiful”, and tells us something I for one didn’t know:

headline: Image of the Day: January 4
text: Burning the Chinese flag in New Delhi.

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: How far can the Broncos and Bengals go in the playoffs? Just what is going on with the Colts and Bears? Can the jets be put back together again? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

headline: Santorum Celebrates Strong Finish in Iowa
text: JOHNSTON, Iowa — Rick Santorum often speaks in biblical terms, weaving references to God and Christian faith into his speeches on the campaign trail. Before a national audience on Tuesday night, he offered a glimpse of how large a theme religion will be in his quest for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: UniCredit Offering Weighs on Its Shares
text: The Italian bank UniCredit, which is seeking to raise capital to comply with new requirements, offered existing shareholders a significant discount on new stock on Wednesday, sending its shares tumbling.

headline: Despite Close Finish, No Recount in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — It was, perhaps, the closest finish ever between two candidates in a presidential caucus.

headline: Was Anna Hazare a Media-Created Farce?
text: “Last week in Mumbai, an old man accepted defeat,” Manu Joseph writes in the International Herald Tribune. What sounds like it might at first be an indictment of the Anna Hazare movement, though, is actually a dissection of the news media that transformed him into a movement.

headline: Five Things to Listen For in Cuomo Speech
text: When Governor Cuomo lays out his priorities on Wednesday in his state of the state address, listen to the details of his proposals for a new state education commission, financial incentives to schools, more state aid, mandate relief and his intentions when it comes to teacher evaluations.

headline: Both Sides Hang Tough on Teacher Evaluations
text: The city and the teachers union remain in a stalemate over a system to evaluate teachers in the city's struggling schools. While state officials say there's still time for them to reverse their decision, $60 million in federal aid to those schools remains on hold.

headline: Sights for Sore Eyes
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: For Wall Street Overseer, Progress Comes at a Crawl  |  Leading a new federal agency intended to help prevent another financial crisis may seem like a dream job for most economic gurus, but the government made a nomination only last month after a painfully slow search process.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Space Tourism Flights Departing Soon
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Iowa Under the Microscope and China vs. the West
text: Just when you thought the intense news analysis of the presidential choices of 120,000 Iowa Republicans couldn’t get any more granular, Tuesday night’s caucuses produced a result that, as news anchors are fond of saying, showed that “each vote counts.” It was thrilling stuff for the anchors, who enjoyed the tension, as Brian Stelter writes. “We have no idea when we’ll be able to call this,” Rachel Maddow said at 10 p.m. “It’s great.” The cable networks continued on toward 3 a.m. Eastern, after Mitt Romney was declared the winner by eight votes – though, helpfully, he was ahead by a 10th of a decimal point, 24.6 percent vs. 24.5 percent for Rick Santorum.

headline: U.S. Charges 3 Swiss Bank Employees With Aiding Tax Evasion
text: Wegelin & Company, the oldest Swiss bank, confirmed on Wednesday that three of its employees had been indicted by prosecutors in New York for helping United States taxpayers to hide more than $1.2 billion from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Iowa’s Split Decision
text: In this week’s Campaign Stops column, I argue that given the field they were presented with, Iowa’s caucus-goers produced what was arguably the best possible outcome:

headline: Yahoo’s Renovator in Chief
text: Yahoo has chosen its Mr. Fix-It.

headline: Good Year for Autos, but a Test Waits in ’12
text: DETROIT — American automakers last year posted their best sales since the financial crisis, earning healthy profits from better products amid a steady increase in demand for new cars.

headline: Three New Stars in 3-Point Land
text: The addition of a consistent 3-point shot is one of the great off-season glamor moves in the world of N.B.A. player development, akin to adding “15 pounds of muscle,” or a non-point guard claiming to have put in work on his ball-handling. But there’s good reason for teams and players to value the extension of range back to the 3-point arc; although the long ball is certainly chic, it’s also an incredibly efficient shot and a facilitator for an established halfcourt offense.

headline: McCain Backs Romney After Santorum’s Surge in Iowa
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Mitt Romney marked his arrival in New Hampshire on Wednesday with an endorsement by Senator John McCain, one of the state’s favorite adopted sons. The endorsement came a day after Mr. Romney won the Iowa caucuses by a mere eight votes and helped Mr. Romney consolidate his support among the Republican establishment.

headline: Seeking New York’s ‘Other’ Opera Company
text: By now enough people have gotten on enough soapboxes about New York City Opera’s sorry financial state. But while the company remains in limbo, its precarious situation should be a reminder to look at the bigger picture.

headline: Daily Report: Teachers Resist Rules on Classroom Tech
text: Matt Richtel writes in Wednesday’s New York Times about the conflict over Idaho’s plan to require students to take online courses and to issue them laptops or tablets. While teachers say they are in favor of using technology in the classroom, they would prefer to use it on their own terms, and they are skeptical of the educational value of online courses. They note that the state may have to shift money away from teacher salaries to pay for these programs.

headline: Roku Looks Beyond the Set-Top Box
text: “Set-top box” is one of those puzzling anachronisms, like “record industry,” that seems to persist for no clear reason. Perching a cable tuner, TiVo or Apple TV on top one of today’s slim television sets would require either amazing balancing skills, very strong adhesive or a bit of both.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Saveur: A sketch of the late days of the late, great James Beard, by Jane and Michael Stern. — Julia Moskin

headline: Leading Off: The Carousel Goes Off-Axis
text: For a few minutes on Tuesday, the N.F.L. coaching/front office carousel seemed to be rotating rather smoothly. The Chargers, the Eagles and the Bears had scheduled news conferences to deal with their supremely disappointing seasons. But that’s where the carousel turned into more of a Tilt-a-Whirl, and if you could follow the logic while your head made all those little circles, well, you’re stronger than the rest of us.

headline: Stranger Danger: Personal Finance Really Is Personal
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His new book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this week, and we’ll be running excerpts all week long. Meanwhile, his sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

headline: Bachmann Holds News Conference in Iowa
text: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota has scheduled a news conference for 11 a.m. Eastern time in West Des Moines, after her sixth-place finish in Iowa’s Republican caucuses on Tuesday. Mrs. Bachmann signaled that she would stay in the race after the vote last night; however, The Associated Press reported on Wednesday morning that she had canceledher planned campaign trip to South Carolina.

headline: Defying Republicans, Obama to Name Cordray as Consumer Agency Chief
text: 11:49 a.m. | Updated President Obama will challenge Republican foes of the newly created Consumer Financial Protection Bureau by naming Richard Cordray as its director while Congress is out of town.

headline: Dee Rees on 'Pariah'
text: Dee Rees, the writer and director of "Pariah," discusses her coming-out drama.

headline: After Iowa, Obama Campaign Sharpens 2 Negative Portrayals of Romney
text: WASHINGTON — Bolstered in their view of Mitt Romney as their likeliest opponent, President Obama’s campaign advisers gleefully skewered him on Wednesday as a “weak front-runner” in a narrowing Republican field and made clear they would cast him as out of touch with the concerns of middle-class Americans.

headline: Torre Resigns to Pursue Dodgers Deal
text: Having managed in Los Angeles, Joe Torre now wants to return to the Dodgers, but this time as part of an ownership group.

headline: 19 Web Sites for Travel Savings in 2012
text: HIGHER hotel prices, airline capacity cuts and rising travel demand mean travelers will have to work harder to find a good deal in 2012. But there are plenty of online tools to help keep your vacation expenses in check. Here are 19 go-to Web sites to help you save money this year.

headline: Culture and Control
text: Articles in this series are exploring the struggle to shape the culture of authoritarian China.

headline: The New Improved Heckling of Movies
text: Longtime readers already know that I’m a huge fan of Rifftrax.com. As I wrote last year:

headline: After Long Search, Philharmonic Names Top Executive
text: The New York Philharmonic named its new executive director on Wednesday. He is Matthew VanBesien, a 42-year-old former orchestral player who put away his French horn a decade ago and went on to run the Houston Symphony and then the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra in Australia.

headline: An Ode to Flying
text: The classic Japanese children’s song “Tako no uta” (or “Song of Kites”) is a cheerful ode to flying. It is also one of many Japanese cultural references embedded in “Sora and the Cloud,” Felicia Hoshino’s rich, clever and appealing book. Offering both English and Japanese text, it is itself a lovely tribute to the joys of soaring high.

headline: Introducing the Cuddly Michael Shannon
text: Did you watch the Iowa caucus results last night? Along with Mitt Romney, Rick Santorum and Ron Paul, the winners included Edith Pfeffer and Carolyn Tallet, Clinton County Republican officials who helped explain the vote in a live late-night phone call on CNN, becoming Twitter stars in the process.

headline: The New Goth Nail
text: Black nail polish is no longer just for angsty teenagers making their cosmetics purchases on late-night trips to Duane Reade. There has been a resurgence of the dark nail on the runways, including those of Cushnie et Ochs, Chanel and Rag & Bone, to name a few. And to disprove the idea that there can’t be more than one shade of black comes the Dickensian Volume, a set of 10 deceivingly dark and metallic shades by the indie nail polish line StrangeBeautiful. Its creator, the designer-turned-beauty-entrepreneur Jane Schub, drew inspiration from Charles Dickens and the Brothers Grimm. Wear a different polish on each nail for the full effect.

headline: The Iowa-Is-So-Important Phase Ends, the Iowa-Is-So-Over Phase Begins
text: DES MOINES—In 2008, the very conservative Evangelical Christians in Iowa muddled the Republican presidential nominating contest, giving their support to an unelectable candidate, Mike Huckabee, who won here over the person that Republicans were most likely to settle for in the end, John McCain. That meant the G.O.P. had to spend millions more dollars, run more nasty ads, and toss around more radical right-wing ideas before turning their attention to the general election.

headline: Caucus Video: On to New Hampshire
text: Michael D. Shear reports from Des Moines on the virtual tie in Iowa between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum as the 2012 campaign moves to New Hampshire and South Carolina.

headline: On Our Radar: Dredging the Gowanus Canal
text: The Environmental Protection Agency releases a study weighing technologies for cleaning up the Gowanus Canal, which was declared a Superfund site by the agency last year. [Environmental Protection Agency]

headline: Jackman to Try to Work His Box Office Magic as Houdini
text: Hugh Jackman, whose recent Broadway concert smashed several box office records, grossing $14.6 million in just 10 weeks, has committed to returning to Broadway in the 2013-14 season to star as the early-20th-century escape artist Harry Houdini in the long-gestating musical “Houdini,” the lead producers of the project announced on Wednesday.

headline: Myanmar’s First Girl Band Pushes Limits of Censors, and Parents
text: YANGON, Myanmar — With their sensual choreography and provocative outfits, the five members of Myanmar’s first girl band are pushing the limits of artistic acceptability in this socially conservative country.

headline: Bachmann Says She Will Not Continue in the Race
text: 12:12 p.m. | Updated WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — On the morning before Iowa’s first-in-the-nation caucuses, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota said she was counting on a “miracle” to resurrect her faltering campaign. On the morning after, she acknowledged that it was beyond saving.

headline: With New C.E.O., Yahoo Charts Independent Course
text: With the announcement of its new chief executive on Wednesday, Yahoo appears determined to chart its own course, rather than selling out.

headline: Making Texts More Graphic With Emoji
text: A few weeks back, a colleague, Jenna Wortham, wrote about the growing popularity of emoji, which are much more elaborate versions of emoticons.

headline: Indonesia Activists Call for Boy’s Release in Petty-Theft Case
text: JAKARTA — More flimsy, worn-out sandals piled up around Indonesia on Wednesday as part of a protest campaign against the trial of a 15-year-old boy a police officer has taken to court, accusing him of stealing his old footwear.

headline: Identity, Discovery and ‘Pariah’
text: While “Pariah” tells the coming-out story of a young African-American lesbian in Brooklyn, its director, Dee Rees, sought to make a film with broader themes. Ms. Rees, who received a Gotham Award this season for breakthrough director and a best director prize from the Black Film Critics Circle, sees her film as a story about identity and self-discovery. “Pariah,” which stars Adepero Oduye, was a breakout hit at Sundance last year and finally made it to theaters last month. Reviewing the film for The Times, Stephen Holden called it “an acutely observed examination of strait-laced parents trying to deny a child’s homosexuality while all the time knowing better.”

headline: Samurai Shopper | Pillow Talk
text: Winter white is always chic. With my off-white faux fur from Portobello Road, my ivory crepe de chine shirt from Gucci and Ann Demeulemeester’s rabbity-white leggings, the Michelin Man’s got nothing on me.

headline: Happier Staffers at Nonprofit Nursing Homes
text: Reading between the lines of a study published in The Gerontologist recently, I noticed another vote for nonprofit nursing homes.

headline: After South Boston, a Restaurant Was Easy
text: Emerging from the housing projects of South Boston where James Bulger, known as Whitey, once ruled, Barbara Lynch has become one of Boston’s most successful and celebrated restaurateurs.

headline: Negotiating My 13-Year-Old’s Social Life
text: Last week my almost-14-year-old son, Nathaniel, asked me if I would let him go to a New Year’s Eve party. Even though he had yet to be invited to one — plans were still taking shape — he was certain of one thing: He was too old and too cool to hang out at home with his mom, dad and grandma for dinner and a movie to ring in the new year.

headline: Audit Group Accepts Circulation Practice of The Journal in Europe
text: The British auditing group investigating a complex circulation practice at The Wall Street Journal Europe, which led to the resignation of the paper’s publisher in October, said Wednesday that the practice complied with its official newspaper circulation reporting standards.

headline: My Lipstick? It’s in Here Somewhere
text: FOR many of us, the new year brings with it a frenzy of resolutions to streamline and organize one’s life. Let’s not overlook the pocketbook. More specifically: the makeup in one’s pocketbook.

headline: Citing Drug Resistance, U.S. Restricts More Antibiotics for Livestock
text: WASHINGTON — Federal drug regulators announced on Wednesday that farmers and ranchers must restrict their use of a critical class of antibiotics in cattle, pigs, chickens and turkeys because such practices may have contributed to the growing threat in people of bacterial infections that are resistant to treatment.

headline: Feoktistov’s Journal: A Lot of Miles, and Another Tough Loss
text: We heard all about the tradition at Notre Dame and were glad to be playing the Fighting Irish, ranked third in the country. But we lost another close one Tuesday night, 2-1, our third in a row, and it feels like the others — we play hard but we play unlucky.

headline: Do You Own the Building?
text: We’ve just published an interview with Barbara Lynch, an extremely successful restaurateur in Boston who has one big regret about her business: She doesn’t own any of the real estate. “My advice would be, try to own the property,” Ms. Lynch told Glenn Rifkin. “I don’t care if it’s a garage but buy it because with me, nine restaurants later, I don’t own any of my buildings. I lease. I make developers pretty successful, but I’d rather own because when you leave, after 25 or 30 years, you don’t own anything except the equipment, which ages like a car or your body.”

headline: Beauty Spots
text: EYES WIDE OPEN A California plastic surgeon has combined blepharoplasty (eyelid surgery) and browpexy (brow lift) to create an “All-in-One Eye Lid and Brow” lift that he says is less invasive than many similar procedures. The new lift takes 30 minutes and requires two internal stitches and about five days of recuperation. The procedure costs approximately $4,500 and is available at the practice of Tancredi F. D’Amore, in Corte Madera, Calif. (damoreplasticsurgery.com).

headline: A New Year, a New Perspective
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — I don’t make specific New Year’s resolutions because I always have goals. Something that I began to think about as 2012 approached, though, is what my expectation is for the coming year. Then I read this quotation:

headline: Deflating Defeats in the Burswood Bubble
text: PERTH, Australia–Though sanctioned as the official mixed team championships of the International Tennis Federation, the annual Hyundai Hopman Cup in Perth is occasionally derisively referred to as an exhibition, the sort of low-stakes tennis crowd-pleaser oft-called a “hit-and-giggle.”

headline: Post Offices in Small Towns Fight for Survival
text: The residents of tiny towns across the country learned last summer that their post offices were being studied for possible closing by the United States Postal Service.

headline: A New Music Festival Downtown to Offer Fresh Sounds and Words
text: A music producer and a downtown theater said on Wednesday that they would establish a festival of new music-theater works next January called “Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now.” The festival will last two weeks and take place at the Here Arts Center in the South Village, in collaboration with Beth Morrison Projects, which produces musical events.

headline: A Fight for Post Offices and Towns’ Souls
text: FOX, Ark. — People over a certain age here remember what happened to Mozart.

headline: Libyan Leader Says Militia Clashes Could Create Civil War
text: After deadly clashes between rival fighters in Tripoli this week, Libya’s transitional government expressed growing concern that the country could descend into civil war if its militias were not brought under control.

headline: Los Angeles Arson Suspect Is Charged With 37 Counts
text: LOS ANGELES — The man suspected of setting more than 50 fires in the Los Angeles area was charged on Wednesday with dozens of counts of arson.

headline: Straight (and Gay) Talk From Simon Doonan
text: Simon Doonan, the creative ambassador at large for Barneys New York and the author of the new book “Gay Men Don’t Get Fat,” responds to reader questions about the dietary theories — serious and otherwise — that he expounds in his book and in an interview with The Times. Chiefly, he says the ideal diet is “bisexual,” mixing foods that he categorizes as straight or gay.

headline: New Limits on Commodity Trades Are Approved
text: 7:44 p.m. | Updated

headline: Cuomo Pushes Job Creation in 2012 Agenda
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, vowing to revive New York’s stagnant economy, on Wednesday unveiled more than a dozen initiatives aimed at creating jobs across the state, including building the nation’s largest convention center in Queens and offering $1 billion in incentives to lure companies to Buffalo.

headline: In Stanford Loss, Echoes of Elway
text: There are many ways to lose a football game, but you would be hard-pressed to find one as heart-wrenching as the way Stanford lost to Oklahoma State in the Fiesta Bowl on Monday night. The Cardinal did not trail until the final whistle, had six different 7-point leads in the game, had the ball for 70 percent of the clock and outgained the Cowboys by 178 total yards, including a 243-13 advantage on the ground. Yet still Stanford could not come away with the win.

headline: Boeing to Shut Wichita Plant, Citing Cuts at Pentagon
text: With the Pentagon pushing to cut costs, Boeing said on Wednesday that it would close its sprawling military airplane plant in Wichita, Kan., over the next two years and lay off many of the 2,160 workers.

headline: Will Amazon Offer Analytics as a Service?
text: Amazon.com, through its Web services business, stores vast amounts of data for companies worldwide. Does it want to start analyzing it too?

headline: A Protester, Along With Students, Returns to St. David's
text: Picketing resumed on Wednesday outside St. David's School after a judge refused to halt a demonstration by a neighbor that the school had sued for defamation.

headline: Sundance Offers a Web Afterlife for Its Alumni
text: WHAT happened was, Tom Noonan won at the Sundance Film Festival, and his movie disappeared.

headline: Americans Feeling More Financially Secure
text: At the end of last year, Americans said they were feeling more secure about their financial situation than they had in months — especially those under 30 and those who were more affluent.

headline: Assessment Complete — Perry to Stay in Race
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who said after the Iowa caucuses that he would return to Texas to “assess” whether there was a path for him to the Republican nomination, decided on Wednesday that there is a way forward.

headline: Man Is Sentenced for Raping Ex-Girlfriend and Then Framing Her
text: Updated 5:42 p.m. | The Queens private detective who raped his ex-girlfriend and then framed her for a series of fictional crimes was sentenced to the maximum of 32 years in prison on Wednesday, bringing to a close one of the most bizarre cases to grace a courtroom.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 4
text: The day in sports included Serena Williams injuring her left ankle at the Brisbane International, and the Water Polo by the Sea match between Australia and the United States.

headline: My Three Favorite Colbert Moments
text: In this week’s magazine, Charles McGrath writes about the many sides of Stephen Colbert. Here, his three favorite Colbert moments.

headline: Text: 2012 New York State of the State Address Text
text: The text of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s speech delivered on January 4, 2012 in Albany, N.Y.

headline: Video of Cuomo’s State of the State Address
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, New York’s 56th governor, delivered his second State of the State address on Wednesday at the Empire State Plaza convention center in Albany. Mr. Cuomo’s speech, which can be watched in the player above, focused on economic development issues, including the expansion of casino gambling, and on increased accountability for the state’s public school system.

headline: For McCain, a Choice Between Old Enemies
text: For Senator John McCain, the last Republican presidential nominee, choosing between former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts or Rick Santorum, a former Senate colleague, was a pick between old enemies.

headline: Plaque Honoring Michael Landon Is on a Highway to Huh?
text: Though it may lack the drama of a saloon fistfight or shootout on the Ponderosa ranch, the saga of a marker honoring the “Bonanza” star Michael Landon that was posted in Collingswood, N.J., has yielded differing accounts of what happened to it before it reached the office of a weekly newspaper there and, if nothing else, has revealed how strong sentiment for the actor still runs.

headline: Apocalypse Iowa
text: David Brooks: Gail, anybody can be a pundit when there’s some decisive thing to talk about, but when you’ve got a tie, that’s when we separate the pros from the amateurs. If a tie in a football or a baseball game is like kissing your sister, then a tie in an Iowa caucus would be like kissing Rick Santorum’s sister.

headline: TimesCast | January 4, 2012
text: The Republican presidential field narrows, and candidates head to New Hampshire | The historical precedents of a Republican insurgency.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: The Lowdown | Cody Critcheloe
text: Arguably the most wonderfully weird thing to come out of Kansas City in recent memory, Cody Critcheloe and SSION (pronounced “shun”), his band of merry eccentrics, have bounced back and forth across the country for more than a decade, releasing their own music, directing music videos for groups like the Gossip, Peaches and CSS, and making their mark at MoMA PS1, Deitch Projects and the Hole. Now Critcheloe has planted his feet firmly in New York City to, we assume, turn the art of the music video forever on its head.

headline: A Chicer, Cheaper New Outlook
text: ON New Year’s Eve, Andrew Peters, a public relations associate from Washington, was on the prowl for new eyeglasses, something to mix up his conservative day-to-day look. So a friend took him to Warby Parker, a pop-up store in SoHo where prescription glasses are priced mostly at $95, instead of several hundred dollars.

headline: Michele Bachmann Ends Campaign
text: After finishing in sixth place in the Iowa caucuses, presidential-hopeful Michele Bachmann ended her campaign.

headline: A Photographic Blast From the Past
text: In January 1972, the Environmental Protection Agency asked nearly 100 freelance photographers to roam the country in the pursuit of a single goal: documenting “the environmental happenings and non-happenings” of the decade. By 1977, the photographers had submitted more than 80,000 images for the project, known as Documerica. About one-quarter of the photographs were shown in public exhibitions but then filed away and largely forgotten.

headline: Comcast’s 10-Year Deal With Disney Includes Out-of-Home Viewing
text: 1/5/12 | Updated In a deal that represents billions of dollars in revenue for the Walt Disney Company, the entertainment giant and Comcast said Wednesday that they had reached a decade-long distribution agreement covering all of Disney’s television content, including streaming for iPads and other devices.

headline: Tortorella Fined for Winter Classic Comments
text: 8:30 p.m. | Update Tortorella was fined $30,000 by the N.H.L., according to a league official.

headline: Insider Trading Accusations Are Reported Against Swiss Bank’s Chairman
text: FRANKFURT — Philipp M. Hildebrand, chairman of Switzerland’s central bank and a well-known architect of tougher global banking regulations, came under pressure Wednesday after a Swiss publication reported that he profited from currency trades made before and after he oversaw steps to prevent the Swiss franc from becoming too strong.

headline: Auditor Clears The Journal Of Improprieties in Europe
text: The British auditor for newspaper sales said on Wednesday that an unusual distribution arrangement operated by The Wall Street Journal Europe appeared to comply with its reporting standards, saying an investigation had turned up “no clear evidence” of violations.

headline: ‘Celebrity Apprentice’ Goes Higher Profile as NBC Bets Heavy on Reality TV
text: Looking to keep a veteran reality format alive, NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” announced a cast for the coming series that is heavier on familiar faces than in recent seasons — as well as funny ones.

headline: DLA Piper Hires 5 Energy Lawyers From Hogan Lovells
text: Big news in Big Law: Five partners at Hogan Lovells have announced that they are leaving the firm to join DLA Piper.

headline: Hockney Tweaks Hirst Over Authorship of Art
text: The art world has generally come to accept that some pieces are produced by people who work for the artists they are attributed to, rather than the artists themselves. Not David Hockney. Posters for his upcoming exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London include an apparent dig at the artist Damien Hirst, The Guardian reported on Monday, in the form of a note that reads, “All the works here were made by the artist himself, personally.”

headline: Yahoo’s Gain Is eBay’s Loss
text: When Yahoo poached PayPal’s president, Scott Thompson, as its new chief executive this morning, it represented a huge loss for eBay.

headline: Former M.T.A. Chief Recounts His Ups and the System’s Downs
text: Not much has been heard from Jay H. Walder, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, since he resigned abruptly last year to take over the sleek and generously financed rail system of Hong Kong.

headline: Amazon to Publish Novel by James Franco
text: James Franco, the laconic actor who collects M.F.A.’s when he isn’t starring in movies or hosting the Oscars, will publish his first novel in 2013. “Actors Anonymous,” a follow-up to “Palo Alto,” a book of short stories that was released in 2010, was acquired by Amazon Publishing New York, the company said on Wednesday. Ed Park, the senior editor who acquired the book, called it “a hugely ambitious and wild ride.”

headline: Bucking Senate, Obama Appoints Consumer Chief
text: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio — President Obama touched off a fierce election-year confrontation with Congressional Republicans on Wednesday, defying their deep opposition to appoint Richard Cordray as director of a new consumer protection agency and fill three labor board vacancies.

headline: Margaret Court Defends Her Views on Gay Marriage
text: PERTH, Australia — After receiving a great deal of criticism for her opinions about gays and lesbians, Margaret Court affirmed her opposition to gay marriage in an interview Tuesday, but said that her views did not reflect hatred.

headline: Bryant’s Ailing Wrist Forces Adjustments
text: Kobe Bryant, the Lakers’ star guard, is making some subtle changes to his shot to help his ailing right wrist. Bryant has been playing through the injury, which has been an issue since he tore a ligament Dec. 19 in a fall in an exhibition game against the Clippers. The injury did not seem significant at the time, but it has recently caused Bryant to curtail the follow-through on his shot.

headline: Adele Finishes 2011 at Top of Charts
text: Adele, the British retro-soul singer who dominated music in 2011, rounded out her exceptional year in a truly appropriate way: at the top of the charts.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 5
text: Scuba influenced dresses, a Proenza Schouler bag, and the Stella McCartney store relocates to Soho.

headline: Making the Invisible Visible: Exploring and Addressing Water Pollution
text: Overview | What is bioluminescence, and what function does it play in living organisms? How have researchers harnessed bioluminescence in studies of toxicity and pollution? In this lesson, students explore deep-sea bioluminescence, learn how scientists use this property to identify contaminants in water and participate in a forum on water pollution.

headline: Tip for London Police Officers: Booze and Secrets Don’t Mix
text: LONDON — Do not indulge in “late-night carousing” with journalists. Do not flirt with them, either. And above all, advised a report released here on Wednesday, if you are a police officer, do not let a member of the news media ply you with alcohol in an effort to get you to “drop your defenses” and start saying things you should keep to yourself.

headline: Building a ‘Knowosphere,’ One Cable and Campus at a Time
text: As I wrote over the weekend, the transition to a new year has provided a valuable moment to review goals for this blog and, more generally, assess prospects that the human condition (including the quality of our relationship with our environment) will be improved by the planet’s fast-spreading web of communication tools. I looked at blogging on Dec. 30.

headline: Chrissie Miller, Popular and Still Ready to Hang Out
text: “I THINK I’m a hang-out-aholic,” Chrissie Miller said before emitting her high-pitched laugh, a combination of nasal Upper East Side-ese with the rasp of a born-and-bred New Yorker who has done her fair share of smoking and partying.

headline: Raid on Rivals in South Sudan Shows Escalating Violence
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — About one week ago, an enormous column of 8,000 armed youths was advancing through the bush in South Sudan, bent on revenge. United Nations aircraft had been steadily tracking its movements and relaying information back to the head office in Juba, South Sudan’s capital. Several hundred peacekeepers and government soldiers were rushed into place, but the authorities knew they were far outnumbered, and so they told residents to flee.

headline: 2 British Contractors Are Held On Weapons Charges in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two British citizens detained by the police in Kabul and accused of carrying an arsenal of 30 unlicensed AK-47 assault rifles in their sport utility vehicle were private security contractors, officials in Afghanistan said Wednesday.

headline: New York Daily News Picks as Editor Colin Myler, Formerly of News of the World
text: The Daily News of New York on Wednesday appointedColin Myler, a former editor of the recently closed News of the World tabloid in London, its editor in chief.

headline: Prosecutor Accuses Security Forces of Interfering in Mubarak Trial
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian prosecutor in the trial of former President Hosni Mubarak said Wednesday that the military-led government’s security forces had obstructed his case, suggesting that the nation’s law enforcement officials were not all committed to a vigorous prosecution of their former boss.

headline: No Charges Expected in Staten Island Girl’s Suicide
text: The police said Wednesday that “no criminality is suspected” in the case of the 15-year-old Staten Island girl who died Monday after jumping in front of a city bus, and whose uncle alleged that bullying at school was partly to blame.

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: This country, which is No. 7 on our list of 45 places to go in 2012, is coming into its own as an upscale safari destination. Guess where this is in the comments below.

headline: ‘Relatively Speaking’ to Close at the End of the Month
text: “Relatively Speaking,” a triple bill of short comedies that marked Woody Allen’s return to Broadway as a playwright after 30 years, will close on Jan. 29 after a total of 153 performances, the show’s producers announced in a statement on Wednesday. A spokesman for the producers said that they expected to recoup their full investment by the time the show closes; the producers declined to provide that dollar amount.

headline: Republican Race Moves Beyond Iowa
text: DES MOINES — After a weeks-long battle over the allegiance of Iowa caucusgoers, the race for the Republican nomination broke open into a wider contest on Wednesday, as the remaining candidates moved to exploit a still-unsettled electorate and expanded playing field in New Hampshire and South Carolina.

headline: Remembering Michael Dummett
text: Sir Michael Dummett, one of the most influential philosophers of the 20th century, died last week in Oxford, England. He held the position of Wykeham Professor of Logic at Oxford University from 1979 until his retirement in 1992. Below is a gathering of reminiscences from fellow philosophers, including Hilary Putnam, Timothy Williamson, Dorothy Edgington, Daniel Isaacson, and several others who knew Dummett, worked with him or were influenced by his life and work. We invite readers to offer their own contributions in the comments section.

headline: The Competitive Vegan Bodybuilder
text: Jimi Sitko is a competitive vegan bodybuilder that has forged a distinctive, small subculture of anti-beefcake beefcakes who hope to change more of their competitors' eating habits.

headline: Cell Carriers Show Little Interest in C.E.S.
text: Wireless carriers will have a lower profile than in previous years at next week’s Consumer Electronics Show, one of the largest technology conventions in the world.

headline: Sculptured by Weights and a Strict Vegan Diet
text: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — Jimi Sitko gets up at 4 most mornings, works out two to four hours a day and can bench-press nearly twice his weight. He has a shaved head and a brightly colored tattoo on his left arm, and he can easily be mistaken for a Marine separated from his platoon.

headline: Pro-Gingrich Group Posts Anti-Romney Ad, Featuring McCain
text: MANCHESTER N.H. — On the day Mitt Romney rolled out the endorsement of Senator John McCain of Arizona, a “super PAC” backing Newt Gingrich dug out an old gem and put in on the Web.

headline: ‘Butter’ Loses its Republican Primary Connection
text: LOS ANGELES— So Michele Bachmann is out of the presidential race. And that means a movie with partisan potential, “Butter,” set for release by the Weinstein Company on March 16, will have to trade more on Hugh Jackman’s smile and Olivia Wilde’s good looks than on Jennifer Garner’s parody of a seemingly Bachmann-like character who is caught up in the overheated world of Iowa politics and butter sculpting.

headline: And Now, the Oil Industry Caucus
text: North America could be self-sufficient in gasoline and diesel fuel in 15 years if only the government would get out of the way, the president of the American Petroleum Institute said on Wednesday in a “state of American energy” address intended to raise the industry’s profile in the presidential election.

headline: Poisonous Herb Spices Cat Stew in Felonious Pot
text: SHANGHAI — There was one very disagreeable ingredient in the steaming hot pot of stew that may have killed a Chinese tycoon. And it was not the cat meat.

headline: Cuomo Calls for Education Commission, But Is Vague on Details
text: In a speech that only touched on educational matters -- and when it did was very short on details -- Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo did not say whom he would appoint to a new bipartisan education commission, or whether he would look to outside education groups rather than state agencies. But he did say that commission members would be jointly appointed by himself and the Legislature.

headline: M.I.T. Professor: High Weight and Horsepower Nullify Gains in Efficiency
text: That cars have put on weight and added horsepower should be no great surprise to even casual observers of the auto industry. But a report by an economics professor at M.I.T. tries to quantify to what degree vehicle bloat has impacted the fuel economy that might have been.

headline: Knitty Gritty
text: Chunky, cabled, cropped — wool is popping up in everyone’s wardrobes this season. (Chalk it up to all those knitting clubs and yarn-bombers.) But who would expect to check into a hotel room and find the sheets, the bedside lamp and even the morning breakfast knitted?

headline: Quinn Stands Behind Decision on Seabrook Funds
text: Updated, 5:23 p.m. | A slightly testy City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn on Wednesday defended her decision not to strip Councilman Larry Seabrook of control over more than $350,000 in discretionary funds in the coming budget cycle, even as he awaits a second trial on corruption charges related to his use of such funds.

headline: A New Sign, and a Liquor Store Becomes a Wine Shop
text: The sign is now of the times.

headline: New York’s ‘Other’ Opera Companies
text: With New York City Opera facing financial difficulties, other companies will have to fill the void left by the dominant Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Falcons’ Clabo Laughs Off Jab from Tuck
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — After the crowd of reporters disbanded from in front of his locker here Wednesday, Tyson Clabo, the Atlanta Falcons offensive tackle, said he wished he could have been more creative with his answer to the controversy of the day, but that he did not have time.

headline: Too Much ‘Self-Reliance’?
text: Today, writer Benjamin Anastas went on NPR’s “On Point” to discuss his Riff for the magazine, “The Foul Reign of Emerson’s ‘Self-Reliance'” with Tom Ashbrook. You can listen to Anastas explain his piece and fend off Emerson acolytes here.

headline: The Fed’s Advice on the Housing Crisis
text: The Federal Reserve tried Wednesday to stir interest among policy makers in the problems afflicting the housing market, sending a white paper to Congress outlining suggestions for easing those problems.

headline: Near Toulouse, a Restored House Hides in Plain Sight
text: A property with a swimming pool, a movie theater and spalike baths, behind an original workaday exterior.

headline: House Hunting in ... Southwestern France
text: A RESTORED MEDIEVAL HOUSE WITH SIX BEDROOMS IN SOUTHERN FRANCE

headline: For Univision, the Holidays Bring Viewers
text: What happens when the broadcast networks decide to scale down their programming for a week because of the holidays? They lose viewers to Univision.

headline: Team Draws Criticism From Past and Present Jets
text: In separate radio interviews Wednesday, Jets quarterbacks past and present unloaded on the team for fostering a culture of dysfunction and selfishness. And neither of them was Joe Namath.

headline: New Programming, Same Old Results as CBS Reigns
text: With the return of new programming CBS resumed its usual Tuesday-night perch as the No. 1 network in total viewers and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. “NCIS” led the way as it broke the 20-million total viewer barrier while “NCIS: Los Angeles” had its largest audience of the season with 17 million.

headline: Stumbling Through an American Muslim Maze
text: What a pleasure to encounter a first novel as self-assured and effortlessly told as Ayad Akhtar’s “American Dervish.” Mr. Akhtar, a first-generation Pakistani-American, has written an immensely entertaining coming-of-age story set during the early 1980s among the Pakistanis in the author’s hometown, Milwaukee.

headline: Obama Tempts Fight Over Recess Appointments
text: 5:41 p.m. | Updated  President Obama’s decision on Wednesday to grant recess appointments to four officials — even though the Senate contends that it is not in recess — was an unprecedented legal step that brought into sharper focus a recent bipartisan struggle over presidential power.

headline: Teaching Children to Love Healthy Food
text: Chicken fingers. No one — no chef and no parent — wants to raise a child who eats only chicken fingers. Or only white bread, or pasta-with-butter-and-nothing-else. The question of how to raise that highly desirable child who eats everything is one many first-time parents grapple with, and Fanae Aaron, an author and art director, was one such parent. Unlike most of us, though, who approach the process through trial and error, asking around the playground and either embracing or completely rejecting the foods we grew up with, Ms. Aaron set out to ask chefs how they fed their kids (who, she rightly presumed, mostly ate more than just white food).

headline: Romney on Jobs
text: Greg Sargent has been demanding that Mitt Romney be held accountable for two claims that he makes about jobs: (1) That Obama has been a job-destroyer (2) that he, Romney, created 100,000 jobs at Bain.

headline: Europe Takes Bold Step Toward a Ban on Iranian Oil
text: PARIS — Iran on Thursday sought to downplay the importance of intensified economic sanctions against it, even as European Union countries moved closer to agreement on an embargo on Iranian oil, their boldest step so far in the increasingly tense standoff with Iran over its nuclear program.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iowa and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iowa, New Hampshire, Bahrain and Egypt.

headline: On the Oscar Shortlist for Visual Effects
text: The Academy winnowed the number of contenders for best visual effects today. On the shortlist are:

headline: California Urges Drivers to Change the Oil Less Often
text: A California agency is campaigning to get car owners to change their motor oil at a longer interval, claiming that the time-honored practice of switching the oil every 3,000 miles is financially wasteful, detrimental to the environment and unwarranted.

headline: German President Rejects Calls to Quit in Scandal
text: BERLIN — President Christian Wulff of Germany fought back on Wednesday against a barrage of criticism over his handling of a private loan scandal, insisting in a nationally broadcast interview that he would not consider stepping down while admitting that he had made a “grave mistake.”

headline: British Seek Data on Suspect Breast Implants
text: With the British government under increasing pressure to follow the French health authorities’ recommendation to remove breast implants made with low-grade silicone, Health Secretary Andrew Lansley ordered British clinics on Wednesday to quickly report how many of the implants have ruptured or oozed.

headline: The Nonsense Problem
text: Brad DeLong does a lot of work meeting a challenge from Kantoos, who insists that neither Brad or I have done justice to John Cochrane’s arguments. And what Brad finds is … nothing that makes a bit of sense.

headline: Golden Globes Alert: Seeking the Next Young Actress to Reign
text: During this year’s Hollywood awards season, the fashion world will be scouting for the next ingénue to soar to its upper ranks.

headline: The Perilous Art of Giving Books
text: Long ago, The Onion ran the mock-headline: “Book Given As Gift Actually Read.” More recently, the Tumblr site The Books They Gave Me has collected autobiographical reminiscences that illustrate the sometimes perilous task of finding the right book for the right reader. But what about book-giving as a theme in literature itself? The Times ran a feature last month itemizing the books “authors love to give and receive,” but the examples below suggest that some writers have taken a dim view of book-giving in their own work:

headline: Seeking the Next Red Carpet Knockout
text: AT last year’s Golden Globes ceremony, when Hailee Steinfeld, then 14 and a star of “True Grit,” traipsed down the red carpet in a cream-colored Prabal Gurung gown that artfully toed the line between age-appropriate and demurely chic, she went from plucky Hollywood newcomer to fashion It Girl in about a nanosecond.

headline: TimesCast: Heading to New Hampshire, and a Look Back
text: Richard W. Stevenson, The Times’s political editor, looks at the narrowing Republican presidential field as the candidates head to New Hampshire. Sam Tannenhaus, editor of the Book Review, examines the historical precedents of a Republican insurgency.

headline: The Last of Last Year’s Food Links
text: Meat consumption is on the decline and expected to decline further in 2012. Meanwhile, even U.S. News & World Report is recognizing “The Mainstreaming of Vegan Diets.”

headline: Resolution: Better Personal (and Financial) Organization
text: This week on Bucks, the whole Your Money gang is laying out their financial resolutions for 2012. On Tuesday, Ann Carrns wrote about the paper savings bonds in her closet. I’ve got two things on my mind.

headline: Barnes & Noble Said to Put Publishing House Up for Sale
text: Barnes & Noble has put Sterling Publishing up for sale, nearly a decade after it bought the publishing house, a person briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: ‘Much Ado About Methane’
text: David Archer, the author of “The Long Thaw” and a Realclimate.org contributor, has weighed in at length on questions and assertions about the greenhouse risk posed by methane released from warming Arctic seabeds and tundra.

headline: The Buzz

headline: Boîte: Red Egg
text: CHINATOWN restaurants that moonlight as night spots have become kitschy refuges on the downtown fashion circuit. One of the few to approach quasi-permanence is Red Egg, where a lively dance party replaces fish balls and duck mei fun several evenings a week. The soirees started during Fashion Week in September, replacing the flash-in-the-pan Madame Wong, and continue to steam up the dumpling house this winter.

headline: Comparing Economic Mobility

headline: For the Hawks, It’s a Marvin Williams Moment
text: Seven years ago, a bad decision by then Hawks general manager Billy Knight consigned Marvin Williams to a career of unfair comparisons. Despite the fact that Williams had only played one unremarkable year of college ball, Knight passed on the highly touted Deron Williams and Chris Paul to make Williams, a sixth man and combo forward out of North Carolina, the No. 2 overall pick in the 2005 draft.

headline: Homes for $998,000

headline: What You Get for ... $998,000

headline: A Newcomer Is Showing Her Comfort Among Stars
text: The second act of “Stick Fly,” Lydia R. Diamond’s meaty soap opera about an affluent black family, begins with its youngest character, 18-year-old Cheryl, the daughter of the family’s maid, on the phone in the family’s well-appointed kitchen. She’s getting bad news from her mother. Life-changing bad news.

headline: Michigan Has Its Say
text: Jonathan Mahler’s article on Benton Harbor, Mich., prompted responses from all over the world. Not surprisingly, a disproportionate number of respondents hailed from Michigan.

headline: In Iowa, the Drama Behind the Drama

headline: In Iowa, the Drama Behind the Drama

headline: Fox News Leads in Iowa Ratings; CNN, in Second, Has Big Falloff
text: The cable news networks finished in slightly scrambled positions in the ratings for coverage of the Iowa caucuses Tuesday night, with the perennial leader, Fox News, in first, CNN in second, and MSNBC in third. Typically, MSNBC is second and CNN is third.

headline: The New Adventures of Tim
text: It was Landon Donovan’s 2012 debut (on a short-term loan) in the English Premier League Wednesday, but it was Everton’s other American — goalkeeper Tim Howard — who made a huge impression when he became the fourth goalkeeper in E.P.L. history to score a goal.

headline: Adviser Accused of Using LinkedIn to Promote Bogus Deals
text: LinkedIn is best known as a social networking hub, where people can locate and research just about anyone.

headline: When an Actress Prepares (No Eye Contact, Please)

headline: Today’s Wearable Computers Help You Sleep, Not Tweet
text: I recently wrote a column about wearable computing, in which I discussed a future in which people will eventually wear glasses and contact lenses with built-in screens, delivering content we can use. It will be like having smartphones in our eyes, but much smarter ones.

headline: A New Diversity Monitor for the S.E.C.
text: 8:52 a.m. | Updated

headline: Some Countries Are More Social Than Others, Survey Finds
text: In the big cities of India and China, it seems, people can’t help being social. Nearly everyone who uses the Internet there is also active on social networks, according to a vast global survey by Forrester Research, and most of them do much more than read and watch what’s posted online. Three out of four of them write blog posts or upload pictures and music.

headline: Pushing New Boundaries

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Walmart Acquisition and African Song-Swapping

headline: Karzai Gives a Lukewarm Welcome to Taliban Talks

headline: Scenes From a Career

headline: Eyeing Santorum’s Possible Base in New Hampshire
text: While Rick Santorum received strong support from evangelical Christians and voters who described themselves as very conservative in the Iowa caucuses, he most likely won’t be able to count on that deep of a base in New Hampshire.

headline: Tortorella Apologizes; League Issues Fine

headline: Mr. Zeitgeist
text: ON a rainy Thursday last month, Tyler Brûlé huddled over a cappuccino at Le Pain Quotidien in Greenwich Village, offering a peek at the future: a Heritage G2 tabletop radio designed for Monocle 24, a new radio station he is starting.

headline: Sales at Calypso, Crate & Barrel and Others
text: Many pieces of furniture are up to 40 percent off at Crate & Barrel, through Sunday (the Saija chair in Marimekko Spinning fabric, regularly about $1,000, is about $500); (800) 967-6696, crateandbarrel.com.

headline: Real Connections in Game Land
text: I used to talk to Natasha on the phone.

headline: Presenting Sacred Works in a Style From the 1600s
text: The soprano Jolle Greenleaf and the violinist Scott Metcalfe may not have fully realized that they were on to something big when they started the Green Mountain Project, an outgrowth of Ms. Greenleaf’s superb vocal ensemble, Tenet. The idea was to assemble the proper forces for Monteverdi’s Vespers of the Blessed Virgin — a collection of sacred works published in 1610 — and to ring in 2010 with a performance celebrating the 400th anniversary of the work. The concert proved a resounding success, and Ms. Greenleaf (the group’s artistic director) and Mr. Metcalfe (its music director) reconvened their forces at the start of 2011 and attracted a huge audience.

headline: Bachmann’s Next Decision: Whether to Run for Re-election
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Having only decided not to continue her presidential bid on Wednesday morning, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota has yet to decide whether to run for re-election to Congress.

headline: At Hotel The Exchange in Amsterdam, Fashion Checks In
text: The United States has Alex Calderwood, the risk-taking owner of the Ace Hotel chain with its street art aesthetic, but the Netherlands has Suzanne Oxenaar and Otto Nan. The enterprising art-world duo opened their first hotel, The Lloyd, in Amsterdam in 2004, and it quickly became the go-to place for artists, musicians and designers. In 2010, they opened the pop-up Llove Hotel in Tokyo, a tongue-in-cheek twist on that city’s pay-by-the-hour hotels.

headline: Cleaning That Dryer Vent
text: It’s the holy grail of New York apartment living: your own washer-dryer. But along with the convenience comes the job of keeping the dryer vent clean, a chore that, for apartment and single-home dwellers, might be a good candidate for that 2012 to-do list.

headline: With a Wave in Mind Comes a Table
text: The Wave Dining Table, by Salih Teskeredzic, a Bosnian furniture designer, was inspired by the Neretva River, which overflowed during a storm in the autumn of 2010. “The waves that day gave me the idea of the wave, the shape of it,” said Mr. Teskeredzic, 49.

headline: Décor NYC, a Consignment Store With Class
text: Another consignment store, Décor NYC, has just opened in New York, with 6,000 square feet of space for furniture and decorative accessories from consumers, decorators and designer showrooms.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. My apartment doesn’t get much natural light. What can I do to improve the way it looks to buyers?

headline: Who Had Diamond King? Declarer Didn’t Care
text: The Swiss Teams event that was held on Dec. 30, the final day of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan, was won by Sylvia Moss, Migry Zur-Campanile-Albu and Pietro Campanile of New York City, and Alex Ornstein of Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

headline: A Pantone Executive on Changing the Country’s Tone
text: For the last 12 years, Leatrice Eiseman, executive director of the Pantone Color Institute, author and the owner of a color consulting company, has headed the committee that chooses Pantone’s color of the year, in an effort, she says, to distill the prevailing mood into a single hue.

headline: A Cold Lesson in Fire Safety
text: THE Christmas Day fire that killed five people, including three children, in Stamford, Conn., has sent many homeowners scrambling to check their own safety equipment.

headline: 10 Questions for the Dean of Admissions of the University of Pennsylvania
text: In spring 2009, The New York Times started a blog called The Choice to demystify the process of applying to American colleges and universities, and paying for it. The blog has since offered countless tips and reams of news on all aspects of the American college admissions process to an audience of students and their families, as well as to their counselors and to college admissions officers themselves.

headline: A Home for a Designer Eager to Renovate
text: Rolf Bruggink, a Dutch designer, calls his crumbling town house in Rotterdam the Black Pearl, after the black-painted brick facade.

headline: In Rotterdam, a Town House Reborn
text: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands

headline: The Pirates of the East End
text: A COMBINATION of luck and astoundingly cheap credit several years back put me in possession of a house in East Hampton, N.Y. My downfall had to do with the manly art of maintenance. Shortly after my Hamptons dream house was completed, the ducts that carry exhaust outside from the basement dryer fell to the floor, spewing dust and lint.

headline: A Leader in Iowa, Santorum Still Has Trouble Online
text: 3:14 p.m. | Updated Coming within eight votes of victory in the Iowa caucus has brought new respect to Rick Santorum from the news media, and even prospective voters. Just not yet from the Google search engine, or Bing or Yahoo, for that matter.

headline: For G.O.P., One Party but Three Platforms

headline: Gene Bartow, Successor to John Wooden at U.C.L.A., Dies at 81
text: Gene Bartow, who succeeded the legendary John Wooden as coach of the U.C.L.A. basketball team and who coached five other college teams over a 34-year period, died on Tuesday at his home in Birmingham, Ala. He was 81.

headline: If Only the Beer Grew, Too
text: THE folks at Hammacher Schlemmer have always been expert salespeople, convincing legions of Americans that they need all sorts of products to solve problems they didn’t know they had. (If your dog could talk, surely it would tell you it wants you to order that $150 heated car seat for pets.)

headline: Relax. There’s Plenty of Room.
text: TEXANS aren’t known for understatement, so when Mark Williamson starts describing his couch (“We call it ‘Texas depth’ ”), it’s a good bet he’s not talking about a love seat.

headline: Ties to China Linger as Issue as Taiwanese Prepare to Vote
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As he nears the end of his first term, President Ma Ying-jeou faces a litany of challenges that might sound familiar to Western politicians: stagnant wages, a growing wealth gap and steep housing prices that have frozen young urbanites out of the real estate market.

headline: Meredith Buys FamilyFun Magazine From Disney
text: The Meredith Corporation has agreed to purchase FamilyFun magazine from Disney Publishing Worldwide, adding another title aimed at mothers to its portfolio of magazines, which include American Baby, Parents and Family Circle.

headline: Taiwan's Noisy Presidential Elections
text: On January 14th, Taiwan heads to the polls. During the campaign, piggy banks have become a symbol of opposition to incumbent President Ma Ying-jeou.

headline: The Giants’ Secondary Is Burned No More
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The words used to accurately describe the Giants’ secondary this season have not been flattering: burned, scorched and barbecued, in addition to confused, struggling and lost.

headline: Civilians Killed in War

headline: Texas: Student With Pellet Gun Is Killed by Police
text: A 15-year-old student at a Brownsville middle school was shot and killed by police officers on Wednesday after he displayed a gun in the school’s main hallway, the authorities said. The weapon was later identified as an air-powered .177-caliber pellet gun. The eighth grader, Jaime Gonzalez, had brandished the weapon in the hallway at Cummings Middle School, after most students were already in their classrooms. The student pointed the gun at Brownsville police officers who came to the scene, and he ignored numerous commands to drop it, police officials said. Two officers fired their weapons, and the student was shot twice. Police officials said he had assaulted a student before the officers arrived and told witnesses that he was going to confront the officers with the weapon.

headline: Back to School, and Debt
text: To the Editor:

headline: California: Bishop Who Fathered 2 Children Resigns
text: A Roman Catholic bishop in Los Angeles has resigned after the revelation that he has two adult children. Gabino Zavala, an auxiliary bishop in the Los Angeles Archdiocese, submitted his resignation to the pope, which was accepted, according to a letter sent out Wednesday by the archbishop of Los Angeles, Jose H. Gomez. Bishop Zavala will cease taking part in the ministry. The letter stated that the two children, whose identities have not been made public, live with their mother in another state. The archdiocese has offered to help finance the children’s college costs. Roman Catholic priests are required to remain celibate.

headline: F.D.A. Orders Surgical Mesh Makers to Study Risks
text: The Food and Drug Administration issued an order on Wednesday requiring makers of implantable surgical mesh used to treat urinary incontinence in women to study its risks.

headline: Falcons Still Pursuing Elusive Playoff Victory
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — The Atlanta Falcons are caught between floors, between smooth and wrinkled, between coming or going. They are considered solid, often better than that, but no one is going to give the Falcons their due until solid turns into something substantial, like a playoff win or two.

headline: Louisiana: Payments for Gulf Spill Resume
text: Kenneth R. Feinberg, administrator of the $20 billion fund created to pay damages from the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, has reopened the cash window. Mr. Feinberg halted payments on Tuesday while seeking clarification from the federal judge overseeing litigation related to the disaster. Judge Carl J. Barbier recently ruled that 6 percent of settlements after Nov. 7 be put in escrow for certain plaintiff litigation expenses. On Wednesday, he issued a ruling stating that the payment only applies to new settlements, and that the 6 percent will be calculated from the net amount of the settlement after withholding for liens and other obligations, not from the gross amount.

headline: Work as Usual for U.S. Warship After Warning by Iran
text: ABOARD U.S.S. JOHN C. STENNIS, in the North Arabian Sea — If Iran’s warning on Tuesday to this American aircraft carrier was intended to disrupt the ship’s routine or provoke a high-seas reaction, nothing of the sort was evident on Wednesday.

headline: MDC Partners Picks Up RJ Palmer
text: RJ PALMER, a leading independent media agency, is being acquired by MDC Partners in a deal that underscores the growing importance to marketers of media services in a digital age.

headline: Candidates Who Do Better Than Expected Win More Media Attention

headline: Retired, but Overcoming Her Pain to Help Disabled Children Ride, and Walk, Tall
text: Mary Anderson tugged on the strap of Kiarra Boodram’s helmet, making sure it was secure, then pushed Kiarra’s wheelchair up to Hot Diggity, a white pony three and a half feet tall with gray and black patches.

headline: In a Shift, the President of Yemen Will Stay Put
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Less than two weeks after President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen said he would travel to the United States for medical treatment and to calm tensions in his country, officials in his government said he had reversed course and would not travel because of escalating turmoil at home.

headline: Cuomo Vows New Push to Improve Education
