text: For the beleaguered music industry, any positive news about sales is cause for celebration. And in 2011, the numbers were slightly up.

headline: Keeper Scores Goal to Upstage Donovan’s Encore
text: It was supposed to be Landon Donovan doing the headlining on his return to the English Premier League on Wednesday, but clearly Tim Howard did not get the memo.

headline: Facebook Aside, Market for I.P.O.’s Stays Cool
text: It will take more than Facebook to heat up the tepid market for initial public offerings.

headline: Factory Orders Increase 1.8%
text: Orders to American factories rose in November by the most in four months, showing that gains in manufacturing will help the economy grow.

headline: Hailing the Wrong Taxi
text: WHEELCHAIR users have long been deprived of a quintessential New York City experience: riding in a taxi. So after years of discussion, litigation and experimentation, the governor and the mayor of New York last month announced a deal to put 2,000 wheelchair-accessible cabs on the streets, setting aside up to $54 million in subsidies and loans to retrofit vehicles for wheelchair use or buy new wheelchair-accessible vehicles.

headline: Basketball Is Reborn at an Old Bronx Gym
text: Opulent sunlight filtered through the windows at one end of Rose Hill Gym in the Bronx on Wednesday, a fitting picture after one of the brightest moments the Fordham men’s basketball team had experienced in decades.

headline: Iowa’s Republicans, Divided by Gym Partitions and Conservative Ideologies
text: ALTOONA, Iowa

headline: In New Strategy, Panetta Plans Even Smaller Army
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta has concluded that the Army has to shrink even below current targets, dropping to 490,000 soldiers over the next decade, but that the United States should not cut any of its 11 aircraft carriers, according to Pentagon officials and military analysts briefed on the secretary’s budget proposals.

headline: On Stage, an Awkward Reminder of Personal Rifts in G.O.P.
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Everybody went by the script during a highly choreographed endorsement Wednesday at a school gymnasium here. Mitt Romney called Senator John McCain a “hero” and a “great friend.” In supporting his once-bitter rival for president, Mr. McCain called on Joe Louis for inspiration and said that President Obama “can run” from Mr. Romney, “but he can’t hide.”

headline: At Delhi Auto Expo, Upscale is the New Cheap
text: Just a few years ago, the buzz word in the Indian auto world was cheap.

headline: Brooklyn Legislator Pleads Not Guilty in Latest Bribery Case
text: Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr., a Brooklyn Democrat who was indicted on charges of soliciting and accepting thousands of dollars in bribes from undercover federal agents, pleaded not guilty on Wednesday before a federal judge in Brooklyn.

headline: Lobbyist Pleads Guilty to Paying Bribes to a State Senator
text: Over three decades, Richard J. Lipsky built a reputation as a staunch lobbyist for the underdog, even though his side did not always win and his clients were sometimes more establishment than mom-and-pop.

headline: With the Wind at His Back, Santorum Flies Into New Hampshire
text: BRENTWOOD, N.H. — Rick Santorum flew into New Hampshire late Wednesday afternoon with a tailwind of fresh momentum following his unexpectedly strong challenge to Mitt Romney in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: After a Red-Eye, Gingrich Reloads
text: LACONIA, N.H. — As Newt Gingrich stepped into the Barley House pub opposite the State Capitol to meet Republican lawmakers on Wednesday, a protester held a blowup of a famous cartoon portraying him in diapers as a “crybaby.”

headline: Talking With the Taliban
text: The Taliban’s announcement that they plan to open an office in Qatar and possibly begin peace negotiations deserves a close look and a full draught of skepticism.

headline: Romney Takes a Victory Lap as Santorum Plays Catch-Up
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Mitt Romney flew here Wednesday, displaying his financial and organizational muscle in New Hampshire against the upstart candidacy of Rick Santorum, who was seeking to use his near-victory in the Iowa caucuses to become the standard-bearer of a conservative insurgency.

headline: A Bit of a Balancing Act for Republicans Critical of Paul
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Republicans who were alarmed by the strong performance of Representative Ron Paul in Tuesday’s Iowa caucuses must tread carefully as they deal with his rise: he has legions of supporters and could mount an independent bid should be fail to get the party’s nomination.

headline: Mr. Cuomo’s New Year
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo spent a good part of his State of the State address congratulating himself and lawmakers for ending the “dysfunction” of state government. He made real progress, but Albany still has a long way to go.

headline: Oil Price Would Skyrocket if Iran Closed the Strait of Hormuz
text: HOUSTON — If Iran were to follow through with its threat to blockade the Strait of Hormuz, a vital transit route for almost one-fifth of the oil traded globally, the impact would be immediate: Energy analysts say the price of oil would start to soar and could rise 50 percent or more within days.

headline: After a Child’s Death, a Religious Politician Became a Cultural Warrior
text: WASHINGTON — As a teenager growing up in Butler, Pa., Rick Santorum spent Sunday mornings as an altar boy, taking wheelchair-bound veterans to Roman Catholic Mass. In the ninth grade, he announced his intention to hold elective office. “I’m going to be governor of Pennsylvania,” he declared, according to his brother Dan.

headline: Quiet Excellence of Saints’ Colston
text: With all the late-season record chasing by Drew Brees, Darren Sproles, Jimmy Graham and the Saints’ offense as a whole, wide receiver Marques Colston remained under the radar, as usual. But when Colston, the quiet Hofstra alumnus, passed 1,000 yards receiving for the season Sunday against Carolina, it was the fifth time in his six years that he had accomplished the feat.

headline: A Convention Center at Aqueduct Is Urged
text: One of Manhattan’s most desirable real-estate assets was at the center of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposal Wednesday to build the country’s largest convention center at a racetrack-casino in Queens.

headline: Defense Had Big Role in Rise of the Broncos
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — Despite what fan adulation and ceaseless television chatter indicated, the 52-year-old N.F.L. team at the eastern base of the Rockies did not change its name to Tim Tebow and the Denver Broncos this season.

headline: U.S. Announces Proposals to Clean Gowanus Canal
text: The toxic cocktail that is the Gowanus Canal took a century to mix. Now plans for the federal government to transform it in 10 years from an environmental blight into a healthy urban waterway are taking shape amid optimism from neighbors and frustration from City Hall.

headline: Crackup at Radio City
text: “Will the party from the psychiatric wing of New York University Hospital please come to the front desk?”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Giants Go From Facing Rex Ryan to Rob Ryan to Matt Ryan
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — By the end of the day Sunday, the Giants will have faced a number of notable opponents on their quest for a Super Bowl: the New England Patriots, the San Francisco 49ers, the New Orleans Saints, the Green Bay Packers and three guys named Ryan.

headline: Night in a Baghdad E.R.
text: Now that the United States military has left Iraq, the long-term legacy of two decades of war and sanctions will become clearer over the coming months and years. Not only through violence, but also in the emergence – or otherwise – of civil institutions and their ability to provide basic services. Here, one Iraqi doctor writes about how her hospital is coping.

headline: Devices to Keep Track of Calories, Lost or Gained
text: When it comes to New Year’s resolutions, year after year the No. 1 spot is most likely occupied by “lose weight.” Its persistence probably has something to do with the fact that most people have trouble actually succeeding.

headline: Olbermann in a Clash at New Job
text: The broadcaster Keith Olbermann is famous for estranging himself from his bosses, be it at ESPN, Fox or MSNBC.

headline: Sorting Out an Avalanche of iPad Apps for the Best of 2011
text: Like owners of iPhones and Androids, users of iPads faced a surge of new apps last year, to the point where it was easy to miss great ones. Here’s my list of 10 favorites from 2011, along with a few runners-up. Note: as with 2010’s Top 10, seasonal sensations like MLB.com’s At Bat aren’t included, nor are games, which I’ll cover separately online.

headline: Role of Monitors in Syria Comes Under Scrutiny
text: The Qatari foreign minister, Sheik Hamad bin Jassim al-Thani, consulted on Wednesday with Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, about enhancing the performance of the Arab League monitors in Syria. “The monitors have tried their best,” Sheik Hamad said, but they lack any previous experience, so could benefit from United Nations technical help. The protocol that Syria signed with the Arab League demands that the government, not the monitors, halt the violence, the minister said, so forging a regional solution and avoiding a referral to the Security Council requires that Syria respect that agreement.

headline: The Consumer Bureau Gets a Chief
text: Nearly six months after it opened its doors, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau finally has a director, after President Obama’s recess appointment of Richard Cordray, a former attorney general of Ohio who served as the bureau’s chief of enforcement.

headline: From Dreams of Reality-Show Stardom to Accusations of Tough-Guy Extortion
text: The alleged Genovese crime associate was the owner of one of Staten Island’s most popular catering halls, and he came to believe that his life had the makings of a reality television drama. He produced slick promotional videos for the show that he conceived and hoped to star in, “Banquet Boyz,” and posted them on YouTube.

headline: How a Retired Officer, Trying to Stop a Robber, Shot an Agent Doing the Same
text: A woman ran into the deli screaming that a pharmacy three doors down was being robbed. The deli owner, a retired Nassau County police lieutenant, took off running, as did a customer, a young off-duty New York City police officer. Both had guns.

headline: The March of the Non-Mitts
text: PETERBOROUGH, N.H.

headline: Walker Returns to Garden, Site of Big East Glory
text: When Kemba Walker was last in Madison Square Garden, he was the best player on a Connecticut team that was beginning a roll that would carry it to the N.C.A.A. championship.

headline: Thursday: Shells of Shells
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Most people who get into crossword puzzle constructing start out with an early-week, simply-themed grid. Once in a while, however, we see someone debut with a theme that’s slightly trickier or a bit more clever, and that’s just what we have today.

headline: Internet Access Is Not a Human Right
text: Reston, Va.

headline: Productive and Popular, but Facing a Challenge in Remaining So

headline: Road Work Ahead, Forever
text: Wilfredo Torres spotted the pothole ahead of him. He knew that if he swerved, he would veer into the next lane and cause an accident. If he slowed, he would probably be rammed from behind by a tractor-trailer.

headline: Covering ‘America the Beautiful’
text: Mitt Romney has done a swell job memorizing the words to “America the Beautiful.” Especially since that awkward afternoon in 2008 when he had trouble reminding a houseful of Iowans about “our beautiful land and our mountains and … and … and our waving, or, uh, what is it, let’s see, waving filled … no, how does it … and uh …  amber waves of grain!”

headline: Appointment Clears the Way for Consumer Agency to Act
text: WASHINGTON — Payday lenders, money transfer agencies, credit bureaus and debt collectors, take notice: the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is coming after you, and quickly.

headline: Charges Against Journalists Dim the Democratic Glow in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — A year ago, the journalist Nedim Sener was investigating a murky terrorist network that prosecutors maintain was plotting to overthrow Turkey’s Muslim-inspired government. Today, Mr. Sener stands accused of being part of that plot, jailed in what human rights groups call a political purge of the governing party’s critics.

headline: Stoudemire and Shumpert Return, but Knicks Still Fall

He was 82.

headline: Explosions Across Iraq Kill Dozens Amid Political Crisis

The attacks come amid a political crisis that has brought the government to a halt less than three weeks after American troops withdrew.

headline: 15 Kidnapped Pakistani Soldiers Executed by the Taliban in a Retaliatory Gesture
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Taliban insurgents executed 15 security soldiers who had been recently kidnapped and dumped their bodies on a hilltop in northwestern Pakistan on Thursday, in retaliation for the killing of a militant commander by government forces, government and military officials said.

headline: Jan. 5, 1914 | Henry Ford Implements the $5-a-Day Wage
text: On Jan. 5, 1914, Henry Ford, head of the Ford Motor Company, introduced a minimum wage scale of $5 per day, more than doubling the wages for most employees. He also offered profit sharing to employees who lived a clean lifestyle, reduced the daily worker’s shift to eight hours from nine and declared that no employee would “be discharged except for proved unfaithfulness or irremediable inefficiency.”

headline: On the Trail of an Intercontinental Killer
text: A little after 9 a.m. on Sept. 15, 1990, the owner of a steel-products company pulled up to her office in Vinegar Hill, near the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and spotted a black garbage bag sitting on the sidewalk out front. She parked her car and went to move the bag when she noticed it leaking blood. The woman called 911. Within the hour, Ken Whelan, a homicide detective from the 84th Precinct, peered into the bag. It was full of human body parts.

headline: Sculpting a Photograph With Light
text: For more than 20 years, the fine art photographer Harold Ross has been making images using a technique known as “painting with light,” which involves casting light on and around subjects in the dark during a time exposure. Mr. Ross, who also does commercial and studio photography, prefers to call the process “sculpting with light.” Using a Phase One Back on a Hassleblad for still life photographs and a Cambo Wide RS for landscapes, he spends hours creating his images, which look like oil paintings, rich in color and depth.

headline: Do Your Teachers Use Technology Well?

Many teachers are now incorporating digital tools into their lessons, via interactive whiteboards, social media, class blogs and wikis, devices like cellphones or video cameras, or programs on computers or tablets.

headline: Fiat Increases Stake in Chrysler

headline: Pork and Apples
text: It is a classic — really killer — combination, but one most people don’t play around with much. Once I started to think about it, though, the possibilities for pork and apples seemed myriad: obviously, you can cook chops and chunks in a cast-iron skillet, maybe with a little bacon and onions . . . an easy vision. Bacon-wrapped apples, skewered and roasted or broiled (or grilled, for you warm-climate people) is another. A B.C.A. — bacon, cheese (soft, mild, brie-ish cheese, especially) and apple — is a fine sandwich, especially when cooked as you would a grilled cheese.

Like other investors, Northwest and Ethical Investments  was concerned that James L. Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis, RIM’s co-chief executives, also serve as co-chairmen.

headline: For Seal Pups on Thin Ice, a Short Childhood
text: For a mother harp seal, timing is everything. Pups are born and nursed on seasonal sea ice during a brief window before the spring sun melts the ephemeral nursery. After only 12 days, the mother weans her pups and the family slides into the ocean together.

text: The stock indexes in the United States ended mixed on Thursday, but banks and technology companies rallied and employment data bolstered optimism in the economy. Treasuries fell, and the euro and commodities dropped.

headline: Transforming a Body — and a Performance
text: What does it take to make an Oscar-worthy performance for an actress? From Nicole Kidman’s nose to Charlize Theron’s pounds, a physical transformation is often key. The Bagger took a close look at the hopefuls in this season’s race, who endured piercings and shavings (Rooney Mara in “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo”), gained weight (Michelle Williams, who wanted it for her curves in “My Week With Marilyn”) and added British teeth (Meryl Streep in “The Iron Lady”). In “Albert Nobbs,” Glenn Close and Janet McTeer even changed gender, a process that Ms. McTeer said quickly gave her a window into her character.

headline: Morning Take-Out

headline: The Cult of Kirchner

Supporters gathered outside the hospital since Tuesday night cheered in jubilation.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Adele Lifts Album Sales, and Tension on the Olbermann Set
text: Sales of complete albums reached 330.6 million in the United States last year, a 1.3 percent increase from 2010, according to Nielsen SoundScan. As Ben Sisario writes: “Some businesses might call that level of growth flat, but since album sales had fallen every year since 2004, it was a notable improvement.” That boost can be traced by the huge sales for Adele’s “21” (XL/Columbia), which sold 5.82 million copies, the best one-year sales total since 2004.

headline: In Creating Successful Schools, One Size Does Not Fit All

headline: Cuomo's Education Commission: Still Missing the Who, When and What

headline: The Demise of the Public Library
text: LONDON — A couple of years ago, after a reading in Karachi, I told off a young man who was asking me to sign a pirated copy of one of my books. Piracy is destroying publishing in Pakistan, I told him. He said he understood but added that because pirated books are cheaper he could buy more of them. It’s not as if Karachi is filled with public libraries, he said.

headline: Cuomo’s Push for Casinos Not Good News for All Gamblers

Cuomo began his “State of the State” speech on Wednesday,  a middle-aged woman walked away from a slot machine called Great Wall in the new gambling hall adjoining Aqueduct racetrack. That machine had taken enough of her money for one day, said the woman, who preferred to keep her name to herself.

The “Sherlock” star Benedict Cumberbatch, who offers a contemporary portrayal of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s consulting detective, Sherlock Holmes, on that BBC and PBS series, has been cast in a major role in a sequel to “Star Trek,” the cinematic reimagining of James T. Kirk’s outer-space adventures from J. J. Abrams and his crew. But just what role Mr. Cumberbatch will play in the new movie is a mystery all its own.

text: Serena Williams, a favorite to win the Australian Open, had a major setback in her second-round match at the Brisbane International on Wednesday, spraining her left ankle just points away from a straight sets victory over Bojana Jovanovski of Serbia.

headline: Josef Skvorecky, Czech-Born Writer Oppressed by Right and Left, Dies at 87
text: Josef Skvorecky, a renowned Czech author who drew on his experiences under the Nazis and the Communists to write fiction that captured the corruptions and humiliations of the 20th century, died on Tuesday in Toronto. He was 87 and had lived and continued to write in Canada for many years.

headline: A Mother Pays Tribute to Her ‘Little Girl Tribe’
text: The woman in black stood before friends and strangers, parents and their children, family who loved her and local residents who knew nothing of her life, only the nightmare of her recent past.

headline: Cobbled Together | The Office of Angela Scott
text: The designer Angela Scott’s lovingly offbeat boots and heels don’t sell by the thousands and can’t be found in more than a handful of stores — Jeffrey in New York and Tomorrowland in Japan are two of them — but that’s exactly how the Texas-based designer likes it. “I think there’s something unique about a product that isn’t overproduced,” says Scott about her shoes, all of which are bench-made in small-batch factories by cobblers who hand-stitch and mold the vegetable-tanned leather and eco-friendly cork soles that characterize Scott’s collection. “I’d love to just be in one shop, the best shop, in cities around the world. That would be a lovely place for me to sit,” she says.

headline: Akram Khan Cancels Show Due to Injury
text: Akram Khan’s first full-length solo work, “Desh” received rapturous critical notices and attracted capacity audiences when it had its premiere at Sadler’s Wells this past October. So much so that the theater, unusually, decided to present “Desh” — a work in which Mr. Khan explores the confluence of his Bangladeshi origins with his British upbringing — again this season, in February. But Mr. Khan has had to cancel these coming performances, as well as a run of “Sacred Monsters,” with Sylvie Guillem, in France this week, because of an injured Achilles tendon, which is likely to keep him offstage for several months. Sadler’s Wells plans to schedule a replacement run of “Desh” in October.

headline: New Hampshire Polls Show Small Movement
text: 11:55 a.m. | Updated  MANCHESTER — Results from New Hampshire tracking polls over the last week show some slight movement in the field of Republican candidates, as Rick Santorum began making gains in Iowa polls.

headline: Tell Us Your B.Q.E. Horror Tales
text: Time seems to move slower on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, where for the last 50 years, the road has been under endless construction. Almost anybody who has traveled on the 16.8-mile stretch from the Grand Central Parkway in Queens to 92nd St in Brooklyn has a story of a lane closure, an accident or both that makes driving – and sitting — a slow form of torture.

headline: 36 Hours: Vienna
text: The city in photos.

headline: 36 Hours: Vienna
text: FOR years, Vienna has lingered in the fading glory of the fin-de-siècle era, understandably satisfied with the grandeur of its Hapsburg-era architecture and parks. Now a new wind is blowing through this imperial city, with the opening of dazzling hotels, new and renovated museums and a reinvention of the gasthaus, that ubiquitous pub where Viennese artists and philosophers, workers and shopkeepers linger over schnitzel and beer well into the night. This year, the city celebrates the 150th birthday of its most famous artistic export, Gustav Klimt, whose gold-toned paintings will be on display at 10 of the city’s museums.

headline: Romney Calls Obama a ‘Crony Capitalist’
text: SALEM, N.H. — Mitt Romney on Thursday branded President Obama a “crony capitalist” for making three appointments to the National Labor Relations Board without Congressional approval, suggesting the move was a reward to organized labor for its political support.

headline: An Online Presidential Debate That’s Meant to Be Laughed At
text: In this presidential election cycle can you handle just one more Republican debate? If that already sounds like a joke — and we haven’t even mentioned that it will be moderated by Larry King and its panelists will include Mike Tyson — that’s precisely the goal of a satirical event that will be presented on Friday morning by Yahoo! and Funny or Die and hopefully offer some comic relief from The Election Season That Wouldn’t End (And Yet Somehow Only Just Started).

headline: Trailers to Tempt the Theatergoer
text: How do you make the experience of live theater pop on film in a way that makes a potential ticket buyer say, “I’ve got to see that”? Television commercials are a mainstay, but expensive. Trailers — which can run longer than 15 or 30 seconds and be widely distributed — are increasingly being used to promote theater, but producing them is still a challenge in terms of style, access and cost.

headline: At the Orange Bowl, a Crying Game
text: It would be interesting to calculate when exactly in West Virginia’s absurd 70-33 victory over Clemson in the Orange Bowl Wednesday night that most of the weeping began. No, not by Clemson’s supporters, who were probably too numb to weep. And not by the poor bowl mascot Obie, because we know exactly when the walking orange got turned into a tackling dummy after one Mountaineer touchdown. And not by the Big East, whose sobbing has been going on all through the conference realignment fiasco that is about to turn it into the Big Whatever.

headline: Obama Puts His Stamp on Strategy for a Leaner Military
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has for the first time put his own stamp on an all-encompassing American military policy by turning from the grinding ground wars that he inherited from the Bush administration and refocusing on what he described as a smaller, more agile force across Asia, the Pacific and the Middle East.

headline: Clashing With College Children Over Holiday Break
text: “What’s the definition of mixed emotions?” goes the joke I heard as a young man. “Your mother-in-law driving off a cliff in your new Cadillac.” LOL.

headline: Seeing Things | Sori Yanagi’s Everyday Beauty
text: The Japanese designer Sori Yanagi, who died on Dec. 25 in Tokyo at the age of 96, is best known for his 1956 Butterfly Stool. It is both elegant and utterly simple: two curved pieces of molded plywood are held together through compression and tension by a single brass rod. The stool’s graceful shape recalls a butterfly’s wings, and has also been compared to the form of torii, the traditional Shinto shrine gates. According to Matilda McQuaid, the deputy curatorial director at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, the stool “epitomizes Yanagi’s approach to design. He loved traditional Japanese crafts and was dedicated to the modernist principles of simplicity, practicality and tactility that are associated with Alvar Aalto, Charles and Ray Eames, and Le Corbusier.”

headline: Saltwater May Not Deter Florida’s Pythons
text: The python, a staple creature in the tales of Rudyard Kipling’s India, is poised to move to Ernest Hemingway’s Florida Keys, and a new study by scientists at the United States Geological Survey indicates that it may happen sooner than later.

headline: A Recap of the Pentagon Briefing on Defense Cuts

headline: Wheelies: The Clash of the Teutons Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Israel Plans New Rules on Exchange of Prisoners
text: JERUSALEM — Israel, which recently traded 1,027 Palestinian prisoners for one soldier held by Hamas, is planning on establishing rules that would prevent it from making such a lopsided exchange in the future, Defense Minister Ehud Barak said on Thursday.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Geoffrey Kabaservice discusses his new book about the decline of moderate Republicanism; Theda Skocpol on the Tea Party; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: A Little Visitor Hovers Awhile Longer
text: Like a hit holiday revue whose run has been extended into the new year, the rufous hummingbird who showed up outside the American Museum of Natural History last month has delayed her journey southward and was seen “feeding rather vigorously” Thursday morning on Mahonia japonica flowers, recent frigid weather notwithstanding.

headline: Paul Taylor Adds a Performance With a 1962 Price
text: These days, $3.50 won’t even buy a “tall” latte at Starbucks. But in 1962 that’s what a ticket cost to see a performance of Paul Taylor’s work “Aureole,” set to the music of Handel.

headline: Manufacturing Revival
text: Employment in manufacturing jobs rose in 2010 and 2011, and manufactured exports also rose. A monthly survey of manufacturers shows more were hiring than firing for 27 consecutive months, the third-longest string since the survey began in 1948.

headline: HBO Ends DVD Discounts for Netflix
text: Netflix said a month ago that it sees HBO as its chief rival. And it appears that HBO agrees, as the company confirmed on Thursday that it had decided to stop selling DVDs to Netflix at a discount.

headline: U.S. Asks China to Pressure North Korea to Avoid Provocations During Transition
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A senior American diplomat on Thursday called on China to help restrain the new leadership in North Korea from military provocations during the transition of power there.

headline: TimesCast | January 5, 2012
text: Explosions kill dozens in Iraq | Rick Santorum takes his message to New Hampshire | Myanmar’s first girl band.

headline: Why Awareness Beats Anxiety
text: Gathering information — being in the know — is not the same thing as being mindful, being aware, being present for what’s actually going on behind the news and the chatter and the stuff that just doesn’t matter.

headline: More Fat-Fighting Wisdom From Simon Doonan
text: Simon Doonan, the creative ambassador at large for Barneys New York and the author of the new book “Gay Men Don’t Get Fat,” has been answering reader questions about the dietary theories — serious and not — that he expounds in his book and in an interview with The Times. Following is his latest advice.

headline: G.M. to Reinforce Battery in Its Hybrid Car, the Volt
text: DETROIT — General Motors on Thursday said that it would upgrade the steel structure and liquid cooling system that surround the battery in its Chevrolet Volt to address concerns that the car could catch fire after a severe crash.

headline: A Lively Debate Over Teacher Salaries
text: Are Teachers Overpaid? That question, posed in The Times' Room for Debate, drew a lively response, including from teachers who insisted the answer is a fervent no.

headline: Jessica Chastain to Star in ‘The Heiress’ on Broadway
text: The upcoming Broadway revival of “The Heiress” has found its Catherine Sloper: Jessica Chastain, who received critical acclaim for film performances last year as a snubbed southern wife in “The Help” and as a nurturing young mother in “The Tree of Life,” will play the title role in the 1947 play to be directed by Moises Kaufman (“33 Variations”), the producers announced on Thursday.

headline: The Shame of Filling a Prescription
text: Amy, a single mother living in a middle-class suburb (she asked that only her middle name be used), is an educated professional who is reasonably savvy in most medical matters. But every month she goes through an arduous, prolonged and humiliating process: filling a Ritalin prescription for herself and her 11-year-old son.

headline: Continuing Education, at the Bar
text: FOR many, January means back to the lecture hall, and not just at colleges and universities. Across New York the backrooms of bars and the main stages of clubs are coming to resemble secret annexes to the Learning Annex — homes to a boom in alternative lecture series that combine the spirit of the seminar room with the atmosphere of speed dating.

headline: Ancient Pornographic Artifact Discovered by the Thames
text: A bronze disk recently discovered in the mud near the Putney Bridge in London seemed innocent enough, but on close inspection it has turned out to be one of the oldest pieces of British pornographic art, according to the Guardian.

headline: Under the Radar: 5 Questions About ‘Alexis: A Greek Tragedy’
text: In December 2008, weeks of rioting erupted in Athens after a police officer shot and killed a 15-year-old boy named Alexandros Grigoropoulos. Two years later the officer was convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison.

headline: Another Try for Bipartisanship
text: A year ago, as Washington grappled with the shooting rampage that nearly took the life of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, the centrist group Third Way made a modest suggestion to members of Congress: Mingle with lawmakers from the opposite party at the State of the Union address.

headline: A Community Time Bank
text: Joan Black took a serious tumble two years ago, climbing up on a stepladder to reach for a punchbowl. She was about to host one of her frequent patio parties for a regional theater company in Montpelier, Vt.

headline: First Post-Iowa Polls Show Bounce for Santorum
text: The bounce that candidates receive in the polls after a primary or caucus is typically as much a function of exceeding expectations as their actual performance. Although Mitt Romney won the Iowa caucuses by eight votes, it looks as though Rick Santorum will see the largest improvement in his poll numbers.

headline: A Party of Extremists?
text: Unlike the liberal writers quoted in my last post, Jacob Weisberg’s column on Mitt Romney’s inevitability doesn’t indulge in wishful thinking about how the primary campaign is rendering Romney unelectable in the fall. But his desire to insist on the G.O.P.’s extremism to leads him into this seemingly-contradictory analysis:

headline: The Importance of Being Ernest Hemingway
text: Melena Ryzik has a drink with the actor Corey Stoll, who plays Ernest Hemingway in Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris.”

headline: Some Words of Wisdom for Applicants from India
text: Given the growing and passionate interest of students from India in American universities — a recent New York Times article noted that Indians are now “the second-largest foreign student population in America, after the Chinese, with almost 105,000 students in the United States” — The Choice is undertaking a pilot project in collaboration with a new blog aimed at readers in India.

headline: Winter Wonders | Lovers of Puffers
text: The recent Northeast chill requires serious outerwear — the kind that’s stuffed with down, lined with fleece and trimmed with fur. Here, the television personality Alexa Chung dials down her metallic Marc Jacobs dress and Mary Janes with a furry and more utilitarian parka; the actress Julianne Moore makes an anorak look elegant by pairing it with chic black and brown accessories; and the actress Naomi Watts bundles up in dusty red denim and motorcycle boots.

headline: The Top 10 Travel Articles of 2011
text: Life on a giant cruise ship, dealing with canceled flights, an alternate route to Machu Picchu — these are all subjects that attracted Web readers in 2011. As with last year’s version, this year’s list is topped by our annual Where to Go roundup. Other popular articles included spring weekend getaways, a different way to look at Paris and an essay on why we travel in unsettling times.

headline: Five-Ku: Short Poems on the Career of Mark Wahlberg
text: Dirk Diggler, porn star;Marky Mark makes the most ofA sizable part.

headline: Jim Huber, Sports Broadcaster and Essayist, Is Dead at 67
text: Jim Huber, an Emmy-winning broadcaster whose essays on the human dimension of sports were a staple on CNN during his nearly three decades with Turner Broadcasting, died on Monday in Atlanta. He was 67.

headline: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast
text: The Slap Shot contributor Christopher Botta talks hockey with Jim Devellano, the senior vice president of the Red Wings and the former assistant general manager of the Islanders. Also, Brian Compton of NHL.com and Adam Rotter of SNYRangersBlog join in. Topics include Rangers Coach John Tortorella, the Islanders’ John Tavares, Bruins-Devils and the N.H.L. draft.

headline: N.H.L Hands Down Two Suspensions
text: Calgary Flames forward Rene Bourque and Chicago Blackhawks wing Dan Carcillo may now be wishing that they had not again incurred the wrath of the N.H.L.’s disciplinary department. The two players received significant suspensions — five games for Bourque and seven for Carcillo — in response to their actions in recent games.

headline: A Place to Lay My Heart
text: WHEN I met Joe, he told me he was trying to decide where to live. At the time, he lived in — well, that was hard to say.

headline: Fusing Identity: Dollops of Humor and Shea Butter
text: RASHID JOHNSON was discussing his coming exhibition at the Hauser & Wirth gallery recently, when Marc Payot, a gallery partner, mentioned that a previous owner of the gallery’s sleek town house on East 69th Street in Manhattan was the boxing promoter Don King.

headline: Resolution: Become a Mint.com Power User
text: This year I resolve to become a Mint.com power user.

headline: The Writers Guild Goes for the Laugh With Its Nominees
text: Is this the year that funny finally gets its due?

headline: Racing Against Time Around the Great Lakes
text: To a dedicated band of tinkerers willing to devote a week or more to nursing old cars over a 1,000-mile rally route, the Great Race is catnip. This year’s race, which will route participants around the Great Lakes region in a four-state, one-province loop, begins in Traverse City, Mich. on June 23 and will conclude, at least for those whose old iron withstands the ordeal, in Dearborn, Mich., on July 1.

headline: Europe Stands Firm on Airline Emissions, Raising Fears of a Trade Conflict
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission said on Thursday that airlines that did not follow a new European law requiring them to account for their emissions of greenhouse gases could face being banned from European airports.

headline: A Sportswriter’s Hall of Fame Tribute Is Out of Place to Some
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — In a quiet, sun-splashed corridor, beyond the storied gallery of bronze plaques, a seemingly ordinary exhibit has created a singularly awkward situation for the Baseball Hall of Fame.

headline: A Role That Was Good and True and Stole the Scene
text: Corey Stoll was just a little-known actor who happened to be appearing opposite Scarlett Johansson in “A View From the Bridge” on Broadway when Woody Allen – who cast Ms. Johansson in his film “Match Point” — came to see the show. Not long after, Mr. Stoll, best known from his role as the bald detective on the short-lived “Law & Order: Los Angeles,” was called in to see Mr. Allen about a part in “Midnight in Paris.” He was duly petrified but wound up with the role of Hemingway. He donned a wig and a mustache, and on screen he was one of the most memorable stars in a cast that included Owen Wilson and Marion Cotillard.

headline: Alone Again, Naturally
text: ONE cold, misty autumn morning, I slipped and fell. I was on my way out to do errands, the mossy wooden deck on the north side of my house was slick with dew, I was in a hurry, I skidded, and both feet flew out from under me.

headline: Romney, in South Carolina, Sets His Sights on Obama
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Enjoying a strong lead in New Hampshire polls, Mitt Romney flew here Thursday to get a jump-start with voters in the first Southern primary and begin what might be his biggest challenge yet: convincing Republicans in this socially conservative state that he is the candidate who best represents their values.

headline: Swiss Bank Chief Vows Not to Resign Over Currency Trades
text: FRANKFURT — Philipp M. Hildebrand, head of the Swiss central bank, said Thursday that he regretted currency trades that have threatened his international reputation as an advocate for tougher bank regulation, but he maintained that he had violated no laws or regulations and would not resign.

headline: Legislator Calls for Hearing on State Aid Suspension
text: State Assemblyman Felix W. Ortiz of Brooklyn is calling for a public hearing on the state education commissioner’s decision to suspend payments on federal grants that are meant to help boost results in struggling schools in New York City and nine other New York  school districts.

headline: What’s a Protester to Do?
text: These are strange days to walk the streets of New York in the company of protesters.

headline: Frank Gehry to Try His Hand at Mozart
text: Having designed the auditorium for the Walt Disney Concert Hall, the architect Frank Gehry is now turning his attention to the stage itself, creating a set for the Los Angeles Philharmonic’s production of “Don Giovanni.”

headline: Be It Resolved
text: IT’S still early in 2012, so let’s be optimistic. Let’s assume you have made a New Year’s resolution and have not yet broken it. Based on studies of past resolutions, here are some uplifting predictions:

headline: Jets Fine Scott $10,000
text: Bart Scott’s frustration cost him $10,000. The Jets levied that fine on Scott for making an obscene gesture toward a photographer Monday, the day after Santonio Holmes’s skirmish with teammates in a season-ending loss to Miami that eliminated them from playoff contention.

headline: Lawyers Intercede in Rift Between Olbermann and Current
text: At this point it could be called Keith Olbermann vs. Current TV.

headline: Richard Cordray’s Appointment: Was It Justified?
text: President Obama’s recess appointment of Richard Cordray, as the head of the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, has resulted in a lot of partisan bickering.

headline: Hoberman Is Out at Village Voice, and Curtain Drops on an Era
text: On Wednesday, two long-running trends in journalism came together in a single layoff: Jim Hoberman, a senior film critic at the Village Voice since 1988, was let go, yet another instance of the The Voice taking aim at a veteran — and presumably well paid — employee. He joins a list of longtime Voice writers who have been laid off.

headline: German President Retreats on Openness
text: BERLIN — A day after a televised interview in which he promised greater openness and transparency, the president of Germany, Christian Wulff, refused on Thursday to allow the country’s biggest-selling newspaper to publish a transcript of a threatening voice mail message he left for the newspaper’s editor.

headline: Scrutinizing Stand-Ins: Working With Nouns and Pronouns
text: Overview | What are pronouns, and what are their purpose and function? How are they used in speech and writing? In this lesson, students identify the connection between nouns and pronouns and discuss how the clarity of a sentence is affected by using a noun as opposed to a pronoun.

headline: Still Searching for Republicans With Climate Concerns
text: The Climate Desk, a collaborative journalism project of Mother Jones and several other publications, has produced a video searching in vain for a Republican presidential candidate willing to make any science-based statements on climate.

headline: In Borneo, a Safe Place for Orangutans
text: At Camp Leakey, one of three research outposts in Tanjung Puting National Park, Indonesia, semiwild orangutans living in the surrounding forest often drop by for bananas and company.

headline: A Gadget Is More Than the Sum of Its Parts
text: As a teenager growing up in the Cleveland suburbs, my first real job was at a Chick-fil-A restaurant in a local mall. I did everything: manned the cash register, made sandwiches and cleaned up.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 5
text: The day in sports included heavy snowfall at the biathlon World Cup in Oberhof, Germany, and an upset in the quarterfinals of the Brisbane tennis tournament in Australia.

headline: Responsible Bidders Sought for Titanic Auction
text: The New York auction house Guernsey’s explained on Thursday that all bidders in its planned winner-take-all auction of more than 5,500 artifacts salvaged from the wreckage of the Titanic must agree to abide by 19 pages’ worth of court-ordered covenants and commitments governing the collection. “The court has final approval and the right to make sure the buyer has the capability and the desire,” said Arlan Ettinger, president of Guernsey’s. “It’s like getting a puppy,” he added. “It takes a great deal of care.”

headline: Writers, Art Directors and Now Uggie
text: Until someone or Kanye West  tells us otherwise, the Bagger will take this as evidence that blog campaigns and wild Twitter sprees work: The fine folks at Movieline, who started the “Consider Uggie” campaign on behalf of the little dog in “The Artist,” point us to a prize that the Jack Russell terrier has already won. It’s from the French, bien sûr. Last month he earned a special mention in the Prix Lumière Awards, France’s equivalent of the Golden Globes, with “The Artist” picking up four other nominations – best film, best director, best actor and best actress – over all.

headline: Afghanistan Closes Firm Providing Security
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government said Thursday that it was shutting down the operations of one of the largest foreign security companies operating in the country after detaining two of its contractors on suspicion of gun smuggling.

headline: New Lawsuit Means All Major Labels Are Suing Grooveshark
text: Grooveshark, a popular digital music service that is being sued for copyright infringement by three of the four major record companies, now has problems with the one big label that it has a licensing deal with.

headline: Judge Cites Bias in Halting Brooklyn Development Plan
text: The blighted border of Williamsburg, Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick has been more like the Bermuda Triangle than the Broadway Triangle for developers over the last two decades.

headline: The Get | Alice Cicolini Ring
text: Alice Cicolini, a London-based Central Saint Martins graduate, works with Kamal Meenakar, a master craftsman in Jaipur, India, on her candy-colored jewels. The pieces get their distinct finishes through champlevé, an intricate enameling process (called meenakari in India). “I’m drawn to enamel because it’s like painting on precious metal,” said Cicolini, whose latest creations incorporate exotic shapes and motifs associated with religious architecture found along the ancient Silk Road.

headline: Of Women, Politics and Laughs
text: The South African novelist, poet and playwright Zakes Mda has a formidable political lineage. His father, A. P. Mda, was a guiding light in the 1959 founding of the Pan Africanist Congress. He was a lawyer and by all accounts a stern, serious man. Zakes Mda (pronounced EM-dah) is a serious man of a different sort: one who refuses to be somber. In “Sometimes There Is a Void,” his new memoir, his life and hard times are mostly played for wistful comedy.

headline: The Caucus | Santorum in New Hampshire
text: Rick Santorum takes the fight for the nomination to one of Mitt Romney's strongholds, New Hampshire.

headline: After Brief Calm, Europe Again Worries Over Debt
text: PARIS — Five months after the United States lost its AAA credit rating, buyers are still flocking to bonds issued by Washington. But in Europe, where the euro zone crisis and chronic economic problems may soon erode the credit scores of big countries like France, Italy and Spain, investors are far more wary.

headline: Clergymen in Cuffs as Protesters Are Arrested
text: Updated, 6:26 p.m. | Four pastors, including a member of City Council, were among seven men arrested Thursday morning in front of the city Law Department during a protest of the city’s ban on allowing churches to hold worship services in public school buildings, the police and organizers said.

headline: Sports Fans Are Having Trouble Keeping Their Time Warners Straight
text: Hell hath no fury like a New York sports fan scorned.

headline: Caucus Video: Santorum in New Hampshire
text: Rick Santorum takes the fight for the nomination to one of Mitt Romney’s strongholds, New Hampshire.

headline: Economisting
text: I’ll shortly be on my way to the ASSA meetings in Chicago. What with travel and all, quite possibly no posting for some time. At the meetings all my stuff will be on Saturday: a joint presentation of my work with Gauti Eggertsson at 8 AM, a meet-and-greet at the Worth booth from 3:30-5, and a presentation of my 33-year-old paper on interstellar trade (kept fresh by time dilation) at Yoram Bauman’s humor in economics session at 8 PM. What will I do with all my free time?

headline: Miami Nice: Zambrano Joins Guillen
text: At Carlos Zambrano’s lowest moments in the major leagues, Ozzie Guillen has been there. In June 2010, after a dugout fight with a teammate during a game against the White Sox, Zambrano had dinner with Guillen. Last August, after Zambrano packed his belongings and left the Cubs during a game in Atlanta, Guillen’s wife spoke with him and Guillen publicly called Zambrano his friend.

headline: ABC, With No Reruns, Proves a Magnet for Viewers
text: As the only broadcast network boasting an entire lineup of original programming on Wednesday night, ABC easily finished in first place in all the major ratings categories. “Modern Family” led the way as the highest-rated show in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, and it drew its largest audience since its season premiere in September, with 14 million total viewers.

headline: Alderson Says Mets Must Improve From Within
text: Several weeks after reaching contract agreements with relievers Frank Francisco and Jon Rauch, the Mets introduced the pitchers on a conference call with reporters Thursday. Unlike many off-seasons, there has been no need for a news conference at the ballpark to show off a splashy new addition.

headline: Yankees, Nakajima Unable to Make a Deal
text: 9:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: Tata Technologies Readies a Conceptual E.V. for Detroit Auto Show
text: The Tata Technologies electric mobility concept, or Emo, is a pure concept vehicle, with no clear path to production. So why was it built?

headline: Get a Midlife
text: YOU may be surprised to learn that when researchers asked people over 65 to pick the age they would most like to return to, the majority bypassed the wild and wrinkle-less pastures of their teens, 20s and 30s, and chose their 40s.

headline: Prosecutors in Egypt Call for Mubarak to Be Hanged
text: CAIRO — Egyptian prosecutors called on Thursday for hanging former President Hosni Mubarak, saying his authority over the security forces made him responsible for the deaths of hundreds of protesters who challenged his rule.

headline: Don’t Shoot the Sitter
text: My sister accused me of manipulating my father into giving me money for pet-sitting fees in advance of a recent trip I took. I planned to repay him but I didn’t even get into that with my sister. She is full of grievances about our father’s money, and I wanted to avoid a fight. My question is: How should I deal with the pet sitter, who is clearly my sister’s source of information?

headline: ‘Die, Nazi Scum!’: Soviet Tass Propaganda Posters, 1941-1945
text: Andrew Edlin Gallery

headline: TimesCast | Sectarian Attacks in Iraq
text: January 5, 2012 — Michael S. Schmidt reports from Baghdad on the sectarian violence and explosions that killed dozens in Iraq.

headline: Signs of Hope on Jobs, and Some Caveats
text: With as dismal a run as we’ve had in the economy over the last few years, it’s tempting to start looking for the glass to be half full.

headline: After Man’s Death, a Family Sues the Police for Details
text: The family of a Canadian man struck and killed by a truck while riding his bike in Brooklyn has sued the Police Department to release records of the accident.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Twenty Sided Store
text: Named for the dice used in many role-playing games, a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, shop attracts gamers in search of a community.

headline: Theater Talkback: Finding Other Thrills in Dance, Song and Wide Receiving
text: Covering theater is a far cry from being a war correspondent, heaven knows, but there are times during the busier passages of the season when the number of incoming shows feels like an overwhelming barrage of aesthetic artillery. (Insert joke about bombs exploding right and left here.) Simply keeping on top of all the fall openings can put you in a bunker mentality. Weeks can go by when I don’t have a chance to attend any cultural events that I’m not directly covering, which is not an ideal way of maintaining the properly wide frame of reference that a critic considering any discipline should strive to attain.

headline: Where Gamers Freely Unleash Their Alter Egos
text: ON a moonless winter night you journey across a perilous landscape of snaking subway trains, howling traffic and steam-hissing sewers. The rattling dice in your pocket guide you like an oracle toward the object of your quest. At last you spy it: the blue-painted crystal glowing in the window of the Twenty Sided Store.

headline: Michael St. John: ‘In the Studio Twenty Eleven’ and ‘The Wedding (The Walker Evans Polaroid Project)'

headline: Hackers Threaten to Post Source Code for Symantec Product
text: Hackers have posted a file online that they claim is a confidential glimpse into Symantec’s Norton Antivirus program and have threatened to release source code for the security giant’s flagship antivirus product.

headline: This Time the Accent Is on ‘Chamber’
text: The Manhattan Chamber Orchestra, when it comes down to it, is really just one musician, the composer, conductor, violinist and violist Richard Auldon Clark, along with however many players he can bring together for the project at hand. In prosperous times it was an actual orchestra, assembled from New York’s rich freelance pool. When finances are tighter — now, for example — it is a chamber group. So if it seemed odd that the orchestra’s 25th-anniversary celebration, at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia at Symphony Space on Wednesday evening, was a program of duos, trios and quartets, think of that as a measure of Mr. Clark’s flexibility.

headline: Galaxy’s Gonzalez Goes to Germany on Loan
text: 11:45 a.m. Jan. 6 | Updated With Gonzalez’s Injury Omar Gonzalez tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee in his first practice with Nuremberg of Germany’s Bundesliga and is returning to Los Angeles.

headline: A Dissident Director of High-Camp, Low-Budget Films
text: On Bizarro World, a planet in Superman’s universe, people do everything backward and ineptly. If this anti-Earth had a filmmaker, that person would probably be a lot like George Kuchar (1942-2011), the pioneering underground filmmaker who dedicated his life to upending the values of conventional cinema.

headline: Santorum Has Testy Exchange on Same-Sex Marriage
text: CONCORD, N.H. — Rick Santorum engaged in an extended and sometimes testy exchange over same-sex marriage with a group of college students during a campaign appearance on Thursday.

headline: Good News on Gay Rights
text: This week started out with some very bad news for those of us who regard marriage equality as a pressing civil rights issue: Rick Santorum’s runner-up finish at the Iowa caucuses. Even within the Republican party—no friend to gay couples—he’s an extremist. In a 2003 interview with the AP, he made clear that he does not believe in a fundamental right to privacy and supports laws against sodomy. He also seemed to compare homosexuality to “man on child” and “man on dog” sex. (How do those ideas pop into his head in the first place?)

headline: Parental Quandary Considered: Should You Bring a Child to an Adult Party?
text: Every week, the Motherlode Parental Quandary team of experienced, expert parents (that’s all of us — own it!) weighs in  on a dilemma of an ethical, social or moral nature that could only happen to a fellow parent. We offer fantastic advice, and this week’s advice was unusually universal. Nearly all of us were agreed on what last week’s  parent should have done — but caught off guard on the phone isn’t the best time to call to mind even the clearest of solutions.

headline: Whitney and Storm King to Share a David Smith
text: For more than a decade museums have been joining forces to buy expensive art. It’s an arrangement that works to everyone’s advantage: as prices for contemporary art rise, it’s a way to defray costs while allowing a wider public to see significant work.

headline: Up on the Roof, Dancing With Fire
text: “Does anyone have a lighter?”

headline: A Good Rental History Can Help Borrowers
text: IF you’re planning to buy a home for the first time later this year, your chances of qualifying for a mortgage might be better if you’ve had a history of paying the rent on time.

headline: Back to the Barricades, Antigone
text: The dialogues keep multiplying and echoing, contracting and expanding, blurring and zooming into focus. In the raw and resonant “Alexis. A Greek Tragedy,” one of the opening works in the Under the Radar festival of experimental theater, conversation is hardly limited to the words exchanged by the actors on the stage of the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa.

headline: Young Love as Divine, but a Perilous Insanity
text: The dreamy, protracted love scenes in “Norwegian Wood” recall that now quaint era near the peak of the sexual revolution when intense young love fired the collective imagination with envy, prurience and awe. Yes, there were casual hookups then, but they were not called that in the late 1960s, when the story takes place. Romantic sex still bore a mystical aura.

text: Benefits of Buying From a Sponsor

headline: 18-Century Artisans, Tracked the Modern Way
text: Furniture made in Rhode Island before 1800 would sound like a manageable topic for a thorough Web site. After all, “Rhode Island is not that big a state,” said Patricia E. Kane, lead curator of American decorative arts at the Yale University Art Gallery.

headline: Water Power Meets Resistance
text: WOODBURY

headline: In the Presence of the Mountain
text: R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, is climbing Mount Kilimanjaro this month to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts will appear occasionally in Bats.

headline: Little Creatures, Witty and Erotic
text: Stop by Ubu Gallery this month and you may find yourself asking, “How did I not know about this guy?” Unless you are exceptionally well informed about the history of French Surrealism, the name Georges Hugnet (1906-1974) may have slipped your notice. It did mine, and the gallery’s exhibition of his collages and altered postcards comes as a delightful revelation.

headline: The Minimalist: Curried Tofu With Soy Sauce
text: Many of the best soups, stews, and braises start with careful browning that creates a flavor that’s rich and seductive.

headline: State Leads Nation in Down-Payment Size
text: BUYERS in New Jersey have the highest down-payment rate in the country, putting down an average 13.71 percent of the purchase price, according to a new report from LendingTree. That surpasses percentages in cities like Washington, and states like New York, Hawaii and California, though only by tenths of a point. In New York, the average down payment works out to 13.47 percent. The national average is 12.24 percent, for the year ending in November.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Pakistan, New York and the Netherlands.

headline: The Remote-Controlled House
text: ROBERT STEININGER and his wife, Anh, shopped for a second home on the East End for five years before they stumbled across a “modern barn” built on speculation by Plum Builders of East Hampton. They loved the gabled design of the five-bedroom five-bath clapboard home, with its vaulted wood-planked ceilings and “open and unique layout.”

headline: A Documenter of Protests Has a Run-In of His Own
text: When Occupy Wall Street protesters set up their encampment in September in Zuccotti Park, a new category of activist emerged alongside fixtures such as meeting facilitators and medics.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Vanishing Jobs and the Need for Coders
text: Interesting things that Bits reporters and editors found on the Web. More here.

headline: Anatomy of a Murder, in Raging Rock
text: The easily downloadable single dominates pop music today, which makes “Goodbar,” a music-theater piece being presented at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar festival, a throwback in more ways than one. The show, created by the band Bambï and the downtown theater troupe Waterwell, is essentially a staged concept album. (Remember them? Remember albums?) It’s based loosely on “Looking for Mr. Goodbar,” the 1975 novel by Judith Rossner about the dark side of that other singles scene — in the bars, that is, where the heroine, a lonely schoolteacher named Theresa, meets a punishing fate.

headline: Still Hung Over From the ’90s
text: Everybody hates the rich.

headline: Dance Listings for Jan. 6-12
text: Dance

headline: C. P. H. Gilbert: The Wild Years
text: CHARLES PIERREPONT HENRY GILBERT could shoot from the back of a galloping horse and design a mean neo-Gothic mansion. The Jewish Museum, completed in 1909 at Fifth Avenue and 92nd Street, is part of his string of lacy town houses along Fifth and Madison that came to define the upper-class residence.

headline: With This Torch, I Thee Weld a Ring
text: Making a ring in a day is about as challenging as a soufflé is for a newbie cook.

headline: Singing Hindi in the Rain
text: It’s one of the most famous sequences in Indian movies. And, not surprisingly, it’s a song. A Chaplinesque tramp with holes in his shoes, too-short pants and a slightly goofy hat skips down a country road and sings these lines in Hindi: “My shoes are Japanese/These pants are English/On my head is a red Russian hat/But still,” he says, pointing to his chest and delivering the kicker, “my heart is Hindustani.”

headline: Leaving Behind an Arduous Commute
text: FOR her internship in the fashion field last summer, Kate Kelly commuted to New York from Philadelphia.

headline: One Man’s Fight With Google Over a Security Warning
text: Jan. 6, 6:55 p.m. | Updated  See our followup post on the reaction to this one.

headline: Diller Scofidio + Renfro to Redesign the Pines Pavilion
text: The architects Diller Scofidio + Renfro and the architectural firm HWKN (HollwichKushner) have been hired to design a new entertainment complex to replace the Pavilion dance club, a gay landmark in Fire Island Pines that was destroyed in a fire last year.

headline: Success Academy Blitzes Cobble Hill
text: The Success Academy charter school network is promoting its new school in Cobble Hill with a bus shelter advertisement, and by hanging leaflets on doors.

headline: Vain Glorious | The Happy Heel
text: “These are not aristocratic feet. I’m here to tell you these are working feet,” says Park Avenue’s go-to podiatrist, Suzanne Levine, after a quick examination of my not-so-pretty pieds. In all fairness, my childhood and adolescence were spent studying ballet. Anyone who’s worn a pair of pointe shoes will confirm that dancing in them is a kind of quiet torture that ceases to bother only after you’ve grown numb to the pain. Your feet never really recover from the trauma. I sought out Levine and a few other foot gurus after determining spring’s must-have shoes: the bejeweled slip-ons from Oscar de la Renta, the velvet clogs from Miu Miu and the heel-less metallic numbers with super-pointy toes from Louis Vuitton, among others. The problem? All of these options are of the 18th-century mule variety. In other words, they leave your heels fully exposed, and mine, still callused and battered to a point seemingly beyond return, were in no position to be naked.

headline: Bull Riders at Madison Square Garden; the Brooklyn Navy Yard
text: It’s a new year. Who knows where it will take you? For this week at least, the Miser does, with a hodgepodge of cheap fun to guide you from the Brooklyn Navy Yard of the mid-19th century to the future of bull riding in the 21st. Ah, the possibilities.

headline: Rent-a-Box Services Make Moving Easier for Some
text: FOR Sara Schmidt, an actress, moving to a new apartment used to involve a tiresome quest for cardboard boxes. She picked up castoffs from the street and canvassed her local liquor stores for others — and even then, she still found herself buying expensive new boxes and supplies like packing tape.

headline: Gingrich Goes Local on New Hampshire Issues
text: Newt Gingrich is running for president of the United States, but as he blazed a trail over the White Mountains, he showed that he had not forgotten that all politics is local.

headline: With This Torch, I Thee Weld
text: MOST couples want their wedding to be awe inspiring. And therein lies the foundation of an enormous industry that, for a price, can guarantee bragging rights for the betrothed, whether it’s beachside fireworks, a chocolate-candy-bar multitiered cake flown in from Napa or flower-covered candelabra.

headline: To New Beginnings, With a Dash of Bitters
text: Elizabeth and the Catapult, a New York City band led by the piano-playing songwriter Elizabeth Ziman, got around to new songs about halfway through a set at the Mercury Lounge on Wednesday night. First came a cheerful ditty about a lazy New Year’s Day that “feels like a new beginning,” with poppy la-las punctuating each verse. Then Ms. Ziman announced: “O.K., let’s get serious. My label just dropped me.” She half-smiled. “So I wrote a song for them.”

headline: Bloomberg Says He Will Fight for Fingerprinting Rule
text: A day after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vowed to end New York City’s policy of requiring food stamp applicants to be electronically fingerprinted, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg defended the policy and said he would try to convince the governor to keep it in place.

headline: Grand Galleries for National Treasures
text: IN 1924, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art opened its American Wing, the Met’s president, Robert W. de Forest, cautiously toasted the state of what he called “American domestic art.” “Perhaps, at the moment, it has more acclaim than future generations would think it ought to have had,” he said. “It has filled the antiquity shops, it has crowded the auction rooms, it is vogue.”

headline: Serendipity as Urban Curator
text: WITH apologies to provincial visionaries everywhere, it’s always been tough to argue with Ezra Pound: “All great art is born of the metropolis.”

headline: The Caucus Click: McCain’s Slip on the Stump
text: John McCain accidentally praised President Obama during a speech in support of Mitt Romney at the Founders Hall Charles Towne Landing State Historic Site, in Charleston, S.C.

headline: Presidential Primary Lulz
text: In riffing on the multiple reasons that I’m enjoying the Republican nomination process as a supremely entertaining piece of transmedia storytelling, I made passing mention of Rick Perry’s Unpopular Opinions, a one-topic Tumblr inspired by the Texas governor’s ad titled “Strong.” In that spot, Perry asserted that “you know there’s something wrong in this country when gays can serve openly in the military, but our kids can’t openly celebrate Christmas.” The Internet found that argument laughably suspect, and in addition to making the YouTube version of the commercial one of the most “disliked” videos ever, responded with a barrage of interactive/remix mockery. The aforementioned Tumblr is a conspicuous example, and is made of up GIFs of the same self-assured, Carhartt-clad Perry from the commercial, captioned with phrases like “ ‘The Wire’ was a dumb show” and “Kim Jong the Second was a humane leader.”

headline: Ejected From a Job With a Band, Landing Back With Mom in Queens
text: About an hour into “Roadie,” a film about a middle-aged rock ’n’ roll Sherpa who’s lost his job and moorings, there’s a jumpy, viscerally uncomfortable scene in a motel room — a tempest fueled by booze and coke, old grudges and new hurts — that’s so strong and beautifully played that it lifts the movie out of its doldrums. A roadie, Jimmy Testagross (a gruffly tender Ron Eldard), has crawled back to his childhood home in Forest Hills, Queens, after being cut free by his longtime employer, Blue Oyster Cult. From his wounded look it seems as if he weren’t only fired, but also stripped of his identity. Refusing to admit the truth, even to himself, he tells everyone he’s the band’s manager.

headline: Concert Revenue Was Up in 2011, Led by U2
text: After one of its worst years in recent history, the concert industry rebounded slightly in 2011. But with consumers buying fewer tickets, the industry was still down from its peak in 2009.

headline: Hey, Kids, Don’t Mess With the Town Undertaker
text: Someone involved with “Beneath the Darkness” has either watched too many horror movies or not enough. There is not an original thought in this story, written by Bruce Wilkinson, or in the way it is directed by Martin Guigui. That makes for few genuine scares and, by the end, some unintended laughter as the proceedings grow too silly to bear.

headline: The Pander Waves of Grain
text: In Iowa earlier this week, Mitt Romney was guilty of an outrageous falsehood: He said that the “amber waves of grain” in the song “America the Beautiful” include corn.

headline: Obama Makes His Presence Felt in Iowa With Online Ad
text: As if competing against all the other Republican presidential candidates wasn’t hard enough.

headline: Political Role for Militants Worsens Fault Lines in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — It was one of the deadliest insurgent groups in Iraq in recent years, an Iranian-backed militia that bombed American military convoys and bases, assassinated dozens of Iraqi officials and tried to kidnap Americans even as the last soldiers withdrew.

headline: Santorum Insists West Bank Is ‘Part of Israel’
text: Following Rick Santorum’s sudden rise to prominence in the race for the Republican presidential nomination, new attention has been paid to his views on foreign policy issues, which apparently include a firm conviction that the West Bank is “part of Israel.”

headline: ‘Carnivorous Nights’
text: Photos of attendees at an event hosted by the Secret Science Club at the Bell House in Brooklyn.

headline: Taking Parking Lots Seriously
text: Images of different designs and uses of parking lots.

headline: Rally Against Bronx Science Principal, This Time By Students and Alumni
text: About two dozen current students and recent alumni gathered on the field across from the entrance to the Bronx High School of Science to protest the school's high rate of teacher turnover and what they perceive as a marked shift in the quality of classroom instruction.

headline: A Classroom Fight: The Tech Invaders
text: To the Editor:

headline: Under the Radar
text: Photos of the shows “Alexis. A Greek Tragedy” and “Goodbar.”

headline: Lesbian Alien Looks for Love Light Years Away
text: In “Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same,” Madeleine Olnek’s witty ode to urban love and shoestring sci-fi, a lonely Manhattanite and an exiled extraterrestrial find interspecies contentment.

headline: Angry Critters Spearhead an Ecological Battle
text: “Pom Poko” — one of the final offerings in the welcome Studio Ghibli retrospective at the IFC Center — wasn’t directed by the studio’s master animator, Hayao Miyazaki, but certainly bears his influence. Directed by Mr. Miyazaki’s frequent collaborator Isao Takahata, the film, from 1994, credits Mr. Miyazaki with “planning,” and it’s easy to see: its ecological concerns, nuance and occasional lyricism place it squarely within the Ghibli oeuvre but not among its masterpieces.

headline: Free Trade vs. Jobs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Can Ron Paul Move the Charts? Kelly Clarkson May Not Prove It
text: Attention politically opinionated pop stars: plugging a presidential candidate may not help your sales, especially if that candidate is Ron Paul.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
