text: Part 12: The filmmaker recalls the best thing he ever said to his wife.

headline: U.S. Navy Rescues Iranians Held by Pirates
text: Updated | 6:33 p.m. In the middle of a tense standoff between Iran and the United States, the crew of an American destroyer patrolling the North Arabian Sea rescued 13 Iranian fishermen who had been taken hostage by Somali pirates more than a month ago, the Pentagon announced on Friday.

headline: Tip of the Week: Make Your Own Shortcuts in Word
text: Microsoft Word, for both Windows and Mac OS X systems, is full of keyboard shortcuts to help speed things along as you work. Although the Web has plenty of pages listing the shortcuts (like Microsoft’s own collection for Word 2010), you can also generate your own chart right from the Word program itself — which can be handy if you want to print it or edit the list to add your own custom key commands.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Zombies Continue Their Reign
text: It has become old hat to see “The Walking Dead,” the series about human survivors in a world overrun by zombies, on our best-seller lists. This week, two more collected editions join the lists. On the hardcover list, the second omnibus of the series, which reprints issues 24 through 48 of the series, written by Robert Kirkman and illustrated by Charlie Adlard, arrives at No. 4. On the paperback list, vol. 15, which reprints issues 85 through 90, lands at the top spot. It’s in good company, with a compendium edition including the first 48 issues at No. 2, and vol. 1, which contains the first six issues, at No. 9.

headline: Baffling Reader Correspondence of the Week
text: In this past week’s Ethicist column, Edith Palmer of Brooklyn explained why her political differences with David Koch kept her from taking her granddaughter, Rachel, to see a production of “The Nutcracker” that he sponsored.

headline: TimesCast | January 6, 2012
text: A bomb kills at least 25 people in a Damascus neighborhood | The United States adds 200,000 new jobs in December.

headline: In Winter’s Chill, Vegetable Risotto Adapts
text: A RECENT ski trip with friends allowed me to transport the City Kitchen philosophy to the slopes. Our little group gets together annually to enjoy the invigorating and rejuvenating process of speeding downhill on fresh powder. We also spend a lot of time eating, drinking, making merry — and cooking.

headline: Megan Fox and Josh Duhamel, but No Optimus Prime
text: The Academy’s tagline for this year’s Oscars is “Celebrate the movies in all of us,” and with its first promo for the Feb. 26 show, to be broadcast on ABC, the movie they would most like to celebrate is … “Transformers.” Megan Fox and Josh Duhamel star in the spot, which pokes gentle fun at the dust-up over the ouster of Brett Ratner and Eddie Murphy as producer and host, and features cameos from William Fichtner (correctly cast as a version of the telecast’s new producer, spiky-haired Brian Grazer), Robin Williams and others. To be fair, the promo, made with the imprimatur of FunnyOrDie, also has shades of “Mission: Impossible” and “The Princess Bride,” at least in Mr. Crystal’s hair and makeup (although he looks more like Carol Kane). If it’s a sign of the kind of telecast we’ll see next month, we can bet on highly referential, high-production-value montages and familiar humor.

headline: The Myth of Japan’s Failure
text: Tokyo

headline: Giving Turnips a Second Look
text: Last fall, I was speaking with the Meatball Shop chef, Daniel Holzman, and the conversation turned to one of his favorite side dishes: Smashed Turnips With Fresh Horseradish.

headline: Fox News Hires Liz Cheney as Analyst and Substitute Host
text: Liz Cheney, the daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, is joining Fox News Channel as a paid contributor and substitute host, the channel confirmed Friday.

headline: A Risotto in Winter
text: The trick with risotto is learning how to cook it right, which takes a certain amount of repetition. A proper risotto is made by adding hot broth, in increments, to a particular kind of short-grained Italian rice (arborio or carnaroli) and cooking it, uncovered, over a brisk flame. Ideally it’s best to learn at the elbow of someone who knows how, because the process can be a bit difficult to describe. Risotto is not so much about a recipe as it is a technique. Once mastered, it is a joy to make.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Portlandia’
text: The second season of Carrie Brownstein and Fred Armisen’s rigorously lo-fi comedy “Portlandia” arrives on IFC on Friday night riding a relentless wave of hype. Not many shows this small-bore — six half-hour episodes in the first season, expanded to 10 for Season 2 — get this kind of attention, with late-night guest spots, a red-carpet New York premiere (for the second season!) and a tour, which comes to Brooklyn and Manhattan on Jan. 20 and 21.

headline: Filmmakers Take Dual Roles in Quest for Truth
text: WHEN the Arkansas men known as the West Memphis Three were released from prison this summer, it was a momentous occasion not only for those convicts, who had each spent nearly 20 years behind bars for murders they say they did not commit, but also for the people who had followed their case and become convinced of their innocence.

headline: Romney and Santorum See Bounce in South Carolina Poll
text: Now that Iowa’s caucus is over, the candidates’ standings are rolling in from the next set of states in the primary lineup. And more poll results are expected before the day is over.

headline: Romney Leads South Carolina Polls
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — The first South Carolina polls in more than two weeks are out, and they show a lead for Mitt Romney but with Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich in a competitive position.

headline: A Historical Cycle Bodes Ill for the Markets
text: AT the turn of the last century, it was widely accepted that American stocks were virtually certain to be good long-term investments. Now, far fewer people are confident of that.

headline: Dean & DeLuca Baking Its Own Breads
text: Nearly 35 years after Dean & DeLuca opened its first shop, on Prince Street in SoHo, this specialty-food chain has made another big leap. It has started baking its own bread, in a kitchen on West 28th Street, instead of selling only a collection of breads from companies like Sullivan Street Bakery and Amy’s Bread. The baker is Louis Volle, above, a 28-year-old New Yorker who grew up in France and worked at Fauchon before returning to bake bread at Per Se and Bouchon Bakery. He has introduced a basic baguette and a fine round sourdough at Dean & DeLuca, as well as some less-common standouts. In Mr. Volle’s hands, pain de mie, a dense French white bread meant for slicing, has a beautifully fluted crust and is delicious as a substitute for brioche, with a slab of pâté. His dark chestnut bread has a deep earthiness. Several other loaves are studded with fruits and nuts.

headline: The View From L.S.U.: It’s Jordan Jefferson’s Team Now
text: Finally, the day is near.

headline: The View From Alabama: A Rematch Is the Right Thing
text: Alabama Crimson Tide players sat at their team banquet on Dec. 4 awaiting the final B.C.S. standings to see if they would get a second chance against the Louisiana State Tigers.

headline: S.E.C. Changes Policy on Firms’ Admission of Guilt
text: WASHINGTON — The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a fundamental policy shift, said Friday that it would no longer allow defendants to say they neither admit nor deny civil fraud or insider trading charges when, at the same time, they admit to or have been convicted of criminal violations.

headline: In the City, but Not of It
text: THE grand houses of Fieldston — about 260, all single-family — are mostly generations old, devoid of the uniformity in other parts of the city and in suburban subdivisions. Nearly a century after it was conceived, this flowing suburban community in the northwest corner of the Bronx retains its dash of country, as well as its easy access to city life, having kept faith with its developers’ original vision.

headline: On Radio, Mayor Shares Wide-Ranging Thoughts on Politics
text: An unusually analytic Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday reflected on the political landscape, describing in a radio interview why he tries to support Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, revealing an interest in the presidential candidacy of Jon Huntsman, and theorizing that the rise of air travel has contributed to the decline of bipartisanship in Washington.

headline: Economists Take Solace (but Only a Little) in Jobs Report
text: Economists viewed the latest jobs numbers as at least moderately encouraging, although some of them warned, as usual, against reading too much into the results of any single month — especially December.

headline: Notes Hover a Moment, Speed-Land the Next
text: The pianist Steven Beck has become a mainstay at Bargemusic over the last decade and has been heard there in an enormous range of repertory, including a complete Beethoven sonata cycle; plenty of Bach, Brahms and Debussy; and a goodly amount of chamber music, both familiar and unusual. But he has become best known as an eloquent and persuasive performer of contemporary works.

headline: City Warns Against Scam Training Schools
text: The city's consumer affairs commissioner shares tips with WNYC's Brian Lehrer on how to avoid predatory G.E.D. or vocational programs that can't offer the degrees or jobs they promise, but will help you run up your student loan bills.

headline: ‘It’s Nice That . . . ‘
text: As an art director I’m constantly scanning design, illustration and art blogs to seek out new talent for the magazine.

headline: Brooklyn's Rube Goldberg
text: Joseph Herscher builds Rube Goldberg machines in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. In this video he constructs his newest contraption, called “Page Turner.”

headline: Gleeful Sounds From Memories of Childhood
text: THE success of “Glee” and “American Idol” in the last few years would seem to make Hollywood particularly amenable to the work of Todd Graff, a writer-director who describes himself as “a big old musical theater queen from way back.” His résumé is eclectic, but the films that are nearest to his heart involve characters making music in one form or another.

headline: Jenna Miranda and Mitch Meyers
text: HANGING out with her girlfriends and dating fun-loving men was the norm for free-spirited Jenna Gayle Miranda, who grew up in Miami. So when Mitchell Douglas Meyers approached her at a sports bar in Bloomington, Ind., seven and a half years ago while they were students at Indiana University, she was game for a friendly conversation.

headline: U.S. to Ban New Uranium Mining Near Grand Canyon
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar is expected to announce on Monday that he has approved a 20-year moratorium on new uranium mining claims in a million-acre buffer zone around the Grand Canyon.

headline: Under the Radar: 5 Questions About ‘Word Becomes Flesh’
text: This year’s Under the Radar festival will be a homecoming for Marc Bamuthi Joseph. His 2003 spoken word piece, “Word Becomes Flesh,” a one-man show told as a series of letters from fathers to their unborn sons, returns to the festival lineup after being presented at the first Under the Radar in 2005. (It also had a run at the former Dance Theater Workshop in 2004.)

headline: HTC’s Decline Is Samsung’s Gain
text: Samsung Electronics on Friday posted record fourth-quarter profits, citing high sales of its Android devices, while HTC, another major Android player, reported a drop in profits, its first decline in two years.Samsung, based in Seoul, South Korea, said its profits increased 73 percent compared to 2010’s fourth quarter. It cited record-breaking sales of its smartphones, as well as the sale of its hard drive business to Seagate.

headline: Finley Helps Yi, Prepping Own Comeback?

headline: Who Says Machines Must Be Useful?
text: ON the roof of a small row house in Brooklyn, a black powder fuse flared brightly against the gray sky. Hissing and sparking, it burned through a platform installed inside a repurposed Ikea bookshelf, sending four colored balls into action, lighting camp stoves, swinging fly swatters and knocking over books in a frenetic burst of organized chaos. In less than a minute, the final ball had dropped to the ground and was pocketed by Joseph Herscher, 26, the kinetic artist behind this real-world Rube Goldberg machine.

headline: What Are You Paying More for in 2012?
text: The new year is a time for rebirth and renewal. It’s also a time for businesses to squeeze a few more pennies out of their customers.

headline: In Rome, Bending Joints but Limiting the Budget
text: The true star of “The Devil Inside,” the latest addition to the fake, hand-shaky documentary horror subgenre, is a flexible little miss with the fabulous name Pixie Le Knot. That performer, whose name appears fairly low in the credits, surely deserves a higher berth, given the visceral impact her shoulder popping and back bending had on the audience I saw the movie with. The men around me all went, “Ew” — me, I wanted to head straight to yoga class.

headline: NBC Entertainment Head Weighs In on ‘Community,’ ’30 Rock’ and ‘House’

text: The White House will propose a 0.5 percent pay raise for civilian federal employees in the 2013 budget, an administration official said on Friday.

headline: ‘24/7’ Episode 4: A Final Salute
text: There were so many story lines woven into the Winter Classic between the Flyers and the Rangers, you had to wonder how HBO could possibly do it justice. Sean Avery was waived. Ilya Bryzgalov was benched (and went straight to the news media). Marc Staal was cleared to play. Questionable calls were followed by questionable reactions.

headline: Duck Versus Duck: Pitting Ssam Bar’s Duck Lunch Against Wong’s Duckavore Dinner
text: “DUCK really is the other pork, isn’t it?” a friend observed last week. And of course, she’s right. The two animals meander around the barnyard, grazing and grunting and generally acting like hungry teenagers. But all the while they are building up a formidable cushion of sweet fat that has the miraculous quality of improving just about any food it touches.

headline: On Our Radar: Road Checks for Invasive Species
text: For the first time, state officers in Minnesota will conduct random road checks this year for invasive species that could be hitchhiking on trailers, boats and other vehicles. [Duluth News Tribune]

headline: Victor Cruz Decides Not to Go ‘Dancing’
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – Part of the reason Giants receiver Victor Cruz’s popularity has exploded this season – beyond his franchise-record 1,536 receiving yards – is his trademark salsa dance, which he has done after most of his 9 touchdowns.

headline: Perseverance in a Collapsing World
text: IN Meg Stuart’s “Blessed” a white-clad man in sandals — picture a Brazilian hippie passing a lazy day at the beach — traverses a stage that resembles a storybook island. His flattened movement gives him the two-dimensional air of Nijinsky on holiday. But there’s something not quite right about this strange scene: the set, which features a palm tree, a hut with a chair and an enormous swan, is made entirely of cardboard. Soon enough it begins to rain. There’s trouble ahead.

headline: Remembering an A.T.F. Officer Killed While Trying to Stop a Robber
text: A funeral service was held Friday in Seaford, N.Y., for John Capano, a federal agent, who was shot by a retired Nassau County police officer during a confused situation last Saturday while trying to detain a man who had robbed a pharmacy, according to law enforcement officials.

text: WASHINGTON — Democrats took to the floor of an empty House chamber on Friday to mock Republicans who they said were taking a vacation rather than buckling down to work on legislation to create jobs, cut taxes and extend unemployment benefits for millions of Americans.

headline: With Nook Plan, Barnes & Noble Readies Another Shake-Up
text: Barnes & Noble is trying to shake up its business by potentially spinning off its fast-growing Nook business. This is yet another effort by the bookseller to rejigger its operations, amid a history replete with spinoffs and attempted deals.

headline: Prostate Cancer Screening Shows No Benefit
text: Updated findings from one of the largest studies of prostate cancer screening show that the commonly used P.S.A. blood test did not save lives, although questions remain about whether younger men or those at very high risk for the disease might benefit.

headline: C.D.C. May Lower Threshold for Lead Poisoning
text: A federal advisory committee has recommended that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lower the threshold for diagnosing lead poisoning in children, the first recommendation of its kind in 20 years and one that would mean hundreds of thousands more kids meet the standard for lead poisoning.

headline: Another Crowd Confronts Santorum

text: A reader worries about whether teachers can require students to join Facebook, and about possible legal ramifications. Linda Fogg Phillips, who is Facebook's consultant on education and parent issues, responds to her query.

headline: How the Spurs Can Survive Without Ginobili
text: San Antonio’s Manu Ginobili will miss six weeks of action as he recovers from surgery on his left hand, but so far the Spurs have been just fine without him. That won’t last; although San Antonio has pulled off a comeback win and a dominant blowout victory over the last two days, this team is unquestionably lesser without Ginobili in the lineup.

headline: More Time to Buy in Italy, but Is That a Good Thing?
text: ROME — The first days of the new year have heralded a subtle revolution in Italy: the deregulation of operating hours for commercial venues like shops, bars and restaurants. And as revolutions tend to go, the measure has aroused praise in some corners and howls of protest in others.

headline: Bjork Bringing ‘Biophilia’ to New York
text: Bjork said on Friday that she would perform her “Biophilia” show for 10 nights in New York in February. The residency will mark the first time the Icelandic singer and songwriter has brought the elaborate stage performance of her recent compositions about nature to North America. Six performances will take place at the New York Hall of Science in Queens, starting on Feb. 3, and four shows will be staged at Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan, beginning on Feb. 22. No other performances have been scheduled in the United States. The show had its premiere at the Manchester International Festival in England and has received ecstatic reviews from critics. Performed in the round, it features a 24-woman choir, a giant Tesla coil and several large custom-built instruments that Bjork and her collaborators invented: a portable pipe organ, four 10-foot pendulums that play harp notes as they swing, a gramophone-like contraption called a “Sharpsichord” and another piece called a “gameleste,” which is a fusion of a celesta and a gamelan. The songs are eerie and convoluted, with unusual melodies and fluctuating meters, meant to capture the patterns in natural phenomena like those of gravity, lunar cycles, DNA and crystals.

headline: Laid Off, With Retirement Almost in Sight
text: Achieving financial security in retirement is hard enough for most working Americans. But for those who lost their jobs just as the finish line was within sight, the whole notion may now seem out of reach.

headline: Just One Look | Lanvin
text: “This collection is about fabric, technology and volume,” Alber Elbaz said at the start of his prefall presentation earlier today. Citing innovations in fabric — first, with the incorporation of metals into knits and wovens, and now with things that have been bonded, plastified and waxed — as his muse, Elbaz went on to show a collection full of texture (felted wool and fox), shine (sequins and coated cotton so glossy it looks wet) and stunning proportions (fly-away jackets and exaggerated, egg-shaped shoulders). Here, a romantic all-emerald look that illustrates all three of Elbaz’s points is anchored by a giant cameo pendant.

headline: At Risk, the Core of a Car’s Identity

headline: Some Tips for Unemployed Older Americans
text: Though the latest jobs report provided some reason for tempered optimism, older Americans who find themselves unemployed are typically out of work much longer than their younger peers. And that can make the road to retirement much more challenging.

headline: Tributes That Leave Hollywood Speechless
text: HOLLYWOOD’S collective fascination with the silent-film era is hitting a peak with “Hugo” and “The Artist,” each a homage to a bygone time. The tributes continue with Film Forum’s series of MGM silent features, complete with live piano accompaniment (through Feb. 6); an exhibition at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts (through Feb. 25); and a new DVD release of the recent restoration of the only known color copy of the 1902 Georges Méliès masterpiece “A Trip to the Moon,” which is featured in “Hugo.”

In the age of the horseless carriage, the transportation historian James Flink wrote, electric cars looked even more like carriages.

headline: Outside the Electric Box
text: Electric car manufacturers are adopting one of two overriding design philosophies: make it exciting, or make it familiar.

headline: Humphries, the Boo-Birds’ New King

He’s so unpopular that he’s being soundly booed in arenas across the country if he dare sets foot on the court. In Toronto the other night, fans mocked him by waving large posters.

headline: For a Team Called Soft, Falcons Run With Ferocity
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — The Atlanta Falcons, who play their home games in the living-room comfort of a domed stadium, began practice outdoors here Wednesday morning in a 38-degree chill, but without topcoats. A national radio sports talk host labeled the Falcons a finesse team that will capitulate in the kind of chilly, sloppy weather the Giants occasionally play in, which made Falcons running back Michael Turner laugh.

headline: British Clarification on Implant Scandal Leaves Women Only More Confused
text: LONDON — The British government said on Friday that there was still not enough evidence to recommend routine removal of breast implants made by a now-defunct French company using silicone of dubious quality. But it also said that it would allow about 3,000 women who received the implants under the National Health Service to have them taken out and replaced free of charge if they and their doctors decided it was “right to do so.”

headline: U.S. to Expand Its Definition of Rape in Statistics
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government is changing its longstanding definition of “forcible rape” in compiling national crime statistics — expanding both the definition of victims, to include males, and the types of sexual assault that will be counted in the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s Uniform Crime Report.

headline: A Short Career in Lurid Hollywood
text: DOROTHY MACKAILL may be having her moment. When this British-born actress, a star in silent films and early talkies, died in 1990 at 87, she merited only a 153 word obituary in The New York Times. And the unsigned article didn’t even mention the movie most responsible for her current revival: “Safe in Hell,” a 1931 melodrama that seems remarkably lurid and sordid even by the loose standards that prevailed before Hollywood began enforcing the production code with vigor in 1934.

headline: The F.D.A.’s Token Gesture
text: My column last week described how the Food and Drug Administration is declining to regulate the use of antibiotics in animal agriculture. After withdrawing its own 34-year-old request/promise to restrict the routine use of penicillin and tetracyclines in farm animal feed, the F.D.A. made it crystal clear that, despite the increasingly common threat of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in supermarket meat, it would leave the regulating up to industry itself.

headline: A Search for a Child, or Maybe Her Mom’s Marbles
text: There’s something perhaps inadvertently timely about “Bunny Lake Is Missing,” now at the Brick in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. This stage noir, about a single mother’s desperate search for her 3-year-old daughter after she disappears from nursery school, speaks to parental anxiety in an age when child abuse seems rife. The play — based on Evelyn Piper’s 1957 pulp mystery (the source for Otto Preminger’s 1965 screen adaptation) — derives tension from its resonant, inescapable subtext.

headline: Hearing to Scrutinize Medicaid Reimbursement to Schools
text: The New York City Council will hold a public hearing next month to scrutinize the Education Department’s system for collecting Medicaid reimbursements for services it provides to special-needs students, after a report in The New York Times last week about the city’s failure to recover many millions of dollars in reimbursements in recent years.

headline: ‘Super Night Shot’
text: Scenes from the show from the British-German troupe Gob Squad.

headline: Romney Times Four
text: FOUR of Mitt Romney’s five sons — Tagg, 41; Matt, 40; Josh, 36; and Craig, 30 — were sitting in a hotel room in Des Moines on the eve of the Iowa caucuses last week, debating which of them was most likely to carry the Romney mantle of politics and public service. The verdict was Mr. Romney’s oldest son, Tagg, or maybe Josh. But that’s where things got tricky.

headline: Labor Board Backs Workers on Joint Arbitration Cases
text: The National Labor Relations Board ruled on Friday that employers could not prevent workers from filing work-related group or class actions, essentially banning employment agreements at many companies that require workers to pursue all claims individually through arbitration.

headline: Hey, You, Would You Mind Being in Our Movie?
text: Disposable fame is sweet in “Super Night Shot,” the collective title for the instant films being shown at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar Festival. The mission of this project from the British-German troupe Gob Squad is to wage “the war against anonymity.” Now that is something you might argue that the United States has been doing quite well on its own, thank you, what with all those hungry reality TV shows that require regular feeding.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Ice Pack
text: It was 13 degrees out! Collars were pulled up, caps were pulled down, scarves were twisted round and round, and eyes peered out of narrow slits.

headline: Feminine Truth, Pursued in Breathing Exercises
text: “You don’t have to judge anything.”

headline: Turning a Page, the Joseph Herscher Way
text: A step-by-step visual detailing one of Mr. Herscher’s Rube Goldberg machines.

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 6
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include New Year’s Eve celebrations, renovations at the State Capitol and the funeral for three sisters killed in a Christmas morning fire.

headline: Film About the Hunt for Bin Laden Leads to a Pentagon Investigation
text: LOS ANGELES — When the movies get real, moviemakers can count on real headaches.

headline: Juan Rivera Goes Free
text: Juan Rivera, the subject of Andy Martin’s Nov. 27 article, “The Prosecution’s Case Against DNA,” was released this evening from the Stateville Correctional Center near Joliet, Ill., 19 years after being convicted of the murder of 11-year-old Holly Staker. Martin wrote about (and discusses in this video) the state’s attorney’s office in Lake County, Ill., and their novel theories to explain away exculpatory DNA evidence in Rivera’s case and others. Michael Mermel, the prosecutor quoted extensively in Martin’s article, was asked in early December to leave his position. Michael J. Waller, the Lake County state’s attorney, said: “The comments attributed to Mike Mermel do not reflect my views on the role of the Lake County state’s attorney’s office. Nor do they reflect the manner in which my staff has conducted themselves over the last 21 years.”

headline: Mets Sign Ronny Cedeno
text: The Mets agreed to terms with the Venezuelan infielder Ronny Cedeno on a one-year contract worth $1.1 million with extra performance bonuses based on playing time in the event he becomes a regular player.

headline: Anticipating M.L.K. Day
text: How do you think the civil rights movement should be taught? What can be done to freshen the content and stimulate students' understanding of this crucial period of American history? We ask as schools commemorate Martin Luther King Jr. Day on Jan. 16 and head into Black History Month in February.

headline: A Very Good Year for Nicki Minaj
text: The rapid rise of the hip-hop star Nicki Minaj within the fashion world.

headline: More Polls Cement Romney’s Lead in New Hampshire
text: Echoing Friday morning’s Suffolk University tracking poll, two new statewide polls in New Hampshire show Mitt Romney firmly in place as the front-runner, with Rick Santorum and Ron Paul gaining support in the wake of their strong finishes in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: The Mod Classicist in the Mirror
text: We now come to the analogy part of the exam. Please assess the following as true or false.

headline: Where You Can Pull Your Own Guinness
text: I STILL remember the first time I had a Guinness properly poured and at the optimal (not too cool) temperature. It was in a small pub in a small town in Ireland, and it was like nothing I’d ever tasted — thick and rich and full of flavor. I wanted to drink it slowly, almost eat it with a spoon. I had dinner that night, too, but I couldn’t tell you what I had: The experience was all about the beer.

headline: My Back Pages: Digital Diary Traces Memories
text: LIKE many 29-year-old Web designers from Brooklyn, Kelsey Rahn spent part of New Year’s Day hung over, poring over a list of resolutions. “Make more time for myself.” “Make soup in my Crock-Pot twice a month.” “Join the gym by Friday.”

headline: Ambience Is Gothic, but Flavor Is Mexican
text: UNLIKE most Mexican restaurants, Red Lulu Cocina and Tequila Bar, in South Norwalk, favors clubby gothic over cactus and sombrero. Its ornate chandeliers, some adorned with black birds, are set to a dim luminescence. Capacious booths, with privacy draperies, surround a cruciform communal table decked out with a super-elongated candelabrum. There is a surfeit of red throughout — from the velour curtains by the entrance to the lights strung along the railing of the upstairs balcony. And films projected onto one of two brick walls add to the sense of hyperactivity.

headline: Sitting and Drinking and Flirting and Pondering Life With Your Multiple Selves
text: Outside the curtained door are two lights, one green and one red. When the green light comes on, you pass one of your allotted cards between the curtains and into an unseen hand. When the red light comes on, you enter. Inside you meet yourself.

headline: Steelers Assistant Sustains Burns in a House Fire
text: The Pittsburgh Steelers’ running backs sensed something was wrong when they arrived at work on Friday for an early-morning film session in preparation for their Sunday playoff game against the Denver Broncos and their coach, Kirby Wilson, was not there.

headline: 2013 Scion FR-S
text: 2013 Scion FR-S slide show

headline: Obama Has Lunch With Contest Winners — From Swing States
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama dined for the second time with four winners of the quarterly “Dinner With Barack” contest, and for the second time, all four winners were from states that the Obama campaign considers battlegrounds that could help determine whether Mr. Obama is re-elected.

headline: In H.P. Tale, a Question of Truth or Titillation
text: “Ms. Fisher was scared. She was a nervous wreck but attempted to appear relaxed. She sat down on one of two love seats in the sitting room. She was worried when you came over and sat directly next to her and put your arm on the back of the love seat. As you did so, your hand brushed across her breast. ... It happened a second time and Ms. Fisher said ‘you know that you are touching my breast, right?’ You said, ‘Oh, sorry, sorry’ and then laughed it off.”

headline: Indian Cuisine With a Glossy Finish
text: MINT makes a good first impression. The restaurant, a seven-month-old Garden City branch of an Indian restaurant in Manhattan, is a beauty.

headline: A Long History of Political Brawling for Santorum
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Rick Santorum loves professional wrestling, and has been thrilled to meet savage icons of the squared circle like Bruno Sammartino, Gorilla Monsoon and Hulk Hogan. He even lobbied for the World Wrestling Federation for a while.

headline: John Paulson’s Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Year
text: The pain of 2011 has finally ended for John A. Paulson, the billionaire founder of the hedge fund Paulson & Company.

headline: A Taste of Old Beirut, With Quirks All Its Own
text: THERE is no shortage of worthy Middle Eastern restaurants sprinkled throughout northern New Jersey, from mom-and-pop falafel joints to white-tablecloth establishments, but few offer quite the same array of offbeat charms as Kamil’s Lebanese Cuisine.

headline: Morgan Stanley Discloses Stakes in Zynga and LinkedIn
text: Morgan Stanley, as of late the go-to underwriter for tech initial public offerings, disclosed its stakes in Zynga and LinkedIn on Friday, according to securities filings.

headline: Big Payday for Yahoo’s New Chief
text: Scott Thompson is getting a very friendly welcome to Yahoo.

headline: Illinois: Inmate Cleared by DNA Is Freed
text: A man who has been convicted three times in the 1992 murder of an 11-year-old baby sitter in suburban Chicago was released from prison on Friday after a local prosecutor decided not to challenge an appellate court’s ruling that reversed the last conviction. The man, Juan Rivera, 39, had been incarcerated at the Stateville Correctional Center in the far southwest suburbs of Chicago. The Lake County state’s attorney, Michael Waller, in a statement defended his office’s prosecution of Mr. Rivera, whose case was featured in an article in The New York Times Magazine. “I am mindful that for Mr. Rivera and some others, this decision will be viewed as too late in coming,” Mr. Waller said. Though there was no physical evidence linking Mr. Rivera to the crime, he was convicted of raping and murdering the baby sitter, Holly Staker, based largely on his confession. In 2005, DNA testing determined that Mr. Rivera was not the source of semen found inside Holly, and he was awarded a new trial, his third. Mr. Rivera was convicted again. In its reversal order last month, the appellate court suggested that Mr. Rivera’s confession was coerced. The investigation into Holly’s murder has been reopened.

headline: Council Member Resigns and Pleads Guilty
text: Harry Thomas Jr. pleaded guilty on Friday to charges that he stole from programs receiving federal money and filed a false tax return. Mr. Thomas resigned from the Council of the District of Columbia on Thursday night. Judge John D. Bates of Federal District Court said that Mr. Thomas could spend up to 47 months in prison and that the sentence would determined at a hearing on May 3.

headline: For Iranians Waylaid by Pirates, U.S. to the Rescue
text: ABOARD THE FISHING VESSEL AL MULAHI, in the Gulf of Oman — Senior Iranian military officials this week bluntly warned an American aircraft carrier that it would confront the “full force” of the Iranian military if it tried to re-enter the Persian Gulf.

headline: Don Carter, First Big Star of Golden Era of Bowling, Dies at 85
text: Baseball had Babe Ruth, boxing had Jack Johnson, and, during its golden age in the 1950s, bowling had Don Carter.

headline: A Billionaire Lends Haiti a Hand
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Almost two years after an earthquake ravaged this city, some half a million people are still living in filthy tents, cholera has infected a similar number across the country and the president works from a flimsy prefab structure behind the still crumpled Presidential Palace.

headline: At a New Theater, Ambitious and Varied Beginnings
text: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y.

headline: A Tie for Players of the Year
text: Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York City scored a trifecta at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan at the end of December. They won the two main events, the Truscott Board-a-Match (with their teammates, R. Jay Becker and Chris Willenken of New York City) and the Goldman Pairs. And these victories gave them enough points to tie as the Greater New York Bridge Association’s Players of the Year and Team Players of the Year. They were well ahead as Players of the Year, but won the Team Player by only one point from Willenken.

headline: Senator Says His Concerns With Nominee Aren’t Personal
text: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey denied Friday that he was blocking an Obama administration nominee to a federal judgeship because of a grudge against her longtime companion, who led a corruption investigation of the senator during his tough election fight of 2006.

text: BEIJING

text: MANCHESTER, N.H.

headline: Bahrain Rights Activist Says He Was Beaten During Attack on Protest
text: Updated | Saturday | 10:57 a.m. A prominent human rights activist in Bahrain was briefly hospitalized on Friday night after the security forces attacked a protest in the capital, Manama.

headline: Penn State’s Choice of Coach Displeases Former Players
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The news that Bill O’Brien would become Penn State’s first new football coach in almost a half century upset some former Nittany Lions players, left some observers wondering why the search took nearly eight weeks, and moved fans here and afar to ask: “Who?”

headline: EMI Label Sues ReDigi, the Used Digital Music Store
text: Another day, another lawsuit over digital music.

headline: A Tough Question for Mitt Romney
text: At a town hall in Tilton, a New Hampshire voter cited Mr. Romney’s personal wealth in a question about tax cuts.

headline: Lululemon Athletica’s Founder Takes a Step Back
text: Lululemon Athletica, the yoga wear retailer, said on Friday that Dennis J. Wilson, its founder and former chief executive, would leave his remaining executive role as chief innovation and branding officer at the end of January. The company, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, offered no explanation about the move. He will remain as chairman. Christine Day, a former Starbucks executive, has been the company’s chief executive since 2008. Mr. Wilson, who is known as Chip, has said that he was greatly influenced by Ayn Rand and has used her books, which promote the idea of people living for their self-interest, to guide his business. Last November, Lululemon provoked an outcry from some customers after it used the opening line from Rand’s “Atlas Shrugged” on its shopping bags.

headline: L.S.U. Cornerback Is Overshadowed, but Not Overlooked
text: NEW ORLEANS — There is no Vince Young, Cam Newton or Tim Tebow in the Bowl Championship Series title game this year. The most recognizable star in Monday’s game between Louisiana State and Alabama is the flamboyant L.S.U. defensive back Tyrann Mathieu, who said Thursday that he researched the names of his opponents’ mothers in order to talk trash to them.

headline: N.C.A.A.’s ‘Justice’ System
text: I stand corrected.

headline: The Capital of Sports
text: NEW ORLEANS — On Friday, players from Alabama and Louisiana State answered questions on the field at the Superdome, where S-A-I-N-T-S spread across the end zones and the B.C.S. national championship game logo decorated midfield. Such is life here, at the center of the American sports universe.

headline: Wall Street Braces for Dismal 4th Quarter
text: For most Wall Street bankers, 2011 was a year they would rather forget. Investors will soon find out just how bad that year was for the country’s biggest financial institutions.

headline: Santorum Concedes He Is Unlikely to Win in New Hampshire
text: NASHUA, N.H. — Rick Santorum conceded Friday night that he was unlikely to win the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, but said he was proud of the progress he had made.

headline: Paul, After Texas Detour, Gets Back to the Campaign
text: NASHUA, N.H. — Representative Ron Paul made his first presidential campaign appearance Friday at the rather leisurely hour of 2 p.m. — his first stop in New Hampshire since finishing third at the Iowa caucuses three days before.

headline: Celebrating Fluxus, a Movement That Didn’t Create by the Rules
text: Last year was a big one for Fluxus, despite the fact that this international network of artists, composers and poetic pranksters has been defunct for several decades. Attention in art history is often bestowed posthumously, however, and because 2011 was the 50th anniversary of Fluxus’s first New York project — an exhibition in book form of performance-related materials — half a dozen shows have been mounted locally to commemorate the group’s existence. One of them is “at/around/beyond: Fluxus at Rutgers University” at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick.

headline: One Bad Energy Subsidy Expires
text: Now that the most polarized and paralyzed Congress in memory has managed to kill one of its most resilient boondoggles — the three-decade-old, multibillion-dollar subsidy for corn ethanol — we hope it has not exhausted its resolve and will take a hatchet to other harmful energy subsidies, chiefly those it gives to fossil fuels.

headline: U.S. Navy Intercepts Pirate Attack
text: The aircraft carrier John C. Stennis broke up a high-seas pirate attack on a cargo ship in the Gulf of Oman, freeing 13 Iranian hostages who had been held captive by pirates for more than a month.

headline: Waiting for Recovery
text: In its broad strokes, the December employment report is an upbeat finish to a difficult year. Job growth accelerated, the workweek expanded modestly, wages ticked up and the unemployment rate declined.

headline: Another Step Up for a Bronx Native Who Led the Archdiocese in Baltimore
text: The other American elevated to cardinal by the Vatican on Friday is a Bronx boy who exercises regularly on a treadmill, roots ardently for the Yankees and, according to friends, is so devoted to the idea of doing what he asks others to do that he learned how to parachute before serving as a military chaplain in Vietnam.

headline: Haitians in Brazil
text: Fleeing misery, Haitians head to Brazil in search of work and a better life.

headline: For Father Working Three Jobs, a Startling Diagnosis
text: The morning of March 31, 2009, is stamped on Jose Perez’s brain. He woke up with stabbing pains in his legs. His wife called an ambulance, and he was taken to Staten Island University Hospital. A nurse ran a blood test. Half an hour later, five doctors walked into his room.

headline: Haitians Take Arduous Path to Brazil, and Jobs
text: BRASILÉIA, Brazil — Of the odyssey that delivered him to this town in the Brazilian Amazon, Wesley Saint-Fleur could muster only a look of exhaustion and bewilderment.

headline: Lax Security, Stacks of Cash: Robbers’ Easy Pickings
text: The first robbery occurred on July 29. Or maybe not. At MetroPCS cellphone stores, it is hard to keep count, and five months later, a manager in Brownsville, Brooklyn, could not remember if that was the day he himself was held up at gunpoint, or if someone else was.

headline: Giants Say Captains Earn Respect
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Not many Giants watched the boiling point moment in the Jets’ season-ending defeat last weekend, when an in-the-huddle fracas banished wide receiver Santonio Holmes to the sideline and a solitary seat on the bench. But the Giants knew what had happened or had seen televised video of it.

headline: Dolan Elevated as Pope Names New Cardinals
text: Pope Benedict XVI named 22 new cardinals on Friday, including Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York, in a set of appointments that reflected the pope’s reliance on Italians and Vatican insiders at a time when the church’s population base has shifted to the Southern Hemisphere.

headline: A Shrinking Military Budget May Take Neighbors With It
text: WASHINGTON — Military spending has transformed the faded farmlands of northern Virginia into a land of glass-block office parks, oversize homes and sleek cars. Average household incomes there are among the highest in the United States.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Common-Sense Immigration Move
text: The Obama administration is taking a major step toward bolstering legal immigration and protecting families — while removing some of the arbitrary cruelty from the workings of the immigration bureaucracy. It announced on Friday that it would change a notorious process to avoid separating families when immigrants apply to become legal permanent residents.

headline: In New Hampshire, Fiscal Anxiety Despite Relative Economic Health
text: PITTSFIELD, N.H. — Karen Eastman has worked at the same small manufacturing company for 18 years and makes a solid living stitching sleeves for firefighter coats, but the economy is still her foremost concern heading into this state’s presidential primary voting next week.

headline: Plenty of Sun, but Few Stars, on Opening Day in Hawaii
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii

headline: Romney Advantages Could Prove Disadvantageous
text: TILTON, N.H. — The advantages for Mitt Romney are abundant in the Republican presidential primary here, but there is one obstacle that stands far taller than Rick Santorum, Newt Gingrich or any rival: The inclination of New Hampshire to knock a front-runner down to size.

headline: Shaky Knicks Rally to Keep Wizards Winless
text: WASHINGTON — The desperation was spelled out on the scoreboard, across the Knicks’ bench and finally in their lineup. They were teetering on the edge of disaster before finding momentary salvation from sources both obvious and unexpected.

headline: Finding Beauty in Land
text: Americans were not in the forefront of advanced art in the 19th century, but they did have one thing going for them: an interest in the novel and innovative. And so they embraced Impressionism — a radical, anti-academic movement at that time, though today it has come to seem like a tasteful and slightly saccharine idiom (think of Thomas Kinkade, the mass-market painter who has trademarked himself as a neo-Impressionist “Painter of Light”).

headline: Relax, if You Want, but Don’t Put Your Feet Up
text: William D. Peppers recalled how empty the subway car was. It was not yet 4 a.m. on a Friday, so most of New York was still asleep, but he was already late for his job at a Bronx bakery. As his train passed through Midtown Manhattan, Mr. Peppers stretched out, closed his eyes and nodded off.

headline: Living Amid the Violence in Iraq
text: The boom and shudder of numerous explosions woke me. It was my first morning in Baghdad in nearly five years, and, coincidentally, only days after the withdrawal of the American troops from Iraq.

headline: Saturday: One Whose Head Is Turned
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Now that’s a fairly wide open grid, isn’t it? Joe Krozel has used that grid before (Across Lite, Solution, blog), and he’s back today with another 64-word puzzle that builds what looks to me like the beginnings of a log cabin: we have those double stacks of 15’s crossing each other near the edges of the grid. And they are some pretty nifty 15’s, I must say.

headline: ‘Occupy’ Protesters in New Hampshire Seek Visibility Ahead of Primary
text: Occupy New Hampshire has a full slate of events ahead of the state’s primary on Tuesday, but many members of the group are distancing themselves from some of the tactics that saw members of Occupy the Caucus arrested last week in Iowa.

headline: Inspector at Fire Dept. Took Bribes, Officials Say
text: A longtime Fire Department employee who oversaw safety inspections of day care centers in New York City was charged on Friday with accepting thousands of dollars in bribes for ignoring or playing down safety violations.

headline: Chinese News Agency Warns Against U.S. Moves
text: SHANGHAI — China’s state-run news media warned Washington on Friday not to “recklessly practice militarism” or engage in “war mongering,” a day after the Obama administration outlined a new military strategy with an increased focus on China.

headline: Michelle Obama as Critic and Advocate
text: Mrs. Obama’s adjustment to the White House — including, at times, severe tension with her husband’s staff — illuminates some of President Obama’s central challenges.

headline: Mets, in Hiring Financial Firm, Insist It’s Not About Bankruptcy
text: CRG Partners lists as its special talents financial advisory work, restructuring and reorganization, and turnaround management — polite descriptions of services needed by companies in distress. The firm’s Web site names a long list of clients, from Kmart to Popeyes Chicken to Sunbeam Products.

headline: Recharging Body and Soul
text: Michael G. Grimm, a freshman United States congressman representing Staten Island, has been a Marine, an undercover F.B.I. agent and the owner of a health food restaurant in Manhattan called Healthalicious. After a week in Washington, Mr. Grimm, 41, a Republican, spends his Sundays in the Heartland Village neighborhood of Staten Island, where he lives on the top floor of a multifamily house with his puppy, Sebastian, a Yorkshire terrier. The dog is a regular presence in his office in the Capitol.

headline: China to Release More Data on Air Pollution in Beijing
text: SHANGHAI — China said on Friday that it would begin to publish more detailed air quality data on Beijing later this month, following a public outcry over official government readings that critics said underestimated the severity of the air pollution problem in the smog-filled capital.

headline: You Say You Made a Resolution
text: The urge to eat virtuously is one of those things that come around each January — like cold weather and the Rose Bowl — only, for most people, inevitably to pass. At Candle 79, however, a fine-dining organic vegan restaurant on 79th Street and Lexington Avenue, diners can preserve their culinary purity the year round, with dishes like the seitan piccata with creamed spinach or spaghetti and wheat balls, and drinks from the eco-friendly bar. (Who knew the Maker’s Mark distillery had a low-carbon footprint?) While there were no self-announcing resolution-makers in the crowd the other night, there was — by coincidence — a Stanford University psychologist,  Kelly McGonigal, celebrating the publication of “The Willpower Instinct,” her scientific study on the nature of self-control.

headline: The G.O.P.’s ‘Black People’ Platform
text: That didn’t take long.

headline: The Run and Bump
text: During the past four-plus decades of football, since a Giants receiver slammed the ball to the turf and invented the end-zone spike, the touchdown celebration has been subject to countless fads and elaborate variations. When viewers tune in to the first round of the N.F.L. playoffs on Saturday, they will most likely see the latest trend, which, however simple, is lacking in one critical way: it does not have a name.

headline: Planting a Park
text: Q. There’s a tiny, thin park in the West Village bounded by West Houston and Bedford Streets and Avenue of the Americas. The only name I could find was a parks department sign that said, “Greenstreets.” Why is the park called that?

headline: Church Hints It May Serve as Mediator in Russia
text: MOSCOW — A senior official of the Russian Orthodox Church has indicated that the church is moving toward a middle position between the government and opponents who staged two huge demonstrations last month, warning that if the authorities do not respond to people’s concerns they could be “slowly eaten alive.”

headline: In M.T.A. App Contest, Many Buttons Worth Pushing
text: HOW do you create public-service software? Run a contest.

headline: A Salsa Dance That Isn’t as Stellar as the Score
text: When you are devoted to a marginalized art form like dance, you tend to look for it in everything as a way of justifying its importance to the world. I like to imagine that the Knicks are really just dancers and that the fall dance season actually begins at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Indiana Labor Measure Is Expected to Progress
text: INDIANAPOLIS — House Democrats brought state lawmaking to a halt in Indiana for much of this week, refusing for a third straight day on Friday to come out to their chamber floor in a procedural effort to stop “right to work” legislation at the center of a mounting battle over unions here.

headline: Increasingly Isolated, Iranian Leader Set to Visit Allies in Latin America
text: When President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran begins a four-nation tour of Latin America on Sunday, showcasing his support in the region against a backdrop of international tensions over his nation’s nuclear program, he is set to visit some of the United States’ most ardent critics: Venezuela, Nicaragua, Cuba and Ecuador.

headline: U.S. to Block New Uranium Mines Near Grand Canyon
text: The Obama administration is set to announce on Monday that it will block new uranium mining on one million acres in northern Arizona near the Grand Canyon, lobbyists and Interior Department employees who had been informed about the decision said on Friday.

headline: Crowned New King of Kong
text: ON Feb. 26, 2010, a snowstorm canceled Dr. Hank Chien’s surgery schedule, allowing him to sleep in, and the world of competitive Donkey Kong would never be the same.

headline: Corrections: January 7
text: WEEKEND

headline: Like Phillips, Texans’ Defense Steadies and Toughens
text: HOUSTON — Exhaustion hits Wade Phillips about 5 p.m. each day as if he had set an alarm clock. He no longer has a gallbladder, removed during an operation that also involved a kidney, and less than a month ago was watching from the hospital as the Houston Texans limped toward the playoffs.

headline: Michigan Puts the Foot in Football
text: NEW ORLEANS — In the Michigan locker room, just before the Wolverines set out to play Virginia Tech in the Sugar Bowl on Tuesday, one friend reassured another.

headline: Peru: American Returns for Parole
text: Lori Berenson, the New Yorker who served more than 15 years in prison in Peru for aiding a rebel group, returned to Lima on Thursday night after a court-sanctioned holiday visit to see her family in Manhattan. Ms. Berenson, who traveled with her young son, Salvador, was required to return to continue serving her parole, which calls for her to remain in the country until the end of her 20-year sentence in 2015. Many in Peru, where she is seen as a symbol of a bloody period of violence and terror, had questioned whether she would come back from the trip and were surprised when she returned well ahead of a Jan. 11 deadline.

headline: Exxon and Salazar in Settlement on Offshore Leases
text: The Exxon Mobil Corporation and Kenneth Salazar, the interior secretary, agreed to settle a lawsuit in which Exxon, the world’s largest publicly traded oil company, challenged the government’s decision to cancel offshore leases that may yield “billions of barrels of oil,” according to a court filing. The accord “will allow Exxon Mobil to develop this very large, but technically challenging, resource as quickly as possible using a phased approach,” Patrick McGinn, a spokesman for Exxon, said in an e-mail. Exxon sued on Aug. 12 over a ruling by the department that canceled Gulf of Mexico leases for the so-called Julia unit. The company and the government entered into a settlement agreement on Dec. 30, according to a filing Friday in United States District Court in Lake Charles, Louisiana. Exxon said in its complaint that it sought a suspension for its Julia leases in 2008 because of drilling complexity. It cited federal regulations that allow oil oil producers to suspend production in their fields, partly “to facilitate proper development of a lease.” The Interior Department denied the request in 2009, stating that the company“had not demonstrated a commitment to production” according to court papers. Unsuccessful appeals followed.

headline: Mitt’s Young Republican, Up From the Streets
text: A Republican presidential candidate choosing a campaign chairman in New York City is essentially looking for the least-enfeebled arthritic to climb Everest. New Yorkers may elect Republican mayors, and even members of Congress, but we do not contribute to the victories of Republican presidents. Failure here is preordained.

headline: China: TV Limits May Hit the Web
text: Restrictions on the broadcasting of television historical dramas in China that went into effect on Jan. 1 may soon also extend to Web sites, according to a report released this week by Marbridge Consulting, a business analysis company. The report said that the agency regulating film and television, commonly known as Sarft, had said that as of Jan. 1, at least half of any satellite television network’s dramas must be set in the modern day. Last year, the agency expressed disapproval of time-travel shows, which often involve a modern-day protagonist’s being propelled back into a dynastic era. The Marbridge report said that of more than 50 dramas in production at Hengdian World Studios in Zhejiang Province, more than 30 historical costume dramas had halted because of the new restrictions. Sarft’s clampdown on historical dramas is occurring at the same time that it is limiting reality television programs, which it considers “vulgar.” The actions are part of a much wider push to better control culture that was announced last October by Communist Party leaders.

text: The day in sports included Arkansas defeating Kansas State in the Cotton Bowl and another outdoor hockey game at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia.

headline: Anne Tyng, Theorist of Architecture, Dies at 91

text: Republican candidates have, combined, attended dozens of campaign events in New Hampshire since leaving Iowa on Wednesday, fighting for a respectable finish in the top three.

headline: A Conviction After Vancouver Riot
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Ryan Dickinson, a 20-year-old from suburban Coquitlam, accepted a plea bargain Friday in Vancouver Provincial Court and will be sentenced Feb. 7. His charges include participating in the June 15 riot after the Canucks lost Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals and breach of recognizance. He has been in jail since his arrest last month for violating a court-ordered curfew connected with a previous assault charge.

headline: Japan: New Limits on Reactors
text: Japan said Friday that it will set more stringent age limits on nuclear reactors and require operators to prepare for severe accidents as part of legal changes in the wake of the nuclear crisis at Fukushima. The age limit could also be a step toward fulfilling a government promise to eventually phase out nuclear power in the quake-prone nation. Japan already requires utilities to conduct safety checks on reactors at 30 years, and again at 40 years, to stay in operation. Fresh legislation will set the legal lifespan of reactors at 40 years, though the government will still approve extensions on a case-by-case basis. Excluding the six damaged reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi plant, 13 others in Japan will hit the 40-year limit in the next decade, according to the Ministry of Trade.

headline: Fiji Lifts Martial Law, but Installs New Regulations
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Fiji’s military rulers on Saturday officially lifted a state of martial law that has been in place since 2009, setting the stage for public deliberations on a new constitution and a promised return to democratic elections within the next two years.

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood in North America Edition
text: Bollywood star Shah Rukh Khan’s newest film, “Don 2,” has surpassed the 2011 record for the highest-grossing Bollywood movie in North America.

headline: It’s Nicki’s World

Or maybe it was the neon puffball tunic, which made her look as if she’d fallen into a bowl of Dippin’ Dots, that she wore to Carolina Herrera’s spring 2012 show in September. But few in 2011 could take their eyes off Ms. Minaj, the Technicolor Barbie with the big voice and an elastic smile.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition

While misfits and castoffs have always been D-League staples, the latest minor league trend has brought longtime N.B.A. players to the D-League to enact their comeback plans.

headline: Far From the N.H.L., a League That Survived Hopes to Grow
text: In recent years, the Northeast has been fertile ground for hockey dreamers, with new, independent minor leagues striving to take root. Yet time and again, reality has stamped out hope. The five-team Mid-Atlantic Hockey League did not complete its inaugural season in 2007-8. The four-team Eastern Professional Hockey League lasted one year in 2008-9. The next year, the North East Professional Hockey League started with four teams, was down to three at the season’s start and lasted only 15 games.

headline: Legal Problem Grounds a Bird Migration

headline: Investing in Early Childhood
text: My Sunday column looks at new evidence of the importance of early childhood and pregnancy on life outcomes. I’ve been increasingly impressed by the research that suggests that biological mechanisms — such as the way cortisol floods a small child under stress, disrupting brain development — appear to lay the groundwork for social disadvantage later. But I was looking for a peg to write about this, and then the American Academy of Pediatrics provided it by issuing a landmark policy statement endorsing this new science of toxic stress.

On one of those walls, a television was showing trains in North and South Korea preparing to cross the border for the first time since the 1950-53 Korean War. The report also noted that South Korea was donating 400,000 tons of rice to North Korea.

headline: Lagunitas Creek Watershed

headline: The Random Horror of the Death Penalty

text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — There comes a time in every frazzled parent’s life when he or she hears themself saying things that in the heat of battle sound, if not mentally deranged, then at least unlike anything they might say when adult company comes over.

headline: Shannon: The Correct Personality
text: Part 7: The actor talks about his reputation for playing “crazy” characters, and recalls his less-successful days as a young actor.

headline: Shannon: Just in Time to Meet Scorsese
text: Part 4: The actor talks about meeting and working with Martin Scorsese, and recalls his roots in theater acting.

text: Part 8: The actor tells the story of how he got fired from the set of Peter Bogdanovich’s 1996 made-for-TV movie “To Sir, With Love 2.”

text: Part 13: The actor reflects on why he took the “Boardwalk Empire” part, and explains the appeal of signing on to tell a story whose ending isn’t yet known.

text: Part 11: The actor recalls the challenges he faced playing his roles in 2009’s “The Missing Person” and 2010’s “The Runaways.”

text: Part 2: The actor talks about his film “The Iceman,” and describes his method for balancing family life with his often-intense and draining roles.

headline: Yes, They Pay a Dividend, but Can You Afford Them?
text: WHEN gains in the stock market are hard to come by, dividend-paying stock funds really stand out.

headline: Somali pirates captured in the Gulf Of Oman
text: Late on Thursday afternoon, as the American destroyer U.S.S. Kidd loomed alongside this hijacked Iranian dhow, the warship’s loudspeaker issued a command in Urdu to the dhow’s frightened Urdu-speaking crew. American sailors stood ready, weapons in hand.

headline: How Often to Trade? It’s Tricky for Funds, Too
text: AS an indecisive market kept reversing direction last fall, portfolio managers faced a choice: Try to time its helter-skelter moves, or simply sit back with confidence in an existing portfolio, resisting the temptation to trade with each new bullish or bearish lurch.

headline: Slower Growth in Asia May Yield Bargains
text: THE European credit crisis has dominated the headlines, but the biggest reaction to shaky global economic and financial conditions has been in Asia. Stock markets there — and funds investing in them — trailed other major regions during the fourth quarter of 2011.

headline: For Three Funds, a Front-Row Seat on a Rally
text: THE Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index returned nothing in 2011, but a lost year overshadowed a late rally. Managers of three of the fourth quarter’s better-performing mutual funds found winners in such varied places as small-capitalization stocks, auto parts retailers and aerospace companies.

headline: For Bond Investors, a Year to Tread Carefully
text: BOND funds as a group outperformed stock funds last year, though not in the fourth quarter. And despite the bond funds’ less-volatile performance, choosing one is scarcely a piece of cake.

headline: Don’t Become Your Money’s Enemy
text: WITH sincere apologies to Roseanne Roseannadanna, when it comes to events that can harm the value of your investments, it’s always something. Today, it’s the European debt crisis, or the chance of a double-dip recession, or Congressional gridlock.

headline: Dempsey Scores Hat Trick in Fulham’s F.A. Cup Win
text: Fulham’s Clint Dempsey scored a hat trick, Aston Villa’s Brad Guzan saved a penalty kick in injury time and Landon Donovan had an assist on Everton’s opening goal in a memorable day for American players in England. All three were playing matches in the F.A. Cup, as the Premier League — and the rest of England — took a break from league play for a weekend of matches in the world’s oldest domestic cup competition. For more, read our soccer roundup here.

headline: In Florida, Lawmakers Consider Gambling Bill
text: MIAMI — As the Florida Legislature sprints into action on Tuesday for its annual two-month session, lawmakers will face the politically volatile task of redrawing the electoral map (sure to attract a court challenge) and devising new ways to plug a $2 billion deficit in the state budget.

headline: A Vote for Charles Haley; Pick Your Hall of Famers
text: The Pro Football Hall of Fame selection committee has narrowed the list of 26 semifinalists to the group of 15 modern-era finalists who will be considered for the class of 2012. The list is at the bottom of this post.

headline: Appointments Challenge Senate Role, Experts Say
text: WASHINGTON — To many Republicans and some constitutional scholars, President Obama’s decision last week to ignore a sitting Senate and sidestep the confirmation process for several appointees risked nothing short of an end to the Senate’s role of providing advice and consent on presidential appointments.

headline: Iraq Turns Justice Into a Show, and Terror Confessions a Script
text: BAGHDAD — The cameras were rolling and the reporters were ready inside the auditorium, so the Iraqi police officer gave the signal: Bring in the prisoners. In they shuffled, 21 men accused of terrorism and murder, hands shackled, eyes tracing the floor. This was no day in court. Today, they were lined up to meet the press.

headline: Lull in Strikes by U.S. Drones Aids Militants in Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — A nearly two-month lull in American drone strikes in Pakistan has helped embolden Al Qaeda and several Pakistani militant factions to regroup, increase attacks against Pakistani security forces and threaten intensified strikes against allied forces in Afghanistan, American and Pakistani officials say.

headline: Vote Result From Disputed Precinct Deemed Official
text: 8:56 p.m. | Updated Iowa’s Republican chairman said on Saturday that the vote count from a disputed precinct had been deemed official by the Iowa Republican Party, despite multiple accounts of a vote-counting discrepancy that could potentially have made Rick Santorum the winner of the Iowa caucuses.

headline: An Unfamiliar Sound: Students Cheering DePaul
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Appointments Unsettle State of Venezuelan Politics
text: Ever since President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela fell ill with cancer last year, intense speculation has focused on his inner circle and who might be groomed as a possible successor. Now, with a lengthy re-election campaign ahead of him, Mr. Chávez has once again upended expectations, scattering some of his closest confidants and promoting some old associates in a way that seems certain to provoke alarm at home and abroad.

headline: Shh! We’re Going to Connecticut
text: Connecticut commuters may want to practice their indoor voices this weekend, because on Monday, Metro-North Railroad will introduce “quiet cars” to its New Haven line for the first time.

headline: Government Secrecy May Be a Relic From the Cold War and a Wave of the Future

headline: School Cuts Also Threaten Culture Sites
text: As Texas schools whittle their budgets in response to the state’s multibillion dollar education cuts, they are eyeing every expenditure, from athletics to busing and even field trips.

headline: Day-Glo Meets Cowboys in Father-Son Art Show
text: SULPHUR SPRINGS — It was a perfect family moment for Gary Panter — the punk visionary, underground comics master and “Pee-wee’s Playhouse” set designer — and his father, Mel. The son’s culture-bending Day-Glo artwork was displayed in a small-town gallery in Northeast Texas alongside his father’s oils of iconic Texana.

headline: Lift-Off for Aviation Trainees
text: Linda Merritt, 56, and Kent McDaniel, 39, are both unemployed. PurpleStates follows them over eight months as a vocational training program offers them a chance at a new career.

headline: Private Sector Gets Job Skills; Public Gets Bill
text: KERNERSVILLE, N.C. — Some of Caterpillar’s newest factory workers are training inside a former carpet warehouse here in the heart of tobacco country. In classrooms, they click through online tutorials and study blueprints emblazoned with the company’s logo. And on a mock factory floor, they learn to use wrenches, hoses and power tools that they will need to build axles for large mining trucks.

headline: Video: Private Sector Gets Job Skills; Public Gets Bill
text: When companies are deciding where to build new facilities or whether to expand in places where they already have factories or offices, states compete to shower them with incentives like tax breaks and help buying land. Increasingly, companies have come to expect that state and local governments will pay for job training, too.

headline: Posada Expected to Retire as Yankee
text: Pride is a character trait often associated with Jorge Posada, who used it to fuel an illustrious 17-year career in which he contributed to five World Series championships. That same trait is probably fueling Posada’s decision to end his career how it started, as a Yankee.

headline: Police on Long Island Release Sketch of Woman Whose Skull Was Found Last Year
text: The graphite sketch is of a woman with light eyes and perhaps sandy hair. Below it is almost all that police know of her: her legs were found in 1996, her skull just last year.

headline: James Returns With a Vengeance Against Nets
text: NEWARK — The official injury report read like an orthopedist’s patient caseload: Brook Lopez (broken right foot), MarShon Brooks (sprained left ankle), Damion James (sore right foot), LeBron James (left ankle sprain), Dwyane Wade (left foot contusion) and Mickell Gladness (left foot infection).

Kelly of Westport, Conn. Msgr. Thomas J. Klinzing, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Edward Church in Palm Beach.

On Dec. 10, the couple had a symbolic wedding event in Pittsburgh, where Zack Exley, a friend of the couple, led a ceremony that incorporated Jewish and Lutheran traditions at the Renaissance Pittsburgh Hotel.

text: Ginny LaRoe and Matthew Stephen Lee Cate were married Saturday afternoon at the Headlands Center for the Arts in Fort Barry, a former Army post in Sausalito, Calif. Judge Jeremy Fogel, a United States District judge for the Northern District of California who is on leave to serve as the director of the Federal Judicial Center in Washington, officiated.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Outlook magazine asks an important question this week: “Who Calls The Shots?” The article is about Mamata Banerjee, West Bengal chief minister and ruling coalition ally, opposing legislation pushed by the central government. The writers believe her strong stand has to do with building her profile as a robust regional leader and breaking free of whatever remains of her roots as a Congress politician.

headline: A War of Words Over Water
text: Futurologists say that the next world war will be fought over water because fresh supplies will become increasingly scarce. Pakistan has already added water to the long list of disputes with India and people in India have grown concerned about what they say are Chinese efforts to dam the Brahmaputra River.

headline: Germany Resists Europe's Pleas to Spend More
text: FRANKFURT — Spain, Italy and Greece are taking a knife to public spending because they have no choice. But Germany is still healthy enough that it could do its troubled trading partners a favor and focus more on promoting demand and less on cutting debt.

headline: North Korea Tries to Build New Leader’s Image
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s state-run television called its young, untested leader, Kim Jong-un, a “military genius” on Sunday and showed him driving a tank, sitting in the cockpit of a warplane and interacting with soldiers in a youthful display of camaraderie that was unlike the style of his late father.

text: Eli Manning threw three touchdown passes and the Giants defense pitched a shutout in a 24-2 victory over the Atlanta Falcons on Sunday in an N.F.C. wild-card playoff game at MetLife Stadium.

The impasse raises the possibility that the struggling company may have to cancel its first production, “La Traviata,” and possibly the season.

headline: A Tech Show Loses Clout as Industry Shifts

It will smother the city’s gigantic convention center with gadgets and those who make and promote them; more than 140,000 people are expected to attend for a frenzy of old-fashioned social networking with other members of the tech set.

headline: Oscar Rule Will Cull Nonfiction Contenders
text: LOS ANGELES — In a move to trim the number of documentaries submitted annually for Oscar consideration, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is poised to require a movie review from The New York Times or The Los Angeles Times to qualify a documentary feature for the Academy Awards.

text: Here are four storage solutions designed to make your iPhone-size devices more toddler-friendly.

headline: Life, Mediated in a Journal, by a Writer Busy Being Born
text: The Susan Sontag of the skunk-striped hair and the illustrious reputation as a public figure looks back on another Susan Sontag, a precocious but insecure young woman hungering for experience, in “Sontag: Reborn,” a touching, exquisitely rendered portrait of the artist (and thinker) in the process of self-creation at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar festival.

headline: Consumed in Fire, Cloaked in Ice, Equitable’s Headquarters Fell 100 Years Ago
text: If that enormous White Star liner had made port on her maiden voyage that year, 1912 would probably have been known by generations of New Yorkers as the year of the great Equitable disaster.

headline: Subdued Remembrance of a Dark Day in Tucson
text: TUCSON — The sun had fallen and a crowd had gathered on a chilly Sunday night on the mall at the University of Arizona, for the last event of a weekend commemorating the first anniversary of the mass shooting here one year ago. The vigil began with the Pledge of the Allegiance.

headline: Romney’s Fear of Firing, Minus the Details
text: ROCHESTER, N.H. — Mitt Romney told a New Hampshire crowd on Sunday afternoon that he knew what it was like to fear a pink slip — but so far, his campaign has not been able to provide any examples of a time when Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts who spent more than two decades in the private sector, truly feared for his job.

headline: Axe Adds Fragrance for Women to Its Lineup
text: SINCE its introduction in the United States in 2002, Axe, the body spray and grooming brand by Unilever, has been pitched squarely at young men, with commercials depicting women getting a whiff of Axe users and then aggressively pursuing them.

headline: 2007 Rerun? Giants Take First Step
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Generally, the Giants are not the reminiscing types. Coach Tom Coughlin often scowls when asked to reflect on anything less immediate than that day’s injury report, and quarterback Eli Manning’s sour face is predictable when the subject involves any sort of nostalgia. Scrapbooking, one imagines, is not a favored hobby in the Giants’ locker room.

headline: Corbis to Acquire NMA Group
text: Corbis, the digital media company owned by Bill Gates that licenses the intellectual property rights to photographs, music and public personalities, is expanding again by acquiring the NMA Group in Los Angeles, a pioneer in the realm of branded entertainment, which helps marketers weave products into the plots of movies and television shows.

headline: In House Beautiful, a New Look for Digital Watermarks
text: For magazine readers who find those little black-and-white pixelated boxes, called QR codes, annoying or just unsightly, a new visual cue is on the way.

headline: United Beats City, With a Surprise Guest: Scholes
