headline: Newt Gingrich on a Supportive Super PAC
text: Jan. 8, 2012 - At a press conference in Manchester, the former Speaker of the House answered questions from Jeff Zeleny of The New York Times about new ads from a Super PAC attacking Mitt Romney.

headline: Gingrich Says Bain Capital Looted Companies
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Newt Gingrich assailed Mitt Romney’s business background of buying and selling companies at the investment firm Bain Capital, saying Sunday afternoon that the work was comparable to “rich people figuring out clever legal ways to loot a company.”

headline: Footnote
text: The pop-star power coupleBeyoncé, 30, and Jay-Z, 42, welcomed a daughter, Blue IvyCarter, into the world on Saturdaynight. Jay-Z rented an entirefloor of Lenox Hill Hospital onthe Upper East Side of Manhattanat a cost of $1.3 million, accordingto an online report fromABC’s “Good Morning America.”An official birth announcementfrom representatives of the couplehad not yet been released.

headline: So Much Tension, Pulling at These Strings
text: During intermissions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s lovably mid-20th-century-modern Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium it’s possible to wander through the adjacent galleries of Egyptian art. Attending a concert there, you are aware of history. It makes sense that the Met, with its vast holdings dating back millenniums, should emphasize stability and long relationships in its distinguished concert series.

headline: After Debate, Campaigning Turns to South Carolina
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. – Just two days before voting in the Republican nominating contest is to begin in New Hampshire, Rick Santorum turned his attention here on Sunday night, telling a crowd of several hundred who packed a sports bar that he is the candidate who most reflects their values as “a strong-conviction conservative.”

headline: In the Cave: Philosophy and Addiction
text: Can Plato’s allegory of the cave shed light on the condition of addiction?

headline: Get on TV? Hey, Smack Me Again!
text: Every town has a scene, a subculture, a place where young people go to escape. In Minden, La., a city of about 13,000 some 30 miles east of Shreveport, it’s mixed martial arts, a sport that attracts young men with hopes of punching and kicking and wrestling their way through their opponents, and hopefully their problems.

headline: Partners in Love and the Presidency
text: On the evening of Jan. 12 last year, Michelle Obama sat in the front row of a packed memorial service and fixed her eyes on her husband as he took the stage.

headline: In Hollywood’s Clubby Culture, a Disney Marketer’s Rapid Downfall
text: LOS ANGELES — About a year ago, a team of Disney movie executives traveled to rural Britain to visit Steven Spielberg’s “War Horse” set. Mud and manure greeted them. But knowing that film sets are usually filthy and suspecting this one might be particularly so, the group arrived in grungy clothes and work boots.

headline: Not Dead Yet
text: I did warn readers of a likely gap in blogging; it got longer than I expected as stuff fell in on me. On my way home from Chicago, and normal blogging should resume tomorrow.

headline: Keen Evaluation Ends in Slam
text: The Round Robin Teams top bracket played on Dec. 30, the last day of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan, was won by two married couples: Steve and Rona Levine of New York City, and Ralph and Gloria Tamlyn of Larchmont, N.Y.

headline: Campbell Says Goodbye With Sparkle and Guitar
text: Last June, Glen Campbell announced that he had Alzheimer’s disease, and on Saturday night he came to Town Hall as part of what was billed as the “Goodbye Tour.” Everyone in the room understood. The faithful, reverent crowd appeared not to mind that for much of the show Mr. Campbell was reading lyrics from prompters that had been set between the monitors at the foot of the stage.

headline: A Couple’s Intimate Rotations While Surrounded on All Sides
text: Like many couples, the two people in Nichole Canuso’s “Takes” seem trapped together, trapped by each other and the past. In their case the enclosure is literal: a cube the size of a small room. Its walls are made of a fabric gauzy enough to see through but substantial enough to serve as screens for live video of the dancers inside.

headline: Monday: Better-Than-You Type
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Interesting. You would think a simple, clean theme like this had been done before, but in this debut by Michael Dewey, it seems as if the theme entries are appearing for the first time in The New York Times. It’s possible that similar, avian-themed grids have appeared in other newspapers, but not here.

headline: Cadillac Spells Its BMW 3 Series Fighter ATS
text: Introduced on Sunday, Jan. 8: 2013 Cadillac ATS.

headline: Ear-Openers: New Sounds, No Dogma
text: At best, Winter Jazzfest is an extraordinary thing. It’s a significant jazz festival, not tied to any cultural institution. And it doesn’t rely on the names that would fill Carnegie Hall or Rose Theater, but on those that make up the music’s daily life, chosen with discernment and advocacy. That’s inspired.

headline: PAC Ads to Attack Romney as Predatory Capitalist
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Thanks to a $5 million donation from a wealthy casino owner, a group supporting Newt Gingrich plans to place advertisements in South Carolina this week attacking Mitt Romney as a predatory capitalist who destroyed jobs and communities, a full-scale Republican assault on Mr. Romney’s business background.

headline: Seeking Traveling Giants Fans
text: After Sunday’s dismantling of the Falcons, the Giants now head on the road for a meeting with Aaron Rodgers and the defending Super Bowl champion Green Bay Packers. If you’re a Giants fan who is planning to make the trip to Wisconsin this week, or know someone who is, we’d like to talk with you. Reach out to us in the comments field below, and we’ll contact you by e-mail.

headline: In a Fledgling Country, Perils for the Press
text: In a thatched hut in Juba, the capital of South Sudan, about 10 young men and women sat on lawn chairs made of brown plastic. They loudly typed on the computer keyboards on the tables in front of them. Two fans were blowing heavily. But the loud humming, which turned all speaking in the room into yelling, didn’t come from them. It came from the backyard, and when it suddenly stopped, the young people saved their work. Minutes later their screens turned dark.

headline: In Tribute to New Orleans Institution, Baton Is Passed to New Fans
text: The Preservation Hall Jazz Band, a quintessential New Orleans institution, discovered new out-of-town admirers after Hurricane Katrina, and it brought many of them along for a concert on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall to celebrate its 50th anniversary.

headline: Tim Tebow Is No Good. Except for When He’s Great.
text: The first half of the Denver Broncos’ A.F.C. playoff game against the Pittsburgh Steelers on Sunday was Tim Tebow’s career in a nutshell. In the first quarter, he couldn’t do anything — going three-and-out on two possessions, including one on which Denver actually went backward.

headline: Big Three Newscasts Are Changing the State of Play
text: There was a time when each of the Big Three nightly newscasts on American television tended to open with the same story — the latest campaign speech, a new government study or perhaps a big snowstorm. That time is gone.

headline: Manhattan Borough President Is Still Aiming High
text: For those who think that Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, wants to play it safe by running for re-election, or perhaps for comptroller, rather than for mayor, consider this: he has just persuaded prominent national Democrats to join his 2013 campaign.

headline: Texas Death Offers Grim Reminder That Gun Replicas Can Fool Police
text: BROWNSVILLE, Tex. — In the hallway of a middle school here on Wednesday morning, administrators tried to calm an agitated student who had randomly assaulted another student in a classroom. But then the adults noticed it: the student, a 15-year-old eighth grader named Jaime Gonzalez Jr., had a gun tucked into the waistband of his pants.

headline: Paladino, Ever Unpredictable, Stumps for Gingrich
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Carl P. Paladino, an unpredictable, unconventional and unvarnished Republican candidate for governor of New York in 2010, made an unexpected visit to New Hampshire this weekend to experiment with a new role: as an on-message, on-script and on-team surrogate (of sorts) for Newt Gingrich.

headline: Discovered on Publisher’s Web Site, Aspiring Author Signs Book Deal
text: Penguin Group USA has plucked its first author from its new electronic slush pile.

headline: William P. Carey, Leader in Commercial Real Estate, Dies at 81
text: William P. Carey, who played a leading role in the early use of the commercial real estate transaction known as the sale-leaseback as he built a fortune in investment management, died on Jan. 2 in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include consumer credit for November (Monday); wholesale trade inventories for November (Tuesday); the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, retail sales for December and business inventories for November (Thursday); and the trade deficit for November and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for January (Friday).

headline: Huntsman Goes for Independent Appeal
text: HAMPSTEAD, N.H. – For Al Sandler, an independent voter here, Jon M. Huntsman Jr.’s performance in Sunday’s presidential debate was the clincher. When Mr. Huntsman said that Mitt Romney was wrong to criticize him for being President Obama’s ambassador to China, adding, “The nation is divided because of attitudes like that,” it was music to Mr. Sandler’s ears.

headline: A Ranger Often Overlooked Makes His Hometown Proud
text: Welland may be easy driving distance from Buffalo and Toronto, but many residents of the southern Ontario town have adopted the Rangers as their home team. Dan Girardi, the Rangers defenseman who leads all N.H.L. players in ice time this season — but was not considered good enough just a few years ago to be drafted by any of the league’s 30 teams — was born and raised in Welland.

headline: Bank Regulators to Allow Leeway on Liquidity Rule
text: Since the financial crisis, regulators have been pushing big banks to increase capital and ensure short-term liquidity, a move aimed at avoiding the cash flow troubles that brought the financial system to the brink of disaster in 2008.

headline: In New Hampshire Newspaper, Gingrich Gets Coveted and Ferocious Supporter
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Newt Gingrich may not have much money to spend on advertising here. But he does have Joseph W. McQuaid, the publisher of New Hampshire’s largest newspaper, The Union Leader. And Mr. McQuaid will happily spill barrel after barrel of ink trying to tear every other candidate down.

headline: A Lawyer Who Helped a Family Realize Its Vision
text: On Dec. 21, 2000, Venus Williams stood before a throng of reporters who had come to record another first. Reebok was signing her to the largest endorsement contract signed by a female athlete: five years, $40 million.

headline: Diagnosis Is Concussion for Ross
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As the Giants prepare to face the Green Bay Packers and Aaron Rodgers next Sunday, they must do so with a battered secondary. Cornerback Aaron Ross did not finish Sunday’s 24-2 victory over Atlanta after sustaining a head injury, and the team announced that he had a concussion.

headline: True to Himself, and Loyal to the End
text: When Jorge Posada signed his final contract, after the 2007 season, he had never been on the disabled list. This was a matter of pride for Posada, and considering the rigors of so many years as a catcher, a minor miracle.

headline: Letter to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton
text: A letter signed by 16 Pakistan scholars and sent to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton expressing concern for Husain Haqqani, the former Pakistani ambassador to the United States.

headline: Behind the Counter, an Acute Anxiety
text: Long Island pharmacists talk of the twitchy arrivals who meander around, peering at the ceiling. They talk of the “pharmacy shoppers” who call up, give no name, and wonder if the place has oddly copious quantities of a narcotic painkiller, usually oxycodone. No, we don’t, they will be told. They suspect the caller is a robber, casing a target.

headline: Interpreters Help to Tell the Story Behind the Fight
text: The day before his April bout in Las Vegas with the junior middleweight contender James Kirkland, Nobuhiro Ishida met with the HBO announcers. Ishida, a slender Japanese boxer, was a considerable underdog and he looked the part.

headline: With Preliminaries Over, Primary Season Gets Real
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — After a year or more of anticipation, actual votes have been cast. But the 2012 Republican presidential contest will not proceed in a straight line, evenly spaced out over the next six months. Rather, it is broken up into different phases, each of which will have its own, interesting political dynamic that will affect how the candidates campaign, how they hoard their cash and how they travel.

headline: Tony Blankley, Gingrich Aide and Columnist, Dies at 63
text: Tony Blankley, who frustrated and entertained reporters as press secretary to Newt Gingrich during his rise to power in the House, then joined the press corps himself as a columnist and editorial page editor at The Washington Times, died on Saturday in Washington. He was 63.

headline: Haiti Can Be Rich Again
text: HAITI wasn’t always the “poorest nation in the Western hemisphere,” though it’s almost impossible to read about the country today without coming across that phrase. In the two years since the earthquake that devastated it, Haiti has experienced political conflict and its first ever cholera epidemic; hundreds of thousands of the displaced are still living in makeshift tents strewn like dusty flags by the sides of highways. It is easy to forget that, for most of the 19th century, Haiti was a site of agricultural innovation, productivity and economic success.

headline: Barricaded Inside His Show
text: When I saw the story last week about Keith Olbermann and Current TV lawyering up, I couldn’t help thinking, My, that was quick.

headline: With Family as Foundation, Alabama’s Richardson Perseveres
text: NEW ORLEANS — Emmitt Smith first heard about Trent Richardson a few years ago, from the coach they shared in common. That coach, Jimmy Nichols, long worked at Escambia High School in Pensacola, Fla., and nearly 20 years after Smith graduated in 1987, after he became the N.F.L.’s leading career rusher, another back of similar prowess emerged in his hometown.

text: It is exceedingly rare for a new television newscast to be made almost entirely from scratch, as is the case with “CBS This Morning,” which will replace “The Early Show” on Monday morning.

text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Just a few months ago, Husain Haqqani, the former Pakistani ambassador to the United States, brimmed with charm and confidence as he hosted lavish dinner parties for diplomats, generals, journalists and White House aides in Washington.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage a Priority for Democrats in Trenton
text: Democratic leaders in New Jersey are planning to make a bill allowing same-sex marriage the centerpiece of their agenda for 2012, reflecting a key change from two years ago, when a leading Senate Democrat abstained from a vote on the issue.

headline: Quick Strike From Tebow Helps Broncos Edge Steelers
text: DENVER — Tebow Time met overtime. And just like the other obstacles that have stood in Tebow’s way this season, overtime and the Pittsburgh Steelers had no chance.

headline: Karzai’s Ultimatum Complicates U.S. Exit Strategy
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai’s denunciation last week of abuses at the main American prison in Afghanistan — and his abrupt demand that Americans cede control of the site within a month — surprised many here. The prison, at Bagram Air Base, is one of the few in the country where Afghan and Western rights advocates say that conditions are relatively humane.

headline: Publisher Has Deal for Elton John Book
text: Fans of Elton John, below, will have to wait a little longer for his memoir of sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll. But his publisher is expected to announce Monday that Mr. John, 64, has signed up to write his first book, about his experience in fighting AIDS. The book, titled “Love Is the Cure,” will be “the very personal stories of Sir Elton’s life during the AIDS epidemic, including his agony at seeing friend after friend perish needlessly,” said his publisher, Little, Brown & Company. Mr. John had long wondered why greater effort was not made to cure the disease. “Why are we not doing more?” he wrote in an e-mail from his publisher. “This is a question I have thought deeply about, and wish to answer — and to help change — by writing this book.” Mr. John, a longtime AIDS activist, founded the Elton John Aids Foundation in 1992. Michael Pietsch, the publisher of Little, Brown, will edit the book, to be released in July. A number of musicians, including Keith Richards, Patti Smith, Pete Townshend and Sammy Hagar, have lined up in recent years to write memoirs. Robert Barnett, the Washington lawyer who represented Mr. John in the deal, said that Mr. John had no such plans.

headline: New Liveries in New York With No TVs to Despise
text: There has been plenty of turmoil over the city’s proposed fleet of 18,000 new livery cabs, which will be allowed to pick up street hails in northern Manhattan and the four other boroughs starting later this year.

headline: Happy Lobbyists, Unhappy Citizens
text: Few people were more elated at 2:20 a.m. Wednesday morning when Mitt Romney was declared the winner of the Republican caucuses in Iowa than a small group of lobbyists unknown outside of the Washington Beltway. All indications suggest that the New Hampshire primary this Tuesday will bring similar joy.

headline: On 4th-and-1, Giants Defense Showed Its Mettle
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — If a fourth-and-1 situation sometimes appears like a fierce, primal struggle, a link to football’s 19th-century grunt-and-push origins, it may be worth noting that modern-day pro football players view it no differently.

headline: Steelers’ Momentum Stalls in the Secondary
text: DENVER — Little seemed amiss for the Steelers as they walked to the south end of Sports Authority Field at Mile High to begin the second quarter of their A.F.C. wild-card game Sunday. They led by 6-0 on the scoreboard and the first-down tally. They had limited the Broncos to 8 yards while amassing 119.

headline: Rejected 3 Times, School May Still Open Soon, and With a Grant, Too

headline: Queens Broker Is Accused of Bringing Immigrants’ Ruin
text: For years, a self-made real estate magnate named Edul Ahmad personified the collective dreams of Richmond Hill, Queens, which is populated by many immigrants from Guyana, in South America. Mr. Ahmad drove a yellow Lamborghini, sponsored a cricket team and held white-glove parties at a lavish banquet hall that he owned.

headline: Gifts for Dolan at First Sunday Mass Since News of Elevation
text: Gatherers offered cookies and flowers, cards and prayers, a Styrofoam Jesus and a small stash of beer.

headline: Haiti’s Slow Recovery
text: The Interim Haiti Recovery Commission was one of Haiti’s great hopes after the earthquake, a Haitian-led international partnership that would finally summon the money, will and organizational intelligence to build the country back better than before. But if you visit the commission’s Web site today, on the eve of the second anniversary of the Jan. 12 disaster, this is what you see:

headline: The Sacketts and the Clean Water Act
text: Chantell and Michael Sackett’s case against the Environmental Protection Agency before the Supreme Court on Monday might appear to be David versus Goliath. But those supporting the Sacketts with friend-of-the-court briefs are corporate Goliaths like General Electric and real estate developers eager to weaken the E.P.A.’s ability to protect wetlands and waterways under the federal Clean Water Act.

headline: Islamists in Egypt Back Timing of Military Handover
text: CAIRO — Poised to dominate the new Parliament here, Egypt’s largest Islamist group is putting off an expected confrontation with Egypt’s military rulers, keeping its distance from more radical Islamist parties and hoping that the United States will continue to support the country financially, a top leader of the group’s political arm said Sunday.

headline: Republicans Versus Reproductive Rights
text: In Iowa, the Republican presidential contenders tried to outdo one another in attacking reproductive rights as they sought the support of caucusgoers from the religious right. In New Hampshire, where voters are less socially conservative, the candidates have focused more on economic issues.

headline: Second-Class Commuters
text: This year, more than 2.7 million of the nation’s commuters will have to pay an additional $550 in taxes, thanks to Congress. For those driving, however, not to worry. Commuting tax benefits only get better for them, while the deal for those who take trains or buses will get worse.

headline: Just the Ticket
text: THE beginning of a new year is a time for resolutions, and Hillary Clinton’s admirers are already busily, lovingly resolving on her behalf. On one sideline, her friends tell me that after a few years of hyperactive globetrotting what she really needs is to put her feet up and dictate another volume of her memoirs while nagging Chelsea to deliver grandchildren. (“She’s tired; she needs some time off,” her husband told ABC.) At the other extreme, a couple of Democratic consultants, Patrick Caddell and Douglas Schoen, propose to draft her right now as the 2012 Democratic presidential candidate, whether she likes it or not. (“Not only is Mrs. Clinton better positioned to win in 2012 than Mr. Obama, but she is better positioned to govern if she does,” they wrote in The Wall Street Journal.) Other helpful devotees have noticed that Brown University is looking for a new president, or have imagined her creating a clone of the Clinton Global Initiative focused on empowering women. Or maybe Ruth Bader Ginsburg will decide to put her feet up, opening a seat on the Supreme Court.

headline: Texting While Walking
text: Navigating the sidewalks of New York City can be as challenging as any rushing sport, like football or rugby.  But when your opponents are walking while text messaging, their field of view is impaired, and this can render a three-block walk to Starbucks somewhere between infuriating and life-threatening.

headline: America’s Unlevel Field
text: Last month President Obama gave a speech invoking the spirit of Teddy Roosevelt on behalf of progressive ideals — and Republicans were not happy. Mitt Romney, in particular, insisted that where Roosevelt believed that “government should level the playing field to create equal opportunities,” Mr. Obama believes that “government should create equal outcomes,” that we should have a society where “everyone receives the same or similar rewards, regardless of education, effort and willingness to take risk.”

headline: A Revered, and Divided, Liberator of South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG — With the slaughter of a snorting black bull, a sumptuous banquet and a golf tournament, the African National Congress celebrated its 100th anniversary this weekend at a lavish jamboree, focusing on its revered history rather than the bitter schisms and accusations that now divide it.

headline: In Kansas, a Clash of Science and ‘Gobbledygook’
text: Three fine performances in contrasting hues lend a vivifying spirit to “How the World Began,” a thoughtful but pokey drama by Catherine Trieschmann in which a well-meaning New York liberal parachutes into a heavily Christian town in Kansas, with combustible results.

headline: Parallel Points of Light Ricochet Across Time
text: A constellation of light bulbs glows from the stage at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, where the monologuist extraordinaire Daniel Kitson has set up his own planetarium. In “It’s Always Right Now, Until It’s Later,” which opened on Sunday night and runs through Jan. 29, Mr. Kitson maps an earthly cosmology: the points of light in two separate lives that might otherwise be lost to the shadows.

headline: U.S. Orders Venezuelan Envoy in Miami to Leave
text: In a move sure to further strain relations between the United States and Venezuela, the State Department on Sunday said that it had ordered a Venezuelan diplomat based in Miami to leave the country.

headline: Fox Plans Block of Cartoon Shows for Late Night on Saturdays
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Emphasizing its history as the network that built a franchise around animated comedy shows like “The Simpsons” and “Family Guy,” Fox announced here on Sunday an ambitious plan to create a block of cartoon shows that would play in the late-night hour on Saturday.

text: The first round of the N.F.L. playoffs came to an electrifying finish in Denver, the F.A. Cup continued in England and biathletes endured heavy snow in Germany.

headline: With Work Scarce in Athens, Greeks Go Back to the Land
text: CHIOS, Greece — Nikos Gavalas and Alexandra Tricha, both 31 and trained as agriculturalists, were frustrated working on poorly paying, short-term contracts in Athens, where jobs are scarce and the cost of living is high. So last year, they decided to start a new project: growing edible snails for export.

text: CAIRO — The Arab League called again on Sunday for Syrian security forces and armed groups to immediately halt the violence in the country, and urged the Syrian government to comply with the terms of a peace deal to end months of bloodshed.

headline: Enduring a Ceaseless List of Heartbreak, Together
text: In the Cordis family, the two daughters, Judy, 20, and Christina, 19, do most of the talking. Their mother, Patricia Cordis, 53, keeps a silence that masks a mountain of pain. headline: Malaysian Opposition Leader Acquitted in Sodomy Trial
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Ending a politically charged two-year trial, Malaysia’s High Court acquitted the country’s opposition leader, Anwar Ibrahim, of sodomy charges on Monday.

headline: At Tournament of Champions, Talk of Tebow and Tebowing
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii — Jonathan Byrd carries a Bible verse in his back pocket, in his yardage book, but would he ever consider a more conspicuous display of his faith after a round, like dropping on his knees and praying a la Denver Broncos quarterback Tim Tebow?

headline: Yahoo to Distribute Tom Hanks Series
text: Tom Hanks has engaged Yahoo to be the first digital distributor for “Electric City,” an animated science-fiction series that he created and that he is producing and starring in. Yahoo, which is trying to become recognized for TV-quality Web shows, is to announce the distribution deal on Monday. “Electric City” is the first original scripted program to be distributed by the Web site. The 90-minute series presents Mr. Hanks’s vision of a future metropolis that is challenged but not doomed. Yahoo plans to show the series in several parts and incorporate extra features, like interactive maps and casual games. It will be available in English, French, Spanish and other languages.

headline: Barnes & Noble to Offer Nook Discount to Subscribers of 2 Publications
text: Barnes & Noble, in a move to increase sales of its Nook devices, will offer deep discounts on them to customers who also buy subscriptions to the Nook editions of People magazine or The New York Times, the retailer is expected to announce on Monday.

headline: U.S. Agents Aided Mexican Drug Trafficker to Infiltrate His Criminal Ring
text: WASHINGTON — American drug enforcement agents posing as money launderers secretly helped a powerful Mexican drug trafficker and his principal Colombian cocaine supplier move millions in drug proceeds around the world, as part of an effort to infiltrate and dismantle the criminal organizations wreaking havoc south of the border, according to newly obtained Mexican government documents.

headline: Little Engines of Creativity, Spinning Freely in the Motor City
text: DETROIT — Navigating tables laden with lentil burgers and smoked wild salmon B.L.T.’s, Sharon Robinson escorted a guest toward paintings hanging on the high walls of the Cass Cafe, a venerable gathering place near Wayne State University popular with students, poets and visual artists. The cafe is about three miles from Cobo Center, the site of the North American International Auto Show, where press previews officially begin on Monday.

headline: How to Understand the World in 2012
text: “If you want to understand the world, you need to understand Asia,” Nicholas D. Kristof writes in The New York Times’ Travel section, and that means traveling to China and India. Mr. Kristof recommends India’s metropolises as well as Varanasi and Amritsar.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Diane’s Latest Inappropriate Admirer
text: When “The Good Wife” came back from its holiday hiatus on Sunday with an episode titled “Alienation of Affection,” in which a divorced couple sued Lockhart Gardner for $44 million and Alicia found herself at the center of the case, it seemed obvious that we should be looking for connections between that story line and Alicia’s personal history. I’ve thought about it for 10 minutes and haven’t come up with any that were worth the trouble, so I’m going to skip it. Please let us know in the comments what I’m missing.

headline: The New Hampshire Primary
text: Presidential candidates have been visiting New Hampshire, one of the first battleground states, for a year.

headline: The New Scapegoats of Europe
text: One afternoon in November, Océane Sluijzer, a 13-year-old Belgian Jewish girl, was beaten up after soccer practice by a group of schoolmates. Her tormenters, girls of Moroccan descent, called her a “dirty Jew” and told her to “go back to her own country.”

headline: Huntsman Has Momentum, but He Lacks Time
text: In a nomination contest in which literally every other major opponent to Mitt Romney has surged in the polls at some point, it is only fitting that the candidate who seems to have the late momentum in New Hampshire is the one who hadn’t: Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former governor of Utah.

headline: Gazing Through the Transfer Window at a Few Americans
text: The European transfer window opened on Jan. 1, and that, combined with the buildup to the Mexican Primera Division’s Clausura season, means that there are plenty of Americans abroad who are either on the move or rumored to be changing clubs.

headline: The Caucus | Candidates on the Trail
text: Jan. 9, 2012 — A look at all five of the presidential candidates in New Hampshire and their different approaches to the campaign trail.

headline: Acquittal of Opposition Leader May Level Field in Malaysia
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The surprise acquittal of Anwar Ibrahim, the Malaysian opposition leader, of sodomy charges is likely to make the country’s next national elections a tightly contested affair, analysts said Monday after the verdict was announced.

headline: Jan. 9, 1968 | NASA’s Surveyor 7 Probe Makes Soft Landing on Moon
text: On Jan. 9, 1968, the Surveyor 7 space probe made a soft landing on the moon. It was the final mission of the Surveyor program, a series of unmanned explorations of the lunar surface.

headline: News Quiz | Jan. 9, 2012

headline: Iran Imposes Death Sentence on U.S. Man Accused of Spying
text: Iran’s judiciary on Monday sentenced to death an imprisoned American convicted of espionage for the Central Intelligence Agency. The punishment shocked his family and was imposed against a backdrop of increasingly bellicose relations with the United States over the disputed Iranian nuclear program.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 9, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “With Victory No. 700 Comes a P.S.A.L. First.”

headline: Building an Archive From the Rubble
text: In 1989, Larry Racioppo got his first regular job in years: taking pictures showing New York City at its worst. He spent his days stepping through dank basement crack dens and apartments that were as burned-out as their inhabitants. On rooftops, spent shell casings littered the tar like fallen leaves. At street level, entire neighborhoods had been reduced to empty lots.

headline: South Korea Investigates Vote-Buying Scandal
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Lee Myung-bak’s ruling Grand National Party faced a growing crisis on Monday as prosecutors investigated an allegation from a whistle-blowing lawmaker that one of its former chairmen tried to buy votes in a party leadership race .

Which is harmless fun, or another opportunity to argue about religion (as a Fifth Down post argued last month, that would be a shame.)

headline: Complaint Box | Addressee Deceased
text: The Post Office used to have something called the “Dead Letter Office,” where mail for people who could not be located was put. It’s now euphemistically called the “mail recovery center,” as if the dead are not to be spoken of.

headline: Santander Lifts Capital Cushion Months Ahead of Deadline
text: Banco Santander of Spain, the bank with the largest market value in the euro zone, said on Monday that its core capital ratio now stood at 9 percent, six months ahead of the deadline set by Europe’s main bank regulator.

headline: Meet Madagascar’s New Lemur
text: Finding a new species may look easy on paper, the conservationist Jonah Ratsimbazafy says, but it takes a long, long time. He and his colleagues spent many a night in the jungle chasing after camouflaged hamster-size creatures hopping around the branches and brush. Their work paid off, though: after snagging 14 mouse lemurs, they were surprised to find they had a new species.

headline: Away From Cobo Center, Automobiles for the Other Half
text: DETROIT — For many gearheads, seeing rare, expensive cars is the whole point of attending an auto show. But with the likes of Aston Martin, Ferrari and Lamborghini again skipping official appearances at the Detroit auto show, organizers staged a special viewing Sunday night of 28 exotic automobiles at the MGM Grand Detroit on the eve of the show’s press previews — exclusively for sponsor invitees and 100 members of the public who paid $500 per ticket for the privilege.

headline: The Hunt for the Missing Millions
text: How much should the city be receiving from the the state and federal government as reimbursements for services it provides to special needs students? By the city's own estimates, tens of millions more than it has been receiving. The City Council will hold a hearing on Feb. 28 to try to figure out why city schools are not getting the money they are due.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Wall Street Braces for Dismal 4th Quarter  |  For most Wall Street bankers, 2011 was a year best forgotten. Investors will soon find out just how bad the year was for the country’s biggest financial institutions.

headline: Hyundai Elantra Is Car of the Year; Range Rover Evoque Is Truck of the Year
text: DETROIT — Selected by a jury of 50 automotive journalists from print, television, Web and radio, the Hyundai Elantra compact sedan was named North American Car of the Year here on Monday morning. Of the Elantra, which beat out the Ford Focus and Volkswagen Passat, Ken Gross, an automotive journalist, said in a media release that it offered “beaucoup bang for the buck, impressive mileage; it feels like a more expensive car.” Even so, there was a collective gasp here at Cobo Center when the announcement was made.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Suze Orman’s Debit Card and a New CBS Morning Show
text: Suze Orman, the CNBC financial adviser, has introduced a prepaid debit card, investing more $1 million of her own money in the project. These kinds of cards – which are meant for people with no credit history, or poor credit history – have drawn criticism for sky-high fees and poor disclosure. Ms. Orman says she wants to broaden the debit card market by charging low fees and offering new services, Ron Lieber writes; he adds that the project “raises so many questions that it is hard to even know where to start.”

headline: Bowery Diner Is Set to Open
Daily Report: The Consumer Electronics Show
text: The International Consumer Electronics Show cannot be ignored, reports Nick Wingfield, one of The New York Times reporters at the annual technology extravaganza held in Las Vegas. But he writes that the changing nature of the technology industry is reflected in the fact that the most important developments are no longer coming from the the show.

headline: Jones Group Calls Off Sale of Jeanswear Unit
text: The Jones Group said on Monday that it had ended efforts to sell its jeanswear unit to another apparel maker, Delta Galil of Israel, terminating a months-long process.

headline: Blackmon and Stecklow Join the Exit of Veterans From The Journal

Blackmon, a senior national correspondent who frequently covers politics, will be leaving the newspaper to take an academic post at the University of Virginia and to cover politics for The Washington Post as a contributing editor.

Several districts have had to put children on wait lists in recent years because of demographic changes. Parents of kindergarteners can also expect a more demanding curriculum for their children that is being introduced by the city.

They were not willing to spend lavishly on a good, but not great, starting pitcher like C. J. Wilson and do not appear to be on the verge of signing other decent hurlers like Edwin Jackson, as Tyler Kepner wrote last week.

headline: Leading Off: The Price of Not Believing
text: The alert among you started getting suspicious in the waning minute of the fourth quarter, when the Steelers’ inevitable march to a game-winning field goal against the Broncos stalled inexplicably. Quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, up to then engineering a spirited comeback on one leg, suddenly looked like he had forgotten everything he ever knew. Ominous, dramatic music was cued up somewhere, most likely in your head.

headline: Biomass and Electricity, Part One
text: Burning natural gas releases less heat-trapping carbon dioxide than burning coal does because it has only about half as much carbon per unit of energy. But it can exacerbate global warming if it escapes unburned into the atmosphere as methane; in a century, a methane molecule will trap as much heat as 21 carbon dioxide molecules would.

headline: What’s in a Name? At C.E.S., Oftentimes, It’s Shenzhen

headline: Germans and Aliens
text: The Times has an article today about Germany’s faith in austerity as the answer to depression. It’s sad reading for anyone hoping that Europe will get its act together; it’s especially galling that Germans remain so committed to belief in expansionary austerity, despite the thorough empirical debunking the notion has been given over the past year and a half (see, e.g., this IMF working paper (pdf)).

headline: For Romney, Close Ties to Officials Bear Fruit

They were not just any volunteers: those working the phone banks included a former New Hampshire governor, a half-dozen state senators and Manchester’s mayor.

Kristof points to a new policy statement from the American Academy of Pediatrics based on an increasing wealth of scientific research: “toxic stress” in infancy or early childhood can “disrupt the architecture of the developing brain, thereby influencing behavioral, educational, economic and health outcomes decades and generations later.”

headline: Numberplay: The Spiraling Skater
text: Our puzzle this week was provided by Numberplay reader Hansen Chen (a.k.a. Hans), who first encountered the problem as a Princeton graduate student. Dr. Chen discovered that the problem was being taught incorrectly. The instructor and textbook had it wrong.

Something will be missing, though.

headline: Dudley of N.Y. Fed to Head Organization of Central Bankers

headline: Gingrich Moves On From All-Positive ‘Experiment’

headline: Digital Dressing Room
text: A new social-network shopping site, motilo.com, with links to high fashion e-commerce sites, makes online shopping with friends more like the real thing. Think of it as Polyvore meets Facebook. Register and invite friends to create head-to-toe looks, all the while video-chatting with your fashion buddies. “It’s that power of referral that will often help tip you into making a purchase,” said Sofia Barattieri di San Pietro, the site’s chief executive, who came up with the idea on a shopping trip to Paris with a friend. All of the items featured are linked to retailers like net-a-porter.com and farfetch.com.

headline: Questions for Your Own Circle of Experts

Their answers may both enrich your understanding and appreciation of important elders in your life and improve your own chances of living successfully.

headline: Advice From Life’s Graying Edge on Finishing With No Regrets
text: At 17, I wrote a speech titled, “When You Come to the End of Your Days, Will You Be Able to Write Your Own Epitaph?” It reflected the approach to life I adopted after my mother’s untimely death from cancer at age 49. I chose to live each day as if it could be my last — but with a watchful eye on the future in case it wasn’t.

headline: Michael Moore on How the New Documentary Rules Will Work

headline: Paying the Cost of Security in Iraq
text: In 2008, I returned home from Iraq, having served a year tour as a civil affairs sergeant attached to the 82nd Airborne. Back home for over three years now, I have had time to reflect on the war and my role in it, and to search for meaning amid the chaos and destruction of those days. My deployment, during what came to be known as the surge, was quite different than what I had hoped or expected it would be.

headline: Is Bank of America Trying to Shed Small-Business Customers?
text: Bank of America has once more found itself on the defensive over small-business lending, in the wake of a Los Angeles Times report that said the bank is demanding some borrowers to “pay off their credit-line balances all at once instead of making monthly payments.” According to the report, customers who can’t pay in full “are being offered new repayment plans for as long as five years, but with far higher interest rates than their original credit lines had.”

Huntsman Jr. hustled to independent voter strongholds around New Hampshire on Monday to make the case that he, not Mitt Romney, would be the most formidable Republican challenger to President Obama in November.

headline: Cat-and-Mouse Game in the Gupta Prosecution
text: We often think of prosecutions as involving a single crime that took place at a particular moment, so that the charges are fixed and the information that will be presented in court fairly clear-cut. In white-collar prosecutions, that is rarely the case, as prosecutors refine their case after filing charges, sometimes finding new violations, while defendants try to pry evidence from the government that can help their defense.

headline: CBS Begins to Redefine What’s News in the Morning
text: 3:11 p.m. | Updated On Monday, CBS introduced a revamped morning show that is meant to distinguish itself from its more popular competitors — the top-rated “Today” show at NBC and ABC’s “Good Morning America” — by emphasizing hard news. With the help of a TV remote control and TVEyes, here’s a look at how “CBS This Morning” diverged from the others.

text: So often, political art makes us feel that the cure is as bad as the disease. Didactic, self-righteous and smug, full of easy slogans, this sort of art leaves people just as boxed in as the systems it supposedly critiques.

headline: With One Drought Continuing, Northwestern Looks to End Another
text: When Northwestern fell to Texas A&M, 33-22, in the Meineke Car Care Bowl of Texas on New Year’s Eve, the loss extended the N.C.A.A.’s longest bowl losing streak to nine games.  The only time Evanston’s football faithful have celebrated a postseason win was the 1949 Rose Bowl, a 20-14 victory over California.

headline: Pricing for Sony’s PlayStation Vita
text: LAS VEGAS — When Sony’s new portable device, the PlayStation Vita, arrives in American stores on Feb. 22, customers will have the option to buy two data plans from AT&T to play games online anywhere they are.

headline: Seeing Social Media More as Portal Than as Pitfall
text: More than a hundred years ago, when the telephone was introduced, there was some hand-wringing over the social dangers that this new technology posed: increased sexual aggression and damaged human relationships. “It was going to bring down our society,” said Dr. Megan Moreno, a specialist in adolescent medicine at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. “Men would be calling women and making lascivious comments, and women would be so vulnerable, and we’d never have civilized conversations again.”

headline: Randolph’s Injury Costs Grizzlies Offense, Order
text: The Memphis Grizzlies are in some considerable trouble, and for at least six or seven more weeks, Zach Randolph won’t be able to right their wrongs on the strength of his mid-post game. A nasty medial collateral ligament tear ensured that much, and though Randolph is fortunate to have dodged a need for surgery, his absence has sent Memphis’ offense into a tailspin.

headline: Gingrich Video Criticizes Romney on Taxes

headline: Gingrich’s Own Close Tie to Buyout Industry
text: 8:56 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich has ramped up his attacks on Mitt Romney as a heartless leveraged buyout executive for his years at Bain Capital, asking reporters in Manchester on Monday, “Is capitalism really about the ability of a handful of rich people to manipulate the lives of thousands of other people and walk off with the money? Or is that, somehow, a little bit of a flawed system?”

headline: Childhood: Exercise Yields Dividends in the Classroom

headline: Haiti: Cholera Epidemic’s First Victim Identified as River Bather Who Forsook Clean Water
text: The first Haitian to get cholera at the onset of the 2010 epidemic was almost undoubtedly a 28-year-old mentally disturbed man from the town of Mirebalais, researchers reported Monday.

headline: The Maybach, Conspicuous by Its Presence
text: Of unlikely sights at Cobo Center, a dedicated nook for the doomed Maybach brand would rank high. The Maybach 57S made an obliging appearance next to the sprawling stand of its Daimler sibling, Mercedes-Benz, where hundreds of journalists crowded in for the formal introduction of the Mercedes SL550 roadster (and who lingered afterward for steak tips).

headline: What Are Your Life Lessons?
text: In this week’s Personal Health column, Jane E. Brody writes about the many lessons to be learned from an aging population. After all, the elderly have already experienced the stumbles, mistakes and second chances that are (hopefully) still ahead for the rest of us.

headline: Romney Seeks to Clarify ‘Pink Slip’ Remarks
text: HUDSON, N.H. — After more than a week of not taking questions from his press corps, and after two days of back-to-back comments that his campaign has scrambled to explain, Mitt Romney stepped to the microphone after an event at metal fabricating plant here Monday afternoon, and sought to clarify remarks he has made about fearing the “pink slip” in his private sector career, as well as his statement earlier in the day that he likes “being able to fire” people or businesses that provide poor service.

headline: Worrying Less About Teens, Texting and Social Media

headline: An Apple a Day
text: There are many reasons an apple a day may keep the doctor away. Among popular fruits, apples rank second (after cranberries) in antioxidant power, according to the nutritionist Jonny Bowden. They are extremely high in phenolic compounds (polyphenols), particularly quercetin, and if the apple is red, anthocyanins. These phytochemicals carry many health benefits, both antioxidant and anti-inflammatory. Apples have been linked to lower rates of heart disease in several studies.

headline: Thieves Steal Picasso and Mondrian Paintings in Athens
text: It took thieves all of seven minutes to slip in through a balcony door and steal paintings by Picasso and Mondrian from the National Art Gallery in Athens on Monday, Tthe Associated Press reported. The police said that the burglars intentionally set off alarms Sunday evening to lure guards into disabling a sensor in the museum. One alarm did subsequently go off, but the guards arrived too late to catch a thief.

headline: Keep the Holiday Lights Blinking
text: HOLIDAY parties are over, but brilliantly bejeweled and glittering eye makeup has been lingering on, an easy way to alleviate the January blahs.

headline: Just One Look | Nina Ricci
text: Peter Copping described his prefall collection as a series of uniforms, namely those that women have come to expect to see at Nina Ricci (pencil skirts and pretty cardigan sweaters, for example). But to reinforce his theme, Copping also found clever ways to incorporate military details into his clothes. He made epaulets out of jet beads, he introduced a floral print that hints at camouflage, and he interpreted army netting into gloves and a cutout pouf dress, seen here with the pump that Copping calls “the new peep toe.”

headline: Documenting City at Its Worst, and Its Rebirth
text: Larry Racioppo held all the usual “New York artist jobs” to support himself and the small storefront darkroom he had in Sunset Park. Cabby, bartender and carpenter, to name a few. Turns out that last one – a 10-year stretch working with some sculptors turned contractors – gave him the insight for what would become a photography career, when he was hired in 1989 as staff photographer for the city’s Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

headline: NYT Districts API helps Fractured Atlas help artists
text: The arts, and the benefits to the public they provide, sometimes gets lost, barely noticed by government. Fractured Atlas, a New York City-based multi-disciplinary arts service organization, is finding that by creating information and data services for its members among the city’s arts communities, it can also provide more effective advocacy for the arts to government.

headline: Intel Pushes MacBook Air-Like Notebooks, but for Windows

At this year’s International Consumer Electronics Show, the company, the world’s biggest maker of computer chips, made it clear that it planned to pour a lot of money and effort into turning Ultrabooks into the next big computing phenomenon.

headline: Moments of Awe

text: What's more important in defining a good school, community or curriculum? Two SchoolBook commenters have different thoughts. Peg Tyre, a journalist and expert on what parents should look for in choosing a school, responds with her own opinion.

headline: Mad Libs and Dangling Participles
text: Grammar, the necessary “evil” that English teachers cannot avoid, is often resisted, both by students and teachers alike.  Thus, says one teacher, "we have developed a severe case of Grammarphobia.'' Her solution in the classroom: Use Mad Libs, that popular word game for kids.

headline: Wizards Sinking Fast in the East
text: The Washington Wizards, thanks to a terrible 0-8 start to the season, are the N.B.A.’s worst team right now, and the only club without a victory in the shortened season. The Wizards are 7.5 games in back of the Southeast Division and Eastern Conference-leading Miami Heat (8-1) and digging in at the bottom.

headline: Interior Secretary Signs Grand Canyon Mining Ban
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar formally signed a 20-year moratorium on new uranium and other hard rock mining claims on a million acres of federal land around the Grand Canyon on Monday, saying it was a “serious and necessary step” to preserve the mile-deep canyon and the river that runs through it.

headline: Supreme Court Retains Ban on Foreign Campaign Donations
text: In a terse four words, the Supreme Court on Monday issued an order upholding prohibitions against foreigners making contributions to influence American elections.

headline: Tebow Wins for CBS, Too
text: Fueled by Tim Tebow mania and capped by Tebow’s 80-yard game-winning touchdown pass on the first play of overtime, the broadcast of the Denver Broncos’ 29-23 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers produced huge ratings for CBS on Sunday. According to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates it was the highest-rated National Football League wild-card playoff game in 24 years and CBS averaged nearly 42 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour.

headline: Larkin Elected to Baseball Hall of Fame
text: Barry Larkin’s oldest brother, Mike, was a linebacker at Notre Dame. When Mike chose the Irish over the University of Michigan, the Wolverines’ coach, Bo Schembechler, told Larkin’s mother that he would someday persuade another of her sons to play for him.

headline: Just One Look | Celine
text: All the makings of Phoebe Philo’s Céline were in attendance — Crombie coats and color-blocked sweaters; sporty pants (in leather) and crisp white shirts (with contrast cuffs). Though certain looks from this prefall collection, like the tall black and white riding boots paired with a belted drop-waist dress, felt quite Courrèges-like, the slouchy pants, padded biker jacket, animal print intarsias and singular column dress (white, floor-length, with a tiny peplum high on the waist) kept things from going too retro. Here, the aforementioned boots (key) are worked into a look that slips as easily into the designer’s oeuvre as it does alongside the label’s classic box bag. The front piece on the sweater is mink and the skirt is leather with suede pockets.

headline: To Preserve History on the Moon, Visitors Are Asked to Tread Lightly
text: California’s catalog of historic artifacts includes two pairs of boots, an American flag, empty food bags, a pair of tongs and more than a hundred other items left behind at a place called Tranquillity Base.

headline: As Season Ends, B.C.S. Retooling Begins
text: NEW ORLEANS — College football’s postseason is poised to undergo significant change. B.C.S. officials will meet Tuesday for the first of several discussions on altering the sport’s postseason. Interviews with conference commissioners, athletic directors and television industry officials revealed that change to the current structure of college football’s postseason was imminent.

headline: Gingrich’s Own Close Tie to Buyout Industry

headline: Ronald Reagan Versus Saul Alinsky

It’s young people, especially, who have to worry about a nuclear Iran, and young people who have the most to lose if the economy doesn’t recover.

headline: A Deep-Sea Ecosystem Unlike Any Other
text: Deep in the Southern Ocean near Antarctica, scientists have discovered 23 new animal species living in the hot, dark environment around hydrothermal vents.

headline: Steak ‘n Shake Comes to New York
text: For its first outlet in New York, Steak ‘n Shake Signature, opening Thursday in the theater district, the Steak ‘n Shake chain is making some additions to its menu. Along with the chain’s original “smashed” four-ounce burger, pressed on the griddle to be thin and crisp, the new shop has a six-ounce Signature Steakburger made with organic beef and only gently pressed. And for the first time, there will be beer and wine. This sleek, 20-seat spot has new self-service Coke machines to permit custom flavorings.

headline: King Cozies Up in SoHo
text: At King in SoHo, Francis Derby, who worked at Momofuku Ssam Bar, WD50 and avant-garde spots like Atlas, Tailor and Gilt, has subdued his inventive impulses somewhat for a more classical approach. His menu will offer smoked baby octopus salad, marinated charred mackerel and also chicken for two baked in salt with spaetzle. The approach in this intimate space is European; the room is accented with vintage pieces.The wine and beer lists emphasize Europe, too.

headline: Why This Attack Might Hurt Romney
text: When I was down in South Carolina at the end of the year, hanging out with conservative activists, there were already some rumblings about the plant closing in Gaffney and the attacks that might be coming on Mitt Romney. And here they are. Over on the Caucus, I just posted this column about why this line of attack might be more damaging to Romney than all the others. My magazine article about South Carolina and the meltdown inside the Tea Party movement will be online Thursday and in the magazine Sunday.

headline: Special Vote in March on Successor to State Senator Kruger
text: ALBANY – A special election to replace former State Senator Carl Kruger will be held on March 20, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Monday.

headline: In a Surprise, a Songbird Displays a Sense of Smell
text: It was long thought that songbirds did not use their sense of smell. That was because a 1968 study had found that the olfactory bulbs in their brains are smaller than those of other kinds of birds.

headline: A Primer on the Many-Layered Fugue
text: Bach put everything he knew about writing fugues, which was everything there is to know about the matter, into “The Art of Fugue,” as he titled his collection of 14 fugues and 4 canons. Though Bach worked for years on the project, he never completed it: the final four-voice fugue was left unfinished at his death at 65 in 1750.

headline: All the Colors of a Scriabin Rarity That’s Meant to Be Seen as Well as Heard
text: NEWARK — No hard, fast rule dictates that an orchestra has to engage in elaborate sleight of hand when presenting an unfamiliar work; still, there is something to be said for creating a useful context. A uniting theme, however basic, can provide a starting point for appraising a new or uncommon piece. Surrounding it with familiar music that is in some way related allows the audience to discover and apply its own connections.

headline: A Last-Minute Substitution for ‘Faust’
text: The tenor Roberto Alagna is stepping in for an ailing Joseph Calleja in the title role of “Faust,” by Gounod, at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening, the Met said Monday afternoon. The last-minute substitution means that Mr. Alagna will be singing two major roles in two nights: on Tuesday he is scheduled to appear as Cavaradossi in the season’s opening performance of Puccini’s “Tosca.”

headline: Deadly Viruses: Pro or Con?
text: Thanks so much to all who contributed to our lively — if somewhat technologically challenged — discussion about the scientists who made bird flu take wing. Responses reflected an unusually wide array of ideas, from the conviction that nothing in the world could justify experiments like those in question to the equally impassioned conviction that nothing should get in their way. Similarly, some argued that the data these experiments produced are of only marginal usefulness, while others felt they would prove as invaluable as Galileo’s discovery. But what, as Andrew S asked, is the most appropriate ethical framework for sorting through these claims? For those who might have more to say, we’ll keep the comments open for a while longer. Readers, have at it!

text: I almost never go to a vegetable place – whether it’s the supermarket or the shabby vegetable store in midtown or the farmer’s market – without buying a cauliflower. It’s incredible what you can find to do with them.

headline: When Injuries to the Brain Tear at Hearts
text: At a crowded vigil on Sunday night in Tucson, Representative Gabrielle Giffords held her husband’s hand as she stepped up to the lectern to recite the Pledge of Allegiance.

headline: City Seeks to Close Two Charter Schools
text: New York City's Department of Education announced plans on Monday to close two long-troubled charter schools in Brooklyn and Queens at the end of this school year: Williamsburg Charter High School in Brooklyn, which will see its charter revoked mid-term, and Peninsula Preparatory Charter School in Far Rockaway, which will not have its contract renewed.

headline: Very Serious Scare Tactics
text: As part of a longer-term project, I’ve been looking into the why and how of the dominance of austerity rhetoric over most of the past two years. One aspect is the rapturous glee with which policymakers seized on the theory of expansionary austerity, without waiting to see how well it would stand up under scrutiny (and the answer was, not well at all).

headline: Finding a Way to Put a Zebra in Your Tank
text: NEW ORLEANS — Prowling the animal cages at the Audubon Zoo with tweezers and sandwich bags was an unusual and somewhat disconcerting experience for David A. Mullin and his graduate students.

headline: Giving Windows on an iPad a Boost
text: LAS VEGAS — The iPad seems to be doing pretty well among business customers already. There could be even more of them, though, who would buy iPads if software like Microsoft Office and Windows ran well on the devices.

headline: Spotlighting a Choreographer Through Some Classic Works
text: The mission of Taylor 2, the six-member budget version of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, is to bring Mr. Taylor’s works to places that may not be able to afford the main troupe. It’s an honorable mission, which one group of dancers after another has been fulfilling admirably since 1993. But at the Pace University Schimmel Center for the Arts on Saturday (the second of two programs), the current crop looked decidedly junior varsity.

headline: Painting Bold Promises at CBS With Bright Morning Colors
text: “The news is back in morning news” is the promise splashed across promos for “CBS This Morning,” but on CBS this Monday morning it was hard to find.

headline: Herpes Vaccine Falls Short in Clinical Trial
text: The search for a vaccine to prevent infection with two types of herpes simplex, or H.S.V., is under way, but success is proving elusive. A new vaccine, previously thought to protect uninfected women who have infected partners, has now been found useless against one form, H.S.V.-2, in a double-blinded placebo-controlled trial.

headline: His Story: A Writer of Words and Music
text: When the poet, novelist, piano player and spoken-word recording artist Gil Scott-Heron died unexpectedly last May, at 62, he left behind a prickly and galvanizing body of work. His best songs — “The Revolution Will Not Be Televised,” “Whitey on the Moon,” “We Almost Lost Detroit” — are rarely heard on classic-rock radio; they’re too eccentric and polemical and might kill a workingman’s lunchtime buzz. But they’ll still stop you in your tracks.

headline: Nicotine Patch Helps Against Cognitive Impairment in Study
text: A nicotine patch worn for six months can improve attention, memory and mental processing in people with mild cognitive impairment, a clinical trial has found.

headline: More Health Clinics Pop Up Inside Retailers
text: The growth of health clinics inside retail stores rebounded in 2011 and is poised for a “second spring” this year, driven by well-capitalized retailers and grocers, according to a new report.

headline: Awards Lists Keep ’Em Guessing
text: LOS ANGELES — You’re nobody till somebody snubs you. Especially when it comes to this year’s film awards.

headline: Remembering Tony Blankley
text: This is a personal note about a longtime friend to whom I owe so much.

headline: Traffic Agent With Unpaid Tickets Is Arrested Over Tow
text: Updated, 6:42 p.m. | A traffic agent who owed more than $450 in parking tickets was arrested Monday morning in Brooklyn, accused of trying to stop her S.U.V. from being towed, the authorities said.

headline: Ackman Plans Proxy Fight at Canadian Pacific
text: OTTAWA — The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman said Monday that he would wage a proxy battle to replace the directors and the chief executive of the Canadian Pacific Railway after it rejected his plan to bring in a former rival to run the company.

headline: Where Outlandish Meets Landish
text: CULVER CITY, Calif. — It may be best to stop reading this review right now. Otherwise you will know what to expect at the Museum of Jurassic Technology. And then, when you look through a magnifying glass and see a painted sculpture of Disney’s Goofy standing on the head of a needle, or learn how the stage machinery of Baroque theaters created the illusion of flowing water, or are told that some South American bats seem to fly through solid objects, you won’t have the same mixture of shock, marvel, delight and confusion as I did.

headline: With Its 2-Seat Roadster, Mini Picks Up Where MG Left Off
text: Shown on Monday, Jan. 9: 2012 Mini Roadster.

headline: After Long Gestation, Scion FR-S Makes Auto Show Debut
text: What is it? The name says it all, according to Toyota: FR-S stands for “front-engine, rear-wheel-drive, sport.” The 2-plus-2 coupe measures nearly a foot longer than a Corolla and carries decidedly sportier pretensions. Its Toyota-branded equivalent, the FT, was displayed at the Tokyo auto show in December, but Toyota clearly wants Scion to get a dose of performance cred, which was previously available only from the tC. The FR-S was previewed as a concept at the 2011 New York auto show.

headline: Nicotine Gum and Skin Patch Face New Doubt
text: The nicotine gum and patches that millions of smokers use to help kick their habit have no lasting benefit and may backfire in some cases, according to the most rigorous long-term study to date of so-called nicotine replacement therapy.

headline: A Night When All the World’s Onstage
text: The world was fused at Globalfest on Sunday night. The sold-out event at Webster Hall was the ninth-annual world-music showcase, timed to coincide with the Association of Performing Arts Presenters’ annual convention: 12 acts from 5 continents. At Globalfest the old image of world music as ethnomusicological finds — pure local styles directly imported from out-of-the-way places — has given way to a more worldly music, played by artists who self-consciously decide what to mix. They select from their own heritage and countless other possibilities; after all, they’ve got Internet connections themselves. Globalfest was recorded for NPR.

headline: The C.E.S. No-Shows
text: Thousands of companies come to Las Vegas each year for the Consumer Electronics Show. But it is becoming interesting to see who skips it.

headline: Using Modern Tools to Reconstruct Ancient Life
text: ASHKELON, Israel — To the naked eye, the white, powdery substance appeared to be plaster. That’s what the professional and volunteer archaeologists at a dig in Israel concluded.

headline: In Japan, a Rebuilt Island Serves as a Cautionary Tale
text: OKUSHIRI, Japan — On the night of July 12, 1993, the remote island of Okushiri was ripped apart by a huge earthquake and tsunami that now seem an eerie harbinger of the much larger disaster that struck northeastern Japan last March. Islanders still recall with horror how a wall of frothing black water raced out of the darkness to consume entire communities, leaving almost 200 people dead.

headline: Tensions ‘Resolved,’ Olbermann Plans Campaign Coverage on Current
text: Keith Olbermann will be absent from his nightly “Countdown” on Monday night, and the rest of this week, too.

headline: New Cookbooks From Paula Deen
text: Paula Deen, below, the superstar Southern chef whose extravagant use of butter has inspired rants from fellow food celebrities like Anthony Bourdain, is going to be a busy woman over the next two years. In 2013 and 2014 she will release three e-books focusing on seasonal entertaining and two new cookbooks, her new publisher said. Ballantine Books, part of Random House, has lured back Ms. Deen after losing her to Simon & Schuster more than a decade ago. (Pamela Cannon, now an executive editor at Random House, discovered Ms. Deen in 1997 while dining at her restaurant, The Lady & Sons, in Savannah, Ga., and edited her first two cookbooks.) Gina Centrello, the president and publisher of the Random House Publishing Group, said in a statement, “As her Random House family, we are especially thrilled to welcome Paula Deen back home where together we will build upon and expand her singular and remarkable brand.”

headline: Scientist’s Online Interviews Draw His Peers Out of Lecture Mode

headline: In Brazil, Officers of the Law, Outside the Law
text: NITERÓI, Brazil — Patrícia Acioli, a judge known for imprisoning corrupt police officers, pulled into the driveway of her home one August night in this city across the bay from Rio de Janeiro. Her pursuers arrived at the same time. Then they did their work, shooting her 21 times until her body lay crumpled in the seat of her car.

headline: A Rising Tide of South Korean Golfers
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii — On Wednesday nights before a tournament, K. J. Choi visits the Korean Baptist church closest to the course he is playing, a practice that dates to when he was the PGA Tour’s first and only full-time player from South Korea. In the familiar hymns, sung in his native tongue, Choi experiences a connection, a communion, that he struggled at first to forge on the tour, where the courses and the language were foreign to him.

headline: The London Olympics, Coming in 3D
text: LAS VEGAS — Panasonic and NBC announced on Monday that the network will broadcast the London Olympic Games in 3D. Of course, viewers need a 3D television to enjoy the show, but Panasonic undoubtedly hopes sports fanatics will feel compelled to buy new sets.

headline: Maryland: Former Soldier Charged With Trying to Aid Terrorism
text: A former soldier from Maryland was charged Monday with trying to provide material support to a terrorist organization in Africa. Federal authorities say the soldier, Craig B. Baxam, 24, flew to Kenya last month with the goal of joining the militant terrorist group Al Shabab in Somalia. He converted to Islam shortly before dropping out of the United States Army in July, after four years of service, including in Iraq, federal authorities said. Mr. Baxam planned to donate money to Al Shabab, a violent militia group that opposes the Somalian government, authorities said. He faces a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison.

headline: New Rental Service Focuses on Indie Film
text: If you have a new business that involves indie film, this is your moment to hustle — or at least to hire a publicist to hustle on your behalf. Sundance starts next week, and it’s a make-or-break moment for glom-on marketing.

headline: Disney Movie Marketer Resigns After 20 Months
text: LOS ANGELES — M T Carney, Walt Disney’s president of global movie marketing, resigned late Monday after a difficult 20 months on the job.

headline: Optimism, but Mixed Results, at the Vanguard
text: DULUTH, Ga. — As Grace Min’s eyes followed the flight of her serve toss, about two dozen spectators in folding chairs formed a single row at courtside. Most were friends and extended family, lending support.

headline: Need a Mattress to Go With That TV? You’re in the Right Place
text: AFTER seeing countless wireless gadgets at the annual International Consumer Electronics Show, which begins Tuesday in Las Vegas, attendees may be surprised to encounter the Schick booth, where men in barbershop chairs will have their faces wrapped in hot towels and be shaved by barbers.

headline: No Longer Starting, Lee Set Up Tigers’ Big Finish
text: NEW ORLEANS — During Jarrett Lee’s time at Louisiana State, he has had plenty of occasions to be mad and had plenty of opportunities to be ecstatic. Through them all, he has been stoic, even as his roller-coaster ride of a career has made him the focus of frequent criticism for many Tigers fans.

headline: Recession Holds Down Health Spending
text: WASHINGTON — National health spending rose a slight 3.9 percent in 2010, as Americans delayed hospital care, doctor’s visits and prescription drug purchases for the second year in a row, the Obama administration reported Monday.

headline: TripAdvisor Abandons List of Dirtiest Hotels

headline: Video: The Changing Nature of the Consumer Electronics Show
text: LAS VEGAS — The International Consumer Electronics Show has long enjoyed a central role in taking the pulse of the tech industry. But Microsoft recently announced that it would no longer exhibit at the show after this year. Other tech giants like Hewlett-Packard, Google and Facebook are keeping a low profile at the show, if they bother to show up at all. It all reflects shifts in the tech industry, as Nick Wingfield reported in Monday’s New York Times.

headline: Pentagon Tries to Counter Cheap, Potent Weapons
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s new military strategy has focused fresh attention on an increasingly important threat: the use of inexpensive weapons like mines and cyberattacks that aim not to defeat the American military in battle but to keep it at a distance.

headline: Where Are the Liberals?
text: Why aren’t there more liberals in America?

text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — With a loud crowd of protesters amassed on the sidewalk, Newt Gingrich skipped an appearance at his campaign headquarters in New Hampshire, where about 100 volunteers and supporters waited for him on the eve of primary day.

headline: Recovered Body Could Be Packers Assistant’s Son
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The 21-year-old son of the Green Bay Packers’ offensive coordinator was missing Monday, the same day that a body was recovered from a river in Oshkosh, where the man was last seen.

headline: I.R.S. Renews Disclosure Program for Offshore Assets
text: After collecting $4.4 billion in two previous so-called voluntary disclosure programs for offshore accounts, the Internal Revenue Service said Monday that it would revive the program. Participants will pay as much as 27.5 percent of their most valuable offshore assets or their biggest overseas bank account. They also must disclose the banks and advisers that helped them escape United Sates tax laws.

headline: Santorum Supporter Gets a Taste of the Big Leagues
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Rod Olsen, a stay-at-home father who lives in California, always wanted to work on a political campaign in New Hampshire. For him, the state was the Wrigley Field of politics, the iconic place where political junkies have to go at least once in their lives.

text: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

headline: Rob Glassett
text: Interviews with voters before the New Hampshire Republican primary.

headline: Josh McDaniels, Key Figure for the Broncos, Is Now a Patriot
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — Coach John Fox, though in his first year with the Broncos, has been around the N.F.L. long enough to view success with an appropriately gimlet eye. In the moments after Denver upset the Pittsburgh Steelers in the weekend’s most improbable playoff game, Fox was asked what he would have thought if someone had told him at the start of the season that he would be in this position now.

headline: Peace Talks Are Discussed in a Session in Jordan
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli and Palestinian officials met in the Jordanian capital on Monday, their second session in less than a week, after peace talks had been stalled for more than a year. The encounter was kept at such a low profile, however, that it was almost as if it had not happened at all — attesting to the fragility of the contacts and the apparently minimal expectations each side has for progress.

headline: The Digital Humanities and the Transcending of Mortality
text: This is a blog. There, I’ve said it. I have been resisting saying it — I have always referred to this space as a “column” — not only because “blog” is an ugly word (as are clog, smog and slog), but because blogs are provisional, ephemeral, interactive, communal, available to challenge, interruption and interpolation, and not meant to last; whereas in a professional life now going into its 50th year I have been building arguments that are intended to be decisive, comprehensive, monumental, definitive and, most important, all mine.

headline: Health and Home Field Are Two More Advantages for the Packers
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — It may seem counterintuitive, but the Green Bay Packers — the defending Super Bowl champions, with a 15-1 record and a leading contender for the N.F.L.’s Most Valuable Player award at quarterback — think they are being overlooked.

headline: After Beyoncé Gives Birth, Patients Protest Celebrity Security at Lenox Hill Hospital
text: The couple were visiting their twin daughters in the neonatal intensive care unit at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan on Friday night, as they have done daily since the babies’ premature birth on Dec. 28. But when they tried to leave the sixth-floor unit to go home to Brooklyn at about 11 p.m., the new mother, Rozz Nash-Coulon, recalled, a burly security guard suddenly blocked their way.

headline: Iraq: 16 Killed in Multiple Attacks
text: At least 16 people were killed across Iraq on Monday in car bombings, assassinations, roadside bomb blasts and attacks on security forces. The rash of seemingly unconnected attacks stoked fears that disparate insurgent groups from around Iraq are trying to sow sectarian violence by exploiting the uncertainty and instability of the country’s political crisis. On Monday, two car bombs exploded in Shiite areas of Baghdad — one near a mosque, the other near a market — killing 12 people and wounding 50. Earlier in the day, a bank manager was assassinated outside her home in a middle-class Baghdad neighborhood. In the oil-rich city of Kirkuk, two Kurdish security forces were killed in a checkpoint attack.

headline: A Merger Once Scoffed At Bears Fruit in Detroit
text: DETROIT — The unlikely union of Chrysler and its Italian parent, Fiat, is beginning to produce new vehicles that combine the talents of both companies.

text: Today, I’m going to say some nice things about BP and some not so nice things about the lawyers who are suing BP. Please don’t spill your coffee.

text: I’M a proud dad, and I hate missing my children’s sporting events because of travel. But I do try to get updates, no matter where I am.

headline: The Knife in the Carry-On
text: For most business travelers, the post-Sept. 11 restrictions on carrying sharp objects onto planes are minor inconveniences. But for those who work in an industry focused on sharp or dangerous objects, business trips can be prone to problems without proper planning.

headline: Paying a Price, Long After the Crime
text: IN 2010, the Chicago Public Schools declined to hire Darrell Langdon for a job as a boiler-room engineer, because he had been convicted of possessing a half-gram of cocaine in 1985, a felony for which he received probation. It didn’t matter that Mr. Langdon, a single parent of two sons, had been clean since 1988 and hadn’t run into further trouble with the law. Only after The Chicago Tribune wrote about his case did the school system reverse its decision and offer him the job.
