headline: Voting in N.H. Opens as Romney Fends Off Attacks
text: BEDFORD, N.H. — Mitt Romney fought to keep an upper hand in the Republican presidential race on Tuesday as his rivals sought to slow his march to the nomination and raise doubts about his electability by branding him as a job-killing corporate villain.

headline: Egypt’s Women Find Power Still Hinges on Men
text: CAIRO — At first Samira Ibrahim was afraid to tell her father that Egyptian soldiers had detained her in Tahrir Square in Cairo, stripped off her clothes, and watched as she was forcibly subjected to a “virginity test.”

headline: Laugh During Wartime
text: Americans remember the Civil War for the carnage it caused, the people it liberated and the nation it rebuilt. Rarely do they remember it for the comedy it inspired.

text: Passengers traveling through Terminal 4 at Kennedy International Airport in recent months could be excused for confusing it with a maze under construction.

headline: U.S. Strategy Points to Threat of Cheap but Potent Weapons
text: President Obama and his national security team are drawing attention to what they see as a growing threat to the American military. In an article in Tuesday’s issue of The Times, Thom Shanker reports on the administration’s prediction that security challenges in the coming decade will be defined by the use of relatively inexpensive weapons to keep American forces at a distance, rather than defeat them outright.He writes:

headline: Alexis Weissenberg, Pianist of Fire and Ice, Dies at 82
text: Alexis Weissenberg, a charismatic Bulgarian-born pianist known for his thundering aggressiveness and rational detachment at the keyboard, and for his unapologetic defense of those traits in interviews, died on Sunday in Lugano, Switzerland. He was 82.

headline: With Lumia 900, Nokia and Microsoft Bid for Smartphone Relevance
text: LAS VEGAS — What is it with Jan. 9 and smartphones?

headline: The Corporate Candidates
text: The more Mitt Romney pretends to empathize with the millions of Americans who are struggling in this economy, the less he seems to understand their despair. And the rest of the Republican field seems to have no more insight into the concerns of most voters than he does.

headline: Olympus Sues Executives Over Covering Up Losses
text: The scandal-tainted Olympus Corporation said it was suing 19 current and former executives over their roles in a $1.7 billion cover-up of losses after an independent panel’s report into management involvement in the fraud.

headline: A Paradox of Smaller Wall Street Paychecks
text: Is Wall Street cutting bonuses enough?

headline: Drilling Critics Face a Divide Over the Goal of Their Fight
text: With a deadline looming this week for the public to weigh in on gas drilling in New York State, the antifracking movement itself has become divided over what its goal should be: securing the nation’s toughest regulations, or winning an outright ban?

headline: Renewed Sparring Over Scottish Independence Movement
text: LONDON — The smoldering issue of Scottish independence has ignited again, this time in a political context that appears to give Scottish nationalists at least an outside chance of gaining popular support for the end of Scotland’s constitutional ties with Britain in a referendum among Scottish voters within the next two or three years.

headline: Nigerians Protest Rise in Oil Prices
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Tens of thousands of Nigerians took to the streets in cities across the country on Monday to protest a sudden sharp rise in oil prices after the government abruptly ended fuel subsidies. At the same time, a national strike over the oil price increase shut down much of the country.

headline: A Big Check, and Gingrich Gets a Big Lift
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — For weeks this winter, as Newt Gingrich’s presidential hopes faltered under the weight of millions of dollars in attack ads paid for by backers of Mitt Romney, a small group of Gingrich supporters quietly lobbied for help from one of the richest men in America: Sheldon Adelson, a billionaire casino owner and Mr. Gingrich’s longtime friend and patron.

headline: Violence Continues in Syria
text: The Arab League is failing the Syrian people. President Bashar al-Assad of Syria grudgingly agreed to the league’s peace plan last month, but his brutal 10-month crackdown against mostly peaceful protesters shows no signs of easing. To have any chance of stopping the bloodshed, the league — backed by the international community — needs to get tougher with the butcher in Damascus.

headline: Mr. Menendez’s Missing ‘Blue Slip’
text: Senator Robert Menendez’s decision to hold up President Obama’s nomination of Patty Shwartz, a well-regarded federal magistrate judge, to a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, has the unsavory flavor of political revenge.

headline: Mormon Church’s Plans for Land Upset Harlem
text: The wider world does not often glimpse the internal disputes of the Mormon Church. Formally known as the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the fast-growing religion is expanding in places as far-flung as Africa and Latin America, but most big decisions are still made centrally by a church hierarchy in Salt Lake City.

headline: Gov. Gregoire Comes Around
text: Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington showed her admirable political evolution last week when she urged her state to legalize same-sex marriage. Eight years ago, she was wary, saying the state was not “ready to support” such historic change. Four years ago, she said she would “leave it to the churches to make that call.”

headline: Sawa and Messi Are FIFA’s Players of Year
text: Marta’s five-year run as the top female player in the world came to an end Monday in Zurich when FIFA awarded its Ballon d’Or to midfielder Homare Sawa, who helped Japan win the Women’s World Cup last summer in Germany.

headline: A New Race of Mercy to Nome, This Time Without Sled Dogs
text: NOME, Alaska — In the winter of 1925, long after this Gold Rush boomtown on the Bering Sea had gone bust, diphtheria swept through its population of 1,400. Medicine ran dangerously low, and there was no easy way to get more. No roads led here, flight was ruled out and Norton Sound was frozen solid.

headline: U.S. Inquiry of MF Global Gains Speed
text: The investigation into MF Global is intensifying as federal authorities unearth new details and confront potential obstacles in their hunt for roughly $1.2 billion in customer money that disappeared from the brokerage firm.

headline: Tuesday: Cordial Relations
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I already know what you’re thinking. You’re thinking that TOILET PAPER would have made a spiffy theme entry. I agree. Unfortunately, the long theme entries here are 10s, not 11s, so I’m guessing the bathroom tissue got flushed (sorry).

headline: Ground Game Determines Candidates’ Strength
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — The 2012 primary campaign has been by far the most volatile on record, with one candidate after another surging to the front of the pack and then falling back again.

headline: Where Is Europe?
text: Where is Europe? You might as well ask: What is Europe? For it is a concept as well as a continent, and the borders of both oscillate wildly. For the ancient Persians, it was that small stepping stone separating them from Greece. In the Middle Ages, it became virtually synonymous with Christendom. A relatively recent and generally unaccepted theory sees Europe spanning half the globe, from Iceland to the Bering Strait, nearly touching Alaska.

headline: Please Hold the Cheese
text: A charge of “pious baloney” from the king of sanctimonious salami: that was the taste of Debate Weekend, during which Newt Gingrich of all people called out Mitt Romney for larded self-aggrandizement. Takes one lunchmeat to know another.

headline: There’s No Letting Go of the Girl He Stole
text: Joseph Incognito had the scare of his life seven months ago. Returning home one afternoon, he was told by residents of the apartment building that his wife had just died. He arrived on his floor to see a stretcher and emergency services workers in the hallway. He said he felt as if he was about to have a heart attack — until he realized that the dead person was not his wife, but a next-door neighbor.

headline: A Developer Between Legal Clouds

headline: Daley Stepping Down in Rare White House Shake-Up
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Monday that the White House chief of staff, William M. Daley, was stepping down, jolting the top ranks of his administration less than a year before he faces a difficult re-election. Mr. Daley will be replaced by Jacob J. Lew, the budget director and a seasoned Washington insider with ties to Capitol Hill.

headline: Inspectors Say Iran Is Enriching Uranium at Mountain Site
text: Atomic inspectors in Vienna confirmed Monday that Iran has begun enriching uranium at a new plant carved out of a mountain, an act of defiance that comes amid rising tensions between Washington and Tehran over oil revenues and global sanctions.

headline: Russian Child Disappears Into Pipe After Falling Into a Sinkhole
text: MOSCOW — A woman pushing her child in a baby stroller suffered a horrific accident in a provincial Russian city over the weekend when a section of sidewalk suddenly opened into a yawning crater under her feet, the result of a sinkhole from a broken pipe.

headline: Plan for Trump to Run a Bronx Golf Course Has Critics

headline: From Boardwalk to Barrio, Los Angeles Cracks Down
text: LOS ANGELES — On the boardwalk of Venice Beach, the trinkets seem endless. There are glass pipes, copper necklaces, feather earrings and painted wooden skulls.

headline: Confirmed: U.S. Will Play Italy in February
text: U.S. Soccer on Monday confirmed the worst-kept secret about its national team, announcing that the United States would play Italy in Genoa on Feb. 29. That is the last official FIFA match date for friendlies before June, when the Americans start World Cup qualifying and the Italians begin play in the European championship.

headline: Microsoft Leaves C.E.S. on a Quiet Note

text: Miguel Terekhov, a dancer with the two leading Ballets Russes troupes of the 1940s and ’50s and a co-founder, with his wife, of the School of Dance at the University of Oklahoma, one of America’s leading university dance programs, died on Jan. 3 at the home of a daughter in Richardson, Tex. He was 83 and lived in Oklahoma City.

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi Confirms She Will Run for Parliament
text: BANGKOK — Myanmar’s opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, confirmed on Tuesday that she would run for a seat in the country’s new Parliament in a by-election scheduled for April in which her party, the National League for Democracy, will enter the new political structure for the first time.

headline: North Korea Announces It Will Release Prisoners
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Tuesday that it would release prisoners in its first special amnesty in seven years, a day after soldiers paraded in the capital, Pyongyang, vowing to become “rifles and bombs” to defend the country’s new leader, Kim Jong-un. The military rally in Pyongyang on Monday and the special pardon, effective from Feb. 1, came as North Korea escalated a campaign to consolidate support for Mr. Kim.

headline: Photographing Politics in Changing Times
text: Jim Wilson started at The New York Times in 1980, working primarily as a staff photographer and a photo editor. Covering politics over the decades, he has seen tremendous changes – both in the style of the campaigns and the technology he has used to photograph them. In recent weeks, he’s been covering the Republican presidential campaign in Iowa and New Hampshire, focusing almost entirely on Mitt Romney. He spoke with James Estrin from Manchester, N.H. Their conversation had been edited.

headline: On Lens: Times Photographer Jim Wilson in New Hampshire
text: Jim Wilson covered his first presidential primary in 1976, shooting for The Charlotte Observer. Covering politics over the decades, he has seen tremendous changes ­ both in the style of the campaigns and the technology used to photograph them.

headline: Pakistani Judges Press Premier to Defy President
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The political and legal crisis in Pakistan took a new turn on Tuesday when the Supreme Court threatened to dismiss Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani for failing to comply with court orders to reopen corruption cases against his political boss: President Asif Ali Zardari.

headline: What if Your Parent Ran for President?
text: Four of Mitt Romney’s five sons are actively engaged in helping their father’s campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, as are the adult daughters of Jon M. Huntsman Jr. If one of your parents were to run for president, would you work on his or her campaign? Would you want your role to be highly public and visible, or would you prefer to stay behind the scenes?

headline: Olympus Sues Executives Over Cover-Up, but Does Not Dismiss Them
text: TOKYO — Olympus said on Tuesday that it was suing 19 current and former executives and board members, including its current president, for around $50 million over an accounting scheme to hide losses going back more than a decade.

headline: From Rebels to Rulers
text: JOHANNESBURG — Africa’s oldest liberation movement, the African National Congress (A.N.C.), held a lavish birthday bash last weekend to celebrate its founding 100 years ago. More than 40 heads of state gathered in the small church in the small city of Bloemfontein, the A.N.C.’s birthplace, to celebrate the party’s role in defeating white-minority rule and apartheid. And deservedly: the A.N.C.’s accomplishments as a liberation movement are extraordinary.

headline: The Early Word: Replaced
Tattoos, Through Time: A New Museum for Amsterdam
text: In Amsterdam, which claims to have the greatest number of museums per square mile in the world, few topics are left unexplored. There is a museum that delves into sex, another on war (or at least the Dutch resistance), and a museum dedicated, of course, to marijuana. Last fall, a museum opened with a focus on another topic that rarefied institutions generally avoid: tattoos.

headline: A Brooklyn Tea Company Backed by a Socialist President

headline: Is Mark Wahlberg the Greatest Actor of His Generation?
text: While undertaking my extensive research in order to compose five haiku poems on the career of Mark Wahlberg, I came across this surprising (to me) fact: Wahlberg, the 40-year-old actor, successful producer, onetime rapper, loquacious friend to animals and former Calvin Klein model, has not one but two Oscar nominations to his credit. One is for Best Supporting Actor for “The Departed” in 2007, and one came in 2011 for his role as a producer of the Best Picture-nominated “The Fighter,” in which he also starred.

headline: Kirchner’s False Positive
text: BUENOS AIRES — Last week, I took a look at President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s cancer diagnosis and how she has personalized power far too much. On Saturday, Argentinians were stunned to learn that, after removing the president’s thyroid gland, doctors discovered she didn’t have cancer after all but rather a benign tumor. Following the initial relief, doubts quickly set in: despite assurances that such misdiagnoses can happen, many Kirchner critics cited the episode as another example of why the government’s words can’t be trusted.

The companies did not announce which pay-TV providers would offer enhanced Olympics coverage, Multichannel News reported, “but presumably Comcast — which owns NBCUniversal — will be in the mix, along with DirecTV, which has aimed to be the leading provider of 3DTV in the U.S.”

AT&T talked about new smartphones that would run on its fast 4G network, including the Titan II from HTC. And Nokia, as expected, unveiled the Lumia 900, Nick Wingfield reported from the show. That phone, which runs Microsoft’s Windows Phone operating system, represents a bid by Microsoft and Nokia to return to relevance in the smartphone market, after being marginalized by Apple and Google’s Android system.

headline: Google Adds Posts From Its Social Network to Search Results
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s popularity was built on its ability to help people find just the right Web pages. Then came the social Web, led by Facebook, where people go to see vast amounts of material that has largely been off-limits to Google — conversations and photos posted by their friends.

headline: Snoop Dogg Busted at Same Border Crossing That Snared Willie Nelson
text: If it’s your job to plan the touring schedule of rebellious rock, hip-hop and country musicians, you might consider organizing future itineraries to avoid the Sierra Blanca highway checkpoint near El Paso. It was there, The Associated Press reported, that the rapper Snoop Dogg was arrested on Saturday for a misdemeanor drug charge, which might not be newsworthy in and of itself, except that Willie Nelson was busted at that same border crossing in 2010.

headline: Songbirds as  a Casualty of Warming

headline: A Rare Glimpse Inside the Ivy League’s Academic Index
text: In an article published on Christmas Day in The New York Times, I described specific elements of the mysterious Academic Index, a tool used by Ivy League institutions – and increasingly other colleges and universities – to measure the basic academic qualifications of recruited athletes. The Academic Index, created in the 1980s and never disclosed publicly by the institutions themselves, uses a formula that assigns each recruit a number based on his or her standardized tests scores and high school grade point average.

headline: Fatal Stampede in South Africa Points Up University Crisis
text: JOHANNESBURG — They lined up well before dawn, some driving from the deep countryside with bags of fluffy blankets and neatly packed sandwiches, to wait for the gates to a new life to open. They hoped for a shot at a coveted spot at one of South Africa’s public universities, and with it a chance to escape the indignity of joblessness that afflicts more than a third of the nation. By morning, the line was more than a mile long.

headline: Dispatches From the Annual Designers’ Party
text: DETROIT — In addition to the teeming variety of car paintings, neon Porsche signs, race-car parts and other automotive bric-a-brac arranged throughout Camilo Pardo’s loft on Woodward Avenue, there were two notable newcomers.

headline: What We’re Reading

headline: Big City Book Club: ‘A Walker in the City’
text: I am usually suspicious of memoirs produced by writers who have not yet reached middle age, but Kazin, like so many of his provenance and generation, seemed to possess a voice of centenarian authority as a young man. At 26, he had audaciously established himself as a significant literary critic with “On Native Ground,” his magnum opus on American letters of the first half of the 20th century. His writing hardly betrayed a tentative hand.

headline: Who Fires Whom?

headline: MKZ Concept Is the Next Step in Lincoln’s Reinvention

headline: Doing His Best De Niro Impression, in Front of the Real De Niro
text: Moments before Robert De Niro sat next to him, Jean Dujardin was trying out his De Niro impression. Mr. Dujardin, the handsome, elastic-faced French star of “The Artist,” was at the New York Film Critics Circle awards dinner on Monday night, where “The Artist” won best director and best film. The event capped off a whirlwind day that included a lunch with the publicist Peggy Siegal and the taping of an appearance on “Charlie Rose.”

headline: Other Voices: The Night it Snowed Grebes in Utah
text: Suzie Gilbert, a friend and neighbor, has for many years been a hard-working bird rehabilitator, a career described beautifully in her recent book “Flyaway.” She also recently launched a blog, The Crooked Wing, and alerted me to a post on a remarkable occurrence last month in Utah, when thousands of migrating eared grebes, evidently disoriented by a storm, began crash landing on roads, parking lots and the like — surfaces they apparently mistook for water. They can only take flight from water, making such landings a death sentence for those that survived the impact.

headline: Just One Look | Givenchy
text: “This prefall collection is all about the best of Givenchy,” the house designer Ricardo Tisci said at yesterday’s presentation. Inserting a mix of what Tisci named “American 1950s housewife” and “French ’70s style” into “the best of our men’s, women’s and couture,” he delivered a look that is all tough and refined and, literally, ready to wear now and for seasons to come. Hits include pieces featuring a subtle paillette print, a herringbone and cashmere suit, wool jackets stiffened with men’s fabrications, then wrapped in places with the softest organza, and this expertly tailored croc-trimmed tuxedo. Worth noting also are the collection’s elongating boots, furry baseball caps and sharp talon ear studs (see: editors swooning).

headline: Businessmen and Economics
text: A brief thought on something I’ll try to expand on later. Leaving aside all the questions about what Mitt Romney did or didn’t do at Bain — and about his self-aggrandizing double standard — there’s an even broader question: why does anyone believe that success in business qualified someone to make economic policy?

headline: The Keys to the Cos
text: Here is a series of vignettes from Bill Cosby’s 50-year television career, showcasing examples of what has made him so good for so long.

headline: Leading Off: Bad Season Ends Worse
text: If you were trying to get the college football system torn up and thrown out, you couldn’t have orchestrated the end of this season any more persuasively. Yes, Alabama took all the drama out of who should be No. 1 with its 21-0 victory over thought-to-be-unbeatable Louisiana State Monday night, but what a small victory that turned out to be. It capped the year of Jerry Sandusky and Joe Paterno’s fall, of Ohio State’s probation forming the other big rapids in a raging river of ethical failures and misplaced priorities. It came at the end of a string of uninspired, made-for-bad-TV bowls, played so far after the season ended that even the major players needed name tags. And the finale was a conference rematch about as attractive as a Kris Humphries-Kim Kardashian reunion.

headline: Mining Cosby’s Golden Past
text: For a while now, Bill Cosby has been at the point in his career where people just want to shower him with accolades. A Kennedy Center honor in 1998. The Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2002. The Mark Twain Prize for American Humor in 2009.

headline: Gingrich Goes Negative in Anti-Romney Ad
text: Newt Gingrich has officially done away with the shades of gray in his anti-Mitt Romney ads.

headline: Toyota NS4 Concept
text: Toyota NS4 Concept slide show

headline: What if Insurers Didn’t Pay for Crashes Caused by Texting?
text: Last month, the National Transportation Safety Board called for a nationwide ban on the use of cellphones and other “portable electronic devices” while driving.

headline: The Bright Spot in Tech I.P.O.’s: Enterprise
text: When it comes to initial public offerings of high-tech companies, maybe low profile is better.

headline: Amid Inquiry, Liu Marks His Birthday With a Fund-Raiser
text: As birthday parties go, turning 45 usually doesn’t mean a lot. But it sure did for John C. Liu, the city comptroller.

headline: Coil Festival: 5 Questions About ‘Mission Drift’
text: Rock music, Dutch teenagers, global financial turmoil, the best and worst of Las Vegas: all of it takes the stage in “Mission Drift,” by the New York-based theater company the TEAM (Theater of the Emerging American Moment). The piece comes to New York as part of this year’s Coil Festival after winning several awards at last year’s Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

headline: This Is Citizens United
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — From December 1 until the Iowa caucuses on January 3, 45 percent of all ads airing in Iowa were directed against Newt Gingrich, who promptly lost his frontrunner status and came in fourth. Financing for these ads came from Ron Paul, Rick Perry and Restore Our Future, a Super PAC that backs Mitt Romney.

headline: Just One Look | Chloé
text: Soft round shapes, softer tie-neck blouses and clean, pleated dresses in even softer dusty colors star in Clare Waight Keller’s second collection for Chloé. Paired with all of these pretty, work-ready clothes are accessories that look just as beautiful and uncomplicated, like glossy slip-in ankle boots and slipper-front pumps — and there’s a new bag, Lucy, a slim three-pocket with zipper closures that comes in multiple colorways and fabrics, with leather handles or a chain strap. The check version of the bag is shown here with cropped pants, a brushed wool plaid coat and this editor’s favorite new flat: an emerald green loafer embellished with metal-tipped fringe.

headline: Toyota Grasps for Heartstrings With NS4 Concept
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 10: Toyota NS4 concept.

headline: 2013 Buick Encore
text: 2013 Buick Encore slide show

headline: Attacks on Romney Prompt G.O.P. Backlash
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Attacks on Mitt Romney by some of his rivals set off outrage within the Republican Party on Tuesday as voters went to the polls and the candidates turned their attention to South Carolina.

headline: Cirque du Soleil 3-D Movie Coming at You This Year
text: According to a partial list compiled by Dan Kois for The New York Times Magazine, moviegoers at 3-D films last year had Captain America’s shield, Justin Bieber’s hand and 40 partly chewed bean buns flung at them in stereoscopic illusions. This year, audiences can get ready to guard their laps against Cirque du Soleil acrobats who appear to be flying off the screen: Paramount said on Tuesday that it had acquired the distribution rights for a new 3-D movie about that Montreal-based circus troupe, written and directed by Andrew Adamson (of the “Shrek” and “Narnia” franchises) and produced by, among others, James Cameron (a filmmaker who knows a thing or two about 3-D movies). The film, called “Cirque du Soleil Worlds Away,” will feature performances from various shows presented by the troupe. Rob Moore, the vice chairman of Paramount, said in a statement that it will also include “a timeless original story written especially for this movie.” The studio said “Cirque du Soleil Worlds Away” is planned for worldwide release later this year.

headline: Rule Change Would Allow Some Foreign-Owned Stores to Open in India
text: MUMBAI, India — A month after political opposition led the Indian government to indefinitely delay a decision to allow foreign retailers like Walmart into the country, policy makers on Tuesday changed a rule that would make it easier for predominantly single-brand foreign chains like Ikea and Gap to set up fully owned stores here.

headline: In Talks With the Chinese, Geithner Faces an Uphill Climb
text: BEIJING — Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, came to Beijing on Tuesday hoping to persuade Chinese leaders to toughen their stance toward Iran and to soften their opposition to a stronger renminbi, a move that could help the American economy.

headline: Storm-Ravaged Village Builds a Bond at the Lunch Table
text: SCHOHARIE, N.Y.

headline: Return of the Repressed
text: In the course of the 2000s, under a tax-cutting, business-friendly Republican administration, middle class paychecks grew much more slowly than the economy as a whole, upward mobility for the poor continued to lag behind parts of Western Europe, and the combination of unfunded tax cuts and deficit spending worsened the country’s fiscal picture just as the Baby Boomers were poised to retire. Then came the financial crisis, touched off in part by gross recklessness on Wall Street. Then came the Great Recession, which threw millions of Americans out of work, hit downscale workers much harder than it did the college-educated, and sent the deficit spiraling upward to unprecedented heights.

headline: Just One Look | Prabal Gurung
text: Prabal Gurung’s first prefall collection was consistent with the designer’s aesthetic: pretty with an edge. The silhouettes ranged from classic sheaths (in emerald green) to prim pleated skirts and fish-tail shirtdresses (with contrast colors on front and back). But what makes Gurung the next generation’s red carpet go-to for the avant-garde (Rooney Mara, Jessica Chastain) is his ability to imprint himself on traditional fabrics and textures.

headline: John Hiatt Performs Songs for the Road at Panasonic Press Event
text: DETROIT — As the first day of press previews came to an end on Monday night, in an antiseptic conference room on the second floor of the Cobo Center, music broke out. The Panasonic Automotive Systems Company of America decided to sweeten the appeal of the company’s press conference by presenting John Hiatt, the progressive country and western songwriter and singer known for songs about cars and the roads. He was also promoting his own product, his latest CD called “Dirty Jeans and Mudslide Hymns.”

headline: On Our Radar: A New Snake
text: The Wildlife Conservation Society reports the discovery of a striking snake, the Matilda’s horned viper, in eastern Tanzania. Its habitat, estimated at only a few square miles, is already severely degraded from logging and the manufacture of charcoal, the group says, and the species is likely to be classified as critically endangered.

headline: Lincoln, on the Hot Seat at Cobo Center
text: DETROIT — To build drama around the debut of its MKZ concept, Lincoln used no fog machines. The sedan nevertheless created a wisp of ambience later in the morning here with an electrical fire in the driver’s door panel.

headline: After Departures, Discovery Reorganizes Its Executive Suite
text: Discovery Communications on Monday named a new chief financial officer and spread out the responsibilities of its former chief operating officer, completing a reorganization of the company’s executive suite.

headline: Toyota Prius C
text: Overview of the car.

headline: Taking My Children to the New Hampshire Primary
text: Because I live in New Hampshire, I got up bright and early this morning, loaded the kids in the car and headed out to vote. My children are 10, 7, 6 and 5, and the two oldest remember coming with me to vote in the last presidential election. But a primary is different, and more confusing. Even though I’d explained it several times in the last few weeks, only my oldest child, Sam, really remembered what the primary meant (and when I asked him to name some of the differences between the Republican and Democratic Parties, he offered that the Democrats were represented by a blue elephant — although he was able to correctly identify his grandfather as a Republican).

headline: Brad Pitt, Denbygate and Other Scenes From the Critics Circle
text: There was higher-than-normal security at the New York Film Critics Circle awards dinner, but it wasn’t for fear of a showdown between David Denby and Scott Rudin. (Not that anyone had forgotten about Denbygate – more on that later.)

headline: In an Effort to Greet Voters, Gingrich Finds Mainly News Media
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — “This is like being in New Orleans at Mardi Gras!” Newt Gingrich called out from one of his most intense crowds of the week. But it was not a crush of voters. As he dropped by a polling place at a school just a few blocks from downtown Manchester, he was pounced on by scores of journalists Tuesday morning.

headline: Fed Turns Over $77 Billion in Profits to the Treasury
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said on Tuesday that it contributed $76.9 billion in profits to the Treasury Department last year, slightly less than its record 2010 transfer but much more than in any other previous year.

headline: Romney’s Big Government Critique Runs Into a New Hampshire Roadblock
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.–There was a little-noticed moment in Saturday’s Republican debate that perfectly illustrated why Mitt Romney is having a hard time persuading ordinary voters that he cares about their concerns.

headline: An Alternative Way to Test Students' Progress
text: Studies show that test-focused education is not preparing students for college, says a writer. So why not substitute testing for all with a program of test-based audits using samples of students?, the author asks in an opinion article.

headline: Mayor's Address Will Highlight Small Schools Initiative
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivers his state of the city speech on Thursday, he will do so from a public school. Four schools, to be exact. The mayor will speak from the Morris Educational Campus in the Bronx at 1 p.m.

headline: Video Shows Attack on Arab League Monitors in Syria
text: The Arab League said that 11 of its monitors in Syria sustained “light” injuries on Monday during an attack “by pro-regime elements in Latakia,” a northwestern port city.

headline: What Can U.S. Universities Do About a Student Stampede in Johannesburg?
text: A sad development in South Africa provides fresh support for my shift in this blog toward exploring ways universities can help create a global network for sharing and shaping ideas — what I’ve taken to calling the “Knowosphere.”

headline: Just Where Are Those Voters?
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — There’s a belief among some that the New Hampshire primary is nothing but a media spectacle, one in which out-of-state supporters, protesters, members of the news media and tourists engage in a contrived sound-stage ideal of a “quaint small-town democracy” in a circuslike atmosphere.

headline: Up, Up and Away Into Ford’s Cloud
text: DETROIT — Notwithstanding its recent problems with the Ford MyTouch telematics system, Ford has been keen to trumpet its leading position with respect to in-car technology.

headline: Suicide Attackers Storm Afghan Government Building
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three suicide attackers stormed a government building in eastern Afghanistan on Tuesday, setting off a seven-hour gunfight with Afghan soldiers and police officers that left 10 people dead, including the attackers, the Afghan police said.

headline: Maserati Kubang
text: Maserati Kubang slide show

headline: Why Doesn’t Anyone Check References?
text: Not long ago, I received a call from a furniture-store owner who was checking the references of one of my former employees. He introduced himself, and got right to the point: “I’m calling for a reference for …” He named a former saleswoman.

headline: New Documentary Rules Will Affect DocuWeeks, Group Says
text: LOS ANGELES — The International Documentary Association has weighed in on the rule changes that will winnow films qualified for the documentary Oscar by, among other things, requiring a review in either The New York Times or The Los Angeles Times. In a statement on Tuesday, the association for nonfiction film — which sponsors an annual DocuWeeks program that has qualified documentaries as Oscar submissions by putting them in theaters, but often without getting the requisite review — said the new rules “will certainly have an impact” on its screening program. But that impact, it said, wouldn’t be clear until both the Academy and the editorial staffs of the two newspapers provided more information.

headline: Citibank Lets Loyalty Members Pool Points on Facebook
text: Citibank has offered a new Facebook app that lets members of its ThankYou rewards program pool points with friends and family.

headline: When New York Snubbed Mary Poppins
text: If things had turned out differently 45 years ago, Mark Bransdon might have been looking at a life-size statue of Mary Poppins in Central Park, a few steps from the familiar statues of Hans Christian Andersen and Alice, of “Alice in Wonderland.”

headline: Not Set in Granite
text: Right now, while we indulge New Hampshire’s childish insistence on its presidential primary being “first in the nation,” Americans should decide to bury this tradition. Nearly a century is enough: the Granite State has somehow turned a fluke into an entitlement. Worse, its obsession with primacy prolongs, complicates and distorts the presidential nominating process. In a democracy, no state should be first forever.

headline: Lunchtime at the Loaves and Fishes Cafe
text: The effects of Tropical Storm Irene have not toppled Schoharie, N.Y., where a makeshift cafe has helped sustain community spirit.

headline: A Slow Start for the Magic’s Nelson, but He Has Been There Before
text: While the shadow of Dwight Howard’s trade request hangs over the Orlando Magic, Coach Stan Van Gundy has a few more specific items worthy of his immediate attention.

headline: That Revolving Drama in Which All Are Actors
text: The Argentine writer and director Mariano Pensotti sets multiple stories in motion in his smart and smartly staged play “El Pasado Es un Animal Grotesco” (“The Past Is a Grotesque Animal”). And they really are in motion: the circular plywood stage, divided into four compartments, revolves constantly (and slowly — you won’t feel seasick), as episodes from the lives of four characters are acted out. Their stories cinematically unspool and overlap as time moves onward and even occasionally backward.

headline: TimesCast | January 10, 2012
text: The growing influence of unlimited super PAC money on the presidential campaign | New Hampshire voters speak out on whom they're choosing and why.

headline: Ron Caron, Former Executive for Blues and Canadiens, Dies
text: Ron Caron, one of the front office architects behind the dominant Montreal Canadiens teams of the 1970s, was remembered for his knowledge and passion for the game after he died Monday evening at age 82. His death was confirmed by the other team he helped build, the St. Louis Blues.

headline: Statues Under Wraps in Uttar Pradesh
text: The onerous task of hiding Uttar Pradesh’s enormous stone tributes to the state’s chief minister, Mayawati, and her party began early Tuesday morning.

headline: An Almost-There Debut for the 2013 Honda Accord Coupe
text: Introduced Tuesday, Jan. 10: Honda Accord coupe concept.

headline: NYSE and Deutsche Borse Chiefs to Discuss Plans to Save Merger
text: 4:12 p.m. | Updated

headline: On TimesCast, New Hampshire Votes
text: The growing influence of unlimited “super PAC” money on the presidential campaign. New Hampshire voters speak out on whom they’re choosing and why.

headline: New Hampshire Primary Overview and Forecast
text: Tuesday’s primary in New Hampshire is not likely to be as dramatic as the Iowa caucuses, with one candidate, Mitt Romney, holding a clear lead in all of the polls.

headline: Perry Attacks ‘Vultures’ Like Bain
text: FORT MILL, S.C. — Corporate takeover firms like Mitt Romney’s Bain Capital are “vultures” that pick struggling companies clean and leave local communities to pick up the pieces, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said on Tuesday.

headline: No. 7 Sub Gets Bigger in Greenpoint
text: No. 7 Sub’s new location, opening next Wednesday in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is larger and more elaborate than the original No. 7 in Fort Greene, but will have an inventive sandwich menu that’s similar to the one at the sub shop that the owners, including the chef, Tyler Kord, have in the Ace Hotel in Manhattan.

headline: A Buick, Bigger than a Breadbox
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 10: 2013 Buick Encore.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Billy the Kid’
text: Billy the Kid lived his brief life at precisely the right moment to make him an excellent candidate for an installment of “American Experience” on PBS. It was an era of the kind of enthusiastic newspaper coverage that leads to outsize legends. And it was an era that left a sparse but compelling photographic record, poetic images of hard-living men and prettily posed women who come alive yet remain tantalizingly distant.

headline: Images From a Russian Tanker’s Icy Journey to Alaska
text: As my colleague William Yardley reports, the coastal town of Nome, Alaska, is anxiously watching its frozen waters for an emergency shipment of fuel being brought by a Russian tanker escorted by an American icebreaker.

headline: A Huntsman Throng at a Popular Polling Site
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Polling place madness, rinse and repeat.

headline: In One Girl’s Story, a Test of Women’s Rights in Afghanistan
text: I went to find Sahar Gul.

headline: The Caucus Click: Dutch Get Out the Vote
text: BEDFORD, N.H. — Sake Slootweg, who was photographed outside Rick Santorum’s campaign headquarters here, is part of a group of students from the Netherlands who are learning about the American election process and making campaign phone calls for a variety of candidates, including Mr. Santorum and Ron Paul.

headline: A Sundance Royal Returns
text: Once an Indie Queen always an Indie Queen? Yes – if you’re Parker Posey, who has been in more than a dozen Sundance films over the years, including “Party Girl” and “The House of Yes.” On Tuesday the festival announced that she will host the 2012 Sundance Film Festival Awards on Jan. 28. Ms. Posey, 43, also stars as a cuckoo from cuckoo-ville boss in “Price Check,” a comic drama that will have its premiere at the festival. Sundance on Tuesday also announced its roster of jurors. The full list, which includes names like the director Justin Lin (“Better Luck Tomorrow,” “Fast Five”) and Charles Ferguson (the director/producer of the Oscar-winning documentary “Inside Job”), can be found here.

headline: Showtime Extends Its ‘Anytime’ Service
text: Following the lead of its larger rival HBO, Showtime is beginning to broaden access to an Internet service that lets its subscribers stream hundreds of television episodes and feature films.

headline: More On Japan (Wonkish)
text: Say this for Eamonn Fingleton: he has started a useful blogospheric discussion of just how badly Japan really did. Noah Smith has weighed in on my last post; here’s a further take.

headline: A Seller and a Buyer in a Puzzling Exchange
text: “In the Solitude of Cotton Fields,” a visceral adaptation of a French play by Bernard-Marie Koltés, portrays a high-octane, sexually charged meeting between a dealer and a client, where the goods exchanged are unclear, but the high stakes are not. On another level, this production, staged in Polish with English supertitles by Radoslaw Rychcik, is about a confrontation between theater and rock concert. The rock concert wins.

headline: A Low-Priced Rival Pushes to Take Over France’s Mobile Phone Market
text: PARIS — After popularizing the idea of low-cost broadband Internet service in France, upsetting a few vested interests in the process, the telecommunications entrepreneur Xavier Niel wants to do something similar for mobile phones.

headline: U.S. Navy Reports Second Rescue of Iranian Mariners
text: In the second diplomacy-tinged sea rescue in less than a week, a vessel on patrol with the Navy’s Fifth Fleet near the Persian Gulf saved a group of distressed Iranian mariners on Tuesday, pulling them to safety from a cargo dhow that was foundering with a flooded engine room, the naval central command reported.

headline: At Añejo, Food to Complement Tequila
text: Mexican restaurants all over town have scores of tequilas on the bar, but at Anejo Tequileria y Restaurante, opening next Tuesday in Hell’s Kitchen, a carefully curated selection of about two dozen tequilas, mezcals and also bottles of a similar, less known distillate from Chihuahua in the north, sotol, take center stage.

headline: Just One Look | Stella McCartney
text: The suit from Stella McCartney this season is a bit of a departure from the one she’s best known for, with its soft-edged, single-button jacket. The prefall suit has three buttons and is “much more fitted, tailored and body-conscious,” said McCartney at last night’s presentation. “I’m always designing for women, things they’ll want to wear.” Chances are, much of the collection –– including the quirky monogrammed separates, the green and black buffalo checks (shown here) and the dazzling brocade dresses –– will be on that list, too.

headline: In New Hampshire: Coffee, Guns, Pie and Candidates
text: Candidates make hundreds of stops during a campaign season, and one restaurant can blend into another. In New Hampshire, the setting is a little more constant.

headline: Spectacles That Change Prescriptions on the Fly
text: LAS VEGAS — At the International Consumer Electronics Show you find electronics in everything, even the glass of spectacles. A company called Pixel Optics is demonstrating eyeglasses in which an electronic current is passed through liquid crystals to change the prescription on the fly.

headline: Under the Radar: 5 Questions About ‘Hot Pepper, Air Conditioner, and the Farewell Speech’
text: A group of awkward temporary office workers wiggles, rambles and stumbles about in “Hot Pepper, Air Conditioner, and the Farewell Speech,” three plays written and directed by the Japanese playwright Toshiki Okada. Presented by Mr. Okada’s Chelfitsch Theater Company, the piece is being performed at Japan Society in a co-production with the Under the Radar festival.

headline: Reader Idea | Guiding Critical Thinking About For-Profit Colleges
text: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Fell 3.1% in 2011, With a Weak End to the Year
text: Declines in the second half of last year resulted in a overall drop in advertising pages in magazines for 2011 compared with 2010, according to a report distributed on Tuesday by the Publishers Information Bureau.

headline: Michael Shannon’s Rocky Start
text: The Bagger has already introduced you to the cuddly Michael Shannon, and over the weekend, the protean star of “Take Shelter” spoke with the equally cuddly David Carr about his career, from Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago to being directed by Martin Scorsese in “Boardwalk Empire.”

headline: Awaiting a Greek Payout
text: LONDON — Could Greece’s next rescue payout go straight into the pockets of London hedge funds?

headline: Maserati Kubang Concept: Made in America, but Mum’s the Word
text: Shown Tuesday, Jan. 10: Maserati Kubang concept.

headline: After 30, the Going Is Getting Even Tougher
text: A player winning a Grand Slam singles title past the age of 30 has always been a rare sight: The last one to do so was Francesca Schiavone at the French Open in 2010.

headline: Bike Tour’s Popularity Leads to Changes
text: Given the Bloomberg administration’s continued push to have the city become more hospitable to bicyclists, it should come as little surprise that the TD Five Boro Bike Tour has grown in popularity — almost to its own detriment.

headline: Q.&A.: T-Mobile’s Chief on What’s Next After Failed AT&T Merger
text: LAS VEGAS — For several months in 2011, the wireless carriers T-Mobile USA and AT&T were pursuing a merger to unify their networks and expand their businesses. The deal ultimately collapsed after facing resistance from governmental agencies, which raised antitrust concerns.

headline: Digital Notes: Music Apps Enlist Twitter, a New Hire at Sony Music
text: Updates on the business of digital music:

headline: App Smart Extra: Best iPad Game Apps
text: Software companies of all kinds flocked to the iPad last year, and the results were great. (See my list of Top 10 iPad apps for 2011.) But in the gaming category in particular, the iPad attracted even more of the world’s accomplished software developers. Here’s a list of the 10 best entries from an impressive 2011 vintage, with a nod to various gaming genres.

headline: Meatless in the Midwest: A Tale of Survival
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Delivers Big Audience for PBS
text: The Season 2 premiere of “Downton Abbey” on PBS on Sunday drew an average of 4.2 million total viewers, a number that would impress even the most cold-hearted dowager. That performance doubled the average prime-time rating for PBS, according to Nielsen data, and the show experienced an 18 percent jump in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with the typical rating from the first season.

headline: In Rural Portugal, Ancient Villages and Homemade Delights
text: Three year-old Matilde, dressed in a pink sweatsuit that read “Fashion Beauty Girl,” wanted to take her princess doll to the pig slaughter. Her mom, whom I had met through my hosts in this small Portuguese town, objected. “The piggies are going to make the princess dirty,” she said.

headline: Should We Have National Standards for Sex Education?
text: A group of advocates for sexuality education in schools, including the Sexuality Information and Education Council of the United States, Advocates for Youth and Answer, have joined forces and worked with “40 individuals from the fields of health education, sexuality education, public health, public policy, philanthropy and advocacy” to create what they call “national sexuality education standards (PDF).” The report says that the goal of the proposed standards is to “provide clear, consistent and straightforward guidance on the essential minimum, core content for sexuality education that is developmentally and age-appropriate for students in Grades K–12.”

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: Are the Texans underrated? Where will Andrew Luck land? How many more coaches will lose their jobs before the draft? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

headline: With Racy LF-LC, Lexus Risks the Ire of LF-A Buyers
text: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 9: Lexus LF-LC concept.

headline: Vegetarian Eating in the Land of Iceberg Lettuce
text: This week, A.G. Sulzberger, a national correspondent in the Kansas City bureau, writes about his plight as a vegetarian living in the meat-loving Midwest, where salads are often topped with crumbled bacon and beans are bathed in lard.

headline: U.S. Report Criticizes New York on Monitoring Care of Developmentally Disabled
text: ALBANY — The federal government sharply criticized New York’s oversight of the developmentally disabled in a new report, saying the state agency charged with oversight lacks independence from the governor’s office, failed to account for how it is spending public money and has broken several requirements of federal law.

headline: Giants Know They Can Match the Packers Score for Score
text: Green Bay Packers games are best thought of as basketball games. The Packers are going to score often. Their opponents are going to score often. Defensive play is more appropriately measured in stops and turnovers, not necessarily points allowed. Every forced punt is a success. Keeping the score close gives either team a chance to win in the final seconds.

headline: Violence, Addicting Yet Ugly
text: A Japanese businessman tries to come home on his son’s birthday but finds that an escaped convict has taken his family hostage. Outside, the police appear ineffectual, so this rational, soft-spoken man (his birthday gift was a calculator) decides to fight back himself, taking the wife and son of the criminal hostage. Then he sends a message that he will start cutting off the child’s fingers unless his family is released.

headline: Naval Officer Embarks on PGA Tour Career
text: HONOLULU — Over lunch Monday in the wardroom of the U.S.S. Chung-Hoon, Lt. j.g. Lauren Griebel acknowledged that she met President Obama over the holidays while playing a round of golf with her father on a local course. Smiling broadly, Griebel said, “It wasn’t Billy Hurley, but yeah.”

headline: For Villyan Bijev, Destination Liverpool, With a Stop in Düsseldorf
text: As the week-long United States under-20 camp ended last Sunday in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., one of the players who is shaping up to be an important part of the team in months ahead is the forward Villyan Bijev.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Moving Up in America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Federal Report on Disabled Care in New York State
text: The report from the Department of Health and Human Services criticized New York’s oversight of the developmentally disabled.

headline: European Official Presses for Moroccan Fishing Treaty
text: PARIS — Europe’s top fisheries official pledged Tuesday to work for a new fishing treaty with Morocco after the previous agreement was dropped last month by the European Parliament over concerns of overfishing and other issues.

headline: TV Decency Is a Puzzler for Justices
text: WASHINGTON — In a rollicking Supreme Court argument that was equal parts cultural criticism and First Amendment doctrine, the justices on Tuesday considered whether the government still had good reason to regulate cursing and nudity on broadcast television.

headline: The View From Alabama: Much More Than a Trophy
text: Alabama’s dominating performance in the B.C.S. title game was more than just another championship game victory. It was a victory for the university and the city of Tuscaloosa.

headline: Season of Equal-Opportunity Sexism
text: The battle of the sexes is over on television. Now viewers get to pick between his or her sexism.

headline: Romney Wins New Hampshire Primary
text: Mitt Romney won the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday night.

headline: Via Motors: Big G.M. Trucks With Downsized Thirst
text: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 10: Via Motors E-REV plug-in hybrid Silverado pickup, Suburban and Express Van.

headline: Washington National Opera to Present ‘Ring’ Cycle in 2016
text: The Washington National Opera’s merger with the Kennedy Center is appearing to pay dividends. The company announced on Tuesday that it would present the complete Wagner “Ring” cycle that it had commissioned with the San Francisco Opera but suspended because of money problems. The Washington company, whose merger with the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts was announced a year ago, ended up presenting the final installment, “Götterdämmerung,” only in a concert performance in 2009 after individual productions of the first three operas in previous seasons. It had halted plans for a presentation of the complete cycle, which San Francisco staged last June.

headline: Obama Drops by the E.P.A.
text: President Obama, who has been both applauded and jeered for his record on environmental issues, paid a brief visit to the headquarters of the Environmental Protection Agency in Washington on Tuesday to try to raise spirits at an agency that has been under siege for the past year.

headline: The poop on how zebras might help us solve our energy problems; how to save a marriage after one spouse suffers a brain injury; and a life in the Antarctic polar desert.
text: The poop on how zebras might help us solve our energy problems; how to save a marriage after one spouse suffers a brain injury; and a life in the Antarctic polar desert.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: Google’s Social Move Attracts Critics
text: After Google announced on Tuesday that it was integrating material from Google Plus into its search results, the Web shot back, accusing the company of pushing aside competing social networks like Twitter and Facebook.

headline: Texans Rookie Makes a Play as Big as His Dreams
text: HOUSTON — Only three years ago, J. J. Watt was delivering pizzas, mopping floors and being picked at like a leftover pepperoni pie by doubters who scoffed at his football dreams.

headline: A Stroll This Side of the Mediterranean
text: WHEN the money that had kept New York aloft went away a few years back, some chefs switched into damage control immediately. They clipped prices. They made their menus and dining rooms more easygoing. They put future projects on hold.

headline: Reviewing La Promenade des Anglais
text: The chef Alain Allegretti’s new restaurant in Chelsea is a flashy bistro by way of Nice.

headline: Huntsman’s ‘Country First’ Slogan
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.–There is something quietly devastating about the three-day-old slogan of “country first!” that Jon Huntsman’s supporters have begun chanting at his rallies and appearances here, including one this morning at a Manchester polling place.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 10
text: A view of the day in sports, including a dusty stage of the Dakar Rally.

headline: Interactive Tools to Assess the Likelihood of Death
text: To help prevent overtesting and overtreatment of older patients — or undertreatment for those who remain robust at advanced ages — medical guidelines increasingly call for doctors to consider life expectancy as a factor in their decision-making. But clinicians, research has shown, are notoriously poor at predicting how many years their patients have left.

Since a number of tests and treatments ought to take life expectancy into account, they reasoned, physicians should have these validated tools in one handy online location.

And as fans poured out of the city, 11 conference commissioners and Notre Dame Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick met Tuesday to begin cleaning up the future of college football’s postseason.

headline: Solitary Lives, Abruptly Interrupted
text: The crumbling, all but abandoned manor house as symbol of a social order in distress: the English may have invented that notion, but their former colonial subjects in India have also proved adept at employing it as a literary device. In the three novellas that make up “The Artist of Disappearance,” Anita Desai uses it twice, in differing circumstances and locations, but to the same convincing and plaintive effect.

headline: Israel, Expecting Syrian Collapse, Braces for Refugees

headline: Malnutrition Widespread in Indian Children, Report Finds
text: NEW DELHI — In parts of India, 42 percent of all children under age 5 suffer from malnutrition, a sobering reminder of the persistence of poverty and hunger in the world’s largest democracy, according to a major report released on Tuesday.

headline: Analysis From the New Hampshire Primary
text: Welcome to FiveThirtyEight’s live blog of the New Hampshire primary. Polls have closed, and The New York Times has projected Mitt Romney as the winner, but we will still have plenty of statistical insights into the election.

headline: Jaunty Songs That Reveal a Bleaker Reality
text: An erupting wellspring of euphoria: that would describe the vintage swing emanating from Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks at the 92nd Street Y during Saturday evening’s season-opening program of Lyrics & Lyricists. It is challenging enough for a band to churn out museum-ready facsimiles of 80-year-old pop tunes outfitted with stylistically accurate period arrangements. But Mr. Giordano’s ensemble, like the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra playing the blues, preserves old music with such deep affection and idiomatic understanding that the past becomes the present and the term “quaint” simply doesn’t apply. In its lighthearted way, the music swung as intensely as any being created today.

headline: Just One Look | Carven
text: Carven’s Guillaume Henry was looking at Diane Arbus photographs from the 1960s for inspiration for his prefall collection. “Ordinary people looking extraordinary,” said Henry about his muse: a very specific suburban girl who rides the subway in the early morning, is moody, makes her own clothes (or wears her mother’s) and wants to look pretty but can only afford synthetic shoes. Hence, the plastic tortoise kitten heels, the fabrics that make references to shag carpets and couches (her only resources) and the jackets made of a leather that’s washed to look faux (she’s just not that fancy). “She’s sweet looking but not dull,” Henry said. And she has a terrific, intuitive sense of style, one that doesn’t require money. Here, because he likes “calm, strong, happy colors with metallics,” is a yellow shearling jacket and skirt look paired with the coolest metallic pumps and matching camera bag. Anything but dull, indeed.

headline: Giants’ New House Feels Like Home
text: It has taken nearly two full seasons, but MetLife Stadium finally felt last Sunday like it supplied the Giants with a home-field advantage.

headline: First, Mr. Mayor, What of Beyoncé’s Baby?
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg began taking general questions at a news conference on Tuesday, the first topic was not his coming State of the City address, or teacher evaluation problems that are endangering federal education money, or even the New Hampshire primary.

headline: In the Netherlands, a Child’s Game for Children Only
text: The replay of the Dutch Cup match between Ajax and AZ, which was abandoned on Dec. 21 and is scheduled to be played on Jan. 19, will be for children only.

headline: From A to Z, a Book Deciphers Cooking
text: Every so often publishers issue kitchen guides with definitions, measurements, conversion tables and the like. The Culinarian: A Kitchen Desk Reference is crammed with an unusual amount of information, organized alphabetically from “absinthe” to “zwieback.” The author, Barbara Ann Kipfer, is a seasoned lexicographer, and it shows. Search for “chicken,” and you’ll find two pages of tips and a list of 50 chicken breeds. The shrimp entry decodes size grading, and for meringue, four varieties are defined. The book is a voyage of discovery, with useful information and fascinating trivia on every page. The first few pages list smoke points for various oils, and measurements, yields and equivalents for many foods. In one puzzling choice, though, the book provides weights and measures for medium-size eggs, not the large ones that most recipes require.

headline: Snap, Crackle and (Some) Pop
text: You could view them, unkindly, as duds: pieces of popcorn that have not been popped to their fluffy white extreme. But these crisp little nuggets are less like the hard kernels at the bottom of your popcorn bowl and more like corn nuts. Halfpops, a new snack from the Seattle area, deliver a similar crunch, but are made from air-popped corn — unlike corn nuts, whole corn kernels that are soaked, then roasted or fried. Halfpops come in two flavors: butter and sea salt, and white Cheddar cheese. And beyond mere snacking, they are excellent sprinkled on a salad or vegetables, or served (as corn nuts are in South America) as a nibble alongside ceviche.

headline: Owners of New Republic Seek Sale or New Investors
text: The owners of The New Republic, the nearly century-old magazine that helped define modern American liberalism, are considering selling the magazine or creating a strategic partnership with new investors, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Stringer and Jewish Leaders Condemn Anti-Semitic Acts

headline: Met Gears Up to Be a Player in Contemporary Art
text: Sending a signal that it intends to become a serious competitor in the field of contemporary art for the first time in half a century, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has recruited a prominent London curator to oversee a new department devoted to art of the 20th and 21st centuries. She is Sheena Wagstaff, chief curator of Tate Modern since 2001, who has been responsible for programming there and for helping to organize exhibitions devoted to artists like Roy Lichtenstein, Barnett Newman, Jeff Wall and Eva Hesse.

headline: Shining a Bright Light on Stormy Passages
text: The New School’s chamber music series, founded in 1957 and called the Schneider Concerts (in honor of the violinist Alexander Schneider) since 1993, has a dual mission. For young but accomplished ensembles, it is a venerable forum, known for its sterling track record. The pianist Peter Serkin made his New York debut in the series, as did the Guarneri Quartet, and you could have heard early performances by Murray Perahia and Yo-Yo Ma there. For its audiences the Schneider Concerts are an inexpensive way to hear consistently fine performances. (Tickets go for $17; $15 for 65+; and $5 for students.)

text: Perhaps no institution responded more wholeheartedly to the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks last year than Trinity Church. As well it should have; located prominently at Broadway and Wall Street, Trinity was a near neighbor of the World Trade Center, and its satellite St. Paul’s Chapel, a few blocks up Broadway and directly across from the Trade Center grounds, served as the prime staging area for rescue workers.

headline: Just a Regular Guy and Pickpocket
text: There are a couple of movies, or rather a couple of story ideas, tucked in “Loosies,” an amorphous, laugh-flecked drama about a New York City pickpocket that mostly comes across as a feature-length advertisement for its likable star and writer, Peter Facinelli. A pretty man with an easy grin, Mr. Facinelli has a leading man’s looks if not the presence or credits, and is best known these days for standing around stiffly as Dr. Carlisle Cullen, the forever young paterfamilias of the vampire brood in the “Twilight” flicks. He was infinitely better in the 2007 season of the cable show “Damages,” where he was actually given a character to work with, one whose appeal was tinged with menace.

headline: Cuomo Urges Districts and Unions to Compromise on Evaluations
text: The stalemate over a new teacher evaluation system continues, and on Tuesday Gov. Andrew M. Walcott, repeated his declaration that he will not let money dictate school policy, and the teachers union published its own account of the negotiations.

headline: Oklahoma: Court Upholds Blocking of Amendment Against Shariah Law
text: A federal appeals court on Tuesday blocked implementation of an amendment adopted by Oklahoma in November 2010 that would bar state courts from considering Shariah, or Islamic, law in any proceedings. Soon after voters approved the amendment, the American Civil Liberties Union and the Council on American-Islamic Relations sued and a district court issued a preliminary injunction, saying that the amendment most likely violates the First Amendment. On Tuesday, the 10th Circuit of the United States Court of Appeals upheld the injunction, saying the state had not demonstrated any compelling reason for discrimination against one religion.

headline: Scotland Plans Independence Vote
text: The Scottish government said Tuesday that it would hold a referendum on independence from Britain in 2014, a decision that Alex Salmond, below, who leads the government in Edinburgh, said would be Scotland’s “most important decision for 300 years.” But the path to the referendum promises to be tortuous. Prime Minister David Cameron’s government in London told Parliament that it had the sole constitutional right to approve a referendum, but that he was prepared to devolve the power to the Scottish authorities on terms that would make the referendum result “legal, decisive and fair.” Mr. Salmond said he would hold a referendum on his terms. The Cameron government has said it wants an earlier date for the vote, to end uncertainty that it says is deterring investment in Scotland. The British government also said the question should be a straightforward yes or no on independence, without the third option Mr. Salmond wants on the ballot, which would give Scotland full autonomy as part of Britain.

headline: Britain: Plan Set for Fast Trains
text: The government approved on Tuesday a controversial $51 billion high-speed rail line linking London to Birmingham, Manchester and Leeds with trains capable of running at 250 miles an hour. Transport Minister Justine Greening said the move would shift millions of passengers from commuter airlines and cars to trains. The project would be a major step toward matching Britain’s outdated rail network with those in France, Germany and Japan, leaders in high-speed rail travel. But it faces strong opposition from environmental groups, who say the trains would benefit mainly wealthy commuters and scar stretches of the countryside.

headline: Seagate Adapter Hits Hard Drives With a Thunderbolt
text: LAS VEGAS — Seagate on Tuesday introduced an accessory that will give some hard drives a major performance boost.

headline: Selig Is Likely to Stay in Office at Least 2 Years
text: Sitting at his desk last April, overlooking Lake Michigan 30 floors above downtown Milwaukee, Bud Selig seemed at peace. He had a few initiatives left to accomplish as baseball’s commissioner, but he said that as far as he was concerned, he would retire after the 2012 season.

headline: Restore Our Future Makes New Ad Buy
text: A group backing Mitt Romney has purchased $3.6 million in additional advertising in Florida, a person with knowledge of the decision said Tuesday, the building blocks of a television firewall intended to guarantee that no other Republican makes it past the state’s critical primary at the end of the month.

headline: Italy: Government Official Quits
text: An under secretary to Prime Minister Mario Monti, Carlo Malinconico, resigned Tuesday after the Italian news media reported that he had vacationed at a five-star Tuscan hotel in 2007 and 2008 as the guest of two businessmen later implicated in a corruption investigation. In a statement issued by the prime minister’s office, Mr. Malinconico denied any wrongdoing and said he was resigning to better defend himself and to protect the credibility of the government. When Mr. Monti took office eight weeks ago, he said his cabinet ministers would act with transparency and be free of conflicts of interest. Mr. Malinconico was a high-ranking member of the staff of Romano Prodi, who was prime minister at the time referenced in the allegations.

headline: Too Many Notable People to Name Street for Just One
text: Although he had been blind since age 5 and reliant on a guide dog, Matthew P. Sapolin was the city’s first commissioner of the Mayor’s Office for People With Disabilities, pressing to make the city’s buildings, taxis and sidewalks more accommodating to people who use wheelchairs or cannot see. He was an accomplished wrestler and musician as well.

headline: Egypt: Mubarak’s Trial Extended
text: Judges in the trial of former President Hosni Mubarak on Tuesday scheduled a full month for his defense team to make its case, pushing any potential verdict past the day of demonstrations expected on Jan. 25, the anniversary of the uprising that ended his rule. A recent acceleration in the pace of the trial fueled speculation that Egyptian authorities had hoped for a verdict before Jan. 25 that might help mollify anger at the current military-led government. Mr. Mubarak is on trial on charges of corruption and directing the killing of protesters.

headline: The Republican Nomination: Going the Distance
text: Mitt Romney has pulled ahead of Newt Gingrich in the Florida polls and is the favorite in many of the February contests, but Mr. Gingrich has vowed to continue on until the Republican convention in August.

headline: TVs That Keep Up With Evolution
text: LAS VEGAS — The idea of a smart television is a few years old, but it is evolving so rapidly that Samsung Electronics is worried that consumers may be reluctant to buy a television for fear of missing out on the next big thing.

headline: One First Amendment
text: The Constitution generally prohibits the government from suppressing words and images unless they are obscene. But the Supreme Court upheld a narrow exception to this free speech tenet in 1978, letting the Federal Communications Commission ban “indecent but not obscene” material from radio and television because it said broadcast media were pervasive and accessible to children.

headline: Romney Wins G.O.P. Primary in New Hampshire
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Mitt Romney swept to victory in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, turning back a ferocious assault from rivals who sought to disqualify him in the eyes of conservatives, in a contest that failed to anoint a strong opponent to slow his march to the Republican nomination.

headline: James F. Crow, Population Genetics Pioneer, Dies at 95

headline: As Romney Advances, Private Equity Becomes Part of the Debate

headline: F.D.A. Creeps Forward
text: Last week, the Food and Drug Administration took a small step toward reducing the routine use of antibiotics in livestock, a practice that creates drug-resistant pathogens and threatens the effectiveness of some antibiotics in human medicine. It restricted the use of a class of antibiotics called cephalosporins. Because they require a prescription, farm veterinarians use them less than other antibiotics, like penicillin.

headline: A Seismic Shift for the Subway: Closing Lines for Night Repairs
text: It is a fundamental birthright of New Yorkers that their subway never stops for a breather. The city stays up all night, and so its trains must follow suit.

headline: Mets Sign Batista
text: Miguel Batista pitched the final game of the 2011 season for the Mets, beating Cincinnati, 3-0, at age 40 to become the oldest pitcher in franchise history to throw a shutout. Now Batista will try to see what he can do for the Mets at 41. Batista has signed with them for the 2012 season; his role has yet to be determined.

headline: Romney Focuses on Obama During Victory Speech
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Mitt Romney declared on Tuesday night that his campaign had “made history” in New Hampshire and vowed to continue on to South Carolina as he pursues his party’s nomination to take on President Obama in the fall.

headline: Troubled Online Charter Schools
text: Charter schools, which receive public money but are subject to fewer state regulations, are operating in 40 states. A growing body of research shows that charter schools generally perform no better than traditional schools and are often worse as measured by student test data. This is particularly true of online charter schools, which educate more than 200,000 full-time students and are spreading quickly across the country.

headline: G.M. Looks to Luxury Cars for Higher Profit

headline: 3 Killed as Drone Strikes Resume in Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — The United States on Tuesday carried out its first drone strike in Pakistan’s restive tribal areas in nearly two months, ending a pause that was intended to avoid worsening relations between the countries after an American airstrike in November killed two dozen Pakistani troops.

headline: The Kremlin’s Stooges
text: MOSCOW — A documentary video has just gone viral in Russia. A man and a woman — he a political activist, she a radio reporter — videotaped themselves entering an auditorium they say is located in Moscow’s State University of Transportation. It is a weekend day during winter break, and the room is full. About 50 young people — presumably students at the university, though this is never made clear — are seated at desks, with stacks of papers in front of them. Hundreds of completed forms sit on a long desk at the front of the auditorium. During the nearly seven minutes that the recording lasts, the man and woman keep asking: “What are you doing?” They never get an answer and in the end are forcibly removed from the premises.

headline: What Does Wall Street Do for You?
text: Hating Wall Street is an American tradition that dates back even to the days when Thomas Jefferson cursed that money lover Alexander Hamilton. And for centuries, the complaints about it have largely stayed the same: It does nothing! It creates chaos! It’s a parasite that sucks hardworking Americans dry! (Or something to that effect.) But these are distortions of a fundamentally beneficial business. The country’s largest investment banks, commercial banks and a few big insurance companies (what we generally refer to as Wall Street) play the crucial role of intermediation — matching borrowers with lenders. Most of the time, the industry does this extremely well (though in the case of matching homeowners’ debt to the global financial system, too enthusiastically). Perhaps the best way to really appreciate what Wall Street does is to imagine life without it.

headline: Tottenham Works Its Way Back to the Top

text: That Mitt Romney’s victory in the New Hampshire primary was considered all but assured even before the voting began on Tuesday didn’t stop the news coverage from going into overdrive, Brian Stelter reports. But the operation appeared to be running on fumes. Once a winner was crowned — at 8 p.m., precisely when all polls were closed — the topic turned to second place. That, too, was over early, with Ron Paul declared the runner-up in that same hour. The focus then turned to South Carolina, and how Mr. Romney would fare in a state that would test his conservative credentials: CNN had already assembled a group of undecided Republicans there, Mr. Stelter writes, while Fox News promoted its debate there on Monday.

headline: Twenty-Two Is Quite Enough: Comprehensive James Bond Boxed Set Is Planned
text: If you had to limit yourself to just one James Bond-related purchase for your Q-approved high-end home entertainment system, which would you pick? An early Sean Connery classic like “Goldfinger”? A contemporary Daniel Craig reboot like “Casino Royale”? Or what about a boxed set of nearly every Bond film that’s been released over the last half-century? If you fall into that last category (and, presumably, have the financial backing of Her Majesty’s government) there will soon be a DVD collection to suit your refined tastes. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and 20th Century Fox’s home entertainment division announced that they are planning to sell a boxed set called “Bond 50,” celebrating 50 years of the spy-movie franchise and containing Blu-ray versions of the 22 canonical James Bond films that have so far been released, starting with “Dr. No” (1962).
