text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Colleges Slower to Branch Out Abroad
text: After a decade of rapid growth, universities have slowed their pace of opening branch campuses abroad, and much of the activity has moved from the Middle East to the Far East, according to a survey by the Observatory on Borderless Higher Education, a private British research group, scheduled for release Thursday.

headline: NYT Front Page for 01/12/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 01/12/2012

headline: U.S. Halts Import of Orange Juice
text: The United States has temporarily halted shipments of imported orange juice from all countries while they are tested, and said it will destroy or ban products containing even low levels from a banned fungicide.

headline: India’s Chronic Battle With Malnutrition
text: “It is unrealistic to expect any major breakthroughs in dealing with the diets of impoverished Indians,” a correspondent wrote in The New York Times in an article on Oct. 23, 1981.

headline: On the Floor at C.E.S.
text: Sam Grobart, The Times’s personal technology editor, hunts for the new and novel at the Consumer Electronics Show.

headline: Kim Jong-il to Go on Permanent Display
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Thursday that it would place the body of Kim Jong-il on permanent display in a Pyongyang mausoleum and install his statues, portraits and memorial towers across the country.

headline: A Techie's Test Drive
text: Sam Grobart, The Times’ personal technology editor, test drives a car with a range of computer-assisted features.

headline: Songs for Haiti
text: On the two-year anniversary of Haiti’s earthquake, members of the all-Haitian choir at the Church of the Holy Name of Jesus in Manhattan reflect and heal through prayer and song.

headline: News Quiz | Jan. 12, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: Jan. 12, 1915 | Congress Votes Against Women’s Suffrage Amendment
text: On Jan. 12, 1915, the United States House of Representatives voted, 204-174, to reject a constitutional amendment to give women the right to vote.

headline: European Union Gives Hungary an Ultimatum
text: BUDAPEST — Faced with what critics say is an alarming drift away from democracy by one of its members, the European Union gave the Hungarian government a final warning Wednesday that it would face the start of formal legal action by next Tuesday unless it modified a series of measures that threaten the balance of power in the country.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 12, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from The Local blog post “Local Legends: ‘The French Girl.'”

headline: Satellite Plummets After Possible Attack
text: WHAT is the Phobos-Grunt?

headline: Judith Clark’s Radical Transformation
text: On Oct. 20, 1981, a band of militant zealots armed with automatic weapons tried to rob a Brink’s truck in a shopping mall in Nanuet in Rockland County, N.Y. Before it was over, two armored-car guards were shot and two police officers — one black and one white — were gunned down at a roadblock. The crime was one of the last spasms of ’60s-style, left-wing violence. To the militants, it was an “expropriation” for something they called the Republic of New Afrika, a place that existed mainly in their fevered dreams.

headline: The Tea Party’s Not-So-Civil War
text: I met Karen Martin, a few days before New Year’s, at a cafe in Greenville, the hub of conservative politics in South Carolina. A 54-year-old refugee from the North Shore of Massachusetts, Martin is the lead organizer of the nearby Spartanburg Tea Party. Another Tea Party leader described her to me as a grown-up, and in fact, Martin turned out to be the kind of activist — ideology notwithstanding — who makes you feel hopeful about the new age of political uprising. She recounted how she burst into tears at the moment she realized, watching the news in 2008, that children growing up today wouldn’t have the economic opportunities that she did. She talked about how the Tea Party would need to mature and become more politically sophisticated in the years ahead. “I think the movement is just too young and too emotional,” she said.

headline: Sweetheart of the Rodeo
text: Louise Serpa grew up as a New York debutante, but her heart belonged to the West. By day, she studied at Vassar, but some nights, she became a cowgirl, sneaking out of her dorm room to watch visiting rodeos in Manhattan. Her transformation was complete by her 30s, when she moved to Tucson, and pursued her passion for the sport.

headline: Could Huntsman and the Democrats Ally on Bank Reform?
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: What’s Your Favorite (Printable) Slang Term?
text: A recent New York Times crossword attracted quite a lot of notice after a reader tried to school The Times’s puzzle master Will Shortz on what she sees as the semantic differences between the hip-hop terms “wack” and “illin.” What slang term would you like to see used in a Times crossword?

headline: Kia Chooses Las Vegas, Not Detroit, for E.V. Debuts
text: LAS VEGAS — Rather than at a traditional auto salon like the one running concurrently in Detroit, Kia Motors opted to introduce two electric vehicles at the Consumer Electronics Show here this week.

headline: A Taste for Tidbits Best Served Cold
text: The Hamptons are no place for a friendless soul, but that’s the lot of Nolan Ross, the character played by Gabriel Mann in ABC’s breakout soap “Revenge.”

headline: Part 4: Answers on the Fafsa, the Free Application for Federal Student Aid
text: All this week, Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is answering questions on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa. Mr. Kantrowitz is the author of “Secrets to Winning a Scholarship,” published last February.

headline: The Early Word: Romney Rising
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: At Prague Castle, Treasures of the Czars
text: A rare exhibition of gilded treasures from the Moscow Kremlin museums — some of which had never before left Russia — has been getting rave reviews since its opening at Prague Castle last month.

headline: Bye Bye, Canada
text: A sketch on Montreal’s infrastructure troubles from “Bye Bye 2011,” a Québécois comedy special. After the characters hear a radio report about 2012 potentially being the year of the world’s end, they survive crumbling roadways and joke about such chaos being attributable to the city’s character, not the planet’s demise.

headline: Burmese Government and Ethnic Rebel Group Sign Cease-Fire
text: BANGKOK — The government of Myanmar signed a cease-fire agreement on Thursday with ethnic Karen rebels, whose fight for greater autonomy is one of the largest of the brutal civil wars that has bedeviled the country since it gained independence from Britain more than six decades ago.

headline: Q&A: Changing Google Calendar Notifications
text: Q.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland to Cut 3,500 Jobs
text: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Thursday that it would eliminate 3,500 jobs in its investment banking division over the next three years in response to volatility in global financial markets.

headline: The Bo Ssam Miracle
text: This weekend’s dinner is a slow-roasted shoulder of pig, a meal that can be picked apart by a table of friends armed only with chopsticks and lettuce. A tight and salty caramel crust sits on top of the moist, fragrant collapse of meat, and juices run thick to pool beneath it, a kind of syrup, delicious in its intensity. It is pork as pommes soufflé.

headline: The New Restaurant Will Be Chef Joe’s
text: Arthur on Smith is the name of our new restaurant in Brooklyn. It is a tribute to Chef Joe’s father, who passed away last year but whose spirit will be reborn at 276 Smith Street. Arthur also refers to la strada principale in the Italian section of the Bronx and will make naming any future restaurants a lot easier, like spreading ashes: Arthur on Bleecker, Arthur on Madison, Arthur on. … Wait, I’m getting ahead of myself.

headline: Murray Bets Future on Lendl’s Past
text: No man needs a Grand Slam title quite as much as Andy Murray. His new coach, Ivan Lendl, was once in the same awkward position.

headline: Federer's Wife at the Center of His Game
text: His back, a chronic but manageable concern for years, has been troubling him again, but Roger Federer is in Melbourne with every intent of returning to the court and playing in his 49th consecutive Grand Slam tournament.

headline: Haitian Choir Lifts Every Voice in Healing
text: Within days of the cataclysmic earthquake in Haiti in 2010, the Church of the Holy Name of Jesus in Manhattan, like many houses of worship, responded with donations of food and water.

headline: Europe Gets Some Reassurance in Auctions of Debt
text: BERLIN — Solid government debt auctions in Italy and Spain on Thursday indicated that efforts by the European Central Bank to avoid a regional credit freeze were continuing to show at least short-term benefits.

headline: Foxconn Resolves a Dispute With Some Workers in China
text: SHANGHAI — Foxconn Technology, a major supplier to several electronics giants, said on Thursday that it had resolved a pay dispute with scores of workers at one of its factories in central China after a large protest that involved threats from some workers to commit suicide.

headline: Carmakers Race to Add Tech Touches
text: As cars become ever more vibrant entertainment centers, automakers find themselves having to build safety features to prevent drivers from crashing their smartphone on wheels, Sam Grobart reports in The Times. And in a video from Las Vegas, he test drives a car with a range of computer-assisted features.

headline: Obama Campaign Raises $42 Million in Fourth Quarter
text: Read the full report here.

headline: Pogue on the Highlights of the Show
text: The Consumer Electronics Show displays a future of proliferating gadgetry, from the serious to the frivolous, David Pogue reports in his State of the Art column. He looks at televisions, tablets, smartphone control, ultrabooks and the weird and the wonderful.

headline: The End of ‘My Generation’s’ War
text: I wasn’t alive when Vietnam ended. I remember being a little girl, and watching news reports in the years after Vietnam, but I never really understood why it was important until much later in life. As a soldier, I had no concept of what it would feel like to hear my generation’s war was over.

headline: Getting Ready to React to Fukushima
text: Reacting to Japan’s Fukushima disaster, the nuclear industry is preparing to present regulators with a streamlined package of voluntary safety improvements that it says could be put into effect quickly — although they would not be certified as formal nuclear standards regarding specific threats.

headline: Video: On the Floor at C.E.S.
text: Sam Grobart, The Times’s personal technology editor, hunts for the new and novel at the Consumer Electronics Show.

headline: N.F.L. Divisional Round Probabilities
text: Some statistical story lines for this weekend’s divisional matchups:

headline: Video Inflames a Delicate Moment for U.S. in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A video showing four United States Marines urinating on three dead Taliban fighters provoked anger and condemnation on Thursday in Afghanistan and around the world, raising fears in Washington that the images could incite anti-American sentiment at a particularly delicate moment in the decade-old Afghan war.

headline: Opinion Report: Romney Lurches Right on Immigration
text: From the editorial page

headline: Hungary Update
text: Over the past month or so my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele has posted several times on this blog, reporting on the anti-democratic moves of the Hungarian government. When she started, there was near-silence from the news media on the story; but that has now ended, with extensive coverage in many newspapers.

headline: The 99 Percent Get Sundance Support
text: LOS ANGELES — The Occupy movement is getting a Sundance spin.

headline: Britain to Investigate Role in Claim of Torture by Libyans
text: LONDON — British officials announced on Thursday that they had ordered a criminal investigation into the role played by MI6, the country’s secret intelligence service, in operations that led to two Libyan opponents of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi being delivered to Libyan jails, where, they said, they were tortured by Colonel Qaddafi’s secret police.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: For Europe, Few Options in a Vicious Cycle of Debt  |  As difficult as the last two years have been for Europe, 2012 could be even tougher. Each week, countries will need to sell billions of dollars’ worth of bonds — a staggering $1 trillion in total — to replace existing debt and cover current budget deficits.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Billionaire’s Backing and Digging Deeper on ‘Downton’
text: Politico profiles the three billionaires who “could drag out” the Republican presidential nomination process by nearly single handedly sustaining the advertising campaigns of Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum and Jon Huntsman Jr. Their role – writing large checks to PACs that back their candidate – has been aided by recent federal court decisions weakening checks on political spending. They are: Sheldon Adelson, casino magnate and patron to Mr. Gingrich; Jon Huntsman Sr., patron to his son; Foster Friess, patron to Mr. Santorum.

headline: Be Vewy, Vewy Quiet
text: Andy Rosenthal gets a bit of a laugh out of Mitt Romney’s insistence that the only reason anyone would talk about inequality is the “politics of envy”, and that if the subject is discussed at all, it should only be in “quiet rooms”.

headline: Tougher Times for Charter Schools
text: In the news on Thursday, a question: Is the city beginning to hold charter schools to a higher standard? The closing of Peninsula Preparatory Academy Charter School in Far Rockaway, Queens, has some thinking the answer is yes, writes Anna M. Phillips in The New York Times on Thursday. Also, answer our query: What is the state of your school?

headline: Romney Treads Familiar Path Toward Nomination
text: With the first two Republican presidential primaries of the 2012 campaign now over, there are similarities to the 2008 contest — and lessons for Mitt Romney as he moves toward the general election.

headline: Getting Patients to Take Charge of Their Health
text: One afternoon, I heard a colleague let out an exasperated groan in front of the hospital computers. His patient had been admitted. Again.

headline: Bnter Turns Into Banters and Lets You Post via Text
text: Bnter, a New York start-up company that lets people artfully post their witty text, Twitter and instant-message exchanges online, has attracted just 60,000 users since it began in October 2010. So it is making some changes, updating its site’s design and letting users post via text message, a feature designed with Siri in mind.

headline: Out There | Michael Wang’s ‘Carbon Copies’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Out With the New, In With the Newer at DC Comics
text: A few months into a DC Comics initiative under which the superhero publisher restarted its long-running series at issue No. 1, some of those narratives will go no further: the company announced on Thursday morning that it is canceling six of its comic books and introducing six new ones, keeping the total amount of its continuing titles at the magic number of 52.

headline: London Metal Exchange to Review Takeover Bids in February
text: LONDON — The London Metal Exchange, the world’s largest metal futures market, plans to review initial takeover offers at a board meeting on Feb. 23.

headline: Improving the City With Vigilance for All
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is in the Bronx on Thursday to give his yearly State of the City speech at a campus of small schools that used to be Morris High School. In case you wondered, the high school was named for Gouverneur Morris, one of the country’s founders. It had nothing to do with Philip Morris. Mr. Bloomberg is not the sort to be caught in a place that sounds like a cigarette.

headline: Image of the Day: January 12
text: School children perform mass yoga in Bhopal.

headline: A North Korean Soldier Finds His ‘Casablanca’
text: North Korea, the Stalinist “hermit kingdom” and one of the world’s most backward and isolated countries, is also a realm where fiction making — state-sponsored storytelling, that is — reigns supreme. At least, that’s how Adam Johnson depicts the dictatorial Communist state in his harrowing and deeply affecting new novel, “The Orphan Master’s Son,” which recounts the picaresque adventures of its title character, Jun Do, a soldier turned kidnapper turned surveillance officer, who tries to stay alive as he stumbles his way through the government bureaucracy.

headline: Touch-Screen Gorilla Glass Slims Down
text: LAS VEGAS — The screen on your smartphone or tablet is almost certainly made of a special class of glass known as Gorilla glass. Corning, a major glass maker, introduced the second generation of its Gorilla glass at the International Consumer Electronics Show this week.

headline: A New Set of Awards, Courtesy of the Carpetbagger
text: It was inevitable: after years of covering awards season, the Bagger has come up with some prizes of our own. They are the Thursdays, in honor of the best moments from Oscar hopefuls thus far this week (and the fact that Thursday is also the day our column appears is just a coincidence, surely). The first round of winners are here. But as always there were still more worthy folks who deserved recognition. The Bagger is nothing if not generous with the praise.

headline: Malicious Software Attacks Security Cards Used by Pentagon
text: Chinese hackers have deployed a new cyber weapon that is aimed at the Defense Department, the Department of Homeland Security, the State Department and potentially a number of other United States government agencies and businesses, security researchers say.

headline: Yes, He Discovered the Titanic. No, He Doesn’t Want to Talk About It.
text: Robert Ballard has made quite a few notable discoveries in deep waters around the world in the last 27 years. But most people still want to hear him use the T-word.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: MSNBC: The dodginess of third-party audits rather than government inspections has been highlighted by a Congressional investigation of a cantelope-borne listeria outbreak that killed 30 people last year. The auditor awarded Jensen Farms in Colorado, the source of the tainted fruit, a “superior” rating just before the outbreak. — Glenn Collins

headline: ING Revises I.P.O. Plans
text: The ING Group is abandoning plans for an initial public offering of its combined Asian and European businesses, citing turbulence in the equity markets.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘January’
text: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches W. S. Merwin’s “January” with a 2011 story about enjoying the season despite the cold — “Snow Forecast? Set Up the Patio.”

headline: A Wintry Mix of Opinions on a Season’s Missing Snow
text: Where is the snow? That is the question swirling — unlike actual flurries — across New York City and its suburbs, where sidewalks have been relentlessly gray and yards stubbornly green this winter. After a decade of higher-than-average snowfalls, including last year’s snowiest January ever, nary a flake has fallen since the freak October storm.

headline: Michigan Diary: Getting to Know the Boys
text: This Sunday at Progressive Field, home of the Cleveland Indians, the Wolverines of Michigan will be capping a weekend series with the Buckeyes of Ohio State in the Frozen Diamond Faceoff. With all the pressures of this series (the first game is Friday in Columbus), I’m here to provide some comic relief about our team and past experiences of playing outdoors.

headline: The Good News Bear
text: You have to hand it to Robert Griffin III. It was no small feat bringing joy to this college football season. He not only won a Heisman Trophy while lifting Baylor into a level of the sport’s atmosphere it hardly knew existed, he also made a lot of people happy just watching him play, equal parts glittering talent and spunk and an electrifying sense of occasion.

headline: Thursday Reading: America’s Binge Drinking, on a Map
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Should The Times Be a Truth Vigilante?
text: I’m looking for reader input on whether and when New York Times news reporters should challenge “facts” that are asserted by newsmakers they write about.

headline: California’s Coastline Controversy
text: On January 1, 2012, a controversial series of marine reserves that restrict fishing went into effect in Southern California.

headline: In South Carolina, Romney Defends Bain Record
text: GREER, S.C. — Before jetting off for a quick trip to Florida, Mitt Romney stopped by a motorcycle dealership here Thursday morning, where he defended his record at Bain Capital, which has recently come under attack by his Republican rivals, and sought to subtly play up his pro-life credentials.

headline: In a Test, Target Plans to Add an Apple ‘Store’ Inside 25 Stores
text: Target said on Thursday that it planned to test Apple centers at 25 of its retail locations this year.

headline: Daily Report: The Struggle Over In-Car Tech
text: Sam Grobart, personal technology editor for The Times, reports that automakers are pursuing two tracks when it comes to technology in cars. They want to bring all the tools and entertainment from the drivers’ smartphone onto the dashboard. At the same time they want to add safety features that make driving almost foolproof — which could save a driver from the very distractions that the smartphone integration has created.

headline: Perry Holds Back on Bain Attack Until Pressed
text: BLYTHEWOOD, S.C. – Rick Perry appeared to drop his attacks against Mitt Romney for practicing what Mr. Perry has called “vulture capitalism.” Until he didn’t.

headline: Red Carpet Campaign
text: It is the height of the campaign season, in politics and in Hollywood, and the red carpet gives actors, directors and producers a chance to practice their stump speeches and charm the press.

headline: Romney Backers Release New Anti-Gingrich Ad
text: The Restore Our Future “super PAC” supporting Mitt Romney has unleashed a new ad against Newt Gingrich called “Desperate” that faults Gingrich supporters for attacks on Mr. Romney but then goes on the accuse Mr. Gingrich of having “more baggage than the airlines,” while saying that he has been fined for ethics violations and has been on Freddie Mac’s payroll.

headline: Bolton Endorses Romney, Citing Strong Defense Posture
text: WASHINGTON — John R. Bolton, a neoconservative who served as President Bush’s ambassador to the United Nations, endorsed Mitt Romney for president on Thursday.

headline: Boys’ School Affiliated With Catholic Group Draws Conservatives in Washington
text: POTOMAC, Md. — “Are your jackets on, boys?” Joe Cardenas inspects his charges in a first-period freshman humanities class, sees that they are all appropriately blazered and standing tall, bows his head and begins the morning Hail Mary: “Hail Mary, full of grace, the Lord is with thee ...” Only when they have finished the prayer do they take their jackets off. They sit and open copies of “Sir Gawain and the Green Knight,” the 14th-century English romance.

headline: No-Fishing Rule Roils Southern California
text: When California’s then-governor, Gray Davis, signed into law the sweeping Marine Life Protection Act in 1999, state wildlife officials knew they’d have a fight on their hands.

headline: Dear FloFab: I’m Your Waiter, Not ‘Honeybunch’
text: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Oudin Saves Nine Match Points in Spirited Loss to Robson
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Melanie Oudin’s first Grand Slam qualifying match in more than two years looked like it would be over in a blur.

headline: CVS Settles Prescription Price Case
text: After more than two years of investigation, CVS Caremark agreed on Thursday to pay $5 million to settle charges by the Federal Trade Commission that the company had misrepresented the price of certain prescription drugs in one of its Medicare drug plans, causing many older consumers to pay significantly higher prices than advertised.

headline: Start the Presses: Jeremy Jordan Will Star in ‘Newsies’ on Broadway
text: Clyde died, but Jeremy Jordan will live again on Broadway as Jack Kelly, the rabble-rousing newsboy and leading role in the musical “Newsies.”

headline: Up Front
text: Emma Gilbey Keller, who this week reviews “Girl Land,” Caitlin Flanagan’s take on adolescence, has a prime view of this developmental terrain as the mother of two girls, ages 14 and 9. But according to Keller, the world Flanagan describes — colored by passion and confusion and intensity and often difficulty — is strikingly different from the realm her own daughters inhabit. “My girls talk much more about the exciting things they can do rather than the challenges,” Keller wrote. “I love that. They’re both very gung-ho. They believe they can do anything they set their minds to. I wasn’t brought up to believe that.”

headline: On Second Day of Qualifying, Success for American Women
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — News and notes from the second day of qualifying at the 2012 Australian Open, a day on which all women in qualifying took the court and rain-postponed men’s first-round matches were completed.

headline: Sundance Sued Over Opening-Night Documentary
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s not unusual for the subjects of documentaries to dislike what they see on screen, sometimes resorting to defamation lawsuits. A Florida time-share developer, David Siegel, is taking the unusual step of suing not over the content of a film about his family but over a written description of it.

headline: Megabytes From the Motor Show
text: DETROIT — Paper news releases were rare sights during media previews for the auto show, as automakers continued to give the novelty storage-device market plenty of commissions.

headline: More About T.S.A.’s Confiscated Cupcake

headline: Jason Aldean and Nicki Minaj to Perform at the Grammys

Mr. Aldean and Ms. Minaj are nominated for several awards. They will be joined by Kelly Clarkson, Foo Fighters, Bruno Mars and Taylor Swift.

headline: Age Discrimination Takes Its Toll

headline: Justice Department Memo on Recess Appointments
text: A previously secret legal memorandum concluded that President Obama had the power to lawfully consider the Senate to be on a lengthy break – even though Congress contended otherwise – and make recess appointments.

headline: 36 Hours in Oaxaca, Mexico
text: With the city’s street art scene, a mescal-fueled night life and one of Mexico’s most exciting regional cuisines, Oaxaca is as cosmopolitan as it is architecturally stunning.

headline: 36 Hours: Oaxaca, Mexico
text: WITH Oaxaca’s imposing Baroque churches, plant-filled courtyards and shady plazas perfect for people-watching, it’s tempting to see the city as a photogenic relic of Mexico’s colonial past. But Oaxaca City, the capital of one of the country’s poorest states and a college town teeming with students, isn’t quaint or stagnant; it’s a small but dynamic city, still emerging economically from the social unrest that put it in the international spotlight, and crippled its tourism industry, in 2006. That uprising — a protest by striking teachers that was met with police violence and led to a protracted conflict — is now history, but its legacy is everywhere in a streetscape of politically inspired stencil art, which has turned adobe walls and concrete sidewalks into a public gallery. Combined with the city’s long-established studio art scene, a vibrant cafe culture, a mescal-fueled night life and one of Mexico’s most exciting regional cuisines, Oaxaca is as cosmopolitan as it is architecturally stunning.

headline: Strategies for Surviving the Red Carpet Rigmarole
text: The Bagger took a little tour of this week’s award shows (so far) and asked people how they prepare for the rigmarole of the red carpet.

headline: Foursquare Wants to Plan Your Next Meal — and Vacation
text: Foursquare, the app that lets people share their locations with select friends, is moving beyond the check-in.

headline: Praising God, for an Interception?
text: Why do athletes only thank God when something good happens on the field? If Tim Tebow thanked Jesus after throwing an interception, it would be more of a teachable moment, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: An Invisible Keyboard Aims to Improve Touch-Screen Typing

headline: The Sun, the Moon and the Quail
text: Jennifer Gee, a biologist at the Claremont University Consortium and the University of California, Riverside, writes from the tropical dry forest near Álamos, Mexico, where she and Jennifer Calkins are studying Callipepla quail.

headline: Justice Dept. Defends Obama Recess Appointments
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama had the lawful power to consider the Senate to be on a lengthy absence — even though it considered itself to be meeting regularly — when he made a set of highly disputed recess appointments last week, the Justice Department concluded in a legal memorandum disclosed on Thursday.

headline: Is Age Tipping the Balance in the N.B.A.?
text: Wednesday night a pair of games may have revealed four franchises headed in opposite directions. The nationally televised Dallas-Boston game should have been a power battle. In addition to being the defending champions, the Mavericks have won 50 or more games in 11 straight seasons. Meanwhile, in the last four seasons the Celtics have won a championship, an average of 61 games per season, and four straight division titles. Although the game was a close one — the Celtics tied the score with 25 seconds remaining before the Mavs scored the final five points — it appeared as if these teams aren’t as relevant as they once were.

headline: What the New Dean at Pomona Looks for in an Essay
text: As part of our effort to pass along authoritative guidance on applying to American colleges to an audience of students and families in India, we have recently posted the second installment in a regular Choice series on The New York Times’s India Ink blog.

headline: A View From Russia, on Rails
text: David Gilkey had 16 days to shoot a photo essay aboard the Trans-Siberian Railway. More than two weeks with little to do other than to gaze out the window and catch glimpses of passing towns and people; smoke trailing high above factories and fields quilted with snow.

text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave his State of the City address on Thursday. You can watch it in the player above, and read the full text of the prepared speech as provided by the mayor’s office.

text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Football and the Fear of Concussions

headline: Iran Signals Revenge Over Killing of Scientist
text: Iran expressed deepening fury at Israel and the United States on Thursday over the drive-by bombing that killed a nuclear scientist in Tehran the day before, and signaled that its Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps might carry out revenge assassinations.

headline: Bloomberg Unveils Ambitious Proposals for Schools
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's State of the City address includes proposals to attract, reward and evaluate teachers; open 100 new schools, including 50 charters; increase  partnerships and efforts to connect students to college and careers; and help students obtain financial aid.

headline: Spate of Self-Immolations Reported in Tunisia
text: More than a year after the self-immolation in Tunisia that incited the first revolution of the Arab Spring, Tunisians are setting themselves on fire at a disturbingly high rate, with at least four people doing so in the last week.

headline: London Underground | A Room for London
text: A wonderfully surreal vision comes into view as you walk across Waterloo Bridge: a boat moored atop the Southbank Centre’s Queen Elizabeth Hall. And this is not just any boat. A collaboration between the architect David Kohn and the artist Fiona Banner, it is part sculpture, part micro-hotel. “A Room for London,” as it is known, is the result of a design competition run by two inspired clients — Living Architecture, which commissions and rents vacation houses designed by cutting-edge architects, and Artangel, which commissions contemporary art projects — to offer a unique, one-bedroom accommodation with some of the best views in London, and a program of live performances and events. (“A Room for London” has a one-night, two-person limit, and rates start at 120 pounds, or about $185.65.)

headline: Haven’s Kitchen to Offer Classes, Catering and Retail
text: Alison Schneider, a food-loving, stay-at-home Manhattan mother of five, conducted some Greenmarket tours and taught informal cooking classes here and there. Then she wanted more. So she started pursuing a master’s degree in food studies at New York University. And now she is opening Haven’s Kitchen, an elegantly designed shop, cooking school, catering kitchen and party rooms on two floors of a 19th-century carriage house in Chelsea.

headline: Amid Crisis, President of Pakistan Visits Dubai
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Asif Ali Zardari flew to Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, on Thursday on what an aide said was a short visit for a wedding from which he would return overnight. The move was surprising, coming as tensions between the civilian government and the country’s powerful military have risen sharply and drawn in the judiciary.

headline: North Korean Television Reports Plan to Embalm Kim’s Body
text: As my colleague Choe Sang-Hun reports, North Korea announced on Thursday that it would place the embalmed body of Kim Jong-il on permanent display in a Pyongyang mausoleum, alongside that of his father, Kim Il-sung, who died in 1994 but still holds the title of president.

headline: Polls Show Gains for Romney — But Not in South Carolina

headline: Born in Unity, South Sudan Is Torn Again

headline: In South Sudan, a Descent into Violence
text: Bitter ethnic tensions that had largely been shelved for the sake of achieving independence have ruptured into a cycle of massacre and revenge that neither the American-backed government nor the United Nations has been able to stop.

headline: For One Roaming Bird, Climate Change Is No Albatross

text: About two million people participate in marathons or half marathons every year, and you might think that that kind of strenuous exercise involving so many people would lead to a lot of heart attacks. But you would be wrong.

All-Star teams were announced on Thursday, filling out the rosters after Ottawa fans stocked the top six vote-getters with four Senators (Daniel Alfredsson, Jason Spezza, Milan Mihalek and Erik Karlsson — and yes, Karlsson was the top vote-getter) in honor of the game being played Jan. 29 in lovely suburban Kanata, Ontario. headline: Pink Tea Cup Owner Opens a Harlem Wine Bar
text: Auberge Laurent, an elegant, brick-walled wine bar with a lounge area in the back, serves an array of wines, mostly French, and a few beers by the glass and the bottle, along with a brief menu of cheeses and charcuterie. This newcomer to Harlem is owned by Lawrence Page and was supposed to have been the uptown location for his Pink Tea Cup. Mr. Page, who owns the Actors’ Playhouse in Greenwich Village, bought the original Pink Tea Cup, a venerable diner-style soul food spot on Grove Street, which had closed, and moved it to a larger space on Seventh Avenue South.

The book, “Gone Till November,” is described as an internal monologue based on journals Lil Wayne kept during his eight-month stint at the New York City jail on a gun possession charge.

headline: Dead Voters in South Carolina? Maybe. Maybe Not.

These comments are intended, sometimes in a well-meaning way and sometimes not, to show me that what I’ve written about voter fraud and voter ID laws is wrong.

headline: On Our Radar: A Fracking Confrontation in Ohio

headline: Coming Soon | Steel Toes

The metallic cap toe was first spotted on both a lace-up oxford and a boot at Grenson, a design leader in the very traditional world of English shoemaking. It’s a slightly subversive, chic formal shoe for a daring guy, and also a denim-friendly basic with some extra kick.

headline: The Mayor Has Spoken. What Do You Think?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg laid out an ambitious agenda for the city schools. The reaction has been flying via Tweets, e-mails and Facebook posts. What do you think about his proposals?

headline: Synthetic Windpipe Is Used to Replace Cancerous One
text: Surgeons in Sweden have replaced the cancerous windpipe of a Maryland man with one made in a laboratory and seeded with the man’s cells.

text: Representative Jerry Lewis of California, the Republican who has represented San Bernardino and the Redlands for 33 years in Congress, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of this term.

headline: A Disco in Your Car
text: LAS VEGAS — If you have ever wished you could drive a dance club and have a DJ in your dashboard — and really, who hasn’t? — Pioneer has your car stereo.

headline: LeBron James and the Definition of ‘Clutch’
text: Let’s begin with a fundamental premise, and one that seems particularly popular and relevant in light of the Miami Heat’s overtime letdown in Wednesday’s game against the Los Angeles Clippers:

headline: TimesCast | Carter in Cairo
text: January 12, 2012 — Former President Jimmy Carter is in Cairo this week to help monitor the final round of parliamentary elections. He met with The Times’s Cairo bureau chief, David D. Kirkpatrick.

headline: Porsche Introduces a Brawnier Boxster for 2013
text: A substantially revised Boxster was unveiled by Porsche on Thursday, mere days after the German automaker’s executives packed up from the Detroit auto show media previews.

headline: Court Martial Recommended in WikiLeaks Case
text: WASHINGTON — The military officer who presided over an evidentiary hearing on charges against Pfc. Bradley Manning, accused of leaking hundreds of thousands of confidential government documents to WikiLeaks, recommended on Friday that Private Manning face court martial.

headline: Split Decision in Prime-Time Battle
text: The broadcast networks settled for a ratings split on Wednesday night with ABC’s comedy block taking the top spot in the 18-to-49 demographic while the broadcast of the 38th annual People’s Choice Awards drew enough total viewers (8.9 million) to give CBS the win in that category, according to Nielsen.

headline: Parental Quandary Considered: Grandma Gives Frilly Gifts to a Tomboy
text: Teaching children to graciously receive a gift they are not thrilled with is a common etiquette question, but last week, a parenting quandary came in that took the problem just a little farther. What if those unwanted gifts also bring an unwanted message? Gretchen’s daughter Mia (all names have been changed) has always worn boys’ clothing — not just gender-neutral clothing, but emphatically boys’ clothes, right down to the skin. She’s always said she wished she’d been born a boy. But Mia’s grandmother (Gretchen’s mother-in-law) sends boxes after boxes of fabulously frilly pink dresses, tights and bows.

headline: As the Directors Make Their Documentary Picks, New Oscar Rules Take Effect
text: The Academy’s Board of Governors made it official today: to qualify for the documentary feature Oscar, a film must be reviewed in The New York Times and/or The Los Angeles Times, in addition to the previously required weeklong run in both New York and Los Angeles. Once a film qualifies, the entire Documentary Branch will vote in a process explained here and debated here.

headline: Gulf Nations Aid U.S. Push to Choke Off Iran Oil Sales
text: WASHINGTON — Pressure on Iran mounted on Thursday, with the United States saying it was determined to isolate the country’s central bank, and three of Iran’s largest oil customers — Japan, South Korea and China — getting assurances that Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf producers would help make up any gap in supplies if they curtailed oil purchases from Iran.

headline: Saving Wayward Souls With Pleasures of the Flesh
text: So what if hookers have hearts of gold? Porn stars, as it turns out, are angels.

headline: WowWee Creates Games That Blend the Physical and Virtual Worlds
text: LAS VEGAS — At the International Consumer Electronics Show WowWee unveiled a previously announced line of toys it calls “Appcessories,” which are game pieces, collectable figures and toys that control games on Android or Apple devices.

headline: China Case Reveals Risks of Investing in a Foreign Company
text: The management of the ChinaCast Education Corporation appears to have a novel response to board elections: ignore them.

headline: Exit Left, Wordlessly
text: A STORY that haunts me involves a woman I know whose fiancé went out to inspect a potential apartment for their married life and never came back. He wasn’t dead in a ditch. He was just gone, without clarification.

headline: Vain Glorious | ‘Sontag: Reborn': the Makeup
text: Five years ago, in the Builders Association production of “Super Vision,” the makeup artist Dick Page  turned the actress Moe Angelos into a Sri Lankan grandmother. Now, for the multimedia show “Sontag: Reborn,” currently at the Public Theater, he’s transformed the performer into a young (and old) Susan Sontag. “It was an unusual mandate, because I don’t normally get asked to make people look older, ” Page said, referring to his usual beat: fashion photo shoots and runway shows.

headline: Romney and the Bailout
text: Like a lot of people, I was fairly startled by Mitt Romney’s new defense of his work at Bain: it was just like the auto bailout!

headline: Digital Notes: New Facebook Tool Lets Users Listen Together
text: 5:32 p.m. | Updated Daily updates on the business of digital music:

headline: Host Without the Most
text: I was recently at a dinner party and watched our 82-year-old host berate his 62-year-old wife at every turn. He told her he hated her outfit within five minutes of our arrival. From there, he seemed to criticize every step she took to make the evening pleasant. I was squirming in my chair and couldn’t wait to leave. I don’t know whom to confront about this abusive relationship. What’s a good friend to do? Anonymous

headline: Do College Grads Earn Less Now Than 40 Years Ago?
text: On Wednesday I wrote about how a college degree has gotten more economically valuable in the last few decades. A number of readers wrote in asking whether the numbers might be skewed by incomes at the very top. After all, the top 1 percent has received huge raises in the last few decades, and that group is mostly college-educated.

headline: Like Tebow, Patriots Sharpened Offense at Florida
text: Tim Tebow was still a high school phenomenon in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., not yet the prototypical quarterback for an offense that had begun to sweep college football, when the first phone call from Foxborough, Mass., was made to Gainesville, Fla.

headline: Keith Urban Books First Post-Surgery Gig, at Grand Ole Opry
text: Keith Urban will return to the stage for the first time since undergoing surgery on his vocal cords late last year when he sings at the Grand Ole Opry in February, the Opry announced Thursday. Mr. Urban has been forced to rest his voice since doctors at Vanderbilt University Medical Center removed a benign polyp from one of his vocal cords. Left untreated polyps can bleed when a singer is performing, leading to scarring on the vocal cords that can alter a voice’s timbre.

headline: Surprise! Israel Museum Is Receiving a Richter
text: The trouble with art-world gossip is that it is often wrong, yet it goes around and around so fast that speculation becomes fact. Here’s a recent example: After the best of a group of abstract canvases by Gerhard Richter sold at Sotheby’s in November for $20.8 million, some spectators at the sale decided that the anonymous telephone buyer had been the French billionaire Bernard Arnault. It was an educated guess; Mr. Arnault is a big collector of contemporary art with deep pockets. He also happens to be planning to build a $200 million museum in Paris designed by the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry.

headline: In Victory, Baylor Women Recognize Deeper Loss
text: Krista Pirtle of The Lariat at Baylor University will file reports about the top-ranked Baylor Lady Bears throughout the season for The Quad.

headline: Summing Up Andy Rooney, Who Long Had the Last Word
text: “He actually thought death did not apply to him,” said Andy Rooney’s son, Brian, “which is a great way to go.”

headline: Online Suggestion Box a Peril for Putin
text: MOSCOW — It took only a few hours after its launch on Thursday for Vladimir V. Putin’s presidential campaign Web site to become an object lesson in the hazards that await him between now and the election on March 4.

headline: Obama Adviser’s View of Unequal Opportunity
text: What Mitt Romney a few days ago called “the bitter politics of envy,” President Obama’s chief economic adviser instead described Thursday as the basic economics of unequal opportunity.

headline: ‘Absolutely Nobody,’ Discovering Old Ceramics
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Va. — Robert F. Doares Jr. and Barbara Myers Wood have no doctorates or institutional backing, just time on their hands for freelance ceramics scholarship. A married couple, they have shown up unannounced at the offices of venerable manufacturers, asking to rifle archives, and have then made major discoveries.

headline: Deal Would Lead Letterman to a Late-Night Milestone
text: PASADENA, Calif. – It appears increasingly likely that David Letterman will extend his contract, pushing him past the 30-year run of his idol, Johnny Carson.

headline: JPMorgan Shuffles Management Ranks
text: Jamie Dimon has again shuffled his senior management team.

headline: It’s the ’60s; Detach Yourself
text: In a 1965 essay on postwar science-fiction films Susan Sontag noted a common ingredient: a “depersonalization” of the characters, a kind of emotionless zombie state that occurred when their minds were taken over by aliens or robots. Some of this, she wrote, reflected the basic conditions of modern life. But it also pointed toward something new in the nuclear era. Now humans had to contend not only with the fear of death but also the “psychologically insupportable” possibility of a “collective incineration and extinction which could come at any time, virtually without warning.”

headline: One on One: Stephen Elop, Nokia Chief
text: Stephen A. Elop, the chief executive of Nokia, the Finnish cellphone maker, has a difficult challenge ahead to restore the company’s credibility in the American market, where Google’s Android and Apple’s iPhone are thriving. He’s betting that using Microsoft’s Windows Phone operating system on its devices will help with a turnaround. The following are edited excerpts of an interview from earlier this week at the International Consumer Electronics Show after Mr. Elop introduced a new phone that will be sold by AT&T, the Lumia 900:

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Brennan & Carr
text: In business since 1938, the restaurant has a menu that changes perhaps only once in a generation, and the regulars like it that way.

headline: Ace x Beams, Beams x Ace
text: Today, the Ace Hotel unveils its latest collaboration with the Tokyo-based fashion house Beams. Founded in 1976, Beams is both a private clothing label and department store, as well as a major force within the Japanese retail scene. (The brand operates upwards of 100 locations throughout Japan and Hong Kong, offering music, furniture and art that caters to the ever-changing and expanding tastes of the youth demographic.) Finding something of a kindred spirit in the Japanese brand, the Ace Hotel, another purveyor of hipness, recently collaborated with the company on two one-off projects: a boxing-inspired collection produced with Canada’s Wings + Horns and luggage accessories with the iconic Porter brand.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Stage, the Screen and the Screen on Stage
text: 12:11 p.m. | Updated  Can film and theater live happily together in the same room? It’s not as if they haven’t had a long relationship already, with each regularly borrowing stories and stars from the other. But now these separate but equal art forms are attempting to practice cohabitation.

headline: Compiling a Wish List for the 2012 Tennis Season
text: Every year before the Australian Open, Christopher Clarey, who covers tennis for The Times and The International Herald Tribune, puts together his wish list for the year in tennis. This year his No. 1 wish is something to revive the women’s game. He writes:

headline: Fallout From Urination Video Spreads
text: Graham Bowley reports on the widening condemnation from American officials, the NATO authorities in Afghanistan and the Afghan government of a video showing four Marines urinating on three dead Taliban fighters.

headline: What Does Homeland Security Read?
text: For the last year, the Department of Homeland Security has been routinely monitoring social networking sites like Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and even MySpace. It is an avid reader of The Huffington Post, Jihad Watch, Technorati and, oddly, TruckingInfo.com. But apparently it has no interest in Techmeme and TechCrunch.

headline: Eight Men In: Vintage 2008
text: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team — a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen — are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sunday’s showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men — they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee — have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

headline: Travelers’ Tricks
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Get Them to the Debate on Time: Reporters’ Tips” (Practical Traveler, Jan. 1), on our honeymoon to New Zealand and Australia, we ended up with soft-sided bags and could not have been happier. Soft bags without wheels give you nearly twice as much packing space, and when packed right, they often fit under an airline seat (avoiding the nightmare rush for overhead space).

headline: PAC Deluges South Carolina Airwaves With Anti-Romney Ads

headline: In Zurich West, Feeding the Hip and the Hungry
text: FOR much of the past century, the Zurich West neighborhood was best known for its industry, churning out water turbines, electric motors and even ships in the area between the Limmat River and the railway tracks behind the main train station. Then, as manufacturers moved away, contemporary art galleries, museums and design shops sprouted amid abandoned factories in the mid-1990s, creating a gritty haven for the city’s creative class.

text: The problem of human waste disposal has become impossible to overlook in Port-au-Prince, with the stench of decomposing bodies replaced by that of excrement.

headline: Hot Roast Beef and Close Ties on Avenue U
text: WHEN Eddie Sullivan was a boy, he could earn a dollar from his grandmother for folding the napkins and wiping down the salt and pepper shakers at Brennan & Carr, the restaurant his father, Russ, had just bought in the northeast corner of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. But his grandmother, who had been a waitress there in the 1940s and ’50s, was “a tough old Irishwoman,” he said, and Eddie knew if she found any flaws, that dollar would disappear.

headline: Risks: When Too Much Vitamin D Is Too Much
text: Too much vitamin D may be just as bad as too little, a recent study suggests.

headline: Restaurant Review: Little Bird in Portland, Ore.
text: Of all the dishes served at the Little Bird bistro in Portland, Ore., the charcuterie plate best encapsulates its spirit. On a recent evening there, the plate featured the typical chicken liver mousse, but it also included an unusual and seductive foie gras brûlée, a savory take on the dessert that is so packed with umami and conflicting textures that it’s memorable even without its delicious apricot-Sauternes jam pairing. That the platter has both elements reveals the ethos of Little Bird, where recognizable favorites are served along with more daring choices.

headline: Nephew and Aunt, Like a Wistful Moth and an Enticing Flame
text: “The good thing about mathematics is you don’t have to talk; you create order without words,” declares Nadia (Béatrice Dalle), a haughty, self-destructive mathematician holding forth tipsily to her bohemian friends at a nighttime picnic in “Domain.” A formidable screen presence who suggests a sexy, gap-toothed hybrid of Sade and Fran Drescher, Ms. Dalle exudes a tortured erotic gravitas. This 47-year-old actress, who played a cannibal in Claire Denis’s “Trouble Every Day,” struts through “Domain” like a restless queen of the night.

text: HILTON HEAD, S.C. – Rick Santorum is facing questions about supporting earmarks during his time in Congress. He offered up a decidedly South Carolinian response on Thursday, boiling down his defense to two words: Strom Thurmond.

headline: In Winter, Berkshires Culture Moves Indoors

headline: Church Choir’s Dueling Divas Come Out Singin’ and Slingin’
text: The saving graces of “Joyful Noise,” a flimsy movie musical whose parts are pasted together with chewing gum and Scotch tape, are its ornate gospel renditions of familiar pop tunes. When you put singers in choir robes and arrange the songs for chorus and soloists to give them big, churchy buildups, hits by Michael Jackson (“Man in the Mirror”), Paul McCartney (“Maybe I’m Amazed”), Sly and the Family Stone (“I Want to Take You Higher”), and Stevie Wonder (“Signed, Sealed, Delivered I’m Yours”) become sacred hymns. Thus transfused, “higher” means spiritually exalted, and “yours” means in God’s hands. To which I say hallelujah, sort of.

headline: The New Lady Hawk Shall Be Called Rosie
text: The tamper-resistant re-voting process has been completed, and City Room readers have chosen a name for the female hawk of Washington Square Park, the soon-to-be leading lady of the ongoing Hawk Cam soap opera.

text: The Niseko region sees plenty of snowfall in a breathtaking landscape.

headline: In Bustling Vietnam, a Rare and (Still Untrammeled) Escape
text: IT was my first time operating a motorcycle, but I handled the Honda with the confidence of a veteran, zipping alongside my boyfriend, Caleb, through rain-filled potholes on red clay streets. The morning was overcast after a night of thunderstorms, but we were determined to spend as many daylight hours as possible on Sao Beach, the white sand haven rumored to be among the most beautiful spots on Phu Quoc, an island 30 miles off the west coast of Vietnam.

headline: Patterns: Study Finds Problem Drinkers Get Bigger Endorphin Kick
text: Drinking alcohol causes a pleasant feeling because it releases endorphins, the brain’s natural opioids. But a new study has found that problem drinkers differ from social drinkers in the way alcohol affects one part of the brain. The report appeared Wednesday in Science Translational Medicine.

headline: A Labor Hero’s Route to Leading a Nation
text: “Lula: Son of Brazil” is an unabashed hagiography that follows the rise from poverty to national prominence of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who served as president of Brazil from 2003 through 2010. The film ends in 1980, the year his beloved mother died while he was in prison. In the same year he helped found the left-wing Workers Party, which stood up against the country’s right-wing military government.

headline: Another Good Reason to Tip Your Super
text: In “The Divide,” the residents of Fifth Avenue and 29th Street find hell in their apartment basement. Not unlike many New Yorkers, you’re thinking, but this is worse. Saved and yet trapped by this refuge after a nuclear attack, they devolve into mental and physical depravity. It’s well beyond “Lord of the Flies”: I’m talking Kurtz in “Apocalypse Now,” if he had the energy and mindlessness of youth. I’m talking filthy, horrific torture porn.

headline: Mary Raftery, 54, Dies; Irish Journalist Documented Child Abuse
text: Mary Raftery, a journalist whose television documentaries exposed decades of abuse of needy children in state-sponsored, church-run schools in Ireland, prompting an apology by the prime minister and a government investigation, died on Tuesday in Dublin. She was 54.

headline: Niseko, Japan’s Own St. Moritz
text: I AM barefoot and naked padding along a stone path in the depths of Japanese winter, surrounded by snow-laden pine trees. I slip into a hot pool fed by natural underground springs. Huge, slow-moving snowflakes gently settle on my hair. In the dusk I can see just a few vague figures across the pond-size area — other women barely visible through the steam.

headline: The Italo Calvino Soundtrack
text: This week, the Liverpudlian musician and composer Bill Ryder-Jones — known previously for his guitar work with the British rock band The Coral, and also for his boyish good looks — released his first solo effort, “If…” (Domino). It is an album of mostly instrumental music, written as a kind of soundtrack to the Italo Calvino novel “If on a Winter’s Night a Traveler.” NPR is now streaming the entire record, which came out late last year in Britain to rave reviews.

headline: Struggle and Song Define a Life
text: It’s only fitting that Harry Belafonte’s big, bountiful life has inspired an expansive, understandably hagiographic documentary, “Sing Your Song.” Silky voiced and snake hipped, with a supernova smile that dazzled Americans and helped demolish racial prejudices, he remains perhaps best known for his lilting version of the Caribbean folk tune “The Banana Boat Song” (“Day-O”), a requiem for the exhausted working man. Given his decades of tireless globe-sprinting crusading — alongside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and African activists alike — it’s clear that Mr. Belafonte rarely embraced the plaintive refrain of “Day-O”: “Daylight come and me wan’ go home.”

headline: A Wedding Dance That’s Also a Workout
text: ATTENDING Indian weddings and ending up the night sweaty and tired from hours of bhangra dancing have been regular parts of my weekend repertory since I was a child. The catchy music can entice even the most die-hard wallflower to move. But though my heart beats fast, and my legs end up sore, I’ve never thought of bhangra as a workout.

headline: Not Quite an Honest Day’s Work
text: The absurdity of the story in the largely thrill-free thriller “Contraband,” its hairpin twists and outrageous coincidences, may keep even hungry action fans away. That’s too bad because the story doesn’t matter. (It rarely does.) If anything, the film’s adherence to implausibility as a defining narrative principle — a reliably winning Mark Wahlberg plays a New Orleans super-smuggler on a fast boat to Panama who faces a wolf, an armored truck and a drip painting — is part of its low-key kick, as is the director Baltasar Kormakur’s fondness for industrial landscapes.

headline: Strippers With a Plot; Audra McDonald and Sharon Van Etten
text: Gyms are packed with people who resolved to get fit in the new year, and while we’re all for getting healthy, nothing depresses us more than watching a roomful of hungry New Yorkers fight over free weights and climb Stairmasters to nowhere. The Miser is on vacation this week, living it up in the hedonist’s paradise of New Orleans, so we think it’s safe to assume that she’d prefer to kick back with a martini and a dish of salted peanuts and watch women of all shapes and sizes get their (and their audience’s) heart rates up the old-fashioned way: with stripping and high drama.

headline: Mayor Takes On Teachers’ Union in School Plans
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, directly confronting leaders of the teachers’ union, proposed on Thursday a merit-pay system that would award top performers with $20,000 raises and threatened to remove as many as half of those working in dozens of struggling schools.

headline: Patti Smith Cancels Concert at the Chelsea Hotel
text: 9:48 p.m. | Updated  Patti Smith has canceled a private show she was going to perform for residents Thursday night at the Chelsea Hotel after some said they would not attend.

headline: For Some Brokers, 2011 Was Tops
text: SINGLE-FAMILY home sales in Westchester were down about 4.5 percent in 2011 from the year before, and dollar volume was off about 6 percent — partly the result of the downward trend of house prices, said P. Gilbert Mercurio, who recently retired as chief executive of the Westchester-Putnam Board of Realtors.

headline: Philadelphia Stories
text: In 2001 the artist Zoe Strauss came up with an unusual idea for an exhibition. It would take place under an elevated section of Interstate 95, in her home city, Philadelphia, and would consist of photographs mounted on the columns that supported the highway. It would be a recurring event, appearing yearly over a decade. It would be free and open to the public, with photocopies of the exhibited works available for purchase for $5 each. And it would take the form of “an epic narrative about the beauty and struggle of everyday life,” in Ms. Strauss’s words.

headline: Rick Perry’s Son Emerges, a Tweet Off the Old Block
text: Mitt Romney has a traveling band of look-alike sons. Jon M. Huntsman Jr. has his ever-tweeting daughters. The latest addition to this political kids’ club is Rick Perry’s son Griffin, 28, who has propelled himself into the headlines — and injected some much-needed energy into his father’s decidedly downtrodden candidacy — with his Twitter missives from the campaign trail.

headline: Blasts From the Fed’s Past

headline: Rural Areas Slower to Rebound
text: FOR whatever reason, homes sales picked up in New Jersey in the latter part of 2011. A new statewide market report shows contract signings increased in six of the seven months from May through November, compared with 2010.

text: The All-Star edition of the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast with the Slap Shot contributor Christopher Botta, Adam Rotter of SNYRangersBlog and Billy Jaffe of the NHL Network and MSG.

headline: One Debut and One Farewell in an Opera at the Met
text: This season’s revival of Puccini’s “Tosca” at the Metropolitan Opera features a beginning, an ending and everything in between: a young conductor’s debut, a cast filled with experienced Met singers and the final performances of a company stalwart.

headline: All Lines Lead to a Circle In David Parsons’s Orbit
text: Count on David Parsons to squeeze as much as he can from a single idea. His company, Parsons Dance, opened its season at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with a new work called “Round My World.” Find the shape in the title and you have the idea.

headline: Inside the Fed in 2006: A Coming Crisis, and Banter
text: WASHINGTON — As the housing bubble entered its waning hours in 2006, top Federal Reserve officials marveled at the desperate antics of home builders seeking to lure buyers.

headline: Projects With Mass Appeal
text: THE island never seems to lack for grand building plans. But that is sometimes less obvious than it might be, because of what usually happens when plans meet reality. Years can go by before a shovel enters the ground, what with a tangled approvals process and a tough climate for financing.

headline: A Bookish Teenager and a Wild Child Grow Up
text: Charmingly low-key, the British coming-of-age drama “Albatross” offsets slack plotting with creative casting and sensitive performances.

headline: The Irresistible Allure Of ‘Banned in Beijing’
text: Nothing creates interest in a work like official displeasure, or so, at least, historical precedent suggests. When the British government tried to ban Strauss’s “Salome” in 1910, the conductor Thomas Beecham appealed successfully and led a London run that was the hottest ticket of the season. Time was when the label “banned in Boston” helped guarantee Broadway ticket sales. And after religious figures inveighed against the 1979 Monty Python film, “Life of Brian,” John Cleese said in a television interview that “these people have made me a very rich man.”

headline: As ‘Clear Day’ Clears Out, ‘Leap of Faith’ Will Leap Onto Broadway
text: In a move unusual by Broadway standards, the producers of the new musical “Leap of Faith” said on Thursday that the show would begin performances on April 3 at the St. James Theater, now home to the Harry Connick, Jr., musical “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever.”

headline: ‘The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess’ Opens
text: ”The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” opens on Broadway.

headline: Leaderless, A Hybrid Swings Forward
text: The drummer Terri Lyne Carrington put out an album last year called “The Mosaic Project,” with all female musicians and singers from different aesthetic areas and generations, swing and backbeats, melodic improvising and rapping, the whole thing loosely categorizable as jazz. It involved a revolving cast of more than a dozen musicians; it’s probably impossible to take the project on the road.

headline: Seeing Spots
text: A look at some of Damien Hirst’s “spot” abstractions on display in New York.

headline: Jets Owner Offers Defense of Sanchez
text: The Jets’ owner, Woody Johnson, speaking publicly Thursday for the first time since the late-season collapse that exposed a splintered locker room, briefly addressed the problems that seemed to overtake the team over the last two weeks.

headline: Brought to Us by the B. Q. E.
text: OF all our New York highways, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway under Brooklyn Heights is perhaps the most daring and ingenious, a cantilevered structure narrowly threaded between waterfront warehouses and mansions high above, incidentally creating one of New York’s great parks, the Brooklyn Heights Promenade.

headline: A Studio With a Little Give
text: THOUGH David Kulla was never thrilled with his rental, the thought of moving was worse than the reality of remaining.

headline: Don’t Say We Didn’t Warn You
text: Vincent D’Onofrio can do crazy. Perhaps you know that from his intellectually tormented detective on television’s “Law & Order: Criminal Intent.” Or perhaps you know how far he can really take crazy, to brilliant and frightening effect in, say, “Full Metal Jacket” or “The Salton Sea.”

headline: Juxtaposing Movement And Speech
text: In 2007, after Daniel Linehan unveiled his earnest solo “Not About Everything,” he didn’t get my vote for most likely to succeed. In that piece, which he reprised at the Abrons Arts Center on Tuesday evening, he made a circle of reading material on the stage — along with a copy of Vogue, there was a book about the visual artist Francis Alÿs — and within that structure, he started spinning while reciting lines like, “This is not about therapy.”

headline: ‘Zoe Strauss: Ten Years’

headline: Mysteries and Truths in Black and White

headline: Free-Spirited Enclave’s Reluctant Landowners Fear Capitalism’s Harness
text: COPENHAGEN — Last summer, the Danish state offered to sell a good chunk of the 80-odd-acre former military base at the edge of downtown Copenhagen to Christiania, the alternative community whose residents had been squatting there illegally for four decades. For the residents, who fundamentally reject the idea of landownership, this presented an ideological quandary.

headline: Major Pain, Minor Glory
text: The taunts in the ring may be make-believe, but the slams against the mat are agonizingly genuine in Robert Greene’s vivid documentary “Fake It So Real,” which examines the weeklong preparations for a Saturday night independent-wrestling match in Lincolnton, N.C.

headline: Much More Than Just ‘Maintenance’
text: IN New York, the cost of a co-op or condo can seem an impossible hurdle. But alongside the asking price is another figure that can induce sticker shock: the monthly maintenance fee — or, as it’s called in condos, the common charge.

headline: Blasting Off as a Space Tourist
text: “Man on a Mission,” the most expensive home movie ever made, is one man’s genial account of his trip into outer space. What’s odd about it is that while you can certainly sense the joy that this fellow, Richard Garriott, feels in achieving a lifelong dream, you’re unlikely to be interested in imitating him. Cramped quarters, bulky wardrobe, unappetizing-looking food: it seems like a Worst Vacation Ever candidate.

headline: Somewhere In Europe
text: The latest on Hungary from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, below the fold.

text: This week, some of the most gee-whiz automotive technology was to be found not in Detroit, where media previews for the Detroit auto show concluded on Tuesday, but in Las Vegas, where automakers presented the latest thinking around telematics and infotainment systems.

headline: Packers’ Jennings Is Ready for Giants
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — In the locker room after the short-handed Green Bay Packers defeated the Detroit Lions, 45-41, on Jan. 1, nose tackle B. J. Raji was marveling at what had just taken place.

headline: This Inside Goldman Deal Comes Steamed, With Sauce
text: Kenny Lao has the kinds of credentials — a master’s in business administration from New York University and a former job as a Wall Street analyst — that might come in handy when pitching business to Goldman Sachs.

headline: Texan’s Anti-Piracy Bill Gets Home State Pushback
text: United States Representative Lamar Smith says online piracy is damaging the United States economy and putting American lives at risk. Foreign Web sites that distribute American-made entertainment and counterfeit products, like fake pharmaceuticals, are “stealing our profits, they’re stealing our jobs and they may be endangering the health of Americans,” said Mr. Smith, a Republican from San Antonio.

headline: Somalia: Rebels Attack Kenya
text: Somali militants have attacked a Kenyan police post near the Kenya-Somalia border, killing at least six people and kidnapping several others, Kenyan officials said Thursday. The officials said that three police officers, a civil servant and a teacher were among the dead in the raid at Gerille on Wednesday, and that several government employees were missing. The Shabab militant group posted a message on Twitter saying its forces had “seized Kenyan vehicles, communication equipment and a cache of weapons.” Somali militants have staged several hit-and-run attacks inside Kenya since October, when Kenyan forces crossed into Somalia to fight the Shabab. The Shabab said Thursday that they were “responding to aggressive Kenyan invasion against Muslims of Somalia.”

headline: Evangelicals Hope South Carolina or Florida Winnows Republican Field
text: Conservative Christian leaders have scaled back their goals for a meeting to be held in Texas on Friday and Saturday, acknowledging that they are unlikely to agree on a single alternative candidate to Mitt Romney until after the South Carolina primary on Jan. 21, if then.

headline: Bringing Gang Members to God on a Rooftop
