headline: Vote Holds Fate of Nuclear Power in Taiwan
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — When voters here choose a president and a new legislature on Saturday, their decisions will also determine whether Taiwan pulls the plug on a state-backed nuclear power industry that provides the country with a fifth of its electricity.

headline: Why Taiwan’s Future Matters
text: FOR most of its history, Taiwan’s destiny was determined by three great powers — China, Japan and America. Now, as the 18th-largest economy in the world and a thoroughly democratized nation, Taiwan is still perceived by some in Washington as a potential bargaining chip in crafting a new relationship with China. This is a mistake.

headline: Kastor, After Pregnancy, Sees Trials as New Start
text: HOUSTON — Marathon training was out of the question. Still, Deena Kastor, the 2004 Olympic bronze medalist, figured she could run for 20 or 30 minutes a day during her pregnancy. She was wrong. Aching in her sides and her back grew so acute that even walking the dog around the block sometimes forced her to sit and rest.

headline: Ringing Finally Ended, but There’s No Button to Stop Shame
text: They were baying for blood in the usually polite precincts of Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Sears Chairman Buys Shares, but His Reason Is Unclear
text: When big-name investors increase their personal stakes in stocks, the purchases can be a positive sign for the companies.

headline: Toward a National Coastline Policy
text: The United States has thousands of miles of coastline, and more than half of its population lives in counties bordering oceans or the Great Lakes — areas administered by a hodgepodge of federal, state or other agencies, often with conflicting goals.For years, environmental groups and expert panels have called for federal oversight for these areas.

headline: 4 Commissioners Skipped Taking Required Furloughs
text: Four Cook County commissioners failed to take off some or all of the required 10 unpaid days in the fiscal year that ended Nov. 30, according to a preliminary report by the county comptroller’s office.

headline: Vision for Affordable Energy Even if Indian Point Nuclear Plant Is Shut Down
text: If anyone, or any business, can get a good deal on electricity, it ought to be Consolidated Edison, which buys loads of it every year and then sells it to three million customers in New York City and the suburbs. Like most traditional utility companies, it has gotten out of the power generation business in recent years and is now a distribution company. It buys the electricity that it delivers from generators run by independent companies.

headline: In New Ads, Stirring Memories of Commercials Past
text: AFTER decades of listening to a talking tuna, consumers are talking back.

headline: For Priests’ Wives, a Word of Caution
text: Lafayette, La.

headline: Turkish Official Says a Russian Ship, Perhaps With Munitions, Has Reached Syria
text: ISTANBUL — A Turkish Foreign Ministry official said that a Russian ship thought to be carrying a cargo of munitions reached Syria on Thursday, in defiance of a European Union embargo, after stopping to refuel in Cyprus and receiving what the Turks said was inadequate scrutiny there.

headline: A Murder at Paradise
text: PARKLAND, Wa. — The next time somebody mindlessly bashes a “federal bureaucrat,” as if the term itself were a parasitic disease, remember the bright young woman we said goodbye to here a few days ago: Margaret Anderson, a park ranger in a flag-draped casket.

headline: The C.E.O. in Politics
text: There are two questions concerning Mitt Romney’s service at the private equity firm Bain Capital. The narrower question is: Did Bain help ailing companies and add value to the economy or did it plunder dying firms? The larger question is: Does Romney’s success in business tell us anything about whether he would be a successful president?

headline: F.C.C. May Move to End N.F.L. Blackouts
text: The N.F.L.’s television blackout policy dictates that for a home game to be shown in the team’s market, it must be sold out 72 hours before kickoff. Teams in danger of a suffering such a fate frequently scramble to sell the necessary seats.

headline: Colbert for President: A Run or a Comedy Riff?
text: If anyone can make a mockery of the newest campaign finance innovation, the “super PAC,” it’s Stephen Colbert.

headline: America Isn’t a Corporation
text: “And greed — you mark my words — will not only save Teldar Paper, but that other malfunctioning corporation called the U.S.A.”

headline: Roy Ash, Powerful Budget Director for Nixon, Dies at 93
text: Roy L. Ash, who used tough-minded analytic acumen to build a multibillion-dollar conglomerate, Litton Industries, and to become a force in the Nixon White House, where he headed the creation of agencies like the Environmental Protection Agency, died on Dec. 14 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: Before the Lights Go Out for Good
text: The playoff game on Saturday between the 49ers and the New Orleans Saints will be the most significant sporting event at Candlestick Park since 2003, when the Niners beat the New York Giants in a thrilling wild-card game.

headline: Republicans Asked to Bash Obama, Not One Another
text: NEW ORLEANS — Republican National Committee leaders, meeting here on Thursday amid sharpening divisions in the race for the party’s presidential nomination, implored fellow Republicans from around the country to unite around a message aimed at President Obama, not one another.

headline: A Houseboat Tips Over, but All Onboard Escape
text: The two-story houseboat had been docked on a quiet creek in a hidden corner of the Bronx for a decade. It had withstood the strong winds of Tropical Storm Irene, and as far as its owner could tell, no serious repairs were needed.

headline: Packers Fans Find a Home in Greenwich Village
text: New York, for all of its diversity, is also a city of defined communities, like the group of men who, for years, have gathered in the back of the Kettle of Fish in Greenwich Village. There, around a round oak table that is supposed to seat six but can be home to a few more, and not far from the gaze of a bobblehead Ray Nitschke doll, they watch their Green Bay Packers play — week after winter week, pleasant enough to other fans who share their allegiances yet protective of their small bit of turf deep inside the low-ceilinged bar.

headline: Dangerous Tension With Iran
text: With tensions rising over Iran’s nuclear program, the Obama administration has now warned the country’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, that Iran’s threat to close the Strait of Hormuz would provoke an American response. Earlier this week, international monitors confirmed that Iran has begun enriching uranium at a new underground plant. The United States and  Europe are tightening sanctions to choke off Iranian oil revenues. On Wednesday, an Iranian nuclear scientist died in a bomb attack en route to work, and a government newspaper signaled that the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps might retaliate.

headline: All the World’s a Stage, Even a Motel, a Mint or a Bus
text: Tensions typically run high before a theater company performs a work for the first time, and working outside a traditional theater compounds the worries.

headline: Bill Janklow, a Four-Term Governor of South Dakota, Dies at 72
text: Bill Janklow, a four-term governor of South Dakota with a colorful and brash persona whose political career ended abruptly when, as a congressman, he was convicted of manslaughter for killing a motorcyclist while speeding, died on Thursday in Sioux Falls, S.D. He was 72.

headline: The Ministerial Exception
text: In the case of Cheryl Perich, a teacher fired by a church-run school, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that the Constitution’s protection of religious freedom bars her from suing the church under federal workplace discrimination law.

headline: City Patches Stadium’s Power, and Waits
text: Gambling that the lights will stay on at Candlestick Park during a nationally televised football playoff game this weekend, the City of San Francisco decided to punt on plans to replace two aging electrical switches that were blamed for blackouts during the 49ers’ final regular-season home game last month.

headline: PACs’ Aid Allows Romney’s Rivals to Extend Race
text: Under the old political rules, Mitt Romney arrived in South Carolina this week the prohibitive Republican front-runner: flush with cash, awash in endorsements from a party establishment starting to coalesce behind him and buoyed by victories in Iowa and New Hampshire.

headline: Public Concern Over San Francisco Sheriff’s ‘Private Matter’
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Bloomberg Suffers, Too, in Collapse of MF Global
text: The collapse of MF Global has wreaked havoc on farmers, ranchers and other investors who were clients of the brokerage firm, prompting a loud outcry over the disappearance of $1.2 billion in customer cash.

headline: Back to the Robber Barons
text: With federal campaigns already knee-deep in a new era of laissez-faire money, the Republican National Committee has brazenly proposed the ultimate step — that the 105-year-old ban on direct corporation contributions to candidates and parties be scrapped as unconstitutional.

headline: Bloomberg Backs Effort to Raise Minimum Wage
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, saying that wages for the poorest New Yorkers had not kept up with rising consumer costs, endorsed a proposal on Thursday by the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, to increase the state’s minimum wage above the federal level of $7.25 an hour.

headline: Report Blames Safety Lapses for an Epidemic of Deaths at Wyoming Job Sites
text: DENVER — C. J. Moss was on the final day of his weeklong shift working in Wyoming’s oil fields when he died. A burnt cable electrocuted Mr. Moss, 26, while he was cleaning part of a motor for a drilling rig, killing him instantly.

headline: No Rest (but Four Wins) for the Weary Bulls
text: CHICAGO — One of the brutal stretches that have become a signature of the condensed N.B.A. schedule ended Wednesday night at the United Center. An undermanned, gassed Chicago Bulls team took the floor for its third game in three nights and fifth in six, a grind that rendered legs rubbery and challenged everyone’s concentration.

headline: Friday: Put the Finger On
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Allow me to tell you what I really thought about this puzzle: I loved it. No reservations.

headline: A New Storm’s Brewing Down on Catfish Row
text: The hurricane that’s said to be headed for Catfish Row has yet to arrive early in the second act of “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess,” which opened on Thursday night in a new, slimmed-down reincarnation at the Richard Rodgers Theater. The climate so far might be described as mostly cloudy and mild, as might this version of the show. But suddenly an elemental force takes possession of the stage, and its tremors course through the audience.

headline: Swingman Sparks Seton Hall’s Unlikely Rise
text: NEWARK — At the beginning of the week, the Seton Hall men’s basketball team found itself ranked in The Associated Press top 25 for the first time since 2001.

headline: During Address, Murdoch Goes After Cuomo on Twitter
text: In his first year in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo became accustomed to the grumblings of a peevish and powerful Manhattan billionaire media mogul.

headline: TimesTalks: Kristen Wiig & Paul Feig
text: The actress and screenwriter Kristen Wiig and the director Paul Feig discuss their film “Bridesmaids.”

headline: Panel Chief Raises $450,000 as She Eyes Manhattan Post
text: In a robust showing from a political novice, the chairwoman of Lower Manhattan’s community board has raised more than $450,000 toward a likely bid for borough president in 2013.

headline: Behind an Army of Lobbyists, an Instant Force in Gambling
text: In the summer of 2009, a Malaysian billionaire took an unexpected interest in a small town in the Catskill Mountains in New York. With little notice, he bought a stake in a racetrack casino where the owners had struggled for more than a decade to develop a gambling complex.

headline: Can You Hear Him Now?
text: “A symphony must be like the world,” advised Gustav Mahler, who composed nine symphonies across a brilliant career. “It must contain everything.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Sends Top Iranian Leader a Warning on Strait Threat
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is relying on a secret channel of communication to warn Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, that closing the Strait of Hormuz is a “red line” that would provoke an American response, according to United States government officials.

headline: Vow to Fight Police Misconduct Faces Skepticism
text: After a year that saw a steady drumbeat of police corruption cases and increased scrutiny of several New York Police Department practices, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pledged on Thursday to add four lawyers to the two-person legal staff at the agency responsible for monitoring the department’s Internal Affairs Bureau.

headline: The Narrow and Vulnerable Strait of Hormuz
text: The shipping lanes through the Strait of Hormuz are only six miles wide and are vulnerable to attack by Iranian missiles.

headline: Fire Survivor and a Possible Olympian: A Horse Named Neville
text: AIKEN, S.C. — The horses’ straw beds were ablaze, with the rest of the barn, when two men rushed in against the flames and black smoke to try to save the 11 horses inside.

headline: Grievances and Theatrics in a Lacrosse Lawsuit
text: There was the assistant lacrosse coach pressuring one of the girls’ head coaches to play his daughter and her friends more often. When the coach refused, the girls desiring more time would stop passing the ball to some of their teammates. They would besmirch them, repeating spiteful cracks other girls were supposedly making about them.

headline: Judge in Terrorism Case Orders Hunt for E-Mails
text: A federal judge in Manhattan directed the government on Thursday to conduct a deeper search for e-mails that an F.B.I. agent involved in a terrorism investigation in Nigeria said she had deleted from her computer because of a lack of storage space.

headline: Shutout by Senators Ends Rangers’ 5-Game Streak
text: Each man in the Rangers’ locker room was disconsolate after their 3-0 loss to Ottawa Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. The players acted as if they were in the midst of a lengthy losing streak instead of having just lost for the second time in twelve games.

headline: Woman Struck by a School Bus in Queens
text: A woman was in critical condition on Thursday after being struck by a small school bus in Jamaica, Queens. Five others, including two children on the bus, were injured in the crash, officials said.

headline: Japan: Prime Minister Shuffles Cabinet
text: The Japanese cabinet resigned en masse on Friday, in a routine step that allows Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda to announce a new lineup later in the day. Such reshufflings are common in Japan when a leader wants to push a new policy initiative, and Mr. Noda apparently hopes to convince the opposition to join his push to raise the national sales tax. Mr. Noda, a fiscal conservative, has pledged to submit a bill to the next session of Parliament to raise the national sales tax, currently 5 percent, in an effort to rein in Japan’s ballooning national debt, one of the largest among developed nations. It is unclear how many of his 17 ministers he will actually replace, but local news reports said he was expected to leave about a dozen in place.

headline: Uneasy Neighbors in a Southern Gothic Tale
text: LAURENS, S.C. — The Redneck Shop has been selling Confederate bikinis and white satin robes on the historic courthouse square in this former mill town for so long that most people have learned to ignore it.

headline: Germany: U.S. Will Withdraw Combat Brigade
text: The United States will withdraw another Army combat brigade from Germany, leaving just two brigades in Europe as the military shifts to a new strategy that focuses on the Asia-Pacific region while sustaining a strong presence in the Middle East, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Thursday. He said the United States was not abandoning Europe, and would sustain sufficient forces there to maintain ties with allies. He described the changes in an interview on Thursday with American Forces Press Service, the Pentagon’s media branch. In 2004, the Bush administration ordered that the number of Army combat brigades in Europe be cut to two from four. Last year, the Obama administration decided to retain a third brigade in Europe, but now has decided to leave only one brigade in Germany and one in Italy. A brigade has about 4,000 soldiers.

headline: A Horse’s Journey From Fire
text: Neville Bardos, a 12-year-old horse who competes in eventing, has managed a comeback from severe injuries sustained in a fire.

headline: An Unlikely Comeback
text: After surviving a barn fire, Neville Bardos is now a top contender for the Olympics and a finalist for this year’s international Horse of the Year award.

headline: A Pass That Changed Two Teams’ Paths
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: A Woman’s Struggles Unleash Memories of Trauma
text: For almost 30 years, Brendaly Moczo had a strategy for dealing with life’s darkest moments and the memories and emotions they evoked.

headline: Skier Is Still in Critical Condition
text: The Canadian freestyle skier Sarah Burke remained in critical condition at the University of Utah Hospital in Salt Lake City, two days after sustaining a serious head injury in the 22-foot halfpipe in Park City, Utah, the hospital said. Burke, a 2014 Olympic favorite, hit her head while attempting to land a trick during training. She had surgery Wednesday to repair a tear to her vertebral artery. “With injuries of this type, we need to observe the course of her brain function before making definitive pronouncements about Sarah’s prognosis for recovery,” said Dr. William T. Couldwell, who performed the operation.

headline: With Robots, a New Way to Understand Strokes
text: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Anthony Sprains Ankle as the Knicks Struggle
text: MEMPHIS — The game was drifting away from the Knicks, lost in a haze of errant passes, ill-conceived jump shots and a general offensive malaise long before they watched their scoring leader stumble away in agony. Any hope they had for a revival Thursday night disappeared when Carmelo Anthony did.

headline: Yankees Begin to Stir as Spring Training Nears
text: With a little more than a month before spring training, the free-agent and trade markets are starting to percolate again.

headline: Year of the Immigrant
text: Although everyone is talking about the presidential election this year, I am much more excited about the role of immigrants in the politics of 2012. It’s not a year like 2009 when we waited anxiously for a new president and Congress to create a sensible solution for immigration reform. Those hopes are long gone. They have been replaced by new fears aroused by draconian laws that emerged from Alabama, Arizona and Georgia.

headline: Longer School Day Brings Promise and Questions
text: Twenty hands shot into the air after Ashley Tam asked a question of her third graders during a math lesson on Tuesday morning. One boy threw his arm up with such force that his desk jumped off the ground with him.

headline: Michigan: Bridge Owner Is Jailed
text: Manuel J. Moroun, the billionaire owner of the Ambassador Bridge connecting Detroit to Canada, was jailed Thursday for his company’s failure to complete a project with the State Department of Transportation. A circuit judge found the company, the Detroit International Bridge Company, had avoided fulfilling its contract to help build ramps connecting two freeways to the bridge. The state partnered with the company in 2004 to build the ramps, spending $230 million on the project.

headline: Louisiana: Gunman, 3 Others Killed
text: Police officers killed a gunman in a shootout on Thursday after a car chase and the discovery of shooting victims in a New Orleans home. The police said the chase ensued when a car fled a home in the eastern part of the city where five people had been shot, three fatally. After the car crashed, a man emerged, firing at the police. He was killed and two people with him were wounded, the police said.

headline: How Super is the M.L.S. SuperDraft?
text: It does not quite reach the heights of Orwellian Newspeak, hyperbole is probably good enough, but what exactly is so super about Major League Soccer’s so-called SuperDraft? (This from the outfit that has given us “soccer-specific stadiums” that are anything but specific to soccer.)

headline: California: Burrito Used in Smuggling
text: A Los Angeles County sheriff’s deputy has been charged with taking a heroin-laden burrito into jail. An indictment unsealed Wednesday said Deputy Henry Marin, 27, received the burrito from an unidentified conspirator while he was stationed in 2010 at a county courthouse, with the intention of helping transport the drugs into a jail. He pleaded not guilty.

headline: Who’s Afraid of FDI in Retail: An India Ink & Caravan Magazine Discussion
text: At the start of this month, India Ink collaborated with Caravan magazine to co-host a panel in Mumbai about foreign investment in India’s retail industry. The panel, made up of journalists, an economist and a banker, discussed the controversy surrounding the Indian government’s proposal to allow companies like Walmart to set up stores here. Above is a video of the panel discussion.

headline: U.S. Restores Full Ties to Myanmar After Rapid Reforms
text: WASHINGTON — The United States moved to restore full diplomatic relations with Myanmar on Friday, rewarding the sweeping political and economic changes that the country’s new civilian government has made, including a cease-fire with ethnic rebels and, only hours before, the release of hundreds of political prisoners.

headline: Feral Cats and Social Indicators
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Last month there was an extraordinary attack at the Dhaka Children’s Hospital. One of the dozens of stray cats that call the hospital home reportedly walked into a neonatal ward, mounted a bed where a six-day-old girl was receiving phototherapy treatment for jaundice and tried to take her as prey. According to the Daily Star, the cat had pulled the newborn off her bed and onto the floor, and dragged her partway to the ward’s open door before anyone noticed.

headline: Why I Decided to Join Vistage

headline: Japan Delays Decision on Iran Oil Sanctions
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda said Friday that Japan had yet to decide whether it would reduce oil imports from Iran, continuing to send mixed signals in response to an American request to join in sanctions against the Iranian nuclear program.

headline: From the Jungle to J.F.K., Viruses Cross Borders in Monkey Meat
text: It’s a familiar story: deep within the jungle, an intrepid explorer or hunter awakens something he shouldn’t have. Maybe he bagged the wrong bat or came into contact with an ailing chimp. Whatever the origin, he unsuspectingly becomes host to something deadly and unseen and unwittingly carries it back home across the river or the ocean.

headline: Friday Reading: Heart Attacks Uncommon During Marathons
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Praise and Contempt for Bloomberg's Proposals
text: Characterize his proposals however you will, but one word can describe Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's state of the city speech on Thursday: chutzpah. Called groundbreaking and ambitious -- or stale and failing -- the mayor's proposed ideas have set off a passionate discussion. The New York Post declares: "It's war."

headline: Obama Bid to Cut the Government Tests Congress
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday announced an aggressive campaign to shrink the size of the federal government, a proposal less notable for its goal — the fight against bloat has been embraced by every modern-day president — than for the political challenge it poses to a hostile Congress.

headline: Bubble Memories
text: Hahahaheehee! The Fed transcripts from 2006 show a lot of laughter and an incredible amount of complacency, with people mainly worried about inflation rather than the coming recession.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Colbert for President? and iPhone Riots in China
text: The political performance art known as the Stephen Colbert campaign for president came a step closer to reality last night on “The Colbert Report” on Comedy Central, as Mr. Colbert transferred control of his “super PAC” — Americans for a Better Tomorrow, Tomorrow – to his friend and late-night lead-in Jon Stewart, Brian Stelter reported. Mr. Colbert’s lawyer explained: “You cannot be a candidate and run a super PAC. That would be coordinating with yourself.” Having a good friend run it, however, would be a different story, he said.

headline: Melinda Gates Answers Questions, Part III
text: Ms. Gates, of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, recently returned from a three-day trip to Bangladesh. She, along with Nick, agreed to answer readers’ questions about development issues focusing on that part of the world. Here is the third of three installments.

headline: Mental Health: Study Links Immigrating at Young Age and Higher Risk of Psychosis
text: A new study has found that among immigrants, younger age at the time of migration predicts a higher incidence of psychotic disorders.

headline: Part 5: Answers on the Fafsa, the Free Application for Federal Student Aid
text: In this fifth round of responses to reader questions about financial aid, Mark Kantrowitz, founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, addresses privacy issues, when to file and the rules concerning tuition assistance from grandparents and other relatives.Mr. Kantrowitz is no longer accepting questions. His answers will conclude Saturday. (Questions may have been edited).

headline: Untruths, Wholly Untrue, And Nothing But Untruths
text: I was deeply radicalized by the 2000 election. At first I couldn’t believe that then-candidate George W. Bush was saying so many clearly, provably false things; then I couldn’t believe that nobody in the news media was willing to point out the lies. (At the time, the Times actually told me that I couldn’t use the l-word either). That was when I formulated my “views differ on shape of planet” motto.

headline: The Get | Tooshie + A.P.C. Bathing Suit
text: Tooshie, the Paris-based swimwear line devoted to making bums look beautiful, has now partnered with A.P.C., the Francophile favorite, to create an 11-piece capsule collection. Included in the offering are powder blue trunks for men and this psychedelic one-piece for women. “I like the idea of an eccentric print on a very simple bathing suit,” says A.P.C.’s designer Jean Touitou. “Often you see prints like this on terrible shiny materials. The idea was to find a nice matte one.” As for the fit, Tooshie’s designer Natascha Sayn Wittgenstein took care of that: “It’s not about focusing on shapes — cover this, reveal that — but keeping it elegant with these small pieces of fabric,” she says. Jump in!A.P.C + Tooshie swimsuit, $280. Go to apc.fr.

headline: Kristen Wiig on the Sad Truth About ‘Bridesmaids’
text: It’s deadline day for Oscar nomination ballots and the Bagger hopes there are still a few stray undecideds out there who might be swayed to vote in the “Bridesmaids” direction. The film picked up best comedy at the Critics’ Choice Awards on Thursday night and its producer, Judd Apatow, had an unprintable message for people who think that women can’t be funny.

headline: At Yoko’s Show, Funeral Pyres and Tributes to Mommy
text: Yoko Ono’s first exhibition in India, called “Our Beautiful Daughters,” at the Vadehra Art Gallery in New Delhi, could also be called “Art Under Construction.”  All seven exhibits in the show, which opened Thursday night, ask the spectators to participate in them.

headline: Living His Passion for Hip-Hop
text: A paint-flecked floor is Nelson Seda’s stage. When the weather is too cold or wet, he clears the chairs from his bedroom, turns up the music and dances, his arms and legs a blur of impossibly graceful angles. An hour later, he may pick up his markers and draw – on canvases, old posters, shoeboxes, anything. And for good measure, he might end the day freestyle rapping.

headline: Leading Off: Tebow’s Moment of Truth
text: One week into the N.F.L. playoffs, the most entertaining story of the season travels to the place where fun goes to die: the Tim Tebow phenomenon rolls into New England on Saturday. It’s the hero versus the hoodie, an N.F.L. morality tale in four quarters. You thought last week’s Broncos victory over the Steelers was big? That was just a warm-up. It is possible, if the N.F.L. maneuvers the levers it has implanted in everyone’s heads just right, the entire universe will be watching the Broncos-Patriots game.

headline: What Rhymes With ‘Undead’? Some Poets Know
text: Times may be tough, but if you happen to be a zombie, the future looks bright. Never have the undead seemed more alive.

headline: Burkle Buys Control of Soho House
text: It appears that Ronald W. Burkle isn’t content to simply buy a membership for the Soho House line of luxury clubs. Instead, he’s buying control of the company.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: America’s Test Kitchen: A good explanation of why we heat up the oil in a pan before cooking. — Julia Moskin

headline: The Chinese-Takeout Container Is Uniquely American
text: The Chinese-takeout container, with its Japanese-influenced origami folds, is a uniquely American invention. On Nov. 13, 1894, in Chicago, the inventor Frederick Weeks Wilcox patented a version of what he called a “paper pail,” which was a single piece of paper, creased into segments and folded into a (more or less) leakproof container secured with a dainty wire handle on top. The supportive folds on the outside, fastened with that same wire, created a flat interior surface over which food could slide smoothly onto a plate.

headline: Let’s Start Paying College Athletes
text: I certainly agree with Joe Nocera that basketball and football players are treated like chattel in the present system. Denying players a basic stipend when coaches are making ridiculous amounts is the height of inequity. But paying football and men’s basketball players isn’t feasible, given Title IX regulations and politics. If you disconnect moneymaking sports, women’s sports will very likely lose financing. Paying basketball and football players will not address the core problem of an unsustainable arms race in college sports. The proposition that the N.C.A.A. is in charge and can control college sports is a canard. If the N.C.A.A. pushes too hard, top conferences could create their own basketball playoff and challenge the N.C.A.A. tournament, which is currently a huge windfall for the N.C.A.A. Then the decentralization of power that began with the Supreme Court decision will only get worse. Your proposal offers an important contribution to the debate by arguing for stipends to players, the right to counsel and a defined scholarship term and the opportunity for lifetime health insurance. But getting there isn’t going to be easy.

headline: ‘Why Write Novels at All?’
text: Last year, I found myself mildly obsessed with a cache of YouTube clips, featuring the novelists Jeffrey Eugenides, Jonathan Franzen, Zadie Smith, David Foster Wallace and Nathan Englander at a 2006 literary conference in Italy called Le Conversazioni. Part of what interested me, in a gate-crashing kind of way, was the backdrop: midsummer on the Isle of Capri, with flora aflame and a sky the color of Chablis. Another part, inevitably, was watching Wallace with the knowledge that he would kill himself two years later. Mostly what I kept coming back to, though, was how lighthearted, how loose — how young — these writers seemed here. It’s not that they weren’t already an accomplished quintet, with a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award to their credit. But in 2006 the gravitational center of Anglo-American letters still lay back on U.S. soil with Don DeLillo and Cormac McCarthy and John Updike and Toni Morrison and Philip Roth — those towering figures who, according to a Times survey released earlier that year, produced the greatest American fiction of the previous quarter-century. By comparison, Le Conversazioni might as well have been “The Breakfast Club” and Capri a weirdly paradisiacal high-school library.

headline: Grills
text: A sampling of National Football League face masks

headline: Wael Ghonim Has No Regrets
text: As a Dubai-based Google executive, you created a Facebook page that helped foment the Egyptian uprising. Your memoir, “Revolution 2.0,” recounts how you spent 11 days imprisoned during some of the most dramatic Tahrir Square protests. Major letdown, I imagine. It’s not a matter of enjoying the process as much as looking forward to the result, which is actually why most of the people went down to the streets. When I was released on Feb. 7, I saw Egyptians had managed to stand up together. I felt like I had been jailed for 11 years, but I did not feel I really missed the whole thing.

headline: The Fat Trap
text: Finally, some medical research on weight gain and the difficulty in losing it and keeping it off that does not blame, shame and condemn the person. Get this article to Oprah, Dr. Oz and those bullies on TV’s “Biggest Loser.”

headline: Must I Tell My Fiancé?
text: As a very broke and self-supporting 20-year-old college senior, I donated my eggs in exchange for money. It was a horrendous experience, and I rarely speak about it. Although I assume that some children resulted, I regret my participation and do not wish to know the results. I am now 35, engaged and planning to start a family. Must I tell my fiancé that there may be teenagers walking around with my genetic material? NAME WITHHELD

headline: E.R.: Port-au-Prince
text: It was 2 a.m. when the Haitian National Police brought the rape victim to the emergency room. I was the physician covering nights. The E.R. had only two gurneys, and one was occupied by a gray-haired man receiving IV fluids, asleep despite the overhead fluorescents. I hadn’t slept well in days.

headline: Selling a 300-Year-Old Cello
text: On a cold day last winter, an ailing Bernard Greenhouse, wearing an elegant bathrobe and attached to oxygen, was wheeled into the living room of his Cape Cod home, which was festooned with paper cutouts of musical notes. Relatives and students, locals and caregivers had gathered to celebrate the 95th birthday of one of classical music’s most respected cellists, a founding member of the famed Beaux Arts Trio and a beloved teacher. Young cellists performed for him, and then Greenhouse indulged in a martini and a plate of oysters. Thus fortified, he decided he wanted to play for the company. He picked up his cello and, though a bit wobbly, soulfully rendered “Song of the Birds,” a Catalan folk melody transcribed by Pablo Casals, with whom he studied many years ago.

headline: On Our Radar: Reducing Soot and Methane
text: Reiterating that carbon dioxide need not be the only focus, an international team of scientists suggests 14 ways of controlling emissions of methane and soot, from cleaning up cookstoves to changing cultivation methods for rice paddies. If adopted more widely, the scientists calculate, these methods would reduce projected global warming by 0.9 degrees Fahrenheit by the year 2050. [Associated Press].

Spend the night in a sketchy Burmese border town? Sure! Eat my way through Bridgeport, Conn.? Loved it. Once, I even spent four consecutive Sunday nights in Geneva — in midwinter — an ordeal to which no rational adventurer would willingly submit.

headline: Weekend Fare

The menu — which includes pork belly, sausages and other cuts served with mashed potatoes, sauerkraut and trimmings — is $26 per person, not including beverages, tax or tip. Call (212) 645-5659 or go online to make reservations.

headline: The Mechanics Behind Perspective
text: Once a figure of international renown, Jesús Soto is now mostly remembered as a minor Modernist who worked in the overlap among hard-edge abstraction, kinetic art and Op Art. “Soto: Paris and Beyond, 1950-1970” at New York University’s Grey Art Gallery will not precipitate a run to revive his reputation, but it does open an interesting window on the mid-20th-century philosophical landscape of modern art.

He put out hot cider, cookies and a not-quite-functional chocolate fountain, and for the benefit of the children he picked up his folk guitar to perform “The House at Pooh Corner.”

Quick: shoot over to Meryl Streep, then zigzag to Michelle Williams! Ninety seconds left – can you make it over to Patton Oswalt? And when her husbands’ parents visit, suddenly, the topic of “choosing a church home” comes off the to-do list and into the midst of the conversation.

headline: For Dr. King, Freedom and Education Were Intertwined
text: In honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Day, the dean of the UCLA School of Law looks at the legacy of Brown v. Board of Education and Dr. King, and writes:  "Without a strong sense of how liberty shapes our personhood and dignity, equality can mean little more than a race to the bottom for the unfortunate and disadvantaged."

headline: Writing About Radicals, Then and Now
text: Tom Robbins has a terrific story in the magazine on Sunday about the making — and unmaking — of the ’60s radical Judith Clark. Clark drove one of the getaway cars during the Brink’s holdup in 1981 when two police officers and an armored-car guard were killed. Furious at a system that she thought was unjust, Clark refused to be represented in court, trumpeted revolutionary action and ended up with a 75-year sentence that she is still serving. Over many visits and phone conversations, Robbins explored Clark’s life behind bars and her slow transformation from unrepentant young radical to a reflective, deeply regretful model inmate. Clark talks a great deal about the importance of her relationship with her daughter — who was 11 months old at the time of the crime — in changing her. And the role her parents played in nurturing that relationship.

headline: Brooklyn Awaits Nets, but Their Destination as a Team Is Unclear
text: NEWARK — The question of where the Nets are headed as an organization and as a basketball team leads only to a host of potential destinations that range from exhilaration to dread, with an occasional detour into comic relief. Technically, and temporarily, the Nets are in Newark, on their way to a new home next season in Brooklyn. By all other practical means of appraisal, their dateline should be limbo.

headline: My Berlin Airlift
text: Smuggling Afghan heroin or women from Odessa would have been more reprehensible, but more logical. You know you’re a fool when what you’re doing makes even the post office seem efficient. Everything I was packing into this unwieldy, 1980s-vintage suitcase was available online. I don’t mean that when I arrived in Berlin I could have ordered more Levi’s 510s for next-day delivery. I mean, I was packing books.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE VIEW FROM LAZY POINT: A Natural Year in an Unnatural World,  by Carl Safina. Illustrations by Trudy Nicholson. Maps by Jon Luoma (Picador/John Macrae, $18.) headline: William Gibson’s Future Is Now
text: On one of his trips to New York, William Gibson stopped before an antiques shop that would end up haunting him. He tried the door. It was locked. Over the years, he searched for the shop window many times — it seemed to wander around SoHo and materialize on unpredictable streets. When­ever he peered through it at the treasures within, he felt as if he were glimpsing the props from a dream. “There is no knowing what might appear there,” Gibson writes in one of the essays collected in “Distrust That Particular Flavor.” Once, he spied a collection of toy-size missiles.

headline: Strangers on a Plane
text: As much as teenagers and adults alike try to strategize over the search for love, in the end whether two people connect is a kind of elusive, slippery magic, up to the gods or to some unseen force, and it always comes down to one thing: timing.

headline: Vain Glorious | Jo Malone London Gets a Style Editor
text: Charlotte Stockdale’s career is an inspired one. The British-born beauty is a multitalented success, having done everything from serving as a muse to her good friend Karl Lagerfeld to styling the Victoria’s Secret runway show and holding down the fashion director post at i-D. Today, Stockdale adds the title of style editor of Jo Malone London to her ever-evolving C.V.

headline: You Must Go Home Again
text: Orphaning a protagonist adds a note of plangent depth to a child’s tale, provides a motive for search or for revenge, and hustles meddling authority figures out of the way. Ann Hood, the author of novels for adults like “The Knitting Circle” and “The Red Thread,” updates this grisly fairy-tale motif by divorcing the parents of Maisie and Felix Robbins, the 12-year-old twins at the center of her new chapter book for children. In “Angel of the Battlefield,” the mother is not deceased but simply distracted, settling herself and the children in a new home and proving herself in a new job. Their father has not been killed in battle nor lost to the exploration of faraway lands. He’s a curator who has taken a position at a museum in Qatar.

headline: Recess Appointments and Partisan Politics
text: There’s a lovely literary term for dramas in which there is a lot of excessive emotion and the main characters are driven to all kinds of irrational acts by motives such as revenge and greed. It’s called sturm und drang and we saw a lot of it last week when President Obama made some recess appointments even though the Senate was holding pro-forma sessions (some of them lasting about 30 seconds).

headline: Downgrade of Debt Ratings Underscores Europe’s Woes
text: PARIS — Standard & Poor’s downgraded the credit ratings of France, Italy and seven other European countries on Friday, a move that may have more symbolic than fundamental financial impact but served as a reminder that Europe’s economic woes were far from over.

headline: The Tenacity of Hope
text: “I am not a mathematician, but I know this,” says Hazel Grace Lancaster, the narrator of “The Fault in Our Stars,” the latest novel by John Green, a Michael L. Printz medalist and author of several best-­selling novels for young adults. “There are infinite numbers between zero and one. There’s .1 and .12 and .112 and an infinite collection of others.” The trouble, she says, is, “I want more numbers than I’m likely to get.”

headline: In the Shadows of Oklahoma City
text: Eileen Pollack’s new novel, “Breaking and Entering,” takes place in rural Michigan in 1995 — the epicenter and high point of the militia movement, before increased scrutiny and revulsion at the Oklahoma City bombing put some militia groups out of business and sent others underground. (Though not a militiaman, the bomber Timothy McVeigh attended their meetings and spent time on a Michigan farm with his fellow conspirator Terry Nichols.) The Oklahoma City attack comes about a third of the way through Pollack’s book, a real-world event that informs and shadows the fictional ones.

headline: India Grapples With Web Censorship
text: India has long faced an uneasy tension between allowing free expression to its citizens and staunching sectarian violence among its people. It was one of the first countries to ban “The Satanic Verses” by Salman Rushdie. Lawsuits forced the Indian painter Maqbool Fida Husain to live in exile during the last several years of his life. An academic book about the 17th-century warrior known as Shivaji was banned for fear of offending Shivaji’s modern-day fans, until the Supreme Court lifted the prohibition.

headline: Gil Scott-Heron: The Godfather of Rap
text: Gil Scott-Heron grew up surrounded by heroism. He distrusted empty promises and easy solutions. He also had a very hard time with himself. Whether you expect a memoir to explain how the third sentence relates to the first two will determine how you feel about this posthumous book.

headline: What It Means to Be Middle Aged
text: An upbeat look at middle age? Patricia Cohen had her work cut out for her. Maybe there’s a capitalist culture somewhere that doesn’t make a blazing fetish of youthfulness and keep it stoked with huge amounts of commercial and medical hot air. If so, it’s not the one we live in. Yet nothing in the sometimes pathetic struggle of Americans over, say, 50 to claim a respectable place in the public consciousness puts Cohen in the grumpy mood she could so rightly claim after absorbing some 200 years of the history of middle age. Instead, she’s delivered a lively, well-researched chronicle of the social and scientific forces that brought midlife America to its current befuddled state — better off by most measures than any previous generation, but miserably out of fashion.

headline: Among the Adolescents
text: Gather around, ladies, Caitlin Flanagan is back. And this time she’s after your daughters.

headline: Adele Hints at a Grammy Performance
text: Adele is widely predicted to sweep the Grammy Awards next month. But the question on every tongue in the music industry is whether she will also perform.

headline: Holding Fast to Old-Fashioned Ways
text: EVERY year about this time in Essex Fells, after the first wintry gusts have swept the leaves off the trees and residents have gathered around to watch the annual lighting of the borough’s Christmas tree, a large pond off Fells Road turns into the borough’s meeting place.

headline: Perfectly Happy, Even Without Happy Endings
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: What Friedrich Nietzsche Did to America
text: In 1889, when Friedrich Nietzsche suffered the mental collapse that ended his career, he was virtually unknown. Yet by the time of his death in 1900 at the age of 55, he had become the philosophical celebrity of his age. From Russia to America, admirers echoed his estimation of himself as a titanic figure who could alter the course of history: “I am by far the most terrible human being that has existed so far; this does not preclude the possibility that I shall be the most beneficial.” His origins were humble for the role. The son of a small-town Lutheran minister, he steeped himself in classical literature while growing up in eastern Germany. When he was 24, he secured a professorship in Basel, Switzerland, and a few years later published his first book, “The Birth of Tragedy.” Against the common view of the ancient Greeks as the epitome of serene equipoise, Nietzsche emphasized the “Dionysian” excess and frenzy that complemented the “Apollonian” virtues of clarity and repose. The book’s success was limited, and its author was mocked by one leading classicist as an atavist run amok who should “gather tigers and panthers about his knees, but not the youth of Germany.”

headline: Michel Houellebecq’s Version of the American Thriller
text: Michel Houellebecq’s new novel is a weird air plant of a book: it feeds off atmosphere, rather than soil. The climate of “The Map and the Territory” is very still and very strange, as if something bad had just been detonated over it. The same bad thing may also have convulsed France, where the story is set, because Houellebecq’s Paris exists in a state of flagrant social breakdown and the countryside has become an emptied theme park of itself. This “was exactly what the world would look like,” a character thinks on entering a picturesque French village that only second-home-owners can afford to buy into, “after the explosion of an intergalactic neutron bomb.”

headline: Haunted by the Holocaust
text: Shalom Auslander is my kind of Jew — an unapologetically paranoid, guilt-ridden, self-loathing Diaspora kvetch, enraged by a God he can’t live with or without. While others of his generation may mine the tradition for a fond retrieval of forgotten lore, Auslander throws stones at the fiddler on the roof. He’s a black comic who’s alloyed the manic existential shtick of Lenny Bruce with the gallows humor that’s been a staple of the repertoire since the Babylonian Exile. In his two previous books, “Beware of God,” a collection of wickedly funny if not just plain wicked stories, and “Foreskin’s Lament,” a memoir that torched the bridges to his strict Orthodox heritage, he’s been relentlessly indicting the Hebrew God as a poor role model. In the process he’s made himself both celebrated and notorious: he is patently not good for the Jews.

headline: Current TV Finds a Good Number Within Its Tiny Ratings
text: Current TV’s audience is small — very small. The channel’s executives freely admit that in conversations, and will probably say so again on Friday when they hold a news conference with TV reporters gathered in Los Angeles.

headline: Kim Jong-il’s Romantic Rival
text: The title of Adam Johnson’s second novel is a bit misleading. Raised in the Long Tomorrows orphanage in Chongjin, North Korea, his protagonist believes himself to be the son of the Orphan Master rather than some kid dropped off by his desperate parents. But the primary evidence for this belief — “the unrelenting way the Orphan Master singled him out for punishment” — invites other interpretations. Like the rest of the boys, he is given a name from the list of the 114 Grand Martyrs of the Revolution that will mark him as an orphan for the rest of his life. Pak Jun Do (the given name Jun Do is a homonym of “John Doe”) is appropriate for a character with such a shifting identity, someone who will become both the perpetrator and the victim of countless crimes.

headline: In the Crossfire of the Mexican War on Drugs
text: MEXICO CITY

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A three-bedroom Cape in Norwalk, Conn., and a five-bedroom turreted contemporary in Brookville, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Lenox Hill two-bedroom, a Flatbush Avenue co-op and a Tudor City one-bedroom.

headline: Bookshelf: Presidents
text: GEORGE WASHINGTON’S BIRTHDAY  A Mostly True Tale.  By Margaret McNamara. Illustrated by Barry Blitt.  40 pp. Schwartz & Wade. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

headline: Seeking Wisdom From José Saramago
text: So much attention has been paid to “Pina,” Wim Wenders’s 3D homage to the choreographer Pina Bausch, that it’s easy to overlook another documentary that is also competing for the Academy Award for foreign-language film. “José and Pilar,” directed by Miguel Gonçalves Mendes, is Portugal’s submission, and it too comes with an impressive pedigree. Co-produced by the directors Pedro Almodóvar and Fernando Meirelles (“City of God”), it examines the relationship of love and support that sustains José Saramago, the Portuguese novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1998, and his wife, Pilar del Rio, as Saramago battled to write one last novel before his death in 2010 at the age of 87. Mr. Gonçalves Mendes, 33, is in the United States this month for festival showings of the film and spoke by telephone from Palm Springs. Here is an edited version of what he had to say:

headline: Image of the Day: January 13
text: Lohri celebrations in Amritsar, Punjab.

headline: Inside the List
text: THUNDERING TYPHOONS: Growing up, my brothers and I passed many happy days working our way through the “Tintin” comic books, sprawled on our floors with no concern for the stories’ literary or cultural status. We weren’t hipsters; we were kids. But we were also, apparently, in some kind of vanguard. Now that the Belgian Tintin is having a genuine American moment — a Spielberg movie; a newly translated biography of his creator, Hergé (reviewed next week); a place atop The New York Times’s graphic books best-seller list — we’re hearing that nobody but the elect was in on the secret back then. “Though beloved in most parts of the world,” Charles McGrath wrote in The Times recently, Tintin “is practically unknown in the United States.” Huh. It’s a little weird, finding out you were every bit as out of touch as you feared. While I wouldn’t go as far as the British critic Nicholas Lezard, who compared Spielberg’s film adaptation to a rape, it is disconcerting to see the icons of your youth being pawed at by the mainstream. Next thing you know, they’ll make a movie of the Smurfs.

headline: Mantle of Dreams Yields a Nightmare
text: GOGOL’S short story “The Overcoat” is both compact and richly metaphorical: a humble government clerk becomes a new man when he spends his life savings on a fine coat, but is destroyed when it is stolen. It’s a perfect combination for the movies, and the tale has been filmed many times, most notably by the Soviet experimental filmmakers Grigori Kozintsev and Leonid Trauberg in 1926, and by the Italian director Alberto Lattuada in 1952.

headline: The State of the City, in Your Words
text: Crumbling curb cuts in Rego Park. Yellow rivers in the East 70s. A neighborhood-sustaining tamale vendor at a South Bronx subway stop. Seeking a more granular supplement to the mayor’s sweeping State of the City address, we asked you for the State of your Block.

headline: Russian Tanker Within Miles of Alaska Town
text: Guided by a Coast Guard icebreaker, a Russian tanker carrying emergency fuel to the stranded Alaska town of Nome neared the coast on Friday, The Alaska Dispatch reported.

headline: Video of Skirmishes at Apple Store in Beijing
text: Updated | 7:00 p.m. As our colleague Sharon LaFraniere reports, crowds of would-be shoppers threw eggs and brawled in front of Apple’s flagship store in a tony neighborhood of Beijing on Friday after the store did not open as planned. The company later said in a statement that it had decided to suspend sale of its new iPhone 4S at five of its mainland stores for the safety of customers and employees.

headline: Jason Kidd on the Disappearing Triple-Double
text: On Jan. 1, Rajon Rondo of the Celtics had 18 points, 14 rebounds and 11 assists in a win over the Wizards. Of the 158 games this season, that is the only triple-double recorded so far.

headline: Gingrich Asks ‘Super PAC’ to Address Errors in Ad Against Romney
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Newt Gingrich called on the “super PAC” supporting him to edit or take down a 28-minute pseudodocumentary attacking Mitt Romney’s record at the investment firm Bain Capital after news media fact checkers found a number of inaccuracies.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers and the Return of ‘The Unwritten’
text: The manga list is in flux this week, with seven newcomers. They include regulars on the list, like the latest volume of “Naruto,” about the ninja in training, which lands at No. 1. The other series involve battles (“Yu-Gi-Oh GX,” at No. 2), pirates and treasures (“One Piece,” at No. 3), werewolves and vampires (“Rosario+Vampire,” Season II, at No. 4), a demon bridge (“Black Bird,” at No. 5), romance (“Skip Beat!,” at No. 6) and mourning (“Dengeki Daisy,” at No. 10).

headline: India Wins the Battle Against Polio
text: Today marks the first full year in India’s history when no new polio cases have been recorded, a milestone that just a few years ago seemed India might not reach.

headline: TimesCast | January 13, 2012
text: President Obama asks Congress for power to shrink government | Explaining "super PACs" | Previewing the Golden Globe Awards.

headline: Romney Moves to Blunt Santorum Surge in South Carolina
text: WASHINGTON — Can Rick Santorum surge again, this time in South Carolina?

headline: For the Warriors, Ellis Proves Essential
text: On Thursday night, the “Hack-a-Dwight” strategy became less of an occasional tactic and more of a general basketball philosophy. In desperation because of Kwame Brown’s injury and Andris Biedrins’ foul trouble, Golden State Warriors Coach Mark Jackson employed a game-long plan of intentionally fouling Dwight Howard, a notoriously poor free throw shooter who was otherwise destroying Golden State’s interior defense.

headline: Kate Foster and Sean Hogue
text: AS freshmen at Missouri State University, Kate Foster and Sean Hogue had a whirlwind romance that quickly led to serious talk about marriage. They are still very young, Ms. Foster is 21 now and Mr. Hogue 22, yet their lives have been tempered by disaster — the tornado that devastated Joplin, Mo., last May and destroyed Ms. Foster’s home.

headline: Balotelli’s Pit Stop
text: Manchester City’s Mario Balotelli been called everything from mercurial to daft. One thing is for certain, he knows how to draw a crowd on and off the soccer field.

headline: Ford Recalls 450,000 Vehicles in Two Separate Actions
text: According to documents filed earlier this week with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Ford is recalling about 450,000 minivans and crossovers in two actions.

headline: Industry’s Green Shoots Blossom Into Optimism
text: DETROIT

headline: New Pro-Santorum Ad Touts His Conservative Credentials
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — A “super PAC” supporting the candidacy of Rick Santorum, whose presence was nowhere to be seen on South Carolina television until last week, is quickly catching up to many of its better-funded rivals.

headline: In Iraq Cemetery, Living Among the Dead
text: BAGHDAD — The largest cemetery in the restive province of Diyala has more than 20,000 graves, some date back as far as 1600 A.D., and covers more than a mile and a half of land.

headline: The Rise of the New Groupthink
text: SOLITUDE is out of fashion. Our companies, our schools and our culture are in thrall to an idea I call the New Groupthink, which holds that creativity and achievement come from an oddly gregarious place. Most of us now work in teams, in offices without walls, for managers who prize people skills above all. Lone geniuses are out. Collaboration is in.

headline: Attention: New Official Ed Board Position
text: Coming up with editorial positions for The New York Times is serious and arduous work. Board members agonize over the big issues and consult precedents that, unlike Chief Justice John Roberts, we cannot simply ignore.

headline: Vintry Fine Wines Taps a Fabled Collection
text: A bottle of reasonably priced red to enjoy with dinner is stock-in-trade at most wine shops, including Vintry Fine Wines in Battery Park City. But this sleek, well-lighted new store, with eye-level displays of about 2,500 bottles, including 85 Champagnes and 24 kosher wines, goes well beyond the everyday.

headline: Colbert to Advertise in South Carolina
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Real presidential candidates have real television ads. And now so does Stephen Colbert.

headline: Hostess Has a Lot of Debt, but Few in Finance
text: Hostess Brands is back in bankruptcy again, arguing that its last filing did not really accomplish all that much, despite taking a rather long time.

headline: 4 Marines in Video With Dead Taliban Are Identified
text: WASHINGTON — The United States Marine Corps has identified the four Marines shown in a video urinating on what appear to be dead Taliban fighters, without releasing any names, and has named a lead investigating officer to decide whether they should be charged, Marine officials said Friday.

headline: Catfight Among Dog-Lovers
text: In this past issue’s Ethicist column, I featured two pet-related questions. And if there’s one thing that the Most E-mailed List proves, time and time again, it’s that New York Times readers &#9829 pet stories. Accordingly, the column generated a bumper crop of reader comments and e-mails.

headline: French Swimmer’s Fire Resurfaces in Alabama
text: AUBURN, Ala. — To find the athlete known as the French Mermaid, follow the trail of painted orange tiger paw prints. In this Southern college town, far from her French roots, Laure Manaudou, a triple medalist at the 2004 Summer Olympics, has rediscovered her passion for swimming.

headline: Jan. 15 — 21
text: Theater

headline: Romney Makes Appeal to South Carolina Evangelicals
text: As conservative Christian leaders struggle to coalesce behind a single candidate of the religious right, the Romney campaign has put out a radio ad in South Carolina that in essence asks the evangelical leaders, “Why not me?”

headline: Just One Look | Alexander Wang
text: It’s hard to believe that Alexander Wang, just 28 years old, is presenting his 19th collection. Building off of signature concepts — cutouts, cool-girl black and the use of technical fabrics — Wang’s prefall collection is heavy on the separates; a study in wearable sportswear, akin to that of the 1990s. Pops of maroon (on a printed sheer dress) and a greenish mustard (on a ruched skirt dress) emerge among all of the black, white and gray, carrying over into accessories. A soon to be coveted pointy-toe heel with mesh detailing and tight ankle strap demonstrates Wang’s ability to evolve ideas from one season to the next. (Have a look at his spring shoes and tell us there isn’t a resemblance.) Clarity arrives in the form of a skirt suit bearing the collection’s defining trompe l’oeil plaid.

headline: Federal Contractor Monitored Social Network Sites
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security paid a contractor in 2009 to monitor social networking sites — like Facebook, blogs and reader comments on a news article — to see how the residents of Standish, Mich., were reacting to a proposal to move detainees from Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to a local prison there, according to newly disclosed documents.

headline: Defining Who Can Invest in Private Offerings
text: In the years before the financial crisis, private offerings of stock held much allure. They often offered outsize returns, but only to those who seemed to have the inside track.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $22,375,000
text: A town house on Central Park West that comes with its own 60-foot lap pool and that sold for $22.375 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city public records.

headline: Photo Replay: January 13
text: A collection of photos from the day in sports, including shots from the Sydney International tennis tournament and World Cup downhill skiing.

headline: TimesCast | Merging Agencies
text: January 13, 2012 - President Obama asks Congress for greater authority to shrink the federal government.

headline: As a Broader Group Seeks Early Admission, Rejections Rise in the East
text: Early admission to top colleges, once the almost exclusive preserve of the East Coast elite, is now being pursued by a much broader and more diverse group of students, including foreigners and minorities.

headline: Shell’s Arctic Drilling Plan Clears Hurdle
text: Royal Dutch Shell has been on a six-year crusade to drill in Arctic waters off Alaska’s coast, and has spent about $4 billion on the effort so far without drilling a single well.

headline: Warm Lentil and Smoked Pork Belly Salad
text: Time: About 1 hour

headline: A Lentil, That Object of Desire
text: A FRENCH cook I know, who tends to be rather philosophical, is always saying that cooking (and everything else) is all about desire. And there’s no explaining desire.

headline: Procter & Gamble to Extend Mother-Centric Campaign at Olympics
text: Procter & Gamble, the giant marketer of household staples, will expand a popular advertising campaign around the world in connection with its sponsorship of the 2012 Summer Olympics.

headline: Apple Lists Its Suppliers for 1st Time
text: Apple released a list of its major suppliers for the first time on Friday, bringing the company up to par with other big American corporations, including Hewlett-Packard, Intel and Nike, which have released similar lists.

headline: We’ll Always Have Lentils
text: I spent a recent holiday in Paris appreciating some of the simple things the French do so well. No, not foie gras and Champagne, but rather humbler products, like cured pork and lentils. Nearly every butcher shop sells brined pork (called demi-sel or petit salé), ready to take home and simmer. On a shelf nearby is a box of lentils, usually the certified lentilles du Puy, arguably the best lentils in the world. Cooked together, they are a classic combination, not fancy at all but uncommonly good.

headline: Save the Date, but Watch the Movie First
text: AT first, it looked like any other e-mail. But when friends and relatives of Katharine Wentz and Christopher Mazza clicked on the Vimeo video link inside the message, they were treated to a “save the date” show.

headline: For ’50/50’s’ Writer, the Hardest Part Was the Drama
text: If the gang from “Bridesmaids” was dancing around the line between comedy and emotional honesty, the filmmakers behind “50/50” were stomping on it. The film, inspired by the screenwriter Will Reiser’s real-life story of being given a cancer diagnosis in his mid-20s, treats its subject matter as he did in real life: as dreadfully serious and dreadfully funny. It has been earning some nominations and prizes for its screenplay – and some good-natured ribbing from Mr. Reiser’s friend Seth Rogen, who starred as the best friend and served as a producer with his writing partner, Evan Goldberg.

headline: Photographing Photographers
text: Abe Frajndlich turned the camera on celebrated subjects who were usually behind it.

headline: Photographing Photographers
text: IN the fall of 1970 I arrived at Minor White’s house for a live-in workshop. My first task was to organize his photography library. I was mesmerized by the unforgettable images. Photography has had a relatively short history, and I was struck by the fact that most of the practitioners were anonymous and unknown except to a minuscule circle. Unconsciously I must have started to dream of changing that fact, and widening that circle. More than four decades later, this work is the fruition of that dream.

headline: Crosby Takes First Step in Second Concussion Comeback
text: Sidney Crosby skated Friday, his first time on ice since experiencing a recurrence of concussion symptoms after a game Dec. 5. After the Penguins’ morning skate in Sunrise, Fla., he skated for 27 minutes and sounded afterward like a player whose return to the lineup is far from imminent.

headline: Ex-Official at S.E.C. Settles Case for $50,000
text: WASHINGTON — A former enforcement official for the Securities and Exchange Commission who was accused of blocking or closing at least three investigations into the activities of the Stanford Financial Group, which the authorities claim was a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, has settled civil charges brought by the Justice Department accusing him of violating conflict-of-interest rules by later representing Stanford before the commission.

headline: Sweet, Gooey and an Icon
text: ON the list of happy childhood memories, the Hostess Twinkie occupies a lofty position. Since the 1930s, it has represented the summit of the pastry maker’s art for untold millions of American children seduced by its loaf-shaped golden sponge cake, soft yet springy, and voluptuous vanilla cream filling.

headline: TimesCast | What's A 'Super PAC'?
text: January 13, 2012 - A viewer sent TimesCast a question via Twitter about the role of super PACs in the Republican primaries.

headline: Beyond Apple Pie
text: This week Martha Rose Shulman encourages home cooks to get more creative with apples, taking her recipes beyond traditional dishes like applesauce and apple pie. She also encourages home chefs to leave the skin on when possible.

headline: TPG Is Said to Consider $1 Billion Investment in Olympus
text: TPG Capital is weighing a potential investment in the Olympus Corporation of Japan, in which it would join with a strategic partner to invest as much as $1 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Financial Advice for Those With Small Nest Eggs
text: When Merrill Lynch recently discouraged its thundering herd of brokers from taking on new clients with under $250,000 in assets available for investing, it wasn’t a big surprise.

headline: Mourning in a Digital Age
text: I HAVE found myself in a season of loss. Every few weeks for the last six months, friends in the prime of life have suffered the death of a close family member. These deaths included a mother, a father, a sister, a brother, a spouse and, in one particularly painful case, a teenage child who died on Christmas morning.
