headline: Heart Surgery Is Planned for Edwards; Trial Delayed
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — The criminal trial of former Senator John Edwards has been delayed until at least March because he has a life-threatening heart ailment that requires surgery, a federal judge said Friday.

headline: Newt Gingrich Confronts His Super PAC
text: I have to give Newt Gingrich some credit for asking a super PAC that works on his behalf, Winning our Future, to correct or pull a “documentary” attacking Mitt Romney.

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 13
text: Subjects include the expansion of Terminal 4 at JFK, an overturned houseboat in the Bronx, and the mayor’s State of the City address.

headline: Kate Foster and Sean Hogue — Vows
text: The couple’s wedding, at the First Presbyterian Church in downtown Joplin on Dec. 30, could perhaps be seen as a symbol of the city’s resilience.

headline: Big-Dollar Estimates at Scottsdale
text: FOR several years, the collector car market has had a split personality. Great blue-chip cars have found eager bidders paying record prices at auction, while cars a notch below have often gone wanting. The gulf in dollars separating the best and the rest has continued to widen.

headline: LearnVest, Merrill Edge and Financial Planning for the Middle Class
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I return to a topic that I’ve come at in various ways in recent years: The question of how the merely middle class and semi-affluent among us can get good, ethical, reasonably priced financial advice without having to watch our backs and our wallets.

headline: Wyoming Resort Will Take Ski Passes From Anywhere
text: While many North American ski resorts are suffering from a lack of early-season snowfall, some, like Grand Targhee in Wyoming, have enough to share.

headline: He’s a Quarterback, He’s a Winner, He’s a TV Draw, He’s a Verb
text: On Saturday night in Massachusetts, a Jim Thorpe-Fabio hybrid in a New England Patriots uniform will emerge from the Foxborough shadows with all the confidence granted by good looks, athletic gifts and the home-field advantage: Tom Brady, the quarterback ideal. A three-time Super Bowl champion. Married to a world-famous model. So laserlike in his throws that he could hit the 11 bus in Boston, 30 miles away — in the numbers.

headline: Evaluating Feedback on Fracking Rules
text: As I reported in Thursday’s paper, New York State environmental regulators are sorting through more than 20,000 public comments as they develop the final rules for high-volume hydraulic fracturing, the much-debated process to extract natural gas from underground shale formations.

headline: Walt Disney Studios Quickly Fills Chief Marketing Post
text: Walt Disney Studios on Friday named a Hollywood veteran to lead its worldwide marketing and publicity efforts: Ricky Strauss, the president of Participant Media, a progressive-minded production company with credits like “The Help” and the documentary “An Inconvenient Truth.”

headline: A Return for a Noble, Promethean Climb
text: If one word could summarize the performance of Bruckner’s Eighth Symphony that the conductor Zubin Mehta delivered with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, the likeliest would be “noble.” For nearly as long as Mr. Mehta has been in the public eye — more than 50 years now — he has shown a clear affinity for Bruckner, whose Promethean symphonies require an intensity and focus that do not come easily to every conductor.

headline: Previewing the Golden Globes and More
text: The workweek may be coming to a close, but with the Golden Globes on Sunday, Hollywood is clocking some overtime. Before then, we offer these awards odds and ends:

headline: More Climate Messages from Beyond the ‘Nerd Loop’
text: Regular readers of Dot Earth will know I’m a fan of Randy Olson, the author of “Don’t Be Such a Scientist” and maker of offbeat, provocative films, including “Sizzle.” After my post the other day looking at a Norwegian effort to use a man walking a leashed dog to illustrate the difference between trend and variation, I got in touch with Olson afresh, both to get his reaction to that animation and talk more generally about ways to get beyond what he calls “the nerd loop” in climate communication. Here’s the resulting Q&A:

headline: Prince Fielder Leads the Unsigned All-Stars
text: Scott Boras does not get everything he seeks in every negotiation. But it is wise not to doubt him. This is the agent who persuaded teams to give seven-year, $126 million contracts to Barry Zito and Jayson Werth, and persuaded another to hand not one, but two player options to Rafael Soriano.

headline: Links for the New Year
text: There’s something so inoffensive and old-fashioned about saying “happy new year” that makes it incredibly pleasurable. You can say it with warmth, genuine-ness, sincerity and with a profound lack of irony. I love it. So let me be the last to say “happy new year” everyone.

headline: Defriending My Rapist
text: Facebook suggested I friend him. I guess our social networks overlapped. I guided the mouse toward his photo, and the little pointed hand hovered over his face. Fear and anger swelled up but curiosity won out and I clicked “Add Friend.” He accepted within minutes. Stunned, I wondered if he had forgotten raping me, or if he thought I had.

headline: Seeking a Wider Audience
text: Many American-branded cars at the Detroit auto show reflected global design influences.

headline: It Can Be So Hard to Save the World When Those Hormones Kick In
text: While the frenzy for “Downton Abbey” runs its course, two new series remind us that not all television imports from Britain and its former dominions are so genteel.

headline: Avant-Garde Arts Space Inaugurates New Home, Finally
text: Four years ago Issue Project Room, an avant-garde arts space that has had several homes in Manhattan and Brooklyn, hit a kind of real estate jackpot: a 20-year, rent-free lease on 5,000 square feet in a McKim, Mead & White building in downtown Brooklyn. The catch: the tiny group would be responsible for $3.6 million in renovations and improvements.

headline: Russian Ad Compares Putin Foe to Hitler
text: While Republican voters in South Carolina are being warned in a new ad not to trust Mitt Romney because, “like John Kerry, he speaks French,” politicking in Russia, where a new president will be elected in March, is a good deal less subtle.

headline: ‘Old School’ Logos
text: According to this definition of the term “old school,” I was a child when anything I could technically consider “old school” came into existence. It’s certainly a part of everyone’s vocabulary, but for me it’s a word that especially permeates sports culture in regard to team logos and uniforms. It often means one thing: quality.

headline: Former U.S. Diplomat Rattles Taiwan Before Election
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — In a closely fought election rife with verbal attacks and partisan rancor, the comments of a foreign academic with no official government position might normally be subsumed by the storm and stress of the campaign.

headline: Lead Rajaratnam Prosecutor to Join Dechert
text: The lead prosecutor in the insider-trading case against Raj Rajaratnam is leaving the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan and joining the law firm Dechert as a partner in its white-collar criminal defense practice.

headline: A Fairy Tale Princess Who Takes Bathroom Breaks
text: The toying with expectations essential to an Ann Liv Young production starts before the show. Her reputation precedes her. Even if you’ve never witnessed the verbal abuse, vulgarity, nudity, masturbation, urination or defecation in her previous projects, you’ve almost certainly heard of her predilections. She assumes you have.

headline: Canadiens Trade Cammalleri in a Flash
text: There are some strange things, and a lot of losing, going down in Montreal, and Canadiens fans are in an uproar.

headline: Showtime Plans Cheney Documentary, as Producers Reach Out to Wyoming
text: Last month, ads started running in The Casper Star-Tribune in Wyoming asking for photographs and video of the former Vice President Dick Cheney, who represented the state in Congress and still maintains a home there.

headline: Canadian Pacific Rival Warns Ex-Chief to Stay Away From Ackman
text: 6:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: Antidepressant Use Linked to Increased Pulmonary Hypertension Risk in Infants
text: A study published in the British Medical Journal this week provides stronger evidence that taking some antidepressants during pregnancy doubles the risk of a baby developing pulmonary hypertension. Researchers have long suspected a link between the use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.’s, and the condition, but previous studies have been small and inconclusive (with results ranging from there being no link to a six times greater risk).

headline: Motorcycle-Auction Tripleheader Comes to Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS — A restored, fully operational 1920 Henderson Four Model K was the top sale Thursday at the Auctions America by RM event at the Rio Las Vegas Hotel and Casino, as a three-day, three-auction marathon kicked off at three locations here. Including a 12 percent sales commission, the Henderson changed hands for $50,960, slightly below its preauction estimate.

headline: CBS Tramples the Competition
text: CBS once again managed to dominate prime time among the broadcast networks on Thursday night, easily taking first place in all ratings categories. According to Nielsen, a very large percentage of the 15.9 million people who watched “Big Bang Theory” stayed put and sampled the series premiere of “Rob.” Although that comedy has been poorly received critically, it drew 13.5 million viewers. The new drama “Person of Interest” also did well as it posted its best numbers ever and reached 14.7 million people.

headline: Israel Says Sanctions Hurt Iran
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said in an interview published Saturday that new economic sanctions aimed at stopping Iran’s contentious nuclear program appeared to be having an effect and, if combined with a threat of military action led by the United States, could succeed.

headline: Just One Look | Louis Vuitton
text: The Louis Vuitton prefall collection is an absolute delight. Rounded silhouettes on coats, cap-sleeved baby-doll dresses in peach and yellow and a return of the beloved Stephen Sprouse leopard in blue/navy on a smart suit, all possess the same whimsy we saw at Marc Jacobs’s most recent spring collection. Star accessories include grommeted berets and sharp heels — kitten-height and higher — with shiny steel-toe tips. Fur is sprinkled liberally throughout, on coat pockets, collars and shoes (making feet look like puppy paws; it’s quite fun). Here, a dress with the collection’s signature Sgt. Pepper’s trompe l’oeil gets a pop of pretty pink.

headline: Coney Island, Jan. 3, 1915
text: The Library of Congress has been gradually posting to Flickr its trove of more than 40,000 photos from the Bain Collection, comprising the surviving photos of the Bain News Service, a photo agency founded by George Grantham Bain that flourished in the early 20th century.

headline: Eight Men In: Wearing Giants Blue, Ready for Green Bay
text: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team — a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen — traveled to Lambeau Field for Sunday’s showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It was a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men — they were joined by two pals in Milwaukee — agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes were to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

headline: If They Had Their Choice
text: IT’S anybody’s guess which dresses will make a splash at the Golden Globes on Sunday night. But a handful of top Hollywood stylists weighed in with their nominations for the looks they would most like to see on the red carpet.

headline: Another Weekly Roundup, as News Picks Up in F1’s Off-Season
text: Early into the new year and the Formula One news is picking up again little by little, especially from Italy where the Ferrari team held its annual Christmas company event, called Wrooom, in Madonna di Campiglio, this week.

headline: Another Weekly Roundup, as News Picks Up in F1’s Off-Season
text: Early into the new year and the Formula One news is picking up again little by little, especially from Italy where the Ferrari team held its annual Christmas company event, called Wrooom, in Madonna di Campiglio, this week.

headline: Hollywood’s Power Stylists
text: As insiders see it, the investment is worthwhile: the right red-carpet turnout can help a performer change lanes.

headline: Gingrich, Perry, Santorum and Huntsman Lose Virginia Ballot Fight
text: A federal judge in Virginia on Friday denied Rick Perry, Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum and Jon M. Huntsman Jr. spots on the state’s presidential primary ballot.

headline: Under the Radar Festival: 5 Questions About ‘The Past Is a Grotesque Animal’
text: Ten years in the lives of three couples in Argentina spin, quite slowly, in “El Pasado Es un Animal Grotesco” (“The Past Is a Grotesque Animal”), from the Argentine writer and director Mariano Pensotti. The piece, making its U.S. premiere in a co-production of the Coil and Under the Radar festivals, features actors performing on a slowly rotating set to a soundtrack that includes music from the band Of Montreal.

headline: It’s Winter, So Here Come the Sneaker Ads
text: The early days of winter may seem an odd time to bring out new athletic footwear, but there are some good reasons: for one, millions of consumers have vowed to exercise more in the new year; for another, there are lots of sports events on TV that draw big audiences filled with shoe buyers.

headline: Owner as Regulator, Like Oil and Water
text: Let’s say you’re the biggest owner of a global auto company. You take the company’s flagship new vehicle, twist it, crash it, poke it and leave it outside in the elements for weeks until its battery catches fire. Then you generate a storm of publicity and watch the share price and the value of your ownership stake decline.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: The Power Stylists of Hollywood
text: EVERY red carpet has its head-turners, dresses that captivate, spark style trends, and celebrate turning points in a star’s career. Much the same can be expected when the Golden Globes unfurl the crimson runner on NBC on Sunday night. In past seasons the looks on parade at this annual glam fest helped cement reputations and jump-start careers.

headline: In France, the Pain of Rating Downgrade Is Especially Acute
text: Among the European countries that Standard & Poor’s declared less creditworthy on Friday, France stands out among the tarnished.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iran, Kuwait, Myanmar and New York.

headline: Opening science and doing it yourself; plus the malaria medicine of Chairman Mao
text: Opening science and doing it yourself; plus the malaria medicine of Chairman Mao

headline: Menendez Drops His Opposition to Obama’s Pick for a Federal Appeals Court
text: Reversing himself in what had become an awkward intraparty stalemate for Democrats, Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey said Friday that he would no longer block President Obama’s nominee to a federal appeals court.

headline: A Crow Appears to Find a Source of Winter Sport
text: This video provides a calming capstone to a frenetic week. It is evidently a hooded crow*, apparently in Russia (post if you know for sure), and almost assuredly shows a bird at play (note the multiple tracks in the rooftop snow from earlier “snowboarding” trips):

headline: Two People, One Identity
text: IN person, the identical twins Kirk and Nate Mueller are an uncanny sight. The neatly coiffed hair, the ASOS leather boots, the red lapel flowers from Hook & Albert, the brown wool Topman suits — everything about them is almost exactly the same. Even their jobs: designing sleek iPad apps and Web sites, which has made them overnight design celebrities.

headline: Class Warfare
text: If Mitt Romney had his way, we’d only talk about income inequality in “quiet rooms”—I’m picturing wood-paneling and cigar smoke. If Rick Santorum had his way, we wouldn’t even use the term “middle class” since, apparently, “there are no classes in America.” Middle-income people, maybe, he says, but no middle-class people.

headline: What Did You Expect? It Makes a Difference
text: MY father recently had his second knee operation in a year. The first time, things went poorly. His rehabilitation was difficult and months later, he still could not walk well or, even more important to him, play tennis.

headline: Top Hops to Open, With 700 Beers
text: An arms race seems to have sprung up among the new breed of beer stores that specialize in imports and craft labels. If one offers 250 different brews, the next stockpiles 400. Now, Ted Kenny, a former beer salesman, is raising the ante with at least 700, including 20 on tap, at Top Hops Beer Shop, the new store he plans to open Saturday on the Lower East Side.

headline: Some Teachers Skeptical of Merit Pay
text: Teachers call in to WNYC's Brian Lehrer Show in response to the mayor's State of the City address.  Many of them, says the host, told WNYC that the idea of merit pay was "good in theory, wouldn't work in practice.''

headline: Teachers Union Calls for Renewed Contract Negotiations
text: A day after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he would circumvent the teachers union to create his own teacher evaluation process, the union is trying to force the city back to the negotiation table.

headline: Uh, Uh, Uh ... He’s Nearly Got It
text: Keith Hennessy was quaking in his underwear, wobbling atop a tall stack of foam blocks when he said, “I’m doing this on purpose.” It was near the end of “Almost,” his improvisational performance at the Abrons Arts Center on Thursday, part of the American Realness festival. A moment before, having ad-libbed his way into that precarious position, he had said, dryly, “There’s a load of possibilities here.”

headline: Chic in Review | William and Kate’s +1
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Lynne Ramsay Is Back. Finally.
text: Back in 2002, Lynne Ramsay was a film director on the verge. Her second feature, the gorgeous, impressionistic drama ‘‘Morvern Callar,’’ made its debut at Cannes and grabbed the attention of serious moviegoers; in The Times, the critic Elvis Mitchell called it ‘‘one of the most important pictures’’ of the year. Meanwhile, a dark first novel that Ramsay was preparing to adapt and direct surprised the publishing world by landing at the top of The New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Fighting Antipiracy Measure, Activist Group Posts Personal Information of Media Executives
text: The online activist group known as Anonymous, which has targeted opponents of the Occupy Wall Street movement and businesses that stopped providing services to WikiLeaks, has set its sights on a new adversary: media executives.

headline: Latest Conservative No-No: Speaking French
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Newt Gingrich, parlez-vous français?

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 13
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Trinidadian Gets Life Sentence in J.F.K. Bomb Plot
text: A Trinidadian man who was convicted of plotting to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport was sentenced Friday to life in prison.

headline: Anthony Roth Costanzo to Replace David Daniels at the Met
text: Anthony Roth Costanzo will step into the counter-tenor role of Prospero in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “The Enchanted Island” on Saturday evening. He will replace David Daniels, who is ill, the Met said. Mr. Costanzo is cast as Ferdinand in the opera, and will be replaced in that part by Jeffrey Mandelbaum. The switch also occurred in Act II of Thursday’s performance.

headline: Council Leader Offers Compromise on Wage
text: After months of heated debate over whether New York City should mandate a so-called living wage for workers in city-subsidized projects, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, unveiled a proposal on Friday that would raise wages for some workers in such projects.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Nietzsche Bewitches America and the Science of Middle Age
text: In this Sunday’s Book Review, Alexander Star reviews a new book about the reactions of Americans to the powerful and controversial work of the philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. Mr. Star writes:

headline: Nine Euro Countries’ Ratings Are Cut
text: On Friday, Standard & Poor’s cut the ratings on nine of the 17 European countries that use the euro currency. France and Austria lost their coveted AAA ratings, which were lowered one notch to AA+, and Italy and Spain had their ratings cut by two notches. Germany, Finland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands all retained their AAA status, while the ratings of Portugal and Cyprus were cut to junk.

headline: Reviewing the 2012 Detroit Auto Show
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich, Phil Patton and Paul Stenquist take the measure of the 2012 Detroit auto show, which is scheduled to open to the public this weekend, and where media previews concluded on Tuesday.

headline: A Sacrifice Just May Reduce a Potential Loss
text: Weeklong regional tournaments take place several times a month around the country. The popular Orlando Regional ran from Jan. 2 to 8.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 13
text: More Photographs

headline: An Artist’s Big, Big Plans for Red Hook
text: THE artist Dustin Yellin likes big things. The jawbone of a sperm whale hangs in his studio. His most recent sculpture weighs more than 12 tons. And in June, he became the owner of the former Time Moving and Storage building, a 24,000-square-foot Civil War-era warehouse in Red Hook, Brooklyn, for which he paid $3.7 million.

headline: The Subjective Face of the Death Penalty
text: To the Editor:

headline: Past, Present and Future, All at Once
text: In proclaiming “the emancipation of the dissonance” in a 1926 essay, Arnold Schoenberg meant to justify in historical terms his move from functional harmony toward free atonality and, ultimately, a new 12-tone system of composition. Despite his radical innovations Schoenberg never forfeited his inheritance altogether; a dialogue among past, present and future is precisely what animates his work.

headline: Brooklyn Billboard Topples Onto Expressway
text: Watch a video of the billboard collapse, taken by a security camera, on the Web site of the Polish-language newspaper Nowy Dziennik, about 25 seconds into the newscast.

headline: They Came to Hear Mahler, Not an iPhone
text: To the Editor:

headline: Animal Antibiotics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lazard Names Head of Restructuring
text: Lazard announced on Friday that it had named David Kurtz as its global head of restructuring, bringing new leadership to the investment banking industry’s biggest corporate reorganization and bankruptcy team.

headline: Japan’s Problems
text: To the Editor:

headline: Investing in Head Start
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rocky Hollywood Road Leads Directors Back to Sundance
text: LOS ANGELES — Spike Lee is on the spot. Next week Mr. Lee, the celebrated director of movies like “She’s Gotta Have It” and “Inside Man,” will find himself in a situation he has never been in before: at the Sundance Film Festival, crossing his fingers along with more than 100 other directors hoping for a bite from a distributor.

headline: Bluegrass That Takes the A Train Uptown
text: “This is our first show north of 14th Street,” the mandolinist Chris Thile announced as his bluegrass duo with Michael Daves on guitar started its American Songbook series concert on Thursday night at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Allen Room. They’ve been playing small club shows downtown, and they brought that informality to the Allen Room, punctuating dazzling virtuosity with bluegrass-aficionado banter and “Fiddle Tune Request Time.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Victorian Human Skulls and a Plagiarism Problem
text: Interesting things that reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: A Place Repurchased, and Recast
text: DINERS accustomed to the taste of sticky takeout stir-fry dishes thickened with corn starch and bludgeoned with soy sauce are in for a surprise when they visit Gem Cuisines of China. Here a menu of beautifully balanced dishes will remind them of the infinite variety and subtlety of this great cuisine. Whether peppery, bold, heady or delicate, the dishes offered at Gem reflect the latest in the evolution of China’s culinary arts.

headline: Did Hollywood’s Home Viewing Revenue Fall Further Than First Thought?
text: 8:22 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES — In a report issued on Friday, the analysts at Nomura Equity Research take issue with an only somewhat downbeat assessment from the Digital Entertainment Group, an industry alliance, of United States home entertainment revenue in 2011.

headline: Getting Their Picture Taken, and Taking a Few Themselves
text: LOS ANGELES — If you can judge someone’s star power by the quantity of greetings and congratulations they get at a party – and in Hollywood, you can – the folks from “The Artist” are riding high. At the Critics’ Choice Awards on Thursday and the American Film Institute luncheon today, they were inundated with well-wishers, from Brad Grey, chairman of Paramount, to Sacha Baron Cohen.

headline: Shorter, Modern and Less Than Opera
text: The creative impetus behind “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess,” the adaptation of the classic 1935 opera that opened at the Richard Rodgers Theater on Thursday, was to make the work more accessible, fresh and realistic for today’s musical theater audiences. In a New York Times article last August, before the production was introduced at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., Audra McDonald, who portrays Bess, said “none of us wanted to do a ‘Porgy and Bess’ where the audience would sit back comfortably and just, ahhhhhhh, soak in the big gems from the Gershwin score.”

headline: Forget About a Paper Moon: This Swan’s Cardboard
text: The man sits inside the dubious shelter of his little cardboard shack, staring out at strangers. The strangers stare back. His body makes little twitches. The palm tree and giant swan, also cardboard, are slowly wilting, as is his roof. It has been raining, and hard, for a long time now.

headline: Film’s Oddballs Reunite for a Small-Screen Makeover
text: Has it really been only seven and a half years since “Napoleon Dynamite” was in theaters? It seems longer, perhaps because so many geeky antiheroes have followed Napoleon onto our screens, or perhaps because the film’s deadpan humor was so vaporous that it seemed to vanish as you watched.

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 13
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the expansion of Terminal 4 at Kennedy International Airport, an overturned houseboat in the Bronx and the mayor’s State of the City address.

headline: Breaching the Border Between Pop and Opera
text: To hear Paulo Szot apply his heroic baritone to “If Ever I Would Leave You,” Sir Lancelot’s oratorical love song from “Camelot,” is to hear a flowery list of sweet nothings transformed into sweet somethings by the sheer force of delivery. Its blandishments include a description of “lips red as flame” and a “face with a luster that puts gold to shame.” There was a time when such flattery might get a dedicated suitor well beyond first base. Nowadays, Alan Jay Lerner’s rhetoric sounds so artificial that a strikeout seems more likely.

headline: Man Convicted in Terrorism Conspiracy Is Denied New Trial
text: A federal judge in Manhattan has refused to grant a new trial to a man convicted in 1995 of conspiring to blow up New York landmarks and of the murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane.

headline: It Needs a Good Beat, and a Star’s Endorsement
text: The International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week offered thousands of novel gadgets and high-tech products like remote-controlled indoor helicopters, ultrathin computer glass and refrigerators that play Pandora.

headline: How Dry We Aren’t
text: MAYOR Michael R. Bloomberg has made it clear that he wants New Yorkers to smoke less, eat healthier food, and now, according to The New York Post, also cut back on excessive drinking.

headline: Mississippi: Barbour Defends Pardons
text: As the uproar over his last-minute grants of clemency continued, former Gov. Haley Barbour showed no sign of backing down on Friday, giving a news conference and appearing on Fox News. Mr. Barbour, a Republican whose second term ended this week, described himself as “very comfortable” with the decision to grant clemency, and mostly full pardons, to 215 convicts in his last days in office. He emphasized that 189 of the convicts were not in prison, and that half of the others were given suspended sentences for medical reasons. He said the tradition of granting clemency was “rooted in the Christian idea of giving second chances.”

headline: Beneath a Deeply Silly Campaign, a Deeply Serious Performer
text: Stephen Colbert teasing South Carolina about a run for the presidency is becoming one of America’s great political traditions, right up there with awkward photographs of candidates eating corn dogs at the Iowa State Fair.

headline: Decisions, Decisions
text: I’ve played for many teams in my soccer career and won some significant championships, but it seems I’m still searching for my home.

headline: Super PACs Explained!
text: Earlier today, I wrote about Newt Gingrich and the “super PAC” supporting him that is running an attack “documentary” on Mitt Romney.

headline: Fifteen Minutes Faster and Four Years Wiser
text: HOUSTON — At the 2008 Olympic marathon trials, Desiree Davila reached Mile 22 in fourth place, eight or nine seconds out of third, the final qualifying spot. When she attempted to hit the accelerator, though, she instead hit the brakes.

headline: A Champion of France’s Downtrodden, With Limits of His Own
text: MONTPELLIER, France FIVE seat belts strapped Jean-Christophe Parisot to his seat in a van on his way to a desolate Roma neighborhood in this city in southern France. A home care aide carefully stabilized his head and held a telephone to his ear.

headline: An Interview With Jeremy Langmead
text: The editor-in-chief of mrporter.com discusses how his site combines editorial content with commerce and the future of online retailing.

headline: Reprehensible Behavior Is a Risk of Combat, Experts Say
text: Talk to almost anyone who has fought in combat, and chances are they can tick off a string of reasons why the YouTube video showing four Marines urinating on the bodies of dead enemy fighters in southern Afghanistan is horrible. Horrible for America’s image around the world. Horrible for its strategy of winning support from the Afghan people. Horrible for a professional military that believes its troops behave with the utmost decorum, even in the heat of battle.

headline: Honoring the Struggles and Sacrifices
text: Jessica Ingram still recalls the summer day a decade ago when she stood at Court Square Fountain in Montgomery, Ala., taking in the details spelled out in historical markers. There, near the State Capitol, she read that the square was the site of the city’s slave market. That none of the men, women or children had been given last names. How much they fetched.

headline: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?
text: Back in the late-1950s there was a TV show called “The Millionaire” about a mysterious rich man, named John Beresford Tipton, who would anonymously give checks for $1 million to total strangers.

headline: Defense Once Won Titles, but Score Has Changed
text: As the Pittsburgh Steelers, their top-ranked defense shredded by one of the N.F.L.’s worst passers, trudged into the off-season and a cold Denver night last Sunday, it was tempting to wonder if they might someday be viewed as a relic from a fading era.

headline: Marlene on the Phone
text: It was a bitter cold day on the end of Long Island. I was not alone out there; my two dogs and I had come in from a hike in the woods at the exact instant that the phone rang.

headline: More N.C.A.A. ‘Justice’
text: Last week’s case study in N.C.A.A. injustice took place at the University of North Carolina, where every sport is big time. Today, we move north to a different kind of institution, St. Joseph’s University, a small Jesuit-run school in Philadelphia. With fewer than 5,000 undergraduates, St. Joe’s doesn’t even field a football team, but its little-engine-that-could basketball team has long been a source of pride. During the 2003-4 season, for instance, it went 27-0 in the regular season and made it to the regional final of the N.C.A.A. championship tournament.

headline: Being Garifuna
text: When it comes to being counted in the census, the Garifunas, who are part African, part Caribbean and part Central American, say they don’t fit into any box.

headline: Tenderizing the Tundra With Some Light and Heat
text: The “frozen tundra” is a myth. The ground at Lambeau Field, legendary home of the Green Bay Packers, is heated. It has not been frozen during a football game since it was dubbed the “frozen tundra” more than 40 years ago.

headline: Friday Night Music, Defense Of Marriage Edition
text: A bit of a break from the usual — for some reason I’ve been on a Mozart kick the past few days.

headline: Lending Helps JPMorgan, but 4th Quarter Was Soft
text: Wall Street, more than three years after the financial crisis, has loosened its lending tap. Consumers, however, have yet to reap the benefits.

headline: For Many Latinos, Racial Identity Is More Culture Than Color
text: Every decade, the Census Bureau spends billions of dollars and deploys hundreds of thousands of workers to get an accurate portrait of the American population. Among the questions on the census form is one about race, with 15 choices, including “some other race.”

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: A credit downgrade for several European nations, unexpectedly strong jobs numbers for December and the suspension of iPhone sales in Apple stores in China were among the top business news stories of the week.

headline: Eclecticism by the Sea
text: SAMPLING the lobster roll at Oyster Club in Mystic is practically unavoidable. In one guise or another, it is one of the few constants on a menu that changes daily. Though not a big fan of this shore-side standby, I was converted at first bite. The version on the day I visited (a Saturday in December) combined fat chunks of succulent lobster meat with a delicate mix of truffle oil, parsley and parsley oil. The lobster was stuffed into a house-made potato roll spread with apple butter and topped with crisp-fried shallots; accompanying it were thick-cut fries sprinkled with a flavorsome mix of celery salt, paprika, homemade garlic powder and cayenne that made it easy to forgive the less-than-crisp fries.

headline: No Parade in Hoboken to Celebrate St. Patrick’s
text: There will not be a St. Patrick’s Day parade in Hoboken, N.J., this year, but organizers say they may go elsewhere to march.

headline: A Long Bleak Winter
text: The European Central Bank’s cheap lending to euro-area banks may have briefly stabilized the financial markets. But the respite won’t last. The decision by Standard & Poor’s on Friday to downgrade the credit ratings of nine euro-zone countries, including France, Italy and Spain, should remind European leaders that their economic strategy based on austerity for all is just not working.

headline: The Urination Video and Pressures of Battle
text: The United States Marine Corps has identified the four Marines shown in a video urinating on what appear to be dead Taliban fighters, and has named a lead investigating officer to decide whether they should be charged, Marine officials said. In an article in Saturday’s issue of The Times, Elisabeth Bumiller and Matthew Rosenberg report that Marine officials were also attempting to identify the person who shot the controversial video.

headline: Self-Inflicted Wound
text: Even after seven years, the photos of Army soldiers abusing detainees at the Abu Ghraib prison are an ugly black mark on the American presence in Iraq. Now there is a new scar on the country’s reputation. Four Marines were filmed urinating on what appear to be the corpses of three dead Taliban fighters in Afghanistan.

headline: In Extreme Cold, Accurate Passes Are the Least of the Body’s Worries
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In addition to facing Aaron Rodgers, Greg Jennings and the rest of the Green Bay Packers on Sunday, the Giants will also be forced to battle paresthesia, bronchoconstriction and a persistent though not necessarily overwhelming sensation that they have to urinate.

headline: W.P.S. Holds Its Draft, Just in Case
text: U.C.L.A. forward Sydney Leroux was the top pick in Friday’s W.P.S. draft. Whether she — or anyone else — will get to play in the league this season is another question.

headline: Fisher Picks Rams Over the Dolphins
text: Jeff Fisher, the most sought-after head coach this off-season, chose the St. Louis Rams and their franchise quarterback Sam Bradford over the Miami Dolphins on Friday, ending a nearly two-week waiting game for both teams. The Rams and Fisher were negotiating a contract on Friday afternoon.

headline: A Piece of Thailand in an Inconspicuous Spot
text: IF you had never been to Savory Thai Cooking before, it would be easy to drive past it. It is set perpendicular to the road; on my two visits, its storefront looked dark except for the restaurant’s name and a small lighted “Open” sign; there were very few cars in the parking lot. Inside, though, is a kitchen turning out solid Thai fare.

headline: Wanted by the F.B.I., but Still Popular With the Ex-Mother-in-Law
text: If the Federal Bureau of Investigation and some medical records are correct, a tough-looking mob associate named Jack Mannino robbed a Brooklyn bank two weeks ago while wearing an adult diaper.

headline: News of the Wired
text: The advent of the Internet has prompted endless claims that we are living through an unprecedented revolution in communication, one that has annihilated the concept of distance. Yet the real revolution came with the arrival of the telegraph in the 19th century.

headline: Richard Threlkeld, Award-Winning Journalist, Dies at 74
text: Richard Threlkeld, who in his 33 years as a correspondent for CBS and ABC News covered wars, presidential campaigns, assassinations and the collapse of the Soviet Union, died Friday morning in a car accident on Long Island. He was 74.

headline: Death of Oxford Astrophysicist Evokes Echoes of a TV Drama for the British
text: LONDON — It has all the elements that have made the Inspector Morse detective series a popular success on both sides of the Atlantic: two Oxford University academics, friends and professional collaborators for decades, co-authors of a popular textbook on science mathematics, meet for a pub supper in a village outside the city.

headline: 2 Smiths Add Up to Trouble for 49ers’ Opponents
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — In 2001, Justin Smith set the Missouri record for sacks in a season, with 11.

headline: For Some Applicants, Another Tough Year on the Early Admission Front
text: The Times has posted an article on its Web site by Richard Perez-Pena and Jenny Anderson arguing that “the early-admissions game” was made “much tougher this year for the group that has long dominated it: prep schools in New York and beyond where the vast majority of seniors apply to their top choices in November in hopes of avoiding the springtime scrum.”

headline: The Mayor’s To-Do List
text: With two years left in office, Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced ambitious plans this week to take on the city’s powerful teachers’ union by pushing for extra pay for the best teachers and making other education reforms.

headline: Tanker With Crucial Fuel Delivery Is Sighted Off Nome
text: A Russian tanker that has spent nearly a month making its way to Nome, Alaska, to deliver fuel appeared off the coast on the Bering Sea on Friday, apparently nearing the conclusion of an ocean odyssey that has been both criticized and celebrated.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,856 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Working Twice as Hard
text: In 2000, just two weeks after her fifth-grade graduation, Karla Mejia woke up with numbness on the right side of her body. The diagnosis was multiple sclerosis. She spent almost a year in the hospital, relearning to walk and to write, but her anger and depression over the years left her unable to concentrate on schoolwork.

headline: A Future Sans Corkscrews
text: Long Island wines are increasingly sold from taps in restaurants on the Island and in New York City.

headline: An Old-Fashioned Touch With Classic Italian
text: VERONA RISTORANTE, a five-year-old Italian restaurant in Farmingdale, is anything but trendy. Not only does it still serve patrons a free bread basket — a vanishing amenity — but it also includes a house-made focaccia and three additional breads from a local bakery. That basket is accompanied by butter, marinated olives and chickpeas, and a bowl of chopped tomatoes and onions for making do-it-yourself bruschetta.

headline: Anthony’s Injury Forces Knicks to Adjust
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Twenty-seven percent of the Knicks’ offense will be missing Saturday night, and maybe that will not be the worst thing for the team.

headline: Rauf Denktash, Who Led Turkish Cypriots, Dies at 87
text: Rauf Denktash, former leader of the Turkish minority in Cyprus, who for decades successfully opposed reunification of that divided Mediterranean island in his resolute pursuit of a separate state for his people, died there on Friday at the age of 87.

headline: Bitter Politics of Envy?
text: You’re just jealous. At least that’s how Mitt Romney sees it. The millionaire who posed for a picture with the boys at Bain Capital with the long green clinched between their teeth and poking out of their collars and jackets now says that people who question what he did there, and what rich people do now, are just green with envy.

headline: Like Woods Before, Tebow Becomes Must-Watch TV
text: Tiger Woods and Tim Tebow form an athletic pairing that pleases CBS Sports.

headline: Ruth Fernández, Singer and Senator in Puerto Rico, Dies at 92
text: Ruth Fernández, a soothing and spirited singer known in her homeland as “el alma de Puerto Rico hecha canción” — “the soul of Puerto Rico made song” — died on Monday in San Juan. She was 92.

headline: Saturday: Nutty as Can Be
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Just because there is no theme to talk about on a Saturday doesn’t mean we don’t have things to discuss, right?

headline: More E-Mails Released on Failed Solar Company
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has given House Republican investigators an additional 66 pages of internal correspondence relating to Solyndra, the solar equipment manufacturer that filed for bankruptcy after accepting a $535 million loan guarantee, and the e-mails reflect significant anxiety about the poor financial prospects of the administration’s flagship choice to demonstrate how federal help could add to building a clean energy economy.

headline: Sparano Hears Firsthand Where Jets Need to Improve
text: The philosophy espoused by Tony Sparano is, in his words, “a little different” from that of Brian Schottenheimer, his predecessor as the Jets’ offensive coordinator. When asked Friday to describe that philosophy, Sparano used the word “physical” in seven straight sentences. It was as if he were reading from cue cards held up by Coach Rex Ryan.

headline: For a Lover of Traveling and Languages, Only One Place Can Be Called Home
text: When Alayne O’Reilly looks out the window of her 17th-floor apartment in Greenwich Village and watches the planes go by, she wonders where they are heading. She imagines she knows their destinations, excited by the thought of going to other countries and hearing the different languages.

headline: Gingrich and Santorum Vie to Be the Conservative of Choice
text: DUNCAN, S.C. — Conventional wisdom dictates that for either Newt Gingrich or Rick Santorum to vault past Mitt Romney and win the South Carolina primary on Jan. 21, they must handily win the vote of upstate social conservatives, like the ones who packed a high school lunchroom here Friday night. But if the reactions of the 500 or so people here were any indication, these voters remain split.

headline: Bloomberg Focuses His Legacy on Education Reform
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his first State of the City address in 2002, to a wounded city still shaken by the death and destruction of a terrorist attack, he vowed to rebuild Lower Manhattan, but he also trained his focus on the city’s much-maligned school system.

headline: Corrections: January 14
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Two Guitarists, as Heard in a Woody Allen Film
text: EARLY in 1998, the guitarist Howard Alden got a call from the pianist Dick Hyman, a longtime collaborator of Woody Allen’s, asking whether he would like to work on Mr. Allen’s latest movie, “Sweet and Lowdown.” All he would need to do, Mr. Hyman said, was lay down tracks in the style of the gypsy guitarist Django Reinhardt — a style with which Mr. Alden was deeply familiar.

headline: Middle East Trip Suggests Change in Policy by China
text: BEIJING — Premier Wen Jiabao heads on Saturday to the oil-producing nations of Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, a six-day tour of Iran’s Persian Gulf neighbors that is the first Saudi trip by a Chinese premier in two decades, and the first ever to the other two states.

headline: In Mayor’s State of the City Addresses, a Recurring Theme
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg devoted more than half of his State of the City address on Thursday to education. Throughout Mr. Bloomberg’s 10 years as mayor, it has been a consistent theme of the annual speeches. Following are excerpts:

headline: In Two Deals, Yanks Trade Montero but Bolster Pitching
text: For weeks, people around baseball have marveled at the relative inactivity of the Yankees this off-season. Normally one of the most aggressive actors in baseball in terms of acquiring marquee players, the team was quiet almost to the point of drawing suspicion.

headline: Organs and Pianos at Yale, but No Dueling Keyboards
text: SIMON PRESTON, an organist with a wit as dry as his talent is prodigious, had just concluded a solo concert in Yale University’s Woolsey Hall last November when he was asked to draw a broad comparison between the hall’s monumental Newberry Memorial Organ — on which he had rendered Bach, Mozart, Liszt and Olivier Messiaen to sustained applause — and the other great organs he had played.

headline: U.S. Faces New Challenge of Fewer Troops in Europe
text: WASHINGTON — With word that the Pentagon will bring two combat brigades home from Germany, the Obama administration faces a challenge to convince Atlantic allies that the military’s new orders to refocus on the Asia-Pacific region, while sustaining its role in the Middle East, will not mean abandoning Europe to fit shrinking budgets.

headline: A Southern Town Highlighted by Romney Rivals
text: Gaffney, S.C., a small Southern town, has found itself the unexpected star of the latest bruising fight in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Putting Sociopaths Aside to Tackle Middle-Age Dreams
text: Huntington Bay, N.Y.

headline: Town, Cast as Romney’s Victim, Says, ‘Huh?’
text: GAFFNEY, S.C. — This small Southern town that once boomed with peaches and cotton mills has found itself the unexpected star of the latest bruising fight in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Every Goes Low and Speaks Out
text: Matt Every, who carded a six-under-par 64, was perhaps best known for a three-month tour suspension he received in 2010 for conduct unbecoming a professional after he was arrested during a tournament in July on a misdemeanor charge of marijuana possession. All charges were later dropped.

headline: In Brees’s Great Season, Reviews Have Been Muted
text: METAIRIE, La. — To grasp the grand scale of Drew Brees’s 2011 season, consider Thomas Morstead. He is the punter for New Orleans, and because Brees is the Saints’ quarterback, because he set three N.F.L. passing records, Morstead’s workload, like that of a butcher at a vegan bistro, mostly ranges from light to nonexistent.

headline: Romney Rolls Out the Big Guns in S.C.
text: HILTON HEAD, S.C. — Mitt Romney made an appeal to veterans here in what could be considered the political equivalent of the doctrine of overwhelming force.

headline: Rock’s Scientist Gets a Fittingly Small Tribute
text: MAHWAH, N.J.

headline: Tom Ardolino Dies at 56; Drummer for NRBQ for Three Decades
text: Tom Ardolino, a self-taught drummer who for 30 years provided the impassioned but steady pulse for NRBQ, one of the longest-lasting and most beloved rock groups never to have a Top 40 single, died on Jan. 6 in Springfield, Mass. He was 56.

headline: Twitter, Eggs and ‘Mob Wives’
text: The playwright Katori Hall, a self-described workaholic, is in the middle of a busy theater season: shortly after her play “The Mountaintop,” about the last hours of the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., closes on Broadway on Jan. 22, her newest play, “Hurt Village,” about a soldier returning from Iraq, will open at the Signature Theater Company on Feb. 7. Ms. Hall, 30, who was born in Memphis, lives in Washington Heights with her fiancé, Alan Tumusiime, 28, a video editor and photographer. She spends Sundays avoiding writing, playing guitar and appreciating both reality television and Southern cuisine.

headline: Inspiring Horse Honored
text: Neville Bardos, the horse who survived a barn fire last May, was named the international Horse of the Year for 2011 by the United States Equestrian Federation. Neville was among 11 horses in a  barn in West Grove, Pa., when it caught fire in late May. Six of the horses died. Three months later, Neville  is on a short list of Summer Olympics contenders.

headline: China: Tibetans Ransack Police Station After Killing of Suspect, Group Says
text: Tibetans in Gansu Province protested the death of a Tibetan man whom the police had shot dead after suspecting him of being involved in stealing equipment from an airport construction site, according to a report released this week by International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group based in Washington. The Tibetan man, Gurgo Tsering, in his mid-30s, was killed on Jan. 8 in a late night raid in Achok, in Xiahe County. The new airport in Achok was approved by officials in 2009, but locals have expressed concerns because it is being built near a sacred mountain. Tibetans ransacked the Achok police station after the fatal shooting, and the riot police were called in to put down the unrest, the report said.

headline: Crime, Sage Remarks and Brooklyn Heights
text: SKEPTICS have suggested that New York’s two-decade decline in major crime simply reflects a national pattern. Franklin E. Zimring, a Berkeley Law criminologist, says they’re dead wrong.

headline: What Happened to Baby Annie?
text: THE lives of Li Hangbin and Li Ying were intertwined nearly from the start.

headline: Russia: Billionaire Claims Signatures to Challenge Putin for President
text: The billionaire businessman Mikhail D. Prokhorov said Friday that he had collected the two million signatures needed to compete in the March 4 presidential election. He plans to submit the documents to Russia’s Central Election Commission next week, according to the RIA Novosti news agency. Mr. Prokhorov, in an opinion article in The Guardian this week, called for “evolution not revolution” and said Russia’s era of “managed democracy” had ended. He has reportedly put about $12.5 million toward his campaign, more than any other candidate, but is considered unlikely to defeat Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Julie Andrews to Direct ‘Mousical’ Based on Her Children’s Book
text: Julie Andrews will direct a new musical, “The Great American Mousical,” based on the children’s book of the same name co-written with her daughter, Emma Walton Hamilton. Goodspeed Musicals will put on a developmental production of the show on its second stage, the Norma Terris Theater in Chester, Conn.,, from Nov. 8 to Dec. 2, theater leaders are scheduled to announce on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Germany: A Bear Will Dream in Bronze
text: Plans are now set for Knut the polar bear’s memorial. The Berlin Zoo and the association of its supporters announced the winning design on Friday for a bronze statue of the world-famous bear who died last year. The design, “Knut — The Dreamer” by Josef Tabachnyk, was chosen out of more than 40 proposals and depicts the young polar bear in repose, head on paws, lying on a slab of granite. The $19,000 cost of the memorial is being financed through donations. Knut became a worldwide media sensation as a cub in 2007 after his mother rejected him and zookeepers decided to raise him.

headline: Iran: Acclaimed Director Protest Shutdown of Cinema Guild
text: A critically acclaimed Iranian film director has written a letter to the Culture Ministry challenging its order to close the House of Cinema, Iran’s umbrella guild for cinema professionals and the only domestic organization that supports independent film. The ministry’s order, which has been widely protested by many of the organization’s members, threatens to effectively silence Iran’s last remaining autonomous forum for free expression in the visual arts. The director, Asghar Farhadi, whose movie “A Separation” is favored to win the top honors at the Golden Globe awards on Sunday, told Ministry officials in the letter that “If the decision to dissolve the House of Cinema is based on the idea that the majority of the film community and members of the guild are in agreement with your method, then I suggest that you take a vote on this decision among the few thousand members of the House of Cinema.” An excerpt of the letter was published by the Web site of Shargh, an Iranian reformist newspaper that has often been shut down by the government. Mr. Farhadi’s film, about the breakup of a family, has shattered box-office office records in Iran and won nearly three dozen awards. The Culture Ministry’s order was supposed to take effect this week, and it remains unclear whether House of Cinema’s management committee will seek a way to nullify it.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: Pity Blue Ivy Carter. Her very birth upset many New Yorkers amid reports that her parents, Beyoncé and Jay-Z, had unleashed a small security army on the maternity ward at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, hassling other parents.

headline: In Reversal, Gingrich Calls for Withdrawal of Film Attacking Romney and Bain
text: Misleading and exaggerated claims in a film portraying Mitt Romney as a heartless job killer led Newt Gingrich to ask on Friday that the group behind it change or withdraw it, even though Mr. Gingrich is the intended beneficiary of the film.

headline: Venezuela Closes Consulate in Miami
text: President Hugo Chávez said Friday that he would close his country’s consulate in Miami after the expulsion by the State Department of Venezuela’s consul general there. Mr. Chávez said that he did not intend to expel any United States diplomats in retaliation. The State Department expelled the consul general, Livia Acosta Noguera, after a televised report accused her of having taking part in discussions, during an earlier posting in Mexico, about possible cyberattacks against the United States. The political opposition immediately criticized the move, saying that thousands of Venezuelans used the Miami consulate to vote in Venezuelan elections and that the émigré population there was overwhelmingly anti-Chávez. Mr. Chávez is running for re-election in a vote scheduled for October.

headline: He Just Can’t Turn In the Badge
text: CHARLIE MURELLO still carries his gun and badge, still wears a detective’s sharp suit and tassel loafers, still keeps his dress blue uniform hanging in his closet at home.

headline: Riding the Bulls
text: For the sixth straight year, the Professional Bull Riders kicked off their season in Madison Square Garden, and the cowboys, and their bulls, were well received.

headline: Where Optimism Feels Out of Reach
text: So many of the civic successes heralded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in his annual State of the City address on Thursday — the expansion of the High Line, a new East River ferry service, the luring of Cornell University to Roosevelt Island, groundbreaking on a new Whitney Museum — might have happened in Lithuania for all the effect they have had (or could have) on the lives of people in Brownsville, in northeastern Brooklyn.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: India’s Courts Grapple With Web Censorship
text: India has long faced an uneasy tension between allowing free expression to its citizens and staunching sectarian violence among its people. It was one of the first countries to ban “The Satanic Verses” by Salman Rushdie. Lawsuits forced the Indian painter Maqbool Fida Husain to live in exile during the last several years of his life. An academic book about the 17th-century warrior known as Shivaji was banned for fear of offending Shivaji’s modern-day fans, until the Supreme Court lifted the prohibition.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: An inquiry commission headed by a retired Supreme Court judge began a probe on Thursday, into the custodial death of Syed Mohammad Yousuf, a worker of the ruling state party, the National Conference. The commission has been asked to complete the inquiry within six weeks. The death of Mr. Yosuf in September had raised political controversy in the state (Kashmir Live).

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
text: Salman Khan: Ormax Media, a leading research and consulting firm for the entertainment business released key findings of “Front Page,” their annual report on movies and television. One of the key features of the report is the list of the top 10 male and female stars in Bollywood. Using a star tracking methodology, data was collected through the year from a sample of more than 30,000 moviegoers. The star rankings threw up a few surprises. Among the heroes, Salman Khan was, of course, the top choice for 2011. This is hardly unexpected since he single-handedly propelled two mediocre films – “Ready” and “Bodyguard” – to blockbuster status. But the surprise was how far ahead he is of the competition. He has a 47 percent share, which almost equals that of Shah Rukh Khan (27 percent) and Aamir Khan (22 percent) combined.

headline: Blast Kills Dozens of Shiite Worshipers in Southern Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Insurgents mounted another attack against Iraq’s Shiites on Saturday, as an explosion in the southern city of Basra ripped through a group of pilgrims headed to a mosque to commemorate one of the holiest Shiite holidays.

headline: President of Taiwan Is Re-elected, a Result That Is Likely to Please China
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — President Ma Ying-jeou was re-elected by a comfortable margin on Saturday, fending off a challenge from his main rival, Tsai Ing-wen, who criticized his handling of the economy but also sought to exploit fears among voters that Mr. Ma’s conciliatory approach toward China was eroding the island’s sovereignty.

headline: Last of 6 Parts: Answers on the Fafsa, the Free Application for Federal Student Aid
text: In the sixth and final round of responses to student questions about financial aid, Mark Kantrowitz, founder of the Web sites FinAid.org and fastweb.com, addresses studying abroad and whether a student paying for college on his own can avoid listing his parents’ assets.

headline: Giants and Packers Linked by Lombardi
text: The Giants and the Packers share a long history in the N.F.L. and one everlasting link: Vince Lombardi.

headline: Nobel Laureate Drops Bid for Presidency of Egypt
text: CAIRO — Mohamed ElBaradei, the Nobel-Prize winning diplomat who helped galvanize the demands for democracy here, said on Saturday that he was dropping his presidential bid in protest over the military’s continued hold on power nearly a year after the ouster of the strongman Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Sunday’s Divisional Playoff Matchups: The Good and the Boring
text: Texans (11-6) at Ravens (12-4)Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Ravens by 7.5

headline: Among Small-Business Advocates, Reaction to President’s Plan Is Mixed
text: Advocates for small business — including those in Congress — had near uniformly mixed reactions to President Obama’s proposal Friday to temporarily elevate the Small Business Administration to a cabinet agency but then fold the S.B.A. into a super trade and commerce department. Uniformly mixed in that most people The Agenda contacted praised the decision to make the S.B.A. part of the cabinet but expressed caution about the consolidation proposal.

headline: As Divers Search Cruise Ship, Reason for Crash Is Unclear
text: ROME — As shaken survivors spoke of a mad crush to flee a sinking cruise ship off the Tuscan coast of Italy on Saturday, raising questions about the crew’s preparedness, Italian authorities arrested the ship’s captain amid concerns that the megaship had steered dangerously off course.

headline: Running Back on Rise and Linebacker in Career Twilight Become Friends
text: He is not the stereotypical N.F.L. running back. Start with Arian Foster’s first name, an abbreviated version of Aquarians, chosen by his father and meaning “holder of knowledge.” After Foster scores a touchdown, he eschews aggressive celebratory displays and places his hands together and bows, a gesture of respect in India, in his case to the game he plays.

headline: As Critics Howled, a Coach Didn’t Curse His Lot
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The most divisive figure among Giants fans this season has round glasses and a perpetual smile, and opts to use a code word — instead of cursing — to let his players know he is angry.

headline: Cruise Ship Runs Aground in Italy
text: Survivors from a luxury cruise ship that ran aground and tipped over, leaving at least three dead and 69 people still unaccounted for, described a chaotic evacuation.

headline: Cruise Ship Runs Aground in Italy
text: Survivors from a luxury cruise ship that ran aground and tipped over, leaving at least three dead and 69 people still unaccounted for, described Saturday a chaotic evacuation.

headline: Tim Tebow and David Bowie Become One
text: The fascination with Tim Tebow in our pop culture has been particularly evident in recent weeks on late-night comedy television shows. A few weeks ago, Tebow was visited by Jesus on “Saturday Night Live.” David Bowie fans will appreciate the latest spoof from Jimmy Fallon, who used Bowie’s 1969 classic, Space Oddity, to poke fun at Tebow on Thursday night.

headline: ‘Hit Me’? Maybe Not At This Las Vegas Resort
text: Las Vegas has diversified in the past decade, becoming a destination for tourists interested in culture and dining as well as gambling. A new resort is hoping to tap into an even broader tourist market: gun enthusiasts.

headline: Now Screening | Burberry Fall 2012 Men’s Collection
text: The Fall 2012 men’s collection from Burberry at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Giants’ Tackles Are Guts Behind the Ends’ Glory
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ defensive line may be best described using the metaphor of a home: the tackles are the concrete foundation, important but largely unnoticed, and the ends are the finished exterior, which is what typically draws attention.

headline: No. 1 Everywhere but the Slam Events
text: PERTH, Australia — Caroline Wozniacki is hardly an anomaly.

headline: China Forces Are Reported to Have Shot at Tibetans
text: BEIJING — Chinese security forces on Saturday fired into a crowd of Tibetans in a restive area of Sichuan Province after they tried to take away the body of a Tibetan man who had died after setting himself on fire that morning to protest Chinese policies in the Tibetan areas, according to reports from two Tibet advocacy groups and Tibetan officials in the exile government in India.

headline: For Kudla, a Quick Qualification in Australia
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Before he could battle his own way through the qualifying draw of the 2012 Australian Open, the 19-year-old Denis Kudla needed some help from the rest of the field.

headline: New President of Penn State Endures a Week Under Fire
text: Standing in a hotel ballroom packed with Penn State alumni Friday night, David Roush directed two rapier-sharp questions at the university’s new president, Rodney A. Erickson, that seemed to encapsulate the crowd’s simmering frustration over how the firing of the football coach Joe Paterno was handled.

headline: S&P On Europe
text: S&P’s downgrade of a bunch of European sovereigns was no surprise. What was somewhat surprising — and which went unmentioned in almost all the news stories I’ve read — was why S&P has gotten so pessimistic. From their FAQs:

headline: Ream’s View at Old Trafford
text: Red Bulls defender (for now at least) Tim Ream was at Old Trafford on Saturday to take in Bolton’s Premier League match against Manchester United, a 3-0 victory for the Red Devils..

headline: St. John’s Fights to Pass Course in Improvisation
text: Steve Lavin watched St. John’s defeat Cincinnati, 57-55, last Saturday from his SoHo apartment in Manhattan, sending text messages to his assistants and coaching his team from the couch as best he could.

headline: Robson’s Popularity Outpaces Ranking
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Although there was only room for eight chairs, at least 18 reporters had crammed into the closet-sized Interview Room 1 to talk to 17-year old Laura Robson of Britain.

headline: Players to Watch: Six With Games Suited for Success
text: Geoff Macdonald, the women’s tennis coach at Vanderbilt University, will provide analysis of the Australian Open throughout the next two weeks on this blog.

headline: Things We’re Supposed To Be Quiet About
text: Apologists for rising inequality often argue that since most Americans’ income has risen despite rising inequality, there’s no reason to complain about inequality other than envy. So it’s worth remembering that we used to expect economic growth to deliver large increases in real income, not just a bit of a rise that’s accomplished in large part through longer working hours; and that a major reason so many have seen such small gains is that a large part of growth has been siphoned off to the very high end.

headline: Variety: A Dusty Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The author of today’s quote was one of the pre-eminent writers during the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920s and ’30s. Her books, short stories, plays and essays heavily influenced many of the heavy hitters in literature, such as Alice Walker, Toni Morrison, Ralph Ellison and more.

headline: Emlen Tunnell: The Giants’ Greatest Packer
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Emlen Tunnell, a star defender for the glittering, magnetic Giants, had been summoned to Green Bay. It was 1959, and the new Packers coach, Vince Lombardi, traded for Tunnell, ending his run of 11 record-setting seasons in New York.

headline: Romney-Obama: No Popularity Contest
text: If Mitt Romney becomes the Republican presidential nominee, he will begin the general-election campaign with middling favorability ratings as compared with other recent standard-bearers.

headline: Unit of Chinese Daily Plans I.P.O.
text: SHANGHAI — The online division of the People’s Daily, the official mouthpiece of the Communist Party, won approval on Friday to go ahead with an initial public offering of stock.

headline: Reaching the Summit of Kilimanjaro
text: R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, climbed Mount Kilimanjaro to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts have appeared occasionally in Bats.

headline: Bargaining for a Child’s Love
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: In Pakistan, Talks Aim to Ease Split
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s civilian and military leaders met Saturday for the first time since the eruption of a bitter political and legal controversy that stoked rumors of a military coup and could still topple the precariously weak civilian government.

headline: Zimbabwe’s Unsavory Path to Peace
text: ZIMBABWE is fast approaching a dangerous tipping point. Last month, its ailing octogenarian president, Robert Mugabe, angrily defied his critics, calling for early elections in 2012. If a political settlement with Zimbabwe’s security chiefs is not negotiated before the vote, Mr. Mugabe will no doubt rely on them to once again begin a campaign of intimidation and violence, leading to sham elections that could precipitate a regional crisis.

headline: Traffic Jams With Eastwood and Pitt, Scorsese and Weinstein
text: LOS ANGELES — Aside from “congratulations,” “this is my favorite event” was probably the phrase heard the most often at Friday’s American Film Institute luncheon on Friday. The annual program announces its winners for TV and film in advance – this year they included “Bridesmaids,” “War Horse,” “The Tree of Life,” “Moneyball,” “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” “The Descendants,” “Hugo,” “The Help,” “J. Edgar,” “The Artist” and “Midnight in Paris” – and presents them all with prizes, no speechifying necessary. Instead, everybody schmoozes, lunches and watches clip reels. And because the honorees come from TV and film, there are double the opportunities for stars to rub shoulders.

headline: Busy, Pain-Filled Comeback Pays Off as Keflezighi Wins to Make U.S. Team
text: HOUSTON — This time, Meb Keflezighi kept his breathing strip where it belonged — on his nose.

headline: History vs. the Tea Party
text: FOR more than two years, conservatives have been riding a wave of Tea Party insurgency that has formed the most dynamic force in American politics, a protest movement that promised to slash taxes, close the federal deficit and remake Washington. And yet to judge from the results of the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary, some of the most engaged Republican voters are inching closer to nominating Mitt Romney, the candidate they like least, a Harvard-educated technocrat who is in many ways a mirror image of the president the insurgents want to dislodge.

headline: Despite Uproar Over Clemency, Barbour Finds Lucrative Nest
text: JACKSON, Miss. — But who will pardon the governor?

headline: The Empires Strike Back
text: AS Egyptians and Tunisians vote to replace ousted despots and the Syrian government teeters on the brink, two old imperial powers are competing to exert their political influence over Arab countries in upheaval. And they are not America and Russia. After years of cold-war competition over the Middle East and North Africa, it is now France and Turkey that are vying for lucrative business ties and the chance to mold a new generation of leaders in lands that they once controlled.

headline: Cruise Ship Runs Aground
text: At least three people are reported dead after a luxury liner tips over near the coast of Tuscany, Italy. (Courtesy of Reuters)

headline: What They Don’t Want to Talk About
text: Ever since Newt Gingrich and Rick Perry started criticizing Mitt Romney’s actions at Bain Capital — and talking about the thousands of people laid off as a result of Bain’s investments — party leaders have essentially told them to shut up. That response is a pretty good indication of how deeply party elders fear the issue of economic inequality in the campaign to come.

headline: Rights in the Workplace
text: As a condition of getting and keeping their jobs, millions of employees in the United States have signed agreements to take any disputes with their employers to arbitration rather than court. Typically, the agreements also prohibit the arbitrator from consolidating similar claims.

headline: Good Immigration Policy, on Hold
text: Last summer the Obama administration announced an overdue change in the way it catches and deports illegal immigrants. The head of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, John Morton, said the agency would focus more heavily on deporting convicted criminals and other high-risk offenders, making noncriminals a lower priority.

headline: The Whirling Sound of Planet Dickens
text: In death, Charles Dickens still keeps his greatest secret to himself — the essence of his energy. None of the physical relics he left behind betray it. The manuscripts of his novels — like “Our Mutual Friend” at the Morgan Library — look no more fevered or hectic than the manuscripts left behind by other novelists.

headline: Dueling Parties Before the Globes
text: LOS ANGELES — The Bagger’s whirlwind pre-Golden Globes party schedule on Friday night included stops at the Paramount lot and the roof of the Chateau Marmont, the perennial Hollywood hot spot. Attendance at both by Oscar hopefuls was a bit light – they were all at the Los Angeles Film Critics Association awards presentation.

headline: Mitt’s Big Love
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.

headline: Getting to Know You ...
text: Cairo

headline: The Benefits of Bain Capitalism
text: THE debate over Mitt Romney’s career at Bain Capital, in which several of his Republican rivals sound as if they’re auditioning for a production of “Les Misérables,” is at heart a debate about the last 30 years of American capitalism.

headline: Unlocking the Secrets Behind Hydraulic Fracturing
text: Starting Feb. 1, drilling operators in Texas will have to report many of the chemicals used in the process known as hydraulic fracturing. Environmentalists and landowners are looking forward to learning what acids, hydroxides and other materials have gone into a given well.

headline: Are We Really Monolingual?
text: AMERICANS are often told that in today’s globalized world, we are at a competitive disadvantage because of our lazy monolingualism. “For too long, Americans have relied on other countries to speak our language,” Secretary of Education Arne Duncan said at the Foreign Language Summit in 2010. “But we won’t be able to do that in the increasingly complex and interconnected world.”

headline: Fruit Flies and Love
text: WHAT’S the quickest way to a man’s heart? No, not through the chest wall with a knife.

headline: Why Is Europe a Dirty Word?
text: PARIS

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Mobility and Inequality in Today’s America
text: Readers discuss how to reinvigorate the American promise that anyone can rise to success.

headline: Richard Branson
text: Richard Branson is the leonine founder and chief executive of the Virgin Group, a conglomerate of more than 300 companies with 43,000 employees and global revenues reportedly of $21 billion. A dyslexic who dropped out of high school, Mr. Branson is known for making bold bets in travel (including space travel), telecommunications, health care and entertainment. He is also involved in several philanthropic ventures.

headline: For Romney, Attacks on Bain Career Have Upside
text: BEAUFORT, S.C. — Mitt Romney has spent days defending himself against accusations that he was a job-killing vulture capitalist.

headline: Rivals on Ice
text: A preview in photographs of Sunday’s Michigan-Ohio State hockey game, which will be played outdoors at Progressive Field in Cleveland.

headline: For Michigan and Ohio State, Hockey in the Image of Football
text: CLEVELAND — Even in snowy conditions, the helmets — Ohio State’s gray with a scarlet stripe, and Michigan’s blue with maize wings — will be recognizable. The Game, as matchups between these universities are known, will be played not on a football field but on an ice rink built over a baseball diamond.

headline: Considering the Bulls and Their Point Guard
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Never Bet on a Bird in the Playoffs
text: In dissecting first-round playoff losses by the Bengals, the Lions and the Falcons, the N.F.L. analysts missed the key to the N.F.L. postseason. I learned it two years ago while staring into the comfortless swill at the bottom of my pint in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: The Great Wall
text: On the first Friday night of each month, a large wall of an Oakland office complex morphs into an outdoor theater. A projector on a nearby rooftop shows videos a hundred feet tall on the exterior of a building at the corner of West Grand and Valley Street. The spectators — most of whom also attend the monthly event called Art Murmur in nearby galleries — stand or perch on the curb to watch the show.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Running From Millions
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.

headline: N.H.L.’s Best at the Season’s Halfway Mark
text: In the days of the Original Six, the N.H.L. conducted two votes annually on major awards for individual players. The end-of-season winner was awarded the trophy and a bonus, and the midseason winner received a bonus, albeit a smaller one.

headline: Foreclosure Auctions Show Raw Form of Capitalism
text: PHOENIX — To the unknowing, the few dozen people milling around the picnic tables in front of the Maricopa County courthouse here every day could be jurors on break or scofflaws finally coming to pay a ticket. They tug on cigarettes, sip from big cups of coffee and fidget with their cellphones, often speaking in whispers.
