headline: Man Held as a Fourth Homeless Man Is Found Dead
text: LOS ANGELES—A possible serial killer has been arrested in Orange County following the Friday night stabbing death of homeless man in Anaheim—the fourth killing of a homeless man in Orange County over the past month.

headline: What’s Race Got to Do With It?
text: Mitt Romney may not have officially clinched the Republican nomination, but his victory has never really been in doubt. Nor has his viability in November: the most fanatical Tea Partiers are not about to withhold their votes and risk allowing President Obama to be re-elected.

headline: Yanks Deal From Depth in Their Prospects
text: So this is why the Yankees stockpiled so many catchers in their farm system. Teams need only one starting catcher, after all. Yet on the Baseball America list of the Yankees’ top 10 prospects, they had four catchers — and only two pitchers.

headline: Evangelicals, Seeking Unity, Back Santorum for Nomination
text: BRENHAM, Tex. — Evangelical leaders pursued a last-ditch effort on Saturday to exert influence in the Republican presidential primary race, voting to support the candidacy of Rick Santorum in hopes of undercutting Mitt Romney’s march to the nomination.

headline: European Leaders Use Debt Downgrades to Argue for Austerity, and for Stimulus
text: FRANKFURT — European leaders sought to limit damage from a ratings agency’s downgrade of nine countries on Friday, or even turn the news to their advantage, saying that it showed the need to impose more austerity or else do more to stimulate growth.

headline: Countrywide ‘V.I.P.’ Loans Linked to 2 Congressmen

headline: Spend, Spend, Spend. It’s the American Way.
text: GRIDLOCK in Congress implies that there won’t be any collective decision to spend more as a nation to get out of our slump. Increases in deficit spending seem unlikely, and so does the balanced-budget stimulus I’ve been advocating in this column. For now, we must pin our hopes for a robust recovery on the willingness of millions of consumers to spend substantially more.

headline: An Election in Kazakhstan Will Offer Something New: A Multiparty System
text: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — This capital city has been abuzz for weeks with the latest political news: Soon there will be politics. After an election scheduled for Sunday, Kazakhstan’s Parliament will be guaranteed, under a new law, to consist of more than one political party.

headline: Backing of Evangelicals Could Resuscitate Santorum in South Carolina
text: Polling in the early stages of the nomination race can be extremely fluid, but ordinarily a candidate who is in fourth place with a week to go would have little chance of winning a state primary. This is why the FiveThirtyEight forecast model is skeptical about Rick Santorum’s chances of winning South Carolina, where his numbers have slumped since his near-victory in Iowa on Jan 3.

headline: Joel J. Tyler, Judge Who Pronounced ‘Deep Throat’ Obscene, Dies at 90
text: Joel J. Tyler, who as a Manhattan judge ruled, in a particularly explicit and colorful opinion, that the pornographic film “Deep Throat” was obscene and that the New York City theaters showing it were breaking the law, inadvertently helping it become perhaps the most popular X-rated movie of all time, died in Yonkers on Nov. 9. He was 90.

headline: California’s Reputation Grows With New Events
text: It is not surprising that California is a center of chess in the United States. But in the last couple of years, there has been a burst of activity there, with a large number of international tournaments that have given players a chance to qualify for grandmaster and international master titles. Two groups are behind those events.

headline: Sunday: Weather Report
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Everyone have their umbrellas out? You’re going to need one for today’s delightful puzzle by the Columbia University student Finn Vigeland. The only warning I would give you is that these drops are likely to be a bit heavier than usual, so make sure that umbrella is reinforced. Concrete would probably be good.

headline: Romney Offers Praise for a Donor’s Business
text: WASHINGTON — At a town-hall-style meeting in New Hampshire last month, listeners pressed Mitt Romney on the soaring cost of higher education. His solution: students should consider for-profit colleges like the little-known Full Sail University in Florida.

headline: Frederica Sagor Maas, Silent-Era Scriptwriter, Dies at 111
text: She told of Hollywood moguls chasing naked would-be starlets, the women shrieking with laughter. She recounted how Joan Crawford, new to the movies, relied on her to pick clothes. Almost obsessively, she complained about how many of her story ideas and scripts were stolen and credited to others.

headline: At 20, Surviving Battle With Cancer on His Own
text: Michael Mercado, 20, has made a bargain with fate. He would finish school and find a good job working on cars if only, he says, “the cancer stays away.”

headline: Fear of Civil War Mounts in Syria as Crisis Deepens
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The failure of an Arab League mission to stanch violence in Syria, an international community with little leverage and a government as defiant as its opposition is in disarray have left Syria descending into a protracted, chaotic and perhaps unnegotiable conflict.

headline: A Lifetime of Close Ties and Growing Influence
text: In Rahm Emanuel’s first public appearance after resigning as White House chief of staff in October 2010, he showed up in the Pilsen neighborhood accompanied by Juan Rangel, the community activist. Mr. Emanuel and Mr. Rangel had spoken for the first time only days earlier, yet Mr. Rangel soon would become a co-chairman of Mr. Emanuel’s successful bid for mayor.

headline: California Leads Nation in Unaccredited Schools, and Enforcement Is Lax
text: Dibyendu Malakar needed a graduate business degree to advance his career, but he was working full time and could not afford $100,000 or more for a two-year M.B.A. program at Berkeley, Stanford or another accredited business school. So Mr. Malakar enrolled at Frederick Taylor University, an unaccredited school in Moraga.

headline: Where the Italian Cruise Ship Ran Aground

headline: Eight Men In: The Road Trip to Lambeau Takes Off
text: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team — a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen — are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sunday’s showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men — they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee — have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

headline: White House Says It Opposes Parts of Two Antipiracy Bills
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Saturday that it strongly opposed central elements of two Congressional efforts to enforce copyrights on the Internet, all but killing the current versions of legislation that has divided both political parties and pitted Hollywood against Silicon Valley.

headline: Paterno Describes His Uncertainty Over Allegation
text: Joe Paterno, who was fired as Penn State’s football coach on Nov. 9 in the wake of allegations that his former defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky had sexually abused boys, said in an interview published Saturday that he reported a suspected assault in 2002 to his superiors because he was unsure how to handle the matter.

headline: Track Star Will Return to Olympics in Marathon
text: HOUSTON — After a slow, tactical start, the United States women’s Olympic marathon trials began at 20 miles to distill itself to the three eventual qualifiers for the 2012 London Games: Shalane Flanagan (2 hours 25 minutes 38 seconds), Desiree Davila (2:25:55) and Kara Goucher (2:26:06).

headline: Just Like in the Glory Days, 49ers Seize the Moment in the Playoffs
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Like any 49ers team, this one cannot escape comparisons to the dynastic San Francisco teams of a generation ago. As if trying to fully recapture their gloried past, the 49ers had the 1980s pop icons Huey Lewis and the News sing the national anthem before Saturday’s playoff game. A handwritten sign above the last row of seats of dilapidating Candlestick Park read, “We’re back!” The sentiment in the Bay Area in the days before the game was that the resurrection went unnoticed by anyone east of the Sierra Nevada.

headline: Defense, of All Things, Carries 49ers Just Far Enough
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The hit that changed momentum, that left New Orleans running back Pierre Thomas crumpled on the field, that made the Saints think twice when they ventured across the middle, came early into the first quarter Saturday afternoon.

headline: Palestinian Authority Leaders Talk With Israel and Hamas
text: JERUSALEM — Palestinian Authority leaders pursued dual tracks of reconciliation on Saturday, holding meetings both with Israeli negotiators in Jordan and with Hamas leaders in Gaza. The talks with the Israelis went late into the evening. The Gaza negotiations yielded some results.

headline: Romney Gives Cash to Woman in Need
text: SUMTER, S.C. — After a campaign event here on Saturday, a woman told Mitt Romney that she was jobless and broke. In response, Mr. Romney reached into his pocket and handed cash to the woman, Ruth Williams, 55, of Columbia.

headline: ‘Midnight in Paris’ Gets a Globe Nod but Not a Seat for Hemingway
text: LOS ANGELES – You might think that being a star, writer or director of a Golden Globe-nominated movie automatically means you get a seat to the big show on Sunday. Nope.

headline: Employee Is Stabbed to Death at a Cellphone Store in Brooklyn
text: An employee at a Sprint cellphone store in Flatbush, Brooklyn, was stabbed to death while working on Saturday afternoon after a dispute with a man who might have been a former Sprint employee, the police said.

headline: With Spotlight on Tebow, Brady Stars
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — This season, and most especially in the days leading up to the New England Patriots’ playoff game against the Denver Broncos, Tim Tebow — the off-speed passer, the media phenomenon, the cultural touchstone — was at the center of an extraordinary, endless-loop conversation, about the nature of offensive football and, to the consternation of many, the convergence of sports and religion.

headline: Into the Heart of Lightness
text: THE artist Doug Wheeler tells two stories, both having to do with light, that go a long way toward explaining why he is so revered by many fellow artists — as a visionary and a relentlessly stubborn perfectionist — and also why his work has been seen by so few American artgoers over the last few decades, particularly those in New York.

headline: Liner Captain Is Questioned in Capsizing Off Italy Coast
text: GIGLIO, Italy — The captain of the cruise ship that capsized aground near an Italian island, killing at least five people, may have caused the accident by taking the ship too close to the island’s rocky shore, the owner of the vessel said on Sunday, as rescue workers extracted three survivors and two bodies from the wreck.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: In an analysis of the comparative strengths of political parties in Uttar Pradesh, Outlook magazine finds that no clear majority emerges and predicts that the state elections scheduled for February may end in a hung verdict. “In 2012, the most interesting candidate Faizabad has thrown up is a kinnar (eunuch) who plans to contest as an independent,” the piece observes about the election constituency, which has been a political stronghold over the past several decades. Despite the eunuchs being a marginalized community, a local trader said, “a hijra is better than all of these useless parties,” suggesting a sense of despair about the current crop of political candidates.

headline: Tim Tebow’s Postgame Comments, and Unclear Future
text: Because Tim Tebow has transcended football, he has steadily gained casual fans and many who are barely familiar with the game. These two categories of fans may not be aware  that his  long-term future as a starting quarterback with the Denver Broncos is far from secure.

headline: Why Did Tom Brady Punt Late in the Game?

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Season Premiere Is Set for March 25
text: Jon Hamm has been a bad boy, and not just in his scenes in “Bridesmaids.” A few days ago Mr. Hamm let it slip in a podcast interview that the long-awaited season premiere of “Mad Men,” the AMC period drama on which he plays the advertising executive Don Draper, would be shown on March 25. Though a few days of radio silence from the network followed Mr. Hamm can now wipe those beads of sweat from his Brylcreemed brow: AMC has confirmed the news, announcing over the weekend that Season 5 of “Mad Men” would begin on that date, with a two-hour episode written by the series’ creator, Matthew Weiner, and directed by Jennifer Getzinger, who directed the episode “The Suitcase” last season.

headline: A Score of Ways to Serenade a City
text: The Five Boroughs Music Festival began in 2007 with the idea of presenting concerts all over New York. The festival has no preconceptions about genre: its offerings have included folk music, early music and art song. To celebrate its fifth anniversary the festival commissioned 20 composers to write songs about the city for one to four voices, using texts of their choice (several wrote their own). The resulting “Five Borough Songbook” had its premiere at Galapagos Art Space in Brooklyn three months ago and made its way to Manhattan on Thursday, to the Baruch Performing Arts Center.

headline: As French Vote Nears, Sarkozy Is Haunted by Grim Economy

headline: A New Law Firm With 161 Years of Experience
text: Norman Siegel and Herbert Teitelbaum were classmates at New York University law school. Mr. Siegel is married to Saralee Evans, a former acting State Supreme Court justice. Their wedding ceremony was performed by Emily Jane Goodman, a Supreme Court justice. They all come from Brooklyn. Collectively, they have 161 years of legal experience and a record of impact in and out of court. And now, when most of their contemporaries are contemplating retirement or have already quit, the four of them are starting a new law firm.

headline: The Great Gatsby Curve
text: Alan Krueger, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers — who is not only a colleague of mine at Princeton, but gets a lot of my mail and vice versa — gave a very informative speech on inequality last week that should have received more press than it did. Much of it was stuff that inequality mavens already know, but he had one striking result that was what I suspected but hadn’t seen demonstrated: a clear negative relationship between inequality at a point in time and intergenerational social mobility.

headline: Cruise Operator Says ‘Significant Human Error’ May Have Been Factor in Sinking

headline: But The Top 0.1 Percent Isn’t Diverse
text: The Times has a piece today showing, correctly, that the top 1 percent of the income distribution is a fairly diverse group. But what that mainly reflects is the fact that the slogan “we are the 99 percent” sets the cut too low. A large part of the rising share of the top 1 — about 60 percent, according to the Piketty-Saez data — is actually attributable to the top 0.1 percent. And that’s not a diverse group at all, according to Heim et al (pdf):

headline: Online Shoppers Are Rooting for the Little Guy
text: Harold Pollack used to spend $1,000 a year on Amazon, but this fall started buying from small online retailers instead. The prices are higher, but Dr. Pollack says he now has a clear conscience.

headline: Eight Men In: A Night in Milwaukee
text: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team — a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen — are set to travel to Lambeau Field for Sunday’s showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It will be a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. The men — they will be joined by two pals in Milwaukee — have agreed to create a Titletown travelogue. Their hopes are to stay friends, keep their jobs and, well, see the Giants win.

headline: The Reflected Lights and Shadows of California’s 1970s Troubadours
text: “Too many stories, too many heartbreak songs/ Where nobody’s right, nobody’s wrong,” go the words to “Faithless Love,” the aching country-rock ballad popularized by Linda Ronstadt 38 years ago in a memorable duet with its composer, J. D. Souther. On Friday evening Mr. Souther sang a solo rendition of “Faithless Love” at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series. With its plaintive winding melody and lyrics that picture an endless river of romantic sorrow, the song conjures the darker side of Southern California hedonism during the long-gone heyday of the Laurel Canyon troubadours.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Producer Price Index for December, and industrial production and capacity utilization for December (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Consumer Price Index for December, housing starts for December, and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for January (Thursday); and existing home sales for December (Friday).

headline: Do Thrifty Brains Make Better Minds?
text: Might the miserly use of neural resources be one of the essential keys to understanding how brains make sense of the world? Some recent work in computational and cognitive neuroscience suggests that it is indeed the frugal use of our native neural capacity (the inventive use of restricted “neural bandwidth,” if you will) that explains how brains like ours so elegantly make sense of noisy and ambiguous sensory input. That same story suggests, intriguingly, that perception, understanding and imagination, which we might intuitively consider to be three distinct chunks of our mental machinery, are inextricably tied together as simultaneous results of a single underlying strategy known as “predictive coding.” This strategy saves on bandwidth using (who would have guessed it?) one of the many technical wheezes that enable us to economically store and transmit pictures, sounds and videos using formats such as JPEG and MP3.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday. The stock and bond markets are closed Monday in observance of the Martin Luther King’s Birthday holiday.

headline: A Typical Ravens Success: With Grit and Without Fear
text: BALTIMORE — As television cameras and recorders descended on him in the Baltimore Ravens’ locker room late Sunday afternoon, Terrell Suggs tucked in his dress shirt, slipped into a vest and slid on his watch. Turning around to face reporters, Suggs instead found Ray Lewis waiting to fix his collar, which had stood up.

headline: ABC Kills ‘Work It’
text: The critically panned cross-dressing comedy “Work It” has been canceled by ABC after only two episodes. Repeats of the Tim Allen comedy “Last Man Standing” will run in its place starting Tuesday. “Work It” featured two unemployed men who tried dressing as women to get jobs. It was criticized ahead of its premiere by the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation and the Human Rights Campaign, which said in a joint statement that “by encouraging the audience to laugh at the characters’ attempts at womanhood, the show gives license to similar treatment of transgender women.” The show was poorly received by viewers in early January. Days before the schedule change was made public, Paul Lee, the president of ABC Entertainment, defended the show to TV reporters by saying, “We thought there was room for a very, very, very silly show.” ABC has not said what show will succeed “Work It” in the time slot on Tuesday at 8:30 p.m., but it may go to the returning sitcom “Cougar Town,” which has yet to be assigned a spot this season.

headline: Ricky Gervais, the Host With the Most (Friends in on the Joke)
text: More than a few eyebrows were raised when the Hollywood Foreign Press Association invited Ricky Gervais back to host the Golden Globes tonight. You may remember the kerfuffle that resulted the last time he emceed ceremonies and offended a few celebrities in the room. Or maybe they weren’t entirely offended, as our colleague Dave Itzkoff writes in his profile of the comedian. He adds that Mr. Gervais “has become the entertainment industry’s favorite irreverent person, because he manages to be irreverent in such a deeply reverent way.”

headline: The Ives Songbook, Without Interruption
text: “I think there must be a place in the soul all made of tunes, of tunes of long ago,” Charles Ives wrote in “The Things Our Fathers Loved.” He set that poem to music as the 43rd entry in “114 Songs,” the collection he published in 1922, which was performed in a four-hour marathon on Saturday by the young, ambitious Brooklyn Art Song Society at Galapagos Art Space.

Fortunately, the person assigned the topic for the American Realness festival at the Abrons Arts Center Underground Theater on Friday was Jennifer Lacey, an American artist based in Paris. Her lecture-performance “Gattica” approached the subject semisatirically and had some fun with it.

text: “I thought I had a handle on myself,” Danny tells the audience in “Dedalus Lounge,” a mesmerizing mess of a play at the Interart Theater Annex. “When will I be normal?” he asks, his voice shaking. Those lines are part of an unsettling monologue, and they’re not the only compelling moments in a story that is by turns earnest and odd, tender and disturbing.

headline: Revenge in Garden of Good and Evil
text: No one who encounters “The Poisoned Kiss,” the third of five operas by the English composer Ralph Vaughan Williams, can fail to see why it never found a place in the standard repertory. Seen in what was claimed to be its first professional New York production, mounted by the Bronx Opera Company in the Lovinger Theater at Lehman College on Saturday night, the work readily showed its intrinsic shortcomings: a plot too whimsical for modern tastes, a wayward libretto, a girth too protracted for the frivolity of its material.

headline: Section 5 and the Right to Vote
text: Is Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act still necessary? That provision requires nine states and some counties and towns with histories of severe racial discrimination to get approval from the Justice Department or a court before changing their voting procedures. The question hovers over three consolidated cases the Supreme Court heard last week on redistricting for legislative and Congressional seats in Texas, a state governed by Section 5.

headline: On the Trail of Mortgage Fraud
text: Queens has been harder hit by foreclosures than any other New York borough, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation believes it has found a culprit. Last July, the F.B.I. accused Edul Ahmad, a local broker, of a $50 million mortgage fraud, saying he lured fellow immigrants into subprime mortgages, inflated the values of their properties and concealed his involvement in deals that were ruinous for scores, if not hundreds, of borrowers. Mr. Ahmad pleaded not guilty, and posted $2.5 million bail. Now, according to court papers, as reported in The Times, he is plea-bargaining with federal prosecutors.

headline: Study on Teacher Value Uses Data From Before Teach-to-Test Era
text: My four children have all attended public schools in our middle-class suburban district. When my oldest was in fourth grade, in 1998, he took the state tests, and I was not even aware of it. Later, he said the tests were kind of fun; he got to miss his regular classes.

headline: Open to Interpretation
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: How Fares the Dream?
text: “I have a dream,” declared Martin Luther King, in a speech that has lost none of its power to inspire. And some of that dream has come true. When King spoke in the summer of 1963, America was a nation that denied basic rights to millions of its citizens, simply because their skin was the wrong color. Today racism is no longer embedded in law. And while it has by no means been banished from the hearts of men, its grip is far weaker than once it was.

headline: Suit on Police Treatment of Livery Riders Is to Proceed
text: A civil rights lawsuit accusing the New York Police Department of flouting the constitutional rights of livery cab passengers has been allowed to move forward by a federal judge, who denied the city’s attempt to have the suit dismissed.

headline: Flexing Muscle, Baghdad Detains U.S. Contractors
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi authorities have detained a few hundred foreign contractors in recent weeks, industry officials say, including many Americans who work for the United States Embassy, in one of the first major signs of the Iraqi government’s asserting its sovereignty after the American troop withdrawal last month.

headline: Big Stop From Boley Gives Giants a Lift

headline: The Scapegoat of Ball’s Bluff
text: As 1862 dawned, the Union’s military fortunes appeared decidedly grim. Defeats like those suffered at Bull Run and Ball’s Bluff, as well as the growing realization that Gen. George McClellan was at best a reluctant warrior, gave rise to a growing claque of congressional critics. On Dec. 10, 1861, they had established the Joint Committee on the Conduct of the War, designed to examine every aspect of the war effort and empowered to “send for person and papers” as needed. Far from being a dispassionate check on the Executive Branch, however, the committee was, from the very beginning, a tool for partisan politics, a weapon forged out of, in Senator Charles Sumner’s words, “a strong desire to hold someone responsible” for the Union Army’s recent misfortunes.

headline: Donors Gave as Santorum Won Earmarks

headline: Governor Who Took On Unions May Face a Closely Watched Recall Election

headline: Defying Gravity Proves Easier Than Escaping From Loneliness

headline: The Romney Advantage: Unequally Matched G.O.P. Rivals

headline: Huntsman Withdrawal Should Aid Romney
text: The impending withdrawal of Jon M. Huntsman Jr. from the presidential race, as reported by my colleagues Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny, should provide a small but helpful boost to the man he plans to endorse, Mitt Romney.

headline: Back to School, Not on a Campus but in a Beloved Museum
text: Wanted: 50 former science majors with an interest in teaching — no experience, please — and a willingness to relocate. Must be comfortable sharing a classroom with dinosaur bones and giant squid.

headline: As Syria Offers Amnesty, U.N. Urges End to Killing
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Sunday issued an amnesty for crimes committed during the 10-month uprising, at least the fourth such gesture since protests began and another official step that seemed to underscore the gap between the demonstrators’ demands and the government’s vision for change.

headline: Faculty Shortage Could Thwart India’s Education Dream

headline: Chinese Visit to Saudi Arabia Touches on Oil and Politics

headline: Day Care Centers Adapt to Round-the-Clock Demand
text: ELYRIA, Ohio — Dinner (chicken and mashed potatoes) was long over, teeth were brushed, and a rousing game of Monopoly had come to a close. It was 9 p.m., and the children nestled into bed under blankets emblazoned with superheroes.

headline: Bahrain Opposition Says King’s Measures Fall Short
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Bahrain’s king on Sunday announced constitutional amendments that will give the elected Parliament greater powers of scrutiny over the government, but the concessions fell short of the opposition’s demands for change.

headline: An Unexpected Focus Before the Next Primary
text: The Republican battle for South Carolina was supposed to have been a time for the state’s socially conservative voters to weed out the candidates they found unfit. Instead, the primary has been dominated by a loud and unruly argument over whether Bain Capital, the private equity firm that was led by Mitt Romney, drove companies out of business and put people out of work while enriching itself with billions of dollars.

headline: Russia’s Failed Mars Probe Crashes Into Pacific
text: A Russian scientific probe that was meant to visit a Martian moon but never made it out of Earth orbit crashed into the Pacific Ocean about 700 miles west of Chile on Sunday, a Russian military spokesman said.

headline: ‘The Artist’ and ‘The Descendants’ Take Globes
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Moviegoers looking to the Golden Globe Awards as Oscar forecasters should consider their bets hedged. “The Artist” was Sunday night’s big winner, taking home three prizes, including one for best comedy. But it was a photo finish with “The Descendants,” which won two awards, including best drama.

headline: The Met Reimagines the American Story
text: Right on time for the election year, American art has reoccupied the Metropolitan Museum of Art en masse. After four years of renovation the museum’s galleries of American painting and sculpture — long the most popular part of its now completely reopened American Wing — will be back on view on Monday, washed with light, rich with stories and scenic prospects, and packed with enough politics to fuel any presidential campaign.

headline: Hoarding Is Seen as Cause of Fuel Shortage in Egypt
text: CAIRO — A sudden shortage of gasoline gripped Egypt over the weekend, raising new concerns about its teetering economy and its political stability.

headline: Eight Men In: Savoring a Victory
text: Fifty years ago, if the Giants were headed to Green Bay to play the Packers in the postseason, fans in New York might have considered themselves lucky to catch the game on television. Today, with tickets available online and frequent-flier miles accruing with every credit-card purchase, fans can dare to dream a little more boldly. Six members of a Chatham, N.J., softball team — a mix of lawyers, Wall Streeters and computer software salesmen — traveled to Lambeau Field for Sunday’s showdown between the Giants and the Packers. It was a trip of cheap hotel rooms and high hopes, cramped rental cars and unexpectedly good seats at the game. They were joined by two pals in Milwaukee.

headline: Study of Retail Workers Finds $9.50 Median Pay
text: Retail workers in New York City earn a median of $9.50 an hour, most are part-time or temporary, and just 3 in 10 receive health insurance through their jobs, according to a new study of the city’s larger retailers.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Jason Biggs, Jim Cramer and Bitcoin Get in on the Action
text: It was a curious choice for “The Good Wife”: an episode built around an obscure digital currency called Bitcoin that many of the show’s viewers probably assumed was fictional. (If any Bitcoin evangelists find their way to this post, they can abuse me for calling the virtual money system, which went online in 2009, “obscure.”) The writers clearly loved the case at the center of “Bitcoin for Dummies” on Sunday night, though — I didn’t put a stopwatch on it, but it felt as if the Case of the Week received more time than it had for quite a while.

A decade ago, he received a New York Times College Scholarship, which he used to attend the University of Pennsylvania and earn bachelor’s and master’s degrees.

text: It’s difficult to walk for more than a block in most Prague neighborhoods without seeing a sign for a Chinese bistro. Most of these places are actually run by Vietnamese immigrants but have focused on dishes like sweet-and-sour chicken rather than pho or bun cha.

Mr. Sappern was most recently a senior vice president at Allscripts. The move by PeriGen, which is owned by private equity firms including Trident Capital, may set the company up for deal-making later this year.

headline: Pairings: Sweet-and-Sour Sardines
text: Name your quaff. White, red, still, sparkling, sweet or dry? We sampled them all in our tasting of wines from the Canary Islands. And as food-friendly as these well-balanced wines were, deciding exactly what food would work best with them was the challenge. Some sort of marinated fish seemed to be the best idea, especially one that delivered bold swagger to welcome a red wine. Mackerel, sardines, wahoo or tuna were possible draft choices; a dozen fresh sardines on ice in the market made the team. And dressed in a bright, lemony wine sauce enriched with honey, like a Venetian in saor preparation, they also flattered the wines, whether white, red or sparkling. Sweet would not have been off base either, but deserved to be saved for a cheese course or dessert.

headline: Grapes Born of Volcano and Sea
text: TO drink only the best-known wines from time-honored regions is a little like eating in the same restaurants over and over. You can’t go wrong, perhaps, but without the rewards of exploration, you are missing out on so much more.

headline: Passport for Life
text: MOSCOW — As of last Friday, I am an undocumented person in my own country. I cannot open or close a bank account, receive medical care at a state clinic, buy a cellphone, return a purchase to a store or enter into a contract, which my job requires me to do several times a day. All of these operations and many more require a valid internal passport, a peculiar document that may be the most significant vestige of the U.S.S.R. in modern Russian society.Back when we lived behind the Iron Curtain, these passports entitled us to travel only within the confines of the Soviet Union. Anyone lucky enough to be allowed to travel abroad was issued a special foreign-travel passport just for the occasion and had to surrender it upon returning home. When Russians acquired the right to travel freely, they got to keep their foreign-travel passports. But the internal passport refused to die. So now each adult Russian citizen has two passports. The documents look alike, except that the one for internal use is printed on lighter paper stock, making it feel less substantial.

headline: A Conversation With: Shoma Chaudhury
text: Since it started more than a decade ago, Tehelka has been one of the most aggressive investigative news outlets in India, reporting on and often using sting operations to uncover everything from cricket match-fixing to corruption in the defence industry, toppling government figures, sparking widespread investigations and sometimes raising questions about its methods along the way.

headline: Monday Reading: Where the Snow Is
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: In Milan, Never Dull
text: Casual observers slipping into the Hotel Principe di Savoia this weekend would have noticed they were not the only casual observers. All around the lobby and lounge, groups of young girls, ordering one bottle of water among them, sat with their eyes glued on the front door, hoping for a sighting of the performer Joe Jonas, who was in town, once again, to attend the Calvin Klein men’s show during Milan Fashion Week.

headline: The Golden Globes Applause Meter
text: It’s worth noting the crowd reaction inside the ballroom at the Golden Globes on Sunday. The Beverly Hilton Hotel auditorium was packed with a lot of Hollywood insiders who also get a vote at the Oscars. Who wins a Globe has nothing to do with who wins an Oscar. But the warmth of a winner’s reception in the room can tell a lot about Hollywood sentiment, and where the Oscar ballots are headed.

headline: Growing Doubts in Europe on Future of Carbon Storage
text: MADRID — The European Union’s long-term energy plans to abate global warming while still burning fossil fuels hinge on proposals to capture carbon dioxide emissions and store them in deep underground rock formations. Yet weak support for the untested technology is putting Europe in the rear ranks of its development.

text: Via Mark Thoma, Noah Smith* has a terrific piece on how to argue with economists. All the points are good, but I’d like to focus on Principle 4, “Argument by accounting identity almost never works.”

headline: Teacher Effectiveness Study Uses 1990s Data
text: A highly touted new study by researchers from Harvard and Columbia found a correlation between teacher effectiveness and students' success in life when it comes to earnings, going to college and teenage pregnancy. But Michael Winerip reports in his On Education column that the data comes from the 1990s, a pre-testing era. “It is a key limitation of the study,” Raj Chetty of Harvard, one of the three researchers, acknowledged in an interview.

headline: Teachers Trade Ideas on Keeping M.L.K. Fresh

Six teachers from different types of schools in New York City discuss how they make the civil rights leader and his legacy meaningful to students today.

headline: Exit Huntsman
text: Jon Huntsman had a more impressive resume, a better policy shop, better odds in November and stronger conservative bona fides than many of the candidates vying for the Republican nomination. But several of them are still running while he’s dropped out, and that almost all of them enjoyed temporary surges in the polls while he always languished at the bottom of the pack. For this, there’s plenty of blame to go around: Huntsman can blame the mainstream media, for constantly depicting him as the “sane Republican” tragically doomed to irrelevance by the folly of his party’s base; he can blame his own advisers, for embracing that self-defeating image and trying to re-run John McCain’s 2000 campaign in a very different climate; he can blame Republican voters for dismissing him because of symbolism and identity politics rather than judging him on his record; he can blame conservative machers and opinion-makers for doing the same. (He can even blame his father, who declined — or wasn’t asked, or both — to play Sheldon Adelson to his son’s cash-poor campaign.)

headline: Milan Top 5 | Burberry
text: The obsessively descriptive list of coat styles in the notes for Christopher Bailey’s fantastic Burberry Prorsum show read like a comprehensive history of English outerwear: “heritage trench coats, luggage lock duffle coats, sartorial tailored Chesterfields, college stripe down-filled car coats, cropped bomber jackets” and on and on and on. This is a house built on a coat — the trench — and Bailey always sticks smartly to the program. The torso-hugging, slim-legged suits at the show’s opening were my favorites, with models in tweed flat caps toting umbrellas with carved animal head handles, their coats over their shoulders or buttoned up tight against the cold.

headline: ‘Chinglish’ to Close
text: David Henry Hwang’s Broadway comedy “Chinglish,” about the misadventures and cultural misunderstanding of an American businessman as he is trying to close a deal in China, will end its run on Jan. 29, after 128 performances. The bilingual play, which features Gary Wilmes as the businessman and Jennifer Lim as a Chinese official who becomes his unlikely ally and lover, opened at the Longacre Theater in October to generally favorable reviews, and was named by Time magazine as the No. 1 new American play of 2011. Despite those accolades, and the strong reputation of Mr. Hwang, a Tony Award winner whose previous work includes “M. Butterfly,” box office sales remained modest.

headline: Omelets: The Ultimate Fast Food
text: For some time now the medical literature has been countering the myth that the cholesterol in eggs goes straight to the arteries and that eggs should be shunned by anybody committed to healthy eating. Studies have shown that only a small amount of dietary cholesterol passes into the blood and that saturated fats and trans fats have much bigger effects on cholesterol levels. In fact, according to the Harvard School of Public Health, the only large study that looked at the effect of egg consumption on heart disease found no correlation between the two, except among people with diabetes, who were a bit more likely to develop heart disease if they ate an egg a day.

headline: American McHale Upsets Safarova

headline: Taliban Declares Victory, as Fighting Goes On

headline: Penguins, Hockey and Serious Stuff Too: Scott’s Polar Chronicles
text: The British explorer Robert Falcon Scott finally reached his destination a century ago, Jan. 17, 1912, more than a month too late to claim victory in the race to be first to the South Pole. But the triumphant Norwegian Roald Amundsen could not deny him at least one distinction: Scott was the founder of The South Polar Times, the first magazine to be produced on the Antarctic continent.

headline: Depression Defies the Rush to Find an Evolutionary Upside
text: In certain quarters of academia, it’s all the rage these days to view human behavior through the lens of evolutionary biology. What survival advantages, researchers ask, may lie hidden in our actions, even in our pathologies?

headline: Milan Top 5 | Prada
text: Miuccia Prada’s extravagant show entitled “Il Palazzo” had the typically reserved fashion crowd hooting and hollering by the end of it, so great was the spectacle. Capital “A” actors, including Tim Roth, Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe and Gary Oldman (looking perfectly arch in his part), made a regal procession across a room-dwarfing red carpet that was better fit for monarchs than for models. That said, Oldman’s beautifully cut, high-buttoned double-breasted coat over a layered white turtleneck and crisp white shirt looked ready to reign.

headline: Cracking Open the Scientific Process
text: The New England Journal of Medicine marks its 200th anniversary this year with a timeline celebrating the scientific advances first described in its pages: the stethoscope (1816), the use of ether for anesthesia (1846), and disinfecting hands and instruments before surgery (1867), among others.

headline: Florida Evangelical Leader Now Backs Santorum
text: John Stemberger, president of Florida Family Action, on Monday became one of the first evangelical leaders to switch his support to Rick Santorum after a meeting of evangelicals in Texas last week voted to support Mr. Santorum in his bid for the 2012 Republican nomination.

headline: Son of a Gun
text: One grunt did Marine push-ups. A few guys lolled on their bunks. The model Ricardo Felix, buck-naked and with his back to the audience, rinsed himself under a shower. In a barber chair, Francesco Guzzi received a painful new piece of permanent artwork on his left bicep from Simone Falcetta, a former equestrian champion now best known as the pre-eminent tattoo master of Milan.

headline: Personal Health: Lifelines for People With Hearing Loss
text: Hearing loss, a disability currently untreated in about 85 percent of those affected, may be the nation’s most damaging and costly sensory handicap. It is a hidden disability, often not obvious to others or even to those who have it.

headline: The Caucus Click: Then There Were Five …
text: A sand sculpture here depicting the Republican presidential candidates was correct yesterday, at least. Now there are five.

headline: Puerto Rico Traces Baseball’s Slide to the Draft
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — This used to be the climax of baseball’s peak season in Puerto Rico. The storied winter league lured many of Major League Baseball’s biggest Puerto Rican stars back to the island — from Roberto Clemente and Orlando Cepeda to Roberto Alomar and Bernie Williams — and they would regularly play before tens of thousands of fans during what was otherwise their off-season.

headline: Political Tourism Comes to South Carolina
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Political tourists are a familiar breed in Iowa and New Hampshire. People in the rest of the country understand that voters in those two states have unparalleled access to presidential candidates, and they like to travel there to catch the unique flavor of a presidential race in its early stages and get an up-close look at the contenders while they are still working out their schtick.

headline: Forget the Charts, Adele Tops Karaoke Too
text: Just how popular is Adele becoming? A new survey by a market research group in Britain has found that two songs recorded by the singer accounted for more than a third of all karaoke performances there in 2011. Leading the list, not surprisingly, was “Someone Like You,” a hit single from the CD “21,” which was chosen by one in four karaoke singers and is also up for a Grammy next month in the best pop performance category. In second place, with 10 percent of the three million total performances tabulated, was her cover version of Bob Dylan’s “Make You Feel My Love,” a track from her debut CD, “19.” The top non-Adele karaoke song was “Heroes,” a track written by David Bowie and Brian Eno in the 1970s that enjoyed a resurgence of popularity after it was featured on the television program “The X Factor.”

headline: BASF to Stop Selling Genetically Modified Products in Europe
text: BRUSSELS — BASF, the German chemical group, has abandoned efforts to sell genetically modified products in Europe, including its Amflora potato, because of overwhelming opposition to the technology, the company said Monday.

headline: Liberia’s President Stresses Reconciliation in Second Inaugural Speech

headline: Day Care That’s Available at Night, Too
text: Good day care is hard to find. Good “day” care for the night shift? Impossible, or at least it used to be. Sabrina Tavernise reports that as working hours change (about 40 percent of the American labor force works nonstandard hours now, particularly in the growing fields of nursing, retail and food service), some child-care centers are changing, too. Centers providing “after hours” care make up a large part of growth for a company that runs employer-sponored child-care centers, and many independent child-care centers are offering expanded hours — dinner, homework help and bedtime included.

headline: Hulu Commissions Its First Original Scripted Programming
text: 3:02 p.m. | Updated The online video service Hulu, most of whose programming consists of material licensed from television and film companies, has commissioned its first original script-based program, which is scheduled to be available on Hulu’s free web service, rather than its premium pay Hulu Plus site, as of the middle of next month. Called “Battleground,” the new series is described as a faux documentary-style political drama-comedy set in Wisconsin– which in real life has emerged as a frontline in combat between liberals and conservatives since Republican governor Scott Walker took office a year ago.

She’s one of my idols!”

headline: Slightly Fewer Viewers for This Year’s Golden Globes
text: In a year in which nine of the top 10 movies at the box office have been sequels, perhaps it was appropriate that Ricky Gervais served up a slightly less compelling version of last year’s Golden Globe Awards. NBC said on Monday that its live Globes telecast on Sunday night drew 16.8 million viewers, down a whisker from last year’s 17 million. About 4 percent fewer people in the target demographic, adults age 18 to 49, tuned in, as measured by raw ratings points. (A 5.0 this year compared to a 5.2 last year.) NBC had heavily promoted Mr. Gervais’s acerbic comedic style as a reason to watch. As promised, he delivered a crude monologue – a repeat performance of 2011, when his remarks drew gasps – but shocking people twice with the same shtick is hard to pull off. Other factors possibly affecting interest in the show: NBC has limited ability to promote itself (the network’s overall schedule remains in the ratings basement), and the Globes also celebrated a batch of smaller films like “The Artist” that have produced limited box-office results. Still, the telecast was a win for NBC, delivering the network’s biggest audience, excluding sporting events, since last year’s Globes.

headline: Hungary, Once a Star, Loses Its Shine
text: BUDAPEST — Zoltan Zsoter, an 80-year-old retiree, would seem to be about as far from the world of currency speculation as a person can get. Yet he is an example of how the workings of the global financial system, amplified by the policies of a single political leader, can have a devastating effect on ordinary people.

headline: Juilliard School Announces $20 Million Gift for Early Music
text: Devotees of early music in New York may be experiencing whiplash. The year began in inspiriting fashion, with the Green Mountain Project’s superb annual presentation of Vespers music by Monteverdi, sponsored by Trinity Church at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste. Then, days later, a bleak midwinter seemed to settle in, when Trinity declared a hiatus in its own music program, suspending the activities of its excellent Trinity Choir and Baroque Orchestra at least until March. Now, on Tuesday, the Juilliard School is announcing a $20 million gift to endow its graduate-level program in historical performance. The sheer size of the gift is enough to make heads snap in the early-music world, whose practitioners typically struggle to stay a step ahead of poverty.

headline: For Intrigue, Malaria Drug Gets the Prize

headline: Yeast Experiment Hints at a Faster Evolution From Single Cells
text: Our ancestors were single-celled microbes for about three billion years before they evolved bodies. But in a laboratory at the University of Minnesota, brewer’s yeast cells can evolve primitive bodies in about two weeks.

headline: When Breakthroughs Begin at Home
text: Cathal Garvey’s home laboratory in Cork, Ireland, is filled with makeshift equipment. His incubator for bacteria is an old Styrofoam shipping box with a heating mat and thermometer that he has modified into a thermostat. He uses a pressure cooker to sterilize instead of an autoclave. Some instruments are fashioned from coffee cans.

text: Nearly a third of middle-aged Americans regularly take a baby aspirin in the hope of preventing a heart attack or a stroke or lowering their cancer risk. headline: Anna Dello Russo, Always the Fashion Chameleon

headline: Tunes in Which Everything Is So Complicated
text: To the casual listener the theater songs of William Finn may sound like the agitated stream of consciousness of a compulsive talker running off at the mouth — their loose structures held together by seemingly haphazard internal rhymes. The words sometimes spill over the music. But if you pay close attention to a song like “How to Make Delicious Chocolate Pudding,” a jolly banjo-inflected number sung by Megan Lawrence at the Allen Room on Saturday evening as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, you discover a witty short story that follows its own unconventional songwriting logic.

headline: Lobbyist for Students? New Yorkers Have Their Doubts

headline: Going by Twitter,  Globes Were a Big Hit
text: The ratings for the Globes may have dipped slightly, but it was a robust presence on Twitter, where the Tweets-per-second (TPS) count reached 6,162 at its highest point, more than last year’s Super Bowl (4,064 TPS) or the royal wedding (3,966), though still less than the MTV Video Music Awards (8,868 TPS, which had the advantage of the Beyonce bump).

headline: Lush and Sweet Sounds, by Way of a Youthful Ensemble
text: The early-20th-century Spanish violinist Manuel Quiroga is not as well known internationally as his compatriots Sarasate and Casals, but he is an esteemed figure in Spain. The Cuarteto Quiroga, a youthful ensemble founded in Madrid in 2004, is keeping his name alive and creating curiosity about him among listeners outside Spain, and is doing him proud. Its program, in the intimate concert room at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon, was exquisite: precise, perfectly balanced, interpretively fresh performances, couched in consistently warm hues.

headline: Worlds Within Worlds Within Worlds. And a Duane Reade.
text: All sorts of walls come tumbling down in “World of Wires,” Jay Scheib’s slap-happy, mixed-media murder mystery at the Kitchen. Divisions between reality (that old chimera) and perception — not to mention the borders that separate screen from stage and human from machine — are stomped upon with the glee of a precocious, permanently stoned, science-fiction-reading 14-year-old who has just discovered, like, philosophy, dude.

headline: Silent on the Plane, but Chatty With the Locals
text: ALTHOUGH I really feel as if I’m part of a cattle herd every time I’m at the airport, I still love being on a plane. I don’t have to do anything if I don’t want to. When you work crazy hours, that time to do nothing is really precious.

headline: At Versace Party, the Show Goes On
text: MILAN — Donatella Versace organized a customary dinner party following her men’s fashion show in Milan on Monday night, inviting a few guests into the ornate apartment where Gianni Versace once resided, on the second floor of the company’s headquarters. Once the last of the models, who walked in a collection Ms. Versace called “tough glamour,” had changed into more casual Versace sportswear and made their way upstairs from the show, a man walked through the crowd telling them, “The show is about to start.” Hadn’t it just ended?

text: SINCE the first of the year, I’ve had many conversations with business travelers who said they had made a last-minute trip in December to top off their miles flown for 2011 and qualify for renewal of some level of elite status for 2012.

headline: In Heated Primary Fight, Romney Keeps Focus on Obama
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Speaking at the South Carolina Faith and Freedom Coalition before yet another Republican debate here in Myrtle Beach Monday night, Mitt Romney kept his focus on President Obama, making a point of drawing contrasts between himself and the president on social issues.

headline: Luisi Crosses Border To American Territory
text: During the last couple of seasons, audiences in New York have had ample opportunities to get to know the work of Fabio Luisi, the Metropolitan Opera’s principal conductor, who has been taking over most of the performances the ailing James Levine has had to withdraw from. But on Sunday afternoon Mr. Luisi, conducting the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, revealed another dimension to his artistry. Who would have expected this Italian maestro to be so at home conducting Copland’s jazzy Clarinet Concerto, let alone an aria from “Wuthering Heights,” the only opera by Bernard Herrmann, of “Psycho” fame?

headline: Iran Face-Off Testing Obama the Candidate
text: WASHINGTON — The escalating American confrontation with Iran poses a major new political threat to President Obama as he heads into his campaign for re-election, presenting him with choices that could harm either the economic recovery or his image as a firm leader.

headline: A Merger Proposal For Actors’ Unions
text: After five rounds and nearly two years of negotiations aimed at producing a merger, the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, the two main unions representing actors and other performing artists, have agreed on the terms of an agreement, leaders of both groups said on Monday. No specifics of the accord were officially announced, but news reports said that all differences regarding a new constitution, dues-paying procedures and a governing structure had been resolved. The boards of both groups are scheduled to vote on the agreement on Jan. 28; the guild represents about 125,000 actors, and the federation’s approximately 70,000 members include broadcasters, singers and dancers as well as actors.

headline: As ‘Idol’ Returns, It Must Face New Rivals
text: PASADENA, Calif. — “American Idol” is returning to the Fox network this week amid a growing roster of competitors, but its stars and producers say they sense no threat from the other singing contest on Fox this season, “The X Factor,” and especially not from the version on NBC, “The Voice,” that will start a second season next month.

headline: Beneath Pink Parasols, Identity in Stark Form
text: Young Jean Lee is, hands down, the most adventurous downtown playwright of her generation. In previous shows this Korean-American writer has devised a comic revue about black identity politics, retailored Shakespeare’s “King Lear” and taken to the stage herself to perform a cabaret act mostly about death.

headline: Wayward Children Of the ’80s
text: During his contribution to a shared evening as part of the American Realness festival at the Abrons Arts Center on Sunday, the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones took on animal cruelty, bondage, teenage murderers and Satan worship. But the part that most likely triggered traumatic memories came before all of that, at the very beginning, when the audience was herded onto the stage and greeted by a nervous-seeming man in a sweater vest and tie. The setting was clear: a high-school assembly.

headline: A Warrior’s Quest for Fame, Ending in a Last Stand
text: It’s too bad reality television didn’t come along about a century earlier than it did. There might never have been a Battle of the Little Bighorn because George A. Custer would have channeled his energy into competing on “Dancing With the Stars” instead.

headline: Louise J. Kaplan, Psychoanalyst and Author, Dies at 82

headline: Thwarted Travelers

headline: Many Ills, Constant Care, but Calling Her Own Shots
text: Verona Peters is clear: nursing homes are just not for her. Yes, she takes more than 300 pills a month and needs constant care for a litany of ailments: failing kidneys, high blood pressure, diabetes, congestive heart failure and a bout of diverticular bleeding. Yes, she undergoes dialysis, and the colostomy bag attached to her abdomen must be changed twice a week.

headline: Convenient, but How Secure?
text: According to a survey commissioned by the American Bankers Association last year, 62 percent of Americans preferred to do their banking online rather than at a branch or ATM. Banks and their online customers also lost more than $2 billion in 2010 because of payment card scams, fraudulent wire transfers and other Internet swindles, according to data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as reported by The Financial Times.

headline: A New Day in Suffolk? Here’s Hoping
text: Suffolk County on Long Island got a new county executive this month, Steve Bellone. In his inaugural speech, he went down the list of things he intended to do, like fix the county’s budget woes, hold the line on taxes, make government more efficient, create jobs and affordable housing, and invest in “clean water infrastructure.”

headline: Suspect in Killings of Homeless Men Has Family Link to Homelessness
text: YORBA LINDA, Calif. — The man charged on Tuesday with the stabbing deaths four homeless men in Orange County over the last month, Itzcoatl Ocampo, has a personal connection to the area’s group of homeless: his father lives among them.

headline: Counting Voters Fairly
text: A Federal District Court late last month wisely upheld a 2010 Maryland law that counts prison inmates as residents in their home communities for purposes of redistricting, rather than at the prisons where they are incarcerated.

headline: 9 Years Later, Sorry Still Doesn’t Cut It
text: Matt Allen visited his friend Lawrence Tynes, the Giants’ kicker, at the team’s practice facility last month. Allen — a former punter for the Giants who played with Tynes in college — recalled that as he walked through the building, he realized there were no active players remaining from his final N.F.L. game.

headline: Black Voters Are Wary as Hopefuls Seek Kinship
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — On Martin Luther King’s Birthday, Newt Gingrich spoke to black voters about growing up in segregated Georgia.

text: MELBOURNE, Australia – When Sam Querrey of the United States flashed his slap forehand with a flourish Monday, he overwhelmed Kenny De Schepper of France, a qualifier, 6-3, 6-2, 6-2.

headline: Belgian Church Offices Raided in Abuse Inquiry
text: BRUSSELS — The Belgian authorities searched the offices of bishops in three cities on Monday, removing documents as part of an investigation into child sexual abuse that has plunged the country’s Roman Catholic church into crisis.

headline: Giving Fox Viewers a Clear Window Into Officiating
text: The controversial call during a divisional playoff game between the Giants and the Green Bay Packers on Sunday looked like a perfect Mike Pereira moment. The Giants were leading in the first quarter, 10-3, and one game official ruled that Packers receiver Greg Jennings had fumbled the ball after a catch, but a second official said Jennings’s calf was down before the ball came loose.

headline: Perry Prods Romney on Tax Returns at Debate
text: Rick Perry just put Mitt Romney on the spot, urging him to release his tax returns.

headline: Quietly Confident, Giants Quickly Look Ahead to N.F.C. Title Game
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ locker room was quiet on Monday. There was no hollering among teammates or loud music playing from the speakers. This is how the Giants operate, and it may explain why they are playing this late in the season.

headline: No Closure for Denver’s Beltway Loop
text: GOLDEN, Colo. — Breathes there a soul who really, truly, loves a beltway? Maybe, but you are not likely to find one here in this little city in the Rocky Mountain foothills west of Denver.

headline: The Loneliness of the Guyanas
text: The coming weekend might very well be an historic one for Franco-Brazilian relations. Nicolas Sarkozy will be in French Guiana to deliver his annual New Year’s address to France’s overseas territories, in which he is likely to announce the opening of the bridge across the Oyapock River, French Guiana’s border with Brazil.

text: Sumter, S.C.

headline: Struggling, Egypt Seeks Loan From I.M.F.
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers asked the International Monetary Fund on Monday for a $3.2 billion loan that they had previously rejected, bowing to the realities of a worsening economy nearly a year after the exit of the strongman Hosni Mubarak.

text: An exchange between Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum just now is a reflection of the tension that has built up between the two of them.

headline: Jew Is Charged in Anti-Semitic Acts; Police Cite Business Dispute
text: In December, an 80-year-old Jewish woman in the Sheepshead Bay area of Brooklyn received several phone calls in which the caller made anti-Semitic threats. On Thursday, a 78-year-old Jewish woman living nearby received a similar call.

headline: Dilapidated Distinction for the Rangers’ Best
text: For the first time, the Broadway Hat, a black fedora with a ribbon and a bow, is making its way around the Rangers’ dressing room. No one can, or will, say where the hat came from. The rules for the hat are sketchy. And the looks of the hat are deteriorating.

headline: Embracing the Pretzel
text: At debates his opponents sported ties with colors from the flag: blue or, better yet, blistering Republican red.

headline: Invoking King, Cuomo and Bloomberg Stoke Fight on Teacher Review Impasse
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, each irate that a stalemate over teacher evaluations is endangering federal education aid, fixed their sights Monday on a shared opponent: what they derided as New York State’s education bureaucracy.

headline: An Education, Over the Border and Under the Radar
text: Dozens of high school students cross from Tijuana, Mexico, into Southern California every day to attend American high schools.

headline: Young U.S. Citizens in Mexico Brave Risks for American Schools
text: TIJUANA, Mexico — Weekday mornings at 5, when the lights on distant hillsides across the border still twinkle in the blackness, Martha, a high school senior, begins her arduous three-hour commute to school. She groggily unlocks the security gate guarded by the family Doberman and waits in the glare of the Pemex filling station for the bus to the border. Her fellow passengers, grown men with their arms folded, jostle her in their sleep.

headline: Debate Fact-Check: ‘Super PAC’ Coordination
text: When Mitt Romney was criticized tonight for attack ads that a “super PAC” supporting him has run against his opponents, he dismissed the suggestion that he could do anything about it.

headline: Despite Long Slide by Kodak, Company Town Avoids Decay
text: ROCHESTER — In what was once the ultimate company town, virtually everyone has a trove of bright Kodak moments.

headline: Britain: Nazi Game Led to Brawl, University Student Says
text: The London School of Economics said Monday that it was investigating allegations that a Nazi-themed drinking game during a student union ski trip to the French resort of Val d’Isère last month led to a brawl in which a Jewish student’s nose was broken. The university, one of Britain’s most renowned academic institutions, said in a statement that it was “prepared to take disciplinary action.” The university’s student newspaper said the drinking game involved arranging playing cards on a table in the shape of a swastika, and that players were required to “salute the Führer.” The student who claimed to have been assaulted was not identified by the university, but The Guardian newspaper, quoting an interview with him, said that he had left the card game after “a mix of personal references and general Jewish insults,” that led him to conclude that “I couldn’t forgive myself if I let it slide.” The university was shaken by controversy last year over its decision to accept a $450,000 donation for research from a foundation run by Saif al-Islam al-Qaddafi, a son of the former Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Can a Few Years’ Data Reveal Bad Teachers?
text: Better teachers lead to better test scores and better lives. But with only a few years' data, can districts tell which teachers are good?

headline: Tuesday: Deeply Impressed
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Elizabeth A. Long has had a few puzzles published in The New York Times each year since 2007, although today’s grid is her first Tuesday. Now she has a puzzle for every day of the week, except weekends. So, Ms. Long: are you planning to bat for the cycle any time soon?

headline: Nadal Mends Fences With Federer and Overcomes Knee Problem to Win
text: MELBOURNE — Perhaps Roger Federer had a point about the benefits of keeping negative thoughts out of the public domain. Only a day after Rafael Nadal deviated from a long-established pattern and ripped his friendly rival Federer at a news conference, Nadal sheepishly said that he regretted the outburst, still valued their connection and should have made his comments to Federer in private.

headline: Debate Fact Check: Romney’s 120,000 Jobs
text: While defending his record as a corporate buyout specialist at Bain Capital, Mitt Romney said tonight that companies he had invested in while at Bain “ended up today having some 120,000 jobs.” That number is slightly higher than the usual figure Mr. Romney cites on the campaign trail for job creation under Bain’s supervision – 100,000 – and neither number tells the full story.

headline: A Development Test in Adirondack Park
text: Ballston Lake, N.Y.

headline: Afghanistan: 3 U.S. Contractors Are Killed in Helicopter Crash
text: Three American private contractors working for the Defense Department were killed when their helicopter crashed in southern Afghanistan on Monday, their company said. The contractors’ company, AAR Airlift, said that there were no other passengers on the helicopter and that the cause of the crash was not yet known. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the crash, but Marjan Haqmal, the chief of police of the Nad Ali district of Helmand Province, where the crash took place, said the helicopter had technical problems.

headline: Debate Fact Check: Romney on Tax Returns
text: Mitt Romney declined to commit to release his income-tax returns when challenged twice, first by Gov. Rick Perry and then by a debate questioner, but said he might do so in April. Last month, he had said in an interview that he doubted that he would release the returns.

headline: Romney Is Opponents’ Main Target in G.O.P. Debate
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Mitt Romney withstood forceful attacks during a debate here on Monday evening, with his Republican rivals lining up to question his job-creation record, wealth and character, as they implored voters to scrutinize his candidacy more deeply before allowing him to sail to the party’s presidential nomination.

headline: Growth Fell for China at Year End
text: BEIJING — China’s economy slowed further in the fourth quarter of 2011, the government reported, lowering the growth in gross domestic product for the year to 9.2 percent, from 10.4 percent in 2010.

headline: Mott Wins 3rd Eclipse Prize as the Nation’s Top Trainer
text: Bill Mott is a patient man, and it paid off for him Monday night when he was given his third Eclipse Award as the nation’s outstanding trainer.

headline: A Climate Change Idea That Might Work
text: A new proposal to slow global warming is extraordinary, John Tierney writes in The New York Times, because it would help poor countries now, and “it might actually work.”

headline: U.S. Women’s Olympic Roster Includes Only One New Face
text: Sydney Leroux, the U.C.L.A. striker who was the first pick in last week’s W.P.S. draft, was one of 20 players named to U.S. Soccer’s roster for the Concacaf Olympic qualifying tournament in Canada this month.

text: Times reporters take a closer look at some of the statements made by the Republican presidential candidates during Monday night’s debate in Myrtle Beach, S.C.

headline: With Bill, Washington State Shifts Its Views on Marriage
text: SEATTLE — The bill that would legalize same-sex marriage in Washington State is notable not just for the boldness of its ambition or for the fact that it was proposed by Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat whose last memorable remarks on the issue placed her firmly in the not-yet camp.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Betty White’s Off Their Rockers’
text: What’s the best way to breathe new life into a tired television idea? Not turn it over to the Betty White generation, apparently.

headline: Open Science, Numberplay style!
text: This week’s Science Times has a cover article by Thomas Lin about the open science movement, one of the whose ideas is that by collaborating over a large network, scientists can solve difficult problems much faster than they could alone. Thomas immediately realized that this is exactly the kind of problem-solving approach that happens every week on Numberplay. We have at various times referred to our unique communal problem-solving approach as a “collaboratory” and “a microcosm of how science progresses.” Thomas invited me to design a Numberplay problem that showcased this online collaboration.

headline: Santorum Releases His First Ad Attacking Romney
text: Rick Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator who has called himself the “consistent conservative,” released his first campaign ad that directly attacks Mitt Romney.

headline: Stosur, U.S. Open Champion, Topples Out in Melbourne
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Samantha Stosur, the reigning United States Open champion, became the highest seed to fall from the Australian Open on Tuesday, losing her first-round match to Sorana Cirstea of Romania, 7-6 (2), 6-3, before a stunned partisan crowd at Rod Laver Arena.

headline: Hasina Kharbhih: Raising the Stakes Against Child Trafficking
text: Hasina Kharbhih, 40, has spent the better part of her life working for human rights. She started a nonprofit, Impulse, and developed a comprehensive strategy to prevent child trafficking called the Meghalaya Model, which is being applied in eight Indian states. The activist, who is based in Shillong in the northeastern state of Meghalaya, was in Delhi earlier this month to receive a North East Excellence Award from the Indian Chamber of Commerce. The award honored her service in the field of human rights and trafficking, HIV and AIDS intervention, and for providing livelihood support for individuals in the rural areas of the northeast.

headline: U.S. Presses South Korea to Reduce Oil Imports from Iran
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A senior American diplomat urged South Korea on Tuesday to reduce its imports of Iranian crude oil as the United States continued to seek support from major Asian economies to increase pressure on Tehran to halt its nuclear program.

headline: More Bodies Found on Ship, as Transcripts Reveal Rebuke to Captain
text: GIGLIO, Italy — Rescuers pulled five bodies clad in sodden life vests from the partly sunken cruise liner Costa Concordia on Tuesday, bringing the death toll in the disaster to at least 11, as the Italian news media published transcripts of a tense screaming match between the coast guard and the captain, who fled to a lifeboat after he smashed the ship on a reef.

headline: Jan. 17, 1893 | Hawaiian Monarchy Overthrown by America-Backed Businessmen
text: On Jan. 17, 1893, Hawaii’s monarchy was overthrown when a group of businessmen and sugar planters forced Queen Liliuokalani to abdicate. The coup led to the dissolving of the Kingdom of Hawaii two years later, its annexation as a U.S. territory and eventual admission as the 50th state in the union.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 17, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Op-Ed article “The Rise of the New Groupthink.”

headline: Lost and Alone Under Tokyo’s Red Rain
text: Soon after shooting memorial concerts on the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, my sister called to tell me that our father had died unexpectedly. Two days later, I returned to Japan for the first time in 20 years to attend his funeral. I felt constant vertigo, like I had been violently cut and pasted from New York to Tokyo.

headline: Nearly 90,000 Minis Recalled for Fire Hazard
text: After an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Mini is recalling almost 89,000 of its turbocharged models because they could catch fire when the engine is off.

headline: London Art Fair to Showcase Modern Works
text: Britain’s largest modern and contemporary art show, the London Art Fair, will present works from more than 120 major galleries from Jan. 18 through Jan. 22 at the Business Design Centre, 52 Upper Street. Novices will find themselves side-by-side with museum curators, gallery dealers and artists, all eager to see the paintings, drawings, large-scale sculpture, installations, photography and video on offer. Twenty-four thousand people attended last year.

headline: 49ers Nostalgia: Revisiting Walsh and Montana

headline: What Is the Right Amount of Group Work in School?
text: Group work — love it or hate it, it’s a regular part of the school or work day for many of us. Do you enjoy collaborating with your classmates on projects? Do you learn better as part of a group or by working independently? Do you prefer one style or the other? Why?

headline: With Redesign, a Special Retailer Tries to Create an Equally Special Web Site
text: Bi-Rite Market is something of an institution in San Francisco. A grocery store with a huge and faithful following, it doesn’t see itself as just a grocery store. People actually line up on the street to get inside. The reviews for the store on Yelp are overwhelmingly positive. The homepage on the store’s Web site proclaims, “Bi-Rite is a neighborhood market, feeding our community with love, passion & integrity.”

headline: For Butler, a Slow Start
text: In 2010 and 2011, the Butler Bulldogs were college basketball’s favorite Cinderella story. But this season has been a struggle. Matt Rhinesmith, a sports reporter for The Butler Collegian, will file occasional posts for The Quad about the team’s efforts to return to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: British Maker of Recycled Packaging in $2 Billion Deal
text: LONDON – DS Smith, a British maker of recycled packaging, agreed on Tuesday to buy a packaging unit of Svenska Cellulosa of Sweden for $2 billion to expand its market share in Europe.

headline: Olympus Clears Auditors in an Accounting Cover-Up
text: TOKYO — Olympus, the Japanese camera maker whose executives have admitted to covering up $1.7 billion in losses, said Tuesday that its auditors, KPMG Azsa and Ernst & Young ShinNihon, had not been complicit in the false accounting — though those firms remain under investigation by the Japanese authorities over possible roles in the scandal.

headline: To Intervene or Not to Intervene?
text: As protesters calling for an end to President Bashar al-Assad’s regime continue to be killed in Syria — and with observers from the Arab League due to present a report on the situation this week — commentators consider the prospects of a foreign intervention to stop the bloodshed.

headline: On the Horizon, Planes Powered by Plant Fuel
text: The use of jet fuel from renewable sources is now well demonstrated, but it costs more than double what fuel made from petroleum does, according to airlines, aircraft companies and suppliers. One way to cut the cost may be to tinker with the plants that biofuel is made from.

headline: Morning Take-Out
