headline: Citigroup Earnings Fall Short of Expectations
text: 7:57 p.m. | Updated

headline: Organizers Settle Dispute Over Fashion Week Dates
text: Just as the men’s runway collections came to a close in Milan on Tuesday, organizers of the shows in New York and London announced that they have settled, for now, a dispute over the dates of the women’s runway shows planned this September. The New York and London collections will not overlap with those of Milan, as had been risked by a standoff between the cities over when the season should begin.

headline: European Court Rules Britain Cannot Deport Terrorism Suspect
text: LONDON — The European Court of Human Rights ruled Tuesday that Abu Qatada, a radical Islamic preacher regarded as one of Al Qaeda’s main inspirational leaders in Europe, cannot be deported from Britain to his native Jordan because his trial there would be tainted by evidence obtained by torture.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Plans to Name Names in Fight Against Worm
text: The computer worm known as Koobface was a menace to Facebook users over the past few years, and it played a role in sharpening Facebook’s defenses against attackers of all kinds. Now Facebook is planning to disclose the names of the men it believes are behind the worm, Riva Richmond reports in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Gingrich Finds a Foil and Wikipedia Protests SOPA
text: The presidential debate in South Carolina Monday night — sponsored by Fox News, The Wall Street Journal and the state Republican Party — was notable for its raucous crowd. Newt Gingrich, who was considered by most analysts to have had a very successful night, “seemed to revel” in using one of the questioners, the Fox News analyst Juan Williams, as his foil, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg write. Mr. Gingrich won loud, sustained applause when replying with mock impatience to Mr. Williams who pressed him about his call for schoolchildren to work as janitors, for his description of Mr. Obama as a “food stamp president” and remarks that Mr. Williams said, to loud boos, seemed “intended to belittle the poor.”

headline: Cheryl Tyler: Something Worth Fighting For
text: In December, Public School 277 in the Bronx was slated for possible closure, but school officials decided to keep it open. Ms. Tyler, the principal, said she knows there is much work ahead.

headline: Cuomo Ties State Aid to Teacher Evaluations
text: The governor and mayor each took aim at the teachers unions at M.L.K. Day events and pressed for a more stringent teacher evaluation system. But the governor is about to move beyond rhetoric: In his executive budget, he is expected to announce Tuesday that he will require the creation of an evaluation system as a condition for school districts to receive a scheduled increase in state education aid.

headline: Vain Glorious | Borrowed From the Boys
text: I’ve been wearing men’s cologne since the day I was tall enough to reach for my father’s Van Cleef & Arpels Pour Homme. The striking black lacquered bottle held far more appeal than the delicate, glass-encased floral fragrances on my mother’s vanity, as did the rich, intoxicating aroma. It appears my infatuation with masculine scents is more common than spring’s focus on hyper-feminine fragrances might lead us to believe. Here, five of the city’s trendsetters reveal their own androgynous olfactory obsessions.Santa Maria Novella Acqua di Cuba Cologne“I wear this fragrance because it smells like the Maquis in Corsica, the island where I was born.” — Garance Doré, photographer, illustrator and writer

headline: A ‘Bridesmaids’ Star on Naked Clowns and a Very Special Scene
text: If you saw “Bridesmaids” – or even if you saw it on the clip reel at the Golden Globes – there’s probably one scene that sticks out. It did for Ricky Gervais, who introduced the “Bridesmaids” star Melissa McCarthy by reminding audiences of the moment when, in a pivotal scene in a wedding-dress shop, she defecated in a sink.

headline: The Caucus | Debate Behind the Scenes
text: Jeremy Peters reports from Myrtle Beach on a day spent observing the preparations with the Fox News team ahead of Monday’s presidential debate.

headline: A Spare Lectern and Little Left to Chance at Republican Debate
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Jon M. Huntsman Jr.’s sudden decision to quit the presidential race and endorse Mitt Romney left Fox News with an empty lectern on its debate stage and a gaping hole in its script Monday night. But it also left one of the debate’s moderators, Bret Baier, with a nagging feeling.

headline: When Freedom’s Ring Isn’t a Cash Register’s
text: You would have been hard-pressed to find a New York politician or civic leader who didn’t feel duty-bound to invoke the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Monday, the day his birthday was observed. But there was one vital group of New Yorkers who, as usual, gave Dr. King a pass. They were those who keep this city’s commerce humming.

headline: Confusion and Then Anger Heard in Audio Recordings of Calls to Cruise Ship Captain
text: Updated | 1:54 p.m. In a testy, dramatic conversation late Friday night, an Italian coast guard official ordered the captain of the sinking Costa Concordia to return to the stricken cruise ship.

headline: The Golden Age Of Impersonation
text: In the old days, impersonating someone was hard — you had to find some way to convince people in person that you were someone else, and it was especially hard if the individual you were trying to impersonate was fairly well known.

headline: Literary Agent Helps Create Training Program at Syracuse for Arts Leaders
text: Having served on several cultural boards, the literary agent Morton L. Janklow found that many arts leaders lacked basic business skills necessary to manage their institutions. So he has spearheaded a new master’s of arts degree program at Syracuse University, which is to be announced Tuesday.

headline: Majority of Chinese Now Live in Cities
text: BEIJING — China’s urban population exceeded its rural population in 2011 for the first time in the nation’s history, the government’s National Bureau of Statistics reported, continuing a trend that has helped drive its rapid economic growth but poses an increasingly difficult social transition for scores of millions of Chinese.

headline: Home-Field Advantage Losing Grip in N.F.L. Playoffs
text: We think of Lambeau Field as an impenetrable fortress come January. Visiting teams aren’t supposed to win playoff games there. Except that these days, they do. The Packers are 2-4 in their last six home playoff games. They’re not the only ones.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Daily Aspirin May Not Be for Everyone
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Petzschner’s Bid for Punishing Perfection Falls Just Short
text: MELBOURNE, Australia–All Philipp Petzschner wanted was perfection.

headline: Lebanon, by the Numbers
text: Lebanon’s peculiar brand of democracy, dysfunctional and widely unpopular, is a perennial source of national vexation, debated over Sunday lunches and in the press.

headline: When Some Rigor Helps (Mildly Wonkish)
text: The latest murky debate about fiscal policy — here’s the most recent installment from David Glasner — seems to me to be a useful reminder about the usefulness of mathematical modeling in economics.It’s not so much that the models are true, as the way that, used judiciously, they can cut through verbal confusion.

headline: Look at Them All: George Harrison’s Guitar Collection Gets iPad App
text: Though it has been some years since their owner left this plane of existence, the guitars of George Harrison need not weep for loneliness or lack of use: they are about to be shown off and shared in a new iPad app planned for release next month. On Tuesday the George Harrison estate said that it was working with Bandwdth Publishing, which makes applications for mobile devices, to create a virtual showroom of that singer-songwriter’s trove of guitars that will make use of many of his personal recordings.

headline: Harrison Falls to Murray in Four Sets
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Andy Murray of Britain overcame a faltering start to eliminate Ryan Harrison of the United States, 5-7, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 in a first-round match at the 2012 Australian Open.

headline: Walid Chammah to Retire From Morgan Stanley
text: Walid A. Chammah, the chairman of Morgan Stanley International, is retiring, according to a memorandum sent on Tuesday to employees.

headline: Milan Top 5 | Tom Ford
text: Tom Ford was in town to present a new fall collection that was surprisingly neutral in comparison to brighter seasons past. The handpicked house models walked around the hyper-elegant and intimate showroom so that the clothes’ most tactile qualities could be properly appreciated. Argentine coyote, which has a rougher texture that Ford prefers, topped the lapels of this luxurious tweed coat worn with the softest buttoned knit and a checked, pleated trouser, all in toffee brown tones.

headline: On Our Radar: Capsized Ship Stirs Environmental Worries
text: With an estimated 2,380 metric tons of fuel on board, the wrecked Costa Concordia cruise ship is “an ecological time bomb,” the mayor of the Tuscan island of Giglio said. The waters are treasured by divers. A Dutch salvage vessel is expected to start removing the ship’s fuel within days; the process could take two to four weeks. [The Guardian]

headline: TimesTalks | Neeson & Carnahan: Preview
text: The actor and director describe shooting their film “The Grey” in the frozen Canadian tundra, and talk about what they really think of each other.

headline: Crackdown Continues on Activists in China
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have charged another veteran human rights activist with attempting to subvert the state, the latest in a series of indictments or trials of well-known dissidents that have brought unusually stiff prison sentences and widespread condemnation abroad.

headline: Ralcorp Outlines Post Cereals Spinoff
text: Ralcorp Holdings, the food conglomerate, announced on Tuesday that its board had approved the spinoff of its Post cereals business and offered new details on the structure of the separation.

headline: A Date for the Tony Awards
text: The 66th annual Tony Awards ceremony will be held on Sunday, June 10, at the Beacon Theater in New York and broadcast live on CBS, organizers of the ceremony announced on Tuesday. The Tonys are the best-known awards for Broadway musicals and plays, voted on by hundreds of producers, tour presenters, directors and others in the theater industry. (Off Broadway and regional shows are not eligible.) The organizers also set April 26 as the cutoff date for Broadway shows to open and be eligible for Tony nominations and awards; the nominations are expected to be announced the week of April 30.

headline: Bring Back the Lockout!
text: We interrupt this N.F.L. playoff season with the disturbing news that the N.B.A. season is going on. While the conclusion of the league’s shameful lockout did bring a few benefits, including festive Christmas Day openers and a blissfully shortened season, it turns out the benefits quickly developed downsides. Christmas Day was, alas, only one day. And the blissfully shortened season came with a microscopic preseason, creating teams with all the organization of New Jersey traffic, and has been condensed like a can of tomato soup. There are games on top of games on top of games, all held together by xanthan gum.

headline: George Lucas, Hitmaker
text: On the set of “Star Wars,” “Raiders of the Lost Ark” and more.

headline: George Lucas Is Ready to Roll the Credits
text: This was a new feeling for George Lucas. He made a movie about a plucky band of freedom fighters who battle an evil empire — a movie loaded with special effects like no one had seen before. Then he showed it to executives from all the Hollywood studios. And every one of them said, “Nope.”

headline: In a Slugfest, Tsonga Defeats Istomin
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France outslugged Denis Istomin of Uzbekistan, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2, 7-5 on Tuesday night to gain the second round of the 2012 Australian Open.

headline: Exploring the Arctic Circle by Kayak
text: A rugged trip around Ellesmere Island included fending off a 3,000-pound walrus.

headline: Where the Sun Never Sets, a 1,500-Mile Trip by Sea Kayak
text: To stave off a breaching 3,000-pound walrus from the cockpit of a small sea kayak, Erik Boomer recommends using the paddle.

headline: ‘Dragon Tattoo’ and ‘Bridesmaids’ Earn Editors’ Nods
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo” and “Bridesmaids” may have been shut out at the Golden Globes, but they are still very much a part of the Oscar conversation, as evidenced by the American Cinema Editors nominations, announced on Monday. Both films made the cut, along with other Oscar favorites like “The Descendants,” “Hugo,” “The Artist,” “Midnight in Paris,” “Moneyball” and “War Horse,” which has otherwise been faltering lately. An editing award is considered a must for a best-picture win at the Oscars – no film has received that top prize without at least an editing nomination since 1981 – and the editors’ group has a lot of overlap with the Academy voters in its membership, so its choices are usually an above-average predictor.

headline: Bruno Senna Joins Williams Team
text: Williams announced Tuesday that Bruno Senna would drive for the team in 2012. The announcement carried far more emotional undertone than any other so far this year as Williams was the team for which Senna’s uncle, Ayrton Senna, was driving when he was killed in a crash at the San Marino Grand Prix in Imola, Italy, in 1994.

The announcement carried far more emotional undertone than any other so far this year as Williams was the team for which Senna’s uncle, Ayrton Senna, was driving when he was killed in a crash at the San Marino Grand Prix in Imola, Italy, in 1994.

headline: Romney Says His Effective Tax Rate Is About 15 Percent
text: 2:23 p.m. | Updated FLORENCE, S.C. — After speaking to a smaller-than-usual crowd on Tuesday morning in Florence, S.C., Mitt Romney took questions from the press and said that his effective tax rate was about 15 percent.

headline: As States Weigh Online Gambling, Profit May Be Small
text: It has been more than four decades since states began putting numbers runners out of business by starting their own legal lotteries, which now yield them close to $18 billion a year. Now several states are thinking about trying to plug budget gaps by profiting again from their residents’ optimism — by legalizing, licensing and taxing Internet gambling.

headline: Breaking Riske’s Serve, Radwanska Prevails
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – In the final match of a long day on a distant outside court, Alison Riske of the United States battled for nearly two-and-a-half hours before falling to Urzula Radwanska of Poland.

headline: Romney Shares Some Tax Data; Critics Pounce
text: Under growing pressure from rival Republicans to release his tax returns, Mitt Romney said on Tuesday that he paid a tax rate approaching 15 percent on his millions of dollars in annual income but said he would not make public his full return until April.

headline: Allstate Offers Credit to Clients Unhappy With Claims Service
text: Allstate says that if its car insurance customers aren’t satisfied with the service they received on a paid claim, they can get a credit for six months of auto premiums for the car in question.

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: What does Joe Flacco have to do to beat the Patriots? What do the Giants have to do to stop Alex Smith? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

headline: Hearing Begins on Israeli Foreign Minister
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s state prosecutors began a hearing on Tuesday to decide whether to indict Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman on charges of fraud, breach of trust and money laundering, a move that could shake up Israeli politics and lead to early elections.

headline: In Denver, Patience Is Paying Off for the Nuggets
text: DENVER — There are traditional, tried-and-true methods of rebuilding a team. There is the draft-and-wait philosophy, which has the Oklahoma City Thunder poised for a long stay among the N.B.A.’s elite. There is the future-is-now credo that propelled the Boston Celtics from a 15-year rut without a 50-victory season to 234 wins over the last four years, two finals appearances and a title.

headline: Romney Calls Voters, With an Old Message From Santorum
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. – Rick Santorum has tried to soft-pedal his endorsement of Mitt Romney in 2008, saying he did so because he preferred Mr. Romney to the leading Republican alternative at the time, Senator John McCain.

headline: Obama to Accept Nomination in Stadium After Shortened Convention
text: President Obama once again will accept the Democratic presidential nomination from a football stadium to accommodate tens of thousands more supporters, and after a shorter-than-usual convention, convention planners announced on Tuesday.

headline: Helping Teachers Stand Up for Science
text: Two years ago I wrote about a nascent alliance between people who oppose teaching evolution in the schools and those who oppose teaching about the role of human activity in climate change.

headline: Holidays in the Deep South
text: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier-fed streams.

headline: Money Low, Occupy Wall St. Tightens Budget
text: With donations to Occupy Wall Street falling significantly and money starting to run low, the movement has imposed a partial spending freeze to make sure enough money is available for crucial functions like bailing protesters out of jail.

headline: In S.E.C.’s Actions, a Hint at a Tougher Stance
text: One of the criticisms that has been leveled against the Securities and Exchange Commission is that even when it has pursued cases, it has not been tough enough in seeking sanctions for violations of the federal securities laws. Since the new year began, however, it seems that the agency has taken a couple of small steps to burnish its image as Wall Street’s top cop.

headline: Knicks Idling, Waiting for Baron Davis
text: Perhaps more than any other N.B.A. team, the Knicks have fostered a reputation for laying franchise fortune at the feet of superstars either in the midst of – or well past – their primes: Bob McAdoo, Spencer Haywood, Stephon Marbury, Steve Francis, Amar’e Stoudemire, Carmelo Anthony and, most recently, Tyson Chandler.

headline: Tomic’s Most Important Skill? His Temperament
text: I watched Bernard Tomic come back from two sets down to beat Fernando Verdasco, and marveled at his quirky, inventive game. He reminds me of Andy Murray, with his ability to hold the ball on his strings a little longer to disguise his shots, his superb anticipation, and his use of different spins and heights to confuse and confound more powerful opponents.

headline: Chef Has Diabetes, and Some Say ‘I Told You So’
text: FOR 10 years, wielding slabs of cream cheese and mounds of mayonnaise, Paula Deen has become television’s self-crowned queen of Southern cuisine and one of the country’s most popular chefs, with an empire built on layers of gooey butter cake, fried chicken and sheer force of personality.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each Monday. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Advertisers distributed more than 272 billion coupons in free-standing inserts in 2011, according to a report from Kantar Media, part of WPP, a decline of 6.5 percent from 2010. The drop came after two years of increases, of 8 percent in 2009 and 7.2 percent in 2010. The amount of promotion pages from retailers that appeared in the inserts, which are typically carried in Sunday newspapers, rose 30.7 percent last year compared with 2010, the report said; the retailers included Walmart, Dollar General, Target and Walgreens.

headline: Ship Salvage Workers Roll Up Their Sleeves
text: A Dutch marine salvage company prepared on Tuesday to begin pumping half a million gallons of fuel from the stricken cruise ship Costa Concordia, the first step toward hauling the luxury liner away for a complete overhaul or cutting it up for scrap.

headline: At Least 34 People Killed in Syria as Monitors Are Unable to Quell Violence
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Violence surged in Syria on Tuesday as activists reported that at least 34 people had been killed in several towns and cities across the country, including six soldiers who had defected and three members of the security forces.

headline: The South Carolina Debate and G.O.P. Golden Oldies
text: The people of South Carolina should be grateful. The Republicans competing for their party’s nomination are subjecting them to only two of the carnival sideshows that pass for presidential debates. The first was Monday night and the second will be on Thursday.

headline: A New Pastry Chef for Le Bernardin
text: Eric Ripert, the exectuive chef and a partner in Le Bernardin, has hired Laurie Jon Moran as its new pastry chef. He replaces Michael Laiskonis, who left, as planned, on Dec. 31 to pursue opportunites outside the restaurant world. Mr. Moran, 30, is from England, where he worked at Le Manoir aux Quat’Saisons near Oxford, before joining Daniel here. Most recently he was pastry sous-chef at Per Se.

headline: Former Marketing Executive to Lead Formula One Grand Prix Into New Jersey
text: Tom Cotter, a former motorsports marketing entrepreneur who has worked as an automotive writer for the last decade, was named the president of the Formula One Grand Prix of America at Port Imperial on Tuesday. He will be charged with executing the contract to bring a Formula One race to New Jersey in June 2013.

headline: ‘The Artist’ and ‘Tinker, Tailor’ Top British Nominations
text: “The Artist” and “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy” were the heavies with the Bafta crowd, the British answer to the Oscars, whose members announced their picks today. “The Artist” earned 12 nominations and “Tinker, Tailor,” 11. “Hugo” was close on their heels with 9; “My Week With Marilyn,” “The Help” and “War Horse” all also fared well.

headline: TV’s Game of Three-Card Monte
text: “Alcatraz,” a new show from J.J. Abrams, had its premiere last night, and it bears all the earmarks of an Abrams project: tantalizing mysteries, befuddling questions, whispered promises of startling revelations just over the horizon.

headline: Perry’s Inaccurate Remark on Turkey Draws Rebuke
text: In Monday night’s Republican debate in South Carolina, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas described the leaders of Turkey as “Islamic terrorists,” an inaccurate characterization that drew a swift rebuke from the Turkish government.

headline: Brand Seeks to Make Child’s Play of Cooking
text: The Uncle Ben’s line of rice products is extending a campaign that carries the theme “Begin With Ben” to a group of consumers who, the brand hopes, are just beginning to cook.

headline: When Parents Can Opt Out of School Curriculums
text: Once upon a time in Bedford, N.H., a teacher in a high school personal finance class set out to educate her students on what day-to-day life was like in a minimum wage job. The teacher assigned the students to read Barbara Ehrenreich’s “Nickel and Dimed: On (Not) Getting by in America.” Here’s Ms. Ehrenreich on her time working as a member of a corporate housekeeping team:

headline: Yemeni Official Suggests Delay in Presidential Vote
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Adding to fears of a worsening political crisis in Yemen, a top government official hinted at a possible delay in presidential elections set for February that would mark the formal end of President Ali Abdullah Saleh’s 33-year rule.

headline: UniCredit Gaining Investor Support for $9.6 Billion Rights Issue
text: LONDON — Aabar Investments, an investment vehicle for Abu Dhabi’s sovereign wealth fund, said on Tuesday that it would increase its stake in the Italian bank UniCredit to 6.5 percent from 5 percent after the Milan-based firm completes a so-called rights offering at the end of the month. The deal would make Aabar the largest individual investor in UniCredit.

headline: Morgan Stanley Is Said to Cap Cash Bonuses at $125,000
text: Morgan Stanley employees may want to put their kitchen renovations off until next year.

headline: In Portugal, Mirandese Spoken Here — and Only Here
text: An old woman in a plain gray dress and a shopping bag full of oblong orange squashes called out to me from down the street. I had no idea what she was saying – and that couldn’t have made me happier. After all, I had come to her rural village – Malhadas, in the northeast corner of Portugal – with the specific hope of not understanding anyone.

headline: Santorum Says He May Have Won in Iowa
text: 2:43 p.m. | Updated Rick Santorum expressed new hope on Tuesday that the final vote count in the Iowa caucuses might show that he — not Mitt Romney — actually won there by a small margin.

headline: Red Wings and Sabres Go in Different Directions
text: The contrast couldn’t have been more striking on Monday evening: the Detroit Red Wings, streaking to a 15th-straight win at Joe Louis Arena, and the Buffalo Sabres continuing to slump to new depths. The Red Wings crushed the Sabres, 5-0, thanks to a flurry of three first-period goals.

headline: Indictment for Man Accused in White House Shooting
text: WASHINGTON — A federal grand jury in Washington on Tuesday indicted the man arrested after shots were fired at the White House in November, charging him with attempting to assassinate President Obama along with 16 assault and firearms counts.

headline: Men’s Designers Get Their Pelts
text: Despite the latest signs of continued economic turmoil in Europe, men’s wear designers are not shying away from on luxury fabrics for fall, what with all the press notes about vicuña and cashmere. One unexpected, and very expensive, material that turned up in several collections in Milan was astrakhan, a fairly controversial fur that is also known as Persian lamb, made from the skins of newborn (and sometimes unborn) lambs.

headline: ‘Magic/Bird’ To Land at the Longacre Theater
text: “Magic/Bird,” Eric Simonson’s play about the rivalry and friendship between Larry Bird, the former Boston Celtics forward, and Magic Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers point guard, has a Broadway theater and a complete cast. The play, to be directed by Thomas Kail, will open on April 11 at the Longacre Theater, the show’s producers announced Tuesday. Previews begin March 21.

headline: For India’s Army, Age Dispute Rattles Leadership
text: NEW DELHI — Certainly, India’s army already has plenty to keep it busy. To the northeast lies China, which is quietly but rapidly expanding its military presence along the border. To the northwest lies nuclear-armed Pakistan, which has already fought three wars with India and is now wobbling with political instability.

headline: Davis’s Performance Recalls Winslow’s ‘Epic’ Day
text: It is fitting that in the Year of the Tight End, two of the greatest postseason performances by a player at that position would occur.

headline: Too Dandy for Tough Times — Or Is Couture the Cure?
text: Alexander McQueen is dead but not gone. True to its corset-and-drama heritage, the brand is teaming with the traditional Savile Row tailor Huntsman to create a made-to-order suit service. The designer Sarah Burton announced the move in Milan during the men’s wear autumn 2012 season, writes Suzy Menkes, the IHT fashion editor, where the tilt in men’s fashion toward formal and evening wear is being confirmed every day.

headline: Media Decoder | Web Sites to Go Dark
text: January 17, 2012 — Wikipedia and other Web sites plan Wednesday blackouts to protest two Congressional web piracy bills.

headline: Gingrich Pokes Romney on Taxes
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Newt Gingrich poked fun at Mitt Romney’s acknowledgment on Tuesday that he paid about a 15 percent tax rate because his income was largely returns on investments.

headline: Prized Quarterback Shifts To Notre Dame From L.S.U.
text: The Notre Dame football season ended on a sour note, with a pair of losses and Ohio State’s poaching two of the team’s assistant coaches.

headline: Digital Notes: Royalties for Streaming Music Grew 17% in 2011
text: Royalties Increase for Streaming: SoundExchange, the agency that compensates performers and record labels when music is played on satellite and Internet radio, paid $292 million in royalties last year, up 17 percent from 2010, the group announced. SoundExchange signed up 15,300 new artists and labels last year, yet the agency is still often criticized in the music industry for holding back royalties from unregistered acts and has faced challenges from its biggest contributor, Sirius XM Radio.

text: January 17, 2012 — A recorded telephone conversation with Francesco Schettino, captain of the Costa Concordia, reveals that he abandoned the cruise ship long before all passengers had been evacuated.

headline: In Cuomo’s Budget, Nip-and-Tuck Cuts and Big Policy Aims
text: ALBANY — Presenting what he called “both a budget and a reform plan,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday asked legislators to demand more rigorous teacher evaluations, to restrict pension benefits for future public employees, and to slightly reduce overall state spending by consolidating the state bureaucracy.

headline: 32,100 and Counting: New Yorkers Speak Out on Fracking
text: Officials with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation say they have counted 32,100 statements so far since the close of a public comment period on Wednesday on their proposal to allow hydrofracking in the state.

headline: France’s Oscar Hopes Depend on Its Health Care System
text: Other than Italy, no country has a better track record with the Academy Award for best foreign-language film than France, which has received 36 nominations and 12 Oscars (with 27 and 13 for Italy). But last year’s competition was disappointing for the French: the highly acclaimed “Of Gods and Men,” which won the Grand Prix at Cannes, failed even to make the shortlist, while an Algerian film set in France and spoken largely in French, “Outside the Law,” was one of the five finalists.

headline: What Start-Ups Can Learn From a Crime Boss
text: What lurks in the hearts of mild-mannered software developers? Donald DeSantis’s answer may surprise you. The 29-year-old Seattle techie recently penned a tale of unlikely inspiration called “Everything I need to know about start-ups, I learned from a crime boss.”

headline: Mitt Romney’s Taxes
text: Having suggested at Monday night’s debate that he would release his 2011 tax returns in April, Mitt Romney must have realized he would need to inoculate himself against the inevitable public backlash over his annual income, where it comes from and how little tax he pays on it. He started this process Tuesday morning, when he told reporters in South Carolina that his effective tax rate is about 15 percent.

headline: A Founder of Noma Is the Chef at Acme
text: The way Jean-Marc Houmard tells it, Mads Refslund, a founder of the world-famous Noma in Copenhagen, was in New York on vacation last summer, dining at Bond St., one of the downtown restaurants in which Mr. Houmard is a partner. “We hit it off,” Mr. Houmard said. “At that time we were looking for a chef and we convinced him to drop something he was doing in Copenhagen.”

headline: Carr and Stelter on Wikipedia’s Day of Protest
text: David Carr and Brian Stelter, in this TimesCast video, discuss the decision by Wikipedia to close on Wednesday to educate its audience about proposed antipiracy legislation in Congress that it considers a threat to an open Internet. headline: Caldwell Fired as Colts House-Cleaning Continues

headline: A Le Mans-Winning 1960 Corvette Finds Fame in a Sequel
text: PHOENIX — In June 1960, four Chevrolet Corvettes were entered in the 24 Hours of Le Mans. One of them eventually became the first American vehicle to win its class in the endurance test, held annually on the famed circuit in France.

headline: Your Money’s Worth: Examining Facts and Attitudes About Income Inequality
text: Overview | What does income inequality say about contemporary American society? What should be done to address income inequality? In this lesson, students examine Times infographics about income and wealth distribution in the United States and discuss what this information says about society.

headline: Mushroom and Herb Omelet
text: Mushroom omelets are my favorite type of omelet. You can get fancy with them and use wild mushrooms, but it’s much more economical and equally satisfying to make them with cultivated creminis or white button mushrooms.

headline: Los Angeles Mandates Use of Condoms for Sex Films
text: LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles City Council approved a new mandate Tuesday requiring all actors in pornographic films to wear condoms during any filming that takes place within city limits. The law is the first of its kind in the country, advocates said, and could have a significant impact on what some say is a $1 billion industry.

headline: In Grand Forks, 11 Goals, 16 Penalties, and Dead Gophers on the Ice
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Police Seek Thieves Impersonating Detectives
text: The three men said they were police detectives, but by the time they left a woman’s apartment in the Bronx it was clear that they were something else entirely: thieves.

headline: Romera New York
text: Inside the restaurant that Dr. Miguel Sánchez Romera, a Spanish neurologist turned chef, opened at the Dream Downtown hotel.

headline: A Feast for the Eyes, at Least
text: THE first thing I ate at Romera New York was a jam of black olives and tomatoes. Sticky, sweet and salty, it made a fine spread for the warm roll that came with it, and it was just as appealing eaten with a spoon.

headline: Obesity Rates Stall, But No Decline
text: After two decades of steady increases, obesity rates in adults and children in the United States have remained largely unchanged during the past 12 years, a finding that suggests national efforts at promoting healthful eating and exercise are having little effect on the overweight.

headline: European Union Acts to Halt Hungarian Laws
text: BRUSSELS — Reawakening a debate on what the European Union should do when one of its members threatens its democratic principles, the bloc’s executive arm opened legal proceedings on Tuesday against Hungary, which critics contend is sliding toward authoritarianism.

headline: Photos of the Moment | DSquared2

headline: Europe Leans Toward Blocking NYSE-Deutsche Borse Merger
text: 5:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘Alcatraz’ Could Be a Breakout Hit for Fox
text: The series premiere of “Alcatraz” — which features a crack investigative team tracking former inmates of the infamous prison — managed to capture a large portion of the broadcast audience for Fox on Monday night. The new drama averaged 10 million viewers and outperformed the premiere of the previous time slot occupant, “Terra Nova,” in the 18-to-49 demographic, according to Nielsen data. The numbers also remained consistent throughout the two-hour period, suggesting viewers liked what they saw.

headline: Measuring the Top 1% by Wealth, Not Income
text: After our demographic profile of the 1 percent appeared on Sunday, there were a lot of questions from readers about the top 1 percent by wealth, rather than the measure we used, the top 1 percent by income.

headline: After Years of Decline, Polio Cases in Afghanistan Triple in a Year
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — It has often been called the polio cease-fire.

headline: A Fresh Look at Nuclear Power, from Fukushima to the Hudson
text: Tonight, the PBS program Frontline is running “Nuclear Aftershocks,” a 50-minute documentary examining the implications of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear calamity for the future of nuclear power in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: Cuomo's Budget Targets Evaluations, Busing and Special Ed
text: UPDATED | Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo's executive budget has quite a bit to say about education in New York. Along with a four percent spending increase -- contingent on school districts adopting new teacher evaluations -- the budget includes changes to student busing and special education spending. Read the reactions.

headline: Israel’s Clash of Civilizations
text: Women carefully guarded. Women scientists barred from speaking at podiums. Ultra-Orthodox men spitting on an 8-year-old girl deemed immodestly dressed.

headline: Billy Crystal’s Oscar Reunion
text: If anyone was still wondering whether this year’s Oscar telecast, hosted by Billy Crystal, would be something of a nostalgia-fest, the answer is as certain and as dependably comforting, as a Betty White birthday joke. In a new behind-the-scenes video released by the Academy, Mr. Crystal ruminates on the pressure of returning to host – “there’s so much expected of this,” he says – and, though he wouldn’t reveal anything about his opening monologue (“a magician never tells his tricks”) he did offer some spoilers about the direction of the program. “I think that’s going to be a theme of the evening – how did you fall in love with movies?” he says. “It’s a common experience we all have. We have to celebrate that more.”

headline: Mets Owners Can Look Forward to Trial During Spring Training
text: Judge Jed S. Rakoff’s ruling on Tuesday was full of case citations, legal reasoning, a Yogi Berra quotation and a reference to the hijacked Achille Lauro cruise ship.

headline: Inspector General to Leave S.E.C.
text: WASHINGTON — The inspector general of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who has been a thorn in the side of the agency over its fumbling of early inquiries into the Madoff and Stanford cases, will leave the commission at the end of January to join a private investigations firm.

headline: Romney Disclosure Reignites Debate Over Carried Interest
text: The “carried interest” tax debate that has raged in Congress and on Wall Street over the last half-decade took center stage in the presidential race on Tuesday.

headline: Tips on Shopping for Energy-Efficient Bulbs
text: How many types of light bulbs does it take to confuse consumers? Three, apparently.

headline: Mets Sign Pelfrey, Ramirez, Acosta and Torres, Avoiding Arbitration
text: The Mets avoided hearings with four players eligible for salary arbitration after reaching one-year agreements with starter Mike Pelfrey, relievers Ramon Ramirez and Manny Acosta, and center fielder Andres Torres, the team announced Tuesday.

headline: Turkish Verdict in 2007 Murder of Editor Fuels Outrage
text: ISTANBUL — A Turkish court convicted one man on Tuesday of instigating the 2007 murder of a prominent editor, but acquitted all 19 suspects on charges of being members of a terrorist organization, rejecting claims that the murder was an act of conspiracy by an illegal network within the Turkish state.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Giorgio Armani
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Officers’ Workaday, Work-a-Night Lives, Far From Movie Glamour
text: When our culture represents police officers, it’s usually a good cop-bad cop situation. With notable exceptions, like the characters in “The Wire,” those who enforce the law are typically noble or corrupt, glamorous detectives or dirty dealers.

headline: Open Science And The Econoblogosphere
text: Interesting article in the Times about the push for “open science”, bypassing the traditional structure of refereed journals in favor of a sort of fluid, self-policing online community. I can’t and won’t weigh in on this issue with regards to hard science, but I think there are some interesting parallels with what has been happening in economics.

headline: Wells Fargo Stands Out With Trading Gains
text: Wall Street banks reporting poor trading results might want to take some tips from Wells Fargo & Company.

headline: Turns Out You Can Find Good Bosses These Days
text: Maybe Cate Ryan means “The Picture Box” to be the anti-“Help.”

headline: Police Working on Technology to Detect Concealed Guns
text: For years, detectives trying to distinguish gun-carrying New Yorkers from others have had to rely on observations, street smarts and luck. A man with a gun on his hip might grab the front of his sport coat to keep it from flapping open and revealing the pistol. Someone getting out of a cab might hold tight to his side, to keep a weapon secure.

headline: A 1731 Morality Tale That Aged Well, Unlike Its Characters
text: The long title of the play: “The London Merchant, or the History of George Barnwell.” The short review: excellent.

headline: Sewanee, the University of the South, Announces a Rare, Four-Year Tuition Guarantee
text: The University of the South, a liberal arts college also known as Sewanee, announced Tuesday that it would guarantee a four-year rate of tuition, room and board for the class entering the university next fall. Sewanee’s board of regents set the annual tuition and fees for incoming students at $44,630, and it should hold steady through the Spring 2016 semesters for students starting in 2012, the university said.

headline: Court Rejects Candidates’ Effort to Appear on Virginia Ballot
text: A federal appeals court in Virginia on Tuesday denied another effort by several Republican presidential candidates to appear on the state’s primary ballot.

headline: Organizers Say 1 Million Signed Petition to Recall Wisconsin Governor
text: Critics of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin submitted to the state on Tuesday more than a million signatures, nearly twice as many as required, on recall petitions against him to force a new election.

headline: Iran Offers U.S. Tiny Replica of Lost Drone
text: While Iran’s government has so far refused an American request to return the C.I.A. stealth drone it captured last month, on Tuesday, an Iranian company that is manufacturing miniature replicas of the drone in several colors offered to send President Obama a pink one.

headline: Pressure-Cooked Butternut Squash
text: Nathan Myhrvold, co-author of “Modernist Cuisine,” and Melissa Clark demonstrate how to make butternut squash purée using a pressure cooker.

headline: Obama Taps Lew Deputy to Head Budget Office
text: President Obama on Tuesday promoted the deputy director of his budget office, Jeffrey Zients, to be acting director when Jacob J. Lew, the current budget director, becomes the White House chief of staff later this month.

headline: Simple Sous Vide Salmon
text: Nathan Myhrvold, co-author of “Modernist Cuisine,” and Melissa Clark demonstrate how to prepare simple sous vide salmon at home.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, India, Italy and Iraq.

headline: Sizing Up the Top 25
text: Each week The Quad will analyze the top 25 N.C.A.A. teams (rankings and results are from The Associated Press).

headline: After Space Probe’s Failure, Russia Looks to U.S. Radar
text: MOSCOW — Russian officials said on Tuesday that they were investigating whether powerful American radar systems might have caused the failure of a $170 million scientific probe headed for a moon of Mars.

headline: Yahoo’s Jerry Yang Resigns From Board
text: Yahoo announced on Tuesday that Jerry Yang, a co-founder and board member, had stepped down from the board effective immediately. He has also resigned from the boards of Yahoo Japan and the Alibaba Group.

headline: Questions Fly Over a Flag Flown Upside Down
text: International incident avoided!

headline: Pennsylvania Republican Abides by Term-Limit Pledge
text: Representative Todd R. Platts, a Republican from York, Pa., will not seek a seventh term this year, abiding by the 12-year term limit he has pushed for in Congress.

headline: The (Solar) Light at the End of the Tunnel
text: A consultant for the Defense Department reports that introducing solar installations on nine military bases in the Mojave and Colorado Desert could generate 7,000 megawatts of power.

headline: Coming Soon | Double-Breasted Suits
