headline: Paul to Break From Trail for Debt Ceiling Vote
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Representative Ron Paul of Texas is taking a day off from campaigning on Wednesday to return to Washington to vote against an increase in the nation’s debt ceiling, forgoing a day on the hard-fought trail just three days before South Carolina’s presidential primary.

headline: ‘Porgy and Bess’ Director Will Take on Cirque du Soleil Next
text: Diane Paulus is moving from Catfish Row to a mysterious island. The producers of Cirque du Soleil announced this week that Ms. Paulus, the director of “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess,” which just opened on Broadway, is set to direct “Amaluna,” the company’s latest touring spectacle, which will open in Montreal on April 19 before moving to Quebec City and Toronto.

headline: Sorcerer’s Apprentice Hosts a Dinner
text: MY friends were perplexed when I invited them over for a dinner party based entirely on recipes from “Modernist Cuisine: The Art and Science of Cooking,” the multivolume examination of avant-garde cooking and culinary technology.

headline: Protest Vote Set on Debt Ceiling
text: There is no showdown on the horizon on whether to raise the debt ceiling, but a mini-legislative sign of disapproval is nigh.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  AC Adapters, and Watching Out for ‘Text Neck’
text: Interesting things that reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: The Agony Behind an Erotic Club’s Ecstasy
text: “Crazy Horse,” Frederick Wiseman’s new documentary, invites the viewer to contemplate the intricacies of the creative process, the daily rhythms of a complex organization and the tensions between artistic ambition and practicality — and also to look at very beautiful women wearing very little.

headline: Capital Gains: Romney and the 1%
text: Few aspects of the division between the 1 percent and the 99 percent have proven so divisive as the fact that the rich often pay a lower tax rate than everybody else. That is because the top federal tax rate on capital gains income is 15 percent, compared with a top marginal tax rate of 35 percent on other taxable income, like wages and salaries, that exceeds $380,000 a year.

headline: Robo-Learning and Making Science Fun
text: On Saturday, 43 teams of students between the ages of 9 and 14 competed in Brooklyn in a set of challenges throughout the day, which included using robots that each team had constructed out of Legos to complete various tasks. “The robot we built, we worked together and created something,” said one student, Zohirul Islam. “That teaches you a lot.”

headline: Gingrich's Plan to Turn Students Into City School Cleaners? Only in the Movies
text: The presidential hopeful Newt Gingrich took a potshot at an unusual target in the most recent Republican debate. He lambasted New York City school cleaners for getting paid too much, using them as exhibit A of unions inflating salaries and harming the nation's economy. Here's a check of his facts, and reaction from the union, a high school custodian and students.

headline: Moncler Gamme Bleu Men’s
text: Milan.

headline: Technology Helps Sundance Films Capture the Moment
text: LOS ANGELES — If the Sundance Film Festival is a mirror of America, this year’s installment depicts an unusually stark image of a broken place filled with broken people.

headline: The Great Wikipedia Blackout of 2012: The Media Try to Fill the Void
text: 6:10 p.m. | Updated Our friends at The Washington Post announced an ambitious plan to fill the void during the Great Wikipedia Blackout of 2012: a Twitter campaign to answer Internet users’ questions, à la Wikipedia.

headline: Clásico Overload? Is That Possible?
text: Could a Real Madrid-Barcelona clásico ever be considered to be passéico (with apologies to the city of Passaic, N.J., a place where I worked many, many years ago)?

headline: The Hiss of Steampunk, the Roar of the Digital Judge
text: The residency program at the Here Arts Center in the South Village encourages composers, choreographers, playwrights, video artists and even puppeteers to get into one another’s business and to create freewheeling hybrids. It is an ideal home for a musician like Kamala Sankaram.

headline: Cruise Ship Accident Stirs Thoughts of the Andrea Doria
text: First thing Saturday, Pierette Domenica Simpson’s boyfriend called and said, “Go online. You’ll be interested.”

headline: In the Kitchen With Nathan Myhrvold
text: Nathan Myhrvold, the co-author of “Modernist Cuisine,” visits Melissa Clark, preparing his simple sous vide salmon, gin-infused celery, seared steak and pressure-cooked butternut squash.

headline: Does Elizabeth Warren Read My Blog?
text: In a Thursday blog post on (the obscene amount of) money in politics, I noted that Elizabeth Warren, who’s running for Senate in Massachusetts, raised $5.7 million in the last three months of 2011, while the Republican incumbent, Scott Brown, raised $3.2 million. In the very next paragraph I suggested that individual Democrats around the country should formally pledge to run transparent campaigns so long as the other guy pledges the same.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Producers Sue Taymor for Breach
text: Using caustic private e-mails as weapons, the producers of the popular Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” marshaled a muscular counteroffensive in federal court in Manhattan on Tuesday against a lawsuit by Julie Taymor, the $75 million show’s former director. In it they essentially seek to erase Ms. Taymor from the “Spider-Man” universe going forward.

headline: Recalling When Nighttime Was Dark
text: A documentary about light pollution that is entertaining and thought-provoking? It hardly seems possible, but that’s what Ian Cheney has made in “The City Dark.”

headline: Former Challenger to Barney Frank to Run in 2012
text: Sean Bielat, a Republican who ran an aggressive race against Representative Barney Frank in 2010, said Tuesday that he would again seek the seat in Massachusetts’ 4th Congressional District.

headline: Anne Frank, Still Writing in the Attic
text: At the start of Shalom Auslander’s staggeringly nervy new novel “Hope: A Tragedy,” a doleful Jewish non-farmer named Solomon Kugel climbs fearfully into the attic of his recently acquired farmhouse. He hopes the tapping sounds in the attic are being made by nothing worse than mice.

headline: Beyond the Brightest Searchlights, Other Cases of the Lost
text: As the new series “Find Our Missing” begins, S. Epatha Merkerson — still recognizable as Lieutenant Van Buren from “Law & Order,” despite the braids in her hair — says, “It’s a mystery that has confounded family, friends and the police.”

headline: ‘Modernist’ Dishes for a Dinner Party
text: Melissa Clark, a columnist for The Times, prepares a menu based entirely on recipes from “Modernist Cuisine,” the multivolume avant-garde cookbook.

headline: Surviving a Big Risk on Fifth Avenue
text: The Kushner Companies’ purchase in 2007 of 666 Fifth Avenue, an aluminum-clad office tower in Midtown Manhattan, for a record price of $1.8 billion is considered a classic example of reckless underwriting. The transaction was so highly leveraged that the cash flow from rents amounted to only 65 percent of the debt service.

headline: Windows Into Big but Little-Understood Worlds
text: “Inside Nature’s Giants,” besides being the liveliest scientists-at-work program to come along in a while, is the perfect thing for anyone trying to lose weight. You won’t be doing any snacking while watching this cut-them-open extravaganza.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Producers’ Countersuit Against Julie Taymor
text: The producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” marshaled a muscular counteroffensive in federal court against a lawsuit by Julie Taymor, the former director of the $75 million show, essentially seeking to erase Mr. Taymor from the “Spider-Man” universe going forward.

headline: Obama Campaign Looks Into Ad Rates
text: In a sign that the Obama campaign could be getting close to airing its first television commercials of the 2012 race, aides on Tuesday began asking television stations in certain swing states for their advertising rates.

headline: Judge Dismisses Dot-Com Lawsuit Against Quattrone
text: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Credit Suisse and its former star investment banker, Frank P. Quattrone, ending a decade-old shareholder action brought by investors in AOL–Time Warner stock.

headline: For Opera Star’s Birthday, Spotlight Is on Young Artists
text: It says everything you need to know about the great mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne that she spent her 78th birthday on Monday listening to young singers. She has followed one of the most spectacular singing careers in opera history with devoted work as a teacher and conservatory administrator, always emphasizing the art of the song recital.

headline: Tenants Gain Advantage in Office Tower Market
text: In New York’s most exclusive office towers, the pendulum of power has swung from landlords, who last year basked in rising rents and competition for prime buildings, to tenants, who are now being offered incentives like prebuilt offices to fill empty spaces. And the leverage held by tenants is likely to continue through this year, market experts say.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: ‘Right to Work’ Laws
text: To the Editor:

headline: Terry S. Brown
text: Mr. Brown, 50, is the chief executive of Edens, an independent owner and operator of shopping centers on the East Coast, including the South Bay Center in Boston and the Port Plaza in Port Jefferson, N.Y.

headline: As European Union Beckons, Allure Fades for Wary Croatia
text: HARMICA, Croatia — Zoran Sluga has a small family farm here on the border with Slovenia, his 300-year-old barn filled with thousands of squawking chickens.

headline: Court Weighs Protections for Lawyers of Cities
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday considered whether private lawyers hired by municipalities to conduct investigations are entitled to protections against lawsuits available to government lawyers.

headline: Kitchen Modernism With Nathan Myhrvold
text: Some of the modernist cooking techniques that Nathan Myhrvold showed me for this week’s column seem a lot more confusing than they actually are — at least if you’ve never, say, cooked salmon using fake sous vide before. These four short videos help illustrate the methods. And it’s instructive to hear Mr. Myhrvold talk about the recipes, explaining some of the finer points in more depth than in a written recipe.

headline: Designation of Historic District in East Village Won’t Stop Project
text: It seems like a classic case of closing the barn door after the horses have gotten out.

headline: New Questions Raised About Tamiflu’s Effectiveness
text: A new review of medical evidence continues to raise questions about the safety and effectiveness of the influenza drug Tamiflu, which the United States and other nations have spent billions of dollars to stockpile for use in a possible flu pandemic.

headline: Sometimes a Dragon Needs to Nibble
text: Chinese (or Asian) New Year starts on Monday and celebrations last about a week. To kick off the Year of the Dragon, Peter Callahan, a New York caterer with an office in Philadelphia, is selling clever “fortune cookie” hors d’oeuvres. Though shaped like the folded cookies, they are made with wonton wrappers, fried and filled with a spiced chicken mixture. They come with a little red acrylic tray that has six tiny reusable takeout boxes attached for serving the tidbits. You get three dozen hors d’oeuvres, to be reheated before serving. Add some parsley or shredded cabbage to the bottom of each box for a nice presentation, and put a paper fortune, also provided, on top. You can even order your own custom fortunes.

headline: Robertson and Chamberlain Agree to Terms
text: The Yankees avoided arbitration with relievers Joba Chamberlain and Dave Robertson by agreeing to one-year contracts with both, the team announced Tuesday.

headline: Mind Your Manners: Eat With Your Hands
text: JULIE SAHNI vividly remembers the first time she had to eat with utensils. Ms. Sahni, a New York-based cookbook author and cooking teacher, grew up in India eating the traditional way, with her right hand. Then, in college, she won a dance competition that would take her to Europe. How, she wondered, would she eat?

headline: Killer of 4 Pleads Guilty to Attack in Subway
text: On a quiet Saturday morning last February, a steely-eyed young man stepped in front of a rider on a No. 3 train beneath Times Square, calmly warned him that he was about to die, and lunged out with a large knife to try to make good on the promise.

headline: Moelis Gets $93 Million Investment From Sumitomo Mitsui
text: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank founded by Kenneth D. Moelis, has signed an agreement to receive an investment of $93 million from the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, one of the largest banks in Japan, and SMBC Nikko Securities, a securities firm owned by Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, the companies announced in a joint release on Tuesday.

headline: In Tech, Starting Up by Failing
text: Every entrepreneur hopes to start the next big thing. But sometimes the first try doesn’t go as planned.

headline: Perspectives on the Wives of Priests
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Myth of ‘Anybody but Romney’
text: Perhaps the most fundamental question surrounding this year’s Republican nomination race has been what to make of the fact that support for Mitt Romney rarely exceeded 20 or 25 percent in national polls, despite seemingly running a strong campaign and being up against a somewhat marginal set of opponents.

headline: Iran Tightens Its Security for Scientists After Killing
text: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran has ordered extra security for scientists because of the drive-by assassination last week of the deputy director of the country’s primary uranium enrichment facility, which he attributed to “the evil hands of arrogance and Zionist agents,” the state-run news media reported Tuesday.

headline: Christie Proposes a 10% Income Tax Cut in New Jersey
text: TRENTON — Gov. Chris Christie vowed on Tuesday to press ahead with what he called “the New Jersey comeback,” proposing a 10 percent, across-the-board cut in income taxes and a host of changes to the state’s schools and criminal justice system.

headline: Praise for a Developer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Federal Reserve as a Hedge Fund: Higher Profits, Lower Pay
text: The year 2011 is over, and soon we’ll be hearing again about billion-dollar paydays for select hedge fund wizards.

headline: Beyond Tebowmania: Giving Women a Choice
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Diversified Education
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gingrich Renews Criticism of Romney’s Record at Bain
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Maybe it was the debate talking.

headline: Senna Switches Teams
text: Bruno Senna will drive for the Williams team in Formula One 2012. Williams was the team for which Senna’s uncle Ayrton was driving when he was killed in a crash at the San Marino Grand Prix in 1994. Bruno had raced for the Hispania team in 2010, then finished the season at Lotus Renault.

headline: The Clam Returns to Brooklyn
text: COULD the clam roll become the new lobster roll? Two new Brooklyn restaurants are betting so.

headline: Reginald Hill, Prolific Writer of Crime Novels, Dies at 75
text: Reginald Hill, the prolific British author best known for his 24 idiosyncratic but elegant crime novels featuring the Yorkshire police detectives Andrew Dalziel and Peter Pascoe, died on Thursday at his home in Cumbria, England. He was 75.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Parents Welcome, Too

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Rugby, the Royals and Unruly Behavior
text: Yeah, sure, everybody became upset last week when the police revealed they had smuggled a fake bomb into Olympic Park in a security test announced six months ahead of the London Games.

headline: Egypt: Mubarak Defense Is Opened
text: Lawyers for Hosni Mubarak, the ousted president, called him “a clean man who could not do wrong” as they began laying out their defense on Tuesday against charges that he participated in corruption and directed the killing of demonstrators. Mr. Mubarak’s chief lawyer, Farid el-Deeb, cited the testimony of the former intelligence chief Omar Suleiman that Mr. Mubarak had instructed the police to use only nonlethal weapons like tear gas, water cannons and nightsticks in battling the protests last year that ultimately ended his rule. Mr. Mubarak, 83, was once again rolled into the court on a stretcher. But for the first time since the trial began in August, he then sat up in a wheelchair, presenting his face to the court as he listened to the defense, state news media reported.

headline: At South Pole, a Game of Cricket
text: British adventurers braving weather of 31 degrees below zero played cricket on Tuesday at the South Pole to commemorate the centenary of the arrival there on Jan. 17, 1912, of the ill-fated British expedition led by Robert Falcon Scott, which reached the pole only to discover that a rival team led by Roald Amundsen, a Norwegian, had accomplished the feat a month earlier. The British cricketers won a narrow victory over a “rest of the world” team of scientists working at the Amundsen-Scott research center. The captain of the British team, Neil Laughton, a former Royal Marine commando, said he hoped the victory would have pleased Captain Scott and his four companions, all of whom died on the 900-mile return trek.

headline: U.S. Says Sudan Is Blocking Aid
text: The United States and Sudan traded accusations over the humanitarian situation in the states of Blue Nile and South Kordofan, embattled since the north and south of Sudan split into two nations last summer. About 500,000 displaced people face famine if substantial international aid does not begin to flow by March, said Susan E. Rice, the United States ambassador, calling an aid blockade imposed by Sudan “unconscionable and unacceptable.” Sudan’s United Nations envoy, Daffa-Alla Elhag Ali Osman, said the situation for most civilians in the area was “fantastic,” denying any blockade except in “pockets” where rebels took shelter.

headline: Williams Battles Injury, and Insects
text: MELBOURNE, Australia (AP) — If anything, it was the insects buzzing around Rod Laver Arena that bothered Serena Williams the most.

headline: Beyond Twitter on Capitol Hill
text: The findings of the first Congressional Hackathon were released Tuesday.

headline: Google Plans to Protest SOPA on Its Home Page
text: 11:42 a.m. | Updated to correct the number of unique visitors to Google each month.

headline: Boxers, Briefs or a Hybrid Sheath?
text: KITZBÜHEL, Austria — The latest front in nefarious performance enhancement in sports: underwear.

headline: Young, in Love and Sharing Everything, Including a Password
text: Young couples have long signaled their devotion to each other by various means — the gift of a letterman jacket, or an exchange of class rings or ID bracelets. Best friends share locker combinations.

headline: Knicks Send Two Bench Warmers to D-League
text: Jeremy Lin and Jerome Jordan became the first Knicks ever assigned to the D-League on Tuesday, when team officials sent both players to the Erie BayHawks.

headline: New Sergeant-at-Arms for the House
text: The House elected Paul D. Irving as its 37th sergeant-at-arms on Tuesday, the opening day of the second session of the 112th Congress. Mr. Irving will become the chamber’s top law enforcement official after a 25-year career in the Secret Service.

headline: In Year of Hut, Hut, Hut, the 49ers Hit, Hit, Hit
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Last week, as the San Francisco 49ers’ defense sauntered onto the field, safety Dashon Goldson wore eye black and full pads. His fellow safety Donte Whitner pushed his mouthpiece in. This would have been normal had it happened on game day, but the scene Whitner described took place last Wednesday, in practice.

headline: Gustav Leonhardt, Master Harpsichordist, Dies at 83
text: Gustav Leonhardt, the Dutch harpsichordist, organist and conductor who was a pioneer in the world of period instrument performance and research into Baroque performance styles, died on Monday at his home in Amsterdam. He was 83.

headline: Cardinals and the First Lady Celebrate
text: The St. Louis Cardinals were at the White House on Tuesday to celebrate their World Series championship but shared the moment with Michelle Obama – an avowed Chicago Cubs fan – to mark her 48th birthday.

headline: Jerry Yang, ‘Chief Yahoo,’ Steps Down From Board
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Jerry Yang has left Yahoo, the stumbling Internet company he co-founded 17 years ago, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: Seen It All on Subway? Look Under This Seat
text: It was a few minutes before 4:30 a.m. when the call came in: a suspicious passenger was aboard a Manhattan-bound subway train. Other riders were alarmed. The suspect was said to be making furtive movements.

headline: Jimmy Castor, Musician Who Mastered Many Genres, Dies at 71
text: Jimmy Castor, a singer, instrumentalist and songwriter whose mastery of genres from doo-wop to Latin soul to funk, and instruments including saxophone and bongos earned him the title Everything Man, died on Monday in Henderson, Nev. He was 71.

headline: Twinkies, the Undead Snack
text: The news that Hostess filed for bankruptcy last week was met with nostalgic dismay by millions of baby boomers who lamented what they thought was the imminent demise of the Twinkie. Hostess, which emerged from bankruptcy just three years ago, has maybe 100,000 creditors, mostly labor unions and pension funds (one of which is reportedly owed $944 million) that represent the company’s employees. Its debt approaches a billion dollars, a lot by most standards.

headline: For God So Loved the 1 Percent …
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Industry Weighs Effect of Ship Accident
text: Shares of the Carnival Corporation, the world’s largest cruise ship operator, fell 14 percent on Tuesday as analysts and investors sought to gauge the effect of the grounding of Carnival’s Costa Concordia after days of continual images and videos of the listing ship.

headline: Canada Accuses Naval Officer of Sharing State Secrets
text: OTTAWA — A Canadian naval officer who worked in some of the country’s key military intelligence centers has been charged with breach of trust and passing along government secrets to a “foreign entity.” The officer, Sub-Lt. Jeffrey Paul Delisle, 40, remained in jail on Tuesday after his lawyer asked a court in Halifax, Nova Scotia, to delay a bail hearing to give him more time to study the government’s case.

headline: World Bank Warns Developing Nations of Slowing Growth
text: WASHINGTON — The World Bank is urging developing nations to start planning for a major slowdown in global growth this year.

headline: Letter Accuses Affirmative-Action Opponent of Mismanaging Funds
text: Ward Connerly, the African-American businessman who has been the face of the movement to end affirmative action for nearly two decades, is facing accusations from a prominent former ally, Jennifer Gratz, that he has mismanaged donations.

headline: My So-Called Bipolar Life
text: Washington

headline: Colts Dismiss Caldwell as Shakeup Continues
text: Jim Caldwell was Peyton Manning’s quarterbacks coach for seven years before he became the head coach of the Indianapolis Colts two years ago and promptly led the team to the Super Bowl.

headline: Affirmative-Action Foe Is Facing Allegations of Financial Misdeeds
text: WASHINGTON — Ward Connerly, the black businessman who has been the face of the movement to end affirmative action for nearly two decades, is facing accusations from a prominent former ally that he has mismanaged — and exploited for his own benefit — donations to that cause made by fellow conservatives.

headline: Another Bitter Divorce for Perelman
text: Ronald O. Perelman’s marital breakups — divorces from the actress Ellen Barkin and Patricia Duff among them — have been rich fodder for the gossip pages. Now a split with a longtime business associate promises to be almost as acrimonious.

headline: Sherman’s Southern Sympathies
text: The Baton Rouge dinner party in early 1860 had been enjoyable, but as it went on William Tecumseh Sherman couldn’t help but hear his name mentioned repeatedly down at the table’s far end. He suspected it had something to do with his position as superintendent of the newly formed Louisiana State Seminary of Learning and Military Academy (today’s Louisiana State University). He had held the post for a few months and was well regarded by those who knew him personally, but many who didn’t were concerned that the state’s only college was run by a Northerner whose congressman brother was seen across the South as an abolitionist.

headline: Liu, Facing Investigation, Reports Drop in Donations
text: The New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, reported a sharp drop in his campaign donations on Tuesday, providing the clearest indication yet that his aspirations for the mayor’s office have been hurt by a federal investigation into his fund-raising practices.

headline: Braun, Amid Drug Furor, to Attend Awards Dinner
text: At some point Saturday evening, hundreds of baseball fans, players, officials and members of the news media will sit in rapt attention as Ryan Braun approaches the podium to make a short speech at the Hilton in Manhattan.

headline: Trust, but Verify
text: A few items came across the desk last week that underscore the challenge America faces in making policy toward the Islamist parties that are emerging as the early beneficiaries of the uprisings across the Arab world. The first was a news article about the Jan. 11 meeting in Cairo between Bill Burns, a deputy secretary of state, and Muhammad Morsi, the chairman of the Muslim Brotherhood’s political party, during which Morsi said his party “believes in the importance of U.S.-Egyptian relations,” but said they “must be balanced.”

headline: Hunting, Dear Sir? Delighted!
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.

headline: Kraft Tries an Aged Cheese Marketing Campaign
text: KRAFT FOODS is reviving a vintage marketing recipe with a campaign that promotes five Kraft cheese products together as well as separately.

headline: Romney Looks Past Weekend’s Primary as Rivals Find New Hope
text: FLORENCE, S.C. — Mitt Romney delivered a 13-minute speech here on Tuesday morning, shook hands with an audience that filled only a small part of a ballroom and caught a plane for a fund-raising gala in New York, a clear sign that he is looking beyond South Carolina.

headline: Before Giants Go West, a Few Might Head Downtown
text: The Giants have enjoyed connecting their latest postseason run to the Super Bowl title surge in 2008, but before Sunday’s N.F.C. championship game is played a less positive track record may be tested first.

headline: Greek Premier Says Creditors May Be Forced to Take Losses
text: ATHENS — Taking direct aim at hedge funds and other private holders of Greece’s debt, Prime Minister Lucas Papademos says he will consider legislation forcing the creditors to take losses on their holdings if no agreement can be reached in critical negotiations scheduled to resume Wednesday.

headline: Companies That Sell Services to Nonprofits Begin Deal Talks
text: Blackbaud, which provides software and services to help nonprofit groups manage their relationships with donors and supporters, has made an offer to acquire a competitor, Convio, for about $275 million.

headline: Preaching Division in South Carolina
text: By mixing falsehoods with racial condescension, Newt Gingrich brought a raucous presidential debate crowd to its feet on Monday night in South Carolina, further cheapening his reputation and that of the state Republican Party.

headline: Not the Bane of His Existence
text: Newt Gingrich’s closing argument to South Carolina voters is pretty simple. He’s the only candidate within striking distance of Mitt Romney in the pre-primary polling, which makes him the only candidate capable of preventing a coronation.

headline: Niles Ford, Dancer and Choreographer, Dies at 52
text: Niles Ford, a performer and choreographer who had been active in the downtown New York dance scene since the late 1970s, died on Saturday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 52.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Sound Budget
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo proposed a $132.5 billion state budget on Tuesday that features two promising ideas: one to ensure that New York will not lose more than $700 million in federal education funds and a second to save taxpayers money by reducing public pension costs.

headline: Risks for G.O.P. in Attacks With Racial Themes
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — South Carolina has the nation’s first female Indian-American governor (a Republican), the highest-ranking African-American in Congress (on the Democratic side) and a rapidly growing population of Latinos, all evidence, longtime political players here say, that the state is shedding its racially charged past.

headline: A Death Penalty Commutation
text: On Tuesday, Gov. Jack Markell of Delaware commuted the death sentence of Robert Gattis to life without parole. In doing so, he said he gave “great weight” to the careful decision of the state board of pardons to recommend that the sentence be commuted, the first such recommendation the board has made since the death penalty was reinstated there in 1974. As a condition of the commutation, which is supported by a long list of former judges and prosecutors, Mr. Gattis is expected to waive all legal challenges and live out his life in prison.

headline: How Will You Use Your Leap Second?
text: When February comes, we will receive the gift of an extra day because 2012 is a leap year. But that isn’t all the extra time we get this year. On the night of June 30, there will be one more second in the day — a leap second.

headline: Higgins, Executive and Adviser to Owner, Is Leaving the Jets
text: Matt Higgins, the Jets’ executive vice president for business operations and an adviser to the team’s owner, Woody Johnson, will step down at the end of the month.

headline: Wednesday: Bewhiskered Frolicker
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Yes, I know. Chris Handman did not, technically speaking, add a SPARE TIRE or even a TIRE to each of the starred entries as the payoff at 64 Across indicates. He added the letters T, I, R, and E to each of the entries (Update: this is a correction to my previous statement that there was an S in the theme entries), but taken in the aggregate, and looked at through the forgiving lens of artistic license, I believe he pulled this theme off very well.

headline: Those Who Seek to Make Art Often Find Themselves Alone
text: As Rosemary Harris says the word, “darkness” is a thing with tentacles that clutch and choke and smother. It erupts from her with a soul-deep rumble late in the first act of Athol Fugard’s “Road to Mecca,” which opened on Tuesday night at the American Airlines Theater. And once Ms. Harris has said “darkness”— or said it that way — it’s impossible to look on her character or the play in which she appears with the comfort of detachment.

headline: New Gas Economy Rules Generate Wide Support
text: DETROIT — Writing new regulations that will require cars and trucks to have significantly higher fuel economy by 2025 prompted years of fighting among automakers, environmentalists, regulators and consumer groups.

headline: Two Officers Sentenced in Rikers Island Assault Case
text: Two former correction officers, who were among 15 people implicated in a series of crimes at a facility on Rikers Island for inmates ages 16 to 19, were sentenced on Tuesday after they admitted to assaulting or attempting to assault prisoners in their custody.

headline: Keeping Film Aspirations Intact While Building a Life of Sobriety
text: The bookshelves in Joseph Salters’s bedroom tell the story of his life. On the bottom shelf sit well-thumbed paperbacks with titles like “Adult Children of Alcoholics” and “Narcotics Anonymous.” The top shelf is lined with Shakespeare plays and a copy of “Screenwriting Tricks of the Trade.”

headline: When Different Parts of the Country May Recover
text: Estimate of when jobs will reach pre-recession levels in metropolitan areas.

headline: In Contract Talks, City Opera Reaches Deal With a Union
text: The New York City Opera and its orchestra union have reached a tentative agreement on a contract, a step forward in the company’s effort to put on a season, officials said Tuesday. Management and the other major union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, were still in talks but reportedly making progress.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Money Flows to Republican Backers of Gay Marriage
text: ALBANY — Gay rights advocates from Wall Street to Hollywood poured donations into the coffers of four little-known Republican state senators after the lawmakers provided the decisive votes for same-sex marriage in New York last June, according to new campaign finance filings released on Tuesday.

headline: A Political Coming of Age for the Tech Industry
text: With a Web-wide protest on Wednesday that includes a 24-hour shutdown of the English-language Wikipedia, the legislative battle over two Internet piracy bills has reached an extraordinary moment — a political coming of age for a relatively young and disorganized industry that has largely steered clear of lobbying and other political games in Washington.

headline: Pinkberry Co-founder Arrested in Beating of Homeless Man
text: LOS ANGELES — The co-founder of the Pinkberry frozen yogurt franchise, Young Lee, was arrested Monday in connection with the beating of a homeless man in June.

headline: Veteran Charged in Slayings of Four Homeless Men
text: SANTA ANA, Calif.—The Iraq war veteran accused of killing four homeless men in the past month stalked his victims before striking, enjoyed the media coverage of his crimes and had a list of future victims at the time of his arrest, according to Orange County prosecutors.

headline: What the Polls Can’t Tell Us
text: Between now and November, can we expect big swings in public opinion? And if so, what does that mean for the G.O.P. front-runners?

headline: Pining for Sideshow Rex and His Bickering Jets
text: The N.F.L. conference championship games on Sunday feature nearly everything a fan could want: great offenses, tough defenses, exciting new stars, respected future Hall of Famers with perhaps their final chance at a title.

headline: Duggars Are Surprise Guests at Santorum Event
text: ANDERSON, S.C. — The two speakers who introduced Rick Santorum to the overflow crowd at a Fuddruckers here both proudly described their seven children as blessings — a popular sentiment in a gathering that was heavy with people who call themselves pro-life Christians.

headline: Rangers’ Owner Climbs Aboard Their Bandwagon
text: The giddiness over the league-leading Rangers’ latest victory, 3-0 over Nashville on Tuesday night, led to an impromptu cameo appearance by the team owner James L. Dolan at Coach John Tortorella’s postgame news conference.

headline: Knicks to Face Suns and Steve Nash, the Point Guard They Are Lacking
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

headline: For Gingrich, an Endorsement of Sorts From Sarah Palin
text: ON THE NEWT GINGRICH PRESS BUS, Interstate 20, S.C. — Sarah Palin, who conducted a lengthy flirtation with a run for the Republican nomination last year, ended the equally lengthy speculation over which candidate she would endorse by naming Newt Gingrich — sort of.

headline: Charles M. Haar Dies at 91; Used Courts to Clean Boston Harbor
text: Charles M. Haar, a Harvard Law School professor who helped spur the cleanup of the notoriously befouled Boston Harbor through the strategic use of judicial power, died on Jan. 10 in Miami. He was 91 and lived in Key Biscayne, Fla., and Princeton, N.J.

headline: Corrections: January 18
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Parties Confident of Extending Payroll Tax Cut
text: WASHINGTON — With both parties largely in agreement on a yearlong extension of President Obama’s payroll tax cut, the fight in Congress over the coming weeks will boil down to how to pay for it, and Democrats appeared to hold the advantage as members of the House returned to Washington on Tuesday.

headline: How Exercise May Keep Alzheimer’s at Bay
text: Alzheimer’s disease, with its inexorable loss of memory and self, understandably alarms most of us. This is especially so since, at the moment, there are no cures for the condition and few promising drug treatments. But a cautiously encouraging new study from The Archives of Neurology suggests that for some people, a daily walk or jog could alter the risk of developing Alzheimer’s or change the course of the disease if it begins.

headline: ‘Video Everywhere’ Gets Another Boost
text: Polycom, best known for table top phones in conference rooms, aims to pressure Cisco as the two fight over sales of cheap and easy to use videoconferencing software for small businesses and telephone companies.

headline: Taking a Swing at the Practice of Dowry
text: These are chicks you don’t want to mess with.

headline: Word of the Day | girth
text: girth •\ˈgərth\• noun and verb

headline: For India’s Army, Dispute Over Chief’s Age Rattles Leadership
text: Vijay Kumar Singh, the chief of the Indian army, on Monday filed a petition with the Supreme Court of India, asking “justices to decide a seemingly simple question: When was he born?”, Jim Yardley wrote in The New York Times.

headline: NYT Front Page for 01/18/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 01/18/2012

headline: Few Cities Have Regained Jobs They Lost, Report Finds
text: Less than a tenth of the nation’s metropolitan areas have regained the jobs they lost in the economic downturn, according to a report being released Wednesday by the nation’s mayors as they gather in Washington to express their exasperation that the federal government seems more intent on cutting aid to cities than on sending more.

headline: Delaware: Governor Commutes Death Sentence
text: Gov. Jack Markell approved the first sentence commutation in Delaware’s recent history on Tuesday, converting the death sentence of Robert Gattis to one of life in prison without the possibility of parole. Mr. Gattis, who was convicted of the 1990 murder of his longtime girlfriend, Shirley Slay, was scheduled to be executed by lethal injection on Jan. 20. Advocates for Mr. Gattis petitioned the State Board of Pardons for clemency, arguing that his abusive childhood was not understood by the court at the time of his sentencing. Mr. Markell, a Democrat, followed the advice of the board, making Mr. Gattis’s commutation conditional on his agreement not to ask for an additional commutation or a pardon. Mr. Gattis’s lawyers say he will accept those conditions. “This commutation in no way relieves Mr. Gattis of his moral or legal guilt,” Mr. Markell wrote in a statement. “My decision is among the most difficult I have had to make in all my years in public service.”

headline: Since 1980s, the Kindest of Tax Cuts for the Rich
text: The effective federal income tax rate paid by the wealthiest Americans has dropped significantly during the last several decades, largely because of tax cuts on investment income.

headline: Playing at Sundance
text: Images from select films appearing at the 2012 Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Wikipedia Blackout Lets In Some Light
text: Wikipedia’s much publicized 24-hour blackout in protest of online antipiracy laws is not, it turns out, quite so dark.

headline: Smoke Bomb Tossed Over Fence at White House
text: A smoke bomb was lobbed over the north fence of the White House on Tuesday night from a crowd of protesters affiliated with the Occupy movement participating in demonstrations aimed at lawmakers returning for the next session of Congress.

headline: McHale’s Patience Propels Her Into Third Round
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Trailing by a set and surrounded by about 100 fans encouraging her opponent to “Put her away!”, Christina McHale of the United States worked her way back from the brink of defeat on Wednesday.

headline: Rushdie’s Uncertain Date With Jaipur
text: Will Salman Rushdie show up or won’t he? That is the question everyone is asking days ahead of the Jaipur Literature Festival, which starts on Friday.

headline: Young Concedes Poor Play in Four-Set Loss
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – It wasn’t Donald Young’s day.

headline: Homai Vyarawalla, ‘First Lady of the Lens’
text: Homai Vyarawalla, India’s first female photojournalist, who died on Sunday, chronicled India’s independence with a spirit that was unmatched by the following generations, in part because of changes in India itself.

headline: Jan. 18, 1912 | Robert Falcon Scott Discovers Tent of Explorer Who Beat Him to South Pole
text: On Jan. 18, 1912, one day after reaching the South Pole, the English explorer Robert F. Scott and his expedition found a tent erected by Roald Amundsen’s expedition, which had reached the pole five weeks earlier. Inside the tent, Scott found a note addressed to him from Amundsen. Should he not return home safely, Amundsen wanted someone to tell King Haakon of Norway that he had indeed reached the pole.

headline: Disaster Cripples Cruiser, Not Cruising
text: PARIS — As every seafarer knows, it’s an ill wind indeed that blows nobody any good.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 18, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “Saints Sweep Past the Lions, Mostly by Going Over Them.”

headline: Sites Go Dark to Protest Web Piracy Bills
text: WHY is Wikipedia “going dark” today?

headline: Greek Premier Warns Hedge Funds
text: My colleague Rachel Donadio reports that Lucas Papademos, Greece’s prime minister, warned hedge funds and other private bondholders that he would consider legislation forcing them to take losses on their Greek bond holdings if no agreement can be reached in critical negotiations scheduled to resume Wednesday. It was Mr. Papademos’s first interview with a newspaper since he came to office in November. Read the full article »

headline: A Mess on the Ladder of Success
text: Throughout American history there has almost always been at least one central economic narrative that gave the ambitious or unsatisfied reason to pack up and seek their fortune elsewhere. For the first 300 or so years of European settlement, the story was about moving outward: getting immigrants to the continent and then to the frontier to clear the prairies, drain the swamps and build new cities.

headline: The Fast Life of Oscar Pistorius
text: Oscar Pistorius trains inside a converted garage at the home of his personal trainer, a former professional rugby player. Iron pull-up bars and a variety of ropes and pulleys are bolted to brick walls. Free weights are lined up on the floor, along with hammered-together wooden boxes that serve as platforms for step-ups and standing jumps. Some of the equipment is clamped to an exterior wall of the garage, opposite an uncovered patio; when it rains, athletes just carry on and get soaked. “It’s old-school,” Pistorius said as we drove up to the place early one morning. “Some of the guys who train here, they bang it so hard, they often get sick in the garden. Nobody judges them.”

headline: The Heart of the Matter: Love
text: In the spring of 1965, my husband, Grey Villet, was given a Life Magazine assignment to photograph the Lovings, an interracial married couple then embroiled in legal tangles after their arrest for miscegenation in Virginia. Grey did not concern himself with those entanglements. He chose, as he did in every essay we ever worked on together, to seek out the literal heart of the matter: a love story.

headline: Given Unlimited Resources, What Scientific or Medical Problem Would You Investigate?
text: The Science Times this week has several articles about “citizen scientists” taking research into their own hands, whether through labs open to the public (including non-scientists), or via collaborative, online sites for sharing science research and knowledge.

headline: Captain of Stricken Vessel Says He Fell Overboard in Passenger Panic
text: GIGLIO, Italy — The saga of the stricken cruise liner Costa Concordia took further twists Wednesday, with a warning from Italy’s environment minister that it could sink and news that the captain claimed he had slipped on deck and tumbled overboard, winding up in a lifeboat during the panicky passenger escape — not abandoned ship like a coward, as accused.

headline: China Expands Program Requiring Real-Name Registration Online
text: BEIJING — China will expand nationwide a trial program that requires users of the country’s wildly popular microblog services to disclose their identities to the government in order to post comments online, the government’s top Internet regulator said Wednesday.

headline: Womenscapes
text: The Female Factor is the IHT’s look at the place of women in the early 21st century. Many women have more power over their bodies and their fates than at any time in history. What are they doing with this new-found influence? Where do they want to go? This year, the third of this uniquely broad and thorough series on the world’s women, we will paint ‘’Womenscapes,’’ portraits that illustrate the vast possibilities — and the limitations — in a world that has now largely embraced women’s empowerment as a positive force.

headline: Decision to Attack Iran Is ‘Far Off,’ Israel Says
text: JERUSALEM — Israel moved to calm the increasingly tense discourse over Iran’s nuclear program on Wednesday, with the Israeli defense minister asserting that any decision on a possible pre-emptive military strike on Iranian targets was “very far off.”

headline: Mind Your Manners: Eat With Your Hands
text: “Until recently, you would have been hard-pressed to find many restaurants in the United States — especially those with $20 or $30 entrees — where digging in manually was encouraged,” Sarah DiGregorio writes in The New York Times. “Now, several high-profile chefs are asking diners to get their hands dirty, in the belief that it heightens the sensual connection to food and softens the formality of fine dining.”

text: Sara Holladay is the Fantasy Football Librarian.

headline: Ask the Elder Law Attorney: Disclosures and Loans
text: Craig Reaves, past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices elder law in Kansas City, Mo., and fields occasional questions from New Old Age readers. Submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your queries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves cannot respond with individualized legal advice. Questions have been edited and condensed.

text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: MTV’s Latest Facebook App is About Scholarships, Not Snooki
text: MTV, home to television shows like “Jersey Shore” and “Teen Mom,” might be the last place many students would think to turn for guidance about financial aid. But on Wednesday the network is launching a Facebook application to help students efficiently navigate the financial aid morass.

text: Chrome, that onetime ubiquitous detailing material with the come-hither glint, is making a comeback, if not in its original form.

headline: Tip of the Week: Easy Switching Among Programs
text: Do you have a bunch of programs open on a PC or Mac and want to switch around between them without fumbling for the mouse? On a Windows system, just hold down the Alt key while pressing the Tab key to see a box showing your open windows and applications. Keep holding down the Alt key while pressing the Tab key to cycle through the icons and let go when you get to the program or window you want to use.

headline: Man Group’s Funds Decline
text: LONDON — Man Group, the world’s largest publicly traded hedge fund, said on Wednesday that its funds under management fell 9.5 percent, to $58.4 billion, in final three months of 2011, as investors withdrew money in response to volatility in financial markets.

headline: Romney Holds Solid Lead Over Rivals
text: Mitt Romney has solidified a sizable coalition of Republican primary voters nationwide over his rivals for the G.O.P. nomination, fracturing key blocs of the party’s base, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Mind the U.N.-A.U. Gap
text: JOHANNESBURG — President Jacob Zuma of South Africa gave an unusual speech at the U.N. Security Council last week. In a plea for better relations between the United Nations and the African Union, he blamed the West for the weakness of the ties between the two organizations. Citing the intervention in Libya last spring, he accused NATO of running roughshod over the African Union’s preferences for how to prevent and resolve conflicts in Africa.

headline: On Berlin’s Literary Calendar (for English-Speakers)
text: Berlin’s rich and diverse literary scene is a crucial component of the city’s creative makeup. Since reunification, it has attracted a number of established and aspiring writers — all drawn to its openness and support for artistic expression.

headline: A Digital Wallet Now Available on Some Smartphones
text: Good news for people suffering from discomfort caused by sitting on a thick wallet full of credit cards and credit card receipts for a long duration: Visa, the credit card company, said it supported making wireless payments through some smartphones, though it would replace the plastic Visa cards issued by banks.

headline: Prediction and the Brain: A Response
text: Sincere thanks for all the thoughtful reactions to my post on the thrifty and predictive brain. I was cheered that so many posts found value or resonance in the piece, and I am especially grateful for the various suggestions of additional concrete examples in our daily life.

headline: Digital Textbooks From a Company Not Named Apple
text: There’s an old saying that if you want to be a leader and you see a parade, jump in front of it. So it is with digital textbooks, an area that’s about to experience the high-tech equivalent of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade as Apple prepares to push into the business.

headline: Cute but Tough, With a Nose for the Food in Your Bags
text: New York City does not lack for exotic and specialty food shops, but perhaps the most diverse display of ever-changing imported produce can be found in what is called the grinding room in the customs area of John F. Kennedy International Airport’s Terminal 4, the major gateway for international arrivals.

headline: Wind Turbines and Health Hazards
text: There is no conclusive evidence so far that wind turbines are responsible for health problems ranging from balance problems to diabetes, an independent panel of health experts reports.

headline: Brazil’s Ruling Family of Film
text: SOMETIMES they limit themselves simply to producing movies, though on many other occasions they have also written, directed or actually filmed them. But by any standard the Barretos — Luiz Carlos and Lucy and their children, Bruno, Fábio and Paula — are the first family of cinema in Brazil.

headline: Daily Report: A Political Coming of Age for the Tech Industry
text: The battle over two Congressional bills intended to prevent copyright violations on the Internet marks a political coming of age for the tech industry, reports Jenna Wortham in Wednesday’s New York Times. The relatively young and politically disorganized tech industry has found its voice in opposing the bills, which it says would go too far — potentially violating free speech and stifling innovation — by allowing media companies to shut down Web sites they say are abusing copyrights. It’s an issue that has led to a rare show of unity for the industry’s players — from venture capitalists to the smallest Web sites.
