headline: A Case of Good Timing, Perhaps, in Romney’s Tax Disclosure
text: The pile-on began just moments after Mitt Romney — a man easily worth more than $200 million — admitted Tuesday morning that he pays federal taxes at a rate of about 15 percent.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Wikipedia Turns Off the Lights
text: Wednesday is a day of Web-wide protest over proposed antipiracy laws. Some sites, like Google and Craigslist are donning black and encouraging visitors to contact their local members of Congress (both are still operating, however). Others, most notably the English-language Wikipedia portal, have closed for the day, while also asking visitors to lobby Congress.

headline: Street Wise | Tel Aviv’s Hot New Block
text: Nahalat Binyamin Street, which crosses lower Rothschild Boulevard — Tel Aviv’s chief axis of white Bauhaus beauties — is emerging as the microhood of the moment. By day this thin strip is all garment-district shuffle and cheeky graffiti art, but at night the street takes on a moody but electric air. You might find Bar Refaeli, or at least plenty of women who look like models, at the street’s hottest spot, Mizlala (No. 57). Here the city’s star chef, Meir Adoni, whips up dishes like fish kebabs, garlic-sage linguine with white asparagus and something called Palestinian tartar — ground beef, raw tahini paste, pine nuts, charred eggplant puree, cumin and parsley.

headline: Cuomo Puts Money Where His Mouth Is
text: As expected, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo released his proposed state budget on Tuesday, and over all it contained good news for public education: a 4 percent across-the-state increase in aid for schools. There's a catch: only districts that approve teacher evaluation systems will be eligible for the aid.  “The equation is simple at the end of the day,” Mr. Cuomo said. “No evaluation, no money. Period.”

headline: In Williamsburg, a Charter School Divides North From South
text: Community organizations and church groups packed a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, middle school on Tuesday night to protest the planned arrival of a Success Academy charter school, which they maintained is aimed at wealthy, white families, not Latinos.

headline: Court Sanctions Man Who Claims to Own Facebook Stake
text: Paul Ceglia, the man who claims to own half of Facebook, has been held in contempt of court and fined at least $5,000 – all for refusing to share.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Obesity Rates Stall, but Don’t Decline
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: How to Diagnose What’s Wrong With Your Business
text: Over the years, I have met a lot of entrepreneurs who have been frustrated by low profits, lack of growth, or the stress of the never-ending demands. Many struggle with all three. While every business is different, there are common denominators. In fact, I believe there are 10. The tricky part is that failing to have a handle on just one of these areas can result in mediocre performance, a stressful existence, or ultimate and intimate failure. That is one reason the failure rate for small businesses is so high (here are some others).

headline: Christie Takes Mild Swipe at Cuomo on Tax Plan
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey struck a remarkably friendly tone in his State of the State speech on Tuesday, but that didn’t stop him from taking a swipe across the Hudson River at Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo (though he did call him “my friend Andrew Cuomo”).

headline: Protests Against Antipiracy Bills Take to the Streets
text: 1:26 p.m. | Updated  Adding details from the rally.

headline: Russian Says Western Support for Arab Revolts Could Cause a ‘Big War’
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, warned Wednesday that outside encouragement of antigovernment uprisings in the Middle East and North Africa could lead to “a very big war that will cause suffering not only to countries in the region, but also to states far beyond its boundaries.”

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Wine Review Online: How does the alcohol content of a wine affect the body? Michael Apstein examines the question scientifically. — Eric Asimov

headline: I.M.F. Seeks $500 Billion More to Lend as It Plans to Cut Growth Forecast
text: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund announced Wednesday that it was seeking as much as $500 billion more to lend as it prepared to slash its forecasts of global growth.

headline: What the Top 1% of Earners Majored In
text: 12:21 p.m. | Updated to add a fuller list of majors at the bottom of the post.

headline: Turning Off the Dark in Myanmar?
text: PARIS — It has been almost giddy, almost gooey, even meteoric, the recent Western embrace of the regime in Myanmar.

headline: Death Penalty Death Watch: Ohio
text: Charles Lorraine, who was convicted of killing an elderly man and his bedridden wife in 1986, was scheduled to be executed by lethal injection today in Ohio. But the Sixth Circuit court isn’t going to let that happen, which is good news for those of us who oppose capital punishment. (We also wrote on our editorial page today about the Delaware governor’s decision to commute a prisoner’s death sentence to life without parole, so there are really two bits of good news.)

headline: Mutual Funds Invest in Brazilian Online Deals Company
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Peixe Urbano, Brazil’s first online daily deal company, has closed a series C round of financing with mutual funds and institutional accounts managed by Morgan Stanley Investment Management and T. Rowe Price Associates. General Atlantic and Tiger Global Management, who had previously backed the company, also participated. The size of investment was not disclosed.

headline: The Spirit of Youth, Circa 1970 New York
text: NOT long ago Alanna Heiss, the renowned curator and self-described art radical, brandished two guns at the Clocktower Gallery, the nonprofit art space she runs in Lower Manhattan. “They’re props,” she said with a grin, adding, “but they’re also for critics.”

headline: On Our Radar: Ailing Rice Coral in Hawaii
text: Scientists have discovered an outbreak of a disease in rice coral in Kaneohe Bay off Oahu, a popular spot frequented by snorkelers, bathers, divers, boaters and fishermen. [United States Geological Survey]

headline: A Performer Disappears Into Her Songs
text: Two tough sentries guarded Santigold at all times on Monday night.

headline: For Your Consideration, Ads We Wish They Ran
text: The “For Your Consideration” ad, paid for by studios and directed at Academy voters, started appearing in Hollywood trade publications sometime in the 1950s and are often quite elaborate, even for movies that don’t have a shot at winning an Oscar. (Michael Jordan, best actor in “Space Jam,” anyone?) As with everything Oscars related, they have their own artistry and market-tested logic. But though they are designed to promote an actor’s performance or a film’s good reception, they are not always entirely accurate. We know, you’re shocked, shocked!

headline: How I’m Surviving (or Trying to) Without Wikipedia at My Fingertips
text: My Internet is broken today. Hitting that “all known thought” button on my toolbar gives me a quick, maddening glimpse of Wikipedia that is then overtaken by a black screen that asks me to “Imagine a world without free knowledge.” I just did and I didn’t like it, now can I have my Wikipedia back?

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: Surfing for a Vacation Rental
text: WITH hotel rates on the rise, vacation rentals are looking attractive, often providing more space and amenities for less than you would spend on a hotel. But finding that apartment in Paris or seaside cottage in Florida can be a daunting task.

headline: Of Parrots, Paras and Time
text: A principal considers a conundrum in education today: That even as more schools are expected to try to put children with all different abilities into an "integrated'' classroom, and teachers are expected to understand that all children learn in different ways, schools still expect all children to reach the same academic goals in the same time frame.

headline: Are Inequality and Immobility Inseparable?
text: I’ve written a number of posts and pieces pushing the idea that American conservatives need what I’ve called an opportunity agenda — one that focuses more on the problems of upward mobility and stagnating wages than does the current standard Republican line, but doesn’t share contemporary liberalism’s tendency to blame the struggles of downscale Americans almost entirely on the richest 1 percent. I thought I’d use this post to respond to the most plausible left-wing critique of this idea. (I’ll tackle the most plausible right-wing critique in a later post.) First, here’s Matt Yglesias, pivoting off an excellent piece by my colleague Jason DeParle to question the idea that there’s any real distinction between fighting inequality and fighting immobility:

headline: Milan Top 5 | Gucci
text: The rich jacquard roses sprouting throughout Frida Giannini’s fall collection, an ode to the tortured prose of Wilde and Rimbaud, added a refreshingly romantic note to the usually sexy Gucci guy. A drop-shouldered, double-faced coat slouched over a low-cut sweater and scarf atop those slim floral pants, in a style Giannini describes as “Visconti grunge,” stood out most and was hardly a look for the tormented wallflower type who inspired it.

headline: Leading Off: What’s Next in Indy?
text: Even with the surprise value of the Colts firing Coach Jim Caldwell on Tuesday ranking near zero — when you lose your quarterback to injury but the rest of the team plays like it should be hospitalized, it does not look good on a coaching résumé — it did immediately bring a much larger issue to the top of the pile. With the Colts seemingly intent on ridding all vestiges of the Peyton Manning era, what does this mean for Peyton Manning?

headline: Analyst Who Is Able to Back Up Opinions
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii — During a telecast on the eve of golf’s season-opening event, Nick Faldo waded into shallow waters by predicting a “fabulous run” in the majors for a fellow Englishman, Luke Donald, the No. 1 player in the world and the reigning money champion on the PGA and European Tours.

headline: New Museum’s Record-Breaking Höller Exhibition Prepares to Close
text: A group of intrepid museum-goers as large as the population of Myrtle Beach, S.C. – slightly more than 30,000 – have screwed up their courage and plummeted down the two-story tubular slide at the New Museum’s Carsten Höller exhibition, which closes Sunday after an almost-three-month run, the museum announced.

headline: Another Mother’s Son Lost
text: I knew her name from the newspaper articles, but I did not know if I should speak to her. What would I say to the woman whose son had fallen dead at my son’s feet?

headline: Baby Brothers
text: Little brothers crop up all the time, but picture books about pesky little brothers in the shape of anthropomorphized animals who happen to be named Peter? Not so much. This month brings two of them: “Another Brother,” written and illustrated by Matthew Cordell (“Trouble Gum”), and “Peter Is Just a Baby,” written and illustrated by Marisabina Russo. Both titles could easily have rolled right out of a resentful older sibling’s mouth.

headline: Fish Is Ousted at Australian Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — No. 8 Mardy Fish, the top-ranked American, became the first top 10 player to fall in the men’s draw when he lost in the second round to the 71st-ranked Alejandro Falla of Colombia, 7-6 (4), 6-3, 7-6 (6), in three hours Wednesday.

headline: Japanese Reactors Could Operate Beyond 40-Year Cap
text: Japan could allow nuclear reactors to operate for up to 60 years if they pass safety checks, the government said Wednesday, already revealing a loophole in recently announced plans to cap their lifespans at 40 years. Chief Cabinet Secretary Osamu Fujimura told reporters on Wednesday that the 40-year cap on reactors, announced earlier this month, will still apply in principle — but operators will likely be allowed a single 20-year extension for each reactor, providing they meet strict safety standards.

headline: Isner Outlasts Nalbandian in Disputed 5-Set Victory
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – In a stunning point-blank shootout at net, John Isner of the United States slammed a forehand volley past a lunging David Nalbandian of Argentina to claim a grueling victory, 4-6, 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 (5), 10-8.

headline: In Prada’s Spring-Summer 2012 Collection, Shoes With Tailfins
text: Decades ago, Converse advertised its Chuck Taylor sneakers as “limousines for the feet.” Nike designed its Air Jordan 14 basketball shoes after Michael Jordan‘s favorite Ferrari years before Ferrari produced shoes with Puma.

headline: In Fight Over Piracy Bills, New Economy Rises Against Old
text: WASHINGTON — When the powerful world of old media mobilized to win passage of an online antipiracy bill, it marshaled the reliable giants of K Street — the United States Chamber of Commerce, the Recording Industry Association of America and, of course, the motion picture lobby, with its new chairman, former Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat and an insider’s insider.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 18
text: A view of the day in sports, from snowboarding in the Alps to cycling Down Under.

headline: The Cavs Aren’t Terrible. How Come?
text: On this day one year ago, the Cleveland Cavaliers held an astoundingly awful 8-32 record, and were right in the thick of what would become a 26-game losing streak. LeBron James had sneaked out in the night (as much as one can “sneak out” on national television), Anderson Varejao had been ruled out for the season with an ankle injury, and Mo Williams – the Cavs’ top remaining player – had been injured just days earlier.

headline: Runway in Review
text: Diesel Black GoldDesigner: Roberto LorenziDate and Location: Tuesday, Jan. 17, Via Savona, 56Photos: slide show

headline: Moncler: Fall 2012 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Rivals and Supporters Urge Romney to Release Tax Data
text: Mitt Romney‘s rivals and supporters urged him on Wednesday to release his tax returns, a day after he acknowledged that he pays an effective federal tax rate of roughly 15 percent rate.

headline: Kenneth Branagh, Star-Struck
text: The Bagger doesn’t like to play favorites – at least not yet. That comes later, when we’re trying to win our Oscar pool. But every awards season there are a few people who seem to rise above the hype machine and have engaging conversations that keep everything in perspective. (Shouts to our girl Michelle Williams.) This year the Bagger has found a new gimlet conversationalist in Kenneth Branagh, Ms. Williams’s co-star in “My Week With Marilyn.”

headline: For Callan, Life After Lehman Includes a New Husband
text: Erin Callan, the former chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, all but disappeared from Wall Street after the collapse of the firm.

headline: Those Incredible Shrinking Savings Account Rates
text: As far as savings accounts go, 2012 appears to be a continuation of last year’s Incredible Shrinking Rates.

headline: Brutal, With a Touch of Magic
text: BERLIN

headline: Regime in North Korea is Tottering, Says Kim’s Eldest Son
text: The eldest of the late Kim Jong-il’s three sons believes the despotic North Korean regime is vulnerable to collapse, according to a new book by a Tokyo-based journalist. Kim Jong-nam, who lives primarily in the gambling enclave of Macao, also says the late leader’s youngest son, and North Korea’s new leader, Kim Jong-un, is simply a figurehead. Their father died Dec. 17 at the age of 69. Read the full story from The Associated Press»

headline: A Zoo Roams Large on Milan Runways
text: MILAN

headline: Taking to the Streets of Cairo, Wielding Video Projectors
text: Updated | Thursday | 11:49 a.m. As Egyptian protesters and the ruling military council brace for confrontation next week, on the first anniversary of the revolution that forced former President Hosni Mubarak from office, activists have deployed a new weapon in their battle for public opinion: portable video projectors.

headline: Five Dishes at Romera New York
text: Miguel Sánchez Romera, the Barcelona chef who has set his sights on Manhattan with his restaurant Romera New York, is a highly articulate, cerebral cook.

headline: A D.J. Master Talks About Dance Music
text: Tiësto may be one of the older D.J.’s on the booming dance-music circuit these days, but the Dutch dance music master was one of the first musicians to prove a D.J. could compete with pop and rock acts in filling arenas. He is one of the biggest-drawing electronic acts in the world.

headline: Are the Dangers of Epidurals Overstated?
text: Does the question of whether or not a woman should have an epidural during the birth of her child really need to be a polarizing one? On Slate, Melinda Wenner Moyer considers the claims of both sides of the issue — all of which were impressed upon her during her pregnancy last year.

headline: ‘Clybourne Park’ Coming to Broadway in April
text: A critically acclaimed production of “Clybourne Park,” the 2011 Pulitzer Prize winner for drama by Bruce Norris, will open on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater on April 12, a spokesman for the show said on Wednesday.

headline: A Franchisee Decides to Take Charge
text: Last week we published a case study about William Burris, one of 10 franchisees who learned that their Australia-based franchiser, Rent Your Boxes, had gone bankrupt. Mr. Burris, who had invested more than $100,000 to purchase three territories in the Washington area, rallied by creating a new company, Rent Our Boxes, for himself and his nine fellow franchisees.

headline: Milan Top 5 | Umit Benan
text: The unmistakable sound of a tattoo gun could be heard coming from backstage while we waited for the start of Umit Benan’s fall show. Curiosity overtaking decorum, I popped behind the curtain to see an already inked model getting another actual tattoo, with a pretty raw arm to show for it. He was one of a group of real guys taking part in a barracks tableau, jubilantly postwar, that included a naked “soldier” showering (eventually he got dressed for his trip down the runway), a bruiser boxing and other assorted military types. It was a fine line to walk for a presentation, but it steered clear of cliché by committing wholeheartedly (and bodily) to the enactment. Though at times a bit too literal an interpretation, the clothing featured a lot of clever riffs on the theme, with the actual tattoo artist’s rig being the most clever. He wore a high-buttoned vest with oversize envelope pockets over a striped shirt and tie with cropped cargo pocket pants, and carried a military style jacket with leather sleeves. It was a vivid, memorable show.

headline: The Book on Mitt
text: When John McCain endorsed Mitt Romney just before the New Hampshire primary, there was some tittering about all the nasty things the Senator from Arizona said about his former rival during the 2008 Republican nominating contest—like when he called Mr. Romney a “phony” in an ad. That was a little embarrassing, especially since the John McCain who ran for president, and lost, was also a “phony” hard-righter.

headline: U.S. Debt? Bain Might Leverage It
text: Imagine how Mitt Romney would campaign if he actually ran as a private equity executive, dangerous though that may be in this era of the Tea Party and Occupy Wall Street.

headline: Federer, Murray, and Dolgopolov: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Christopher Clarey, who covers tennis for The Times and The International Herald Tribune, answers questions from readers. Additional answers will be posted on Straight Sets throughout the Australian Open.

headline: In Sweden, Twitter Is Democratic, and File Sharing Is a Religion
text: This week, Sweden is a lesbian truck driver named Hanna.

headline: LL Cool J to Host Grammys
text: LL Cool J will host the Grammy Awards next month, marking the first time in seven years that the show’s producers have decided to go with a single master of ceremonies, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced on Wednesday. Since 2008, the rapper and actor has been the host for the televised nominations concert the Grammys produces in the fall. This is the first time, however, he will be asked to keep the main ceremony moving along.

headline: The FOF Theory of the GOP Primary
text: Steve Benen notes that by normal standards, Mitt Romney is a terrible candidate — but just not as bad as his rivals. He adds,

headline: Clijsters Seeks Meaning as She Winds Down Her Career
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It looked so easy for Kim Clijsters at the Australian Open on Wednesday as she leaned into her strokes from inside the baseline and dispatched the overmatched Stéphanie Foretz Gacon, 6-0, 6-1, in well under an hour.

headline: TimesCast | January 18, 2012
text: Internet companies flex their political muscle by opposing proposed piracy legislation | Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich vie for South Carolina's conservative voters.

headline: Academy Releases Foreign-Language Shortlist
text: The Academy has released its shortlist for the foreign-language Oscar and it’s an interesting list, with some names expected (like the entries from Iran, Israel, Germany) and some more surprising. The Belgians declined to nominate the Dardenne brothers’ film “The Kid With a Bike,” and their choice, “Bullhead,” a crime drama, made the cut:

headline: Can I See Your Tax Return?
text: David Brooks: Gail, I’m sorry we missed each other in South Carolina, but I’ve moved on to the next primary state, Florida, in search of people who pay Mitt Romney’s 15 percent tax rate. I’m in Palm Beach now. I think I’ve found them.

headline: Down on the Farm, a Sculpture Finds a Second Life
text: At Pennsylvania’s Farm Show, a boy of around 10 proudly presents his prize dairy calf to onlookers. Chin held high, he accepts the golden ribbon for best of show. Today, he’s the talk of the town, but tomorrow he’ll be converted into a pile of melted grease to be mixed in with liquid manure. He’s part of the show’s famous 1,000-pound butter sculpture, and he’s going to be recycled.

headline: Inside Debate Prep at Fox News, a Discussion Over Race Question
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — The frosty exchange over race and social welfare between Juan Williams and Newt Gingrich during Monday night’s Fox News debate has become a breakout moment of the South Carolina primary. For many conservatives, it demonstrates how liberals defend a broken entitlement system. And for many liberals, it shows how minorities are often unfairly caricatured as addicted to government aid.

headline: For the Love of Ink and Paper
text: Earl Kallemeyn insists that he is not a designer. He is not a businessman. He is not an artist or an engineer. He’s just the person who puts the ink on the paper.

headline: Rejecting Pipeline Proposal, Obama Blames Congress
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday rejected, for now, the proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline, saying the $7 billion project could not be adequately reviewed within the 60-day deadline set by Congress. While the president’s action does not preclude later approval of the project, it sets up a baldly partisan fight over energy, jobs and regulation that will most likely persist through the November election.

headline: Climate in Classrooms
text: There’s much to explore about the challenges in teaching about the evolving relationship between people and their climate.

headline: Coming Soon | Belted Coats
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Gingrich Says His Tax Rate Was 31 Percent
text: WINNSBORO, S.C. — I’ll show you mine. Now you show me yours.

headline: Reactions to the Web’s Protests Against Piracy Bills
text: On Wednesday morning, as people tried to gain access to  7,000 sites around the Web — including Flickr, Tumblr, Wikipedia, Google and Reddit — they were greeted with gloomy black boxes and error messages.

headline: Some Comments on the Rise and Fall of Twinkies
text: The third-to-last of the nearly 40 ingredients that make up a Twinkie is listed on the package as “sorbic acid (to retain freshness).” It’s the only ingredient that comes with an explanation of its purpose, as if it’s essential for us to understand that this Twinkie is as good as it was when it was made.

headline: The Giants Get Ready for Some Stormy Weather
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – As the Giants began practice Wednesday for the N.F.C. championship game this weekend, they did so with a virtually full complement of players. Running back Ahmad Bradshaw was the only player not working in early drills, and linebacker Mark Herzlich – who has been out with an ankle injury – returned to the field for the first time since Nov. 28.

headline: Have Soccer Questions? Jack Bell Has Answers
text: Who will win the English Premier League–one of the two Manchester teams or Tottenham? Has the U.S. men’s national team made any progress since Jurgen Klinsmann took over as coach last July? How will the U.S. women’s national team do in its Olympic qualifying games in Vancouver this month? Jack Bell, who covers soccer for The Times, will answer questions from readers. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear early next week on Goal.

headline: Letterpress
text: Earl Kallemeyn has been a pressman all his life. He reflects on why the letterpress is an important tool, and its changing role today.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 19
text: Model Karlie Kloss on what she’s wearing now and hip Hawaiian shirts from J. Crew and Stella McCartney.

headline: Time to Face the Pain
text: Last year in Mexico, just a couple of days into my vacation, I fractured my kneecap. In the emergency room, through pain so severe I found myself yelling at all helpful parties around me, particularly my wife, the doctors noted that they did not have painkillers to send home with me. “WHAT!?” I screamed. “No oxycodone, hydrocodone, nothing?” They explained that Mexico’s drug laws had grown so strict due to the actions of the narcotraficantes that pain meds were tough to come by (and only provided to patients who had been admitted to the hospital).

headline: Justices Rule for Inmate After Mailroom Mix-Up
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that an Alabama death row inmate who missed a filing deadline thanks to a mix-up in the mailroom of a prominent New York law firm must be given another chance.

headline: Adele Ties ‘Titanic’ on Billboard Chart
text: At this point, Adele’s run at the top of the Billboard chart is titanic. Literally: This week Adele’s “21” (XL/Columbia) notches its 16th No. 1, the first time since the “Titanic” soundtrack in 1998 that a release has topped the list as many times. As Billboard notes, only three albums in the last 20 years have had more weeks at No. 1: Billy Ray Cyrus’s “Some Gave All,” which had 17 in 1992; Garth Brooks’s “Ropin’ the Wind,” with 18 in 1991 and 1992; and the soundtrack to “The Bodyguard,” with 20 in 1992 and 1993.)

headline: New York City Opera Announces Deal With Unions
text: New York City Opera cleared a major obstacle in its effort to forge ahead in reduced form and without its Lincoln Center home, saying on Wednesday that it had reached agreements with both of its major unions. Rehearsals were to begin immediately.

headline: The History Of Capital Gains Taxes
text: Here’s how Romney’s low taxes will be defended by smarter conservatives (the less smart ones will just shout “class warfare”): they’ll claim that there are compelling reasons to have low taxes on capital gains, and that there is therefore nothing wrong with having very high-income people paying lower tax rates than the middle class. David Frum offers a good example.

headline: Scouting Report
text: EVENTS

headline: Behold the Power of Google
text: Talk about instant gratification.

headline: The Pleasures and Pitfalls of Off-the-Grid Solar
text: For our year living in the woods of Maine, I wanted a place where I could see and hear wildlife. Someplace both quiet and remote.

headline: Facing Elections, Sarkozy Focuses on the Jobless
text: PARIS — With the French jobless rate at a 12-year high and elections approaching, President Nicolas Sarkozy brought union and business leaders together on Wednesday for a “social summit” meeting to discuss legal changes to promote greater economic flexibility.

headline: Veil of Silence Lifted in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA — As a solitary voice intoned a traditional Indonesian harvest song, dancers acted out the gathering of rice. Members of the audience joined in — most knew the words — until the song was overtaken by a vigorous hip-hop backbeat.

headline: Winter Wonders | Dark Stars
text: There comes a time in every woman’s winter when nothing but a simple black coat will do. Here, the actress Rachel McAdams goes bare-legged in one with cool buckle closures; the actress Jessica Alba chooses a collarless style with shiny shoulder embellishments (an easy complement to all that color underneath); and the actress Catherine Zeta-Jones elevates a sharper duster with a cherry red clutch and heels.

headline: Trial Set for Financier Accused in Decades-Long Ponzi Scheme
text: HOUSTON — A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that R. Allen Stanford, the Texas financier accused of defrauding thousands of investors in a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, will go on trial next week, nearly three years after his arrest.

headline: Where Koreans Go to Reunify (Hint: It’s Not the Koreas)
text: SIEM REAP, Cambodia — At a roadside restaurant here near the sprawling ancient ruins of Angkor Wat, busloads of South Korean tourists file in to witness an unexpectedly exotic spectacle: doll-faced North Korean women performing everything from saccharine ballads to a rousing number from Bizet’s “Carmen.”

headline: A ‘Matchmaker’ for Drivers and Parking Spaces
text: We’ve all been in this situation: You drive to an important appointment in the city — or a big outing, say, at a sports arena — and waste precious time frantically looking for a parking spot that won’t cost you a day’s wages.

headline: On the Sea of Tranquillity
text: THE fashion industry’s concept of a cruise season has long amused and confused me. Also known as resort, a term that might gain momentum following the deadly crash of the Costa Concordia, it’s a small, lightweight collection of clothes marketed at people who can afford long jaunts to the tropics when the rest of us are trudging through sludge and applying extra lashings of bronzer to our ghastly January pallor. It blithely ignores what the great wobbly mass of American humanity tends to wear while traveling — e.g., velour tracksuits and Disney mouse ears.

headline: Bill T. Jones Takes a Turn on the Stage in New Work
text: It’s tempting to say that Bill. T. Jones has followed the classic trajectory from artistic outsider to consummate insider. Mr. Jones, a choreographer, writer and theater director whose reputation was built on provocative work that marries high-art aesthetics with social concerns, has journeyed from the stages of downtown dance to two Tony awards for choreography and a Kennedy Center Honor. But Mr. Jones, in a recent interview, insisted that he is still a “stranger in a strange land,” making an “audacious” shuttle between avant-garde and commercial audiences.

headline: Manning Leaves Practice Because of Illness
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – In what can only be thought of as stomach-churning news for the Giants, quarterback Eli Manning left practice early Wednesday because of illness.

headline: Instead of a New Novel, Cormac McCarthy Delivers a Screenplay
text: “An aged man is but a paltry thing/A tattered coat upon a stick, unless/Soul clap its hands and sing,” Yeats wrote in “Sailing to Byzantium,” the poem whose first line Cormac McCarthy borrowed as the title of his 2005 novel, “No Country for Old Men,” which was made into the Oscar-winning movie by Joel and Ethan Coen.

headline: Teachers Urged to Attend Panel Meeting
text: In a robo-call placed to teachers on Tuesday night, their union's president, Michael Mulgrew, urged them to attend the monthly meeting of the Panel for Educational Policy at Brooklyn Technical High School in Fort Greene on Wednesday night. "We’re going to express our opinion," Mr. Mulgrew said about his plans for the evening.

headline: TimesCast | Tech Sector's Clout
text: January 18, 2012 - As Wikipedia and other websites go dark Wednesday, protesting proposed anti-piracy legislation, a new axis of influence emerges in Washington.

headline: Peer Review Meets D.I.Y.: Publishing a Student Science Journal
text: Overview | How are scientific discoveries made, and how does science advance? In this lesson, students consider and analyze the longstanding peer review model, consider it the context of a movement to make science more open and collaborative and conduct an exercise in peer review and journal publication.

headline: Tigers Lose Martinez to Knee Injury, Mull Signing a Replacement
text: The hopes of the Detroit Tigers took a big jolt when the team announced on Tuesday that the valuable designated hitter Victor Martinez sustained a torn anterior cruciate ligament and could miss the 2012 season. Martinez’s injury occurred last week, during an agility workout to prepare for spring training and the upcoming season. He is in the process of seeking other opinions on his treatment options, but the outcome is expected to be the same: reconstruction surgery and many months of rehab.

headline: Carlyle Readies an Unfriendly I.P.O. for Shareholders
text: It is quite possible that the Carlyle Group, the private equity firm that is preparing to go public, is proposing the most shareholder-unfriendly corporate governance structure in modern history.

headline: ‘The Mountaintop’ Recoups On Broadway
text: The Broadway production of “The Mountaintop,” Katori Hall’s drama about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s final night before his assassination, has recouped its entire capitalization of $3.1 million, the lead producers Jean Doumanian and Sonia Friedman announced on Wednesday. The play opened to mixed reviews in October, but ticket sales proved durable in part because of the drawing power of its stars, Samuel L. Jackson (as King) and Angela Bassett (as a mysterious motel maid).

headline: Scene City: InStyle’s Golden Globes After-Party
text: Wall-to-wall celebrities at the undersea-themed party.

headline: After the Globes Show, the Party Rush
text: IF it weren’t for the wall-to-wall celebrities, the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Los Angeles might have been mistaken for the Los Angeles airport.

headline: New Episodes Lift Fox on Slow Night
text: After a monthlong holiday hiatus, “Glee” and “New Girl” returned with new episodes to give Fox a lift in the broadcast television ratings on an otherwise sluggish Tuesday night. How sluggish? According to Nielsen data, CBS was still the No. 1 network in total viewers despite a full slate of repeats on the schedule. Fox was first in the advertiser-coveted 18-to-49-year-old demographic, as “New Girl” was the highest-rated program of the night in that category. The show also had a total audience of 6.9 million viewers. “Glee” finished with more viewers (7.5 million) but was second among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Museum of Contemporary Art to Create Original Programming for YouTube
text: Joining its hometown industry and betting on the success of YouTube’s new initiative to promote original content, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles announced that it would start an online video channel in July featuring news and talk-show programming, among other art-focused shows.

headline: Italian Trial of American Antiquities Dealer Comes to an End
text: ROME – The trial of the American antiquities dealer Robert Hecht ended this week in Rome when a three-judge panel ruled that the statute of limitations on his alleged crimes – receiving artifacts illegally looted from Italy and conspiring to deal in them – had expired.

headline: Mitt’s Best Friend
text: There’s some buzz today about a Gingrich surge, based on a national Rasmussen poll showing him rising after this week’s debate performances, as well as non-statistical indicators like Sarah Palin’s kinda-sorta endorsement and the Romney camp’s decision to stop ignoring the former speaker and start attacking once again. In the absence of any hard data on the South Carolina race, though, I’m sticking by my assessment in this week’s Campaign Stops column, which argues that Gingrich has been an ideal rival for Romney:

headline: The Get | Marni Clutch
text: This two-in-one Marni clutch has a girlish pink polka dot on one face and a bolder, more Marniesque green and black print on the flip side. Big enough to carry your BlackBerry and Kindle but not so big that you lose your lipstick in it, the versatile accessory tackles mood swings as easily as it does the whole day-to-night dressing thing. What to do? Just switcheroo!

headline: On TV, Antipiracy Coverage May Include a Disclosure
text: As television networks have covered Internet companies’ positions against antipiracy legislation before Congress this week, they have had to consider whether to disclose the positions of their parent companies — virtually all of which have campaigned in favor of it.

headline: Obama to Start Advertising as Early as Thursday
text: President Obama’s campaign has begun buying advertising time in a handful of key battleground states, making his first purchase of television time so far this election.

headline: Gap Narrows Between Android and iPhone
text: It looks like the holidays were very big for the iPhone.

headline: Web Sites Aim to Join Protests While Keeping Their Mojo

headline: New Laws Possible In Wake of MF Global’s Demise
text: Lawmakers are considering new policies aimed at preventing a repeat of the MF Global debacle, in which the futures brokerage firm misused an estimated $1.2 billion in customer money as it collapsed.

headline: Romney Hits Some Bumps in South Carolina
text: SPARTANBURG, S.C. — Just a week ago, Mitt Romney, flush from a big victory in the New Hampshire primary, was all high hopes and big smiles as he boarded a charter flight to South Carolina — “It’s a lovely state, can’t wait to be there,” he said, before adding that he expected South Carolina, a state where he finished fourth four years ago, to be a “challenge.”

headline: TimesCast | S.C.’s Conservative Vote
text: January 18, 2012 — In South Carolina, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingirich are dueling to be the more conservative alternative to Mitt Romney.

headline: Bosh and Anderson, Efficiency Experts
text: Shot creation has long been crucial to ascendancy as a premier scorer, but Michael Jordan’s eminence brought that particular skill to unprecedented heights. Jordan revolutionized one-on-one play with his electricity; one of his many enduring legacies is the way scorers are perceived and evaluated today.

headline: Imperfect Makeup Is a Trend for 2012
text: Goodbye, lip liners, brow pencils, spackled-on foundations.

headline: You Can Fall Out of Bed and Look Good
text: GOODBYE, lip liners, brow pencils, spackled-on foundations. The hottest beauty trend of 2012 is imperfection.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: BEAUTY SCHOOL START-UP Frustrated with YouTube makeup tutorials? Here’s a more hands-on option: the Make Up for Ever Academy. The company has branches in Paris (where its headquarters are); Nice, France; Hong Kong, and Beirut. A school in Union Square (above), which opened this month, is its first in North America. That one includes a lecture room with individual stations and a photo studio. Three makeup courses are available: Beauty-Fashion, Television-Film and Stage-Artistic (a seven-week program costs $4,450). Apply at makeupforeverusa.com/mufe/academy/.

headline: Dennis Kucinich’s Favorite Film
text: Like everyone else on the Internet today, the Bagger is dedicated to providing you with weird facts that you would otherwise find on Wikipedia. Has anyone demanded their money back after seeing “The Artist,” for being a silent film in an era of talkies? Yup. Is Tina Fey the queen of photobombing awards shows? You betcha. What is Representative Dennis Kucinich’s favorite movie this year?

headline: Before Tearing Out a Wall, Check Your Phone
text: I’m never more inspired to tackle a home improvement project than after watching a TV show in which an attractive expert rejuvenates a living room in a day, for less than $200.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Two novelists who turned heads with their debuts are back this month with their sophomore novels, mingling with two first-timers and two more seasoned writers. And something must be in the water, as two of the books practically share an aquatic title.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Gaza, Indonesia, Italy and Israel.

text: In South Carolina, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingirich are dueling to be the more conservative alternative to Mitt Romney.

headline: Concerts to Be Focus in Shift From HDNet to AXS TV
text: 6:25 p.m. | Updated Ryan Seacrest, his talent agency CAA and the events promoter A.E.G. have been talking for three years about making a cable channel for concerts, live events and other entertainment.

headline: Online Fracas for a Critic of the Right
text: For Corey Robin the author it’s been a bruising few months. Shortly after his essay collection “The Reactionary Mind: Conservatism From Edmund Burke to Sarah Palin” appeared last fall, The New York Times Book Review published a review by Sheri Berman dismissing the book as “a diatribe that preaches to the converted,” “so filled with exaggeration and invective that the reader’s eyes roll.” Then in late December, The New York Review of Books ran a withering assessment by Mark Lilla, who dismissed the book as “history as W.P.A. mural, ” if not the left-wing scholarly equivalent of Glenn Beck’s blackboard scribblings.

headline: Patients With Normal Bone Density Can Delay Retests, Study Suggests
text: Bone loss and osteoporosis develop so slowly in most women whose bones test normal at age 65 that many can safely wait as long as 15 years before having a second bone density test, researchers report in a new study.

headline: Shopping for Writing Desks
text: The novelist Arthur Phillips found writing desks from the sublime to the affordable.

headline: Writing Desks
text: When Arthur Phillips bought his wife an enormous television for Christmas, he failed at what he calls the “manly art” of measuring. Too big for its intended cabinet, the TV now sits on Mr. Phillips’s desk.

headline: Yu Darvish Signs With the Rangers
text: For several years Yu Darvish, an icon of Japanese baseball, has been dominating batters on the other side of the planet, mostly unseen by Americans other than the legions of scouts and executives who yearned for the day when he would test his skills in Major League Baseball.

headline: Heather Armstrong and Her Husband Announce Their Separation — by Blog
text: Heather Armstrong, a k a Dooce, a k a Queen of the Mommy Bloggers, has announced, via blog post, that she and her husband, Jon, are at least temporarily separating. Mr. Armstrong echoed her words on his own blog, Blurbomat, and publicly announced that he’s available — for work, that is. The small media empire the couple spun from Ms. Armstrong’s blog, Dooce.com (which famously got Ms. Armstrong fired from her job in 2002), once supported them both, along with two daughters and a dog. But apparently the company Ms. Armstrong runs will no longer support Jon  (at least not until they’re talking settlement).

headline: How Wikipedia Turned Off the Lights
text: On Wednesday, Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia, directed its English-language visitors to a spooky, black-and-white Web page that read, “Imagine a World Without Free Knowledge.” The page, part of a protest against two online piracy bills, was simple and minimalistic. But the path to its publication was more complicated.

headline: Anthony Giardina on How a House Speaks for Its Owner
text: “If you know you’re looking for a beautiful house, you approach it with a certain discernment,” Anthony Giardina said. But when a piece of real estate captures your imagination from out of nowhere, he added, “The desire gets amped up.”

headline: Inching Closer to Agreement on Evaluations for Teachers
text: In the long-simmering debate over how to judge the quality of New York State school employees, there is one thing all sides agree on: a system should be in place. The sticking point has been agreeing on how to do it.

headline: Gingrich Cuts Romney’s Lead in South Carolina,  Poll Finds
text: Newt Gingrich has gained significant ground on Mitt Romney in South Carolina as the two men intensify their rhetoric with three days left before Republicans go to the polls on Saturday.

headline: Campaign Fund Balances Hint at Candidates for City Races
text: Political chatter in New York City has focused on the 2013 campaign for mayor, as Michael R. Bloomberg prepares to leave City Hall after 12 years in office.

headline: Gingrich Feels Heat From Romney, and Welcomes It
text: WARRENVILLE, S.C. — Newt Gingrich is having a flashback to mid-December, when the word “surge” appeared in every news account mentioning his name, and Mitt Romney perceived him as a real enough threat to bother to attack him.

headline: Bloomberg Says He Pays Highest Tax Rate and Opposes Hedge Fund Break
text: A day after Mitt Romney conceded that he paid a lower tax rate than many Americans, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg — another politician who made his fortune in the financial industry — said on Wednesday that he personally paid “the highest personal income tax rate.”

text: President Obama has at times failed to stand up for his principles (or at least what I thought were his principles) under the relentless Republican campaign to deny him anything he wants, even if the nation badly needs it.

headline: EBay Reports Stronger Earnings, Fueled by PayPal
text: SAN FRANCISCO — EBay’s net income soared in the fourth quarter, in large part because of the sale of its remaining investment in Skype and continued success of PayPal.

headline: Pollo
text: TUCKED under a sign for a Vietnamese restaurant in a hard-to-find pocket of Chinatown, the Mexican restaurant Pulqueria does not have to work overtime to feel hidden. Owned by Heather and Christopher Tierney, the brother and sister who operate Apothéke, an absinthe den next door, Pulqueria gets a cool crowd that is drawn to its speakeasy atmosphere and inventive cocktails.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I’ve inherited a rundown home. Is it better to sell as is or invest in repairs and upgrades?

headline: A Grim Aspect of Modernity (and a Breezy Tour)
text: While visiting the Alhambra, Cullen Murphy, editor at large at Vanity Fair, overheard a guide recounting the momentous events of 1492. King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella united Spain under a single Roman Catholic monarchy; Columbus journeyed west; and all Jews who refused to convert to Christianity were expelled, part of the rulers’ full-bodied embrace of the Inquisition.

headline: What You Get for ... $1 Million
text: CLIFTON TOWNSHIP, WIS.

headline: Older Women and Bone Tests
text: How often should older women be tested for thinning bones? Though it’s been nearly 15 years since Congress passed the Bone Mass Measurement Act mandating Medicare coverage for bone density tests to prevent osteoporosis, nobody really knew — until now.

headline: Pressed by Europe, Hungary Backtracks on New Laws
text: BRUSSELS — Accused of undermining fundamental democratic principles, Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban, beat a tactical retreat on Wednesday. He offered to change details of controversial new laws, but he rejected claims that his country was sliding toward authoritarianism.

headline: Pass the Tea and the Remote and Put on Your Tiaras
text: TO much of the civilized world, the “entail” sounds like some part of a cow that Mario Batali might serve alla Romana. But to aficionados of “Downton Abbey,” which recently began a second, highly anticipated season on PBS, it is “the great matter,” the root of all evil — and all delight.

headline: Bling! Vavoom! Celebrities! A Concert, Too

headline: On Spec: Vintage-Style Glasses Online
text: AT Morgenthal Frederics, the fashionable eyeglass store, a pair of espresso-colored Stephanie frames, hand-carved from 12 layers of horn from Asian water buffaloes, sells for $1,495. And that’s not counting the mother-of-pearl flourishes, which push the price to $1,795.

headline: For Online Protests, Throwing Spaghetti Against the Internet
text: The World Wide Web is still learning how to stage protests online, with people and companies trying different tactics, throwing spaghetti against the Internet and trying to see what sticks.

headline: Does Gingrich Have Momentum in South Carolina?
text: Every contentious campaign seems to have moments when there is conflicting evidence about which candidate, if any, has the momentum in the race.

headline: Digital Notes: Grooveshark Copyright Suit and Its Unusual Evidence
text: In the music industry’s frequent lawsuits over unauthorized content online, the court documents are often stuffed with dreary material like server logs and long lists of copyrighted songs. But the latest high-profile case, against Grooveshark, centers on some unusual and controversial evidence: a pair of anonymous blog comments.

headline: Bloomberg 'Optimistic' on Teacher Evaluations
text: A day after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called on school districts to negotiate new teacher evaluations with their unions or risk losing hundreds of millions of dollars in aid, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Schools Chancellor Dennis Walcott toured a Bronx high school and said they were optimistic they can still strike a deal. But they said they are also pursuing a separate plan to close and reopen 33 failing schools.

headline: At P.S. 41, College Planning Begins in Pre-K
text: Because of a new program P.S. 41 in Staten Island launched earlier this month, the "college" word will be used a lot more within the school’s walls, said Elise Feldman, the principal. The program teaches students about the importance of getting a college education, and it's based on the belief that it's never too early to start planning for it.

headline: The Key to Creativity: Solitude or Teams?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Commercial, Sandwiched Between Lines of Dialogue on ‘Hawaii Five-0’
text: Product placement in scripted television shows has quickly become a fact of life, as struggling networks seek new ways to make money. Sometimes it’s done subtly, sometimes with a sledgehammer. But this example from “Pu’olo,” Monday’s episode of “Hawaii Five-0″ on CBS, was particularly egregious — the most jarring, disruptive and insulting example I’ve seen.

headline: Two Teenagers on the Bottom Rung, Yearning to Improve Their Uncool Status
text: The timing of the animated series “Unsupervised” is unfortunate. A kind of reversed “Beavis and Butt-Head” — in which the teenage heroes, while losers in just about every way, are also social strivers yearning for suburban domesticity and dispensing Oprah Winfrey-style affirmations — it has the bad luck of coming along three months after the original was revived by MTV. The new show looks awfully pale by comparison.

headline: Nine Things You Didn’t Know About Twitter
text: Twitter, the minimalist-format social network that claims to have 100 million users, has built its reputation around its simplicity. Members can post to the service only in text messages of 140 characters or less. They can include a link to another site, or to a photo or video. They can repost other users’ messages on their own pages. They can send each other equally spartan private messages. That’s about it — or so it seems.

headline: Poll Shows Obama’s Vulnerability With Swing Voters
text: President Obama opens his re-election bid facing significant obstacles among independent voters, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, with the critical piece of the electorate that cemented his victory four years ago open to denying him a second term.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 12 through 17 with 1,154 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,021 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Sharp Edges, but a Soft Glow
text: The carbon fiber Victory lamp made by Novaled, a German company, features a new type of light source: organic light-emitting diodes, or OLEDs, a technology that uses thin layers of film to produce a more diffuse light than traditional LEDs. “If you look into the light source, there’s no glare whatsoever,” said Uli Petzold, founder of the Miami lighting design company Uli+friends, the exclusive distributor of the $7,500 lamp in the United States. “The color temperature is very warm.”

headline: Pill Organizers Pretty Enough to Come Out of the Cabinet
text: Hoping to remedy an everyday annoyance — the management of medications and vitamins — the health and wellness company Sabi has developed a range of products. Created by the industrial designer Yves Béhar, they can be used to dispense, organize, carry, crush and cut pills. With shapely, ergonomic curves, the pieces are intended to be easily used by an aging population, but visually appealing to all generations.

headline: What's the Best Way to Protect Against Online Piracy?
text: Online protests against anti-Web piracy measures sent lawmakers scrambling, but what’s the alternative?

headline: Photographing the Pool, as California Icon
text: What is the most enduring symbol of the Southern California lifestyle? Daniell Cornell, senior curator at the Palm Springs Art Museum, believes it’s the swimming pool.

headline: Madeline Weinrib Branches Out
text: It’s been almost 14 years since Madeline Weinrib, the granddaughter of the ABC Carpet & Home founder Max Weinrib, introduced her first collection of rugs there. Several years later, she turned an area on the sixth floor of the store into what she called her Atelier, which sold the rugs, as well as pillows, napkins and other objects she designed.

headline: Sales at Canvas and Dempsey & Carroll
text: Decorative pillows are up to 30 percent off at the Michele Varian shop at ABC Carpet & Home, through Jan. 28 (the Skull and Sword ultrasuede pillow in black, originally $245, is $172); 888 Broadway (19th Street), (646) 602-3367.

headline: Quiet Strutting at the Men’s Shows in Milan
text: MILAN

headline: How to Argue About Politics
text: As a philosophy professor, I spend much of my time thinking about the arguments put forward by professional philosophers. As a citizen (and an occasional columnist for The Stone), I also spend lots of time thinking about the arguments put forward by Democrats and Republicans on currently disputed political issues. Of course, there are differences in logical sophistication and complexity between the philosophical and the political arguments. But, allowing that popular political arguments require shortcuts from full academic rigor, there is not, I think, that much difference between the logical acumen of politicians and philosophers.

headline: An Oscar Shortlist Tilts East
text: Two films from the Islamic world and one from Israel. An Asian historical epic with a strong resemblance to the futuristic “Avatar.” And a dance meditation that’s also a contender for best documentary. The shortlist for the Oscar for best foreign language film, announced Wednesday by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, can always be counted on for surprises and intrigues. This year’s semifinalists, which include a Canadian entry, underlined a shift away from the Academy’s Eurocentric focus in the past, with just four films from Europe rounding out the group.

headline: For Super Bowl XLVI, a Bigger Batch of First-Time Advertisers
text: SOMETIMES a team comes to the Super Bowl having never played one. That is also true on the advertising side of the game. And for Super Bowl XLVI, to be broadcast by NBC on Feb. 5, there will more first-time sponsors than usual.

headline: Leading Your Weakest Suit Can Distract Your Opponent
text: At the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., the winners of the first two-day knockout teams, on Jan. 10 and 11, were Kelley Hwang of New York City; William Ehlers of Montclair, N.J.; Richard DeMartino of Riverside, Conn.; and John Stiefel of Wethersfield, Conn.

headline: Obama Plans Trip to Five States
text: President Obama plans three days of travel to five battleground states after he delivers his nationally televised State of the Union address next Tuesday, a trip that the White House bills as official but one that has all the markings of his first campaign swing of the year.

headline: Icahn Raises Bet on WebMD
text: Carl C. Icahn won’t be deterred by WebMD‘s woes.

headline: Headphones to Shut Out the World
text: In the olden days, you didn’t need much to enjoy air travel: a pair of goggles, a trusty biplane and a song in your heart. These days, the equipment list is slightly longer: a roll-on bag, a neck pillow and an eye mask — not to mention T.S.A.-friendly slip-on shoes, a fold-out laptop case and an all-plastic watch.

headline: Unearthing the Meaning in a Massacre
text: There’s a revealing image late in “Grey Matter”: a lingering close-up of wind chimes made from keys and shards of green glass. Shortly before, the glass was part of a bottle, shattered by a young man as a means to slit his own throat. From despair, art.

headline: Norman Finds Comfort Zone With Clinton
text: LA QUINTA, Calif. — Greg Norman did not expect to like President Bill Clinton, whose politics he opposed. So when the call came from the White House inviting Norman to play golf with Clinton in Norman’s native Australia in 1994, he was inclined to turn it down.

headline: Brown Asks California to Cheer Rail Project
text: SACRAMENTO — Gov. Jerry Brown on Wednesday threw his unequivocal support behind a $100 billion high-speed rail line that has come under fire here in California and across the country, embracing it in a strikingly optimistic State of the State speech in which he asserted that government should pursue ambitious ventures even during times of economic strife.

headline: Regulators Concerned About How to Apply Volcker Rule
text: A federal proposal that seeks to bar banks from trading with their own money has found few friends in Washington and on Wall Street.

headline: Clarity on Pipeline Decision, From North of the Border
text: For White House reporters covering President Obama’s controversial decision on Wednesday to reject, for now, the proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada to the Gulf of Mexico, it helped to have a colleague reporting from the Canadian prime minister’s office.

headline: Hudson Valley Democrat Won’t Seek 11th Term in Congress
text: Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, a 10-term Democrat from the mid-Hudson Valley, announced on Wednesday that he would not seek re-election this year.

headline: Cruise Lines Use Law and Contracts to Limit Liability
text: The wreck of the Costa Concordia has attracted those habitual companions of disaster: lawyers.

headline: Financial Aid Advice for Indian Students From Colgate University
text: For many Indian students thinking about going to American colleges, one of the biggest questions is “Can I afford it?” We asked Katryna A. Swartwout Ryan, associate dean of admissions at Colgate University, who oversees the recruitment and selection process for international students, and travels around the world to recruit, several questions about financing your college education.

headline: The Literary Circus Comes to Jaipur
text: Page Two columnist Manu Joseph writes  that “Delhi’s writers, readers, publishers, critics, television anchors — and politicians who can read and write” will shift to Jaipur on Friday for the five-day Jaipur Literature Festival, a serious salon at its heart and a circus on its fringes.

headline: Public Domain Works Can Be Copyrighted Anew, Supreme Court Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld a federal law that restored copyright protection to works that had entered the public domain.

headline: U.S. Drafts Abdul-Jabbar as a Cultural Ambassador
text: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar’s life has been a case study in the art of the possible, from his humble Harlem roots to N.B.A. fame and through his life after basketball as a historian and scholar. His next endeavor will draw on all of it.

headline: Warm Winter Deflates Prospects for Retailers
text: As winter approached, retailers ordered clothes for cold weather, arranged their stores for cold weather and then just started hoping for cold weather.

headline: Hungary’s Junk Democracy
text: Budapest

headline: China: Dissident Author Flees to U.S.
text: Yu Jie, a prominent writer of 11 books and a critic of the Chinese Communist Party, said Wednesday in a news conference in Washington that he and his family had left China on Jan. 11 after more than a year of harassment and house arrest. Mr. Yu said his ordeal began Oct. 13, 2010, when he was placed under house arrest after the announcement that his close friend Liu Xiaobo, an imprisoned writer, had won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize. That December, Mr. Yu said, he was detained for four days and tortured nearly to death. He said security officers criticized him for planning to write a biography of Mr. Liu and for writing “China’s Best Actor: Wen Jiabao,” a scathing critique of the prime minister. Mr. Yu was then kept under house arrest, with a travel ban, until this month.

headline: Obama Fights Back Against Koch Brothers in New Ad
text: 10:09 p.m. | Updated COLUMBIA, S.C. — Facing attacks on his character from some particularly aggressive and well-financed opponents,President Obama will begin running the first broadcast television ad of his presidential re-election campaign on Thursday.

headline: Britain: Rendition Inquiry Put on Hold
text: Justice Minister Kenneth Clarke announced Wednesday that the government was scrapping an inquiry into allegations that the secret intelligence service, MI6, was complicit in the abuse of terrorism suspects who were caught up in the American-run process of extraordinary rendition after the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. Clarke said that a team of lawyers and investigators under a retired judge, Sir Peter Gibson, had reviewed more than 10,000 secret documents, but that the next phase, summoning testimony by MI6 officials and others, could not proceed until all related criminal investigations were completed.

headline: In Pakistan’s Coup Intrigue, an X-Rated Plot Twist
text: The complex political and legal drama Pakistani reporters call “Memogate” veered into unexpected territory on Wednesday, when an American businessman who claims that Pakistan’s government asked the United States to help it stave off a military coup admitted that he once played a supporting role in a racy music video that featured naked female wrestling.

headline: Hedge Funds May Sue Greece if It Tries to Force Losses
text: LONDON — Hedge funds have been known to use hardball tactics to make money. Now they have come up with a new one: suing Greece in a human rights court to make good on its bond payments.

headline: Afghanistan: Report of Molestation by British Troops Is Being Investigated
text: The British Defense Ministry said Wednesday that the Royal Military Police had begun an investigation into allegations of inappropriate behavior by two servicemen in Afghanistan after a report of child abuse. The British newspaper The Sun reported that the two servicemen had been questioned about claims that they had encouraged a boy and girl, both about 10, to “touch them through their clothes.” The servicemen are accused of filming the children and showing the images on laptop computers to other soldiers who alerted the military authorities, the newspaper reported.

headline: This Year, Voters Focus More on a Man Than on His Religion
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Four years ago, Mitt Romney’s Mormon faith was a point of considerable concern, if not contention, for many Republican voters in South Carolina, a state where many voters are evangelical Christians and one that is known for its bare-knuckled politics.

headline: As a 49er, Carr Saw Alex Smith’s Confidence
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — While the rise of San Francisco 49ers quarterback Alex Smith this season has surprised many around the N.F.L., the Giants backup quarterback David Carr is not among those stunned. As a former backup to Smith, the No. 1 overall pick in 2005, Carr saw how he handled a difficult season in 2010 — which included a stadium full of 49ers fans chanting for him to be benched — and came away impressed by Smith’s mental toughness.

headline: The 1% and That 15%
text: During the Republican debate on Monday, Mitt Romney suggested that he might release his 2011 tax return, but only in April. On Tuesday, he told reporters that his effective tax rate was “probably closer to the 15 percent rate than anything.”

headline: Classless in the Clásico?
text: Barcelona defeated Real Madrid, 2-1, in the first leg of their Copa del Rey quarterfinal series. But as usual, there was more to it than three goals.

headline: Russia: Blogger Meets With Cleric
text: A popular Russian opposition leader, the blogger Aleksei Navalny, met Wednesday with a top official of the Russian Orthodox Church, Archpriest Vsevolod Chaplin, adding to speculation that the church would try to mediate between Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin and his critics.

headline: Road Safety Agency Is Urged to Add Expertise in Electronics Systems
text: DETROIT — A branch of the National Academy of Sciences reported Wednesday that federal safety regulators lack the expertise to monitor vehicles with increasingly sophisticated electronics.

headline: At Stake, a Super Bowl Berth, and a Loaf of Sourdough Bread
text: As inspiring pregame speeches go, the New York Giants head coach, Tom Coughlin, could perhaps do better than, “Our mayor needs that sourdough bread!”

headline: Unrepentant, Killer of Four Is Sentenced to 200 Years
text: Grinning, glaring and hurling epithets to the friends and family members of the people he killed in a violent rampage across Brooklyn and Manhattan last winter, Maksim Gelman turned what was to be a predictable life sentencing into one final perverse spectacle.

headline: For Darvish, Small Shoes to Fill
text: The Texas Rangers are spending a lot of money on Yu Darvish, and they have to hope he is a lot better than the other Japanese players who have already pitched in the major leagues.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Banker with Misleading Investors
text: A Florida banker who is known for tangling with his critics, including with a prominent bank analyst during the financial crisis, was charged by federal regulators on Wednesday with misleading investors about his company’s real estate portfolio as the housing market turned south.

headline: A Maestro Sets the Tone
text: SOMETHING historic happened at the New York Philharmonic on the evening of Jan. 10, about an hour into Mahler’s Ninth Symphony. During the introspective, achingly beautiful fourth movement, an audience member’s cellphone loudly rang. And rang. And rang again. It was the kind of marimba riff we’ve all heard at some point on the street from a stranger’s phone.

headline: Kim Clijsters, Mama Champion
text: MELBOURNE — Rare is the professional athlete who takes much interest in the interviewer across the table, but Kim Clijsters, finding out that I had three daughters, quickly asked a few questions of her own on Wednesday: “How old are they?” “How do you handle the schooling if you’re going back and forth between Europe and the States?”

headline: Dismantling Detroit
text: The filmmakers Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady look at young men who salvage scrap metal from Detroit’s derelict buildings, set against the backdrop of globalization.

headline: Dismantling Detroit
text: We chose to focus our cameras on Detroit out of a gut feeling that this city — often heralded as the birthplace of the middle class — may well be a harbinger of things to come for the rest of the country.

headline: Facebook Adds New Apps to Its Timeline
text: To help usher in Facebook’s coming seventh birthday, the company is learning how to use more verbs.

headline: Ravens’ Flacco Is Used to Getting Little Credit
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — For a brief moment Wednesday afternoon, Ray Rice morphed from Baltimore’s star running back into an M.C., welcoming the quarterback with more victories in his first four seasons than any other in N.F.L. history. When that quarterback, Joe Flacco, reached the podium, Rice leaped toward him. Flacco did not move.

headline: Reporter Dies in Pakistan, and Taliban Warn Others
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility on Wednesday for the killing of a reporter for the Voice of America, a radio service financed by the United States government, and warned that others would be targets in the future.

headline: From an Attempted Suicide to Salvation, Then to Helping Others
text: On a cold December day in 2009, Sheaneen Holimon stuffed the tailpipe of a car with a sock, sat down in the driver’s seat with the doors and windows closed, and started the engine. She was tired of fighting a losing battle with drugs and alcohol.

headline: Wikipedia Absence Is Noted, but as a Brief Inconvenience
text: The day of protest at English Wikipedia brought measurable results, the site’s administrators reported: four million people used the tool Wikipedia had provided to find their member of Congress by entering their ZIP code; 90 million came to the site and learned about the antipiracy legislation that Wikipedia and other Web sites are protesting.

headline: U.S. Charges 7 for Insider Trading of Dell Stock

headline: When the Lights Go Down in the City
text: Los Angeles

headline: Britain: Protesters’ Eviction Approved
text: London authorities can evict protesters from the Occupy London encampment that has surrounded St. Paul’s Cathedral since October, a British court said Wednesday. A prompt appeal was expected. The battle between protesters and the Corporation of London, the authority overseeing the land outside the historic cathedral, began late last year when the demonstrators refused to heed eviction notices pinned to tents.

headline: Britain: Weighing New London Airport
text: The British government agreed Wednesday to assess the possibility of easing heavy congestion at Heathrow and other airports by building an $80 billion airport on an island in the Thames River estuary. Heathrow draws criticism from among its 70 million annual passengers, and from neighbors who complain about the noise pollution from its 480,000 flights a year. Mayor Boris Johnson of London and others have said a replacement is essential if Britain is to remain competitive as an international aviation hub. Environmentalists opposing the plan say the favored site, on the Isle of Grain, 35 miles east of London, is a major center for wintering birds and a summer breeding ground for bird species like avocets and marsh harriers.

headline: As Attacks Heat Up, Romney’s Lead Narrows in S.C.
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — For Mitt Romney, the South Carolina primary probably can’t come soon enough, as he faced a day of nonstop negative ads,  questions about his religion and his taxes, and new poll numbers that showed his comfortable lead narrowing.

headline: With Twitter, Blackouts and Demonstrations, Web Flexes Its Muscle
text: The Web buzzed with protests large and small on Wednesday as the tech industry rallied against Congressional legislation to curb Internet piracy.

headline: The False Ideals of the Web
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Priest, Newly Installed, Is Removed From Post for Fathering Child While in Seminary
text: A newly minted Roman Catholic priest has been removed from his parish in Orange County, N.Y., by church officials for secretly fathering a child while he was attending seminary.

headline: Online Piracy and Political Overreach
text: For months, it seemed as if Congress would pass an online antipiracy bill, even though its main weapons — cutting off the financing of pirate Web sites and making them harder to find — risk censoring legitimate speech and undermining the security of the Internet. But the unmovable corporations behind those bills have run into an unstoppable force: an outcry by Internet companies led by Google and Wikipedia that culminated in an extraordinary online protest on Wednesday.

headline: 35 Accused of Selling PCP in an Open-Air Drug Market
text: In a courtyard between two housing complexes in Upper Manhattan, an 8-year-old boy would sometimes steer a line of customers toward an enclosed area called the Pit.

headline: A Second Here a Second There May Just Be a Waste of Time
text: On Thursday, the world will go to battle over a second.

headline: Coalition Spends Millions Pushing Cuomo’s Agenda
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday unveiled a new Web site promoting his proposed state budget, featuring a photograph of the smiling governor, his sleeves rolled up, greeting farmers in a flood-stricken upstate community.

headline: Penn State’s Trustees Recount Painful Decision to Fire Paterno
text: It was growing late on the night of Nov. 9, 2011. John P. Surma, the chief executive of U.S. Steel and the vice chairman of Penn State University’s board of trustees, sat at a rectangular table at the Penn Stater Hotel. Gov. Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania was on the speaker phone. Other trustees were present, many emotionally spent.

headline: Gingrich Camp Responds to Ex-Wife’s Interview
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Anticipating a potentially damaging interview with one of Newt Gingrich’s former wives ahead of the South Carolina primary, the Gingrich campaign issued an open letter on Wednesday night to “ABC News leadership,’’ the network that conducted the interview, in preparation for a Thursday night broadcast.

headline: Republican Senator Runs Away From the Party Line
text: BOSTON — Two years ago, Scott P. Brown was a little-known state legislator on the cusp of one of the biggest upset victories in modern politics: capturing Edward M. Kennedy’s longtime Senate seat in this overwhelmingly Democratic state, costing that party its filibuster-proof majority and becoming a Republican sensation.

headline: Cuomo Limits State Money for Salaries of Contractors
text: ALBANY — Looking to rein in the use of public money to pay what he called excessive salaries, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed an executive order on Wednesday placing a $199,000 limit on the amount of state funds that contractors can use to pay executives.

headline: Forgot to Move Car? City Council Votes to End a Sticker of Shame
text: For a quarter-century, it has stood out as a scourge to New York City drivers, a scarlet letter in a bright hue, stuck onto the windows of vehicles whose owners neglected to participate in the ritualistic alternate-side parking dance.

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Hoo boy, this grid exhausted me. Were you exhausted? Every corner, a different TO-DO. In fact, I wouldn’t hesitate to call this the Drama Queen of All Puzzles.

headline: It’s a Dehumanizing Business, Becoming Top Dog

headline: Romney Riches Are Being Seen as New Hurdle
text: With a fortune estimated to be as large as a quarter of a billion dollars, Mitt Romney is among the wealthiest men ever to run for president.

headline: Obama’s Pipeline Move: Something for Everyone
text: There’s been extensive coverage of President Obama’s decision, forced by a Republican legislative maneuver, to reject the application for a much-debated pipeline project, known as Keystone XL, that would have carried a tarry oil precursor from Canadian oil sands to American refineries.

headline: Once Again, Wilfork Anchors Patriots’ Defense
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Three trips to the Pro Bowl apparently were not enough. Anchoring the defense only on certain occasions would not do, either.

headline: Is Banking Bad?
text: When I spoke at Swarthmore College recently, I was startled by one question: Is it immoral for students to seek banking jobs?

headline: Mexico’s Drug War Bloodies Areas Thought Safe
text: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican drug war that has largely been defined by violence along the border is intensifying in interior and southern areas once thought clear of the carnage, broadening a conflict that has already overwhelmed the authorities and dispirited the public, according to analysts and new government data.

headline: Suns and Nash Deal D’Antoni 4th Straight Loss
text: Mike D’Antoni’s glorious past and still-jumbled present collided at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, and presumably this should have produced a frantic festival of points and fast breaks. Instead, the evening came down to a solitary man, standing at the foul line, methodically putting away a low-scoring game with a series of free throws.

headline: Iran’s Currency at Low vs. Dollar
text: Iran’s currency, the rial, fell to its lowest level ever against the dollar on Wednesday in unofficial foreign exchange transactions in Tehran, Iranian news agencies reported.

headline: Higher Deficits Seen in Romney’s Tax Plan, and His Rivals’, Too
text: When Mitt Romney suggested this week that he pays a lower tax rate than most wealthy Americans do, he refocused attention on his tax proposals — which, like those of his major Republican rivals, would largely cut taxes for the rich while driving down tax collections and widening the nation’s deficit.

headline: Governor Romney, Meet Governor Dukakis
text: A couple of months ago, Mitt Romney was a hapless would-be frontrunner who couldn’t stay ahead of a motley crew of unelectable cranks, extremists and vanity candidates. (There’s some overlap in these categories.) Then he won the first two states. Now, ahead in the polls in South Carolina and Florida, Romney is on track for the Republican nomination in the worst election year for an incumbent party since — well, since 2008.

headline: Michigan: Officials Revive Transit Plan
text: The City Council of Troy has voted to save a transit infrastructure project it voted down in December. Construction costs for the project have been scaled back to $6.3 million, from $8.5 million, to win the vote of a council member who had expressed concerns about the cost, though the federal government fully financed construction. The city will seek “a business model that will relieve the local taxpayer of ongoing operating costs” of $30,000 per year, said Michele Hodges, president of the Chamber of Commerce. Mayor Janice Daniels, a Republican who is active in Tea Party politics and led the opposition to the project, said that she had not changed her opinion, but that “it is in my best interest, and all of Troy’s best interest, to work toward making this a fiscally responsible venture.”
