headline: Details of the Candidates’ Tax Plans
text: A look at the Republican candidates’ tax plans.

headline: The Jets’ Tomlinson Sheds Further Light on Turmoil
text: When the Jets were ousted from playoff contention with a loss to Miami on Jan. 1, LaDainian Tomlinson delivered the strongest on-the-record rebuke of Santonio Holmes and the strife that had engulfed the team.

headline: Checketts on Way Back to New York
text: For the past decade, Dave Checketts’s sports interests have taken him out of New York, where he had been the president of Madison Square Garden for seven years and the president of the Knicks for three.

headline: Group Sues Over Denial of Permit to Protest at Courthouse
text: A group that is planning to protest at a Manhattan courthouse around the second anniversary of the Supreme Court’s decision in the Citizens United case, which eliminated barriers to corporations’ political speech and spending, sued federal officials on Wednesday after its request for a permit to gather was denied.

headline: A Good Call on the Pipeline
text: President Obama has properly rejected, at least for now, the Keystone XL oil pipeline that would run from Canada to the Gulf Coast. He rebuffed the demand of House Republicans that the controversial project be decided in haste under an election-year deadline.

headline: A Way of Life on its Way Out in Wichita
text: After eight decades as one of its biggest employers and most prestigious brands, Boeing leaves Wichita in a trail of broken promises and bitter recriminations.

headline: Boeing Departure Shakes Wichita’s Identity as Airplane Capital
text: WICHITA, Kan. — The crowd gathered at the local headquarters for Boeing was euphoric. The company had just won one of the largest military contracts in history. Thousands of the resulting jobs, Boeing had promised, would be headed here, to the sprawling manufacturing complex where residents have been building airplanes for generations.

headline: Budget Wars Are Revived With a Vote in the House
text: WASHINGTON — The House voted Wednesday to block President Obama’s request for $1.2 trillion in additional borrowing authority, knowing that its action was mainly a symbolic protest with no effect on the seemingly inexorable increase in the federal debt.

headline: Marty Springstead, Longtime Baseball Umpire and Supervisor, Dies at 74
text: Marty Springstead, who umpired games in Major League Baseball for 20 years and supervised major league umpires as an executive for more than 20 more, died on Tuesday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 74.

headline: Edward J. Derwinski, First V.A. Secretary, Dies at 85
text: Edward J. Derwinski, who honed an effusive political personality in Chicago’s American Legion halls, then put it to use as a top-ranking Republican congressman, a high State Department adviser and the first secretary of veterans affairs, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Oak Brook, Ill. He was 85.

headline: Michael Mussa, Adviser to Reagan on Economy, Dies at 67
text: Michael L. Mussa, a former chief economist for the International Monetary Fund who was known for his blunt and often witty economic assessments, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 67.

headline: Trump Cleared to Manage Golf Course, Despite Opposition
text: Over the objections of critics, Donald J. Trump has been cleared to run a new public golf course in the Bronx.

headline: Will Europe Ever Get Its Supergrid?
text: Many renewable energy supporters see the creation of an energy supergrid as an indispensable part of Europe decreasing its reliance on fossil fuels. The supergrid would take renewable energy from where it is produced — say, on wind farms in Scotland or in solar arrays in Spain or North Africa — and deliver it to Europe’s faraway population centers. In addition to the environmental argument, there is also an economic one. In this Business of Green special report, Beth Gardiner writes:

headline: News Quiz | Jan. 19, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: A New Fight on Licenses for Illegal Immigrants
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — It is legislative season in New Mexico, which means it is time once again to debate whether illegal immigrants should be granted driver’s licenses.

headline: Why Doctors Can’t Predict How Long a Patient Will Live
text: Slender, in her 60s and possessing the stoicism of someone who had single-handedly raised children in the toughest section of the city, our patient faced a difficult challenge of the medical kind. She had diabetes and such severe peripheral vascular disease that even the strongest antibiotics could not heal a long-standing foot infection. She needed an operation.

headline: YouTube Announces New Film Competition With Venice Film Festival and Ridley Scott
text: YouTube’s aggressive effort to leave its low-rent entertainment reputation behind continues: On Thursday the Google-owned video hub plans to announce a partnership with the Venice Film Festival and Ridley Scott’s production company to create what it’s calling an online film festival.

headline: BankUnited Calls Off Short Sales Process
text: BankUnited, the private equity-owned bank that went public last year, said on Wednesday that it had ended an effort to sell itself and planned to remain independent.

headline: ‘Idol’ Begins 11th Season With Auditions in Georgia
text: Kicking off its 11th season Wednesday night with an audition show filmed in Savannah, Ga., American Idol kept things light and hopeful, relegating most of the painful performances to montages and sketching out a few of the storylines of the standouts who made it to the next round.

headline: I.M.F. Seeks $500 Billion More to Lend
text: The International Monetary Fund said Wednesday, that it was “seeking as much as $500 billion more to lend as it prepared to slash its forecasts of global growth,” Annie Lowrey wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Obama Strategist Plans Post-Vote Academic Role
text: CHICAGO — David Axelrod, the longtime political strategist for Barack Obama, is already making plans for after the 2012 election, and they do not involve another candidate or another trip to Iowa. Mr. Axelrod says he plans to lead a new, nonpartisan Institute of Politics at the University of Chicago aimed at helping students seeking careers in public and social service.

headline: After Protest, Wikipedia Says ‘We’re Not Done Yet’
text: The (day)long national nightmare is over.

headline: Nash Shows Knicks What They’re Missing
text: Steve Nash raised his arms triumphantly near halfcourt. It was not his corner 3-pointer that bounced off the rim and kissed the top of the backboard before falling through the net to give the Phoenix Suns a 5-point lead with 35 seconds to play. It was Shannon Brown’s.

headline: Eastman Kodak Files for Bankruptcy
text: Eastman Kodak, the 131-year-old film pioneer that has been struggling for years to adapt to an increasingly digital world, filed for bankruptcy protection early on Thursday.

headline: Kops-Jones and Spears Fall to Unseeded Pair
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – The Americans Raquel Kops-Jones and Abigail Spears, seeded 15th, lost on Thursday to an unseeded pair, Julia Görges of Germany and Kaia Kanepi of Estonia, in the first round of women’s doubles play at the Australian Open.

headline: Pakistan’s Prime Minister Makes Plea to Avoid Jail Time
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A bitter legal clash between Pakistan’s top court and its civilian government inched toward resolution on Thursday as the prime minister made a dramatic court appearance to ward off possible imprisonment while his legal team agreed to engage the court over the key issue of presidential immunity.

headline: Michael Bradley in Italy: ‘He’s Bravissimo’
text: VERONA, Italy — “He’s a painting with lots of different colors,” said Tommaso Franco, the press officer of the Italian Serie A team Chievo Verona, about the United States international Michael Bradley. “There’s red, there’s blue, there’s yellow. He’s bravissimo.”

headline: Jan. 19, 1937 | Howard Hughes Breaks His Own Transcontinental Flight Record
text: On Jan. 19, 1937, the millionaire Howard Hughes flew his monoplane from Los Angeles to Newark, N.J., in 7 hours, 28 minutes and 25 seconds, breaking the record he set a year earlier by about two hours. He averaged 332 miles an hour during the 2,490-mile journey.

headline: Insurgents Kill Dozens in Southern Afghanistan
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — More than two dozen people were killed in a four insurgent attacks in southern Afghanistan that began late Wednesday and continued through Thursday afternoon, Afghan authorities said.

headline: With Pollutants a Peril, Italy to Seek a Buffer to Avert Future Cruise Ship Disasters
text: GIGLIO, Italy — Alarmed by potentially disastrous pollutants lurking in the bowels of the Costa Concordia shipwreck, Italy’s environment minister will seek a three-mile-wide coastal no-go zone for the luxury cruise liners that have long plied the picturesque Italian shoreline, his spokesman said Thursday.

headline: Will Higher Taxes Dampen Demand For Gold?
text: Indian officials have turned to an old tool to help it rein in its twin deficits in trade and the federal budget: higher import duties on gold and silver.

headline: Primary Season 101
text: This edition of 6 Q’s poses questions that help students use the rich resources of The Times’s Campaign 2012 Politics section to learn about the Republican presidential primaries. Each question links to an article or graphic in which answers to that question can be found.

headline: British Aide Admits Russian Spy Claims
text: LONDON — For the first time, a former senior official has confirmed Russian accusations that the British spy service was caught trying to use a fake rock in Moscow to hide electronic communication equipment six years ago.

headline: Why Saudi Oil Pledge Could Prove Hollow
text: PARIS — Can Saudi Arabia live up to a promise to fill the oil-supply gap if new U.S. and European sanctions succeed in locking down Iran’s exports of crude?

headline: Cynthia Nixon, All Grown Up
text: Decades of performances, from the film “Little Darlings” to Tony Award-winning play “Rabbit Hole.”

headline: Life After ‘Sex’
text: When Cynthia Nixon was 9, she played an impostor on “To Tell the Truth.” “There was a little girl who was a professional horse rider who had won all these blue ribbons,” she recalled, “and the cool thing about her was she rode a Shetland pony, and I pretended to be her. My mother worked on the show; her job was to brief the impostors, coach them in pretending. But I couldn’t believe that no one on the panel recognized me, because I was around the studio a lot. So when I rode out on the horse with a cowboy hat on, I was like this” — she ducked her head low — “because I knew they absolutely remembered me.” Even now, her face fell. “And no one recognized me.”

headline: Egypt’s Human Bellwether
text: On a recent winter evening, a gray Mitsubishi sedan made its way slowly down the narrow main street of Qalyubiya, a farming town in the Nile River delta, hemmed in on all sides by shouting fruit vendors, bumping donkey carts, strings of colored lights and tiny bakeries and butcher shops. Election posters were plastered to every available surface, and a voice squawked loudly over a distant, tinny loudspeaker: “God willing, we will all soon live in an era of social justice. The revolution taught us that we are all equal.” As the sedan reached a crowded election rally outside a mosque, the back door opened and out stepped a striking man with deep-set eyes and a broad forehead. “He is here!” someone shouted. “The hero of the revolution!” Almost instantly, a murmur rippled through the crowd, and the man was surrounded by adoring fans. A pair of burly aides grabbed his arms and bustled him through. “God is great!” the crowd chanted as he smiled and waved, making his way toward a brightly lighted stage. “Freedom and Justice! Tomorrow we will be strong!”

headline: Washing Dishes, Herding Reindeer

headline: Should We Trust Paid Experts on the Volcker Rule?

headline: Whom Would You Share Your Passwords With?
text: A  recent article described the “intimate custom” of teenage couples expressing affection for each other by sharing their passwords to e-mail, Facebook and other accounts. Have you ever shared your passwords with someone else? What do you think of the practice in general? Do you know any stories of password-sharing gone awry?

headline: The New Student Activism
text: ASHLEY WARD, an aspiring idealist with waning faith in the world, was standing in the newsroom of her college paper at Humboldt State University in Northern California when a fellow student rushed in with startling news.

headline: A Sharper Mind, Middle Age and Beyond
text: IN 1905, at age 55, Sir William Osler, the most influential physician of his era, decided to retire from the medical faculty of Johns Hopkins. In a farewell speech, Osler talked about the link between age and accomplishment: The “effective, moving, vitalizing work of the world is done between the ages of 25 and 40 — these 15 golden years of plenty.”

headline: A West Coast University Targets Spanish Speakers Struggling with English
text: The pathway to higher education can be blocked for some would-be students because they are not proficient enough in English to succeed  in a traditional college. And as they grow older, they may find their opportunities further constrained by their lack of a degree.

headline: Fiat to Unveil 500 Wagon at Geneva Auto Show
text: In an interview with Bloomberg, Olivier François, the head of the Fiat brand, said that the Italian automaker would show a wagon variant of the 500 supermini at the Geneva auto show in March, which would go on sale in the United States next year.

headline: Josh Norman Gains Notice Before Shrine Game
text: Cecil Lammey will file reports leading up to the East-West Shrine Game on Saturday. It is the first of the major postseason scouting events.

headline: Securities Lawsuits Hold Steady but Below Average
text: While some commentators may believe that corporate America is awash in class-action lawsuits by angry investors, a new study to be published on Thursday suggests otherwise.

headline: Bogomolov Switches Flags in a Boost For Russia
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — When Michael Llodra of France is playing his best tennis, one can almost hear light chamber music playing softly from somewhere in the distance, matching Llodra’s airy, graceful prancing around the court, his one-handed backhand sweeping like a conductor’s wand.

headline: Swiss Re Appoints New Chief Executive
text: LONDON — Swiss Re, the world’s second-largest reinsurer, said on Thursday that Michel M. Liès will take over as the company’s chief executive on Feb. 1.

headline: Tomlinson Says Rex Ryan Should Tone It Down
text: After the Steelers traded Santonio Holmes to the Jets for a fifth-round pick in April 2010, this question was posed on The Fifth Down:

headline: A Sauce Worth Slaving Over
text: A couple of years ago, a friend told me that a vegan Japanese restaurant called Kajitsu was doing “the best food in the city.” I ignored him. (Typical: I ignored him when he told me about Noma, and I at first ignored friends who told me about Momofuku, El Bulli and, in 1987, the young chefs Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Thomas Keller. So much for the vision thing.) After this friend called me stupid once or twice, I made it over to the place, which is in the East Village, just down the block from the Good Beer Store. The word “best” should not be thrown around, but I will say that Kajitsu is distinctive, astonishing and wonderful.

headline: Do Men Treat Female Business Owners Differently?
text: There are many ways a factory can botch an order of dresses. Susan Parker spent the last month of 2011 dealing with a couple of them. She shared her experiences during the most recent meeting of our business group, and we wandered into a discussion of the challenges faced by women who own businesses, especially those operating in male-dominated industries like the garment business.

headline: A Federal Budget of Just $10 Million, but Something’s Familiar
text: This is going to sound unpleasantly like a question on a high school history exam: Compare and contrast the federal budget of 1797-98 with the federal budget of 2012.

headline: Santorum Edges Ahead of Romney in Iowa
text: 2:25 p.m. | Updated  Rick Santorum’s campaign claimed a belated victory in the Iowa caucuses on Thursday morning after certified results from the contest showed him leading Mitt Romney by 34 votes, a reversal from the eight-vote edge for Mr. Romney on caucus night.

headline: Big Serve, Bright Future for a Young Canadian
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It is the shot, the gift, that could make Milos Raonic a big tennis star in an era already brimming with them. It begins with Raonic selecting the most promising of three balls and stepping to the baseline.

headline: What a Difference a Year Makes
text: CAIRO — When I first met Sally Toma last year, she was flush with victory. After 18 days of protests in Tahrir Square, Hosni Mubarak, Egypt’s long-time strongman, had been toppled and the credit went to the Coalition of Revolution Youth, the 17-member committee of representatives from different youth groups that had started the protests. Toma, a 33-year-old psychiatrist, was the only woman and Coptic Christian member.

headline: Murdoch Settles Suits by Dozens of Victims of Hacking
text: LONDON — Rupert Murdoch’s media empire has agreed to pay substantial damages to several dozen high-profile victims of phone and e-mail hacking, and lawyers for those victims said Thursday that they had seen documents showing that senior managers not only knew about the hacking but also lied about it and destroyed evidence as part of a cover-up.

headline: Pilots Who Fought to Soar Above Racism
text: “Patriotic,” “jingoistic,” “old-fashioned,” “corny” and “inspirational for teenage boys.” Those are the words of George Lucas, the executive producer of “Red Tails,” describing his whiz-bang action film about African-American fighter pilots in World War II on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart.”

headline: ‘Peter and the Starcatcher’ Will Land on Broadway in March
text: Peter Pan is coming back to Broadway – though not the flying, singing Peter who audiences know well. Rick Elice’s play “Peter and the Starcatcher,” which had a well-reviewed Off Broadway run at New York Theater Workshop last spring, will begin preview performances at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on March 28 and open on April 15, the producers of the show said on Thursday.

headline: Title Game Probabilities: Giants Should Be Favored
text: Recency bias is when we overemphasize the importance of recent events, just as many observers are doing this week with the most recent Ravens and Patriots games. Baltimore eked out a win over the Texans with a lackluster performance on offense, while New England dominated the Broncos on both sides of the ball. Don’t put too much stock in those two games. In Baltimore’s case, keep in mind that Houston owned one of the very best defenses this season, allowing only 5.2 yards per pass attempt and yielding only a 39 percent run success rate, good for second and seventh in the league. And regarding New England, remember that Denver was overmatched in several departments and had backed into the playoffs with a mediocre record.

headline: More Veterans Receive Help With Heating Bills
text: The number of low-income veterans receiving government assistance for their heating and cooling bills hit a new high last year, according to a survey by a federal energy-assistance program.Over the last four years, the survey found, the number of low-income households with at least one military veteran receiving federal energy assistance rose by about 1.1 million households, to 1.78 million.

headline: Teachers Turn Out in Force at PEP Meeting

Carrying signs, blowing whistles and booing loudly, they at times drowned out panel members, as well as parents and teachers trying to address the room during the public comment period. Then they marched out.

He said it sent an unmistakable message to lawmakers grappling with new media issues: Don’t mess with the Internet.

headline: In Bat Deaths, a Catastrophe in the Making?
text: A “biodiversity crisis”: that’s how some conservationists describe new numbers released this week by the federal Fish and Wildlife Service on so-called white-nose syndrome. According to the agency, 5.7 million to 6.7 million bats have died from the fungal ailment in eastern North America since an epidemic first broke out in upstate New York in 2006.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Web Rages and Gingrich Pushes Back at ABC

The letter, signed by Mr. Gingrich’s two daughters from his first marriage, Kathy Lubbers and Jackie Cushman, faulted the network for engaging in “talk about the past, just days before an important primary election,” Trip Gabriel and Brian Stelter reported. The interview will be broadcast on “Nightline” at 11:35 p.m. Thursday, shortly after a Republican debate sponsored by CNN.

In 2007, Gov. Eliot Spitzer (remember him?) banned finger-imaging for most of the state beyond the city. Mr. Berg reminded us that one elected official among Mr. Spitzer’s fellow Democrats vigorously attacked the governor for this action.

headline: The Tweeting Dead
text: Oy. Ari Fleischer is using Twitter to repeat the old zombie lie about how the tax burden on the rich has risen, because they’re paying a higher share of federal taxes than they used to. Mark Thoma handles this fine, no need for me to weigh in. Basically, if the income of the 1 percent has tripled relative to the income of the middle quintile, how are they suffering if their tax burden relative to the middle class rises by a substantially smaller amount?

headline: Say’s Law For Thee But Not For Me
text: In correspondence, Mark Thoma notes a double standard in the conservative outcry over the Keystone XL decision. As he notes, when it comes to the question of whether government spending can create jobs, the usual suspects claim that it’s logically impossible: income has to be spent somewhere, so all the government can do is divert funds from other uses. But when it’s a private investment, somehow that logic no longer applies.

headline: Long-Awaited Scipio Tombs Reopen in Rome
text: The founder of one of ancient Rome’s most illustrious clans, consul Lucius Cornelius Scipio Barbato, began building monumental tombs for his relatives in the third century B.C., and the family continued to use the site as a place of rest until the first century A.D. The site was forgotten, then made into a public park in 1929 and shuttered for restorations in 1992. This week, for the first time in two decades, the tomb of the Scipios has been reopened to the public (Via di Porta Sebastiano 9, www.060608.it).Among the Scipios entombed there were two of the Punic War’s greatest Roman heroes: Scipio Africanus Major, the general who defeated Hannibal and ended the Second Punic War, and Scipio Africanus Minor, who destroyed Carthage and ended the Third Punic War.

headline: Edgar Allan Poe Fans Say ‘Nevermore’ to Vigil for Mystery Admirer

headline: Media Deal Brings Ads to Photographs

headline: Seeing Things | Found Muji
text: I make a beeline for Muji whenever I visit Tokyo (or New York, London or Paris). Japan’s chicly simple no-brand brand hasn’t set up shop yet in Los Angeles, and I’m addicted to its basic, everyday products. When I was in Tokyo a few weeks ago, I was excited to discover Found Muji, a new concept store that opened in November. (The Web site is in Japanese only.) Housed in the Aoyama-area retail space where Muji’s first stand-alone store opened in 1983, Found Muji takes the company back to its roots.

headline: How Tweet It Is (or Is Not)

Or the biggest imagined football news of the decade, depending on whether the voices Lowe was “hearing” that told him Peyton Manning is retiring were from an actual person who knows something or were just the ones inside his head.

headline: And the Official Winner in Iowa Is … Who Cares?
text: I travel to Iowa for the caucuses every four years, like all political journalists, but I’ve never quite understood the point. Yes, I know Iowa is commonly referred to as the first delegate selection contest in the nation. But it’s not. No delegates are actually selected at the caucuses. It’s supposed to be a bellwether for the nation, but it’s not. The Iowa caucuses, especially the Republican ones, have a mixed record at predicting the next nominee, and a fairly bad one at predicting the next president.

headline: 36 Hours: Hamburg, Germany
text: NO one tells you how pretty Hamburg is. That’s because so few people mention Hamburg in the first place. American tourists and businesspeople gravitate toward other German cities: Berlin, Munich, Frankfurt. And so Hamburg, bigger than all but Berlin, remains a bit of a mystery, poised to become a thrilling discovery. Did you know about the lake? It’s smack dab in the city center and skirted by regal buildings, a postcard-ready tableau if there ever was one. And the canals? They lattice the part of the city nearest the Elbe River, allowing Hamburg to joust with Stockholm, Amsterdam and Bruges for informal rights to call itself the Venice of northern Europe. Hamburg in winter is cold and often gray. No getting around that. But the indoors migration of many Hamburg residents gives the city a quiet and peace that I relished on a recent visit. Sure, the blustery weather persuaded me to skip the lake ferries and Elbe cruises recommended in summertime. But it wasn’t an obstacle to appreciating Hamburg’s formidable charms.

headline: Someone Done Her Wrong. Horrible Mistake.
text: When you think about it, the phrase “action movie” is a bit redundant. Really, what else are motion pictures for? In the earliest days of cinema our ancestors were thrilled to behold images of galloping horses, hurtling trains and capering dancers. Though our entertainments are now more elaborate, our appetites are not so different. A large part of what we crave is action: running, jumping, fighting, driving, flying. Sometimes everything else — plot, character, emotion — can seem superfluous.

headline: Broadway’s Big Prime-Time Moment
text: DECADES before his elaborate film productions like “E.T.” and “Saving Private Ryan,” Steven Spielberg cut his teeth as a high school stage manager in Phoenix, feeding lines to forgetful actors in “Guys and Dolls” and trying to keep the members of a large “Brigadoon” cast from turning into bumper cars. Backstage drama provided the first adrenaline rush of his career, he said, and always struck him as good material. So much so that, a few years ago, Mr. Spielberg began shopping around a television series set on Broadway, but he met with rejection from HBO (where he made “Band of Brothers”) and the broadcast networks.

Clean with modern finishes (light gold hardware, single zipper pouch inside) and not a logo in sight, the canvas shopper also comes in navy, orange and yellow leather. Get ready to literally hold everything.

headline: Theater Talkback: Watching Without Expectations
text: The new production of “Porgy and Bess” that opened recently on Broadway – now crassly, not to mention inaccurately, branded “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” – has become perhaps the most controversial musical revival in recent memory. It has been interesting to note how people are reacting to the show in different ways according to their familiarity with the score, and more particularly their history (or not) of hearing it in the opera house, where it has most regularly been performed since its Broadway debut in 1935. Despite l’affair Sondheim, many people seem to enjoy it.

headline: New Springsteen Album Coming on March 6
text: Bruce Springteen announced on his Web site Thursday that he would release a new album, “Wrecking Ball,” on March 6, and he released the lead-off single to whet the appetite of his fans. Called “We Take Care of Our Own,” the track is musically upbeat but alludes to the economic and political climate in the United States, with lyrics like “Where’s the promise, from sea to shining sea?”

headline: Agriculture and Climate Change, Revisited
text: Agriculture has long been a stepchild in global negotiations over the climate. Hopes had risen that this might change at the latest big global climate session, in Durban, South Africa, in December. It did not.

headline: For Bankrupt Saab, a Wrenching Farewell to Its Heritage
text: More than 100 Saabs, from the streamlined 1947 prototype known as the Ursaab to a 2010 9-5 sedan, are to be taken from their home at the company’s museum in Trollhattan, Sweden, and sold to the highest bidder.

headline: Gingrich Tied With Romney in South Carolina Forecast
text: The FiveThirtyEight model now shows Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney in a virtual tie in South Carolina, with each having about a 50 percent chance of winning the primary.

headline: All the Buzz With Adrien Brody
text: When Adrien Brody wasn’t preparing for his modeling turn in the Prada show on Sunday, he was talking about trends in men’s facial hair. Mr. Brody, who is turning into a veritable style guru, also has a relationship with Gillette, currently promoting something called a Fusion ProGlide Styler, which is a multitasking razor that is designed for trimming and edging.

headline: TimesCast | The Race for South Carolina
text: January 19, 2012 — Two days ahead of the South Carolina primary, Republican contenders rise, drop out, and face new hurdles.

headline: Coldplay, Rihanna and McCartney to Perform at Grammys
text: Coldplay and Rihanna will perform together live for the first time at the Grammy Awards on Feb. 12, and Paul McCartney will sing a song as well, the National Academy of Performing Arts and Sciences announced on Thursday.

headline: F.D.A. Delays Approval of New Diabetes Drug
text: The Food and Drug Administration has decided not to approve the first of a new class of diabetes drugs, saying that more information was needed to assess the medicine’s safety and effectiveness.

headline: Busy Day Both Tests and Rewards Gingrich
text: A frenetic swirl of developments in the Republican presidential campaign over the last 24 hours is testing whether Newt Gingrich can manage tricky political crosscurrents as he seeks to emerge as the undisputed alternative to Mitt Romney.

headline: Mike O’Brien Is Famous! (On the Internet)
text: Magazines do profiles of TV and film stars, so why not profile celebrities on the, arguably, just as relevant medium of the Internet? Online, there exists a different set of A-Listers, whose work reaches an audience of millions and attracts rabid, devoted fans. And no one in the real world has any idea. Internet fame can be cultivated or unexpectedly backed into. It can lead to TV pilot deals, commercial work, merchandise sales, book agents and other tangible successes. It’s time these secret celebrities got introduced to the mainstream in “They’re Famous! (On the Internet).”

headline: Mike O’Brien Would Like to Kiss You
text: Mike O’Brien is what might be called Web nouveau: he’s earnest rather than snarky and seems genuinely baffled by meme culture. Yet O’Brien, who didn’t even have a Twitter account until September, has become famous — at least on the Internet — as the host of “7 Minutes in Heaven,” an extremely funny Web show based on the adolescent make-out game.

headline: Ireland Said to Face Downturn in 2nd Year of Austerity

headline: English Proficiency Classes Shrink as Demand Climbs
text: Every year, New York State attracts more and more immigrants from around the world seeking new jobs, new opportunities, new lives. Many of them, not surprisingly, arrive not knowing how to speak English well, inhibiting their search for work and their ability to assimilate.

headline: Favorite-Class Tweets
Helping Injured Dogs Walk Again
text: An experimental drug being tested on dachshunds and other dogs with spinal cord damage may eventually lead to new treatments for people with similar injuries.

headline: 7 Charged as F.B.I. Closes a Top File-Sharing Site
text: In what the federal authorities on Thursday called one of the largest criminal copyright cases ever brought, the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized the Web site Megaupload and charged seven people connected with it with running an international enterprise based on Internet piracy.

headline: Self-Immolation Protest in Morocco Captured on Video
text: Silhouetted against a ball of flame, a Moroccan protester lurched forward through a screaming crowd in the center of Morocco’s capital, Rabat. The scene, captured on video, offers a rare glimpse of the spate of self-immolations across North Africa and the Middle East in emulation of the Tunisian protest that helped set off the Arab Spring.

headline: Parental Quandary Considered: Lying to the In-Laws About Church
text: S. admits it. She and her husband have been lying to her in-laws about going to church. I suggested they were fibbing, but whatever you call it, the truth remains: it’s so much easier to pretend, on the phone to her husband’s minister father and his wife, that the religion S. and her husband both grew up in remains a part of their daily life. But as S. said when she described her quandary to me, the differences between the way she and her husband practice their religion and the way his parents do can’t be tiptoed around for long — not with a chatty toddler in the mix.

headline: The Dubious Case For Privileging Capital Gains
text: I’ve had several people ask for a followup on my piece about David Frum and capital gains taxes — namely, what is the case for special treatment, and the case against?

headline: Bonuses Are Not the Answer, Teachers Say
text: Many of the teachers who responded to a SchoolBook query about the mayor's offer of bonus pay for high-performing teachers dismissed it, saying bonuses don't accomplish their goal. Said one:" I've been in the classroom for 12 years, now. I have yet to see a single teacher who says, 'Gosh! If only I had some sort of monetary incentive, I would work just a little bit harder!' "

headline: New York Fed Sells $7 Billion in A.I.G. Assets to Credit Suisse
text: More than three years after the financial crisis, some of the most troubled assets involved in the housing collapse are still changing hands.

headline: Il Buco Is Selling Its Own Salumi
text: Il Buco Alimentari & Vineria, the newest of the city’s Italian market-restaurants, has just started selling assorted salamis and other cured pork products that it is making in-house. Among them are a tangy finocchiona salami lightly kissed with fennel; a lusty hunter’s sausage called cacciatorino; peppery Tuscan salami; a sweetly rich culatello, (similar to prosciutto; and an elegant nutty-sweet lonza (cured loin). Fatty products like guanciale, pancetta and lardo are deliciously buttery.

headline: Santorum Claims Victory in Iowa

headline: How Humans Spread Both Ecological Disruption and Diversity
text: Erle Ellis of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, is one of a growing network of biologists charting the fate of living systems in the Anthropocene, this epoch in which that phenomenon once known as “nature” is increasingly shaped, wittingly or not, by human actions.

headline: New Definition of Autism Will Exclude Many, Study Suggests
text: Proposed changes in the definition of autism would sharply reduce the skyrocketing rate at which the disorder is diagnosed and might make it harder for many people who would no longer meet the criteria to get health, educational and social services, a new analysis suggests.

headline: Newt Gingrich, Nutty Radio Talk Show Host
text: BEAUFORT, S.C. – Newt Gingrich is climbing past Rick Santorum in the polls here, and is already proclaiming himself the only conservative alternative to Mitt Romney. The reason for his rising popularity is not really because he’s more conservative than Mr. Santorum – he’s not – or because he will bring about more conservative change, as Rick Perry said in endorsing him today before leaving the race.

headline: Corporate Taxes And The .01 Percent
text: Some readers have asked whether the picture of very low taxes on the very rich changes once you take taxes on corporate profits into account, and impute them to stockholders. The answer is that yes, it does, somewhat — but there are a number of implications of such an imputation, and if I were a conservative, I really wouldn’t want to go there.

headline: Two More Billion-Dollar Weather Disasters
text: The count of billion-dollar weather disasters for 2011 has taken another jump. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, still adding up the costs of the extreme weather events that plagued the country last year, announced on Thursday that two more had surpassed the $1 billion mark, for a total of 14. And the agency is still counting.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Wilde but Not Crazy
text: The show notes promised “psychedelic elegance” and “Wilde meets Zappa,” and backstage Dries Van Noten explained that his men’s collections had become “so serious” and that he wanted to get a little crazy. Both Oscar Wilde and Frank Zappa are fairly loaded guns, and after seeing the show tonight at the Grand Palais, I can’t really tell you how much of either man was represented in the multicolored prints (mildly psychedelic), the calligraphy-lettered quotations on shirts (definitely Wilde), or the elongated ’70s tailoring (could be Frank). The prints certainly didn’t make a crazy statement. If you’re in the market next fall for a good-looking peacoat or streamlined overcoat with modest military styling, this collection is worth a look. But there was very little madness in Mr. Van Noten’s method.

headline: Reading With Strangers: Ways to Study Literature Collaboratively
text: Inspired by the example of two New Jersey high school teachers who brought their students together in reading John Steinbeck’s “Of Mice and Men,” we offer you some ideas for reading alongside others in different places, circumstances and stages of life, and perhaps to bridge some divides.

headline: City’s Jobless Rate Rises as Nation’s Falls
text: Almost since the recession began, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has boasted that New York City’s economy weathered the downturn better than the rest of the nation and bounced back faster.

headline: Swiss Downhill Star Cuche Announces Retirement
text: KITZBÜHEL, Austria — The skier Didier Cuche, a former butcher from the small Swiss village of Le Paquier, has won an Olympic medal, 4 world championship medals and 18 World Cup victories. His impressive 19-year career was hardly showing signs of a steep decline, as he has won four of the last five World Cup downhill titles.

headline: ABC Worked for Months to Get Marianne Gingrich Interview
text: The television interview of Marianne Gingrich, a former wife of Newt Gingrich, that will be broadcast on Thursday night was initiated back in November, when ABC News was looking into an old federal investigation that involved the family.

headline: Stephens’s Talent and Promise Evident in Loss
text: Sloane Stephens’s close loss to the veteran Svetlana Kuznetsova in the second round of the Australian Open Thursday was filled with subtle lessons. She had chances to win the first set, but Kuznetsova prevailed, 8-6, in the tiebreaker. The set took 69 minutes and Stephens came away with nothing. It is perhaps the harshest aspect of the tennis scoring system: sets and games — no matter how close — are winner take all. Other sports (football and basketball come to mind) stop at halftime and each team still has a chance to win. In other words, the losing team’s points are not erased.

headline: Yet Another Insider Trading Case Begins to Unfold
text: The government has moved yet again in its effort to crack down on insider trading, filing charges against seven defendants with ties to hedge funds who federal prosecutors say operated as a “circle of friends” by trading information.

headline: State Department Readies an R.S.V.P.
text: Congressional Republicans, furious over President Obama’s rejection of the proposed Keystone XL pipeline, are calling for Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to address the State Department’s review of the project at a House hearing next week.

headline: Unearned, and Taxed Unequally
text: Whatever happened to “unearned income”?

text: Crime detection pays.

headline: Laurents/Hatcher Playwriting Prize Goes to ‘Modern Terrorism’
text: A new play titled “Modern Terrorism” has been selected for the 2012 Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award, a generous theater prize that provides $50,000 to the author – in this case, Jon Kern – and an additional $100,000 toward the production costs for the play’s premiere. Trustees for the foundation of the writer and director Arthur Laurents (“West Side Story,” “Gypsy”) and his partner of 52 years, Tom Hatcher, announced the selection of Mr. Kern on Thursday; he is a graduate of the Columbia University master’s program in playwriting as well as the University of Chicago.

headline: Tout Wants to Tame Your Inbox
text: Each year, the average person receives about 15,000 e-mails. For business professionals, the number is a bit bigger, anywhere from 40,000 to 80,000 messages a year, according to Tout, a small start-up company that tries to help people manage their e-mail accounts.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 19
text: A view of the day in sports, including ski jumping in Poland and dog sledding in Scotland.

headline: Suicides Among Active-Duty Troops Rose in 2011, U.S. Army Says
text: WASHINGTON — Suicides among active-duty soldiers hit a new high in 2011, Army officials said on Thursday, although there was a slight decrease in suicides overall, if non-mobilized Reserve and National Guard troops were included in the calculation.

headline: Gingrich Does Not Respond to Ex-Wife’s Claims
text: BEAUFORT, S.C. — It was a day of extraordinary contrasts for Newt Gingrich, who welcomed the endorsement of Rick Perry, and hoped to use it to unite conservatives and add to his momentum in the polls, while playing down how “values voters” might respond to a former wife’s claim that he had asked for an “open marriage.”

headline: Musical Version of ‘Far From Heaven’ Will Debut at Williamstown
text: From Douglas Sirk to Todd Haynes and now to the stage of the 2012 Williamstown Theater Festival: that’s the journey to be taken by “Far From Heaven,” a musical adaptation of Mr. Haynes’s 2002 film of the same name, which starred Julianne Moore and Dennis Quaid.

headline: TimesCast | Phone Hacking Settlements
text: January 19, 2012 — In the legal battle over phone hacking, lawyers identify some of the high-profile victims, including Jude Law, who have reached settlements with the News Corp.

headline: Ethnic War Rekindled in Myanmar
text: For years, the Kachin Independence Army controlled Myanmar’s northern hills, which separatists call their ethnic homeland. Now, the Burmese Army has pushed in, displacing thousands.

headline: Violence Against the Kachin in Northern Burma
text: A report from a fact-finding mission to northern Myanmar in October 2011 to document violence against the Kachin ethnic group. (Warning: Contains Graphic Images)

headline: In Battle for Autonomy, Kachin Come Under Siege in Myanmar
text: A look inside territory controlled by the Kachin ethnic group in Myanmar, near the border with China.

headline: Gagosian Sued for Selling Lichtenstein Painting Without Owner’s Consent
text: A prominent art collector has sued the dealer Larry Gagosian, claiming that he sold a 1964 Roy Lichtenstein painting from her collection without her consent. The suit, filed Wednesday in state court in Manhattan, is part of a tangle of art deals that led to two earlier lawsuits against the dealer in federal court, one of which Mr. Gagosian settled for $4.4 million last year, according to court papers.

headline: An Ethnic War Is Rekindled in Myanmar
text: MAIJA YANG, Myanmar — Even as the Burmese government initiates political reforms in much of the country, it has intensified an ethnic civil war here in the resource-rich hills of northern Myanmar, a conflict that at once threatens its warming trend with the United States and could alienate Chinese officials concerned about stability on the border.

headline: Google’s Results Disappoint, Sending Shares Down
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Larry Page, Google’s chief executive and co-founder, celebrated the first anniversary of the announcement that he would take over the company with the news Thursday that it had exceeded $10 billion in quarterly revenue for the first time.

headline: Egypt’s Military Ruler Told Carter Video of Soldiers Stomping on Woman Was Fake
text: During a conversation with former President Jimmy Carter last week, Egypt’s current head of state, Field Marshal Mohamed Hussein Tantawi, claimed that widely circulated video images of soldiers beating, stripping and kicking a female protester on the pavement of Tahrir Square last month were entirely fake.

headline: Profit Increases 6% at Intel
text: Intel’s profit rose only 6 percent in the fourth quarter, the company said Thursday, as the impact of last year’s catastrophic flooding in Thailand, which devastated hard-drive production, began to affect PC sales.

headline: New York City Opera Ratifies Agreement
text: New York City Opera’s orchestra ratified a three-year contract on Thursday that provides for deep cuts but also a new labor-management committee to deal with fund-raising, planning and artistic matters. An agreement had been reached earlier this week, ending a lockout and nearly a year of bitter negotiations. Tino Gagliardi, the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the orchestra players, said in a statement that they agreed to “deep concessions” in hopes of raising City Opera “from the ashes.” The financially pressed company has moved out of its home at Lincoln Center to present a sharply reduced season in several theaters around New York.

headline: Ben Jonson: In and Out of Shakespeare’s Shadow
text: Writing a few decades after the deaths of the two greatest writers of the Elizabethan and Jacobean era, the poet and critic John Dryden came clean about his feelings toward both. “I admire him,” he wrote of Ben Jonson, “but I love Shakespeare.”

headline: Watching Them Watching Me

This was going to be a stay-at-home anniversary; we had splurged on our 20th knowing that by this year our oldest son would be frighteningly close to college. So a quiet dinner and a movie — our own movie — were what I had in mind.

headline: Another American Dancer Joins a Russian Ballet Company
text: Keenan Kampa, a member of the Boston Ballet  and a rare American to attend the Vaganova Ballet Academy in St. Petersburg, Russia, is joining the Mariinsky Ballet. The Mariinsky said Ms. Kampa, 22, was becoming the first American in its ranks. She starts June 2012. The announcement follows the news last year that David Hallberg was joining the Bolshoi Ballet, the first American to become a principal dancer there. Ms. Kampa, from Reston, Va., attended summer programs at the Boston Ballet and American Ballet Theater in New York as well as master classes at the Kennedy Center. The Mariinsky said she was also the first American to receive a degree from the Vaganova, a storied school that produced George Balanchine, Vaslav Nijinsky, Rudolf Nureyev and Anna Pavlova, among other prominent dancers.

headline: A Lilac-Hued Bacon at Christie’s
text: Have a Francis Bacon to sell? London is where many auction house experts are advising collectors to try their luck. “We’ve seen extraordinary prices paid for Bacons in London in recent years,” said Brett Gorvy, international chairman of Christie’s postwar and contemporary art department. “Americans have competed as aggressively as buyers from emerging markets.” And with so many rich Russians and Middle Easterners putting down roots in London, it’s the obvious place to sell.

headline: The Children’s Cup
text: Amsterdam Arena, capacity 52,342, became one of the biggest day-care centers in the world Thursday when about 20,000 children (joined by their minders) were given free admission to the Dutch Cup replay between Ajax and AZ in the Netherlands.

headline: Reinventing Textbooks: A Hard Course
text: A technology company announces plans to reinvent higher education by encouraging the creation of a new kind of textbook. Students will learn better, faster, cheaper. They will be spurred to new triumphs that will finally reverse the persistent decline in American education and the American way of life.

headline: Migraine Art
text: A series of paintings by migraine patients.

headline: A City Portrayed by Diarists Who Had Their Own Problems
text: When Simone de Beauvoir, the French existentialist, first tried to smoke marijuana, she, like Bill Clinton, did not inhale. It was May 3, 1947, and she was as new to New York City as she was to the drug.

headline: Sniffing and Pinching Help Her Deal With Her Grief
text: Grief causes people to do odd things. Like sniff their grown daughter’s bra. (Not while it’s being worn, but still.) Or pinch a police officer. Twice.

headline: Meeting Complex Bartok With Ease and Imagination
text: The superstar pianist Lang Lang may shamelessly cultivate a flamboyant persona. And he has been criticized widely for exaggerated expressivity. Still, no fair-minded person can deny that Mr. Lang has stupendous technique and keen musical instincts.

headline: A Master and His Peers in the Glow of a Golden Age
text: You won’t see much of Rembrandt in “Rembrandt’s World: Dutch Drawings From the Clement C. Moore Collection,” at the Morgan Library & Museum. This exhibition of about 90 works on paper, all promised gifts to the Morgan, includes just four drawings attributed to that master.

headline: At a Winter Perennial, Old Objects That Are Never Passé
text: This year’s Winter Antiques Show at the Park Avenue Armory offers the usual embarrassment of riches. Shining suits of knightly armor, mysteriously sensuous classical Indian stone sculptures, ceramics and red lacquer boxes from the Far East, sumptuous rugs, rare books and autographic documents, paintings and furniture from several centuries, jewelry, fancy early-American rifles and countless hard-to-classify oddities are displayed by 73 dealers from around the world.

headline: Beauty Queen With No Place to Hide
text: A first-rate art-house thriller, “Miss Bala” tells the strange, seemingly impossible story of a Mexican beauty queen who becomes the accidental pawn of a drug cartel. It’s an adventure story that could be called a contemporary picaresque if it weren’t so deadly serious, and might be called fantastical if it weren’t loosely based on a true story of a former Miss Hispanic America. One day a beautiful young woman, Laura (a sympathetic Stephanie Sigman), is trying to enter a Miss Baja contest; a few hours later she’s cowering in a nightclub, dodging gunfire and gangsters who bequeath her another title, Miss Bala — Miss Bullet.

headline: Brokers Say Good Riddance to 2011
text: Melville

headline: What Other Auctioneers Decide to Leave Behind
text: As soon as a rich New Yorker dies, the major auction houses typically send condolence letters. Then their experts go to the apartment or town house, offering to handle antiques and artworks worth more than a few thousand dollars each. Once the estate has been settled and the best stuff taken away, the secondary auction houses help clean out anything else old.

headline: Belly Up to the Basement Bar
text: THERE was a classic ’50s wet bar in the basement of a Bloomfield Cape sold by Roberta Plutzik Baldwin a few years ago. It had knotty pine paneling, a plaid carpet, sea netting and harbor lights — and it looked, Ms. Baldwin recalled, as if Troy Donahue might show up any minute.

headline: Why Taxes Aren’t as High as They Seem
text: WASHINGTON — When people heard that Mitt Romney’s federal income tax rate was about 15 percent, the immediate reaction of many was to assume that their own rate was higher. The top marginal rate is 35 percent, after all, and the marginal rate on a couple with $70,000 in taxable income is 25 percent.
