text: As Republicans battle to see who will win the presidential nomination, a familiar Democrat is turning up on covers of Esquire magazine’s February edition: Bill Clinton.

headline: For Edith Wharton’s Birthday, Hail Ultimate Social Climbers
text: In dramas about the British aristocracy we Americans await with tingly pleasure the inevitable moment when the family learns that there is no more money to run the estate, and everyone must retrench or — worse  — the heir must get a job. Then, like the arrival of the cavalry in a western, all is saved — the footmen, the ancestral portraits, even the Georgian silver — by the imminent commingling of fortunes with an American kissing cousin who has daughters and dollars. The “Upstairs Downstairs” details long familiar from novels, movies and television shows, and now from the popular “Downton Abbey,” seem to render us spellbound.

headline: Edith Wharton Turns 150
text: As the popular “Downton Abbey” proves, stories of Americans mingling with members of the British aristocracy titillate as much as they did when Edith Wharton wrote of them.

headline: Two Fairs, Not Homogenized
text: New York has become saturated with art fairs in the past decade, with committed art viewers spending much of late February and March wandering through partitioned spaces in convention centers, former warehouses or hotels turned into ad hoc trading posts. Not surprisingly, complaints of a homogenizing effect have been on the rise; all that newness, hipness and being in sync with the discourse can have an anesthetizing effect. Two smaller, idiosyncratic fairs taking place this weekend offer a slightly different experience.

headline: AT&T Raises Data Prices for New Smartphone Customers
text: AT&T, the wireless carrier, will raise the cost of Internet data for new smartphone customers beginning Sunday. Though AT&T’s overall prices have increased, the new plans give customers more value per megabyte.

headline: Plenty of Opponents, Outside and In
text: Hands tell the story in “On Freddie Roach,” a six-episode documentary series beginning on Friday on HBO. The flashing fists of young boxers in the ring move in counterpoint to the trembling fingers of Mr. Roach, a trainer and former fighter who now does battle with Parkinson’s disease.

headline: The Semantics and Statistics of Santorum’s Win in Iowa
text: Amid the swirl of developments on Thursday came word from the Iowa Republican Party that it had certified the results from the state’s Jan. 3 caucuses — and that Rick Santorum, not Mitt Romney, had gotten more votes. Mr. Santorum received 29,839 votes in the state’s certified tally, 34 more than Mr. Romney, who had 29,805.

headline: High-Level Track and Field and Squash to Enjoy
text: The Miser’s new year exercise regime has not quite kicked in. No matter. This weekend is better for watching sports than for playing them. There’s a lot to choose from: squash at Grand Central Terminal and track and field at the Armory. Then next week there’s wrestling, the first tournament of the NYC Mayor’s Cup 2012 season, at the Harlem Armory.

headline: 3.1 Phillip Lim: Fall 2012 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: The Trip Calculator of Another Time
text: BEFORE GIS, before GPS, before Google Earth, there was the milestone. These heavy markers, inscribed with distances to City Hall or other locations, went up in series as early as 1769, and once numbered 40 or 50 in all. About two dozen now survive, mostly in museums. Even at several feet high and weighing 200 pounds, the markers have proved remarkably difficult to track.

headline: Sarah Burke, Freestyle Skier, Dies From Injuries in Training
text: Hurtling down a towering halfpipe on a pair of skis, no maneuver is routine. But Sarah Burke had done this one, the 540 Flat Spin, countless times.

headline: Time to Stay Put
text: EIGHT years ago, after couch-surfing in faraway places, Ben Schulson called a friend who lived in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. His friend suggested that the footloose Mr. Schulson stay in his spare room, enticing him with the news that some “cute girls” shared the duplex downstairs.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto Men’s
text: Paris

headline: Beyond the Roaming and Rambling, The Sensitive Side of Woody Guthrie
text: “I never dread the day that I will die/Because my sunset is somebody’s morning sky,” Woody Guthrie wrote in his journal on April 17, 1942. More than six decades later those words became the bridge in “My Battle,” an unpublished Guthrie lyric set to music by the folk-rock singer-songwriter Jonatha Brooke and recorded on her 2008 album, “The Works.” That record was the focus of Ms. Brooke’s 90-minute Lincoln Center American Songbook show, in celebration of Guthrie’s centennial, in the Allen Room on Wednesday night.

headline: Symbiotic Bond for Stage and Screen Versions
text: FOR decades Broadway producers regarded Hollywood as the agent of death. They fought to delay film adaptations of “West Side Story,” “Hello, Dolly!,” “The Wiz” and other shows for fear that those movies would decimate ticket sales for the Broadway originals and their national tours. But this winter producers of the hit Broadway play “War Horse” have been cheering Steven Spielberg’s new screen version, while those on the musical “Rock of Ages” have been helping rush the movie version (starring Tom Cruise and Alec Baldwin) toward a June release.

headline: Birds, Jesus, Crystal and Rainbows, Dancing
text: When you think back on a concert in the hours and days after it’s over, it is no longer a unified whole. You have a general impression, sure, but what sticks out most are specific moments, individual players, passages of special eloquence.

headline: Cronenberg’s World
text: Images from films appearing in the Museum of the Moving Image series on David Cronenberg.

headline: Happy to Mine Hidden Charm in Youthful Anger
text: SALLY FIELD likes the Welsh actor Matthew Rhys, she really likes him.

headline: Some Smoother Edges, Soon to Come
text: Just how long will it take for Howler to become very, very handsome? It’s the sort of transformation that happens to young and deeply capable bands plucked from relative obscurity — the bustling Minneapolis indie-rock scene in this case, but still — and delivered to the wider world.

headline: Buildings Once Institutional, Now Exclusive
text: THERE have been times in New York’s history, in response to economic downturns, when large apartments have been split up into smaller units. This is not one of those times.

headline: Tracking the Hezbollah Connection in Thailand
text: PARIS — When police in Thailand this week discovered large stockpiles of chemicals often used to make bombs, they quickly said the material was going to be shipped out of Thailand to another (unnamed) country. The chemicals —fertilizer ingredients in bags labelled as kitty litter — were going to be packed into boxes labeled electric fans and exported.

headline: West African Rhythms And a Catalog Retooled
text: The E. J. Strickland Project and Olatuja Project, which appeared one after the other at 92Y Tribeca on Wednesday night, have a lot more in common than the last word in their names. But that mundane point of overlap tells you something about each group. One, led by the jazz drummer E. J. Strickland, made its set a bundle of newly rearranged Stevie Wonder songs; its project was discrete, like a home-improvement job. The other, led by the bassist Michael Olatuja and his wife, the singer Alicia Olatuja, simply delivered a well-honed message; its project was a perpetual thing, a way of being.

headline: He Made Blood and Guts Familiar and Fabulous
text: The International Center of Photography has been Weegee Central since the end of 1993. That’s when it was bequeathed 16,000 photographs and 7,000 negatives by Wilma Wilcox, the longtime companion of Arthur Fellig (1899-1968). Fellig, the Austrian-born son of Jewish immigrants, grew up poor on the Lower East Side, fell in love with photography as a darkroom assistant, and in 1935 set out as a freelance news photographer.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2012 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Perry Exits, and So Does His Depleted War Chest
text: Gov. Rick Perry took his fund-raising muscle with him Thursday when he bowed out of the Republican presidential race. His exit freed not only what was left in his federal campaign coffers, but also the support of the political action committee that had spent $3.9 million in Mr. Perry’s favor.

headline: Matt Hoyt: ‘2006-2011’
text: Bureau

headline: ‘The Woodstock Story Told in Paintings, Photography, Sculpture and Ceramic’
text: D. Wigmore Fine Art

headline: Vivian Maier: ‘Photographs From the Maloof Collection’
text: Howard Greenberg Gallery

headline: Thousands in Turkey Protest Verdict in Journalist’s Murder
text: ISTANBUL — Tens of thousands of people marched in central Istanbul on Thursday to mark the fifth anniversary of the murder of the prominent journalist Hrant Dink, and to protest a Turkish criminal court’s refusal this week to investigate whether the killing had resulted from a conspiracy by an illegal network.

headline: A Nuclear-Free Zone in the Middle East?
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Interiors’: Pierre Bonnard, Marc Camille Chaimowicz, William Copley, Édouard Vuillard
text: Andrew Kreps Gallery

headline: McConnell Urges Delay on Piracy Bills
text: 7:06 p.m. | Updated Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, lent his voice Thursday to the growing chorus of lawmakers distancing themselves from legislation aimed at curbing Internet piracy that has lit up the Web with netizen protests.

headline: Will Super Bowl Viewers Use an App During the Game? Chevy Hopes So
text: The Chevrolet division of General Motors, one of many car brands that will be advertised during Super Bowl XLVI on Feb. 5, is seeking to stand out by offering an app that viewers can use during the game to play games, interact with one another through Twitter and win prizes.

headline: Women’s Rights in Israel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Health Premium Increases
text: To the Editor:

headline: Evaluating Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Military-Related Investments
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Final Indignity, Where the Crusade Began
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Year after year, the legend grew, in election night parties that always ended the same way — in victory.

headline: Greece Inches Toward a Deal With Its Bondholders
text: LONDON — Greece and its private-sector creditors inched closer late Thursday to a completed deal over how much of a loss investors should take on just over 200 billion euros in Greek government bonds

headline: Richard J. Sheirer, City Emergency Chief on 9/11, Dies
text: Richard J. Sheirer, the former head of the city’s Office of Emergency Management who led the agency during the Sept. 11 attacks, died on Thursday morning while driving to work in Manhattan, the city said.

headline: Two Koreas, at War but Closely Entwined
text: The barren expanse of rocks and dirt where most of Jang Hun’s Korean War drama, “The Front Line,” takes place is a hilly wasteland that has nothing of value beyond its strategic location near the disputed border of North Korea and South Korea. To watch the soldiers scrambling up and down slopes scarred with trenches and foxholes is to observe a maddening exercise in futility. Each engagement produces a new round of slaughter.

headline: Brown Kicks Off Campaign by Warning of One-Party Control
text: WORCESTER, Mass. – At a rally to kick off his re-election campaign on Wednesday, Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts reminded several hundred supporters that he had defied steep odds to win a special election for the late Edward M. Kennedy’s Senate seat in 2010 and urged them to help prevent Democrats from reclaiming it in November.

headline: After a Campaign That Fell Apart, a Second Act Is Still Possible
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Moralizing’s High Cost
text: Multiple marriages and even adultery are not automatic disqualifications for the presidency. If they were, the country would have a very different roster of former presidents and candidates. But when a political party decides that moralizing about personal conduct is as important as public policy, it inevitably makes some of its leaders vulnerable to the worst charges of hypocrisy.

headline: A Case of She Said, She Said and He Can’t Say
text: Structured much like the triangle from which it takes its name, “Scalene” opens with a scene so volcanic and mystifying that we are immediately ensnared.

headline: Capital One Expects to Complete ING Direct Deal Soon
text: Whatever happened to Capital One’s bid for ING Direct USA?

headline: ‘Weegee: Murder Is My Business’
text: The tabloid crime photographer Weegee is the subject of two new exhibitions in New York.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,859 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: UnitedHealth Beats Forecasts
text: UnitedHealth Group, the nation’s largest health insurer by sales, reported fourth-quarter earnings Thursday that beat analysts’ estimates after the company gained members and controlled costs.

headline: A Match That Ends at Deuce
text: Pablum tarted up with tennis racquets, “16-Love” is, in a sense, the perfect movie for teenagers: you can text and tweet to your heart’s content and never miss a thing.

headline: Gary Carter Has New Brain Tumors
text: Gary Carter’s condition has worsened with the discovery of new tumors on his brain, his daughter said Thursday on the family’s blog.

headline: Redefining Autism
text: After a proposed change to the definition of autism and a related disorder, far fewer people would meet the criteria for autism spectrum disorder.

headline: A Jedi of Deals Brings His Magic Back to Morgan Stanley
text: Charles Cory, a longtime Morgan Stanley deal maker, spent the financial crisis cloistered in academia, working as a law professor at the University of Virginia.

headline: Giants Pick Honorary Captains With Super Bowl Pedigrees
text: The Giants announced Thursday that three former Super Bowl winners – Mark Bavaro, Michael Strahan and Rich Seubert – would serve as honorary captains for Sunday’s N.F.C. championship game against the San Francisco 49ers.

headline: Governor Cuomo to Be Subject of a Biography
text: A new – if inevitable — subgenre of New York political literature has arrived: the Andrew M. Cuomo biography.

headline: Teamwork Propels a Plan to Expand Gambling
text: As lawmakers prepare for their spring legislative session, supporters of expanding gambling in Illinois said they were working toward a breakthrough agreement that might finally resolve one of the state’s longstanding items of unfinished business.

headline: Who Owns My Ticket?
text: Washington

headline: City Says It Will Focus on College Readiness
text: In a joint hearing of the higher education and K-12 education committees, City Council members asked Department of Education officials how it was possible to assign meaning to an increasing graduation rate if a majority of students remain unprepared for college.

headline: A Renewal of Urban History
text: “The Pruitt-Igoe Myth” tells the story of a public housing project in St. Louis that opened in the mid-1950s, part of the postwar dream of replacing slum apartments with modern, affordable high-rises. By the 1970s Pruitt-Igoe was in such disrepair that it was torn down, the demolition was televised, and a myth was born: public housing was a disaster, an example of government overreaching. The architect Charles Jencks even called the project’s demise the death of Modern architecture.

headline: A Judge Rules Vermont Can’t Shut Nuclear Plant
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Thursday blocked Vermont from forcing the Vermont Yankee nuclear reactor to shut down when its license expires in March, saying that the state is trying to regulate nuclear safety, which only the federal government can do.

headline: Russia: Election Official Offers to Resign
text: The country’s top election official, accused of overseeing a fraudulent parliamentary election last month, submitted his resignation on Thursday, Russian news agencies reported. But in a sign that the official, Vladimir Y. Churov, left, remains in favor with Russia’s leaders, the Central Election Commission immediately rejected his resignation. Mr. Churov, an ally of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, has called the elections free and fair, and he has denied any wrongdoing.

headline: The Wealth Issue
text: Mitt Romney is a rich man, but is Mitt Romney’s character formed by his wealth? Is Romney a spoiled, cosseted character? Has he been corrupted by ease and luxury?

headline: Rwanda: 4 Military Officers Arrested
text: The government has placed four senior military officers under house arrest on counts of indiscipline and illegal business dealings in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, the military said Thursday. The arrests, which were made Wednesday, include Rwanda’s chief of military intelligence and chief of external intelligence. “They were arrested for their dealing with civilians doing business in the Congo,” a military spokesman, Col. Joseph Nzabamwita, said. The arrests come amid growing tensions between the government and a league of exiled soldiers in South Africa that the government accuses of trying to destabilize Rwanda. Colonel Nzabamwita denied the arrests were in connection to security threats, calling the suggestion a “wild rumor.”

headline: Anime Heroes to the Rescue
text: Welcome back the Elric brothers, Edward and Alphonse, heroes of the “Fullmetal Alchemist” franchise. You may not know them, but plenty of anime fanatics do: a manga that began in 2001, the property later became two television series (one still on the Cartoon Network) and later a feature. (“The Sacred Star of Milos” is the sequel.)

headline: For Online Privacy, Click Here
text: SOMETHING viewed online billions of times a month would seem to need no further promotion, but that assumption falls short when the something in question — a turquoise triangle in the upper right-hand corner of banner ads — is a critical piece of the debate about online privacy.

headline: Gingrich Angrily Denies ‘Open Marriage’ Request at Debate
text: There may have been no better way for Newt Gingrich to hammer back at the personal allegations from his ex-wife than to make the media the enemy for telling her story.

headline: Taxes at the Top
text: Call me peculiar, but I’m actually enjoying the spectacle of Mitt Romney doing the Dance of the Seven Veils — partly out of voyeurism, of course, but also because it’s about time that we had this discussion.

headline: After 14-Year Run, Squash Juggernaut Loses a Match
text: The last time the Trinity men’s squash team lost a match, President Clinton was denying he had sexual relations with an intern and Michael Jordan was midway through his final season with the Chicago Bulls. Since that loss to Harvard on Feb. 22, 1998, Trinity won 252 consecutive matches, including 13 national championships — the longest winning streak in college sports history. But The Streak, as it is known in squash circles, came to an end in New Haven on Wednesday when Yale downed Trinity, 5-4.

headline: Pick Your Poison: A Bullet or a Virus
text: “The Viral Factor” wants to be both an action movie and a soap opera. But the merging of the two genres by Dante Lam, a director based in Hong Kong, is clumsy, and so is the film.

headline: Aon’s Move to Britain and a Fleeting Notion of Corporate Citizenship
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: More on Romney’s Tax Rate (and Everyone Else’s)
text: There are any number ways to calculate a household’s tax rate. You can look at just the federal income tax and conclude that almost half of Americans don’t pay taxes, or look at all taxes and conclude that a vast majority of Americans do pay taxes.

headline: Syria’s Rising Toll
text: The death toll from the brutal 10-month war by President Bashar al-Assad of Syria against his own people is now more than 5,400, according to the United Nations and others. Yet the international community still has not mustered the tough pressure that might force Mr. Assad to stop the killing, or Syria’s Army and business elite to toss him out.

headline: Looking for Halston, Finding the ’70s
text: Early in “Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston,” Liza Minnelli, dressed in Halston stretch velvet leggings (“wonderful!”), gives the director, Whitney Sudler-Smith, a great piece of advice: “Go do some research.”

headline: How Lennon’s Death Affected U.S.-Chinese Relations
text: In “Watching TV With the Red Chinese,” Tzu, Chen and Wa, three proud young Communists, arrive in New York in 1980 to pursue higher degrees in systems science. Dexter (Ryan O’Nan), an English literature graduate student living across the hall, becomes their cultural guide, decoding American customs and activities, like Halloween and football.

headline: Spain’s Central Government to Rush Aid to Financially Ailing Regions
text: BARCELONA, Spain — The central government of Spain has moved to shore up the finances of the country’s 17 regional governments — some of which are having trouble paying their bills — while taking steps to tighten control over their spending.

headline: The Pulse: Low Health Revenues Afflict County Budget
text: Cook County’s revenues fell $166.3 million (7.1 percent) short of expectations in the fiscal year that ended Nov. 30, with nearly all of the shortfall attributed to lower-than-expected patient fees from the county’s health system, the county’s interim comptroller said Wednesday.

headline: Traveling to Teach English; Getting Sermons Instead
text: A few weeks before Christmas, someone passed Malachy F. Cleary Jr. a flier as he rushed from the subway station to class at Hunter College on the East Side of Manhattan. It was a call for volunteers to teach at an “English Camp” in Mexico during the winter break, no experience needed; $300 would cover transportation, room and board.

headline: Santorum Attacks Romney and Gingrich on Health Care at Debate
text: Rick Santorum may have just made his clearest, most aggressive case yet that he — not Mitt Romney or Newt Gingrich — should be the nominee.

headline: In a Family Emergency, $204 and Help With Red Tape
text: Last winter, when Salena Johnson had no money, her two young sons missed school for a week.

headline: The Pulse: Woman Who Inspired Farmers’ Help Dies
text: Carol Bolander, 45, whose battle with cancer inspired the DeKalb County farm community to pull together and harvest her family’s crops, died on Jan. 12 at home before dawn on the prairie, with her husband, Glenn, clasping her hands.

headline: Gingrich Reports $3.1 Million in Income for 2010
text: While Newt Gingrich was beating up on the CNN moderator John King at Thursday’s debate, his staff released his 2010 tax return.

headline: A Complex at Aqueduct Is Risk-Free, Cuomo Says
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, stung by widespread doubts about his support for the privately financed construction of the country’s largest convention center at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, offered a full-throated defense of the proposal on Thursday, saying the only cost to the state if the project failed would be “an empty building.”

headline: Putin Welcomes Kissinger: ‘Old Friends’ to Talk Shop
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin will meet Friday with former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to discuss world affairs, including elections in Russia and the United States, said Mr. Putin’s press secretary, Dmitri S. Peskov.

headline: A Milestone in Fisheries Management
text: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is about to reach a historic achievement. By May, the agency will have set annual catch limits for every federally managed fish species, more than 500 in all. What’s more, this vital task has been accomplished in a genuinely bipartisan manner. The law requiring annual limits, the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act, was reauthorized in 2007 with support from President George W. Bush and has been carried out by the Obama administration.

headline: The Brute Force Behind the 49ers
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. —  The legend of Justin Smith began long before he shoved a Pro Bowl left tackle backward into his own quarterback, as if steering a child’s push toy, on national television. It began even before he chased down a wide receiver in the open field to cause a fumble earlier this season.

headline: Charleston, S.C., Debate Live Blog
text: The Republican presidential candidates — minus one, after Rick Perry dropped out earlier Thursday — take the stage in Charleston, S.C., at 8 p.m. Eastern time Thursday for the final debate before Saturday’s South Carolina primary.

headline: On Gary Carter and Faith
text: There is sad news about Gary Carter, the Hall of Fame catcher and a hero of the 1986 World Series for the Mets. Carter’s daughter wrote on the family’s Web site Thursday that her father’s doctors had discovered “several new spots/tumors on his brain.” The Daily News called his condition “extremely grave,” and said doctors were deciding whether to continue his cancer treatments.

headline: Romney Continues to Be Dogged on Tax Returns
text: Will Mitt Romney follow his father’s lead and release a dozen years of his tax returns?

headline: The End of a Friendship?
text: We just witnessed the implosion of a long-time friendship and political alliance, as Mr. Santorum unloaded against Mr. Gingrich, his one-time mentor in the House – on his “grandiosity,” not having “cogent thoughts” and worrying whether “something’s going to pop” about his personal life.

headline: Italy Finds a Heroic Foil for Its Scorned Captain
text: ROME — In Gregorio Maria De Falco, the until recently unknown head of operations at the Port Authority in the Tuscan coastal city of Livorno, Italy found itself not just a national hero, but the anointed foil to Capt. Francesco Schettino, the reckless and apparently cowardly captain of the cruise ship Costa Concordia.

headline: Lechery, Immodesty and the Talmud
text: IS it possible for a religious demand for modesty to be about anything other than men controlling women’s bodies? From recent events in Israel, it would certainly seem that it is not.

headline: The Meaning of Scouting
text: The Colorado affiliate of Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. showed admirable understanding, and taught its young members a valuable lesson, when it said that it welcomes youngsters who were born male but identify as a girl and have a family that “presents her as a girl.” The group clarified its policy after the mother of a 7-year-old was mistakenly told that her child could not join a troop because he has “boy parts” and she publicly complained. The Scouts contacted the mother, but the child has not enrolled.

headline: Candidates Weigh In on Internet Piracy Bills at Debate
text: The Republican candidates for president appear to be on the side of the Internet, not Hollywood.

headline: Bankrupt, Kodak Vows to Rebound
text: In filing for bankruptcy protection early Thursday morning, Eastman Kodak executives say they are seeking to follow the path of American corporations that have reinvented themselves after a court-supervised reorganization, like United Airlines and Chrysler.

headline: Would South Carolina Be Better Off Blue?
text: Given its challenges, perhaps the Palmetto State is best served by a Democratic president.

headline: Gunfire on Rocky Top
text: Despite being in the geographic center of the Civil War, battles in Appalachia were few and far between. There are a few conventional explanations. The area’s topography made it a near-impenetrable borderland for an army of any size. And there was little there for a large occupying force to conquer in any case.

headline: Legs That Go On and On, but Maybe Not for Long
text: SAG HARBOR, N.Y. — Of the sassy pair of female legs in retro stockings stepping out into Sag Harbor’s historic district, one can say this:

headline: Active-Duty Soldiers Take Their Own Lives at Record Rate
text: WASHINGTON — Suicides among active-duty soldiers hit another record high in 2011, Army officials said on Thursday, although there was a slight decrease if nonmobilized Reserve and National Guard troops were included in the calculation.

headline: Giants Receivers Put Trust in Manning
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Police Shoot Suspect in Queens
text: An officer shot a man in Queens on Thursday after he tried to steal an elderly man’s car and brandished a painted BB gun, the police said.

headline: Drone Strike Kills Qaeda Operative in Pakistan, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — A Central Intelligence Agency drone strike in Pakistan’s tribal area on Jan. 10 killed an operative of Al Qaeda who was believed to be planning attacks against the West, an American official confirmed on Thursday.

headline: Celebrated Trade, Celebrated No More
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

headline: Judge Says Protesters Can’t Rally at Courthouse
text: Protesters hoping to hold a rally on Friday against a Supreme Court decision that removed a ban on corporate political spending got no help from a federal judge on Thursday.

headline: Public Outcry Over Antipiracy Bills Began as Grass-Roots Grumbling
text: When Wikipedia went dark and Google blacked out its logo on Wednesday, millions of people could not help but notice. For most, it was the first time that they had heard about two antipiracy bills. One puzzled Twitter user wrote: “Isn’t a SOPA some kind of food?”

headline: Dodd Calls for Hollywood and Silicon Valley to Meet
text: WASHINGTON — When Jack Valenti walked the halls of Congress, friends by the dozen gripped, grinned and took note of what was worrying the movie industry’s dapper chief lobbyist.

headline: Los Angeles Police Investigate Human Remains Found in Bronson Canyon
text: LOS ANGELES — First there was a head, severed at the neck, found inside a plastic grocery bag near a popular hiking trail in the Hollywood Hills on Tuesday. Then on Wednesday, one hand was found, then the other. Then two feet.

headline: A Boost for the World’s Poorest Schools
text: Since the turn of the millennium, the world has made stunning progress toward the goal of universal primary education.  In sub-Saharan Africa, enrollment in primary school has risen by 18 percentage points; in Asia and Latin America there has been more limited progress. While globally, 69 million school-age children do not attend school now, in 1999 that figure was 106 million. This is a huge achievement.

headline: Friday: If You Add Up the Pros and Cons
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This one took me a while, and I sweated over it.

headline: Budget Provision Raises Worries About Cuomo’s Reach
text: ALBANY — One of Andrew M. Cuomo’s big achievements last year in his first year as governor was taming a feisty Legislature.

headline: New Normal on Wall Street: Smaller and Restrained
text: With firms like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley reporting weak results for last year, Wall Street is having to confront doubts about itself.

headline: Penguins Make Rangers Pay for Their Mistakes
text: The Penguins may have skated without Sidney Crosby, who missed his 17th consecutive game with concussion symptoms, but they are still a dangerous team — especially when opponents are sloppy with the puck.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Caged? Writing a Book? The Next Stage in Life for a Subway-Riding Opossum
text: It was the case of the missing marsupial.

headline: Challenges Have Turned Into Just That
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As the Giants flew home from Green Bay last Sunday night, defensive end Dave Tollefson turned to a teammate and asked a simple but stumping question: “When’s the last time we won a challenge?”

headline: Gingrich Jousts With Rivals on Matters Professional and Personal
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Newt Gingrich angrily turned aside questions about his marital history at the outset of the final Republican presidential debate before the South Carolina primary, and then aggressively took on Mitt Romney and the other remaining candidates in a raucous confrontation on Thursday night about immigration, abortion, conservative credentials and electability.

headline: Ally of Christie Will Seek U.S. Senate Seat
text: Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., a prominent Republican state senator who is a close friend of Gov. Chris Christie, announced on Thursday that he would run in New Jersey this year for the United States Senate, seeking to unseat Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat and a bitter rival of the governor.

headline: Romanian Protesters Urge Government’s Ouster
text: BUCHAREST, Romania — Thousands of protesters gathered in Romania’s capital on Thursday to demand the ouster of the government and new elections, as a week of demonstrations against far-reaching austerity measures and years of difficult reforms seemed to gain strength.

headline: For Obama, a Day at Disney World and a Night of Fund-Raisers
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — While the Republican presidential contest in South Carolina riveted media attention on Thursday, President Obama literally flew above the fray in a day that captured the perquisites of incumbency for a president facing re-election.

headline: After Anti-Semitic Crimes, Revisiting the Nightmares Forever Within
text: They come to talk about their families, to laugh, to learn and to praise Hilda Weiss’s famous chocolate coffee cake. headline: Live From the V&A: What’s in a Pose?
text: Can a great model inhabit the style of a designer without necessarily wearing the clothes? Do her gestures and poses reveal fashion’s magic, as surely as a great photographer does, and can those movements be isolated and set in motion in a different venue? On Friday, the curator Olivier Saillard may answer those and other questions when he presents “Models at Work,” a performance at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, as part of its Fashion in Motion series. You can watch the live stream here at 12 p.m. The models will include Axelle Doué, Claudia Huidobro, Anne Rohart, Violeta Sanchez and Amalia Vairelli.

headline: Afghanistan’s Soldiers Step Up Killings of Allied Forces

That movement forced another suspension in the search for bodies as relatives of the missing gathered on this picturesque Tuscan island, hoping their loved ones had miraculously survived.

headline: Reactions to the Supreme Court Decision on Vodafone
text: India’s Supreme Court said Friday afternoon that Vodafone Group was not liable for about $2.5 billion in back taxes (and interest and fees that would have brought the figure above $5 billion) related to its 2007 purchase of the Indian assets of Hong Kong’s Hutchison Telecommunications International. The case has been closely watched by foreign investors and local businesses alike, who said before the decision that it could seriously impact investment in India in the future. For Vodafone, which has been expanding rapidly in emerging markets, with mixed results, the decision will free up cash which could be put towards further investment in India.

headline: Romney’s ‘Prevent Defense’ Yielding Big Gains to Opponents
text: Most football fans have learned to hate the “prevent defense,” a strategy that is employed when a team holds a lead late in the game. In theory, the strategy involves being willing to yield short completions to the offense in an effort to prevent a big gain. In reality, it seems to yield plenty of short completions — but also its share of big gains as the offense takes advantage of the soft coverage. Hence the aphorism “the prevent defense only prevents you from winning.”

headline: Do You Think You’re Brave?

headline: What You (Really) Need to Know
text: A PARADOX of American higher education is this: The expectations of leading universities do much to define what secondary schools teach, and much to establish a template for what it means to be an educated man or woman. College campuses are seen as the source for the newest thinking and for the generation of new ideas, as society’s cutting edge.

headline: Come Hell With High Water
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Earlier this month, Bangladesh’s foreign minister chided the world’s developed nations for failing to honor their pledge to help this low-lying, water-logged nation adapt to the effects of climate change. Of the $30 billion that poor countries were promised three years ago, just $2.5 billion have been disbursed. “Our achievements — social, economic, environmental — of the past decades” are at risk, Dipu Moni told the Guardian.

headline: Deadline Approaches for European Banks’ Recapitalizations

Once again it stirred up trouble.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: At G.O.P. Debate, News Media in the Cross Hairs
text: Newt Gingrich seized Thursday night’s Republican presidential debate from the start with a scathing response to a question from John King, of CNN, about the allegations from Mr. Gingrich’s ex-wife that she was asked “to enter into an open marriage.” He met the “question with cold anger,” Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny reported, denying the account from Marianne Gingrich, which was reported first on Thursday by ABC News, and he put the blame squarely on the news media:

headline: Just Opened | The Oracle Club
text: Anyone lamenting the dearth of surrealist literary salons in New York has only to stop by The Oracle Club, a new members-only workspace for artists and writers in Long Island City. Open since early December, the club is the result of Jenna Gribbon and Julian Tepper — a couple who live above the space and a painter and novelist, respectively — having asked themselves, one morning in October, “What would be the most amazing scenario we could imagine for ourselves?” The three-room space includes a library, a living room and an art studio, all decorated by Gribbon and Tepper. “It’s Salvador Dali’s house meets Whistler’s Peacock Room meets Coco Chanel’s house meets Cocteau’s Chapel,” Gribbon said. For monthly fees ranging from $50 to $175, members get a key; access to the space from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m., seven days a week; and a standing invitation to any readings or events held at the club. The interior is still evolving. “I’m looking for the perfect small kaleidoscope to put in the bathroom wall as a fake peep hole, so you think you’re going to peep into the bathroom but it turns out to be a kaleidoscope,” Gribbon said. “Everything in time,” Tepper said.

headline: Changing Science of Movie-ology
text: IN 1958 the writer and independent filmmaker Jonas Mekas contacted Jerry Tallmer, an editor and critic at The Village Voice and asked why the paper, which had started three years earlier, didn’t have a regular movie column. Mr. Tallmer invited Mr. Mekas to write one. He did. His first movie column that year inaugurated The Voice’s extraordinary, decades-long commitment to deeply personal, often political, always partisan, sometimes cranky and wonderfully crazed film criticism written by Andrew Sarris, Molly Haskell, Amy Taubin, Georgia Brown and David Edelstein, among many others, a tradition that effectively came to an end this month, when that paper’s longtime senior film critic, J. Hoberman, was laid off and told that his position was being eliminated.

headline: Whoops, I Tripped Into a Lifeboat
text: Capt. Francesco Schettino would have us believe that he did not abandon his ship, the Costa Concordia, after it struck a reef. He does not deny that he was safely off board before hundreds of others, but he claims his absence was accidental.  He told the Italian newspaper La Repubblica that he was dutifully escorting passengers into lifeboats “in an orderly fashion” when, “[s]uddenly, since the ship was at a 60-to-70 degree angle, I tripped and I ended up in one of the boats. That’s how I found myself there.”

headline: Seven-Minute Shakespeare
text: Over on Education Life, I have a short piece about CliffsNotes Films, a new series in which classic literature becomes animated “edutainment.” The first offerings — six Shakepearean plays — debuted online in October.

headline: Totes Shakespeare
text: IF reading Cliffs Notes’s “Hamlet” seems to be a pokey, 20th-century way to speed-comprehend Shakespeare, never fear. Now there’s a seven-minute cartoon version, complete with a talking Yorick’s skull. Think of it as Cliffs Notes for Cliffs Notes.

headline: ’30 Rock’ Seeks to Close a Controversial Chapter With Comedy
text: When real-life events pierce the fictional world of “30 Rock,” the NBC series unhesitatingly turns it into fodder for comedy, whether it’s the death of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il or a controversy that engulfed its co-star Tracy Morgan while the show was on hiatus.

headline: More About Corporate Taxes And The .01 Percent
text: A further thought about the proper calculation of tax burdens on very high income Americans: if you remember past debates, it’s kind of peculiar to see conservatives jumping up and down to say that Mitt Romney does too pay reasonable taxes if you include the profits taxes on the corporations in which he invests. Because if memory serves me, just a few years ago conservatives were denouncing the “flypaper theory” of tax incidence, arguing that much of the burden of corporate taxes really falls on labor, not on stockholders. Is it just my imagination?

headline: An Architect Returns to His First Triumph
text: At 89, the architect Kevin Roche finds himself back in the spotlight with the opening this week of the renovated American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Marking an Epic Polar Journey in London
text: Few scientific explorations have captured the public’s imagination like Robert Falcon Scott’s expedition to Antarctica from 1910 to 1913. He and a team of scientists withstood incredible hardships  and perished before reaching home, but not before they had discovered a large number of zoological and geological specimens that greatly furthered scientific knowledge of the vast region. These included 2,109 different species of animals and plants from land and water, more than 400 of them new to science.

headline: After Burke’s Death, a Time for Contemplation—and Questions
text: This is when sports gets hard, on days when people like Sarah Burke die, when the awe over spectacular performances in increasingly dangerous sports is replaced by horror that someone could die doing them. Burke’s sport, freestyle skiing, is one of a long line of sports growing more perilous as the athletes get better and  the physics get riskier as speeds and heights increase. Sure, we cheer as we see skiers and snowboarders flip in the air, gasp as race cars pass inches from one another at top speeds, howl as hockey players and football players pound each other, our knowledge of the dangers safely stashed away. But when the worst happens, then what? How long can the knowledge stay stashed away?

headline: Take It Slow. Look Around. Watch Out!
text: EARLY in “The Innkeepers,” a film about two desk clerks at a soon-to-be-shuttered hotel who engage in some amateur ghost hunting, one tells the other to watch closely a video clip that purports to contain evidence of paranormal phenomena. There’s the image of a lone, stationary rocking chair on a dark porch. Tension builds, and the score swells, but what happens next is a surprise, one that challenges audience expectations. The moment reflects the filmmaking goals of its director, Ti West, who has spent his relatively brief career subverting the assumptions of horror fans.

text: The Supreme Court on Friday instructed a lower court in Texas to take a fresh look at election maps it had drawn in place of a competing set of maps from the Texas Legislature. The justices said the lower court had not paid enough deference to the Legislature’s choices and had improperly substituted its own values for those of elected officials.

headline: Pilot’s-Eye View of the War in the Air
text: THE Academy Award nominations for 2011, which will be announced on Tuesday, will most likely include a few nods to “The Artist,” Michel Hazanavicius’s careful if sometimes condescending pastiche of silent-era filmmaking. Most people seeing “The Artist” will probably be seeing a movie without (much) spoken dialogue for the first time; the trick will be getting them to see a second example, preferably an authentic one.

headline: Debt And Transfiguration
text: Ryan Avent points out an important fact: if you look at total debt, public and private, the United States is doing better at deleveraging than countries that talk much more about the evils of debt than we do. I thought I would redo the calculation for the US so that I understood it. I focus on nonfinancial debt — that’s because money that banks owe to each other is more a reflection of the structure of the financial system than of the degree of overborrowing more broadly. So here’s nonfinancial debt, public plus private, as a percentage of GDP:

headline: How Americans Have Reshaped Language
text: There has always been disagreement on these American shores as to just what the “best” English is. The status of Parisian French or Tuscan Italian has long been unassailable. Yet in the early 1940s, fusty Chicagoans were writing to The Chicago Tribune declaring Midwestern speech America’s “purest,” while New York radio announcers were speaking in plummy Londonesque, complete with rolled r’s. Down in Charleston, S.C., the elite’s sense of the best English involved peculiar archaisms like “cam” for “calm” and “gyardin” for “garden.”

headline: The Art of Mastering Many Tongues
text: Among the most surprising qualities of “Babel No More,” Michael Erard’s globe-trekking adventure in search of the world’s virtuosos of language learning, is that a book dealing with language acquisition and polyglot linguistics can be so gripping. But indeed it is — part travelogue, part science lesson, part intellectual investigation, it is an entertaining, informative survey of some of the most fascinating polyglots of our time.

headline: Experts Consider Changing the Definition of Autism
text: Autism, as a psychiatric disorder, is defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, published by the American Psychiatric Association, which covers all mental health disorders for both children and adults. That definition matters — an official diagnosis of autism is what opens up access to services and treatment to many affected individuals, both children and adults.

headline: Guidebooks to Babylon
text: Librarians may regard me as a highbrow pervert, frowning over their spectacles at my choice of reading matter. In certain archives, I’ve even been directed to sit at a solitary table, where my movements can be carefully watched. But I’ve learned to ignore the suspicious looks. The truth is, for any writer who is researching a “golden age” of vice — whether it be Renaissance Venice, Georgian London, belle époque Paris or fin de siècle New Orleans — there is nothing quite so satisfying as a guide to local harlots.

headline: (Photographing) Murder Was His Business
text: Arthur Fellig had a knack for being in the right place at the right time. He also had an eye.

headline: Author Q&A: ‘The Insurgency in Chechnya and the North Caucasus’
text: Today, for those who follow the North Caucasus or who keep up with books on conflict, we have a treat: a guest appearance on the blog from Lt. Col. Robert W. Schaefer, a Green Beret specializing in the Russian-speaking world.

headline: After an Online Firestorm, Congress Shelves Antipiracy Bills
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders on Friday indefinitely shelved two antipiracy bills that had rallied the Internet and rocked Capitol Hill, dealing a major defeat to the traditional media industry while emboldening a new breed of online political activists.

headline: ‘Pity the Billionaire’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Roger Williams
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE BALFOUR DECLARATION: The Origins of the Arab-Israeli Conflict,  by Jonathan Schneer (Random House, $17.) Schneer’s richly documented study puts the famous declaration — a Nov. 2, 1917, letter by the British foreign secretary Arthur James Balfour supporting the establishment in Palestine of “a national home for the Jewish people” — in the context of Britain’s promises to Arabs, Jews and its European allies in World War I.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: DISTRUST THAT PARTICULAR FLAVOR,  by William Gibson (Putnam, $26.95.) Instead of predicting the future, Gibson, one of our greatest science-fiction writers, finds the future all around him in this beguiling collection of essays.

headline: Up Front
text: Charles Isherwood, who reviews Ian Donaldson’s biography of Ben Jonson on the cover, has been a theater critic at The New York Times since 2004. “When I grew up theater was what the adults did, mostly,” Isherwood wrote in an e-mail. “But I evinced an early sensitivity to the form. One of my first memories is of being taken to see a stage version of ‘The Wizard of Oz.’ I was so traumatized by the appearance of the Wicked Witch of the West that I had to be taken home in hysterics at the intermission. Not the last time I’ve gotten weepy at the theater.” Isherwood went to Stanford, where he was “a generic English major”: “My mother bemoaned this fact, and remains pleasantly surprised that I am still employed today. I took classes in Shakespeare and Restoration comedy and Japanese theater, but never formally studied theater. For me college was basically an excuse to sit around reading Henry James novels, when I wasn’t racing off to San Francisco in my secondhand Chevy Vega to see bands like Siouxsie and the Banshees and the Gang of Four and dance all night at clubs. Had I known the path my career would take, I would have spent a lot more time on Molière and Stanislavsky.”

headline: Cheaters Never Win
text: A big city never looks the same once you’ve walked its streets with a hard-boiled private eye. Preferably someone as perceptive and thoughtful as Leonid McGill, the shady but honorable bruiser-for-hire in an addictive series of New York crime novels by Walter Mosley. A former mob fixer who has gone straight, McGill doesn’t so much walk the city as case it for danger. Keeping pace with him is as much an education as an adventure.

headline: Paris Men’s: Lean and  Still Hungry
text: The plaids and patchwork in Junya Watanabe’s show Friday looked culled from a farm supply store or a college town like Portland, Ore., and so felt a bit in a worn groove. At Yves Saint Laurent, Stefano Pilati stuck to slim dark tailoring with leather insets and flashes of silver on shoes. There was much black leather, which was based on motorcycle gear but given more polish and presented in ensemble. You can imagine people coveting pieces, especially some of the nicely shaped jackets, but the show didn’t offer much direction.

headline: Day Planner (Turn Off the Alarm)
text: So you’ve skied the chutes of Jackson Hole and you’ve risen at dawn to porpoise through the powder from a helicopter. But are you ready for your greatest challenge — learning to throttle back and enjoy skiing the Spanish way? Then stop counting the day’s vertical feet and follow this itinerary.

headline: Taking Your Ease in the Pyrenees
text: The ski area is enjoyed as much for its slopes as for its embrace of the good life.

headline: Skiing the Spanish Pyrenees
text: NOTHING made sense.

headline: Enough Snow?
text: To the Editor: Re “Oh, for Just a Little Snow” (Practical Traveler, Jan. 15), I teach skiing at Park City Mountain Resort. Maybe the snow totals look weak, but with top-gun snowmaking and state-of the-art grooming, the main runs are as good as it gets. The days are sunny and warm. No one is unhappy. I’ve been up there since opening day in mid-November and have not hit a rock yet.

headline: Kia Recalls 146,000 Optimas and Rondos for Driver’s Air Bag Flaw
text: Kia is recalling about 146,000 vehicles because the driver’s air bag may not deploy in a crash, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Q&A With Yolanda Edwards, Editor and Blogger
text: WHEN Yolanda Edwards gave birth to her daughter, Clara, friends said her traveling days were done. Refusing to accept this, she booked a trip to England from New York when Clara was five weeks old, and from then on, they often joined her husband, a photographer, on assignments. “There I was on maternity leave,” she said. “So I thought, why shouldn’t we all be together as much as possible?”

headline: The Momentum of Ideas
text: During last night’s Republican debate, the candidates were asked to name something from the campaign that they would have done differently. Here was Newt Gingrich’s answer:

headline: A Widower Hits the Dating Scene
text: In the opening lines of Hilma Wolitzer’s wonderful new novel, the recently widowed Edward Schuyler stands in his living room, ironing, when the telephone rings. He picks it up to hear the clamorous, intrusive voice of a female suitor, attempting to break in on his grief. But he’d rather iron the blouses of his deceased wife, Bee, “as a way of reconnecting with her when she was so irrevocably gone” than date any of the women now scurrying in his direction. Bee, on her deathbed, had predicted this fate: “Look at you. They’ll be crawling out of the woodwork.”

headline: Saxapahaw, N.C., Middle of Somewhere, Becomes a Draw
text: I WAS polishing off a steaming bowl of coconut curry soup when a server appeared bearing a plate of plump pan-seared diver scallops atop creamy applewood-bacon succotash and braised asparagus. The food was befitting a candlelit restaurant, but I had a view of gas pumps outside and, a few steps from my table, fluorescent-lighted aisles packed with workaday necessities — toilet paper, motor oil, sauerkraut juice (aids digestion, according to the label).

headline: BuzzFeed Makes Another Splashy Hire, This One From Rolling Stone
text: BuzzFeed, the social Web site that made a splash last month by hiring the blogger Ben Smith away from Politico, will signal its expansion plans on Friday by announcing that it has hired Doree Shafrir of Rolling Stone to oversee culture coverage.

headline: In Jane Eyre’s Footsteps
text: When Margot Livesey was 9 years old, growing up motherless and lonely in Scotland, a book on her father’s shelf caught her eye: “Jane Eyre.” Livesey’s discovery of Charlotte Brontë’s masterpiece was transformative. The promised friend between the covers, a character whose indomitable spirit has consoled and inspired readers for over a century and a half, allowed ­Livesey to understand that “life is change.” “Like Jane’s, my life had changed for the worse,” Livesey wrote in an essay a few years ago, “and like hers, it could also change for the better. Time would, irrevocably, carry me to a new place.”

headline: Hotel Review: Element Times Square West, N.Y.
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Hollywood Needs Unified Effort, Dodd Asserts
text: WASHINGTON — As Hollywood and its indie film counterparts head to Park City, Utah, for the Sundance festival, there’s a question they might kick around in the après ski lounges: Should everyone in a movie business that is clearly grappling with serious issues be doing more to advance their interests in Washington?

headline: Singapore Hawker Stalls Move Indoors
text: “JUST look around,” said Malcolm Lee, a 27-year-old Singaporean chef, as he gestured toward the dozen or so street food stands surrounding our table. “I doubt that one of these hawkers is under the age of 40. When this generation is gone, their recipes will probably go with them. Their children want to be bankers or lawyers. Who wants to slog it out six days a week, morning through night, in a hot, dirty environment?”

headline: U.S. General Urges Closer Ties With Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called Friday for closer engagement between the United States and Israel during a short visit here at a time of tension over Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Documentary Footage Raises Questions About Lawsuit
text: PARK CITY, Utah — David Siegel, a Florida time-share mogul, is suing the Sundance Institute and Lauren Greenfield, the director of a documentary about his family, “The Queen of Versailles,” for defamation. The plot twist: Mr. Siegel’s lawsuit may turn out to be more embarrassing for him than Ms. Greenfield’s film.

headline: Dave Grohl: From Antsy Student to Nirvana to Foo Fighters
text: Among musicians, drummers are a breed apart. On the one hand, the drummer is the timekeeper, the one who counts off the song and keeps the other band members on the beat. On the other, the drummer sits behind everyone else and usually doesn’t write songs or sing them, so often he’s “only the ­drummer.”

headline: Restaurant Review: Blu Ice Bar and Splashing Rock Restaurant, Two Harbors, Minn.
text: At restaurants on Lake Superior’s North Shore in Minnesota, the fish tends to be fresh and local. At the Blu Ice Bar, in Two Harbors, much of the restaurant is as perishable as the catch of the day.

headline: The Political Price of Austerity
text: Most books about contemporary politics are designed for quick obsolescence. A notable exception to the rule is the work of Thomas Byrne Edsall, whose five careful books, starting with “The New Politics of Inequality” in 1984, are still found on the shelves and in the footnotes of everyone who writes about politics — left and right, academics and journalists alike. Edsall’s distinctive method combines his own reporting with rigorous use of data from across the social sciences, including psychology and anthropology. Though his previous book, “Building Red America,” seemed poorly timed when it appeared in 2006 just as Karl Rove’s quest for permanent Republican dominance collapsed, its insights into conservative attitudes about authority and autonomy remain as useful as anything written more recently about the Tea Party and the right-wing resurgence.

headline: Temple Oranges, Here Today …
text: I’m no great fan of snow or the groundhog, but one arrival I look forward to each winter is temple oranges — shiny, spongy to the touch and deeply rutted with pores, like a cartoonist’s idea of an orange. I spotted a temple-like pyramid (a ziggurat?) of them the other day in front of Fairway on the Upper West Side.

headline: Revisiting Shakespeare’s ‘Coriolanus’
text: Some women swoon for swashbuckling Antony or bodice-ripping Othello, but I’ve always had a soft spot for prideful, imperious Coriolanus. Next to Shakespeare’s other tragic figures, who sometimes sound like Freudian case studies — Hamlet, that whiny, dithering ball of nerves who accidentally murders his girlfriend’s father; Lear, who judges his daughters so egregiously in a vicious game of favorites that he deserves to be left out on the moors — Coriolanus comes across as downright noble. Uniquely among these figures, this war hero turned disgraced politician does nothing truly wrong: he is punished without having committed a crime. In fact, his worst fault might be his refusal to speak anything less than exactly what he believes.

headline: The Choice on ‘Today': Tips on Fafsa, and Net-Price Calculators
text: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

headline: A Brazilian Beach Beauty, Refined and Untouched
text: FROM the balcony of Quinta do Bucanero, a pousada in the center of Praia do Rosa, the appeal of the Brazilian seaside town is obvious. Perched on top of a cliff, the 10-room hotel is surrounded by a tropical jungle and forested mountains, with views of a long, sweeping stretch of golden sand and two lagoons. Surfers dot the waves, and orchids scent the air.

headline: On a Brazilian Island, Sophistication With a Barefoot Atmosphere
text: Praia do Rosa has only two paved roads, but in recent years the town has seen the opening of new hotels and night spots.

headline: There Goes the Neighborhood
text: A co-worker of mine saw a van plow into two parked cars. She wrote down the license plate number as the van drove away, but when she pulled up alongside it, she recognized the driver — a known criminal in her neighborhood who is always armed and has a very bad reputation. They made eye contact, and he knows that she saw the accident. Is it her responsibility to get involved with this dangerous man? YAMIT REMZ, NEW YORK CITY

headline: The Hand-Held Highlighter
text: Once, when readers wanted to remember something, they had to mark important passages with thin, wobbly lines in drab, hard-to-relocate colors. Before the rise of the highlighter, says Dennis Baron, a University of Illinois professor and the author of “A Better Pencil,” attentive readers relied on “a combination of underlining and marginal notes.”

headline: How Many Stephen Colberts Are There?
text: We all knew that there was Stephen Colbert, the man, and Stephen Colbert, the character on television. Well, Charles McGrath tells us there’s a third Colbert: his televised persona interacting with our reality. For those of us waiting for the G.O.P. primaries to be over so we can just get to November and cast our pre-determined vote, we may actually have to pay attention, because Stephen Colbert (and his multiple personalities) will be providing some quality entertainment. And who knows? Maybe he will accidentally (or purposely?) change the entire process.

headline: The Not-So-Retiring Barney Frank
text: You recently said about Newt Gingrich: “He’s just one of the worst people I know of who didn’t commit violence on somebody.” Did he kill your dog?He transformed American politics from one in which people presume the good will of their opponents, even as they disagreed, into one in which people treated the people with whom they disagreed as bad and immoral. He was a kind of McCarthy-ite who succeeded.

headline: All Bent Out of Shape
text: I first heard about William Broad’s debate-sparking article, “How Yoga Can Wreck Your Body,” in yoga class on Saturday afternoon. As the class inhaled in an extended downward dog, the teacher asked if anyone had read the article. As we were guided into pigeon pose, the teacher offered this: “The thing is,” she told us, “if you’re mindful, you won’t get hurt.” I went home and read the article. I had not so much a crisis of confidence, but a feeling that “if you’re mindful, you won’t get hurt” was very possibly an inadequate answer.

headline: The Fat Trap
text: In “The Fat Trap” (Jan. 1), Tara Parker-Pope implied that obesity is virtually incurable based on the observation that eating calorie-restricted diets (less than 1,200 or 1,500 calories a day) doesn’t cure it.

headline: Inside the List
text: FEMALE POWER: Jayne Ann Krentz’s latest paranormal romance, “Copper Beach,” is new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. Krentz is no stranger to this page — she’s had more than 30 New York Times best sellers — and with her success she has become a vocal defender of the romance category as a whole. In interviews, she talks about the genre’s link to the “heroic tradition,” and as far back as 1992 she edited a cultural studies anthology, “Dangerous Men and Adventurous Women,” in which she argued that romances were by nature both feminist and subversive: “Readers understand that the books celebrate female power. In the romance novel . . . the woman always wins. With courage, intelligence and gentleness she brings the most dangerous creature on earth, the human male, to his knees.”

headline: Georges Remi: Learning His Lines
text: Cartoonists are a peculiar breed of artist. For one thing, they’re hesitant about the use of the A-word. Their craft — now that’s better — also comes with great constraints. Because the work appears in newspapers and comic books, it must strike a commercial chord quickly: there isn’t much time for it to “find an audience.” The field doesn’t boast many lonely geniuses whose work is discovered posthumously. The demands of reproduction put limits on complexity, and the panel format — those squares and rectangles — erects graphic walls. For successful cartoonists, producing every day on someone else’s schedule, the grind is relentless. Cartoonists tend not to be boulevardiers; their way of life is sedentary and often solitary, and their days are spent in the company of invented characters in an invented world. Life and work can merge in curious ways. I happen to be the son of a cartoonist — a happy and well-adjusted cartoonist — and collaborated with him on “Prince Valiant,” but it was clear to all of us in the family that our situation was not quite normal. Or, thinking back to the moment when an electrician came into my father’s studio and found him posing — on his back, wearing a wig and a skirt, holding a garbage can lid as a shield and using a plunger on a rubber tube to snap a Polaroid — it may just have been that we had a different sense of what “normal” was.

headline: Margaret Fuller: Woman of the World
text: Margaret Fuller, a woman of great talent and promise, had the misfortune to be born in Massachusetts in 1810, at a time and place in which the characteristics of what historians have termed “true womanhood” were becoming ever more rigidly defined. Well brought-up women like herself were to be cultured, pious, submissive and genteel. Fuller, by contrast, was assertive and freethinking. She was also — and to some extent, still is — a difficult person to like.

headline: William Gass’s Lifelong Attachment to Literature
text: “When reviewers take the trouble to compliment a writer on her style,” William H. Gass writes in “Life Sentences,” his new collection of essays, “it is usually because she has made it easy for them to slide from one sentence to another like an otter down a slope.” Gass’s sentence enacts its own dissent from this critical preference for clear and simple prose: as soon as the otter barges in, the reader’s attention is forcibly drawn away from Gass’s meaning and toward his style.

headline: The Shadow of Nuremberg
text: On the campaign trail in June 2008, Barack Obama commented on the Supreme Court’s extension of the constitutional right of habeas corpus to detainees held at the naval facility at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. “During the Nuremberg trials, part of what made us different was even after these Nazis had performed atrocities that no one had ever seen before, we still gave them a day in court, and that taught the entire world about who we are but also the basic principles of rule of law,” Obama said. “Now the Supreme Court upheld that principle yesterday,” he added. Obama’s statement linked Nuremberg to an idea central to his presidential campaign: The Bush administration in the fight against Islamist terrorists had compromised American values and undermined America’s wartime rule-of-law legacy. The Supreme Court had begun the task of restoring those values, Obama suggested, and he promised to finish the job as president.

headline: What We Find Gross, and Why
text: Did you hear the one about the Texan at his first Passover Seder? He was mightily impressed with the soup. “These matzo balls sure are delicious, ma’am,” he told his hostess. “What other parts of the matzo do y’all cook with?”

headline: Tightening Race Comes as Abrupt Blow to Romney Team
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — With Mitt Romney facing the biggest challenge to his presidential aspirations since he announced his candidacy, his aides acknowledged Friday what seemed unthinkable just seven days ago: He could lose the South Carolina primary.

headline: On Hold
text: A story in doodles.

text: This week, Charles Isherwood discusses a new book about playwright Ben Jonson; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: On Our Radar: Compensation for Yellowstone Spill
text: Exxon Mobil agrees to pay $1.6 million in penalties to the state of Montana for pollution caused by a pipeline break last summer that fouled dozens of miles of shoreline along the Yellowstone River. Of that amount, $300,000 is a cash fine and the rest is to go toward future environmental projects. Exxon says that more than 63,000 gallons of crude swept into the river. [The Associated Press]

headline: A Monster in the Age of Abolition
text: Few of its readers are likely to forget Barry Unsworth’s “Sacred Hunger,” a co-winner of the Booker Prize in 1992. The novel contains a vision of hell on earth unlike any in contemporary fiction, largely because its account of the unimaginable cruelties of the slave trade is told in the well-wrought prose of an old-fashioned 19th-century novel with an omniscient narrator. The effect is uncanny: its intelligent, controlled and immensely readable sentences glow with a deathly pallor.

headline: When Children’s Speech Turns Lethal
text: In a career spanning nearly 20 years, Ben Marcus has written just four spare volumes: a story collection, two novels and a chapbook. Formally inventive, dark and dryly comic, this work has earned him critical praise and a small army of devoted fans. His prose is heavily metaphorical yet coolly ironic; it traffics in the language of scholarship, myth and history, and until now has forsaken the conventional trappings of narrative. Indeed, the pieces in “The Age of Wire and String” (1995) function more like prose poems than stories; their emotional impact is derived from their distinctive diction and syntax. The opener, “Argument,” might serve as a map of Marcus’s early career, with its stated goal of “cataloging a culture” through “an array of documents settling within the chief concerns of the society, of any society, of the world and its internal areas.” The book’s archness is both bracing and absurd; it attempts to reinvent story by repurposing, gleefully, the jargon ordinarily used to analyze it.

headline: Ecological Connectivity as Climate Warms
text: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier-fed streams.

headline: Etta James Dies at 73; Voice Behind ‘At Last’
text: Etta James, whose powerful, versatile and emotionally direct voice could enliven the raunchiest blues as well as the subtlest love songs, most indelibly in her signature hit, “At Last,” died on Friday morning in Riverside, Calif. She was 73.

headline: He’s So Vain, He’d Be Right in Thinking This Post Is About Him
text: I am not one of those people who think the president should be “just like me.” He should be in touch with the needs and aspirations and fears of ordinary Americans, sure. But how many of your neighbors would you like to see with the nuclear trigger in their hands?

headline: For Fans, a New Focus on the Best Soccer in the World
text: There is a new breed of sports fan in the United States.
