headline: Country and Tropicália in a Punk-Folk Diet
text: FOR two decades Ani DiFranco has been a fiercely independent folk singer in punk clothing, a writer of feminist anthems, protest songs and clear-eyed explorations of the messy side of love. But when she’s listening for pleasure and inspiration, Ms. DiFranco ranges farther afield, she said, adding, “I’m not even someone who listens to a lot of music you would consider similar to mine.”

headline: A Valkyrie’s Voice Flashing More Than Steel
text: Vienna

headline: Once a Millstone, GE Capital Is Now a Profit Center
text: GE Capital weighed heavy on General Electric during the financial crisis.

headline: The Big Profile: John Mulaney
text: In the post-Al Franken, post-Robert Smigel, post-Tina Fey era of “Saturday Night Live,” it is perhaps only its nerdiest and most obsessive viewers who have a favorite writer on that NBC late-night sketch show. But since joining the “S.N.L.” writing staff for its 2008-09 season, John Mulaney has found himself a place in the hearts of completists and casual fans alike: a Chicago-born standup comic, Mulaney has gained recognition as a creator and writer of Stefon, the ultra-hip nightlife correspondent played in frequent “Weekend Update” appearances by Bill Hader; and for his own occasional riffs, delivered as himself from the “Update” desk. (Also joining him in this modern-day pantheon is his fellow “S.N.L.” writer and Internet microcelebrity Mike O’Brien.)

headline: In England, Bond Cars of the Villains, Vixens and Dapper Hero
text: With a new James Bond film, “Skyfall,” being released this fall, and Her Majesty’s favorite cinematic spy franchise celebrating its 50th anniversary, an exhibition of Bond cars has opened at the National Motor Museum in Beaulieu in the south of England.

headline: Agile Patriot Thrives in a Teammate’s Hulking Shadow
text: FOXBORO, Mass. — On the fourth play of the Patriots’ divisional playoff game against Denver, Aaron Hernandez broke a 43-yard run to the Broncos 7-yard line.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The Chinese New Year commences Monday, but some restaurants will jump-start their celebrations and offer special menus this weekend. At Masak, 432 East 13th Street (between First Avenue and Avenue A), in the East Village, a preview menu is offered today through Sunday, with items like arrowroot chips and roasted quail stuffed with rice, chestnuts, lotus seeds, kale and a salted duck yolk. A more extensive New Year menu is offered starting Tuesday. To celebrate the Year of the Dragon, Chinatown Brasserie, 380 Lafayette Street (Great Jones Street), in NoHo, will cook up dim sum specials, traditional Chinese fare and an assortment of desserts starting on Sunday. Culinary tours led by Adventure on a Shoestring this weekend include a walking tour of Manhattan’s Chinatown at 1 and 3 p.m. with samplings of dumplings, pastries and ice cream. The tours will meet at the southeast corner of Canal and Mott Streets. The fee is $10 and does not include food. Call (212) 265-2663 for more information.

headline: Off the Charts: New-Car Registrations Decline in Europe
text: The number of new passenger cars registered in the European Union declined 15.8 percent from 2007 to 2011. Registrations fell in 17 of the 24 European countries with populations over 1 million.

headline: My Wine’s Long Way Home
text: PARIS — In my latest column, I look at the wines of Galicia, in the far northwestern corner of Spain, where the cool influence of the Atlantic is strong. For anyone expecting big, Mediterranean style reds, you’ll have to look elsewhere.

headline: Defrosting the Hamptons
text: FRIGID winter temperatures have just arrived in the Northeast, and beach-ready bodies are thousands of sit-ups away. But for some buyers and summer renters — especially year-end bonus recipients — now is when thoughts turn toward house-hunting in the Hamptons.

headline: Justices’ Texas Redistricting Ruling Likely to Help G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday rejected elections maps drawn by a federal court in Texas that had favored Democratic candidates there.

headline: Paris Top 5 | Louis Vuitton
text: The giant silver globe that was suspended over the runway at Louis Vuitton made it clear from the moment we took our seats that we were in for quite a trip. Kim Jones, an Englishman in Paris, presented his stunning second collection for the luxury house. Exploring influences from both Tokyo and the City of Light, the clothes paid homage to the legendary fashion illustrator Antonio Lopez, an artist with links to both fashion capitals. Lopez’s drawings were brought vividly to life in a group of graphic, patterned (and LV-monogrammed) blanket coats with coordinating scarves pinned at the neck. A vicuna double-breasted, belted coat (see Coming Soon: Belted Coats) worn with a mink scarf, kimono-style shirt and gray double-faced pajama trousers made references to both East and West in the most luxurious way possible.

headline: In Europe, Cars Stay in Showroom
text: THE new passenger car is becoming an increasingly rare item in some European countries.

headline: Video Feed of Wisconsin Recall Count Draws Thousands
text: The daily work of government bureaucracy may not be as captivating to watch as Shiba Inu puppies or giant pandas sleeping. But the risk of boredom has not deterred tens of thousands from visiting a site broadcasting video from a Web camera trained on a cinderblock office in Madison, Wis., where state workers are processing signatures calling for the recall of the governor.

headline: Pipeline Project Emerges as Marker in Tax Fight
text: 1:55 p.m. | Updated BALTIMORE – House Republicans, undaunted by the payroll tax holiday debacle that dinged their conference last month, said Friday that they were considering using the Keystone XL Pipeline as a chip in the next round of negotiations over the tax break, as part of their overall efforts to push back against White House policies this year.

headline: In Ankara, Turkey, New Restaurants Enliven the Diplomatic Area
text: The neighborhood has gone from a staid diplomatic hub to Ankara’s choicest destination for an evening out.

headline: Religious Groups Get Delay in Birth Control Insurance Requirement
text: The Obama administration said it would give religious organizations one additional year to comply with a new policy requiring employers to provide free contraception services in insurance plans.

headline: A Dyslexia Film and a Director’s Family
text: PARK CITY, Utah — It’s an emotional strain for a filmmaker to bring a project to Sundance. The thrill of getting in is quickly followed by fear: What happens if nobody likes it? Now imagine what added emotions might be surging through a director whose film showcase’s his son’s disability.

headline: The Ivies Squash Back
text: The streak is over. After 13-plus years, after 13 consecutive national championships, after 252 straight victories — the longest such run in college sports — the Trinity men’s squash team has lost a match, to Yale.

headline: Wedding Q&A
text: The Significant Other Is Not Insignificant

headline: TimesCast | January 20, 2012
text: The Citadel remains an important stop for Republican candidates | Nate Silver on South Carolina primary projections.

headline: At Men’s Fashion Shows, A Mix of Aspiration and Powerful Intrigue
text: The movies often keep fashion designers in duds, as we saw at Miuccia Prada’s fall men’s show in Milan and a few days later at Rick Owens in Paris. But these designers approach the imagery very differently.

headline: Time for a Fresh Approach to Bankruptcy Fees
text: The executive office of the United States Trustee plans to revise professional fee guidelines, especially as they apply to lawyers retained in big Chapter 11 cases.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $9.5 Million
text: The director M. Night Shyamalan — whose breakthrough film, “The Sixth Sense,” told the story of a boy empowered to see and talk to the dead — was finally able to commune with a living buyer for his TriBeCa penthouse after more than a year, selling it for $9.5 million, the biggest sale of the past week, according to city records.

headline: How Did the Eurostar Lose Its Luster?
text: BETWEEN PARIS AND LONDON — What has happened to the Eurostar, this train I so envied as an American university student studying in Paris?

headline: Dear Rajiv Gandhi
text: In 1988 a rising novelist penned an open letter to then Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in The New York Times, after his book was banned in India.

headline: Eating His Way Through Amsterdam
text: Mark Bittman goes on the hunt for real Dutch food.

headline: Tomic-Federer Headlines a Clash of Generations
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Week 1 of this Australian Open has been a record-breaking bull market for experience.

headline: Eating Out in Amsterdam: Way Beyond Herring
text: NEARLY 10 years ago I went to Amsterdam in search of Dutch food; for the most part what I found was Mediterranean. This past fall I tried again. To put it nicely, I failed less miserably. Because although it is safe to say that the Dutch have yet to rediscover their culinary heritage in the fashion of some of their nearby neighbors, there has been much progress.

headline: Dear Governor: Lobby to Save a Love of Reading
text: After a New Year's Eve encounter with the state's third-grade reading test, two city school parents write: 'In his recent State of the State address, Governor Cuomo said he wants to be an advocate for children. Let him lobby to protect their natural curiosity and love of learning from the onslaught of anti-intellectual, ends-oriented teaching practices forced on our educators by over-emphasis on standardized tests.'

headline: The Teacher 'Brand' Gets a Makeover
text: The image of teachers is taking a hit in the political arena. A New York design firm undertook a challenge to overhaul the "brand" of teachers. After many sketches and debate, they arrived at the concept of connecting the dots, and assisting students with inquiry. Take a listen and click on the "Read More" button, to see what they came up with. Let us know what you think.

headline: Car Batteries Are Not Just For the Car
text: Coda Automotive is supposed to start selling its electric sedan next month. On Friday, its parent company announced that it was also moving into a related line: stationary batteries for electricity storage.

headline: Business Social Media: Rise of the Machines
text: Maybe the old guard in enterprise software is firing back at the social media upstarts. At least one, Tibco, is using the best ammo it has, boring old business data.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Dries Van Noten
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Looking Inside the Twinkie
text: The news that the food maker Hostess filed for bankruptcy protection has triggered a national discussion of its products, including Wonder bread, Ho Hos and that nostalgic lunchbox favorite, the Twinkie.

headline: The South Carolina Primary
text: Two candidates dropped out in South Carolina as the campaigns have gotten more aggressive in the Palmetto state.

headline: Parental Quandary: The Sex Offender Next Door
text: C. has a problem perhaps too serious to be called a quandary. A few months ago, she says, her family received a flier from the local sheriff. A registered sex offender was moving to her street of small, single-family homes. Hers is a long street, though, and she expected the offender to be some distance away and easily avoidable.

headline: First Ratings for ‘CBS This Morning’ Highlight Steep Challenges Ahead
text: 1:39 p.m. | Updated The ratings for the first week of “CBS This Morning,” which were released on Friday, gave CBS reasons for optimism — but they also reiterated the cliff-like, uphill climb that the network is facing.

headline: Four Years Ago, Romney’s Wealth Was Not an Issue
text: In 2008, Mitt Romney willingly — and publicly — tapped into his personal fortune to run for president, pumping nearly $45 million directly into his political campaign.

headline: The Caucus Click: Romney on the Farm
text: Mitt Romney visited Harmon Tree Farm with Gov. Nikki Haley in Gilbert, S.C., on Friday.

headline: Six Words at the Jaipur Lit Fest
text: Packed with writers, publishers, school kids and chief executives, the Jaipur Literature Festival can and has been described in many ways, from circus to the “front lines” of the fight against extremism.

headline: Pie Face Offers Australia to Go
text: Do you celebrate Australia Day, that country’s national holiday, coming up on Thursday? If not, this would be a good year to start. With a mess of Australian meat pies to go and some shiraz or Foster’s, you’re all set. And for those pies, there is a new source in New York: Pie Face, the first American outpost of a down-under takeout chain.

headline: Leslie Hawke and David Weiss
text: IN the 12 years since she left online publishing to do humanitarian work with disadvantaged children in Romania, Leslie Hawke has advised many younger women on matters of the heart.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: X-Men Take Over Top Spot
text: “X-Men: Schism” lands at No. 1 on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. When an international incident sends hatred of mutants into a new frenzy, Cyclops and Wolverine are divided in their response and cause a rift in the team. This collected edition contains the five issues of “Schism,” written by Jason Aaron with each issue illustrated by a different powerhouse artist (Carlos Pacheco, Frank Cho, Daniel Acuna, Alan Davis and Adam Kubert). It also includes the standalone special “X-Men: Regenesis,” written by Kieron Gillen and illustrated by Billy Tan, in which the other X-Men choose whether they will stand with Cyclops or Wolverine. The X-Men are synonymous with change, with the characters getting reshuffled into new teams every few years, so the fracture among the heroes may be temporary. (Particularly with a huge conflict with the Avengers coming right around the corner.)

headline: Overmisunderestimating Rick Perry
text: On Thursday night I happened to call a friend just before 10 p.m. and caught her a little tipsy — she had been out celebrating Rick Perry’s ignominious withdrawal from the presidential race.

headline: Runway in Review
text: Dries Van NotenDesigner: Dries Van NotenDate and Location: Thursday, Jan. 19, Grand Palais – Galerie Sud Est – porte H bis – av Churchill, 8Photos: slide show

headline: Coping With High-Priced Insurance That Lenders Make You Buy
text: FORCE-PLACED insurance. Most homeowners never hear about it until their mortgage lender sends them a letter saying that they must have flood or some other kind of insurance and that if they don’t act quickly, the lender will buy it for them — at a price, it turns out, that is almost always much higher than the market rate.

headline: Death Penalty Death Watch: The Mailroom Mix-Up
text: Today’s installment in my continuing series on the folly of America’s refusal to abandon the death penalty comes courtesy of an article by Adam Liptak in The Times. As Mr. Liptak reported, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that just because someone messed up in the mailroom, you don’t necessarily deserve capital punishment.

headline: City Auctions Stone Cow Heads and Other Relics
text: Heaps of rusted metal, moldering bathroom appliances and stone steers’ heads have found new homes.

headline: Madagascar Ex-Leader Plans to Return
text: JOHANNESBURG — The ousted former president of Madagascar plans to return to his country from exile here on a flight Saturday morning, he told a news conference here on Friday.

headline: In Washington, Mayor Bloomberg Makes His Case for Teacher Evaluations
text: Speaking in Washington at a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors Thursday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called on the teachers' union to stop blocking a new system of evaluations.

headline: Closing Peninsula Prep Leaves Inferior Options
text: A parent leader at Peninsula Preparatory Academy, which is slated to be closed, writes: '95 percent of Peninsula Prep's students find themselves being directed by the city Department of Education to zoned public schools that Peninsula Prep outperformed.'

headline: Photos of the Moment | Louis Vuitton
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Bicoastal Approach to Crab Salad
text: THERE are lots of crab-meat salads out there. Some are fine, but many tend to be rather indifferent mixtures of crabmeat and bottled mayonnaise.

headline: Scientists to Pause Research on Deadly Strain of Bird Flu
text: The scientists who altered a deadly flu virus to make it more contagious have agreed to suspend their research for 60 days to give other international experts time to discuss the work and determine how it can proceed without putting the world at risk of a potentially catastrophic pandemic.

headline: 538 | S.C. Primary Projections
text: January 20, 2012 - Just a day before the South Carolina primary, Nate Silver's latest projections show a shift in the lead.

headline: The Caregivers’ Bookshelf: An Alzheimer’s Classic
text: More than 30 years ago, when the psychiatrist Dr. Peter Rabins and the psychologist Nancy Mace began working with dementia patients and their families at Johns Hopkins Hospital, they had to write and mimeograph (younger readers: look it up) small pamphlets to explain to them what was going on and what was to come.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘Who’s On First?’ Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Reading the Fine Print on Apple’s Book-Making Software
text: Apple’s free book-creation tool, iBooks Author, seemed too good to be true: it gives anyone the ability to easily lay out an interactive book with no programming required, slap it up for sale in Apple’s iBooks Store and ideally make a quick buck. But hours after Apple released the software on Thursday, people noticed that they were not allowed to sell these books outside Apple’s store.

headline: Fast and Easy Omelet Meals
text: If you’re looking for a simple meal, the egg is a good place to start, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: A Versatile and Direct Voice: Etta James
text: Etta James has died at age 73.

headline: Many Evangelicals See Something to Admire in Candidates’ Broods
text: The Republican presidential field has produced a lot of babies. There is Mitt Romney, father of five sons. Ron Paul, an obstetrician by training, is also a father of five, and his campaign Web site credits him with bringing 4,000 babies into the world. Newt Gingrich and the recent dropout Rick Perry have only two children each, but Rick Santorum, who has said contraception is “not O.K.,” has seven children, and so does another former candidate, Jon M. Huntsman Jr.

headline: Just One Look | Valentino
text: There was a lot to get excited about at Valentino this morning. The accessories, for one, are stellar and studded: the season’s new loafer, pictured here, is stamped on top with a large gold pyramid stud; the combat boot, another favorite, is ruffled in the front; the brogues come in patent leather with spiky metal toe caps (similar to the ones we just saw at the men’s shows in Europe). Romantic, rose-embellished and decorated with bows and lace, the dresses and skirt looks are lovely and expertly tailored. Just what you expect from the Italian house — though it’s the suit story made of nipped silk satin tuxedos and soft, tie-neck blouses that caught this editor’s attention. Here, the rippling asymmetrical lapel on a blush-pink jacket flirts with Le Smoking without going all the way.

headline: For Gallinari, a Long-Awaited Return to New York
text: Danilo Gallinari is ready to come back to New York. It was Feb. 22 of last year when “il Gallo,” one of most popular players during Coach Mike D’Antoni’s tenure with the Knicks, was involved in the trade that brought Carmelo Anthony to New York.

headline: Landmarks on the Fringe
text: Wallabout is a two-block-wide semi-industrial neighborhood inland from the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Where History Meets Industry
text: SLOPING down from Myrtle Avenue to the walled fortress of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Industrial Park, and bisected by the rumbling equator of the elevated Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the two-block-wide semi-industrial neighborhood of Wallabout would seem to have some unenviable physical challenges. It lacks subways, and although it shares a name with nearby Wallabout Bay, its residents are cut off by the Navy Yard from the tantalizingly close waterfront.

headline: Obama Reaffirms Insurers Must Cover Contraception
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that most health insurance plans must cover contraceptives for women free of charge, and it rejected a broad exemption sought by the Roman Catholic Church for insurance provided to employees of Catholic hospitals, colleges and charities.

headline: Giants, Ravens, Patriots, 49ers (and the Jets): Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers questions from readers.

headline: Vending Machines May Not Cause Student Weight Gain, Study Says
text: Pulling the vending machines out of schools has long been something of a battle cry for parents concerned with childhood obesity. Many schools and districts rely on vendor contracts to finance extracurricular activities (in New York City, snacks sold in vending machines are limited in calories, fat and sugar content), while advocates worry that the omnipresent snacks will mean weight gain in students.

headline: Washington Post Managing Editor Leaves for The Journal
text: The Wall Street Journal has hired Raju Narisetti, a managing editor of The Washington Post, to become managing editor of its online news properties, Dow Jones, the parent company of the Journal, announced on Friday.

headline: Hungarian Leader Softens on Central Bank Merger
text: BRUSSELS — Hungary’s prime minister promised Friday to abandon plans to merge the nation’s central bank and its financial markets regulator, seeking to defuse criticism from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund over the country’s increasing centralization of power.

headline: A Marriage of Influences
text: Hisham Modine and Nadia Bishai live in a brownstone in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: His Style, Her Style, Their Style
text: THE brownstone at 127 St. James Place in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, boasted a lustrous pedigree. Its elderly owner, Adele Premice, was the daughter of Lucas Premice, a Haitian aristocrat who fled to the United States in the early 20th century. Her younger sister, the glamorous actress Josephine Premice, reigned for decades as the toast of Broadway.

headline: Russian Envoys Leave Canada After Officer Is Accused of Spying
text: OTTAWA — Four Russian diplomats have left Canada just days after a naval intelligence officer was charged with passing government secrets to a “foreign entity.”

headline: The Whole Fish, and Little but the Fish
text: A WHOLE roasted fish is the aquatic analogue to roast chicken.

headline: A Word From the ‘J. Edgar’ Contingent
text: In the undulating curve of expectations, hype and maneuvering that is Oscar season, “J. Edgar” has had a hard time catching on. Clint Eastwood’s biopic, starring Leonard DiCaprio as Hoover and Armie Hammer as his associate and paramour, Clyde Tolson, might wind up being the Jon Huntsman of the awards race: it had high expectations – the Bagger started hearing about it last Oscar season, when Mr. Hammer, then making the rounds for “The Social Network,” was cast – some glowing reviews and many of the right elements for prize glory, including a good back story.

headline: Will Standardized Tests Kill Reading?
text: Please click over to the SchoolBook blog to read a fantastic post from Anne Stone and Jeff Nichols about their unusual choice for a New Year’s Eve activity with friends: they took the third-grade English language arts practice test one of their children took home over vacation.

headline: Citadel Clears Its High Water Mark
text: Citadel, the hedge fund behemoth that experienced losses of more than 50 percent during the financial crisis, has finally recovered.

headline: A Steep Drop in Ratings for ‘American Idol’
text: 5:11 p.m. | Updated “American Idol” may have officially crossed over from phenomenon to mere hit television show on Thursday, as the second outing of this year’s edition fell a steep 27 percent in the ratings from its performance on the same night last year – and 44 percent from its number two years ago.

headline: Brent Bozell and Ghetto Crackheads
text: Whenever I write about the undertones (and sometimes overtones) of race in American politics, I get a lot of critical emails and Tweets, some reasonable, some pretty nasty.

headline: European Union Moves Closer to Imposing Tough Sanctions on Iran
text: PARIS — The European Union moved closer to imposing a phased oil embargo on Iran and some form of narrow sanctions against transactions with Iran’s central bank, European and French diplomats said on Friday.

headline: From Icy Waters, a Cold-Weather Pleasure
text: This time of year, after a few weeks of post-holiday deprivation and perhaps a little too much foul weather, a bit of decadence may seem in order, at least for one meal. Why not treat yourself and your table mates to the one of the cold season’s treats, and indulge in a fresh crabmeat salad? In this week’s City Kitchen, we’re making a deviled crab salad with slightly bitter chicory greens and a lemony, mustardy dressing, suitable for a fine first course or weekend lunch.

headline: The Dangerous Notion That Debt Doesn’t Matter
text: WITH little fanfare, a dangerous notion has taken hold in progressive policy circles: that the amount of money borrowed by the federal government from Americans to finance its mammoth deficits doesn’t matter.

headline: Christophe Bellanca Is Chef at L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon
text: Joel Robuchon has anounced the appointment of Christophe Bellanca as the new executive chef for L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon in the Four Seasons Hotel in New York.

headline: Laying the Beetle’s Foundation
text: Josef Ganz, a Jewish engineer, laid out the basics for the original VW Beetle before being forced from Germany.

headline: 2012 Volkswagen Beetle
text: Volkswagen has redesigned the Beetle, making is more masculine and even getting rid of the interior flower vase.

headline: The Caucus | A Political Army
text: The Citadel Military College is an imposing political symbol on its own, but it also has engaged students who are deciding among the candidates.

headline: Founder of Shuttered Web Site Sought Limelight
text: BERLIN — Some uninvited guests showed up at Kim Dotcom’s mansion outside Auckland, New Zealand, on Friday: the police, in two helicopters.

headline: Normally United, Citadel Cadets Differ on Republican Favorite
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — At the Citadel, cadets wear matching uniforms, march in lockstep and endure rigorous physical training together. But these days, the Republicans among them — and they are overwhelmingly Republican — are divided on a crucial issue: whom to support as the next commander in chief.

headline: Obama Says 2012 Choice Is Stark
text: It is a political truism: fear is a major motivator for voters. And President Obama wants supporters to know that whoever emerges from the blood bath of the Republican primaries, that presidential nominee will be much farther to the right than Mr. Obama’s 2008 opponent, Senator John McCain.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom 1948 colonial in Little Falls, N.J., and a six-bedroom fieldstone and wood home in Hartsdale, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An Upper West Side one-bedroom, a Fashion District loft and a Park Slope condo.

headline: Photo Replay: January 20
text: A look at the day in sports, from the tennis courts in Australia to a World Cup skeleton race in Switzerland.

headline: Fashion Silhouettes, Sharply Drawn
text: Last season, Rei Kawakubo used bridal lace in her men’s collection; this time, she went for old-time pink roses on gray suiting, sweet polka dots and boxy shorts or culottes with jackets that evoked the classic Chanel cardigan. And the shoes came with little heels and socks with boldly colored ribbing, while the models wore Joan Jett wigs, at times with a beribboned bowler hat. All these elements felt warmly and securely Comme des Garçons, but perhaps the most appealing thing about the show today was the silhouette: longish and free at the waist, with those full shorts (or knee-length skirts) and, naturally, hairy calves before the splash of pink at the ankles. One impulse was romantic — Jane Eyre, I thought — the other punk.

headline: Why Students Leave the Engineering Track
text: 1/21/12 | Updated to correct Professor Babcock’s academic affiliation.Amid broader discussions about the future of the American work force, the National Science Foundation has just released a comprehensive report on the state of engineering and science in America. There’s a lot of meat in the report, but I found this chart to be particularly striking:

headline: Debates Aren’t to Blame for Perry’s Failure
text: Nineteen times this political season, the Republican candidates for president have stood shoulder to shoulder on a stage, regardless of how much money they had raised or how many endorsements they had won, and passionately laid out for the voters the ideas and qualifications that they believe make them the best choice for the nation’s highest office.

headline: Chic in Review | Carey Mulligan Double-Dipped a Dress
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Auction Winners Pay It Forward in Arizona
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Charitable organizations that assist wounded American veterans received unexpectedly large windfalls Thursday at the Barrett-Jackson classic car auctions here, with help from the prominent motorsports figures Roger Penske and Mario Andretti.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: With Athleticism and a Deft Touch, Egyptians Put Their Mark on Squash
text: Egyptians are having a moment, though it is nothing political. It involves a rectangular walled squash court rather than an outdoor square, and an offensive shotmaking style that is more beguiling than combative.

headline: Two Art Fans Complete the Circuit of Hirst Spot Shows
text: A blogger and a magazine editor are the first two adventurers to complete Damien Hirst’s wacky spot challenge.

headline: Union Leader at Murry Bergtraum Asks Teachers: Tell Us How You Really Feel
text: Responding to an informal survey conducted by a teacher who is the union chapter leader, about half the staff members at a Lower Manhattan high school  indicated concerns about school safety and the integrity of the school's academics.

headline: Interior Candidate Bows Out
text: President Obama will not renominate his chosen candidate for assistant secretary of interior for parks and wildlife, who ran into a firm wall of Republican opposition in the Senate.

headline: Nominating Fight Wears on Romney’s Favorability Ratings
text: This chart from Talking Points Memo shows what seems to be a reasonably sharp rise in Mitt Romney’s unfavorable ratings among the broader electorate, much of which seems to have come since we last checked in on the issue just a week ago.

headline: Somali and African Troops Hit Rebel Posts in Mogadishu
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Government and African Union forces began a heavy offensive early on Friday against insurgent strongholds on the outskirts of the capital, Mogadishu, trying to drive the Islamic militants they have long battled out of the city, officials and witnesses said.

headline: Fields Less Comfortable Amid Knicks’ Changes
text: Last season, Landry Fields took New York by storm, winning over Knicks fans almost instantly in his rookie year. He seemed to fit perfectly into the team’s lineup, serving as a defensive cog in a first unit that was otherwise filled with offensive firepower.

headline: Looking for Signs of Crime in Megaupload’s Memos
text: For those who follow copyright issues, cases of infringement are usually fought with civil lawsuits. Yet the operators behind the site Megaupload have been charged with criminal offenses, and four of them are being held without bail in New Zealand. What is different about Megaupload, and why have the authorities cracked down so hard on it?

headline: Rick Santorum and the Three Bears
text: LEXINGTON, S.C. – Rick Santorum has started using an unfortunate new metaphor to describe his position among the remaining candidates: Goldilocks and the three bears.

headline: Indian Authors Protest Threats to Rushdie by Reading From His ‘Satanic Verses’
text: As my colleagues Vikas Bajaj and Sruthi Gottipati report, the Indian-born author Salman Rushdie canceled a planned appearance at a literary festival in India on Friday, citing recent death threats.

headline: Honda NC700X Set for U.S. Sales
text: Honda kicked off the 2012 New York motorcycle show early, revealing a new model on Thursday night intended for the American market. The NC700X was first introduced at the EICMA industry show in Milan in November, but was described then as a Europe-only model.

headline: Under the VW Big Top, Even the Sky Isn’t the Limit
text: TESTED 2012 Volkswagen Eos Lux

headline: In Beetle’s Creation Story, a Plot Twist
text: THE tale is intriguing: a Jewish engineer and journalist, whose designs and published work in the 1930s laid out the basics for the Volkswagen Beetle championed by Hitler, was arrested, chased from Germany and nearly airbrushed out of history.

headline: To Be Cute as a Bug Isn’t Enough Anymore
text: THE New Beetle is dead. Long live the all-new Beetle, as Volkswagen calls the successor, squeezing together the adjectives just as it has squashed down the roof.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Ben Jonson, In and Out of Shakespeare’s Shadow
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Charles Isherwood reviews Ian Donaldson’s “Ben Jonson: A Life.” Jonson, a playwright and “Britain’s first literary celebrity,” was a contemporary of Shakespeare. In his book, Mr. Donaldson makes the case that Jonson was as central as Shakespeare to the development of the British theater. Though he was posthumously eclipsed by his fellow writer, Jonson was the more noticeable of the two while they lived. Mr. Isherwood writes:

headline: One on One: Jimmy Wales of Wikipedia
text: Wikipedia has been a household name for years. But when the site announced that it would black out its English-language site earlier this week in support of a Webwide protest against two antipiracy bills, it became a hot topic of conversation.

headline: A Beguiling Electric Diversion
text: History suggests that the latest edition of the Beetle, like its predecessors, will spawn myriad variations. At the Detroit auto show this month, VW introduced the E-Bugster, a design study for an all-electric version.

headline: JPMorgan Hires Credit Suisse’s Granetz to Lead Finance Initiative
text: JPMorgan Chase has hired Marc Granetz, until last month a senior banking executive at Credit Suisse, to spearhead an internal push to improve the firm’s own financial strength and strategy, the bank announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

headline: An Often-Painful Lesson in Insurance
text: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about force-placed insurance — something that most homeowners don’t know about until their mortgage lender sends them a letter telling them they need it. If the homeowners don’t act quickly, the lender will buy the insurance for them, almost always at a price that’s a lot higher than the market rate.

headline: Pistons to Daye: Please Don’t Take the Ball to the Basket
text: The Detroit Pistons have one of the worst offenses in the N.B.A. The ball never seems to get to the players it should, the shots seem to go up before a quality opening is actually created and the team as a whole stumbles into an alarming number of miscues. It’s no trick of scheduling that lost Detroit 12 of its first 15 games, as the inability to score in any kind of efficient or consistent manner has been a big problem – and sadly, a big problem among many – for the Pistons thus far.

headline: Fish Without the Fear
text: In this week’s column, I roast a whole fish. If it sounds familiar it’s because we posted a video of the process last winter. Here it is again, and it may help flesh out the recipe if you have any questions about the techniques.

headline: Olympus Is Given Fine but Avoids Delisting
text: TOKYO — The Tokyo Stock Exchange said Friday that it would allow Olympus, the Japanese camera maker that has admitted hiding $1.7 billion in losses, to remain listed after paying a small fine for its false accounting.

headline: Another Independent Dream Comes True
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Melanie Lynskey has playing wacky down cold. She’s done it for years on “Two and a Half Men” as Rose, the off-kilter neighbor. And she shines in dramatic parts, as when she played Matt Damon’s wife in “The Informant!”

headline: A Painful Farewell to Saab’s Heritage
text: More than 100 Saabs, from the streamlined 1947 prototype known as the Ursaab to a 2010 9-5 sedan, are to be taken from their home at the company’s museum in Trollhattan, Sweden, and sold to the highest bidder.

headline: Sharing Where Speed Traps Lie
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: Michael Anthony Returns to Gramercy Tavern After Surgery
text: Michael Anthony, chef and partner at Gramercy Tavern, returned to the kitchen last week after recovering from surgery to repair a tear in his aorta, Papermag reports. Mr. Anthony, 44, had surgery in the fall for a rare condition.

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 20
text: Subjects include a billboard collapse onto the B.Q.E., a beagle with a nose for illegal produce, and master watch restorer.

headline: David Helfand’s New Quest
text: AFTER 35 years at Columbia University, where he was chairman of the astronomy department and co-director of the Astrophysics Laboratory, David J. Helfand is on leave to serve as president of Quest University Canada, a tiny liberal arts college in British Columbia that graduated its first class last spring. It is Canada’s only private, secular nonprofit university.

headline: E-Testing: The Future Is Here
text: IT’S midterms, but instead of taking the test during class with a No. 2 pencil, you sign up for 7 p.m. Thursday (your biorhythmic high) and march over to the e-test center on campus. And instead of all multiple choice, there’s a video-based question, and diagrams with drag-and-drop labels.

headline: The World’s Most Difficult Quiz
text: THE General Knowledge Paper has stumped pupils at King William’s College for over a century. Upper-level students would sit for the test on the last school day before Christmas. Over the next month they would pore over reference books and retake the test in January.

headline: General Studies Moves to the Mainstream
text: ALISSA MORRONE had hoped to attend Johns Hopkins, perhaps Carnegie Mellon. But both returned thin envelopes. What she thought was a safety school, Boston University, sent similarly defeating news. Its College of Arts and Sciences rejected her, but the envelope was not thin. The College of General Studies, the letter promised, had a place for her.

headline: One Percent Education
text: IT has been a populist winter. As Occupy Wall Street needles America’s financial sector over the country’s economic imbalance, it also focuses attention on another issue that helps feed that imbalance: educational inequality.

headline: A Bridge to Recovery on Campus
text: IN their undergrad uniforms of fleece and sweats, a clutch of Rutgers students gathered on the worn red couches of their dorm’s common room and told their stories. A good-looking, fun-loving 23-year-old named Greg described arriving at college freshman year with a daily pot-smoking habit and a close relationship with alcohol. He soon followed the lead of his alcoholic father and was binge drinking (five drinks or more in a row). “It was pretty scary,” he said.

headline: For Math, Click Calculate
text: THE banner hanging above the speaker at a TED conference on math instruction seemed to sum up the prevailing thinking: “Stop teaching calculating. Start teaching math.”

headline: Bottom Lines
text: THE big sto­ry con­cern­ing early ad­mis­sions pro­grams this past fall was the re-en­try of Har­vard and Prince­ton into the fray. Af­ter de­cid­ing four years ago to no long­er of­fer ap­pli­cants an early op­tion, both de­cid­ed to re­in­state sin­gle-choice early ac­tion pro­grams be­gin­ning with the class of 2016.

headline: The Debate X Factor
text: HOW does a tiny regional college in Danville, Ky., with just over 1,300 students attract 29 million TV viewers? Host a debate.

headline: Renaissance Man
text: AFTER midnight, when most college students are cavorting or cramming, Jeremy Gleick is just settling into his “learning hour.” He occasionally curses when the hour looms so late, but he still does it.

headline: Blogs vs. Term Papers
text: OF all the challenges faced by college and high school students, few inspire as much angst, profanity, procrastination and caffeine consumption as the academic paper. The format — meant to force students to make a point, explain it, defend it, repeat it (whether in 20 pages or 5 paragraphs) — feels to many like an exercise in rigidity and boredom, like practicing piano scales in a minor key.

headline: A Nurse Need Never Forget
text: THESE days, when a nursing student at the University of Iowa fields a question about a drug, “the answer is often, ‘I don’t know, but give me a few seconds,’ and she pulls out her phone,” according to Joann Eland, an associate professor there.

headline: How Big-Time Sports Ate College Life
text: IT was a great day to be a Buckeye. Josh Samuels, a junior from Cincinnati, dates his decision to attend Ohio State to Nov. 10, 2007, and the chill he felt when the band took the field during a football game against Illinois. “I looked over at my brother and I said, ‘I’m going here. There is nowhere else I’d rather be.’ ” (Even though Illinois won, 28-21.)

headline: Stress Survival Guide
text: Student photographers snap their classmates for The Times. This issue: how students relax during exam time.

headline: Citing Security Fears, Rushdie Won’t Attend Literary Festival
text: JAIPUR, India — In the latest setback for free speech in India, Salman Rushdie, the author who has survived a 23-year-old Iranian fatwa calling for his death, backed out of attending a literature festival in his native country because of a new assassination threat against him.

headline: The Dawn of Lower Pay on Wall St.
text: The day of reckoning may be at hand.

headline: George Washington Was A Hypocrite
text: OK, that’s not what I believe. But it’s apparently what Scott Brown believes.

headline: General Studies: Nuts and Bolts
text: General studies takes various shapes. But many programs are aimed at students who are not accepted elsewhere in the university and referred by admissions. If in good standing on completion, they can transition into the larger university.

headline: Interactive Graphic: Tracking Independent Spending
text: Since the start of the presidential campaign, independent groups have spent at least $29.5 million asking voters to elect or defeat candidates through television advertisements and other means. The most active groups have been “super PACs,” which can raise unlimited money from individuals, corporations and labor unions. Although these groups cannot legally be tied to a candidate, several of the most-active ones are run or advised by former associates or campaign staff. Track the spending of each of these independent groups here.

headline: In Fire Investigation, Regulators Say They Found No Defect in Volt
text: DETROIT — Federal safety regulators on Friday closed their investigation into the Chevrolet Volt, saying that they found no evidence of a defect and that plug-in vehicles posed no greater fire risk after a crash than gasoline-powered ones. Still, analysts say that General Motors faces a challenge to rebuild consumer confidence in the car and that related safety concerns could hurt overall acceptance of the growing number of electrified vehicles coming on the market.

headline: Is Bridal Fashion Taking a New Turn?
text: Unwritten rules that have long hemmed in the traditional bride have been jettisoned in favor of statement-making fashion-forward choices.

headline: Wear a Denim Bridal Gown? Not Yet, but ...
text: SHOPPING for a gown, one of the first to-do’s on any bride’s checklist, is about as unfettered and do-as-you-please as it has ever been. Unwritten rules that have long hemmed in the traditional bride (like wearing white, unless it’s a second wedding) have been jettisoned in favor of statement-making fashion-forward choices that better express a bride’s true personality and tastes, industry experts say.

headline: A Dancer Who Can Remember The Giants
text: IF Wendy Whelan were a Hollywood star, glossy profiles about her would forever be opening with vignettes underlining how remarkably down to earth and likable she is.

headline: Union Goes Up With Anti-Romney Ad in Florida
text: The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the giant public employees’ union, will begin airing a 30-second video ad in Florida on Saturday attacking Mitt Romney for making what it said was a $473,000 profit from his firm’s investments in a medical company that admitted engaging in Medicare fraud.

headline: Time Travel at the Met, Thanks to CDs
text: For insatiable opera buffs, there can never be too much of a good thing. These consumers are certainly in the sights of Sony Classical and the Metropolitan Opera, who are collaborating on a project to release no-frills, remastered recordings of historic live Saturday afternoon broadcasts from the Met.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 20
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Bahrain, Virginia and South Carolina.

headline: Friday Night Music: Enya Meets The Queen Of The Night
text: Or that’s what it sounds like to me!

headline: Entering Weegee’s World
text: Our colleagues downstairs at the Lens blog have a great post today about the current exhibit of Weegee’s photographs at the International Center of Photography.

headline: Bill Cunningham | World Unite
text: The fashion and design worlds are looking back to the Renaissance and the Victorian era for guidance on discovering a new aesthetic for today.

headline: A Frightening Drug Resurfaces
text: The police found five additional gallons of liquid PCP in an East Harlem housing project that was raided this week, with officials calling it a dug-in hub for a drug thought to be an obsolete relic.

headline: On Foreign Policy, Romney Breaks With Advisers
text: In October, Mitt Romney announced a roster of national security advisers that lent his campaign instant gravitas. Studded with heavyweight names, many from the Bush administration, the list suggested that Mr. Romney was the clear choice of the Republican foreign-policy establishment.

headline: A Believer Packing Beer and Guitars
text: CRAIG FINN has always been a religious guy. He sees God as just but also notices that he has a wicked sense of humor. The barflies, losers and knock-around guys that he writes about in the songs for his band, the Hold Steady, often end up on their knees, sometimes retching, but more often praying for that moment when everything both aligns and goes off the rails at the same time. It’s a moment of clarity, often seen through beer goggles: “Went down with a tallboy can and he woke up in a cargo van,” he sings on “Barfruit Blues” from the band’s 2004 debut album, “Almost Killed Me.”

headline: Obama Vow on Exports Is on Track, With Help
text: WASHINGTON — Two years ago, President Obama popped a surprise into his State of the Union address: His administration would double American exports in five years, helping to create two million jobs.

headline: Britain Revokes Iranian TV Network’s License
text: LONDON — Britain’s media regulator revoked the broadcast license for the Iranian state-owned television network Press TV on Friday, saying the network had failed to address concerns over its editorial independence and had not paid a fine.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Bahrain, Syria and Israel.

headline: In the Arts, a Fleeting Freedom
text: Over the last couple of decades, musicians have been reconstructing the legacy of composers who spent World War II in Terezin (also known by its German name, Theresienstadt), a garrison city near Prague that the Nazis turned into a concentration camp. About 140,000 Jews were sent there, starting in 1941, including an unusually large number of musicians, writers and painters.

headline: A Yippie on Familiar Turf, Both in New York and in Jail
text: A jail stint and a heart attack have done nothing to temper the spirit of Dana Beal, who still has his bushy, General Custer-style mustache, his thick head of gray hair, and the activist streak that has defined his nearly half-century of marijuana activism and radical politics.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cellphone Stacking and the Next SOPA
text: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: Android Is No. 1, But Google Says It Still Makes Little Money
text: In just three years, Android has become the king of mobile operating systems. But it’s only now starting to make money for Google, says Larry Page, Google’s chief executive.

headline: How Redistricting Plans Differ
text: An example of how the new Congressional district plan drawn by the Texas State Legislature differs from the one drawn by a special three-judge federal court.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Stylish New Storybook App for Kids
text: Moonbot Studios, the developer of one of my top 10 iPad apps of 2011, The Fantastic Flying Books of Morris Lessmore, this week released a new book app, “The Numberlys” ($6).

headline: A Program for Singers Shows Them the Way to Carnegie Hall
text: “I’m still here,” an ebullient Marilyn Horne crooned to a delighted audience at Zankel Hall on Thursday night, invoking the classic Stephen Sondheim song. On one level this great mezzo-soprano was referring to herself, having come through extensive treatments for cancer in recent years. But her words also applied to the Marilyn Horne Foundation, which has provided support to young singers and fostered the art of the song recital.

headline: Jan. 22 — 28
text: Theater

headline: Gingrich Gains on Romney in Final South Carolina Polls
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The latest survey of likely voters in Saturday’s Republican primary suggests that Mitt Romney has lost the advantage he once held.

headline: Disdainful of Strategists, Gingrich Acts as His Own
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — If Newt Gingrich soars on his strong debate performances this week, overcomes the blowback within his party from attacking Mitt Romney as a corporate buyout king, and goes on to do well when South Carolina voters go to the polls on Saturday, one political strategist will get both blame for the stumbles and credit for successes: Mr. Gingrich himself.

headline: Reviewing the Volkswagen Beetle
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Phil Patton reviews the 2012 Volkswagen Beetle, the German automaker’s sleeker, sportier and, above all, more masculine bug.

headline: Tulum, Mexico, Is a Hot Spot for Fashion Insiders
text: Tulum has become a destination so popular with the fashion crowd this time of year, it almost feels like Fashion Week.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 20
text: More Photographs

headline: G+ Hangout | South Carolina Primary
text: Michael Shear and Paul Volpe of the New York Times Politics desk talk with readers on the eve of the South Carolina primary.

headline: Milan Gets a New Star Recruit
text: MILAN

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 20
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a billboard collapse onto the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, a beagle with a nose for illegal produce, and a master watch restorer.

headline: Neutral Milk Hotel’s Frontman Does Most of the Work Himself, Including Horns
text: Sex, devastation, war, death, God, reincarnation and “how strange it is to be anything at all” were some of the things Jeff Mangum sang about on “In the Aeroplane Over the Sea,” the second album by his band Neutral Milk Hotel, released in 1998. Then he made himself scarce, rarely performing in public until 2010.

headline: New in Your Wireless Store: The Cable Guy
text: Customers walking into a Verizon Wireless store in Portland, Ore., or Seattle this week may notice something unusual: cable salesmen.

headline: Olympic Qualifying: U.S. Women vs. Dominican Republic
text: 2:37 a.m. | Final Score: U.S. 14, Dominican Republic 0 The United States women’s national team opened the Concacaf Olympic qualifying tournament by thrashing the Dominican Republic, 14-0, on Friday night in Vancouver, but the joy of a record-setting night was tempered by what was described as a “serious” knee injury sustained by defender Ali Krieger.

headline: Long Nap Didn’t Improve Her Mood All That Much
text: Milla Jovovich may have the zombie post-apocalypse covered with the “Resident Evil” series (guided by her husband, Paul W. S. Anderson). But in vampire-werewolf warfare, Kate Beckinsale rules, with the “Underworld” movies (guided by her husband, Len Wiseman). No wan, moony “Twilights” these: we’re talking more than a thousand years of battle between Lycans (werewolves) and vampires, recounted in three installments before the latest, “Underworld: Awakening.” (“Underworld” scholars, see Chapter 3, “Rise of the Lycans,” for some origin details.)

headline: Lighting the Shadows Behind the Queen and Her Consort
text: “Prince Philip: The Turbulent Early Life of the Man Who Married Queen Elizabeth II.” By Philip Eade. 368 pages. Henry Holt. $28.

headline: Digital Notes: Blogger Rejects Subpoena in Grooveshark Case
text: Blog Responds in Grooveshark Case: Digital Music News, an industry blog that has found itself in the middle of a copyright infringement suit against the streaming service Grooveshark, has responded to a subpoena it received in the case. A pair of anonymous comments on the blog, purportedly written by Grooveshark employees, have become central pieces of evidence in the major record labels’ case against the service, and last weekend Grooveshark served Digital Music News with a subpoena for information about those comments. Paul Resnikoff, the blog’s publisher, explained in a detailed post on Friday addressed to Grooveshark’s lawyers why he would not comply with the subpoena. He noted that to protect the identity of anonymous commenters, the site “flushes” relevant data after 24 hours and that he is entitled to the protection of state shield laws for journalists. He wrote:

headline: Roots of a Problem
text: My boyfriend’s mother, who is in excellent health and has a full head of hair, has taken to wearing wigs. She photographs herself in them and texts the pictures to us. My strategy has been to ignore the photos and hope the wigs go away. My boyfriend responds by saying how much better she looks with her own hair. Should we come right out and tell her we don’t like the wigs?

headline: Good-Humored Maturity When Life Proves Tough
text: Last month LaChanze, the winsome Broadway star who won a 2006 Tony Award for best performance by a leading actress in a musical (“The Color Purple”), turned 50. That milestone wouldn’t be worth noting had she not announced it on Thursday night at the Allen Room, where she appeared as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series. Her concert was also a 10th anniversary; she last visited the series in 2002 at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse.

headline: Cracking Teenagers’ Online Codes
text: WITH her coordinated zebra-striped scarf, tights and arm warmers (arm warmers?), spiky out-to-there hat and pierced tongue, 34-year-old Danah Boyd provides an electric Gen Y contrast to the staid gray lobby of Microsoft Research in Cambridge, Mass., which she enters in a flurry of animated conversation, Elmo-decorated iPhone in hand. In a juxtaposition that causes her no end of mischievous delight, her laptop bears a sticker of Snow White, whose outstretched arm gently cradled the Apple logo.

headline: Central Bank Becomes an Unlikely Hero in Euro Crisis
text: BERLIN — Throughout the month, countries caught in the eye of the European financial storm, including Italy, Spain and France, have repeatedly defied expectations, selling big batches of bonds to the public at interest rates significantly lower than investors demanded at the height of the euro crisis late last year.

headline: In a Chair’s Curves, a Past Reclaimed
text: MANY great talents started young, charging forward right out of the gate.

headline: New York City Ballet
text: Performances of the Paul McCartney-Peter Martins vehicle, “Ocean’s Kingdom,” and two other ballets at Lincoln Center.

headline: Chinese Poets, Public Enemies
text: It’s a heady thought — if a bit preposterous — that a few lines of verse might undermine a government. But poetry, it is now clear, can be tantamount to treason in China, just as it was in Czechoslovakia (Václav Havel), the Soviet Union (Joseph Brodsky and many others) and other authoritarian regimes of yesteryear.

headline: Social Satire as a Sustainable Career Move
text: ON a walk down Main Street in Santa Monica with David Wittman, everything suddenly looks like a kooky California cliché. The young women in Lululemon pants prancing into the raw-foods cafe. The guy with the “Ask me about my divorce” T-shirt. The “coexist” bumper sticker on the back of a Prius.

headline: Investment Firm Y Combinator Goes on Offensive Against Hollywood
text: After the Stop Online Piracy Act and Protect Intellectual Property Act were shelved on Friday, some Web sites and venture capitalists went on the offensive against the people and companies behind the controversial piracy bills.

headline: Diving Into Sea, and Then Gershwin
text: Some stories get better with age. In ballet, when the timelessness of a great fairy tale meets the ephemeral nature of dance, you end up with a “Swan Lake," a work that never loses its ability to enchant.

headline: The 2012 International Motorcycle Show
text: An up-close look at the bikes featured in the industry’s annual expo in New York City.

headline: Gingrich, Riding High, Dismisses Romney’s Call to Release Ethics File
text: ORANGEBURG, S.C. — It was a day when not much could go wrong for Newt Gingrich.

headline: 2 Families Face a Gust of Fortune
text: Gerald and Kitten Dowden have a name for the blessing that’s changed their lives and that of their family: “mailbox money.” Not long ago they found that their Shreveport, La., home sits atop a natural-gas well, and now they receive six-figure checks for the hard work of staying put.

headline: Air Kisses, Spike Heels and Ample Rubato
text: It was like something out of a fever dream: Donald Trump air-kissing both of Julie Andrews’s cheeks on the stage of Carnegie Hall, just a few feet from the piano Vladimir Horowitz played for more than 40 years.

headline: Everything Went ‘Whoosh’ and a Friend, Lighting PCP, Died
text: The last hour of Hilda Santiago’s life began in a pew at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul in East Harlem. An odd place to find someone on her way to buy drugs, but there she was last Sunday, between Masses, with her friend and partner in crime, Krystle Ortiz. They made this trip often from their apartments in the Bronx: the No. 4 train downtown to the No. 6 train, then to church, then to 1780 Madison Avenue to “cop some dust,” as they called buying PCP.

headline: Clouding Together for a Storm, and Shedding Light on Immigration Stories
text: Last year’s inaugural FLICfest (Feature-Length Independent Choreography), a festival of dance created by Jeramy Zimmerman in partnership with the Irondale Center in Brooklyn, generated a lot of goodwill buzz for its mission of supporting evening-length work.

headline: For South Carolinians, No Escape From the Messages
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Darlene Kleckley was at home recovering from knee surgery one recent afternoon when she heard the phone ring. It does that a lot these days.

text: Paris

headline: A ‘Porgy’ for Theatergoers, Not for Fans of the Opera
text: The new production of “Porgy and Bess” that opened recently on Broadway — now crassly, not to mention inaccurately, branded “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” — has become perhaps the most controversial musical revival in recent memory. It has been interesting to note how people are reacting to the show in different ways according to their familiarity with the score, and more particularly their history (or not) of hearing it in the opera house, where it has been performed most regularly since its Broadway debut in 1935. Despite l’affaire Sondheim, many people seem to enjoy it.

headline: A Nobel Laureate’s Problem at Home
text: Monrovia, Liberia

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: A Web uprising over Congressional efforts to halt online piracy — followed closely by the closing of a popular Web site on charges of copyright infringement — and a bankruptcy filing by Eastman Kodak were among the top business stories of the week.

headline: With Hours to Decide, Few Are Willing to Commit
text: BELTON, S.C. — Heidi Trull does not usually allow customers to talk politics or religion at Grits and Groceries, her restaurant here in the farmland that defines the northwest corner of the state.

headline: Audience Has Its Say in the Controversy
text: The New York Times theater critic Charles Isherwood’s essay on “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” follows an online discussion between the Times chief theater critic Ben Brantley and the Times chief classical music critic Anthony Tommasini about the production, which is scaled back and has eliminated parts of the score. Following are edited responses from readers:

text: Paris

headline: Romney Turns His Attention Away From Gingrich and Toward Obama
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Hitting the campaign trail on Friday, the day before South Carolina voters head to the polls in the Republican primary, Mitt Romney turned his focus away from Newt Gingrich.

text: Paris

headline: Playing Well and Being Lucky at District 3 Winter Regional
text: Friday the 13th is supposed to be unlucky. This month it wasn’t for R. Jay Becker and Brian Glubok of New York City, who won the two-session Open Pairs that day at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y.

headline: The Gingrich Question: Cheating vs. Open Marriage
text: If more couples considered monogamy optional, would divorce and cheating be less common, and unmarried cohabitation less attractive?

headline: Developing Arm Strength Feet First
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — One day last week, a visitor walking by the weight room at the Giants’ practice facility could look through the glass windows and see Eli Manning, in a gray T-shirt, slowly and deliberately doing bicep curls with medium-sized dumbbells. Half a room away, offensive lineman Chris Snee was also lifting weights — with a barbell that looked to be sagging from all the pounds plated at each end.

headline: Violin Masters on Parade
text: VIOLINISTS are hardly an unknown quantity on the Westchester County concert stage. But over the next month, three leading practitioners of the instrument will turn the Purchase College Performing Arts Center into a veritable violin mecca, presenting the music of Brahms, Bach and the Bard of Avon in concerts of varying scale, style and temperament.

headline: Gingrich Gets a Boost on Intrade
text: Newt Gingrich’s presidential candidacy is on the upswing in South Carolina, if Intrade, a popular online market for political bets, is any indication.

headline: Weegee’s Killer Decade
text: Steps away from the sanitized, commercialized and pacified Times Square is a portal to a sinister urban past, where two-bit hoods lay sprawled in pools of blood with stogies clenched in their lifeless jaws, watched over by the police and the curious alike. It’s a world of men with guns and hats who played their final hands under elevated tracks and tenements that have long since vanished.

headline: Bad Year for Wall St. Not Reflected in Chiefs’ Pay
text: Wall Street stocks and profits took a beating in 2011. But there is one corner of the Street that took a lighter hit: the compensation paid to chief executives.

headline: West Coast Brew Gave Kezar Stadium Its Color
text: SAN FRANCISCO — N.F.L. Hall of Famers called it home. It was where the alley-oop was invented. The 49ers’ founding owner died in his seat at the 50-yard line while watching a game. And it was there, atop a midfield hash mark, where Dirty Harry shot a serial killer called Scorpio.

headline: A Brazilian Magnate Points to Himself for Inspiration
text: RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: Prison Death Brings Outcry Against Cuba
text: MEXICO CITY — Human rights advocates and American officials condemned the Cuban government on Friday for continuing to limit political freedom, reacting to the death of an imprisoned Cuban dissident who had carried out a hunger strike to protest his sentence.

headline: From Patti Smith, Images Romantic and Morbid
text: Patti Smith entered the world of famous people in 1975 with her album “Horses,” which combined punk and classic ’60s rock with elements of Van Morrison and Bob Dylan’s folk agitation. But Ms. Smith has always been more than a musician. In the late ’60s and ’70s, living in New York, she wrote poetry, music criticism for Rolling Stone and Creem, and a play with her onetime partner Sam Shepard. Her memoir, “Just Kids,” about her relationship with the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, won the 2010 National Book Award. And last year she marked another celebrity rite of passage with a television acting debut on “Law & Order: Criminal Intent.”

headline: Dolphins Hire Packers Coordinator as Head Coach
text: The Miami Dolphins, who last year tried to woo Jim Harbaugh while still employing Tony Sparano, and who were rebuffed by Jeff Fisher last week, finally abandoned their quest for a big name and chose Joe Philbin as their new coach on Friday.

headline: The Caucus: Republican Candidates at the Citadel
text: Over on The Caucus, Ben Werschkul follows the Republican candidates to the Citadel, the military college of South Carolina. Candidates and presidents alike have long used the Citadel as a backdrop for foreign policy speeches.

headline: Kansas Law on Sodomy Stays on Books Despite a Cull
text: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — Gov. Sam Brownback created the Office of the Repealer to recommend the elimination of out-of-date, unreasonable and burdensome state laws that build up in any bureaucracy over time.

headline: Amish Man Held in Beard Attacks Seeks Bail Deal
text: Samuel Mullet Sr., the renegade Amish leader being held in Ohio in connection with beard-cutting attacks on Amish rivals, made a new request for bail on Thursday, telling a federal judge that he would allow electricity inside his home to permit electronic monitoring. But federal prosecutors replied on Friday that Mr. Mullet posed a danger to the community and that the Amish aversion to electricity had not figured in the decision to keep him in custody until his trial, which is now scheduled for March.

headline: Opening Newt’s Marriage
text: Right now, you are probably asking yourself whether two divorces, a history of adultery and an ex-wife who says you asked for an open marriage would be enough to disqualify a person from becoming president of the United States.

headline: Who Else Is Paying Your Doctor?
text: It took longer than expected, but the Obama administration is finally poised to enact badly needed regulations requiring that the manufacturers of drugs, medical devices and medical supplies disclose all payments they make to doctors or teaching hospitals. The information, which would be posted on a government Web site, will allow patients to decide whether they need to worry about any possible conflicts of interest.

headline: Sobering Report Describes Trends in Deaths of Abused and Neglected Children
text: The child who came to be known as Case No. 95-2011-00009 was the fourth born into a home where abuse and neglect were practically a family tradition.

headline: Richard M. Ketchum Dies at 89; Chronicled the Rural Life
text: Richard M. Ketchum, an author and editor who co-founded Country Journal, a magazine that offered a blend of the bucolic and the practical, particularly to city folk who had opted for the rural life, died on Jan. 12 at a retirement home in Shelburne, Vt. He was 89 and until four years ago had lived on his nearly 1,000-acre farm, Saddleback, in Dorset, Vt.

headline: Gingrich Is Victim of False Smear Campaign
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Newt Gingrich was the subject of an ugly and false smear campaign on Friday, the day before South Carolina Republican voters were set to go to the polls.

headline: Yankees and Gardner Agree to Contract
text: The Yankees avoided arbitration with outfielder Brett Gardner by agreeing to a one-year contract worth $2.8 million in Gardner’s first year of arbitration eligibility.

headline: China Leader Warns Iran Not to Make Nuclear Arms
text: BEIJING — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao wrapped up a six-day Middle East tour this week with stronger-than-usual criticism of Iran’s defiance on its nuclear program, and with multibillion-dollar oil deals that would seem to signal less reliance on Tehran for China’s growing energy needs.

headline: 49ers Reclaim a Famous Fan
text: Having given up watching football about five years ago because it had grown too violent and far less interesting than baseball and soccer, sports he finds much more poetic, Lawrence Ferlinghetti stumbled into watching the second half of the 49ers’ victory over the Saints last weekend.

headline: Sticky Stickers, Cleaner Streets
text: When it comes to the question of cleaner streets or cleaner windows on cars parked illegally on those streets, the New York City Council has now sided with the vehicles and their owners.

headline: Teen Spirit, With ’80s Hair
text: Photography may be a technological medium, but photographs themselves differ from most products of technology in one significant way: Rather than becoming obsolete, they often get better, or at least more interesting, with age. An example of this can be seen in “Coming of Age in America: The Photography of Joseph Szabo” at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

headline: Once Schooled by Him, Santorum Moves to Give Gingrich Lessons
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Late in Thursday night’s debate, Newt Gingrich yielded his time to Rick Santorum to address whether Mitt Romney genuinely opposed abortion rights.

headline: Guilty Until Proved Innocent
text: In America, a person is presumed innocent until proved guilty. Unless, that is, he plays college sports.

headline: Redistricting in Texas
text: In a closely watched case about a redistricting battle in Texas, the Supreme Court on Friday issued a per curiam opinion that added a further twist in a rushed and messy controversy. In the unanimous ruling, the Supreme Court told a three-judge district court in San Antonio to put aside redistricting plans it created and devise new maps based on those made by the Texas Legislature. And this time, the Supreme Court said, the district court must do a better job of explaining any maps it draws.

headline: At an Unexpected Reunion, Revisiting a Shared Past
text: Perhaps it has happened to you: catching a passing glimpse of somebody familiar and yet changed from the way you fondly knew him or her years ago.

headline: In Battle of Top Teams, a Chance to Measure Potential

headline: U.S. Warns It May Close Embassy in Syria

headline: Egypt’s Economic Crisis
text: In the year since President Hosni Mubarak was ousted, Egypt has faced many challenges: the military-led government’s brutality against protesters and pro-democracy groups, its resistance to handing power to civilian leaders and the rise of Islamists in the country’s first free elections. Now worsening economic conditions are further sabotaging hopes for a democratic future.

headline: With Small Devices, Older New Yorkers Gain Independence and Peace of Mind
text: There was a time when Angelo Boccino did not mind falling — if it was from an airplane and he had a parachute. In fact, Mr. Boccino jumped out of planes on combat missions when he was an Army paratrooper in World War II, he said. Today, he is 93, and falling can be hazardous to his health. So Mr. Boccino, who uses a wheelchair, an electric scooter and a walker to get around, depends on an emergency alert bracelet he wears on his left wrist.

headline: In Flash of Fire, Florida Loses Old Friend
text: LONGWOOD, Fla. — Back, way back, before King Tut was born and Alexander the Great roamed his empire, the Senator sprouted in a swamp here in central Florida, one of thousands of its kind.
