headline: Defense Chief Ends Probation Status of Marine Warplane
text: NAVAL AIR STATION PATUXENT RIVER, Md. — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta visited a flight testing center along the shores of Chesapeake Bay on Friday to give a lift to the beleaguered F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, announcing that he was taking the Marine Corps version of the costly warplane off probation.

headline: City Criticizes Judge in Case Of Hiring At Fire Dept.
text: The federal judge who ruled that the New York Fire Department discriminates against minority candidates and ordered a court-appointed monitor to oversee its recruiting efforts has “lost any semblance of neutrality” and should be removed from the case, the city said in an appeal filed this week.

headline: House Republicans Hone Plan to Take On Obama
text: BALTIMORE — President Obama may be running against Congressional Republicans in his re-election campaign, but they intend to run right back against him.

headline: Italy Announces New Steps to Get Economy Moving
text: ROME — In a bold effort to transform Italy’s protectionist economy and to foster growth amid a deepening recession, Prime Minister Mario Monti on Friday announced a new set of measures aimed at reviving Italy’s sluggish economy by investing $7.1 billion in infrastructure and opening up professional guilds to competition.

headline: Complexity and Intrigue Amid the Old Standbys
text: SOMETIMES having too many projects — and the restaurateurs Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich have many — can dilute even a fine concept. But that is not the case at one of the pair’s newest ventures, Tarry Lodge Enoteca Pizzeria in Westport. A sister to the well-known Tarry Lodge that opened in Port Chester more than three years ago, it is a smoothly run hands-on effort by Mario La Posta, the chef, and Andy Nusser, executive chef and managing partner with Nancy Selzer — all from the Port Chester team. And the bill for a lunch or dinner is reasonable, bucking the current Fairfield County trend of rising prices, which may explain why so many young couples dine there.

headline: A 49ers Linebacker With Two Men to Call Dad
text: BRUCETON, Tenn. — The strange and impromptu family reunion took place Wednesday on a high school basketball court.

headline: A Specialists’ Debate on Autism Has Many Worried Observers
text: A debate among medical professionals over how to define autism has spilled over into the public domain, stirring anger and fear among many parents and advocates of those with the neurological disorder, even as some argue that the diagnosis has been too loosely applied.

headline: Accuser of Syracuse Coach Admits Doctoring E-Mails and Drops Civil Suit
text: A man who accused the former Syracuse assistant basketball coach Bernie Fine of molesting him has withdrawn a civil suit against Fine after acknowledging that he lied and doctored e-mails in an attempt to bolster parts of his story.

headline: The Remarkable Path of a Football Star
text: A look at the background of the star 49ers linebacker Patrick Willis, who was raised by a struggling single father and than a foster father in western Tennessee.

headline: Blacks Face Bias in Bankruptcy, Study Suggests
text: Blacks are about twice as likely as whites to wind up in the more onerous and costly form of consumer bankruptcy as they try to dig out from their debts, a new study has found.

headline: U.S. Investigates Trade Complaint on Washers
text: The Commerce Department agreed to investigate a trade complaint by Whirlpool that said residential washing machines made in South Korea and Mexico were being sold below cost in America. The United States imported $1.1 billion of the washers from the two nations in 2010, the agency said. Whirlpool is requesting antidumping duties on LG and Samsung imports from South Korea and Mexico. The department also is considering whether to impose countervailing duties against the Korean products, to offset benefits of subsidies.

headline: A New Rustic Bistro (Comes With a Crowd)
text: WHEN the owners of a highly regarded restaurant open another place, the new spot is often on a fast track to popularity. Such is the case with Market Bistro in Jericho, which was opened in November by Bill Holden and Bob Caras, proprietors of the well-liked, 20-year-old West End Cafe in Carle Place, along with Adam Acerra, a former bartender at West End.

headline: Probation for a Former Galleon Group Employee
text: David R. Slaine, a former Galleon Group employee who helped the authorities investigate the hedge fund’s co-founder, Raj Rajaratnam, was sentenced to probation for three years for securities fraud. Mr. Slaine wore a hidden device to record dozens of conversations with suspects including Zvi Goffer, a former Galleon trader. Judge Richard J. Sullivan of United States District in Manhattan, who sentenced Mr. Slaine, also ordered him to perform 300 hours of community service and pay a $500,000 fine. The judge praised Mr. Slaine’s cooperation, which began in 2007.

headline: Out in Three Attempts, Another Shot at a Super Bowl
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Steve Weatherford would rather have had the Giants miss the playoffs if they do not win the Super Bowl. It is a perspective in heartbreak he has gained after a few N.F.L. postseasons.

headline: Ejection and Dejection as Knicks’ Skid Goes On
text: The night before the Knicks have to face the possibility that the Denver Nuggets may have stolen their future, Brandon Jennings and the Milwaukee Bucks handed them their fifth straight loss Friday in part by making important steals with the alarming ease of practiced pickpockets.

headline: Threat From Gangs Heightens Anxiety in a Brooklyn Neighborhood
text: In the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Yizbeth Leon and her co-workers stopped walking to the B12 bus stop after dark for fear of being robbed or attacked.

headline: ‘Wall Dogs’ With Paint
text: Sign painters, a k a billboard artists, have almost disappeared, their trade strangled by the advent of vinyl sheets. But there is still call for their artistry, skill and pluck.

headline: On a Cold Night, Good Wine and Cozy Plates
text: The burgeoning Terroir empire of site-specific wine bars concocted by Paul Grieco and the executive chef Marco Canora has touched down in Murray Hill. The two have become known as providers of cozy, comfy small plates that allow imbibers to go all experimental on beverage selections. The narrow room has de rigueur exposed-brick walls, Parson-style tables and rustic wood shelving meant to suggest a Revolutionary War-era farmhouse atmosphere: to wit, the neighborhood is named for the 29-acre farm belonging to the Murray family that once occupied this section of Manhattan. As a tribute to the late Murray Hill Hotel, Mr. Canora plucked, and tweaked, four “historic” dishes from a menu in the New York Public Library archives: smoked beef tongue pastrami, fried scallops, the ever-hardy French dip and an oyster sandwich.

headline: Coffee, Couch Time and a Trip to Jail
text: The perennially ponytailed Ronald L. Kuby, who says he hasn’t had a haircut since 1989, is the counsel of choice for alternative types; five protesters from the Occupy Wall Street encampment retained him after tangling with the New York Police Department. From 1999 to 2007 he was a host of a radio show on WABC-AM with Curtis Sliwa. On Sundays, Mr. Kuby, 55, works a bit but mostly relaxes by cooking, walking or biking, and watching TV. He lives in Chelsea with his wife, Marilyn Vasta, 60, a psychotherapist, and their bichon frisé, Lily; they are sometimes joined by their daughter, Emma, 19, who attends Wesleyan University. The couple also owns a country house in the Poconos.

headline: Petty Differences Mask Consensus on Teachers
text: Popular culture has surely produced no more satiric a view of that great scourge of public progress, the Apathetic Teacher, than last year’s bluntly titled comedy “Bad Teacher.” In the film, Cameron Diaz plays Elizabeth Halsey, a junior high school teacher so incompetent and chemically regulated that she shows movies all day, barely registers one student’s slapping another with coleslaw and steals the answers to a state-administered exam. A bonus of $5,700 is to be given to the teacher whose students score highest on the test, and Halsey pursues it to pay for her adventures in plastic surgery. Perhaps you watched the movie wondering whether it had been subsidized by a political action committee aimed at dismantling the teachers’ union.

headline: Self-Immolation Is on the Rise in the Arab World
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — More than a year after a young Tunisian set himself on fire and touched off revolutions throughout the Arab world, self-immolation, symbolic of systemic frustration and helplessness, has become increasingly common across the region.

headline: After Mt. Everest, the Bronx
text: JINPA SHERPA is unfailingly cheerful and helpful as he rings up your gas and coffee and lottery ticket at the Gulf station mini-mart on Leggett Avenue in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.

headline: Inebriated Love
text: A STRANGER across the bar, a glass in his or her hand, a wild fire in the eyes. What is it that draws us to drunk people? Their volubility? Their lack of inhibition? Or is it that — in a birds-of-a-feather sort of way — our would-be partner’s muddled state is so often a reflection of our own? Whatever the case, intoxication’s influence on romance is a classic literary trope, ably demonstrated in these poems “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: Sharapova Reaches Round of 16
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Maria Sharapova powered her way into the Round of 16 with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Angelique Kerber on Saturday.

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition

She and her partner, Oscar-winning composer Elliot Goldenthal traveled through Rajasthan, Kerala and visited New Delhi and Mumbai.

headline: The Last Sermon of Mr. Fix-It
text: HIS work here is done. His reinvention of a dying church with ratty old wooden pews is emblemized by the 900 brand-new chairs — bought by parishioners for $900 apiece, engraved plaques included — arrayed in the exquisite mosaic, marble and stained-glass sanctuary. With a congregation of nearly 3,400, up from a foundering flock of just a few hundred when he took over in 1994, the Rev. William MacDonald Tully, 65, is retiring from active duty at St. Bartholomew’s Episcopal Church on Park Avenue and 50th Street. His final sermon is on Sunday.

headline: In a Club Fight, Power, Ego and Real Estate

headline: Russia: Putin’s Popularity Inches Upward
text: A respected polling agency connected to the Russian government announced Friday that the popularity of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin had reversed its slow decline, rising above 50 percent for the first time in weeks. The news comes just over a month before presidential elections that Mr. Putin is widely expected to win. The polling agency, VTsIOM, put Mr. Putin’s rating at 52 percent as of Jan. 14. He remains Russia’s most popular politician, but his decision to seek the presidency again after four years as prime minister set off huge anti-Kremlin protests in December. In another survey released this month by the Levada Center, a prominent independent polling agency, 36 percent of Russians said they would vote for Mr. Putin, more than would support any of his opponents, but not enough for him to win the election in the first round.

headline: A Move to Investigate the Investigators in WikiLeaks Case

What is not yet known is where else the Justice Department went looking.

headline: Ivanovic Closes Out King’s Musical Run
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Vania King’s quest for a berth in the Round of 16 ended without a victory song on Saturday when Ana Ivanovic of Serbia prevailed, 6-3, 6-4, in a closely fought match before about 8,000 fans at the 2012 Australian Open.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The Indian Air Force has been asked by the Jammu and Kashmir government to airlift people stranded by heavy snowfall between Srinagar and the Jammu region. The Jammu-Srinagar national highway, an important road link connecting the state to other parts of the country, remained closed for passenger traffic since the last one week, affected by landslides and snowfall, Kashmir Live reports.

headline: African Cup: Ivory Coast’s Last Chance for Glory?
text: The African Cup of Nations kicks off Saturday with two games in Equatorial Guinea but no clear favorite. There’s a reason for that: of the past nine champions, eight failed to qualify for this year’s tournament.

headline: Scheduling Conflict for a Bryan
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Bob Bryan is in Melbourne, playing in another Australian Open. His wife, Michelle, is in Miami awaiting the birth of their first child.

headline: The Quiet End of the Runway
text: IT was a honey-gold morning in Tulum, Mexico, the low-rise, high-key ocean strip in the Yucatán 75 miles south of Cancún. While many visitors saluted the sun in various yoga poses along the white swatch of the Atlantic Ocean beach, Irene Albright and her daughter, Marina, stared at a computer screen in the open-air lobby of the Hotel Nueva Vida de Ramiro. They were looking at Chloé’s Web site.

headline: Gingrich Is Well-Positioned as South Carolina Votes

headline: A Small-Business Owner Bird-Dogs the Republican Candidates
text: One undeniable benefit of holding an early primary (or caucus) in a small state like New Hampshire is that any citizen has a chance to meet the candidates for president individually and interrogate them on the issues — even if the citizen is not, technically, a resident of that early voting state. And so Mark Dunau, a New York farmer and gadfly for the self-employed (through his Web site, dontsubmit.org), headed up to the Granite State to “bird dog” the Republican candidates in the week before the New Hampshire primary.

headline: Divers Resume Search of Capsized Cruise Ship
text: GIGLIO, Italy — A week after the Costa Concordia luxury liner ran aground off the island of Giglio in Tuscany, bodies were still being retrieved from the wreck that is threatening the protected environment here.

headline: The Least Refuse Of A Squirrel
text: People have been asking me about Steve Rattner’s op-ed, which does seem to be aimed at me. My initial reaction was sheer bafflement: Rattner first attacks a view that, as far as I know, nobody holds, then makes his case by saying in as many ways as he can think of that the debt is huge, huge I tell you. What’s going on here?

headline: Hewitt Conjures Some Old Magic to Defeat Raonic

headline: Gronkowski Earning Name for Scores and Spikes
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Conan O’Brien featured him in a parody of the song “St. Elmo’s Fire” on TV last week. The Worcester Sharks of the American Hockey League are paying him $7,500 to “spike” a hockey puck before one of their games next month.

headline: Romney Urges Gingrich Disclosure on Freddie Mac
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — As South Carolina residents began voting Saturday morning, Mitt Romney stopped to thank supporters and volunteers at his campaign office here, and he called on Newt Gingrich to release the details of his contract with Freddie Mac.

headline: Homecoming for Player Who Grew Up Amid Nature but Without a Course
text: IDYLLWILD, Calif. — The sign welcoming visitors into this town’s snug embrace reads: Home of Adventure, Music, Art and Harmony. Nestled like a dogleg in the San Jacinto Mountains, it is protected by tall pines, pocked by boulders and redolent of cedar, and has neither a golf course nor a driving range. It would seem infertile ground for raising a professional golfer, and yet it is where Brendan Steele, the reigning Texas Open champion, grew up.

headline: Variety: A Furry Diagramless
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — About five years ago, we decided to get a dog. My older dogs had crossed the Rainbow Bridge, and, to be absolutely truthful, my kids and I just aren’t used to living without a four-legged companion in the house. We honestly don’t know what to do with ourselves without a dog telling us when it’s time to go for a walk.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: State Laws on Unions
text: Should workers be compelled to join unions or pay dues? Readers debate “right to work” laws now being considered.

headline: Farewell Is Also a Win as Cuche Becomes the King of Kitzbühel
text: KITZBÜHEL, Austria — Two days after unexpectedly announcing that he would retire after this season, Didier Cuche on Saturday won his record-breaking fifth Hahnenkamm downhill, largely considered skiing’s most difficult and prestigious race.

headline: Williams Turns Back the Clock and Turns Up the Heat

headline: Coughlin Goes by the Book, and Wins

When the Jaguars’ stadium was nearly complete, Coughlin ordered Perkins, the son of the former Giants coach Ray Perkins, onto the new field to calculate how many steps there were from the home sideline to the locker room.

headline: Ready for Worst, New York Gets First Major Snowfall

headline: Variations on an Explosive Theme
text: WHEN George Gershwin’s “Porgy and Bess” — arguably the most important piece of American music written in the 20th century — first opened on Broadway in 1935, the opera’s libretto was littered with a word now shunned as an antiblack slur. The African-American residents of Catfish Row, the only slightly imaginary block in Charleston, S.C., where the opera is set, used it liberally, and so of course did the white characters during their occasional menacing visits.

text: Comme des GarconsDesigner: Rei KawakuboDate: Friday, Jan. 20Photos: slide show

headline: Obama to Draw an Economic Line in State of the Union
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will use his election-year State of the Union address on Tuesday to argue that it is government’s role to promote a prosperous and equitable society, drawing a stark contrast between the parties in a time of deep economic uncertainty.

headline: Hungary’s Lurch Backward
text: The soothing words of Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban, do little to counter his government’s assaults on the independence of Hungary’s press, judiciary and central bank. Without strong European pressure, Mr. Orban is unlikely to change the new banking, judiciary and media laws.

headline: The Affirmative Action War Goes On
text: Last month, the Obama administration issued important guidance to colleges and universities on how to increase racial diversity on campuses, explaining ways to navigate the narrow legal channel charted by the Supreme Court. The benefits of diversity, the Department of Education said, contribute to “the educational, economic and civic life of this nation.” The administration’s support for such efforts stands in stark contrast to the policy of the George W. Bush administration to discourage them. That difference has played out between the political parties for decades, as it will in this presidential election.

headline: Rejected in Tucson
text: The Tucson Unified School District has dismantled its Mexican-American studies program, packed away its offending books, shuttled its students into other classes. It was blackmailed into doing so: keeping the program would have meant losing more than $14 million in state funding. It was a blunt-force victory for the Arizona school superintendent, John Huppenthal, who has spent years crusading against ethnic-studies programs he claims are “brainwashing” children into thinking that Latinos have been victims of white oppression.

headline: Friends of Angelo, Part 2
text: Four lawmakers have been referred to the House Ethics Committee for receiving special mortgage loans from the notorious “V.I.P.” program of Countrywide Financial. Ethics rules require members to accept loans only “on terms generally available to the public.” It should be of great interest for the public, particularly those mired in mortgage trouble, to see if anything comes out of the Congressional investigation.

headline: How Mrs. Grady Transformed Olly Neal
text: IF you want to understand how great teachers transform lives, listen to the story of Olly Neal.

headline: Quick Rebound in Cleveland
text: When LeBron James left the Cavaliers, the devastation was supposed to be complete. But in the second season after his departure, they are doing something that few expected: winning.

headline: The Ongoing Debt Transformation
text: A followup on my note about US deleveraging. It turns out that if you measure debt as a percentage of potential GDP (as estimated by the CBO) and use a stacked-area graph, you get a pretty clear picture. Here it is, using nonfinancial debt (for reasons explained in the previous post):

headline: Tallying Disasters and Gauging a Greenhouse Impact
text: I encourage you to read “Global Warming and Severe Weather: Is There a Link?” This excellent new Green Grok post is by Bill Chameides, the blogging dean of the Nicholas School for the Environment at Duke University. (Hat tip @KeithKloor.)

headline: A Good Candidate Is Hard to Find
text: THERE are 300 million people in the United States of America. There are millions of political activists, volunteers, organizers and would-be officeholders. There are hundreds of thousands of elected officials. Yet somehow, out of all this multitude, the Republican Party has been unable to find a candidate for the White House in 2012 who inspires anything but weary resignation from its voters.

headline: Caucus Click: Waiting for Romney
text: A supporter waited for Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, to make a scheduled visit to his headquarters in Greenville, S.C.

headline: How the U.S. Lost Out on iPhone Work
text: When Barack Obama joined Silicon Valley’s top luminaries for dinner in California last February, each guest was asked to come with a question for the president.

headline: Lynn Shelton Offers a Thank-You to Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah — For the films screening here, the crew from “Your Sister’s Sister” might have been the most relaxed. Not only did the film already have distribution, a rarity at this year’s buyer-ready festival, but it came with a lot of good buzz from its premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. That’s where IFC picked up the film, a largely improvised comedy about a depressed guy (Mark Duplass), his best friend (Emily Blunt) and her sister (Rosemarie DeWitt), with plans to release it this summer. So the movie, directed by a Sundance favorite, Lynn Shelton (“Humpday”), was not in competition here. But Ms. Shelton nonetheless felt it was important to show it.

headline: The iPhone Economy
text: Apple’s iPhone is a model of American ingenuity, but most of its components are manufactured somewhere else. The decline of manufacturing led to the loss of other kinds of jobs.

headline: The Energy of New York Still Seduces Jackson
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — Every time Phil Jackson thinks the winter of his career is finally here, he awakens to find it is Indian summer and someone is luring him back to coaching. Elusive as Jackson may be at 66, the hunt continues. With 11 N.B.A. titles, he will not reach the end without saying no to at least a few more teams.

headline: Dempsey on a Roll
text: If this keeps up someone might mistake Clint Dempsey for a prolific Brazilian goal-scorer.

headline: Trying to Appeal to U.S. Under-10 Generation by Shrinking the Game’s Scale
text: At the Australian Open, the news looked grim again for American tennis. For the first time since 1973, no American man reached the fourth round there, and entering the tournament’s second week, Serena Williams is the only American left in the singles draws.

headline: U.S. Men vs. Venezuela
text: Most of Jurgen Klinsmann’s first-choice players have games in Europe this weekend, so he will run out the best of his B and C list on Saturday night for a friendly against Venezuela in Glendale, Ariz. (8:09 p.m. | Updated With Lineups, Below)

headline: Ravens for the Ages, Running Out of Time
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — If he listened closely, Cory Redding could hear the men laughing. The sounds, deep and resonant, were coming from around the corner, in the Baltimore Ravens’ training room, where Redding found Ray Lewis on one table and Ed Reed on another, cracking jokes and poking fun at each other. When Lewis offered advice to a younger teammate, Reed interrupted, pleading not to believe him: “He told me that, too, and it didn’t work.”

headline: ‘Reality Bites’ and the Perils of Being a Generation’s Touchstone
text: PARK CITY, Utah — The 20-something hipsters partying on Main Street here make us feel old enough. Does “Reality Bites” really need to be a Sundance “rediscovered in the archive” selection?

headline: South Carolina Primary Overview and Forecast
text: Just days ago, Mitt Romney appeared to be on a glide path to the Republican nomination. Coming off a big victory in New Hampshire and an apparent win in Iowa, he had just received the endorsement of Jon M. Huntsman Jr., and had as much as a 23-point lead in some national polls of Republican voters. He also led in South Carolina polls, sometimes by double digits, and attacks by Republican rivals on Mr. Romney’s tenure at Bain Capital did not appear to be harming him.

headline: More Than 100 Killed by a Radical Group in Nigeria
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — More than 100 people have been killed in a series of attacks in northern Nigeria’s largest city, officials said Saturday, in what appears to be the deadliest strike yet by a radical Islamist group.

headline: A Year Later, Concussions Keep Savard Off the Ice
text: BOSTON — Marc Savard, the star Bruins forward, said Saturday that he still has headaches and short-term memory loss a year after his last concussion.

headline: Ousted Leader Is Thwarted in a Return to Madagascar
text: JOHANNESBURG — A commercial airliner carrying the ousted president of Madagascar back to that country’s capital was turned around midflight, after government officials abruptly closed the nation’s airspace on Saturday, apparently to prevent the flight from landing.

headline: Q. & A. With Manchester United’s Alex Ferguson
text: Alex Ferguson, marking his 25th season as Manchester United’s manager, turned 70 on Dec. 31. A former player, he began coaching in 1974 with East Stirlingshire in Scotland, which gave him £2,000 (about $3,100) to acquire five players. His 1999 United team won three titles, sweeping championships in England’s Premier League, F.A. Cup and the Champions League. Fox will televise United’s game against Arsenal at 11 a.m. Eastern on Sunday, the first live Premier League match on that network. In an interview with Claire Bloomfield for the British online magazine Sabotage Times , Ferguson recently reflected on how the game, and his job, had changed over the years.

headline: Q. & A. With Manchester United’s Alex Ferguson
text: Alex Ferguson, marking his 25th season as Manchester United’s manager, turned 70 on Dec. 31. A former player, he began coaching in 1974 with East Stirlingshire in Scotland, which gave him £2,000 (about $3,100) to acquire five players. His 1999 United team won three titles, sweeping championships in England’s Premier League, F.A. Cup and the Champions League. Fox will televise United’s game against Arsenal at 11 a.m. Eastern on Sunday, the first live Premier League match on that network. In Claire Bloomfield for the British online magazine Sabotage Times, Ferguson recently reflected on how the game, and his job, had changed over the years. Read the interview here.

headline: New Generation of 49ers Success
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Last weekend at Candlestick Park, it felt the way it used to feel when “Montana” and “Young” and “Rice” were stitched onto jerseys, when the 49ers boasted a franchise as successful as any in sports.

text: One dimension — left to right — doesn’t suffice to deal with today’s political reality.

headline: I Disclose ... Nothing
text: IN New York and a growing number of American cities, diners are encountering sanitary grades in restaurants’ windows — A, B or C. That system is an example of helpful disclosure, researchers say: information that is simple and comprehensible, important to recipients and easily acted upon. I recently chose between outwardly identical Japanese noodle shops on East Ninth Street in Manhattan based on the system, walking into the A rather than the B.

headline: Target for the Next Winter Classic: 104,174
text: Even going into its sixth year, the N.H.L.’s Winter Classic retains the capacity to delight and astonish, as evidenced by last week’s reports that the game next Jan. 1 will be played at Michigan Stadium in Ann Arbor and will feature the Detroit Red Wings and the Toronto Maple Leafs.

headline: Santorum Says He Will Remain in Race Through Florida
text: CHAPIN, S.C. — Rick Santorum said he would be pleased with a third-place finish in South Carolina Saturday but vowed to stay in the presidential race through the Florida primary no matter what.

headline: In Showdown, Penalty by Bruins Leads to Injury and Victory for Rangers
text: BOSTON — It was a showdown of two of the N.H.L.’s best teams this season, a first meeting between voracious opponents who play a similarly relentless style. And when it was over Saturday afternoon, only 3.6 seconds from the end of overtime, the Rangers stood alone, victorious.

headline: Japanese Struggle to Protect Their Food Supply
text: ONAMI, Japan — In the fall, as this valley’s rice paddies ripened into a carpet of gold, inspectors came to check for radioactive contamination.

headline: The Most Important Job in America
text: My Sunday column returns to education, and the importance of teaching as a way to improve education outcomes. I think education is, in the long run, the most important challenge America faces and the one where we’re in greatest difficulties. If we want to maintain economic competitiveness and chip away at poverty, we simply have to improve high school graduation rates and college attendance — and that in turn will depend on an overhaul of the entire education system, starting with early childhood education.

headline: Yemen Legislators Approve Immunity for the President
text: Yemen’s Parliament approved immunity on Saturday to free President Ali Abdullah Saleh from prosecution, following through on a requirement in a deal for him to give up power. The lawmakers extended the legislation to grant immunity for politically motivated crimes committed by all officials working under Mr. Saleh, according to the state-run Saba news agency.

headline: Q. and A. With Tom Seaver
text: The Mets will be honored on the franchise’s 50th anniversary at the Baseball Assistance Team’s annual fund-raising dinner Tuesday in Manhattan. B.A.T. helps former players and baseball employees who have fallen on hard times.

headline: NASA Searches for Loot That Traveled From Space to Another Void
text: HOUSTON — West Virginia lost one, until it turned up one June day on a bookshelf in the basement of a retired dentist. New York has one in a vault at a museum in Albany, but another one given to the state for safekeeping was not kept very safe, because it appears to be missing, though the attorney general’s office has started looking into the case.

headline: Cleaning Up the Old West the Modern Way
text: TOMBSTONE, Ariz. — It is fair to say that well before the Earp brothers shot three cowboys in a lot behind the O.K. Corral, this city had a trash problem. Mule and horse droppings were everywhere. The stench of leather being tanned, charcoal burning and ore being dug out of the earth burned the nostrils. Garbage piled high in the muddy streets.

headline: Karzai Honors Slain Officials in Speech
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a somber but dramatic flourish, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Saturday used a speech during the annual opening of Parliament to recite an honor roll of 49 senior government officials and elders slain over the past year.

headline: In Syrian City, a Calm That Few Expect to Last

headline: A Math Study Provides Hints About the Game’s Gender Gap
text: The findings of a new study about mathematics may explain why there are so few women among the chess elite. It concluded that cultural factors, not biological ones, are the reasons why boys outperform girls in math.

headline: What to Watch in South Carolina

headline: American Voters: Still Up for Grabs
text: A Washington Post-ABC News poll released on Friday found that two-thirds of Americans would consider voting for a third-party presidential candidate, while 48 percent definitely wanted a third party in the race. Now what does that tell you? It tells you that with the campaign about to go into full swing, as the president delivers his State of the Union address next week, voters are still casting about for a leader with a winning message. I can save both parties a lot of money. I am one of those voters, and I can tell you exactly for whom I want to vote — and I don’t think I’m alone.

headline: A Better Tax System (Assembly Instructions Included)
text: IT’S that time again. Start filing all those W-2s, 1099s and scraps of paper you’ll need for your annual tax return. No doubt, this isn’t your favorite activity. At some point, you may ask yourself whether there’s a better way.

headline: Hamas Says That Its Political Leader Does Not Plan to Seek Re-election
text: GAZA — The Palestinian militant group Hamas announced Saturday that its political leader, Khaled Meshal, would not seek re-election, opening the door to a possible leadership contest and adding to the uncertainty enveloping Hamas at a time of regional turmoil.

headline: Trying to Nudge Drowsy Drivers
text: A DRIVERLESS car is not yet ready for the market. But in the meantime, automakers are continuing to market some components of one. The Ford Motor Company announced last month that it would offer “lane-keeping technology” as an option for its 2013 Ford Fusion and Ford Explorer. The price has not yet been set.

headline: Deep Conflict Looms Over Billion-Dollar BART Extension to Livermore
text: A battle is brewing between top Bay Area Rapid Transit leaders over a billion-dollar rail extension to Livermore.

headline: From One Tragedy, Tools to Fight the Next
text: WHEN the devastating earthquake and tsunami struck northern Japan last March, the home of Shoji Tanaka, more than 200 miles south of the quake’s epicenter, was spared any major damage. But he worked as a volunteer in the disaster zone, supplying clothing and helping with clean-up, and said he was “appalled by the horrifying damage.”

headline: Restaurant Bill Shock? Some Readers Say ‘Au Contraire’
text: AFTER every episode of the Haggler, it is a safe bet that a handful of readers will write to say that the Haggler is a patsy and a twit. Or words to that effect. The gist of these e-mails is that the wrong party — an aggrieved consumer, in most instances — has prevailed. The Haggler, it is argued, failed to appreciate the company’s side of a dispute, and the consumer should have known better, or behaved differently, or merely had the decency to shut up.

headline: A Clash of Media Worlds (and Generations)

headline: Why World War I Resonates
text: IN France I live near a little village called Sadillac. It’s no more than a cluster of houses, an old chateau, a church and a graveyard surrounded by a few farms and vineyards. The village probably hasn’t changed much since the French Revolution; its population hovers around 100. By the graveyard is a simple obelisk with the names of the 30 or so young men from Sadillac who died in the First World War, 1914-18. It’s almost impossible to imagine the effect on this tiny community of these fatalities over four years. Every year on Nov. 11 at 11 a.m. — the hour and the day of the 1918 armistice — villagers gather to participate in a short memorial service around the obelisk.

headline: City Grazing
text: The 60 goats living in the rail yard near Pier 96 at the Port of San Francisco contribute to the city of San Francisco in their own way, clearing brush as fire prevention and offering a green alternative to toxic herbicides. Perched on the edge of Bayview-Hunters Point, an industrial area, these hard workers avoid the busy roads and — incredibly — return home when called.

headline: Why Credit Downgrades Can Be Poor Predictors
text: THOUGH Wall Street is worried that the European debt crisis will worsen, the stock market barely budged when Standard & Poor’s downgraded the credit ratings of several euro zone nations — in the process stripping France, Austria and the euro zone’s primary rescue fund of their AAA standing.

headline: What We Give Up for Health Care
text: WHEN it comes to health care, most liberals are committed above all to ensuring that every American has insurance. In their view, the greatest achievement of the health care reform act passed under President Obama is to finally erase the moral stain of the United States’ being the only major developed country without universal coverage. But we also hold the questionable distinction of having the world’s most expensive health care system — what about cost control? For many liberals, that just sounds like a cover for heartless conservatives who care only about cutting benefits and not about helping people in need.

headline: Charges Against Sheriff Present a Political Twist
text: People following Venezuela’s news Web site Noticias24 Tuesday were treated to a plot that might have been lifted from one of the popular Venezuelan soap operas featuring Eliana Lopez.

text: I  WAS born in Lowell, Mass., where my father, a child of Armenian immigrants, was a dentist. He went to dental school on the G.I. Bill and later met my mother when she was working as a dental hygienist.

headline: As Passion Increases for N.F.C. Championship Game, Stadium Officials Are Alert
text: As thousands of passionate fans descend upon San Francisco for the 49ers’ National Football Conference championship showdown with the Giants on Sunday, officials are touting a widely ignored text-messaging service as a solution to bad fan behavior.

headline: Her Key to Efficiency: Arrive Late, Leave Early

headline: Islamists Win 70% of Seats in the Egyptian Parliament
text: CAIRO — Egyptian authorities confirmed Saturday that a political coalition dominated by the Muslim Brotherhood, the 84-year-old group that virtually invented political Islam, had won about 47 percent of the seats in the first Parliament elected since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak. An alliance of ultraconservative Islamists won the next largest share of seats, about 25 percent.

headline: Austin Brothers Fill Idiosyncratic Niche at Sundance
text: The classic Sundance Film Festival story goes something like this: A gifted young filmmaker — say Quentin Tarantino or Kevin Smith — maxes out his credit cards and pours everything into a debut feature. The film is introduced at the festival, in Park City, Utah, where it’s embraced as a bold leap forward for American cinema. Agents and distributors come calling, helping to propel the director into a lucrative Hollywood career and a considerably bigger budget for a second feature film.

headline: High Winds Delay Humana Challenge
text: LA QUINTA, Calif. — In his first competitive round since 1995, former President Bill Clinton broke 70, but only with a huge assist from Mother Nature. Clinton had completed nine holes at the Palmer course at PGA West when play at the Humana Challenge on Saturday was suspended because of high winds that toppled trees, turned portable toilets into projectiles and caused a giant scoreboard to take a dive into the lake along the 18th green at the Palmer course.

headline: Chávez Gets Bluster Back and Reclaims the Spotlight

headline: The Fog of War
text: As the morning fog of Jan. 19, 1862, gave way to the haze of musket and cannon smoke around Logan’s Crossroads, Ky., Confederate Gen. Felix Zollicoffer gingerly approached a regiment of Kentuckians. After imploring the Kentuckians not to shoot one of their own in the confusion of battle, one of the men – perhaps the unit’s leader, Col. Speed S. Fry of nearby Danville – identified Zollicoffer, a Tennessean, as an enemy commander. There was a hail of lead and the white-coated Zollicoffer lay dying on the battlefield. He was the first Confederate commander to die in battle in the Western Theater, but far from the last.

headline: Ron Paul Gives Concession Speech in S.C.
text: Ron Paul says that he realized you promote causes by winning elections and delegates so he will pursue more delegates.

headline: Gingrich Has Kind Words for Rivals and Venom for ‘Elites’
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Newt Gingrich, whose campaign was twice left for dead and came back to win a landslide victory in South Carolina, used his victory speech Saturday night before a raucous crowd of hundreds to attack the “elites in New York and Washington,” whom he identified as President Obama and the news media.

headline: South Carolina’s Divisive Message
text: Since it was first held 32 years ago, the South Carolina Republican primary has been won by the party’s most electable candidate, the one backed by the Republican establishment and invariably the winner of the nomination. On Saturday, the state veered in an extreme direction, and the outcome spoke poorly for a party that allowed itself to be manipulated by the lowest form of campaigning.

headline: Gingrich Gives Victory Speech in S.C.
text: Newt Gingrich praised his competitors saying Rick Santorum showed enormous courage, Ron Paul's critiques about the Federal Reserve are correct and Mitt Romney "is a good example of America."

headline: Video of Candidates’ Speeches From South Carolina
text: The candidates gave their speeches after Newt Gingrich was declared the winner in South Carolina.

headline: Santorum, Optimistic, Plans Effort Nationwide
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Despite the cloud cast over Rick Santorum’s campaign by his third-place showing in the South Carolina primary on Saturday, his aides said he was pressing on to Florida on Sunday while also pursuing a broad national campaign strategy.

headline: Braun Takes M.V.P. Amid ‘Challenges’
text: A murmur of expectation bubbled through the ballroom at the Hilton Hotel in Midtown Manhattan as it became clear Ryan Braun would soon be approaching the podium.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Anthony and Knicks Are Left to Second-Guess
text: This was not about Carmelo Anthony, or grudges or homecomings or controversial trades, or so the participants claimed in the days and hours before the Knicks and the Denver Nuggets finally met again.

headline: More Than 20 Horses Killed in New Jersey Barn Fire
text: More than 20 horses were killed in Lafayette Township, N.J., when a predawn fire engulfed the barn they were stabled in on Saturday, the New Jersey State Police said.

headline: The Scene in South Carolina
text: Newt Gingrich’s victory in the state’s Republican primary has Mitt Romney scrambling and third-place Rick Santorum pledging to continue the fight.

headline: A Long-Awaited Win for Uganda
text: After being unable to take part in the Little League World Series, the Rev. John Foundation team from Kampala, Uganda, finally got to play against Canada in the Pearl of Africa series.

headline: Anne Dean and Peter Zaitzeff
text: Anne O’Donnell Dean, a daughter of Mary Hoskinson-Dean and Robert Dean of Redding, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Peter Zane Zaitzeff, a son of Amine Zaitzeff and Roger M. Zaitzeff, both of New York. Richard J. Sullivan, a United States District judge for the Southern District of New York, officiated at the Museum of the City of New York in Manhattan.

headline: Emily Rover and Charles Grace III
text: Emily Christine Rover and Charles Brown Grace III were married Saturday evening at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Thomas N. Synan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Mia Wilson, Andrue Kahn
text: Mia Angelina Wilson and Andrue Jacob Kahn are to be married Sunday at Central Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi Lisa Rubin is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Emily Stamell, Eric Ruiz
text: Dr. Emily Frank Stamell, a daughter of Susan B. Stamell and Jared B. Stamell of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Eric Litman Ruiz, a son of Stacey Litman Ruiz and Dr. Jorge R. Ruiz Jr. of Pinecrest, Fla. Rabbi David J. Gelfand officiated with Cantor Robert P. Abelson participating at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

headline: Briana Sullivan and Alexander Radetsky
text: Briana Bancroft Sullivan and Alexander Radetsky were married Saturday at the Basilica of St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral in New York. Msgr. Donald Sakano, the cathedral’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Caitlin Loomis and David Stitelman
text: Dr. Caitlin Loomis and Dr. David Hugo Stitelman were married Saturday afternoon at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt. The Rev. Joan T. Osgood, the senior associate pastor of Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., performed the ceremony.

headline: Ardith Spence, John McGinnis
text: Ardith Anne Spence and John Oldham McGinnis were married Saturday at the Chapel of the Reformed Faith at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. Michael L. Lindvall, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jubilance for Gingrich Team in South Carolina
text: After Newt Gingrich’s victory, the campaigns of Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum assessed their positions and moved on.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Mormon’ in French?
text: PARIS — Republican primary voters in South Carolina, many of whom are Evangelical Christian conservatives, made their discomfort with Mitt Romney’s Mormonism plain on Saturday by handing Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives and a conservative Christian favorite, a resounding victory.

headline: A Grand Canyon Cabin Gets New Life, and Guests
text: The oldest building on the South Rim of the Grand Canyon is the national park’s newest overnight accommodation.

headline: Last-Minute Goal and Glimpse of Future Leave Klinsmann Smiling
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — With the top tier of talent of the United States men’s national team still competing in Europe, the lineup fielded on Saturday by the Americans in their first international action of 2012 will not be the one they use in June when the team begins qualifying for the 2014 World Cup.

headline: ‘The Artist’ Wins Producers Guild Award
text: “The Artist” has made its way to pole position in the awards race. The black-and-white largely silent film picked up the top prize, best feature, from the Producers Guild of America, which announced its winners on Saturday night in Los Angeles.

headline: The Caucus | A Race Upended
text: Jeff Zeleny reports from South Carolina on the strong victory of Newt Gingrich and steps ahead as the race moves to Florida and beyond.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Venezuela
text: The United States national team defeated Venezuela, 1-0, on Saturday night on a dramatic stoppage-time header by Ricardo Clark. Jurgen Klinsmann now has his first winning streak as U.S. coach, and the team can head to Panama with a bit of confidence and a sense of satisfaction.

headline: In India, Oprah Woos Crowd
text: Some foreigners come to India and make observations about the country that many Indians find unbearable. Not Oprah Winfrey.

headline: With Giants-49ers, Who Wins With the Weather?
text: The Fifth Down will provide live blogs of both the Ravens-Patriots and Giants-49ers games. Join us.

headline: A Giants Postseason Specialty: Using Their Heads
text: For the Giants, the blue helmet with the red center stripe isn’t just part of the uniform.  Having figured into four of the Giants’ most memorable plays over the past 25 years, it’s also part of the franchise’s lore.

headline: Did Gingrich’s Win Break the Paradigm?
text: During the Republican nominating contest, competing paradigms have arisen for how to interpret the evidence from polls, voting results and other tangible indicators of success or failure. The paradigms present profoundly different conclusions about the most likely outcome.

headline: Romney to Release Tax Returns on Tuesday
text: 10:32 a.m. | Updated Mitt Romney said Sunday morning that he would release his 2010 tax returns on Tuesday, bowing to that mounting pressure that might have helped lead to his defeat in the South Carolina primary on Saturday.

headline: Bloomberg’s Deferred Compensation (of 93 Cents)
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said last week that he paid the highest tax rate on his personal income, but his boast (or lament) does not exactly apply to his salary from the city.

headline: Hotels Band to Offer Their Own Search Site
text: Six of the world’s largest hotel companies have collaborated to create a Web site that allows travelers to search listings and then book rooms directly on hotel sites, effectively cutting out middlemen like Expedia.

headline: A Win in Melbourne for Top-Ranked Wozniacki
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Caroline Wozniacki, the world’s top-ranked women’s tennis player, kept alive her hopes of retaining that title Sunday night with a 6-0, 7-5 win over a former No. 1 seed, Jelena Jankovic, at the fourth round of the Australian Open.

headline: Paris Top 5 | Yves Saint Laurent
text: The “Justify My Love” remix (from Madonna’s steamy “SEX” days, of course) that ricocheted off the marble halls of the Sorbonne set the already sensual mood for Stefano Pilati’s great, tight YSL collection. Glossy black leather and rich, dark cashmere played cat and mouse in a collection that seemed camera ready for Helmut Newton: slick black lapels and cuffs on suits and outerwear; body-hugging shiny shirts and pants styled with motorcycle jackets. Here, a double breasted coat (what did we tell you?) with top-stitching on the shoulders and trim paired with a vest, shirt, and tie contained both the elegance and decadence that made this collection a real success.

headline: Joe Paterno, the Face of Penn State
text: Under Paterno’s leadership, Penn State won two national championships and became a college football powerhouse.

headline: Joe Paterno, Longtime Penn State Coach, Dies at 85
text: Joe Paterno, who won more games than any other major-college football coach, and who became the face of Pennsylvania State University and a symbol of integrity in collegiate athletics only to be fired during the 2011 season amid a child sexual abuse scandal that reverberated throughout the nation, died Sunday in State College, Pa. He was 85.

headline: G.O.P. Turns Its Focus to Florida
text: A drastically reshaped Republican presidential campaign begins anew in Florida on Sunday as the party’s establishment confronts the likelihood of an extended and bitter leadership fight and the increasing possibility that Newt Gingrich could be its nominee.

headline: Turning Subway Tracks Into Ad Hoc Wishing Wells

headline: Notes On Deleveraging
text: The new McKinsey Global Institute report on debt and deleveraging has attracted a lot of attention, and rightly so. I have some quibbles with the way the data are presented, but they’re very useful data — and lead to some surprising conclusions.

text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The reassuring news on a miserable afternoon for Li Na was that one actually can forget these moments.

text: About a week ago, the most recent national New York Times/CBS News poll showed that Republican voters were divided in their assessment of Newt Gingrich.

headline: At Jaipur Fest, Difficult Balancing Act
text: Controversy over Salman Rushdie’s invitation to the Jaipur Literature Festival and the public reading of his “The Satanic Verses” has forced organizers to walk a difficult path between championing free expression and keeping the festival safe and open, William Dalrymple, one of the festival’s co-directors, said Sunday.

headline: Greek Talks Hit a Snag Over Rates

headline: A Chat With the Writer-Director of ‘Bachelorette’
text: PARK CITY, Utah — “I’m warning you, I’m operating on four hours of sleep,” said Leslye Headland, the Kathleen Turner-voiced writer-director of “Bachelorette,” a lacerating comedy that will have its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival on Monday. “Seriously, you’re speaking to a crazy person right now.”

text: Libya’s post-Qaddafi transitional government faced a political crisis Sunday after protesters ransacked its offices in Benghazi, highlighting growing nationwide unease with its leadership and triggering a shake-up in which the governing council’s No. 2 official resigned and several members were suspended.

headline: Yemen Leader Leaves for Medical Care in New York
text: Yemen’s departing president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, left Yemen on Sunday and will travel to New York for medical treatment, Yemeni and American officials said.

headline: Talks With Taliban a Long Way Off, American Envoy Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — No peace talks with the Taliban this week: That was the short message on Sunday from the American envoy charged with starting those negotiations.

headline: Happily Up to Her Ears in Angst
text: The first song Kelly Clarkson sang for “American Idol” judges 10 years ago was “At Last,” the well-worn number popularized by Etta James that is used by bluesy performers to show their mettle. Maybe Ms. Clarkson rushed it a bit back then, smiled too much, did not quite nail the languor of the song. But she was delicate with the lyrics, and she showed off a voice that moved in all sorts of ways, without ever appearing to strain.

headline: ‘Underworld Awakening’ Leads at the Box Office
text: This is why Hollywood keeps churning out sequels: The fourth movie in Sony’s “Underworld” vampire series, “Underworld Awakening,” was an easy No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, taking in about $25.4 million despite winter storms that kept business light in parts of the United States. Solid ticket sales for “Underworld Awakening” were fueled by turnout for higher-priced Imax screens. Even so, this 3-D movie will need to perform well overseas to justify its cost of about $70 million, sharply higher than the budget for “Underworld: Rise of the Lycans” in 2009.

headline: Disruptions: Tech Valuations Defy the Restraints of Reality
text: On a recent Thursday night I stood motionless and perplexed on the dance floor of a San Francisco club. As I looked around, 300 or so people danced and darted back and forth to a free open bar while laser lights shot overhead. Cellphones glowed, like a video of luminescent jellyfish, as people snapped pictures and slung moments of the evening onto dozens of social networks.

headline: China Reports a Second Bird Flu Death in Less Than a Month
text: BEIJING — A man died in southern China on Sunday from the H5N1 bird flu virus, the Health Ministry reported. It was China’s second such death in less than a month.

headline: Stravinsky’s Travels, Recounted in Melody
text: There has been much debate about the Russian-ness of Stravinsky, who lived and worked away from his native country for most of his life. In a program called “Stravinsky Outside Russia,” on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, the conductor Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra offered selections that reflected both Stravinsky’s Russian heritage and the aesthetics of his adopted homelands.

headline: Sandusky Issues Statement About Paterno
text: Reaction to the death of Joe Paterno has come from retired and current coaches, former Penn State players and even a former president of the United States. But one statement may get a little more scrutiny than the others. Jerry Sandusky, the former assistant coach under Paterno who is accused of sexually abusing young boys — accusations that roiled the Penn State community and eventually led to Paterno’s firing last year — released a comment through his lawyer on Paterno’s death:

headline: Some See Two New Gilded Ages, Raising Global Tensions
text: NEW YORK — On a bitter evening in mid-January, a group of bankers and book publishers gathered on the 42nd floor of Goldman Sachs’s global headquarters here. The setting could not have been more New York — skyscrapers twinkled out the windows to the north and a jazz ensemble played softly in the corner. But the appetizers, reflecting the theme of the event, were an international mishmash: thumb-sized potato pancakes with sour cream and caviar, steaming Chinese dumplings, Indian samosas and Turkish kebabs.

headline: Metaphors of Movement Around the Spoken Word
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Bill T. Jones has long talked about his simultaneous attraction toward narration and abstraction, and about how his desire to lay claim to both of these artistic traditions has often left him in conflict. How to tell a good yarn but not be yoked to it structurally?

headline: Tomic Holds His Own Against Federer in Defeat
text: Roger Federer’s straight-sets win over Bernard Tomic was filled with long stretches of inspired play from both players. Unlike Rafael Nadal’s drubbing of his countryman Feliciano Lopez, which looked like a foregone conclusion early in the first set, the Federer-Tomic match had tense moments throughout, as Federer had to play at his sublime best to beat the rapidly improving Tomic.

headline: Let’s Raze Javits Center (but First Finish Renovations)
text: Part of architecture’s appeal, at least to architects, is posterity: the notion that what they design will last. So it came as something of a shock to the architect Bruce S. Fowle this month when he learned that a building he was renovating is already on death row.

headline: Coughlin Not Looking for Vindication, but Ahead to Indianapolis
text: San Francisco

headline: Like Knicks Fans, Nuggets Faithful Were Once Seduced by Anthony
text: Familiarity breeds contempt.

headline: Now Novices Can Try Ice Climbing in Wyoming
text: For seasoned ice climbers, the many cliffside springs and waterfalls banking the south fork of the Shoshone River near Cody, Wyo.  —  about 50 miles east of Yellowstone National Park  —  have long been popular. Now novices and anyone unfamiliar with the valley can get a toehold in the ice with new guided expeditions.

headline: In Middle of Winter, a Sunny Day at the Beach, and Death’s Shadow
text: When the curtain rises on Jerome Robbins’s “In G Major,” the first of three works on the “All Robbins” program performed by New York City Ballet on Friday at the David H. Koch Theater, the setting is simple but unmistakable. Stylized designs on the backdrop evoke sun, sea and sky. Young people gambol about in costumes resembling chic bathing wear. We’re at the French Riviera, between the wars.

headline: Costa Concordia May Have Had Unregistered Passengers
text: GIGLIO, Italy — As rescue workers recovered another body on Sunday from the wreck of the cruise ship Costa Concordia, bringing the death toll to 13, Italian officials offered their first explanation for the shifting numbers of missing people, saying that there may have been unregistered passengers aboard the ship.

headline: Veterans and Young Guns Pay Tribute to the Cuban Father of the Mambo
text: Carlos Henriquez stood front and center with his bass throughout “The Music of Cachao,” Jazz at Lincoln Center’s tribute to the pioneering Cuban bassist and composer Israel Cachao López on Friday night at the Rose Theater. This was, as Mr. Henriquez noted with a chuckle in the concert’s second half, a departure from his usual station near the back of the stage. But it made perfect sense: the tumbaos that boomed from Mr. Henriquez’s bass, in patterns more or less invented by Cachao, gave the music its flexible spine — along with a strong heartbeat, steady in its syncopations.

headline: New York Band, Worldly Desires
text: The 10th anniversary concert of the Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra couldn’t encompass all the ambitions of this remarkable New York institution, even in two generous sets on Friday night that kicked off the group’s two-night appearance at Symphony Space.

headline: François Hollande, Challenging Sarkozy, Calls for Change
text: PARIS — The Socialist Party candidate for the presidency of France, François Hollande, formally opened his campaign on Sunday with a passionate speech calling for change, equality and justice.

headline: Murdoch’s Trusted Outsider Takes a Larger Role
text: Last August, as News Corporation scrambled to contain a phone-hacking scandal at its British newspaper unit, Chase Carey, the company’s president and chief operating officer, proposed an idea to his boss, Rupert Murdoch: buy back $5 billion worth of stock.

headline: Searching the Brain for the Roots of Fear
text: You are taking a walk in the woods ― pleasant, invigorating, the sun shining through the leaves. Suddenly, a rattlesnake appears at your feet. You experience something at that moment. You freeze, your heart rate shoots up and you begin to sweat ― a quick, automatic sequence of physical reactions. That reaction is fear.

headline: A Jewish Museum Shifts Identity
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — The story of how the Judah L. Magnes Museum — whose collection of Judaica is the third largest in the country — became the Magnes Collection of Jewish Art and Life at the Bancroft Library of the University of California, Berkeley, might not seem terribly ripe with complication or implication. In recent years small private museums facing financial strain have often sought refuge by negotiating new lives within universities. Perhaps on Sunday, when the Magnes opened its doors to the public in a building it had long owned near the campus here, it was simply inaugurating another phase of its 50-year life.

headline: U.S. Drone Strike Kills Foreign Commander Fighting for Militants in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A senior foreign commander fighting with Shabab Islamic militants was killed in an American drone strike a few miles south of the capital over the weekend, according to Shabab officials.

headline: ‘Superfly’ in the Air, Corpses in the Trees
text: George Pelecanos’s latest book, “What It Was,” sends his best stock character into an extended 40-year flashback. It begins in a Washington bar, where a song by the Dramatics gets Derek Strange to thinking about the summer of 1972. He was 26. Bell-bottoms and Afros were everywhere. “Fly” was an adjective, as in “regal and fly in their natural hairstyles and up-to-the-minute fashions.” The soundtrack from “Superfly” was on every jukebox not playing the soundtrack from “Shaft.”

headline: Apple And Agglomeration
text: The big Times article on Apple manufacturing was excellent, and I’ll have more to say about it when I have the time. One thing worth noting right away, however, is that the piece is in large part an essay on the economies of agglomeration (pdf, wonkish):

headline: At Rye Brook Open Pairs, the Better of Two X’s
text: The Open Pairs on Jan. 13 at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., was an A/X event. That meant there were two flights: A for players with more than 5,000 master points and X for those with fewer points.

headline: Good Fortune, and Penalty Kick, Help Manchester City
text: If Manchester City is to become England’s champion after 44 years of longing for that title, its followers around the world might remember Sunday as the day Lady Luck finally bestowed her full favors on the Blues.

headline: A Beloved Set of Strings Goes to a Good Home
text: It is considered one of the greatest cellos in the world, a beautifully preserved product of Antonio Stradivari that was once owned by Nicolò Paganini and most recently by Bernard Greenhouse, a founding member of the Beaux Arts Trio. Mr. Greenhouse played the cello for a half century, and after his death last year, his family decided to sell it, hoping it would go to a deserving musician.

headline: Underground Metal and Hardcore, Set Aflame
text: All Pigs Must Die sits right where hardcore and underground metal intersect. Its Rosetta Stone might be the first LPs by Negative Approach, Discharge and Slayer, melted together. About half of the band’s total stance, titles to lyrics to singing, seems inflexible, nonnegotiable.

headline: ‘The Artist’ Wins Producers Guild Prize
text: “The Artist” has made its way to pole position in the movie awards race. This black-and-white, largely silent film, starring Jean Dujardin, above, with Uggie, picked up the top prize, best feature, from the Producers Guild of America, which announced its winners on Saturday night in Los Angeles. The guild has followed the lead of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in nominating 10 films for best picture in the last two years. It has also accurately predicted the eventual best-picture Oscar winner, even in the expanded field. When it chose “The Hurt Locker” over the much higher-grossing “Avatar” in 2010, awards watchers considered it a bellwether prize. (Though the Academy may nominate anywhere from 5 to 10 films this year, the Producers Guild stuck with 10.) Steven Spielberg’s “Adventures of Tintin” won best animated film, and “Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest” earned the documentary feature prize. ABC’s hit “Modern Family” took home the first award of the night, for best TV comedy, and “Downton Abbey” (PBS) won for best long-form show. “Boardwalk Empire” (HBO) picked up best drama, beating “Mad Men” (AMC). “The Amazing Race” (CBS) won for television competition, and “The Colbert Report” (Comedy Central) won for talk show.

headline: Footnote
text: The American Ballet Theater is to announce on Monday that Ethan Stiefel, a principal dancer for the theater since 1997, will retire at the end of the 2012 Metropolitan Opera House season. His final performance is scheduled for July 7 as part of the company’s production of “Le Corsaire,” according to a statement from the theater. “Although it is not easy to step away from performing, I am gladdened by the fact that I have other invaluable opportunities to continue to contribute to the art form,” Mr. Stiefel said in the statement. “I am deeply grateful to everyone who has helped to shape my success as an artist and has supported me throughout the years.” He became the artistic director of Royal New Zealand Ballet in September.

headline: Harding
text: I gather that they’re still trying to claim that the recovery from the 1920-21 recession somehow vindicates austerity policies.

headline: Marketers, Seeking Family Show, Hold Script Contest
text: FOR several years, marketers like Frito-Lay and General Motors have sponsored contests asking consumers to create television commercials, with winning spots appearing on shows including the Super Bowl. Now, a group of marketers has expanded the idea by sponsoring a contest asking consumers to create shows.

headline: A Lesson in Anatomy
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Did everyone do their homework, class? Welcome to Anatomy 101, where everything is on the final but, this being Monday, the class is an easy A.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include pending home sales for December (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, durable goods for December, new-home sales for December and leading economic indicators for December (Thursday); and gross domestic product for the fourth quarter and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for January (Friday).

headline: Drake Feels the Indie-Film Love
text: PARK CITY, Utah – Insert your own sweater joke here: Somehow the knitwear-loving rapper Drake arrived at the one place most welcoming to a cozy cardigan, during a blizzard no less, wearing just a black T-shirt, some gold chains and a parka.

headline: Final: A.F.C. Championship, Patriots  23, Ravens 20
text: In a back-and-forth battle that ended in heartbreak for the Baltimore Ravens and kicker Billy Cundiff, the New England Patriots advanced to Super Bowl XLVI with a 23-20 victory on Sunday.

headline: Women’s Draw Has Contrasting Styles
text: The two matches in the top half of the women’s draw at the Australian Open represent contrasting approaches to playing tennis. In a phrase, it’s offense versus defense.

text: The New York City Ballet performed works by Jerome Robbins.

headline: Final: N.F.C. Championship, Giants 20, 49ers 17, OT
text: Lawrence Tynes kicked a 31-yard field goal almost eight minutes into overtime Sunday to give the Giants a 20-17 victory over the San Francisco 49ers in the N.F.C. championship game at Candlestick Park.

headline: Magnes Collection of Jewish Art and Life
text: Images from the museum at the University of California, Berkeley.

headline: Patriots’ Defense Holds, and Ravens Miss a Last-Second Kick
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — For some franchises, four years is a fragment of time. For the New England Patriots, it is a millennium. Their transformation over that span has been swift and overarching. Their offense, if possible, is more capable and explosive. Their defense is not as formidable or feared. The imbalance created the perception that they were too flawed, too unreliable, to restore glory to Patriot Place.

headline: Cameras May Open Up the Board Room to Hackers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — One afternoon this month, a hacker took a tour of a dozen conference rooms around the globe via equipment that most every company has in those rooms; videoconferencing equipment.

headline: Bird-Watchers Revel in Unusual Spike in Snowy Owl Sightings
text: HELENA, Mont. — From coast to coast across the northern United States, a striking number of snowy owls have been swooping onto shorelines and flying over fields this winter, delighting bird-watchers and stirring speculation about the cause of the spike.

headline: How Esquire Survived Publishing’s Dark Days
text: Esquire magazine, a monument to male vitality, seemed about to keel over in 2009. Famous for laying down a much-followed literary track with an article in 1966 by Gay Talese titled “Frank Sinatra Has a Cold,” the magazine found itself gasping for breath and fighting for survival.

headline: In Florida, Romney Seeks to Link Gingrich to Foreclosure Crisis
text: ORMOND BEACH, Fla., — Less than 24 hours after his disappointing showing in the South Carolina primary, Mitt Romney took his campaign fight to Florida, linking the mortgage foreclosure crisis here – the nation’s worst – to his rival, Newt Gingrich, the victor in the South Carolina contest.

headline: A Mother’s Love and Her Pregame Profanity Sustain a Giant in the Trenches
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — An hour before each opening kickoff, Dave Tollefson retreats to a quiet area of the Giants’ locker room to perform his pregame ritual: a call to his mother. She, in turn, provides support in a manner more mouthy than motherly: a loud, profanity-laced pep talk.

headline: Bruins’ Ference Suspended for Hit on Rangers’ McDonagh
text: Andrew Ference of the Bruins was suspended for three games by the N.H.L. on Sunday for a check on Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh in overtime of the Rangers’ 3-2 victory Saturday in Boston.

headline: How About Not Bombing Iran?
text: If you need more convincing of the grave risks of a preemptive bombing attack on Iran, I recommend these freshly published arguments from Colin H. Kahl, who was until recently Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for the Middle East in the Obama administration; R. Nicholas Burns, who was Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs in the George W. Bush administration; and my Times colleague Roger Cohen, who sums it up this way:

headline: The Film Archivist of Legendary Football Preps for Game Day
text: When N.F.L. Films put a microphone on the Denver Broncos’ surprise star Tim Tebow during a game against the Chicago Bears last month, it knew that every one of its television partners would want a piece of the audio and video of the quarterback.

headline: Mary C. Henderson, Author and Scholar of Theater History, Dies at 83
text: Mary C. Henderson, a scholar of the theater whose interests as a historian and curator spanned centuries and as a Tony nominator and critic were up to the minute, died on Jan. 3 at her home in Congers, N.Y. She was 83.

headline: ‘Hunger Games’ Book Sales Bode Well for the Film
text: Lionsgate’s movie adaptation of “The Hunger Games” does not arrive in theaters until March 23 — still too far away for analysts to predict ticket revenue. But if spiking sales of the books are any indication, Lionsgate’s marketing efforts are whipping up a five-alarm box-office fire.

headline: Edgar Kaiser Jr. Dies at 69; Owned Denver Broncos
text: Starting in 1914, Henry J. Kaiser built one of the world’s largest business empires, encompassing ships, cement, steel, aluminum and even kitchen sinks. In the 1970s his grandson Edgar F. Kaiser Jr. began methodically dismantling it — even as he built his own.

headline: Line of Scrimmage Forms Over Union Bill
text: INDIANAPOLIS — This city is in full preen for its moment in the spotlight, its first Super Bowl. Everywhere, workers sprouted from cherry pickers over the weekend, hanging football banners from signposts, windows, buildings. The constant beeping of machinery backing up filled the air as an 800-foot zip line was built in a Super Bowl Village that is emerging downtown. And right outside the Statehouse, the intersection formally known as Capitol and Washington has fancy new honorary street signs — Dolphins Drive and Browns Boardwalk.

headline: New York’s Bad Bet
text: Philadelphia

headline: Flora, Now in English
text: BOTANISTS long thought the tallest trees on Madagascar all belonged to only three species of the genus Canarium, but two scientists have now determined that there are actually 35 species of the genus there, of which 29 are new to science.
