headline: Federer Heads Into 1,000th Tour Match
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — One thousand tennis matches. In a career full of major milestones, here comes another for Roger Federer, who will hit quadruple digits when he hits his first ball against Juan Martín del Potro in their Australian Open quarterfinal on Tuesday.

headline: Mistaken Early Report on Paterno Roiled Web
text: A rapid succession of journalistic slip-ups on Saturday night led to the spread of false news reports of the death of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State coach, more than 12 hours before his doctors and family members said he had died.

headline: A Week of Challenges and Potential for Romney
text: Mitt Romney enters Florida on Monday wounded by his political collapse in South Carolina and facing a central challenge for his candidacy: How to regain the initiative after being forced for weeks into a defensive crouch.

headline: Sharing a Screen, if Not a Classroom
text: In a hushed first-grade classroom at Public School 55 in the South Bronx, Edward Muñoz, a bashful 7-year-old in scuffed sneakers and a worn hoodie, was sounding out tricky words with his tutor.

headline: A Day That Seemed as if It Would Never Come: Uncle Chichi’s Last
text: Uncle Chichi, a toy poodle whose unusual longevity led to fame and an appearance on “Good Morning America,” died on Tuesday after a yearlong battle with cancer. He was 26. Or 24. Or maybe 25.

headline: Why Politicians Get Away With Lying
text: What sort of lies do people accept from political candidates, and which do they object to?

headline: For Paterno, Lover of Classics, Tragic Flaw to a Legacy
text: Joe Paterno loved the classics. He quoted Shakespeare to his team, devoured the poems of Virgil and donated his money to help save Penn State’s classics department, even endowing a scholarship in the name of his high school Latin teacher, the Rev. Thomas Bermingham.

headline: Dissent in the Jobs Council
text: At Disney World last week, President Obama announced new executive orders to speed up visas for foreign tourists to the United States. The measure, a priority for the travel industry, was one of several sensible recommendations made in the last year by Mr. Obama’s Council on Jobs and Competitiveness, a 27-member panel of corporate executives, academics, investors and labor leaders. The White House has carried out 17 others so far.

headline: Fed Begins an Effort to Remove All Doubt on What It’s Doing
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, which does not like to surprise financial markets, has worked unusually hard to prepare the public for the changes to its communications policies that it plans to introduce on Wednesday.

headline: After Tumultuous Events at Penn State, Death Adds to the Anguish
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. —  They crunched across the snow-blanketed campus Sunday to lay flowers at his statue, to gather for a candlelight vigil outside the Old Main administration building and to simply glance at his home while they walked past. Waves of students, alumni and fans were paying their respects to the man they knew as JoePa.

headline: Mr. Gingrich’s Deceptions
text: Newt Gingrich’s victory in South Carolina turned on an almost comically broad deception, an inversion of the truth in which the insider whose personal wealth and political experience are entirely creations of Washington becomes the anti-establishment candidate. That it worked speaks poorly of voters who let themselves be manipulated by the lowest form of campaigning, appealing to their anger and prejudices.

headline: Pakistan Court Widens Role, Stirring Fears for Stability
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Once they were heroes, cloaked justices at the vanguard of a powerful revolt against military rule in Pakistan, buoyed by pugnacious lawyers and an adoring public. But now Pakistan’s Supreme Court is waging a campaign of judicial activism that has pitted it against an elected civilian government, in a legal fight that many Pakistanis fear could damage their fragile democracy and open the door to a fresh military intervention.

headline: The Emerging Gilded Age
text: As IHT Rendezvous kicks off a week of special coverage of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Chrystia Freeland, an IHT Page Two columnist and Reuters’s global editor at large, writes about the new Gilded Age.

headline: Young Strivers in Two Worlds
text: What is it like to get up at 3 every morning to leave the country to go to school? To walk for miles and wait in long lines at an international crossing, to hustle along by trolley and bus, worrying all the while about missing the 8 a.m. bell? This is the bleary-eyed world of young Mexican-Americans who live in Tijuana and go to school in Chula Vista, Calif., as described by Patricia Leigh Brown in The Times. These striving students, or “transfronterizos,” are not immigrants but American citizens, lawfully crossing the border to get an education.

headline: Searching Through Brooklyn
text: Just as Americans visit the Old World in search of family roots, tourists are showing up at the Brooklyn Historical Society, in hopes of tracking down their grandparents’ neighborhood ties and old houses — brownstones in Park Slope, row houses in Bay Ridge — in the New World. As usual, Walt Whitman anticipated the future: “There will come a time here in Brooklyn and all over America, when nothing will be of more interest than authentic reminiscences of the past.”

headline: After a Legal Setback, Commodity Traders’ Complaint Is to Be Heard by a Lower Court
text: Wall Street’s legal challenge to a regulatory crackdown met a procedural obstacle last week, when a federal appeals court dismissed the case.

headline: Ai Weiwei: Evolution of a Dissident
text: The filmmaker Alison Klayman presents an exclusive look at the Chinese dissident artist Ai Weiwei and his struggle for the freedom of expression.

headline: Ai Weiwei: The Evolution of a Dissident
text: I have always believed that the story of the dissident artist Ai Weiwei is not about how censorship stifles creativity, but rather how one artist is able to work around such obstacles.  It’s not about the system crushing individual expression, but about the power of an individual in the face of forces greater than himself. One thing is clear — Ai Weiwei’s story could not be possible without the Internet. We cannot imagine an Ai Weiwei without the megaphone of blogs and Twitter, without the ability to communicate instantaneously and connect to like-minded netizens around China and the globe.

headline: Bowing to Critics and Market Forces, RIM’s Co-Chiefs Step Aside
text: OTTAWA — Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis, who made the BlackBerry a leading business tool but then presided over its precipitous decline, said they would step down on Monday as co-chairmen and co-chief executives of Research in Motion.

headline: G.O.P. Ventures Into Florida, a State Harder to Pigeonhole
text: TAMPA, Fla. — After three bruising contests that each produced different winners, the Republican nominating contest has moved to a state that is much more like the rest of America in its diversity, its multiplicity of media markets and its voter base, which is less likely to be swayed by the family values issues that played a dominant role in prior contests in Iowa and South Carolina.

headline: Photo Replay: A.F.C. Championship Game
text: The New England Patriots beat the Baltimore Ravens, 23-20, to earn a Super Bowl berth.

headline: Gingrich and Romney Trade Jabs as G.O.P. Race Rolls On
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney, facing a restive Republican Party and a resurgent Newt Gingrich, opened a combative new phase of the presidential campaign on Monday and warned of the prospect of an “October surprise” if Mr. Gingrich emerged as the party’s nominee.

headline: For M.T.A. and Union, Obstacles Delay a Contract
text: One week after the expiration of a labor contract between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Transport Workers Union Local 100, there is no shortage of evidence that the two sides are far apart on a new deal.

headline: Rising Strife Threatens Tenuous Iraqi Stability
text: BAGHDAD — Violence and political instability have escalated across Iraq since the withdrawal of American forces, as political and sectarian factions have fought for power and influence in a struggle that, within weeks, has threatened to undo the stability that allowed the pullout in the first place.

headline: More Lockouts as Companies Battle Unions
text: America’s unionized workers, buffeted by layoffs and stagnating wages, face another phenomenon that is increasingly throwing them on the defensive: lockouts.

headline: Arab League Floats Ambitious New Peace Plan for Syria
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Faced with the failure of its observer mission to curb the violence here as the stark features of a civil war emerge, the Arab League on Sunday unexpectedly floated an ambitious peace proposal that would require President Bashar al-Assad to hand over power to a deputy and start negotiations with his opponents within two weeks.

headline: Flacco Outshines Brady, but Team Comes Up Short
text: FOXBOROUGH , Mass. — He outplayed Tom Brady. Even the most ardent Brady supporter would have to acknowledge that on Sunday, Joe Flacco outshone the New England Patriots’ star quarterback.

headline: As Closed-Door Redistricting Drags On, Incumbents’ Edge Only Grows
text: ALBANY — Howard Leib, a 53-year-old entertainment lawyer, is considering a run for the New York State Senate this year.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Under the Name of a Senate Hopeful, Blog Posts on Sex and Drugs
text: As he travels New York trying to build support for a Senate candidacy, Marc Cenedella has impressed Republican leaders with his Ivy League credentials, his success in building a business and his promise to tap his wealth in the race.

headline: In Egypt, Signs of Accord Between Military Council and Islamists
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s first freely elected Parliament in more than 60 years sits for its first session on Monday, charged primarily with overseeing preparation of a new constitution after the ouster of the strongman Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Bomb-Bomb-Bomb, Bomb-Bomb-Iran?
text: O.K., Mr. President, here’s the plan. Sometime in the next few months you order the Department of Defense to destroy Iran’s nuclear capacity. Yes, I know it’s an election year, and some people will say this is a cynical rally-round-the-flag move on your part, but a nuclear Iran is a problem that just won’t wait.

headline: Former Catcher for Red Sox Wins Case Against Merrill Lynch Adviser
text: Nearly five years after he earned his second World Series ring, Doug Mirabelli has another big win.

headline: Is Our Economy Healing?
text: How goes the state of the union? Well, the state of the economy remains terrible. Three years after President Obama’s inauguration and two and a half years since the official end of the recession, unemployment remains painfully high.

headline: In Race to the Top, the Dirty Work Is Left to Those on the Bottom
text: Even if you think the Obama administration’s signature education program, Race to the Top, will not help a single child in America learn more, you have to admire its bureaucratic magnificence.

headline: Desperate in TV Fight, Some Knicks Fans Buy Tickets
text: Their new star was facing his old team. Their old favorites were returning under the lights of Madison Square Garden. Yet many Knicks partisans could not watch the game on television because of a nasty dispute between Time Warner Cable and the MSG channels, and for those fans, options were limited.

headline: From Unyielding Cameraman, an Acclaimed Film
text: BILIN, West Bank — Emad Burnat was born to the land and, like generations of his family in this hilltop West Bank village, he has eked out a modest living from its rocky soil. But six years ago, at the birth of a son, he was given a video camera and turned unexpectedly into the village chronicler.

headline: In Britain, Rising Outcry Over Executive Pay That Makes ‘People’s Blood Boil’
text: LONDON —  As company boards prepare to vote on the annual compensation of their senior executives, investors and the government in Britain are pushing for ways to shrink what some have called excessive pay packages.

headline: For Giffords, House Comeback Is One Too Many
text: WASHINGTON — For months, Representative Gabrielle Giffords, who was shot in the head in an assassination attempt last year, signaled that returning to Congress, something she desperately longed to do, was in the realm of the possible.

headline: Croatia Votes 2 to 1 to Join European Union
text: BRUSSELS — Croats voted by a two-to-one margin on Sunday to join the European Union, signaling that the bloc retains its allure despite the debt crisis engulfing the euro currency that many of its members use.

headline: Tablet and E-Reader Sales Soar
text: There was no must-have toy of Christmas 2011 — for youngsters, anyway.

headline: Over Turkish Protests, French Lawmakers to Vote on Bill Penalizing Genocide Denial
text: PARIS — The French Senate is scheduled to vote on Monday on a law that would penalize those who deny genocide, taking another step along a path that has already damaged France’s relations with Turkey.

headline: Doubt Cast on Threat That Deterred Rushdie
text: JAIPUR, India — At an old Mughal palace accommodating what organizers called “the greatest literary show on earth,” the headliners on Sunday included Oprah Winfrey, Deepak Chopra and Tom Stoppard. But the absence of another star, Salman Rushdie, continued to overshadow the event.

headline: Many Freed Burmese Weren’t Jailed for Politics
text: WASHINGTON — Fewer than half of the 651 prisoners the Myanmar government announced it was releasing 10 days ago were political prisoners, according to two human rights groups that have compiled lists of those released. Petty criminals, whose sentences are being commuted, were among the rest.

headline: Kvitova Beats Ivanovic in Battle of Fraying Nerves
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Petra Kvitova, the reigning Wimbledon women’s champion, shook off a case of nerves to eliminate Ana Ivanovic, whose own nerves betrayed her on the verge of tying the match in the fourth round of the Australian Open on Monday.

headline: In Guatemala, Former Dictator Is Told to Appear in Court
text: MEXICO CITY — A Guatemalan judge has ordered a former military dictator, Efraín Ríos Montt, to appear in court on Thursday, the first step in a process that could lead to his being tried on genocide charges and to a reopening of the darkest chapter in Guatemala’s brutal 36-year civil war.

headline: Gingrich Bets on Attack Mode Against News Media
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — They were Newt Gingrich’s other adversaries in the South Carolina primary and they helped define his surge to victory as much as Mitt Romney, Rick Santorum and Ron Paul did.

headline: Field Goal by Tynes in Overtime Sets Up a Rematch in the Super Bowl
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The ball skittered sideways, shooting out of the punt returner’s grasp, bouncing into Giants lore.

headline: Thérèse Delpech, French Political Adviser, Dies at 63
text: PARIS — Thérèse Delpech, one of France’s leading foreign policy analysts and intellectual historians, died on Wednesday at her apartment in Paris. She was 63.

headline: Manning Delivers Again, Earning Hug and Praise From Brother
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As the Giants went through their various transformations this season — from a running team to a passing team, from a weak defense to a stout one — the constant was always Eli Manning in the fourth quarter. It did not matter what had happened to the Giants early in the game; a heavy dose of Manning late was the cure for all that ailed them.

text: Oregon Coach Chip Kelly has emerged as the front-runner to become the next head coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, a move that could cause a seismic shake-up in college football.

headline: Special Parking Rules in New York City
text: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Monday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Short of a Win, Garrigus Happy to Have Been in Such a Position
text: LA QUINTA, Calif. — The sun had dipped behind the mountains Sunday by the time Robert Garrigus reached the 18th green at the Palmer Course at PGA West, but it was not nearly as dark as it felt when he stood in the same spot in broad daylight three days earlier.

headline: Early Look at Giants-Patriots Matchup
text: The New England Patriots are back in the Super Bowl, despite the best efforts of their opponents and the preferences of millions of fans who are weary of their mix of arrogant excellence and excellent arrogance. The Jets tried to beat them with rhetoric, the Denver Broncos with an Elvis-strength cultural juggernaut, the Baltimore Ravens with everything but a healthy kicker. But nothing could stop Bill Belichick and Tom Brady from returning to the Super Bowl for the fifth time in 11 seasons. Judging by the chip-shot field goal the Ravens missed at the end of the Patriots’ 23-20 A.F.C. championship game victory, New England is again augmenting its considerable skill with some timely doses of good luck, the way it did in its rise to dominance a decade ago.

headline: Photo Replay: N.F.C. Championship Game
text: A look at the Giants’ 20-17 victory over the 49ers in San Francisco, which sent the Giants to the Super Bowl against the New England Patriots.

headline: Manchester 2, London 0
text: Sunday was yet another big day in Manchester City’s pursuit of the Premier League title, and a 3-2 win over Tottenham will surely be vital to that quest, since it kept City three points ahead of Manchester United.

headline: Strange Bedfellows in the Conflict with Iran
text: 1:29 p.m. | Updated  Europe agrees to impose oil embargo and other sanctions on Iran

headline: Serena Williams Suffers Rare Loss in Melbourne
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It is still a surprise when Serena Williams fails to claw her way out of a bad place against an unseeded player, but it was no shock that it happened at the Australian Open this year.

headline: Tsonga Falls to Nishikori in 5-Set Drama
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Kei Nishikori of Japan barged into the quarterfinals of the Australian Open on Monday with a five-set upset victory over Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France. Struggling from a set down, Nishikori surged back into the match after an unusual 10-minute suspension while officials and workers punctured and tamped down a section of court that had bubbled.

headline: Rattled Heritage: Sikkim’s Monasteries after the Quake
text: For a week after the Sept. 18 earthquake, many towns in Sikkim were cut off from the outside world. The roads slowly became passable and as they did, photographs and video clips began to circulate. Rumors traveled too, especially that the major monasteries – Pemayangtse, Dubdi, Tashiding and Ringhim – were barely standing and that some of the smaller monasteries in Khechiperi and Hongdi had been obliterated.

headline: The Patriots Have No Shot Against the Giants. Just Ask Them.
text: The Patriots hadn’t even carried their A.F.C. championship trophy off the podium on Sunday and already Tom Brady was discussing the one person who had nearly kept them from winning it at all. Namely, Tom Brady.

headline: Navratilova Backs Kvitova; Criticizes Ranking System
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It shouldn’t be surprising to hear one Czech lefty standing by another, but the conviction with which Martina Navratilova defended No. 2-ranked Petra Kvitova was something to be noticed.

headline: Stalemate Deals Grief and Fury in Syria
text: HOMS, Syria — Women threw rice onto three coffins draped with the country’s flag, a tribute to young men of marrying age who died in the violence that is ripping this city apart.

headline: News Quiz | Jan. 23, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: Jan. 23, 1973 | Nixon Announces End of U.S. Involvement in Vietnam
text: On Jan. 23, 1973, President Richard Nixon announced an accord had been reached to end the Vietnam War. In a televised speech, Nixon said the accord would “end the war and bring peace with honor.”

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 23, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Private Sector Gets Job Skills; Public Gets Bill.”

headline: Not to Everyone’s Taste
text: HONG KONG — For weeks now, in the prelude to the Lunar New Year holiday that started Monday in Asia, the ramshackle restaurants along Nhât Tân Street in Hanoi have been jammed with patrons. Happens every New Year. The menus feature meat prepared seven different ways, and the meals, which typically cost about $15, almost always include heroic drinking bouts with rice wine or the local turpentine called ruou.

headline: More of the Same — but Different
text: Paul Octavious never calls the hill from his series “Same Hill, Different Day” by name.

headline: Ringing In the Year of the Dragon
text: Chinese New Year starts today. To mark the beginning of the Year of the Dragon, we pose questions that link to a variety of Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about the holiday and its cultural significance and traditions.

headline: Europe and U.S. Tighten Vise of Sanctions on Iran
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union agreed Monday to impose a phased ban on oil purchases from Iran that officials said was needed to help force a shift in policy and avert the risk of military strikes against Tehran, as the United States expanded its sanctions to include the country’s third-largest bank.

headline: In Paris, Examining the Art of Cuisine
text: The city of light is home to the fourth annual Paris des Chefs festival, an event that seeks to blend cooking and art by having chefs prepare food with a creative partner.

headline: What Is Your Most Memorable Writing Assignment?
text: Chances are, you’ve had many, many writing assignments for school over the years. Whether paragraphs or autobiographies, term papers or journal entries, some of them probably stand out in your memory. What are they? What makes them so memorable?

headline: Apache to Buy Cordillera Energy for $2.85 Billion

headline: From Hero’s Parent to Politician
text: TEL AVIV — Last week, I spoke to a Knesset member from the Kadima Party. The party is losing ground to more fashionable players just entering Israel’s political fray: it holds 28 seats, and a recent poll found that it would win only 11 if elections were held now. I toyed with my phonemate, joking that he should make sure he’s in one of Kadima’s first ten slots or else he’d soon have to find a new job. “Well, what can I do?” he said, “No family member of mine was ever kidnapped, so I guess I don’t have much chance.”

headline: This Week in Small Business: Gross National Happiness
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Cooking With Bill Belichick
text: Bill Belichick may beat the Giants in the Super Bowl in two weeks. He will almost certainly wind up in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. And, Spygate or no Spygate, he may one day be considered the game’s greatest coach.

headline: A Retro-Futuristic Coif
text: For anyone who needs visual inducement to see “Richard III” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, there is Haydn Gwynne’s hair. Coiled to perfection in a manner reminiscent of Wallis Simpson, it lends authority to Queen Elizabeth, Ms. Gwynne’s steely character, and provides the production with a moment of chic.

headline: Daily Report: RIM’s Co-Chiefs Step Aside
text: Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis, who made the BlackBerry the indispensable business tool but then presided over its precipitous decline, said they would step down on Monday as co-chief executives of Research in Motion, reports Ian Austen of The New York Times. The move, while surprising, is not expected to herald major changes at the company. The new chief executive, Thorsten Heins, is one of RIM’s two chief operating officers. He pledged during an interview on Sunday to follow the strategy Mr. Balsillie and Mr. Lazaridis set in place.

headline: Redistricting and Increased Partisanship Fuel House Departures
text: The race for the exits is gaining steam in the United States House of Representatives.

headline: Patriots Open as 3-Point Favorites in Super Bowl
text: The Giants have already beaten the Patriots this season, on the road, but they are not favored to beat the Patriots in two weeks in Indianapolis. The general public’s familiarity with Bill Belichick, Tom Brady and the long-term excellence of the Patriots no doubt played a role in the Super Bowl opening line, which is intended to spur maximum betting, balanced on both sides.

headline: Increasing Internet Can Raise G.D.P., Study Says
text: India’s economy can grow more than 1 percent with every 10 percent increase in Internet subscribers, according to a New Delhi economic policy think tank.

headline: Home, Home … on Less Range
text: To see how thoroughly the concept of ecosystem services — the economic analysis of the natural world’s intersection with human endeavors — is embedded in climate change research, check out this forecast from a group led by researchers at Duke University and the Environmental Defense Fund.

headline: Ticket Talk at the Circuit of the Americas
text: The Circuit of the Americas, the race track in Austin, Texas, where the U.S. Grand Prix is supposed to take place on Nov. 18, opened on Monday a “select seating” waiting list for tickets to the race on its Web site. Actual sales of tickets for the race will not begin until “early summer,” according to a circuit statement.

text: The Circuit of the Americas, the race track in Austin, Texas, where the U.S. Grand Prix is supposed to take place on Nov. 18, opened on Monday a “select seating” waiting list for tickets to the race on its Web site. Actual sales of tickets for the race will not begin until “early summer,” according to a circuit statement.

headline: Five Questions for: Chandrahas Choudhury
text: India Ink is asking authors attending the Jaipur Literature Festival five questions about writing and about themselves. Heather Timmons caught up with the author of “Arzee the Dwarf” and “India – A Traveller’s Literary Companion.”

headline: Opinion Report: The Transfronterizos

headline: Why Bradshaw’s Fumble Wasn’t a Fumble
text: The N.F.C. title game had become a stalemate. It seemed that a turnover might be decisive. The Niners’ Kyle Williams had two. And the Giants had none — with one very close call.

headline: Bullying Changes a School, One Child at a Time
text: A middle school teacher writes about one of her students: 'The true danger of bullying is the way that it changes kids.  After weeks of feeling defensive and guarded, Rocky began to hide her sweet softness. Enough of this transformation in children, and the environment of a school is changed.'

headline: Touring a School? Look Beyond the Superficial
text: If you are shopping around for a school for your child, you may be looking back on the open houses you've attended or ahead to upcoming school visits. Either way, a little expert advice might help you process the experience. Here are some tips from a consultant on school placement.

headline: A Focus on Teachers and Teaching
text: UPDATED | Teachers, teachers, teachers. This was the focus of the education news in the city this weekend, from reports that the state is closer to an evaluation system to a touching account in an opinion column about how one teacher changed the life of one troubled student.

headline: Image of the Day: January 23
text: India’s Agni 4 missile featured in the Republic Day dress rehearsal in New Delhi.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Bad Year for Wall St. Not Reflected in Chiefs’ Pay  |  Wall Street stocks and profits took a beating in 2011. But there is one corner of the Street that took a lighter hit: the compensation paid to chief executives.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Rupert’s Man for Now and Looking Up at Esquire
text: Chase Carey, the president and chief operating officer of News Corporation, was long seen as a placeholder until one of the Murdoch children could take full control of the company. But the hacking scandal in London has complicated succession plans, and Mr. Carey, the blunt long-time aide, has filled the vacuum, writes Amy Chozick: “Never in the $60 billion media company’s history has an executive other than Mr. Murdoch taken such a major role in running the daily operations.” He has, she writes, become particularly critical in getting Rupert Murdoch to focus on the stock price and in soothing Wall Street.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Be Near Sale of British Wealth Manager
text: 9:46 a.m. | Updated

headline: Eli Manning’s Durability on Display
text: You might remember that Brett Favre was the leader in N.F.L. consecutive starts. And then that Peyton Manning took over that title among quarterbacks.

headline: Larry and the Invisibles
text: Ryan Lizza’s new piece on policymaking in the Obama administration is out. One of the documents the piece rests on is a December 2008 policy memo from Larry Summers to Obama on the size and composition of stimulus; Ryan shared it with me to get my take, and some of what I said is reflected in his article.

headline: For an Israeli Director, the Oscar Ceremony Gets Interesting After It’s Over
text: At the age of 43, the American-born Israeli director Joseph Cedar is already a veteran of the Oscar process. Israel has submitted all four of the feature films he has made as official selections. His previous project, “Beaufort,” about Israeli soldiers in the waning days of the war in Lebanon, was a nominee for the Oscar for best foreign-language film in 2008, and his latest film, “Footnote,” was named this week to the shortlist of nine films contending for this year’s Oscar. On Tuesday, he’ll find out if he’s one of the five nominees.

headline: Paris Top 5 | Lanvin
text: The Lanvin runway show took the lion’s share of this season’s trends and solidified them in a singular stroke. The designers Alber Elbaz and Lucas Ossendrijver combined the many amazing but disparate sides of the season –– belted coats, drop shoulders, soft tailoring, proportion, fabric mash-ups, leather and motocross –– and wrapped them all into a collection that was clear, understandable and one of the house’s most wearable yet. Here, a nylon bomber jacket “applied” to a coat over a black-tie outfit deftly interprets the unselfconscious, random art of layering during a big city winter.

headline: More Than You Want To Know About Warren Harding
text: Yesterday I mentioned that they’re still flogging the old line that Warren Harding proved that austerity works. I linked to my old demonstration that the 1921 economy was nowhere near the liquidity trap, and that there was substantial monetary easing, making comparisons to the current situation nonsense.

headline: Tale of Comic Adventures Wins Newbery Medal
text: A sly, gothic and quasi-autobiographical tale of a boy who is grounded by his parents and sent to type obituaries for a neighbor, leading to a string of comic adventures, won the John Newbery Medal on Monday for the year’s most outstanding contribution to children’s literature.

headline: Egypt’s Islamist Parliament
text: As Egypt’s Parliament holds its first session Monday following confirmation Saturday that Islamists had won nearly 70 percent of the seats, opinion writers are assessing what it could mean for the country and the region.

headline: Leading Off: And Then There Were Two
text: In the end, the Super Bowl combatants were not decided by magnificent touchdowns or beautiful interceptions. They were chosen by fate seemingly for their grit and stubbornness, two teams that don’t question themselves when doubt starts raining down on them. They just dig in and refuse to go away.

headline: Soccer’s Battle of the Financial Davids and Goliaths
text: The Beatles told us that money can’t buy you love.

headline: New RIM Chief Not Looking to Split Company
text: Despite the problems at Research in Motion, the company’s incoming chief executive says he is not entertaining the idea of splitting the company into two separate businesses.

headline: After Giants vs. Patriots, It Could Be Christie vs. Bloomberg
text: Stunningly, some would go so far as to say miraculously, the New York Giants of New Jersey are going to the Super Bowl. You know what this means, don’t you? For the next two weeks there may be cross-border skirmishing over whether the west bank or the east bank of the Hudson River gets to organize the celebration if the team wins the big game, scheduled for Feb. 5 in Indianapolis.

headline: Breach of Trust
text: Since I just gave Larry Summers a bit of a hard time over that distressing Dec. 2008 memo to Obama, this is probably a good time to note that way back when he and Andrei Shleifer wrote an essay on the economics of leveraged buyouts (pdf) that is very worth reading now that Mitt Romney is running on the theme that his Bain experience means that he knows how to create jobs.

headline: AbortionDocs.Org
text: You know those Western-style “Wanted” posters that anti-abortion activists liked to distribute? The ones with the names and addresses of doctors who perform the constitutionally protected procedure? That tactic has migrated to the Web.

headline: Pan American to Acquire Minefinders for $1.5 Billion
text: The Pan American Silver Corporation agreed on Monday to acquire the Minefinders Corporation, a Canadian silver and gold exploration company, for $1.5 billion.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Fast Company: For the run-up to Valentine’s Day, a paean to the Philadelphia-based John & Kira’s chocolates, especially the $189 Bee My Love Tug Tower, a fantasy of ganache-filled chocolates, caramel honeybees, drunken figs and dark-chocolate ladybugs. — Glenn Collins

headline: Monday Reading: Web Surfing for a Vacation Rental
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: There Is No Perfect (or Permanent) Financial Plan
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His new book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published earlier this month. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

headline: On Our Radar:  Freshwater Bulge in the Arctic
text: Scientists suggest that a dome of freshwater in the western Arctic Ocean might eventually disturb the warm currents that assure relatively mild weather in Northern Europe. [BBC]

headline: Now, Online-Only Fashion Shows for Busy Editors
text: KCD, the public relations company that produces fashion shows for top labels like Marc Jacobs and Givenchy, announced on Monday that it is offering a new service wherein it will produce some shows in an entirely digital format so that overtaxed editors can watch them online. During Fashion Week, particularly in New York, it has become a common complaint that there are too many shows, something like 300 scheduled within eight days, and that a lot of designers get lost as a result. The new idea, which is being pitched as an alternative to runway or presentation formats, is that rather than slogging across town or making some excuse about being on deadline, an editor or buyer can watch the collection on a computer or mobile device.

headline: Pakistan Rejects U.S. Account of Clash That Ended With Airstrike
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s military issued an uncompromising formal rejection on Monday of the United States report last month on a contentious border exchange of fire that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers, dealing a fresh blow to American hopes of reviving a troubled strategic relationship.

headline: Editor Is the Story as the French Huffington Post Starts
text: PARIS — Anne Sinclair smiled big for the cameras, not as the betrayed wife standing by her man but as the star journalist she once was and hopes to be again.

headline: A Piece of the Manhattan Dream, Only $331.76 a Month
text: With 11-foot ceilings, exposed brick walls, piles of hardcover books and views of chimneys and water towers, Arnold Warwick’s apartment is a 1,200-square-foot monument to the Greenwich Village of our fantasies.

headline: $4.62 Million Mercedes Gullwing Leads Strong Auction Weekend in Arizona
text: As the auctions in and around Scottsdale, Ariz., over the weekend proved, the uppermost reaches of the collector-car hobby remain virtually unfazed by the various crises roiling the global economy.

text: Call it stealth flextime.

headline: Fuel to Be Removed From Stricken Cruise Ship
text: GIGLIO, Italy — Rescue divers discovered the bodies of two women in the submerged Internet cafe lounge of the Costa Concordia shipwreck on Monday, raising the official death toll to 15, as salvage crews were authorized to start extracting the vessel’s half million gallons of fuel.

headline: S.B.A. Readying Program to Invest in Start-Ups
text: With its legislative agenda for job creation stuck for the foreseeable future, the Obama administration has turned inward, looking to the federal bureaucracy for new ways to jump-start the economy.

headline: A Glimpse of Polar History
text: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier-fed streams.

headline: Tim Rice Has No Hosannas for Andrew Lloyd Webber’s ‘Superstar’ Reality Show
text: Look at all the trials and tribulations of Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice. The one-time partners behind some of musical theater’s most successful (and lucrative) works are feuding again, this time over a British reality series that would cast the lead for a new production of “Jesus Christ Superstar.”

headline: Romney Warns of ‘October Surprises’ if Gingrich Is Nominee
text: TAMPA — Mitt Romney raised the possibility that Newt Gingrich might have broken laws in representing corporate interests and warned of politically damaging “October surprises” if Mr. Gingrich became the Republican presidential nominee.

headline: Numberplay: The Five-Pirate Puzzle
text: Five smart, greedy and mean pirates find themselves on a boat with 100 gold coins. The pirates are ranked according to seniority, from 1 to 5, the most senior being ranked 1. Here is the deal: the most senior pirate must make a proposal for splitting the coins among the pirates, including herself (no fractional coins!). If her proposal has at least 50 percent acceptance (she votes, too), she is fine; otherwise, the other four pirates throw her into the shark-infested sea. The remaining pirates play the same game, starting with a proposal from the next most senior pirate, that is, the pirate ranked 2.

headline: Tibetans Fired Upon in Protest in China
text: HONG KONG — Security forces opened fire on Tibetan protesters in western China on Monday, wounding at least 32 people and killing at least one of them in the largest violent confrontation in ethnic Tibetan areas of China since 2008, two Tibetan rights groups and the Tibetan exile government said.

headline: Calling Mitch Daniels
text: For months now, even as the rest of the conservative commentariat has gradually resigned itself to the existing presidential field, the Weekly Standard’s Bill Kristol has continued to pine — publicly, unstintingly, immune to either embarrassment or fatigue— for another candidate to jump into the race. He’s dreamed of Mitch Daniels, touted Chris Christie, talked up Paul Ryan and Marco Rubio, name-dropped Jeb Bush, and circled back to Daniels once more. He’s quoted poetry on behalf of his cause — Yeats, and (with some revisions) Andrew Marvell. He’s endured snark from the Huffington Post, eye-rolling from Slate, mockery from New York Magazine. But he’s continued undeterred — and in the wake of Newt Gingrich’s South Carolina victory, he was back at it again, throwing out a link to “a new online petition was launched Saturday night … at runmitchrun.com.”

headline: Taking Up Taxes on the Campaign Trail
text: Republican politicians talk a great deal about saving small businesses, and routinely play the mom-and-pop card when arguing against raising taxes, or charging a decent minimum wage, or providing everyone with access to health insurance. Last year, when the Senate was debating how to pay for a renewal of the payroll tax cut, Democrats proposed a surcharge on incomes over $1 million a year. Republicans screamed that this would hurt small businesses, and hence the economy, because small businesses are “job creators.”

headline: ‘Romeo’ Is Dead, but Lemur Conservation Endures
text: The Duke Lemur Center’s “beloved Romeo” died this weekend at 19. He was the Western Hemisphere’s only successfully housed captive diademed sifaka, one of Madagascar’s increasingly rare lemur species. Still, his tale is one of hope, with efforts expanding to assure the survival of endangered lemur species.

headline: 2 Live Crew to Live Again
text: The rap group 2 Live Crew, which set off a fierce debate over freedom of speech with its graphic sexual lyrics in the 1980s and early 1990s, plans to reunite and begin touring, The Associated Press reported. The group’s former leader, Luther Campbell, said at the Sundance Film Festival in Utah that the rappers, whose hits like “Me So Horny” drew fire, would get back together. “I just can’t wait to start practicing,” he said. Mr. Campbell, who is 51 and is also known as Luke, visited the festival to promote his appearance in a short film, “The Life and Freaky Times of Uncle Luke.”

headline: Supreme Court Decision: The United States v. Jones
text: In a 5-4 decision, the Supreme Court on Monday unanimously ruled that the police violated the Constitution when they placed a Global Positioning System tracking device on a suspect’s car and tracked its movements for 28 days.

headline: A Journeyman Giant Kept Ending Up in the Right Place
text: SAN FRANCISCO — After all the preparation and posturing, the difference between the Giants and the 49ers on Sunday essentially came down to a 25-year-old special-teams player who managed to be in the right position to fall on a uniquely contoured ball best known for taking strange bounces.

headline: Survival’s Ick Factor
text: Disgust is the Cinderella of emotions. While fear, sadness and anger, its nasty, flashy sisters, have drawn the rapt attention of psychologists, poor disgust has been hidden away in a corner, left to muck around in the ashes.

headline: Federer vs.Tomic: Breaking It Down
text: Roger Federer’s straight sets victory against Australian teenager Bernard Tomic in the fourth round of the Australian Open this morning highlighted a major difference in how the two players view and play the sport.Federer, who will play against Juan Martin del Potro in the quarterfinals Tuesday (Federer’s 1,000th tour match), won, 6-4, 6-2, 6-2, displaying a game style vastly different from his inexperienced yet highly touted opponent.

headline: A Sunscreen Warning for Parents of Teenagers
text: Half of a group of 360 fifth graders told researchers from Memorial Sloan-Kettering that they used sunscreen regularly when in the sun. Three years later, in 2007, among those same children, at least two things had changed: they were now eighth graders, with all the increased rebellion and decreased supervision that that implies — and now, only about 25 percent still used sunscreen.

text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday  ruled unanimously that the police violated the Constitution when they placed a Global Positioning System tracking device on a suspect’s car and monitored its movements for 28 days.

text: “Yuck! The Nature and Moral Significance of Disgust,” by Daniel Kelly. M.I.T. Press, 2011. 194 pages.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Sokolove on Oscar Pistorius
text: Michael Sokolove, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story on the double-amputee Olympic hopeful Oscar Pistorius. Sokolove is the author of three books: “Warrior Girls,” about the epidemic of injuries among young female athletes; “The Ticket Out: Darryl Strawberry”; and “Hustle: The Myth, Life, and Lies of Pete Rose.”

headline: Lunches to Take to Work
text: Many people who have chimed in on the Recipes for Health page on Facebook have requested recipes for lunches they can take to work and eat at a desk. Although I work at home, my lunch requirements are probably similar to those of many of you who work in an office. I don’t like to eat complex dishes with strong flavors like raw garlic or onion at midday, because I don’t want those flavors lingering when I get back to work. I want a lunch that’s light and simple, enjoyable but not distracting. It usually includes protein and a vegetable of some kind, often a complex carbohydrate like whole-grain bread or a grain. I don’t spend much time preparing it because I’ve made it ahead (salad, wraps, something I’ve tested for this column that fits the bill), or because it’s as simple as cottage cheese and avocado with a corn tortilla or two, heated over the gas burner so that it has a nice charred taste.

headline: Buffett Rings in Chinese New Year With a Serenade
text: Warren E. Buffett is many things, but a songster?

headline: Stem Cell Treatment for Eye Diseases Shows Promise
text: LOS ANGELES — A treatment for eye diseases that is derived from human embryonic stem cells might have improved the vision of two patients, bolstering the beleaguered field, researchers reported Monday.

headline: Just One Look | Versace
text: Atelier Versace, the haute couture division of the Italian house, showed for the first time since 2004 this morning at the Beaux Arts. It was a modest return — a presentation of 15 looks on a gold staircase to a standing audience — but very, very Versace: swishing ponytails, smoky eyes, vertiginous heels and lots of sparkle. Sculptural (“ergonomic”) aluminum bands defined the curves of delicate encrusted lace columns and minis. Here, a get-thee-to-a-red-carpet number in brazen persimmon.

headline: Mark Kelly to Join First Lady for State of the Union
text: Capt. Mark Kelly, the husband of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, will sit with Michelle Obama in the first lady’s box at Tuesday’s State of the Union speech, Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said on Monday.

headline: Bang & Olufsen’s Homage to Its Past
text: Bang & Olufsen, best known as makers of high-style audio equipment, is starting what the company is calling its new affordable subbrand, B&O Play, with a high-fidelity lunchbox.

headline: Most Serious Charge in a Private’s Death May Be Dropped
text: A military investigator has recommended that the most serious charge be dropped against an American infantryman implicated in the death of Pvt. Danny Chen, a Chinese-American soldier from New York City who, relatives said, was brutally hazed by members of his Army unit in Afghanistan and then apparently killed himself.

headline: Thomas Langmann, the Man Who Took a Chance on ‘The Artist’
text: American audiences were introduced to Thomas Langmann, a producer of “The Artist,” at the Golden Globes, when he gave one of the evening’s best speeches, about his father, the filmmaker Claude Berri, winning an Oscar in 1966 and not having enough money to come to the United States to accept it. The winning streak “The Artist” is now on – it picked up the top Producers Guild prize over the weekend – may give Mr. Langmann a chance to rectify that; the Bagger and everyone else will start to find out the fate of “The Artist” when Oscar nominations are announced on Tuesday.

headline: New Romney Ad Hits Gingrich on Freddie Mac
text: Mitt Romney is taking his attacks on Newt Gingrich up a notch in a new television ad that tries to link him to the implosion of the housing market.

headline: Don’t Pat On Me
text: Whether or not you agree with them on the issues, it’s nice to find politicians who actually have principles and actually stick to them. Obviously, I’m not talking here about either Newt Gingrich or Mitt Romney. In fact, I’m not talking about the presidential race at all, although the politician I have in mind is at least related to one of the candidates.

headline: Corporate Rule Is Not Inevitable
text: President Obama formally rejected the Keystone XL pipeline. Fingers crossed there, but that, plus the evident death of the SOPA bill (and little things, like B of A, Verizon and Netflix all being forced to change their behavior after massive Web protests by their customers) give reason to hope. The campaign against Citizens United may well pick up steam as more people begin to feel the power. “Corporate rule,” as this piece details, “is not inevitable.”

headline: In Poland, a Pirate of the Highway
text: Moving a trailer of beef along Interstate 80 like John Wayne driving a herd along the Chisholm Trail, many American truck drivers fancy themselves heirs to the cowboy tradition. For at least one of Poland’s knights of the highway, however, the romantic vision of his occupation is more surf than turf.

text: Egypt seats its new Parliament | Romney and Gingrich trade jabs before Monday's debate | China celebrates the Year of the Dragon.

headline: Some Rosy Predictions for Windows Phone 7
text: Sales of new devices running Windows Phone 7 have been so small that even Microsoft is shy about revealing numbers. And yet two research firms predict that phones running the operating system will surpass the iPhone by 2015.

headline: Supreme Court Rebuffs Conservative Group on Health Care Lawsuit
text: A conservative group that wants Justice Elena Kagan to recuse herself when the Supreme Court takes up a challenge to the 2010 health care overhaul has been denied permission to take part in oral arguments in the case.

headline: Etta James: One of Everyone’s Own
text: Perhaps the most astounding thing about Etta James’s voice was how it traveled so freely in so many different musical circles, and that was again the most evident aspect of the tributes given to her over the weekend. On Saturday morning, she was featured on a rhythm-and-blues radio program; later that day, on a rock ‘n’ roll show. On Sunday morning, jazz radio was claiming her as one of their own, and she was even plastered all over the touch screen of the treadmill at my gym. And that seemed the most appropriate format, because no matter what James sang — R&B, rock, blues, jazz, pop — her voice was one that got your blood pumping.

headline: Chaotic Start to Egypt’s First Democratically Elected Parliament
text: CAIRO — As Egypt’s first freely elected Parliament in six decades held its opening session on Monday, the Muslim Brotherhood received a lesson in the unwieldiness of democracy when a dispute over choosing a speaker degenerated into a shouting match that overshadowed the day.

headline: Collision in the Making Between Self-Driving Cars and How the World Works

headline: The Alzheimer’s Reading Room
text: In mid-January, Bob DeMarco, 61, left his 96-year-old mother’s side for the first time in eight years to go to a conference about Alzheimer’s disease just a few hours from the home they share in Delray Beach, Fla. He made elaborate plans for his time away, arranging for his mother, Dotty, who has advanced Alzheimer’s, to stay with nearby friends; getting his first cellphone lest there be an emergency; and bit by bit, day after day, “reminding” her of his coming departure.

headline: Audit Finds Limited Use of City's Data System
text: Many New York City teachers and principals are not using the city's $80 million student information database, according to an audit by the city comptroller, John C. Liu,  released on Monday. Many teachers have not even logged into the ARIS system, the audit shows.

headline: Schoolgirl’s Needlework Sampler Sells for $1.07 Million
text: In 1807, a New Jersey schoolgirl named Mary Antrim embroidered a farm scene with silk thread on linen. On Sunday, Sotheby’s in New York sold her view of livestock, picket fences and clapboarded outbuildings for $1.07 million (the top estimate had been $120,000), setting an auction record for a needlework sampler. The sale contained 198 lots from the collection of the needlework historian Betty Ring. Of all the colorful pastoral views at the Sotheby’s showroom, Mary Antrim’s piece “stood out in a unique way as a folk art statement,” said the dealer David Schorsch, who bought it for an undisclosed client. The auction’s other top prices were in the low six figures and shared by the specialist dealers Stephen and Carol Huber and Amy Finkel. A quarter of the Ring material did not sell, especially images of veiled mourners and gravestones sewn in memory of deceased relatives. The buzz in the field this week, Mr. Huber said, is that “the memorials all died.”

headline: The High Cost of Violating Human Rights
text: It used to be that the United Nations human rights commission denounced violations in some of the nastiest parts of the world – sub-Saharan Africa, South Africa, junta-dominated Latin American countries, Communist-occupied Europe. These days, that office denounces the United States. That’s what happens when you operate a prison on the margins of the law and justice, where people are held without trial, on tainted evidence, without consideration for their rights under international treaties or the laws of the nation that built the prison.

headline: Summing Up the Paterno Legacy: It’s Complicated

headline: Drink Up | Pressed Juicery’s Chalkboard Goes Live
text: Pressed Juicery in Los Angeles began as a labor of love. When the co-founder Carly Brien’s mother got ill, she and her friends Hayden Slater and Hedi Gores decided to change career paths (from public relations, production and full-time motherhood, respectively) and create something healthful and positive. At the time, Los Angeles was lacking a juicery that used a hydraulic press, a machine that squelches an entire fruit or vegetable into a pulp, extracting three to four times more than an average juicer. After yoga class one day, Slater found the perfect spot for one: a 22-square-foot broom closet adjacent to the Brentwood Country Mart. Today, Pressed is a thriving business — a second location (in a truck) opened in Malibu last summer, and at the end of last year Slater and friends brought a storefront to West Hollywood. The juicery also takes orders online and delivers nationwide to loyals who can’t live without its Greens 2 (a blend of kale, spinach, romaine, parsley, cucumber, celery, apple and lemon), Detox 2 (pineapple, green apple and mint) and Almond Milk (almonds, dates, vanilla bean, sea salt and filtered water).

headline: ‘Follies’ Closes Without Turning a Profit

headline: The Pure Romanticism That Fokine Took West Returns After a Detour
text: WASHINGTON — Go west, young man!, the saying goes, and a century ago almost all the Russian choreographers did just that. In 1909 Michel Fokine, master of poetic evocation and characterful dance drama, was the first of them to migrate and make most of his ballets in Europe and the Americas. Thanks to him and those who followed, ballet in the West was transformed. It took most of the 20th century, however, for ballet in Russia even to catch up with what Fokine had been doing elsewhere.

headline: After Being Stricken by Drought, Istanbul Yields Ancient Treasure
text: ISTANBUL — For 1,600 years, this city — Turkey’s largest — has been built and destroyed, erected and erased, as layer upon layer of life has thrived on its seven hills.

headline: Zoos Have a New Head Keeper
text: The Bronx Zoo and its cousins have a new head keeper. Cristián Samper, the director of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of Natural History, will take over as president and C.E.O. of the Wildlife Conservation Society starting in August, the society announced on Monday.

That stuff is hilarious.

headline: Greece Publishes List of 4,000 Tax Scofflaws
text: In a name-and-shame campaign aimed at getting tax evaders to pay up, the Greek government published a list of more than 4,000 people, including several household names, who owe a total of $19 billion to the cash-strapped state. The list published late Sunday includes the veteran crooner Tolis Voskopoulos with debts of nearly $650,000; Pavlos Psomiadis, the owner of a defunct insurance firm, with arrears of nearly $2 million; and Giorgos Batatoudis, a former soccer club president who owes more than $3 million. Greece is under pressure from foreign creditors to curb endemic tax evasion, a key barrier to its economic recovery.

headline: Washington: Gay Marriage Wins a Crucial Backer
text: The state appeared likely to become the seventh to allow gay couples to marry, after a state senator who had previously said she was undecided announced her support on Monday for a marriage bill moving through the Legislature. The measure, proposed by Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat, has wide support in the House and had been just a few votes short in the Senate. After several undecided senators announced their support in recent weeks, Senator Mary Margaret Haugen, a Democrat, said she also would vote for the bill, becoming the decisive vote. A vote has not yet been scheduled. If the measure passes, opponents are expected to challenge it through a ballot referendum this fall. “For me personally, I have always believed in traditional marriage between a man and a woman,” Ms. Haugen said in a statement. “That is what I believe, to this day. But this issue isn’t about just what I believe. It’s about respecting others, including people who may believe differently than I. It’s about whether everyone has the same opportunities for love and companionship and family and security that I have enjoyed.”

headline: The Hasty Retreat of the Dung Beetle
text: After dung beetles collect the substance that gives them their name, they do a little dance, swinging around in one direction, and then sometimes the other.

headline: Missouri: Message-Laden House Will Be Preserved
text: A destroyed house filled with the signatures and well-wishes of thousands of the volunteers who came to Joplin to help with the recovery after the deadly tornado last spring will be preserved, city leaders announced Monday. The house and the messages within had been decaying under the elements because the walls and roof were stripped off by the storm. A makeshift roof was erected to protect the building, which will be sealed on Tuesday with a type of shrink wrap to protect the messages from eroding further, said Patrick Tuttle, director of the Joplin Convention and Visitors Bureau. The house, he said, will soon be moved out of the rebuilding neighborhood and to a city-owned storage area until it can be incorporated into a museum or other public display.

It’s tough flying anywhere direct from Tulsa, so I usually have to change planes, which can create some extensive delays.

headline: U.N. Investigates Allegations Against Troops in Haiti
text: The United Nations is investigating allegations against its police officers in Haiti involving two cases of sexual abuse of minors, the organization’s spokesman said Monday. The allegations were made against United Nations officers in Port-au-Prince, the capital, and in Gonaives. The officers have been removed from their duties while a team from New York investigates the allegations, said Martin Nesirky, the spokesman, adding that the leadership of the organization was “outraged” by the allegations. He declined to identify the nationality of the officers involved. There are about 11,000 United Nations peacekeepers in Haiti, about 3,500 of whom are police officers.

headline: Chesapeake to Cut Number of Gas Rigs

headline: As China Reins In Microblogs, Dissidents Find Haven on Twitter
text: Chinese ringing in the first second of the Lunar New Year on social media bombarded the country’s biggest microblogging service with more than 30,000 messages on Monday, roaring past the previous record for messages per second on a social media site, according to a news release by the company, Sina Weibo, quoted by Chinese news media.

headline: Bingham Ray, Executive Who Championed Independent Films, Dies at 57
text: LOS ANGELES — Bingham Ray, a colorful indie-film executive who helped steer art-house movies like “Bowling for Columbine” and “Hotel Rwanda” to the masses, died on Monday in a hospice in Provo, Utah. He was 57.

headline: France: Government Bans Domestic Islamist Group
text: The government has ordered the dissolution of a domestic Islamist group, saying that it was a terrorist organization training its members “for armed combat,” Interior Minister Claude Guéant said Monday. The Web site of the group, Forsane Alizza or “The Knights of Pride,” says its aim is to fight Islamophobia. The Web site is laced with anti-Semitic material and postings supporting organizations that are widely deemed to be terrorist groups, including the Afghan Taliban. A recent recruitment appeal by Forsane Alizza called for “soldiers,” and the group acknowledges some violent aims, in particular in the defense of Muslim women. The group gained attention last year through demonstrations against a French law banning the wearing of the full facial veil in public. A cofounder of the group, Mohammed Achamlane, said it would contest the dissolution order in court. “This is truly farcical,” he said in a telephone interview from Nantes in western France. “They have absolutely nothing against us.”

headline: As Race Moves to Florida, Facing Political Implications of a Housing Crisis
text: ORMOND BEACH, Fla.— When Mitt Romney swept into the contentious battleground state of Florida on Sunday, the first local issue he raised was the nation’s mortgage foreclosure crisis, which is arguably at its worst here, from this city on the northern coast to the ghost-town developments in what used to be farmland south of Miami.

headline: Chicago Sun-Times Ends Candidate Endorsements
text: For the first time since it began publishing 71 years ago, the editorial board of the Chicago Sun-Times announced late on Sunday that it would not endorse political candidates in the coming elections.

headline: India: 2 Arrested in July Terrorist Attack on Mumbai
text: Authorities in Mumbai announced the arrest of two suspects on Monday in connection with a terrorist attack last July that killed 27 people in bombings across the city. Police investigators also blamed a domestic terrorist, Yasin Bhatkal, who remains at large and has been linked to a radical Islamic group known as the Indian Mujahedeen. Rakesh Maria, a top counterterrorism official in Mumbai, said the police had arrested two men from Bihar State, accused of being Mr. Bhatkal’s accomplices, and have identified others involved in the conspiracy. The attack consisted of explosions at three locations in Mumbai and investigators initially examined the possibility that the culprits were terrorist groups from Pakistan.

headline: Christie Names a Gay Man and an Asian for the Top Court

headline: Mind Your P’s and B’s: The Digital Humanities and Interpretation
text: The question I posed at the conclusion of my last post was how do the technologies wielded by digital humanities practitioners either facilitate the work of the humanities, as it has been traditionally understood, or bring about an entirely new conception of what work in the humanities can and should be? I’m going to sneak up on that question by offering a piece of conventional (i.e., non-digital) literary analysis that deals, as the digital humanities do, with matters of statistical frequency and pattern.

headline: Learning to Fend for Himself and Obey House Rules
text: Travis Watson remembers the moment when he went from having everything to having nothing. He had spent a night at a friend’s house in fall 2010 and was returning to his grandmother’s home in Brooklyn, where he and his four siblings lived. He was greeted by the sight of a moving van loaded with furniture: his grandmother was moving to North Carolina, and Mr. Watson had not been invited to go with her.

Geithner, the United States secretary of the Treasury; Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank; and Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: The Union’s ‘Newfangled Gimcracks’
text: In late December 1861 Abraham Lincoln issued a directive that, had it been vigorously pursued, might have brought the Civil War to a rapid end: An order, via Gen. James Ripley, the Army’s ordnance chief, for 10,000 Spencer repeating rifles. Because Ripley resisted the order for months and did nothing to help put the rifles into volume production, initial deliveries didn’t start until about a year and a half after Lincoln first tested the rifle. Consequently, Union soldiers had to fight with less efficient weapons, handicapping them and greatly lengthening the bloody conflict.

headline: State of New Mexico vs. Financial Advisers
text: Lawsuits claim that state investments were mismanaged and steered by supporters of Gov. Bill Richardson, who left office in 2010.

headline: Insiders Led New Mexico Investments, Suit Claims
text: ALBUQUERQUE — A former financial adviser for the State of New Mexico told his partners at a secretly taped meeting that close associates to Bill Richardson, then the governor, controlled where they would invest the state’s money, according to a lawsuit.

headline: Republican Candidates Debate an 18th Time
text: This contest, at the University of South Florida, was dominated by Mitt Romney’s sharp attacks on Newt Gingrich’s character and post-Congressional career.

headline: Romney Tax Returns Show 2-Year Income of $45 Million
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign released details of his federal tax returns on Tuesday morning, showing that he is likely to pay a total of $6.2 million in taxes on $45 million in income over the two tax years of 2010 and 2011. (View full returns here)

headline: The IHT Is Taking Your Questions to Davos
text: A team of business and economics reporters from the International Herald Tribune has its boots on the ground this week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. They will be interviewing and speaking with some of the world’s most influential leaders in government, business, academia, philanthropy and public service. What are the issues of most concern to you? What would you ask the attendees? Better yet, what can we ask them for you?Submit your queries in the comments field.

headline: Too Much Restraint? Or Not Enough?
text: ‘‘Austerity doesn’t save. It sinks.’’ So reads a somber mural on a concrete wall in Oporto, Portugal, depicting a nose-diving submarine.

headline: Occupy Protesters Build Igloos in Switzerland to Protest Economic Summit
text: The eviction of Occupy Wall Street from Zuccotti Park in November left protesters without the physical birthplace of the movement around which to rally, and put something of a chill on the endeavor. In Switzerland, protesters of the World Economic Forum have made the movement even chillier.

headline: Romney Can’t Rumble
text: Mitt Romney just doesn’t know how to rumble. It comes across as more of a fumble. Sometimes a mumble. And ultimately a stumble.

headline: Five Questions For: Jason Burke
text: India Ink is asking authors attending the Jaipur Literature Festival five questions about writing and about themselves. Malavika Vyawahare caught up with the author of “The 9/11 Wars” and “Al Qaeda: The True Story of Radical Islam.”

headline: Five Questions for: Vinod Mehta
text: India Ink is asking authors attending the Jaipur Literature Festival five questions about writing and about themselves. Nikhila Gill caught up with the author of “Lucknow Boy: A Memoir”.

headline: The Caucus | Housing and the Debate
text: Susan Saulny reports from Florida on the issue of the foreclosure crisis at Monday's debate. While the candidates offered little specifics, it's a dominant issue for voters.

headline: Player Ratings: One Man’s Rules
text: Player ratings in soccer are by definition a subjective measure. One person’s 6 is another man’s 4. And since no two people view players or the game the same way, that is not likely to change. But because some readers have asked, John Godfrey — who regularly contributes ratings to the Goal blog — offers a few insights into what he’s thinking when he fills out his report card.

headline: News Quiz | Jan. 24, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: Jan. 24, 1965 | Winston Churchill Dies
text: On Jan. 24, 1965, former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill died in London at age 90, nine days after suffering a severe stroke. “Winston Churchill’s struggle for life ended this morning, and the people he had cherished and inspired and led through darkness mourned him as they have no other in this age,” The New York Times reported.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 24, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “In Liverpool, Moment of Silence Followed by Impassioned Roar.”

headline: Senior Bowl, Day 1 Impressions
text: It was a rainy day in Mobile, Ala., but spirits could not be dampened as the Senior Bowl got under way Monday. It began with the morning weigh-in, continued through practice in the afternoon, then through the evening at media night at the  U.S.S. Alabama Battleship Memorial Park.

headline: Gabrielle Giffords Resigns From Congress
text: WHO was killed in the mass shooting in Tucson, on Jan. 8, 2011?WHO is governor of Arizona?

headline: Focusing on the Hidden History
text: Perched somewhere above a “We Buy Gold” joint and a Latin restaurant on Kingsbridge Road in the Bronx, a darkroom turned storage closet was once a repository for an almost overlooked visual history. It was an unlikely spot for an equally unlikely – and unrivaled – collection that now comprises 700 photographs by Latino, African-American and Asian photographers and other artists of color.

headline: At Senior Bowl, a Wide Receiver Graduate Seminar
text: MOBILE, Ala. — To the untrained eye, a good wide receiver is a player who can run fast, jump high and catch the ball by any means necessary. This is a basic truth about the position, but there are several explosive athletes who can catch but never succeed in the N.F.L. That’s because of the complexity of the pro game.

headline: Intel About Rushdie Threats Was Real, Rajasthan Says
text: Author Salman Rushdie cancelled an appearance at the Jaipur Literature Festival, which wraps up today, after he was informed by festival organizers of attempts against his life. News reports have cast doubts about that intelligence in recent days, suggesting it was fabricated, and Mr. Rushdie said he thinks he was “lied to.” Those doubts are “baseless,” the Rajasthan State government said in a statement issued late Monday evening. The full statement is below:

headline: What Would You Like to Learn on Your Own?
text: After homework, extracurricular activities, social life and leisure, you may have little time to do anything else. But have you ever made an effort to learn about something outside the classroom, not related to anything you’re studying in school? How would you use a daily “learning hour”?

headline: Siemens, a German Bellwether, Reports a Decline in Profit
text: FREIBURG, Germany — Siemens, an electronics and engineering giant that is a bellwether for German industry, said on Tuesday that profit and new orders fell late last year as the European debt crisis made customers more cautious about investing in new projects.

headline: ESPN Boston Readers Vote Not to See 2008 Super Bowl Highlights
text: The Patriots’ owner, Bob Kraft, and quarterback Tom Brady have said that they have never seen highlights of Super Bowl 42. They’re not the only ones who find it too painful to watch.

headline: Threat of Violence Quashes Even Virtual Rushdie Appearance
text: Salman Rushdie’s virtual participation at the Jaipur Literature Festival was canceled at the last minute Tuesday, after Muslim groups attending the festival threatened violence if his image was shown.

headline: Coding Start-Ups Compete for Booming Market

headline: Sounding an Alarm on Birds and Mercury
text: It was in 2005 that I first accompanied David Evers into the cool dampness of a Catskills forest. At the time, Dr. Evers, a biologist and director of the Biodiversity Research Institute in Gorham, Me., was hunting for some pretty small game. He had draped a net between several trees in a section of the forest in upstate New York and, with the help of a portable cassette player that replicated the sound of songbirds trilling merrily away, was luring tiny wood thrushes into the trap.

headline: An Interview With Donatella Versace
text: Suzy Menkes speaks to the designer about her choice to return to the haute couture calendar, who the true clients are for her elaborate designs and how the brand is reaching a younger consumer.

headline: Nine Films Vie for Best Picture
text: 9:47 a.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES – A chaotic Oscar season found some order on Tuesday as “The Artist,” a mostly silent tribute to old Hollywood, and “Hugo,” another bit of film nostalgia, joined “The Descendants,” about life and love in Hawaii, and “Midnight in Paris,” about literary Paris, in scoring an array of major nominations, including those for best picture and best director.

headline: Coughlin Talks About Special Team Feeling
text: Here’s a partial transcript of Tom Coughlin’s conference call with reporters on Monday. The full version is at Giants.com.

headline: Deadly Blasts Hit Shiite Neighborhoods in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — A series of explosions in Shiite neighborhoods here killed nine people and wounded dozens more on Tuesday, the latest in a wave of sectarian attacks.

headline: Romney Tax Returns Reveal 14% Effective Rate
text: After weeks of speculation and grappling with rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, Mitt Romney’s campaign released details of his tax returns on Tuesday morning. Among the revelations: Mr. Romney paid $6.2 million in taxes on $45 million in combined income in 2010 and 2011, for an effective rate of around 14 percent. Read more »

headline: Calling Mr. DeMille
text: Versace was on the Quai Malaquais, so I went there at 10:30 a.m., killing a few minutes at the nearby Dries Van Noten shop to look at sale pieces and splash on some perfume. There was a crowd outside Versace, though nothing like the crowd that would be waiting at Dior a few hours later.

headline: Who Should Take the Stage at Dior?
text: It has been about a year since John Galliano’s scandalous departure from Christian Dior — and still no successor has been announced. Oh, there have been rumors, lots of them — although Bernard Arnault, chairman of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, said Monday that the suspense will continue.

headline: Those Tricky Vowels
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Image of the Day: January 24
text: Arms surrendered by rebels are displayed in Guwahati, Assam. Nine insurgent groups in northeast India reached cease-fire deals with the government.

headline: Daily Report: Europe Considers a Tough Online Privacy Law
text: Europe is considering a sweeping new law that would force Internet companies like Amazon.com and Facebook to obtain explicit consent from consumers about the use of their personal data, delete that data forever at the consumer’s request and face fines for failing to comply, Somini Sengupta reports in Tuesday’s Times.

headline: Free Homes, Gracias Chávez
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Cacique Tiuna, the Socialist housing commune being built here shows just how the government is planning to leverage housing to its advantage ahead of the presidential election in October. Over a thousand families have been settled in apartments over the last few months – for many, it’s the first time living outside a self-built shack in a shantytown. The housing project is something of a flagship for President Hugo Chávez’s plans to resettle the more than 120,000 people who lost their shanties to flooding in 2010.

headline: Smartphone Sales Are Strong, but Verizon Has a Loss
text: Verizon Communications on Tuesday reported rising iPhone sales and revenue growth in its wireless business, but it booked a quarterly loss, primarily because of previously announced pension charges.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Digital Privacy Makes a Comeback
text: The Republican presidential debate in Tampa, Fla., could be summed up like this: different audience, different debate. The invective was as high as in recent debates in South Carolina, with a newly aggressive Mitt Romney saying that Newt Gingrich, as a consultant to the mortgage giant Freddie Mac, had been an “influence peddler.” But without the raucous audiences of South Carolina, the event seemed more sedate, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg write.

headline: Hollege? Holleer? What Matters Are Mentors
text: The principal of a new high school in Brooklyn writes: 'Call it a holleer or a hollege -- or something else. In the end, it's not what it is named, but what it does to help students make the transition to career or college, with mentors to help along the way.'

headline: New Teachers Union Ad Takes Aim at Bloomberg
text: A solemn, 30-second political-style television advertisement by the United Federation of Teachers will start running on Tuesday, saying that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg "still doesn't get it," and accusing him of playing politics with the city's schools.

headline: A Tale Of Two Bubbles
text: One of the educational things about being something of a public figure is that I keep learning new things about how nefarious and dishonest I really am. The latest evilness I’ve learned about in comments and correspondence is that I have a double standard on bubbles — I talk about the Bush housing bubble, but I never said a word about the Clinton stock bubble.

headline: A New G-Shock Watch Awaits a New Bluetooth
text: As one Las Vegas cab driver told me, the International Consumer Electronics Show held earlier this month seems to be in an economic bubble all its own. “The big fashion industry convention show was down, from 80,000 attendees to 40,000,” he said. “But C.E.S. didn’t seem to get the e-mail that we’re in an economic slump.”
