headline: De-Coding Jefferson Hack’s New Shoes for Tod’s
text: “My first Tod’s piece was a gommini loafer,” says Jefferson Hack, the Dazed & Confused co-founder and editor of AnOther and AnOther Man magazines. “Diego [Della Valle] invited me to have it made to my personal specifications, as I was not a typical Tod’s customer.” And so it began. One trip to the company’s headquarters in Le Marche, Italy, and Della Valle, the C.E.O., was asking Hack to design a capsule collection that would bring the British editor’s subversive-cool aesthetic to the storied Italian house. Featuring seven styles (four for women, three for men) including a sea-blue suede lace-up ankle shoe and a patent leather slipper flat, the collection “breaks with convention and is untethered to the formal codes of dress or casual attire,” says Della Valle, by way of explaining the capsule’s name: No-Code.

headline: State Department Defends Leno After Joke Offends Sikhs
text: Though most comedians hope that their material stands on its own, some additional support from their country now and then doesn’t hurt either: The State Department stood up for Jay Leno after the “Tonight Show” host offended some Indian Sikhs with a joke that implied that a holy shrine in India was a home owned by Mitt Romney.

headline: Renowned Spanish Judge Goes on Trial, Accused of Abusing Power
text: MADRID — Baltasar Garzón, a high-profile Spanish judge who garnered international renown by pursuing political leaders, including Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile, was himself on trial on Tuesday over accusations that he had abused his powers to investigate atrocities committed during the Spanish Civil War.

headline: After a Dispute With Official, Mirza and Vesnina Win Doubles Match
text: MELBOURNE, Australia–Controversial officiating again became a factor in the decisive stages of a match at the 2012 Australian Open, as a women’s doubles quarterfinal was extended past what should have been the final point by an incorrect call.

headline: A Voice for the Riders, Lost Amid Transit Talks

text: WEST PALM BEACH, FLA. — When Mitt Romney pulled in for a campaign rally here recently, he pointedly left his tough stance against illegal immigration far behind in South Carolina, where he had trumpeted the issue repeatedly.

headline: Jared Bernstein On The Summers Memo
text: Jared makes the best case for arguing that Larry wasn’t really worrying about the invisible bond vigilantes. That’s still not how I read it, but again, it’s water under the bridge.

headline: India Art Fair Goes International
text: The India Art Fair, one of the biggest art exhibitions in South Asia,  opens in New Delhi on Wednesday. The five-day event brings together a host of artists, curators, critics, dealers and collectors from across the globe, and this year will draw ninety-one galleries from twenty countries, representing the work of a thousand contemporary and modern artists.

headline: Deadly Confrontation Spreads in Tibetan Region of China
text: HONG KONG — Deadly showdowns between Chinese security forces and Tibetans in a restive region of western China spread to a second town on Tuesday, outside advocacy groups reported. At least two and perhaps as many as five Tibetans were killed by gunfire and many more wounded, the groups said, in what appeared to be the most violent outbreak in the region in nearly four years.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Women May Suffer More From Pain
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Wanted: Parking Space for Nuclear Waste
text: When the Obama administration killed a plan to create a nuclear waste repository at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, the government established a “blue-ribbon commission” to study what to do next. Its final report is due on Sunday, and this week three organizations began a public lobbying campaign for several of the recommendations that they assume the commission will make.

headline: For Butler, a Pivotal Road Trip
text: In 2010 and 2011, the Butler Bulldogs were college basketball’s favorite Cinderella story. But this season has been a struggle. Matt Rhinesmith, a sports reporter for The Butler Collegian, will file occasional posts for The Quad about the team’s efforts to return to the N.C.A.A. tournament.The Butler men’s basketball team started off its longest road trip of the season with wins over Illinois-Chicago and Loyola this past weekend. Playing at Loyola’s newly renovated Gentile Center on Saturday, the Bulldogs were able to cope with a hostile environment and earn a 63-57 victory.

headline: Without a Ravenous Crowd, Gingrich Stumbles in the First Florida Debate
text: Many Republican voters in South Carolina said that much of Newt Gingrich’s appeal stemmed from his masterly debating skills. They believed he deftly made brilliant points, was vastly knowledgeable on his feet, and brutally shut down his opponents, and they dreamed of his doing the same thing to President Obama.

headline: HSBC Sells Latin American Businesses
text: LONDON – HSBC, one of Europe’s biggest banks, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its businesses in Costa Rica, El Salvador and Honduras for $801 million as part of its plan to focus on more profitable operations.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Daily Beast.com: In the end, it always comes down to food and drink. The “beer test” rule in the presidential election, according to the Democratic Party partisan Paul Begala, rates a politician’s electability by whether voters would like to have a few beers with the candidate. Mitt Romney is challenged, he claims, because “you get the feeling he’d be stiff even over a chocolate shake.” — Glenn Collins

headline: Best Sellers From a Vanished World
text: In the last two months, five million or so people got a Kindle Fire. Some of them were upgrading from earlier Kindles. They know the ropes. But millions of others must be new at this, and are stumbling around with their tablets looking for content. If they are like the rest of us and still paying the holiday bills, they want it free. That would be Angry Birds, of course, but also the Kindle Top 100 Free best-seller list. Some of these books are out of copyright — “Dracula,” Jane Austen — and some seem to have originated with Amazon itself. But at the top and interspersed all the way through are novels written by living if somewhat obscure authors. Romances, mostly, often with a Christian theme.

headline: Parsing the Surprises and the Snubs
text: 10:26 a.m. | Updated  As usual, the Bagger and other Oscar watchers were in for some surprises with the nominations on Tuesday morning, starting with the number of nominees. Few predicted that there would be a field of nine best picture contenders, and fewer still – hardly anyone – expected that one of those would be “Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close,” Stephen Daldry’s adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foer’s post-9/11 novel. The film also earned a best supporting actor nod for its 82-year-old star, Max von Sydow. Gasps were heard from the press and others assembled in the announcement room when the poorly reviewed film was called.

headline: A Belgian Surprise and a Snub for Germany in Oscar Race
text: The foreign-language Oscar category delivered two surprises Tuesday morning: the choice of “Bullhead,” Belgium’s unexpected submission, and the absence of Wim Wenders’s “Pina,” Germany’s submission. The three strongest films in the shortlist of nine made public last week were clearly  Iran’s “Separation,”  Israel’s “Footnote” and Canada’s “Monsieur Lazhar,” and all three, as expected, received nominations, leaving only two spots to be fought over by the six other contenders.

headline: For Those Keeping Score:  Streep Sets a Record; Scorsese Has a Chance at One

As the Bagger’s colleagues Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes have noted, Meryl Streep becomes the most-nominated actor in history, with 17 nominations to Jack Nicholson and Katharine Hepburn’s dozen each. “I am honored to be in company with such beautiful artists, and touched deeply by my fellow actors for their generosity in giving me this acknowledgment,” she said in a statement.

headline: Alison Returns, but Not on Dominick Street
text: Alison Eighteen, Alison Price Becker’s return to the Manhattan restaurant scene after an absence of almost 10 years, will evoke memories of her former restaurant, Alison on Dominick Street, when it opens next Tuesday. The chef, Robert Gurvich, is back, and the same designers, Asfour Guzy, have created the new Alison.

headline: Dior: Holding Couture to the Light
text: At 2:30 p.m. Monday, I arrived at Dior, on Avenue Montaigne. Whenever couture is shown in the house, in the grand salons on the third floor, an enormous throng of spectators and paparazzi gathers outside. It sounds far more glamorous than it really is. As I reached the main door, a black-suited security guard bellowed at people to clear the area so a guest’s car could pull up.

headline: Boston University, Where Academic Rigor Is de Rigueur
text: There is an assumption, including among more than a few incredulous parents, that high school seniors often choose their colleges based less on academic offerings than on softer factors like campus amenities (think climbing walls and walk-in, dorm-room closets), the ratio of men to women in the class and even the institution’s tolerance for keg parties.

headline: Déjà Supe
text: Let us be the first to welcome you to Super Bowl matchup hangover day. This is the day when all the giddiness about the conference championship games fades and the excitement about a potentially thrilling Super Bowl is superseded by the knowledge that for the next 12 days you will be overrun by stories about two teams. Making heads throb even worse in much of the country, those two teams are from the New York and Boston areas, which is why Mike Vaccaro of The Post took today to apologize to the rest of the nation. We second his thought. Hang in there.

headline: On Our Radar: Solar Kits for Haitians
text: Haiti’s president says he aims to double the number of rural households with electricity within two years by offering people loans to buy solar kits that can charge cellphones or computers. The $40 million program also calls for installing streetlights in the countryside and repairing power lines in the capital. Only 30 percent of the country’s population is estimated to have access to electricity. [Associated Press]

headline: Romney Attacks Obama’s Address as Nothing More Than ‘Tall Tales’
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney on Tuesday charged that President Obama‘s State of the Union speech will be nothing more than “partisan plans for his re-election campaign,” and “tall tales about America.”

headline: Paris Top 5 | Ami
text: Arriving in Paris Wednesday night, I went straight from Charles de Gaulle airport to a trés Parisienne apartment off Place de la Republique for the designer Alexandre Mattiussi’s cocktail-party-as-fashion-presentation for Ami. Though Champagne and cigarettes abounded, this was no chic Rive Gauche affair; more like the Williamsburg-on-the-Seine scene of Rue Oberkampf or, as our in-the-know illustrator Richard Haines said: “So Bushwick L train/Morgan stop.” So true. It was an über-groovy crowd — hard to discern the models from the viewers — and a perfect welcome to the final leg of the European fashion show season. What’s more, it heralded the arrival of this new French sportswear brand, following the model of A.P.C., with its cult following and affordable prices. Quirky outfits like short leather bombers and trim tweed coats layered over colored sweaters and clashing untucked shirts (with the odd floral or plaid here and there) felt more like great personal style statements than forced fashion. A bright-eyed bearded fellow wore a tee with a floralized bearded fellow on it, along with a harvest-colored houndstooth vest, matching carrot-cut pants (imagine a slightly dropped crotch with full legs that narrow at the cuff) and a tonal, double-breasted plaid coat; an amusing outfit with Parisian charm that had me at “Bon soir.”

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: Coughlin vs. Belichick? Manning vs. Brady? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

headline: From Far Back in the Pack to the Lead in ‘War Horse’
text: Before he went Hollywood, the thoroughbred gelding Finders Key accounted for only torn-up mutuel tickets at Los Alamitos Race Course, a track better known for quarter horse racing in Orange County, Calif. Winless in four $2,500 claiming races, he was beaten by a combined 30 lengths, never finishing higher than fifth.

headline: If It’s ‘The Artist’ vs. ‘Hugo,’ Hollywood Self-References Win
text: 11:23 a.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES—If you accept the theory advanced by some here that the Oscar race is now a showdown between “The Artist” and “Hugo,” then you are facing one of the weirder matchups in Academy Awards history. Both films are about the film business. But from Hollywood’s point of view, one picture comes from the outside and looks in, the other comes from the inside and looks out.

headline: Flying the Friendly Skies of Chanel Couture
text: Karl Lagerfeld spends enough time in the air to eventually think it might be a hoot to stage a Chanel show inside an airplane. He has had icebergs hauled to Paris. He has created farm scenes, a formal garden and a monument to the quilted bag, all in the Grand Palais. What’s an airplane, with a drinks cart and fake clouds floating past the windows?

headline: Springsteen Announces U.S. Tour Dates
text: Bruce Springsteen announced on Tuesday the dates for this year’s “Wrecking Ball” tour, and they include two concerts at Madison Square Garden, two gigs at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., and his first concert at the Prudential Center in Newark. The United States leg of the tour will kick off in Atlanta on March 18, a week and a half after Mr. Springsteen’s new album is to be released on Columbia Records. This tour is the first Mr. Springsteen and the E Street Band have done since the group’s longtime saxophonist, Clarence Clemons, died last year.

headline: Bryan Twins Win Midnight Marathon
text: MELBOURNE, Australia – Bob and Mike Bryan of the United States outlasted Marcin Matkowski and Mariusz Fyrstenberg of Poland in a three-set marathon, 6-4, 6-7 (4), 6-4, to gain the semifinals of the Australian Open.

headline: The Candidates’ Tax Returns
text: Comparing President Obama and Mitt Romney’s tax returns for 2011 to the typical taxpayer and the top 0.1 percent.

headline: A Good Day for Woody Allen and Sony Pictures Classics
text: LOS ANGELES — Is this the year Woody Allen warms up to the Oscars?

headline: Where Our Readers #WanttoGo in 2012
text: For our 45 Places to Go in 2012 article we asked readers to tell us on Twitter where they want to go this year. Some highlights are below. Join the conversation in the comments below and tell us where you want to go in 2012.

headline: Police Gang Tyrannized Latinos, Indictment Says
text: They were known as Miller’s Boys, police officers who worked the 4-to-midnight shift, patrolling the largely working-class town of East Haven, Conn., including the small but growing Hispanic community that has spread out in recent years from New Haven.

headline: The Men Who Didn’t Run
text: Dismissing the argument in my previous post, Daniel Larison suggests that none of the alternative candidates for the Republican nomination possesses the unique skill set that my Sunday column identified as crucial to a successful presidential contender:

headline: Just One Look | Christian Dior
text: For the second season the house of Christian Dior has offered an haute couture collection without announcing a successor to its prior couturier, John Galliano. For spring/summer 2012 the atelier (helmed by Bill Gaytten) went back to the archives and rendered classic Dior silhouettes in translucent organdy. The idea was to create dresses that resembled X-ray images of Mr. Dior’s original designs (as if the pieces had been photographed by the likes of Nick Knight). For the clients it offers a rare opportunity to buy something classically Dior. So why not a ballgown? This one, in black silk, has a bodice of trapped sequins and a swirling skirt of plissé.

headline: Egypt Military Council Partly Curbs State of Emergency Law
text: CAIRO — The army officer acting as Egypt’s de facto head of state said Tuesday that the military government would limit its use of extrajudicial arrests and detentions to cases of what he called “thuggery.”

headline: I.M.F. Trims Estimates for Global Growth on ‘Sharply Escalating’ Risks in Europe
text: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday that global growth prospects had dimmed as the sovereign debt crisis in the euro zone entered a “perilous new phase.”

headline: Can the Cowman and the Panther Coexist?
text: Ranchers in south Florida have long been accustomed to losing calves to coyotes, buzzards, even alligators. They may have to steel themselves for another predator: the Florida panther.

headline: Boehner Offers His 2 Cents on Romney’s Tax Rate
text: Speaker John A. Boehner offered an economic justification on Tuesday for the relatively low tax rate paid on investments by taxpayers like Mitt Romney, and House Republicans fired off more criticism of President Obama in advance of his State of the Union address.

headline: When Breast Isn’t Best: Outcry Over Comic’s Post
text: Two months after she gave birth to twins, Ahna Tessler was feeling confined in her Manhattan apartment and in need of artistic expression. So on Jan. 14 Ms. Tessler, a comedian who lives on the Upper West Side, did what came naturally: she recorded a humorous skit that incorporated her routine of breast-feeding her babies, Madelyn and Elliot, and tried to post the video on the online comedy site Funny or Die.

headline: Timberwolves Work on Extension for Love
text: There is little doubt that power forward/center Kevin Love should be a keeper for the Minnesota Timberwolves. He’s averaging a career-high 24.9 points and 13.9 rebounds per game and logging more than 39 minutes.

headline: Poll: Partisan Split Over Tax Policies
text: It may come as no surprise, but Americans are deeply split along party lines when it comes to federal tax policy.

headline: Brown Fat, Triggered by Cold or Exercise, May Yield a Key to Weight Control
text: Fat people have less than thin people. Older people have less than younger people. Men have less than younger women.

headline: Joseph Murphy Named Pastry Chef at Jean Georges
text: Joseph Murphy has replaced Johnny Iuzzini as executive pastry chef at Jean Georges. Mr. Murphy has been the corporate pastry chef for Jean-Georges Management and the executive pastry chef of BLT Market and the Ritz-Carton New York. Mr. Iuzzini resigned at the end of last year.

headline: Yale Turns To Royal Shakespeare Company For Its New Playwriting Chair
text: The Yale School of Drama announced on Monday that Jeanie O’Hare, the company dramaturg for the Royal Shakespeare Company, would succeed Paula Vogel as chair of the Yale playwriting department beginning July 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names Managing Directors
text: Morgan Stanley said on Tuesday that it had named 210 new managing directors, down from last year’s class of 232.

headline: The Buffett Rule Isn’t About Mitt Romney. Or Is It?
text: There are two words that President Obama is unlikely to utter when he talks about tax fairness during the State of the Union address: “Mitt Romney.”

headline: Austerity Could Again Sow Seeds of Extremism in Europe
text: NEW YORK — Does this sound familiar?

headline: Face Time | Rachel Roy
text: Rachel Roy is constantly in motion, with a namesake fashion collection and diffusion line, Rachel Rachel Roy, various collaborations and charitable work. The designer has even dabbled in makeup, creating a signature day-to-night eye shadow palette that stores couldn’t keep in stock. Next up: a partnership with OrphanAid Africa, an organization that benefits children in need. She also has two daughters, and is beautiful to boot! Naturally, I had some questions.

headline: Abu Dhabi Greenlights Its Mega-Museum Project
text: It was on. Then it was off. Now it’s back on again. The executive council of Abu Dhabi announced through its website on Monday that it had approved construction plans for its multi-billion-dollar vision for a cultural tourist center to be constructed on an island just off the coast of the city, a hub that will include branches of the Guggenheim and the Louvre museums.

headline: For BMW ActiveE, a Home Base That Speaks Fluent E.V.
text: BMW and Tendril, an energy management company, are developing a fully wired home to house the automaker’s electric ActiveE sedan.

headline: The Thrill of the Nod for Viola Davis, Brad Pitt and Gary Oldman
text: Calm. Excited for a fellow nominee. Deeply touched. When it comes to reactions to their good fortune, this year’s nominees are a rather diplomatic bunch. Viola Davis, Brad Pitt and Gary Oldman shared their initial impressions with us:

headline: City Bakery Chef Opens 606 R&D
text: Ilene Rosen, who left City Bakery last summer after 15 years of overseeing the savory dishes, and Sara Dima, who managed the bakery there, are opening 606 R&D, a small homestyle restaurant and bar.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Christian Dior

headline: Putting Candidates’ Tax Rates in Perspective
text: Here is a quick way to put the recent flurry of tax numbers into perspective: Newt Gingrich and President Obama each pay a federal tax rate typical of most affluent Americans, with rates well above those of many middle-class households. Mitt Romney pays a federal tax rate more typical of an upper-middle-class household making perhaps $80,000 a year — higher than the rate of most households but not enormously so.

headline: Punk-Rock History? Or Just a Leather Jacket?
text: Updated, Jan. 25 The contested jacket was withdrawn from auction. Read the follow-up

headline: State of the Union Wish List
text: Despite what some paranoid people on the Internet seem to think,  the New York Times editorial board does not write the president’s speeches (and his speechwriters don’t draft our editorials). But with some regularity we discuss what we wish Barack Obama would say. And, of course, we always have a lot of opinions about what he said – and no, they are not always positive..

headline: Bradley Revives Boston Defense With One-Man Press
text: The Boston Celtics’ defensive domination over the Orlando Magic on Monday night was comprehensive and unrelenting. It began with a statement first quarter; the Celtics held the Magic –- who at the time boasted the N.B.A.’s second-best offense –- to 6-of-18 shooting from the field in the opening frame. Boston allowed just 20 points for the quarter – an impressive mark on its own and a lofty benchmark for the Celtics’ D the rest of the way.

headline: For Romneys, Friendly Code Reduces Taxes
text: Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, made $27 million in 2010. They held millions of dollars in a Swiss bank account and millions more in partnerships in the Cayman Islands. His family’s trusts sold thousands of shares in Goldman Sachs that were offered to favored clients when the storied investment house first went public. The couple’s effective federal tax rate for the year worked out to 13.9 percent, a rate typical of households earning about $80,000 a year.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Chanel
text: For the Couture edition of The Daily Shoe, T picks the most exquisite made-to-measures.

headline: Adoption and the DNA Family Search
text: Many (although far from all) adult adoptees are frustrated by their lack of access to their biological past. The relative openness of adoption records varies from state to state and from year to year, and while many adult adoptees have searched for and found birth relatives, their legal right to information is inconsistent at best. Last year, the adoption advocate Adam Pertman framed it as a civil rights issue: denying adult adoptees access to their original birth certificates, he said, is denying a minority group equal rights under the law.

headline: ‘Very Thin Film’ of Slick Reported from Stricken Cruise Ship
text: GIGLIO, Italy — Salvage and rescue workers reported the first sign of a significant contaminant slick beginning to ooze from the partly submerged Costa Concordia on Tuesday as divers recovered the sodden body of the 16th victim from the Jan. 13 shipwreck.

headline: Documentarians and Animators Go Their Own Ways
text: 5:36 p.m. | Updated  Two groups of Academy voters have traditionally been independent-minded in their choices, and this year is no exception. The documentary branch, which has been roiled by  the changes to its nomination process that will affect selections in the coming years, still managed to have some noteworthy snubs this season, chief among them “Project Nim.”

headline: SPX Sells Auto Tools Business for $1.15 Billion
text: The SPX Corporation, an industrial conglomerate, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its auto tools and solutions business to Robert Bosch of Germany for $1.15 billion in cash.

headline: Reagan Count: Gingrich 55, Romney 6
text: In Monday night’s debate in Tampa, Fla., Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, mentioned Ronald Reagan just four words into his first answer of the night. It was the first of five times that Mr. Gingrich would mention Reagan; no other candidate did so even once.

headline: No Disrespect for the Meatball Hero
text: IF the meatball parmigiana hero were a Southern dish, scholars from Chapel Hill, N.C., to Tallahassee, Fla., would hold academic conferences every six months just to talk about it.

headline: Parm
text: Inside Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone’s Italian-American lunch counter on Mulberry Street.

headline: The Difference Between a Good Web Site and a Great Web Site
text: In last week’s post, we featured the Web site of Bi-Rite Market, an extremely popular San Francisco grocery. One year ago, Sam Mogannam, the market’s owner, redesigned the site and upgraded its social media efforts as part of an overall branding program. Mr. Mogannam reported that he believed the redesign of the site — which promotes the store but does not sell products online — resulted in a steep increase in visitors to the site and a 20 percent increase in the store’s sales.

headline: Scene City: Silent Party for Abramovic at Sundance
text: HBO held this high-concept party to celebrate “Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present,” a documentary playing at this year’s Sundance Film Festival.

headline: TimesCast | January 24, 2012
text: Mitt Romney releases his tax returns | Activists mark the anniversary of the Egyptian revolution | Animated CliffsNotes

headline: Silence for a Talkie
text: PARK CITY, Utah

headline: Edmunds Says Kia Sales Rose 83 Percent in New York
text: Kia experienced exceptional growth in the New York metropolitan area in 2011, with sales increasing 83 percent, according to Edmunds.com. Its Web site compared new-car registration data provided by Polk, the automotive forecasting company, from January through November 2010 with the same 11-month period in 2011. Kia’s performance made it the fastest-growing automotive brand in the metropolitan area among the 35 brands included in the Edmunds analysis.

headline: Mostly Dramas From White Men: Why It’s a Conventional Best Picture List
text: LOS ANGELES — Stretched all the way to nine entries, the year’s field of best picture nominees says one thing loud and clear about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences: It hasn’t changed.

headline: Without Money in Place, ‘Rebecca’ Postpones Broadway Opening Until Next Season
text: The producers of the Broadway-bound musical “Rebecca,” which had been scheduled to begin performances on March 27, said on Tuesday that they were postponing the show until the 2012-13 season because they ran out of time to raise the production’s $12 million capitalization. The musical, which had been set to begin rehearsals on Feb. 6, would have been one of the most expensive of the 2011-12 theater season, but the producers were widely known around Broadway to be struggling to raise the final 20 percent of the show’s budget.

headline: Mitt and Ann Romney’s Tax Returns
text: The Romney campaign released Mitt Romney’s tax returns on Tuesday.

headline: Off the Wall | Alison Eighteen’s Biographical Toile
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Is It Too Early for a Song of the Summer?
text: The quest to name a “song of the summer” has become both more scientific and more quixotic — in part because we’re all entombed in our earbuds now, listening to our niche, custom-curated music feeds, rather than communally riding down Main Street in low-riders blasting “Steal My Sunshine.” And, in part, because most of winter this year, at least in New York, feels weirdly like mid-April.

headline: Big Down Payments Could Bar Creditworthy Borrowers From Market, Study Finds
text: Requiring a minimum down payment of 20 percent, or even 10 percent, on home loans would push many creditworthy borrowers into higher-cost loans or out of the mortgage market entirely, a new study says.

headline: Looking Past the Skepticism on Fate of the Euro
text: PARIS — A decade after the euro’s birth as a full-fledged currency, the anniversary has been more a sickbed vigil than a celebration.

headline: G.M., in Big Ad Move, Consolidates $3 Billion Media Account
text: General Motors, in another effort to cut costs, is consolidating most of an important advertising assignment known as media planning and buying, after pitting four giant media agencies against each other for the task.

headline: Tyne Daly, Ben Vereen Among Theater Hall of Fame Inductees
text: The Theater Hall of Fame, which will hold its annual ceremony on Monday honoring lifetime achievement in American theater, has announced its new inductees. They are the actors Tyne Daly and Ben Vereen; the directors Daniel Sullivan and, posthumously, Paul Sills; the costumer designer Ann Roth; and the producers George C. White, Elliot Martin and Woodie King Jr.

headline: All-American Religion or Reason to Worry?
text: The best musical number in “The Book of Mormon,” the Tony Award-winning play from the holy fools who created “South Park,” is a fantasia that features Hitler, Jeffrey Dahmer, Johnnie Cochran, Genghis Khan and dancing cups of Starbucks coffee. Its title is  “Spooky Mormon Hell Dream.”

headline: Hackers Step Up Attacks After Megaupload Shutdown
text: Last week, after Wikipedia, Reddit and Boing Boing voluntarily blacked out their Web sites to protest proposed antipiracy legislation, hackers began their own blackouts with attacks on dozens of sites across the Internet.

headline: Opening Arguments Set for Perelman Trial
text: Opening arguments are set to begin Tuesday afternoon in trial covering the dispute between the billionaire financier Ronald O. Perelman and his former business partner.

headline: The Buffett Rule Isn’t About Mitt Romney. Or Is it?
text: Debbie Bosanek, who is Warren Buffett’s secretary, will be joining Michelle Obama in the first lady’s box seats during President Obama’s State of the Union address, John H. Cushman Jr. reported for The New York Times Caucus blog. Read more »

headline: A Nominee Toasts His Good Fortune
text: “I’m already drunk!” Demian Bichir announced when he called the Bagger from Mexico City on Tuesday morning, just a few hours after becoming a best actor nominee for his turn as an undocumented immigrant and gardener in “A Better Life.”

headline: A Quirky Set of Technology Predictions for 2012
text: The yearly technology forecasting game tends to be too earnest and too obvious. In part, that is because when the big research houses, like IDC and Gartner, prepare their lists, it is a consensus of their analysts. And why not? The strength of the large research firms is their deep benches — the breadth and depth of their industry smarts. The results, though, are works of what today is called collective intelligence and what used to be called a committee.

headline: Data Law in Works, But Tech Booms in Europe
text: Europe may be on the brink of passing what some tech firms and entrepreneurs view as a stifling law on data protection and the rights of consumers to have their data destroyed. But the chatter at an annual tech conference in Munich where E.U. Commissioner Viviane Reding laid out those data privacy plans this week seemed to be that the Web is booming on a continent better known lately for austerity and cutbacks.

headline: The First Hours of Egypt’s Revolution
text: Egyptian activists and the military council that still rules the country are braced for planned demonstrations on Wednesday, the first anniversary of the start of the revolution that toppled former President Hosni Mubarak. Since our coverage of last year’s events was illuminated by online reports from activists who documented the uprising on social networks, The Lede discussed the anniversary with some of those bloggers.

headline: Federer vs. Del Potro: Breaking It Down
text: The brilliance of Roger Federer is best found by not looking at Roger Federer at all.

headline: Just One Look | Chanel
text: At Chanel haute couture, Karl Lagerfeld built the interior of an airplane in the attic of the Mini Palais and then set loose a collection of dresses rendered in every possible shade of sky. It soared. Each detail lifted the looks from cocktail to cool: the shoulder duster drop earrings in silver and sapphire, the mohawks and quiffs held high with jewels and feathers. Some of the loveliest frocks had voluminous sleeves and embroidery that nodded to Art Deco, like this short number edged in a fan and bird motif.

headline: Officer Pleads Guilty to Civil Rights Violation
text: 5:01 p.m. | Updated  A white New York City police officer pleaded guilty on Tuesday to violating the civil rights of a black man on Staten Island by charging him with resisting arrest knowing that there was no probable cause to support the charge.

headline: Wasting the Wastewater
text: Each day, American municipalities discharge treated wastewater back into natural sources at a rate that would fill an empty Lake Champlain within six months. Growing pressure on water supplies and calls for updating the ancient subterranean piping infrastructure have brought new scrutiny to this step in the treatment process, which is labeled wasteful and unnecessary by a spectrum of voices.

headline: Peyton Manning a Cheerleader for His Brother
text: Peyton Manning spends most of his time in the Indianapolis Colts’ weight room now, in a desperate race to rehabilitate from the neck injury that cost him the 2011 season and could imperil his career. That was where he watched the Giants’ run to the Super Bowl, an extremely well-informed fan with an extremely deep rooting interest.

headline: Global Research Awards Showcase China’s Gains and Efforts to Retain Scientists
text: BEIJING — China’s government has thrown billions in recent years into building a top-notch research establishment, hoping to keep its best scientists working here and lure back those who are abroad.

headline: Council Panel Upholds a Historic Skyscraper District in Brooklyn
text: A historic district composed largely of early office towers in downtown Brooklyn was approved in its entirety Tuesday by the City Council’s landmarks subcommittee, all but guaranteeing that the entire Council will ratify it in turn.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 24
text: A view of the day in sports, including Australian Open action and the departure of the Yankees’ Jorge Posada.

headline: In a Plan to Close a Customs Post, Seeing Harm for Beer, Bananas and a Port Itself
text: The journey of a banana from Ecuador to Brooklyn is a precisely timed affair, from the moment it is sliced off a stalk and then packed onto a ship for a seven-day refrigerated cruise to the Red Hook Container Terminal. From there, the banana has one week to make it from container to distributor to grocery store.

headline: For Posada, an Emotional Farewell
text: 8:15 p.m. | Updated In the latter innings of his career, Jorge Posada faced the painful but inevitable slide of an aging star. Younger and more productive players pushed him lower and lower down the batting order, ultimately resulting in the only real public feud he had with his team.

headline: Giorgio Armani: Spring 2012 Couture
text: Paris

headline: French Bill on Genocide Is Denounced by Turkey
text: PARIS — The Turkish government and news media castigated France on Tuesday, accusing Parliament of racism and a breach of France’s own free speech principles after the French Senate passed a bill late Monday criminalizing the denial of officially recognized genocides, including the Armenian genocide begun in 1915.

headline: Giorgio Armani Prive Couture
text: Paris

headline: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Jack Bell, who covers soccer for The Times, will have answers to readers’ questions on the Goal blog on Wednesday.

headline: Road Trip! But First, Saving Money as You Plan
text: I’m not really your drive-across-America type — more of a train-through-India or Bolivia-by-bus kind of traveler. But I’ve long wanted to do a road trip in Texas. For someone like me, who has never lived west of the Hudson, it’s perhaps the most fascinating state in the nation. It’s vast without being empty, associated with powerful American symbols like cowboy boots and pickup trucks and high school football, carries more than half our border with Mexico, has at least a claim on the nation’s best barbecue (not to mention all that Tex-Mex), and has a long, complicated and fascinating history. It’s at once as American as apple pie and as alien as another planet.

headline: On the Stump: Examining the Form and Function of Campaign Speeches
text: Overview | What is a stump speech, and what makes one effective? In this lesson, students analyze the stump speeches of presidential candidates, then write the stump speech they would use if they were running for president.

headline: Nascar and Ford Unveil Fusion Sprint Cup Car
text: Wearing the automaker’s new corporate face, the Ford Fusion Nascar Sprint Cup racecar was unveiled at a news conference by Ford and Nascar Tuesday afternoon at Charlotte Motor Speedway. The car will be campaigned in 2013, making its race debut at the Daytona 500 in February of next year.

headline: Rick Santorum’s Adventures on the Loony Right
text: There are moments in a political campaign when a sharply aimed question can reveal a great deal about the one thing that candidates most want to hide – their character.

headline: What’s Your Response to Obama’s Third State of the Union Address?
text: 10:55 p.m. | Updated The president of the United States gives an annual speech to Congress called the State of the Union address. President Obama’s third such speech was Tuesday night – and delivered it as his re-election campaign, and the Republican presidential nominating contest, are under way. Did you watch the speech? What did you think of his remarks, and of the Republican rebuttal?

headline: Oscars: Not the Usual Suspects
text: There were no major fashion plates among the Oscar nominees announced this morning, but that might provide for a more exciting red carpet at the Academy Awards.

headline: Hey, Uggie, Christopher Plummer Won’t Back Down
text: “I’m sleepy, but I’m all right.” That was a groggy Christopher Plummer today after he learned that he had received his second Academy Award nomination, this one for best supporting actor for “Beginners.” (Mr. Plummer was also nominated in that category in 2010, for “The Last Station.”)

headline: European Central Bank Moves to Avoid Loss on Greek Bonds
text: LONDON — European leaders have begun discussions with the European Central Bank on several options that might keep it from having to take a loss on its 55 billion-euro portfolio of Greek bonds.

headline: ‘House’ and the Big House Lift Fox
text: With CBS in repeats it was a tight race among the broadcast networks on Monday night as Fox ultimately came out ahead in all ratings categories. “House” returned on Fox after an almost two-month absence, and Hugh Laurie fans were ready and waiting. The medical drama had its best numbers since October and drew 8.8 million viewers. “Alcatraz,” also on Fox, held its ground in its second week with only a modest drop to just under 9 million viewers from the 10 million who tuned in to last week’s premiere. It also dipped in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic by 10 percent.

headline: Five Dishes at Parm
text: This week I review Parm, where Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone are serving food more or less taken from the Italian-American deli canon: Sausage and peppers, potato and eggs, garlic bread, pizza knots and all kinds of parms. I interviewed the two chefs earlier this week about five of the dishes I especially enjoyed.

headline: Why ‘Harry Potter’ Deserved More
text: Maybe the idea is that if the Academy nominates as many movies as possible across the various high-profile categories, more moviegoers will have a rooting interest and more people will watch. “Tree of Life” fans, “Midnight in Paris” fans, “A Separation” fans, “Rango” fans — just about everyone is theoretically covered.

headline: Joining Mrs. Obama Will Be …
text: The guests joining Michelle Obama in her box seats overlooking the House chamber for the president’s State of the Union speech on Tuesday night include Jill Biden, the vice president’s wife; Valerie Jarrett, the president’s senior adviser; and a panoply of ordinary and extraordinary people chosen as archetypes of the policies, priorities and accomplishments Mr. Obama will seek to emphasize.

headline: Grief Could Join List of Disorders
text: When does a broken heart become a diagnosis?

headline: Looking Outside of Schools for Science and Technology
text: WNYC's Brian Lehrer discusses how to get your child exposed to science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) both in and outside of school with the head of the New York Hall of Science in Queens.

headline: TimesCast | Egypt's Revolution Continues
text: January 24, 2012 — From Cairo, Robert Mackey of the Lede blog interviews Gigi Ibrahim, a liberal activist, on the first anniversary of the Egyptian revolution.

headline: Givenchy: Spring 2012 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Givenchy Couture
text: Paris

headline: Union Radio Ad Assails Romney in Spanish
text: The Service Employees International Union began airing a Spanish-language radio spot in Florida on Tuesday that seeks to turn the state’s Hispanic voters against Mitt Romney by accusing him of being two-faced on immigration policy.

headline: Apps for Children With Dyslexia
text: The parent of a second grader newly diagnosed with dyslexia wrote me asking if I knew of any apps that might help her son with reading and math. She’d searched and come up with nothing — and so did I, with the same result. There is software out there designed to help children with dyslexia read (expensive software) but nothing yet in the way of an app marketed for that purpose (and there’s obviously no app that will “fix” dyslexia).

headline: Hundreds of Restaurateurs Sound Off on Sanitary Inspections
text: The New York City Council will announce Wednesday that nearly 1,000 restaurant operators have responded, after only two weeks, to a Web survey seeking their views about the city health department’s new letter-grading system for food safety.

headline: A Bizarre Turn In The Stimulus Debate (Boring)
text: Wow. Just wow. John Cochrane puts up a post that to all appearances amounts to a complete retreat from his previous denunciations of deficit spending in a recession. But he simultaneously denies having ever held the position everyone thought he held, and denounces me and Brad DeLong as big meanies. I’ll outsource the analysis to Noah Smith.

headline: Goldman Makes Money for the Romneys
text: After a long, controversial wait, Mitt Romney released details of his federal tax returns on Tuesday, inciting a flurry of wide-eyed analysis from those curious to see exactly how Mr. Romney’s personal finances stack up.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Star Dancer Quits Royal Ballet
text: Sergei Polunin, the dark-eyed phenom who was the youngest male dancer ever to be made a principal with the Royal Ballet, abruptly quit the company on Tuesday afternoon. Monica Mason, the director of the Royal Ballet, said in a press statement, “This has obviously come as a huge shock. Sergei is a wonderful dancer, and I have enjoyed watching him tremendously, both on stage and in the studio, over the past few years. I wish him every success in the future.”

headline: David Kenny Named Chief of the Weather Channel
text: The Weather Channel Companies, which owns the Weather Channel, replaced its leadership on Tuesday, and named the digital advertising veteran David Kenny its chairman and chief executive.Mr. Kenny will start immediately. Michael J. Kelly, who had been the chief executive since 2009, will become a special adviser to the company and an adviser to Bain Capital, the private equity firm that co-owns the company with the Blackstone Group and Comcast’s NBCUniversal.The surprise change signaled a desire on the part of the co-owners to expand the Weather Channel’s digital and mobile businesses more quickly. Through mobile apps and Web sites like Weather.com, the company sees an opportunity to have a much bigger international footprint.“Six and a half billion people need information about weather,” Mr. Kenny said in an interview Tuesday after addressing the company’s staff in Atlanta.Mr. Kenny also said that the company would make more investments in long-form programming — part of a gradual move away from live weather news and toward taped weather-related reality shows.“Now that people can get the information they need for their forecast off the Web, and certainly on their mobile phone, that gives us more license to do more long-form on the cable channel,” he said. The channel remained committed to live news during severe weather, he added.Mr. Kenny, a member of the board of directors of Yahoo, was the president of Akamai until he stepped down last October. He was previously the co-founder of VivaKi, a digital agency that is part of the Publicis Groupe.In a statement, the three co-owners of the Weather Channel said that Mr. Kenny’s experience “gives him a deep understanding of the TV and digital business, and he has the leadership experience and vision to drive global initiatives across all platforms.”Mr. Kelly, similarly, had a digital media background when he was hired two and a half years ago.Mr. Kenny said he was initially recruited to join the board of the company, and was later asked by the board to consider the chief executive position.“What I’ve long stood for is convergence,” he said. “I think you’ll see us find better ways to run the Weather Channel as one company, really organized around our hundreds of millions of users.”NBCUniversal and the private equity firms have owned the Weather Channel since 2008.

headline: Chinese Manufacturing and the Auto Bailout
text: Jon Cohn, in correspondence, makes an important point with regard to the big Times report on Chinese manufacturing. Since he hasn’t posted about it, I will.

headline: Expanding the Definition of Depression
text: Does grieving over a loved one constitute full-blown depression?

headline: The Lowdown | Cass Bird
text: Cass Bird’s photographs are instantly recognizable: her subjects always look mischievous, and like they are having just a little too much fun. Whether it’s a teenage model, her own children or the actor Viggo Mortensen (whom she photographed for the cover of T Magazine), Bird consistently manages to get the people she shoots to let their guard down so that the images ultimately reflect an integral part of her own personality: the hyperactive goofball. In her work for the Gap, Wrangler, Urban Outfitters and numerous magazines, Bird’s aesthetic is best described as “young, carefree, loving life and you’re so jealous,” and her influence radiates throughout popular photography.

headline: Newt and Marianne and Ted and Alice
text: Since I’m cited repeatedly as the tribune of an unforgiving moral absolutism in Timothy Noah’s piece kinda-sorta defending Newt Gingrich’s request that his second wife tolerate his ongoing affair, it would be unsporting of me not to find something in his brief to dispute. So I’ll take on this point:

headline: Occupy Wall Street Drops Suit on Zuccotti Park
text: Occupy Wall Street protesters have decided to drop a lawsuit challenging the rules that prohibited them from camping inside Zuccotti Park, their lawyers said on Tuesday.

headline: The Long Odds for a Small Canadian Film
text: The Canadian Philippe Falardeau, who wrote and directed “Monsieur Lazhar,” one of the five nominees for best foreign-language film, is at the Sundance Film Festival this week. Early on Tuesday morning, he was in a rented condo with his producers watching the Oscar nominations telecast, and when they heard the word “Canada,” he said, “we screamed so loud, with a mixture of joy and relief, that I didn’t even hear the title of my film.”

headline: After MF Global’s Demise, Futures Industry Explores Tougher Rules
text: It is not every day that Wall Street volunteers for new regulation.

headline: A Low-Key Spot With a High-Wattage Connection
text: THE women made a pilgrimage to West 68th Street, 450 miles from home, squinting in the rain on Monday as they peered through the restaurant’s front windows. The place was closed, they were told.

headline: In Nadal Vs. Berdych, Conditioning Makes a Difference
text: Rafael Nadal withstood a barrage of huge serving and heavy, punishing groundstrokes from Tomas Berdych, prevailing in four grueling sets to advance to the semifinals. The level of play throughout the four hour and sixteen minute match was high, as both players hit more winners than unforced errors. Berdych hit 66 winners while making 56 unforced errors; Nadal had 57 winners and made only 30 unforced errors.

headline: Tigers Make Free-Agency Splash, Sign Fielder
text: The Detroit Tigers are on the verge of pulling off one of the biggest free-agent deals of the off-season, having come to terms with slugger Prince Fielder on a nine-year, $214 million deal, according to multiple team sources. The signing was quickly reported by FoxSports and others.

text: While a weak economy may have driven consumers to cut back, we know that they are still indulging on the little things.

text: When Martin Scorsese goes into an editing room, what he likes to do, said Thelma Schoonmaker, his longtime editor, is just watch a little TV.

headline: The Shanty
text: 79 Richardson Street (Leonard Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 878-3579, nydistilling.com/the-shanty

headline: Givenchy’s Deco Punk
text: Cameron Diaz was having a private tour of the Givenchy spring couture collection, courtesy of Riccardo Tisci, when I popped in to see the clothes. It was nearly nightfall. Some photographers were huddled under an awning in the Place Vendôme, trying to stay out of the rain that has drenched Paris. Mr. Tisci’s collection consisted of 10 outfits, most of which were displayed on suspended dress forms in three rooms, with gilt trim and creaky parquet.

headline: Reviewing the Shanty
text: The Shanty, a new bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that I reviewed this week, serves a whiskey cocktail they call the Lonesome Hero. It’s a terrific drink: an old-fashioned variant made with cherry liqueur and the Czech herbal bitters Becherovka. Yet ordering one feels a little bit like getting the salmon at Peter Luger. That’s because the Shanty – for the moment, at least – is mostly about the gin. The bar is an annex of the New York Distilling Company, which has been producing two types of gin since November. They’re not the only people to do the micro-distilling thing in the borough (there’s also the Kings County Distillery and Breuckelen Distilling in Sunset Park), but they’re the first with their own bar. The Shanty is clearly more than a gin joint, and no one will push you to order the company’s products. But after admiring their gorgeous German-made pot still through a window onto the distillery floor, it’s hard to choose something made elsewhere. This week, they have started distilling the rye that will be ready for bottling a year from now. They already have a great drink to use it in.

headline: Just One Look | Giambattista Valli
text: As the Oscars become fashion’s talking point, actresses and presenters will be looking for glamorous, pretty gowns to get them through the night looking uncontroversially lovely. They could do little better than to turn to Giambattista Valli, whose second haute couture collection again showcased his considerable talents as a draper and festooner of evening wear. His strapless floral look — made of a beautiful devore-esque fabric — is simplicity and whimsy in a superluxurious stunner.

headline: Not All Wetlands Are Created Equal
text: To many, it’s a familiar scenario: a strip mall suddenly pops up in what was once a desolate quagmire or boggy boondock.

headline: In Battered Area, Romney Assails Gingrich on Foreclosures
text: LEHIGH ACRES, Fla. — Mitt Romney toured the epicenter of Florida’s foreclosure crisis on Tuesday as he continued to try to draw attention to Newt Gingrich‘s work on behalf of Freddie Mac.

headline: Baylor Football, Post-Griffin
text: WACO, Tex. — From the time he emerged from the second string as a freshman to recording 10 wins last season, adding a bowl victory and the university’s first Heisman Trophy, it is safe to say that Robert Griffin III put Baylor football back on the map.

headline: Watson Acquires General Lee, His Dream Car
text: SAN DIEGO — A scheduling conflict kept Bubba Watson from answering the call from President Clinton to play in last week’s Humana Challenge outside Palm Desert. Clinton, with his deep-fried Southern roots, might have given Watson his blessing if he had known how Watson spent the weekend.

headline: Germany Permits Itself to Celebrate Prussian King
text: POTSDAM, Germany — The official delegation honoring Frederick the Great’s 300th birthday had just finished laying a laurel wreath and a grand cross of white flowers at his grave here on Tuesday when a 70-year-old retiree quietly slipped in behind them and placed a small potato on the gray slab of stone that marks the monarch’s resting place.

Both actors were tipped to be nominees in the best supporting actor category – Mr. Brooks was even a heavy favorite for his against-type turn as a criminal in “Drive” – and both took to Twitter when they didn’t make the cut.

headline: A Winter Tomato Worth Buying
text: Lucky Lee has been selling vine-ripened Florida tomatoes for decades, mainly to restaurants in winter. Now she has a new one, a hefty crimson beefsteak. It’s meaty, juicy, flavorful and, yes, a winter tomato that’s actually worth buying. Called the Tasti-Lee, it is a hybrid developed by Jay Scott, a tomato breeder at the University of Florida. The Lee part of the name, though, has nothing to do with Ms. Lee, the distributor who has just introduced them in the New York area; Mr. Scott named the tomato in honor of his late mother-in law, Leocadia Czarnomski.

headline: From the Crucifixion to the Internet, You Are There
text: Judith Malina — a founder and unsinkable bulwark of the Living Theater, a beacon of experimental performance in New York since 1947 — instigates another rebellion with “History of the World,” now at the troupe’s Lower East Side home. Though Ms. Malina, at 85, shows no loss of fight, there is something almost elegiac about her latest piece, no less than an exuberant, dizzying and exhausting flight through the course of Western civilization, peppered with political observations. Certainly Ms. Malina has earned the right to conduct such an ambitious survey.

headline: With Defaults Low, Bankruptcy Experts Keep Eyes on Europe
text: It has been more than two years since the busiest time in recent memory for bankruptcy professionals, and the restructuring industry is still waiting for its business to pick up again.

headline: Wines Worth a Taste, but Not the Vitriol
text: ROBERT M. PARKER JR., the powerful wine critic, called it “one of the major scams being foisted on wine consumers.”

headline: Lawsuit Seeks Records From Toyota Investigation
text: DETROIT — Concerned that regulators are dismissing electronic problems in Toyota vehicles, an auto safety firm said Tuesday that it had sued the federal government to get records of its investigation into the unintended acceleration of a Prius last year.

headline: Marveling at a Maestro of Glass, Steel and Light
text: “How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster?,” an admiring documentary about the British architect Norman Foster, by Norberto López Amado and Carlos Carcas, gives the viewer quite a lot to marvel at, which is, after all, the root meaning of the word “admire.”

headline: At Brooklyn Prep, Paterno Learned Latin and Bravado
text: At the Jesuit high school Joe Paterno attended in Brooklyn, students wore jackets and ties and were taught by priests or by lay teachers in academic robes. The curriculum was also rigorously Old World: students took several years of Latin and many added three years of Greek, with three hours of homework per night the rule.

headline: Romney’s Plan for ‘Self-Deportation’ Has Conservative Support
text: When Mitt Romney said in the Republican debate on Monday night that he favored “self-deportation” as a solution to illegal immigration, it seemed to come out of the blue, perhaps an effort, as the race moves to Florida, to soften the hard line he has staked out on immigration.

headline: G.O.P. Debate on NBC Drew Over 7 Million Viewers
text: The Republican debate on NBC on Monday night attracted the second-highest number of viewers of any debate in the current presidential election season, a little over seven million.

headline: Pro-Gingrich ‘Super PAC’ to Spend $6 Million on Florida Ads
text: A “super PAC” supporting Newt Gingrich said Tuesday that it was putting $6 million behind a new advertisement in Florida, giving the spots a major presence on airwaves that have up until now been dominated by Mitt Romney.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Steve Jobs’s Photo Plan, Piracy and Public Outrage
text: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: Facebook Readies Timeline Takeover
text: Facebook announced on Tuesday that it would begin the global rollout of Timeline, a profile-page makeover that displays a user’s entire history of photos, links and other things shared on Facebook in chronological order, making them accessible with a single click.

headline: The First Time’s Surreal, for Muppet, Man or Dragon Tattoo Girl
text: We heard from a few more nominees today, including three first-timers: Bret McKenzie, Jonah Hill and Rooney Mara.

headline: Amid Attacks on Private Equity, Efforts to Study Its Value
text: Controversy swirls around private equity as attacks on Mitt Romney and the entire industry mount. Amid the name-calling, little in the way of evidence has been cited. So let’s take a look at some of the best research on this issue.

headline: Senate Hopeful Says He Takes ‘Full Responsibility’ for Blog Posts
text: Marc Cenedella, a Republican businessman laying the groundwork for a possible run for a United States Senate seat in New York, said on Tuesday that he took “full responsibility” for blog posts about sex, women and drugs that have drawn criticism.

text: As in years past, the Obama administration released excerpts of President Obama’s State of the Union address several hours before the start of the speech:

headline: Readers’ SotU Wish List
text: Earlier today I posted the editorial board’s wish list for Barack Obama’s State of the Union speech. We included issues we find important, without regard to political wisdom. Readers then added to the list in the comments section and on Facebook, and made it even less realistic—with one commenter, for instance, calling on Mr. Obama to argue for Medicare for all in lieu of the hard-won Affordable Care Act. Dream on.

headline: Gates to Pitch His Charity Work at Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Some people come to the World Economic Forum expecting caviar. Bill Gates said he would bring cassava.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Bahrain, Iraq, Spain and India.

headline: Look of The Moment | Natalia Vodianova
text: The Look: Country Strong. An elegant topcoat and tall lace-up boots over white leggings — it’s a study in neutrals that verges on equestrian but leans most certainly toward sexy, too.

headline: In Address, Obama Makes Pitch for Economic Fairness
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama pledged on Tuesday night to use government power to balance the scale between America’s rich and the rest of the public, trying to present an election-year choice between continued leadership toward an economy “built to last” and what he called irresponsible policies of the past that caused an economic collapse.

headline: A Dignitary of Cuban Jazz Holds Court in Carnegie Hall
text: During his final few moments onstage at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, Chucho Valdés stopped playing, midphrase, to issue an instructive edict. He was well into his second encore then, alone at the piano, teasing out a Gershwin medley that had whimsically morphed into the Cuban standard “El Manisero.” The audience, elated, started clapping four beats to a bar. Immediately, his hands lifted from the keyboard to clap a son clave: one, two, three, one-two. He transferred this pattern to the keyboard, implying that the crowd was to follow his lead. Moments later, he was up and gone.

headline: A Formidable Piece by Messiaen, Inspired by Two Breathtaking Places
text: Everything about Messiaen’s “Des Canyons aux Étoiles” (“From the Canyons to the Stars”) is vast. This audacious 100-minute work is scored for 44 individual instruments, including all manner of percussion, and features a formidable solo piano part. It was inspired by Messiaen’s 1972 visit to Bryce Canyon and Cedar Breaks in Utah, where he looked in awe at craggy rock formations and reddish-orange geological vistas.

headline: In Winter Weather, Flying to Find Wolves
text: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

headline: Bloomberg Assails Showing of Anti-Muslim Film to  Police
text: ALBANY – Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that whoever decided to show a film depicting American Muslims as extremists to nearly 1,500 city police officers “exercised some terrible judgment.”

headline: Facebook’s Sandberg Gently Warns Europe About Privacy Rules
text: Concerned about privacy? Maybe you should be concernedabout the economy instead. That was the subtext of a keynote speech by Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, at a technology conference in the heart of Europe on Tuesday.

headline: Not Just for Sundays After Church
text: JUSTIN SOELBERG, the chef at Communal restaurant in Provo, Utah, has heard all the jokes about Mormon food. “People think it’s just casseroles and Jell-O all the time,” said Mr. Soelberg, 30, who grew up Mormon in Idaho and graduated from the French Culinary Institute in Manhattan.

headline: Rubio Stays Neutral, but Defends Romney
text: SARASOTA, Fla. – Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has pledged to remain neutral in the Republican presidential campaign, particularly during the intensifying clash between Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich before the primary here next week.

headline: Storyteller Well Versed in Liszt’s Versatility
text: The pianist Garrick Ohlsson spoke recently of his affinity for Liszt, an empathy that was certainly evident during his stunning performance of Liszt’s Sonata in B minor at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Aspire Prep Says It Should Not Be Penalized for One Bad Year
text: The Bronx middle school Aspire Preparatory claims it is being unfairly tarnished because of one especially bad year. The school earned its first F last year when a high number of teachers were absent and it had to lean heavily on a revolving door of substitutes. Now it will likely be phased out, only a few years after it took the place of an even less successful school.

headline: A Family Film From a Coppola Family Member
text: PARK CITY, Utah – “Goats” is the type of Sundance movie you could accidentally drive right past. The title isn’t all that enticing. Its Tuesday-night premiere slot is deep in the festival, when your attention is starting to sputter.

headline: On a Roll, Bringing a Downtown Attitude
text: MATT ABRAMCYK was obsessed with a seat.

headline: Olympic Qualifying: U.S. Women vs. Mexico
text: The United States women’s team will have revenge on its mind when it plays Mexico on Tuesday night in the Concacaf Olympic qualifying tournament in Vancouver (10:30 p.m. Eastern, Universal Sports/streaming at universalsports.com).

headline: Rushdie’s Video Talk Is Canceled at India Literature Festival
text: Salman Rushdie’s virtual participation at the Jaipur Literature Festival in India was canceled at the last minute on Tuesday after Muslim groups attending the festival threatened violence if his image was shown. After canceling an in-person appearance, Mr. Rushdie planned to address thousands of festival attendees by video conference on Tuesday. “There are a large number of people adverse to this link in and around this property, and they have threatened violence,” said Thakur Ram Pratap Singh of Diggi, the owner of Diggi Palace, the festival site. “This decision is necessary to protect everyone here,” he said. Mr. Rushdie’s plans to attend the festival, above, stirred controversy before it opened, and he said on the first day that he would not attend, citing a risk to his safety. Mr. Rushdie’s “Satanic Verses” was banned in India in 1988, and he has been the target of criticism and a fatwa from Muslim groups. His life was threatened several times before the festival, officials told the organizers. Mr. Rushdie criticized both the Indian government and Islamic leaders in an interview on Tuesday evening with the television channel NDTV. Mr. Rushdie said he had been cast as an enemy of Islam even though the real enemies were “the various extremist leaders and their followers, who behave like this because what they do is to strengthen the extremely negative image of Islam as an intolerant, repressive and violent culture.”

headline: Larry Butler, Producer for Kenny Rogers, Dies at 69
text: Larry Butler, the producer of some of Kenny Rogers’s biggest hits and the only Nashville session leader ever to win a Grammy Award for producer of the year, died on Friday at his home in Pensacola, Fla. He was 69.

headline: Boy With Strange Powers and a Challenged Father
text: One of the smaller leaps of logic in “Touch” — the new Fox series representing Kiefer Sutherland’s full-time return to television — is that the 11-year-old boy at the center of the story has never spoken and is also the show’s narrator. It’s a perfectly acceptable device, if not a particularly interesting one in this case.

headline: In Abu Dhabi, Not Torrey Pines, Woods Acknowledges Lure of Appearance Fees
text: SAN DIEGO — Tiger Woods was asked in December why he was bypassing this week’s PGA Tour stop at Torrey Pines despite having won here 6 times in 12 appearances. It is also the site of his last major victory, the 2008 United States Open. Woods instead committed to play in a concurrent European Tour event in Abu Dhabi with less than half the total purse — $2.7 million to $6 million here.

headline: Martin Agrees to Deal With Yankees
text: Just hours after Jorge Posada, their catcher of the past, announced his retirement, the Yankees said Tuesday that they had agreed on a contract with Russell Martin, their catcher of the present.

headline: J.F.K.’s Final Words in Office
text: Before President John F. Kennedy left the White House for his fateful trip to Dallas, he said he expected a “rough day” when he returned to Washington, according to recently released recordings of his final meetings.

headline: Buffett vs. Mankiw on Taxes
text: By inviting Debbie Bosanek, Warren Buffett’s secretary, to sit in the first lady’s box at the State of the Union address, President Obama has signaled that he intends to talk about the tax rate on some investments. Mr. Obama and Mr. Buffett both argue that many investment managers pay too little tax, because the tax code treats their pay as an investment return — and thus taxes it at a much lower rate than ordinary income. Mr. Buffett has famously said that, as a result, his secretary pays a higher tax rate than he does.

headline: Bill Mardo, Writer Who Pushed Baseball to Integrate, Dies at 88
text: Bill Mardo, a sportswriter for the Communist Party newspaper The Daily Worker who fought major league baseball’s color barrier in the 1940s when the mainstream American news media was largely silent on the subject, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Mudd Resigns as Fortress Chief Executive
text: The Fortress Investment Group said on Tuesday that Daniel H. Mudd had resigned as the investment firm’s chief executive, as he remained the subject of a government lawsuit tied to his tenure as the head of Fannie Mae.

headline: TimesCast | Egypt's Revolution Continues
text: January 24, 2012 — Robert Mackey of the Lede blog interviews Mosa’ab Elshamy, an activist and photographer living in Cairo, about the first anniversary of Egypt’s revolution.

headline: Anger in Iraq After Plea Bargain Over 2005 Massacre
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqis were outraged Tuesday to learn that the Marine considered the ringleader of a 2005 massacre that left 24 of their countrymen dead in 2005 was sentenced on Tuesday to a reduction in rank but avoided any jail time after pleading guilty the day before to a reduced charge.

headline: ‘Downton’ Fans: The Writer Suggests a Book for You
text: To the Editor:

headline: Azarenka Wears Down Radwanska With Power Tennis
text: The Agnieszka Radwanska-Victoria Azarenka match was a textbook case of how aggressive play and offense beats risk-averse defense in big matches. Although Radwanska took the first set, winning an error-filled tiebreaker 7-0 as Azarenka self-destructed, the rest of the match was a clinic in power tennis dominating a more conservative game plan. Azarenka began to take the ball early and move Radwanska mercilessly from side to side. The normally stingy Radwanska (she committed only 3 unforced errors in her fourth round win over Julia Gorges) began to crumble as Azarenka’s heavy groundstrokes found their mark. Radwanska made 31 unforced errors in the match, and gradually wore down under Azarenka’s constant pressure.

headline: Learning Amid the Ruins
text: Poor Cambodian villagers come to Siem Reap to work in the tourism industry around the ruins of Angkor Wat, but many also find a path to higher education.

headline: Our Options for Dealing With Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Regulating the Banks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chip Maker Predicts Lower Sales
text: Advanced Micro Devices, a maker of processors for personal computers, forecast lower sales on Tuesday than some analysts had estimated, hurt by supply shortages and slower demand for PCs.

headline: Live Blog: The State of the Union
text: President Obama made his way down the aisle of the House Chamber at 9 Eastern time on Tuesday, shaking hands and accepting kind words from Republican and Democratic lawmakers before delivering his third State of the Union address. It was also an opening of sorts for a re-election campaign amid some glimmerings of optimism in the economy but stiff headwinds from a weary public.

headline: In Brazil, Fears of a Slide Back for Amazon Protection
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazil has made great strides in recent years in slowing Amazon deforestation and showing the world it was serious about protecting the mammoth rain forest.

headline: Egyptian Activists Say Their Revolution Remains Unfinished
text: As Egyptians prepare to mark the first anniversary of the revolution that toppled Hosni Mubarak but left them under the rule of his top generals, two activists explained in interviews with The Lede on Tuesdau that they plan to protest, not celebrate.

headline: Excerpts From the Republican Response
text: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana will be delivering the Republican response to President Obama’s State of the Union address, and Congressional Republican leaders released excerpts of his speech Tuesday evening:

headline: A Test for Egypt: Hearing All Voices
text: Cairo

headline: For Thousands of Mourners, Paterno’s Legacy Will Remain Unshaken
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Mourners descended on this town in droves Tuesday to say goodbye to Joe Paterno, the football coach who was more than a football coach to them. Wearing suits or Penn State sweatshirts, alumni and fans came from Scranton to Sewickley, and seemingly all points in between.

headline: Director Quits After Changes at Global Fund
text: The executive director of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria resigned Tuesday, culminating two months of struggle over the future direction of the fund.

headline: Syria Rejects Peace Effort From Region
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Saying that “half the universe” was conspiring against his country, the Syrian foreign minister forcefully rejected a regional attempt to broker an end to the 10-month conflict here on Tuesday and suggested that there would be no end to the government’s use of force to put down the uprising.

headline: The Tax Deduction Mitt Romney Did Not Take
text: The release of Mitt Romney’s tax returns for 2010, all 500 pages of them, shines a bright light into the strategies wealthy people use to reduce their tax burden — Mr. Romney managed to reduce his effective tax rate on $21 million of income to just 13.9 percent.

headline: The Florida State of Play
text: We’re exactly one week away from the Florida primary, which looks as though it could be pivotal in the Republican nomination campaign.

headline: Mets Look Back and Ahead
text: The annual fund-raising dinner to benefit the Baseball Assistance Team, a charity that aids former players in need, served Tuesday as a celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Mets. It brought together a wide swath of personalities from the team’s past and present at the Marriott Marquis in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Average Is Over
text: In an essay, entitled “Making It in America,” in the latest issue of The Atlantic, the author Adam Davidson relates a joke from cotton country about just how much a modern textile mill has been automated: The average mill has only two employees today, “a man and a dog. The man is there to feed the dog, and the dog is there to keep the man away from the machines.”

headline: A Way to Make People Buy Homes Again
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Giants Deny Taking Aim at 49er With Concussions

President Obama did not mention the pipeline decision – which some Republicans have vowed to reverse – but he stressed the increase in oil and gas production over the past two years. He said that American oil production is the highest it has been in the past eight years and imports are lower than at any time in the past 16 years.

headline: The State of the Union Address: And So It Begins
text: If anyone had any lingering doubts about whether President Obama is ready to fight for his job, the State of the Union address tonight should have dispelled them. I’m not the biggest fan of the president’s speeches. They can be awfully long, his delivery rather low-key, and his talking points often follow a slow-windup-then-slower-let-down pattern. If he had treated us to that drill tonight, a lot of voters would have switched to a screening of “The Shawshank Redemption” or maybe reruns of “The Big Bang Theory.”

headline: Georgia: Publisher Quits After Column on Obama
text: The publisher of The Atlanta Jewish Times resigned Tuesday after writing that Israel should consider assassinating President Obama. Andrew B. Adler stepped down after an outcry over a recent column in which he suggested that the Israeli military might “take out a president deemed unfriendly to Israel.” Mr. Adler could not be reached but has apologized in other interviews. The Secret Service has said it is investigating the episode. On its Web site, the newspaper said it is seeking a successor for Mr. Adler, who is also the owner, and looks forward to trying to serve readers “more faithfully than ever in the future.”

headline: Russia: Protest by Jewish Group Over Memorial
text: The Russian Jewish Congress announced on Tuesday that it had sent a letter of protest to regional officials over the decision to replace a memorial plaque to Jews killed in the Holocaust with one that mentions only “peaceful citizens of Rostov-on-Don and Soviet prisoners of war.” The plaque was in Zmiyevskaya Balka, near the southern city of Rostov-on-Don. Last November, officials removed a plaque hung in 2004, which read, “On the 11-12 of August 1942, Nazis killed more than 27,000 Jews here.” Where the old text refers to “the Holocaust,” the new one reads “mass killing by the fascists of captured Soviet citizens,” phraseology widely used during Soviet times, according to the Web site of the Russian Jewish Congress.
