headline: Will Israel Attack Iran?
text: As the Sabbath evening approached on Jan. 13, Ehud Barak paced the wide living-room floor of his home high above a street in north Tel Aviv, its walls lined with thousands of books on subjects ranging from philosophy and poetry to military strategy. Barak, the Israeli defense minister, is the most decorated soldier in the country’s history and one of its most experienced and controversial politicians. He has served as chief of the general staff for the Israel Defense Forces, interior minister, foreign minister and prime minister. He now faces, along with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and 12 other members of Israel’s inner security cabinet, the most important decision of his life — whether to launch a pre-emptive attack against Iran. We met in the late afternoon, and our conversation — the first of several over the next week — lasted for two and a half hours, long past nightfall. “This is not about some abstract concept,” Barak said as he gazed out at the lights of Tel Aviv, “but a genuine concern. The Iranians are, after all, a nation whose leaders have set themselves a strategic goal of wiping Israel off the map.”

headline: Come On, China, Buy Our Stuff!
text: The first time I visited China, in 2005, an American businessman living there told me that the country was so huge and was changing so fast that everything you heard about it was true, and so was the opposite. That still seems to be the case. China is the fastest-growing consumer market in the world, and American companies have made billions there. At the same time, Chinese consumers aren’t spending nearly as much as American companies had hoped. China has simultaneously become the greatest boon and the biggest disappointment.

headline: Uncovering a Home Away From Home
text: On the first night in his Tokyo apartment, Greg Girard turned on the radio and heard an English-speaking D.J. “You’ve been listening to the Far East Network of the American Forces,” the voice said, segueing into a recording of “The Star-Spangled Banner.”

headline: Accusations of Delay in Disclosing Volt Fire

headline: A Festival of Experimental Music in Madrid
text: For less than the cost of café con leche and an order of churros, music lovers in Madrid can take in a top-notch concert at the Festival Internacional de Improvisación Hurta Cordel, an annual celebration of experimental and improvised music started in 1996. From Wednesday through Jan. 29, La Casa Encendida will charge four euros admission to see performances by legends like the avant-rock guitarist Fred Frith and free-jazz pianist Alexander von Schlippenbach alongside shows featuring up-and-coming artists from Spain and abroad. (Tickets are also available on www.entradas.com.)Moving across genres like free jazz, contemporary classical and experimental electronica, the musicians push past more mainstream definitions of music, each in his or her own way. The festival lineup includes a collaboration between the established British improvisers Michael Fischer, John Edwards and Mark Sanders, as well as a concert by 2|2code, an Australian-Spanish duo that treads the line between music and conceptual art. 2|2code creates ambient surround-sound mash-ups drawn from sources as varied as classic Hollywood films, amateur news footage, and speeches by George W. Bush.

The following is a stream of messages that, like Gibreel Farishta in The Satanic Verses, Mr. Kumar dreamed he had written.

headline: A Legal Defense Fund for Climate Scientists
text: For years, climate scientists have been assailed from many sides — through e-mail hacking, death threats, politician’s demands for documents, Freedom of Information requests (many having the strong smell of a fishing expedition).

headline: Sometimes Even the Experts Can Be Fooled
text: In the realm of musical excavation, even experts can come to the wrong conclusions. In the Feb. 10 episode of “Michael Feinstein’s American Songbook,” the PBS series that follows Mr. Feinstein, the entertainer and musical preservationist, as he rummages through old musical archives, the discovery of an unpublished Irving Berlin song was to be announced. The song, titled “So Will I,” which was recently copyrighted by the Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization, which administers Berlin’s publishing but had no record of the song, has since been found to have been composed in 1926 by the team of Lew Brown and Cliff Friend and published by the Berlin company. A bouncy, wistful breakup song, it was recorded in 2005 by Ian Whitcomb on his album “Sentimentally Yours.”

headline: Running the Numbers: Why Our Sales Increased
text: My New Year’s resolution a year ago included a vow to do a better job of recording statistics on a wide variety of performance metrics. As it turned out, 2011 was the best year I’ve had in my 26 years of business life. I actually ended up with what seems like a reasonable amount of money in my pocket.

headline: Day 2 of Senior Bowl, Offensive Notes
text: Cecil Lammey and Matt Waldman covered the offensive practices at the Senior Bowl on Tuesday from Mobile, Ala.

headline: Runaway Salmon Stir Conservation Worries
text: As if the Loch Ness Monster wasn’t scary enough. Now, the Lox Ness monsters could be wreaking havoc in Scottish waters.

headline: Daily Report: Apple’s Profit Soars
text: Earnings have taken center stage, with Apple reporting stellar results for the holiday quarter, Nick Wingfield reports in Wednesday’s New York Times. Apple’s results easily surpassed analysts’ expectations. Its profit more than doubled from a year ago, and its revenue rose 73 percent in the same period. “It almost defies words in terms of the strength across all products,” Toni Sacconaghi, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, told The Times. “Everything about it eclipsed even the wildest expectations of analysts.”

headline: Iceman Finishes Winter Preparation in Valencia
text: Kimi Raikkonen, the Formula One world champion of 2007, completed on Tuesday two days of driving in preparation for his return to the series after a two-year absence.

headline: Iceman Finishes Winter Preparation in Valencia
text: Kimi Raikkonen, the Formula One world champion of 2007, completed on Tuesday two days of driving in preparation for his return to the series after a two-year absence.

headline: A Fish Tale With Disastrous Global Implications
text: A reporter’s nightmare: Try to interest people distracted by Newts, Oscars and a looming showdown with Iran in a bony little fish that looks like it belongs in a deli case.

headline: Rubenstein Defends Romney’s Tax Rate
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — It may be small comfort to the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, but he received some moral support at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday from one of his compatriots in the private equity industry.

headline: How Can You Fix the Global Economy if You Can’t Brave the Snow?
text: What’s a little snow among friends?

headline: Mitch Daniels Doesn’t Read the New York Times
text: From the Daniels reply to the State of Union:

headline: Giants-Patriots Week 9 Film Review
text: Andy Benoit contributed weekly film analysis to The Fifth Down this season:

headline: Pakistan Leader Softens Criticism of Army and Spy Agency
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani softened his criticism of senior generals on Wednesday in what appeared to be an effort to ease the tensions between Pakistan’s sparring civilian and military elites, saying the country could not afford further friction between its most powerful institutions.

headline: A Who’s Who of Davos Absentees
text: Earning the coveted white identification badge that grants a select few access to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is tough enough. The last year has demonstrated that it is not easy to keep it either.

headline: When Facts Aren’t Facts
text: The criterion, according to Politifact, seems to be that a fact isn’t a fact if it helps a Democratic narrative.

headline: Opinion Report: The State of the Union
text: From the editorial page

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: In Europe, a Conflict Over Bank Capital  |  Europe’s banks and regulators are at odds about how financial institutions should increase capital reserves.

headline: Wednesday Reading: A Scientific Look at the Dangers of High Heels
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Here Comes the Sun
text: PARIS — Solar storms: a potential threat to civilization as we know it, or just one more thing to worry about?

headline: Italian-American Food, All-American Wine
text: Much has been written about Torrisi Italian Specialties, the terrific Italian-American restaurant on Mulberry Street, including Pete Wells’s review this week of the Torrisi spin-off, Parm. But almost none of the attention has focused on Torrisi’s unusual all-American wine list, which has grown from a half-dozen bottles when the restaurant opened two years ago to around 80 bottles now.

headline: A Putinesque Party
text: MOSCOW— My 10-year-old daughter has just come home from a New Year’s celebration. These annual parties, which begin in mid-December and continue, relentlessly, through late January, are a longstanding Russian tradition in which children endure performances of various levels of vapidity, featuring Grandfather Frost and his granddaughter the Snowgirl. The kids are rewarded for their patience with a bag full of chocolate candy.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Same Old Oscars, and Who’s Missing at Davos?
text: For all the change whirling about the entertainment business (technological and other), the Oscar nominations announced Tuesday morning send an incongruous message: nothing has changed. Parsing the nine best picture nominees, Michael Cieply finds some recurring patterns: no animation (though, with “Hugo,” a 3-D movie was included); all but one from a major studio or a specialty division of same (“The Artist” is the exception); the settings are more past than present. He continues:

headline: Finding a Place for Peyton
text: It seems ever clearer that Peyton Manning will not play for the Colts next season. So where will he play if he decides not to retire?

headline: Top 10 Super Bowl Story Lines, and Reasons to Sigh
text: Here are the Top 10 Super Bowl XLVI story lines that you may or may not get sick of in the next two weeks.

headline: Glenn Close, Already Thanking Her Makeup and Hair Team
text: The Oscar attention that Glenn Close received on Tuesday for her passion project, “Albert Nobbs,” was really a triple win. Yes, she was nominated for best actress – her first recognition by the Academy in 23 years. (Although she’s been nominated five times before, she’s never won.) But her co-star Janet McTeer also got a nod, as best supporting actress. They sent congratulatory text messages to each other on Tuesday morning.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Karo Mrozkova at Armani Privé
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2012 Couture collections in Paris. Here, the model Karo Mrozkova of Marilyn Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Linda Contello and hair by Franco Gobbi. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Davos Potpourri: Day One
text: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, officially began on Wednesday, bringing thousands of world leaders and their entourages to a remote alpine outpost.

headline: Leno Sued Over Joke That Offended Sikhs
text: Just when it seemed that the world was ready to move on from a poorly received “Tonight Show” joke that offended Sikhs – and, perhaps, onto President Obama’s poorly received “spilled milk” joke from Tuesday’s State of the Union address – a man has filed a suit against Jay Leno, the “Tonight Show” host, for what he says are “racist” remarks.

headline: Obama Praises Teachers and Calls for Mandatory Attendance
text: Should students be required to remain in school until age 18? That was the one concrete proposal for K-12 students in President Barack Obama's State of the Union speech on Tuesday night. The president, who focused his speech on "leveling the playing field" when it comes to taxes and economic policy, also had high praise for teachers and expressed his support for local authority in public education.

headline: California’s Lead in Solar Is Slowly Eroding
text: The growth of California’s local solar-power systems, not only on rooftops but in parking lots, farmers’ fields and vineyard irrigation ponds, has kept the state well ahead of others in the total power generated from photovoltaic systems.

headline: The Tigers’ Confounding Royalty Payment
text: Just about the same time Prince Fielder’s gargantuan, nine-year, $214 million contract agreement with the Detroit Tigers set baseball jaws dropping on Tuesday — the wows stemming from how long the contract is, the eye-popping total and that it was the Detroit Tigers shelling it out — it got its whiff of irony by arriving on exactly the same day “Moneyball” was nominated for the Oscar for Best Picture.

headline: Can New Android Software Unify Android Devices?
text: A new wave of smartphones and tablets will be introduced this year with “Ice Cream Sandwich,” the latest version of Google’s Android software. The mobile operating system has been expanded to run on both smartphones and tablets, but it remains unclear how it will fix the problem that plagues Android at its core: fragmentation.

headline: Liberal Populism and 2012
text: This week’s Campaign Stops column considers the president’s speech through the lens of the campaign to come:

headline: India’s Political Blasphemy
text: VARANASI, India — The current storm of censorship and intimidation over Salman Rushdie at the Jaipur Literature Festival is nothing more than a dodge by India’s politicians and Muslim leaders to cover their failure to improve the dreadful conditions in which many Indian Muslims live.

headline: How to Buy Friends and Influence Politicians
text: I almost feel bad for Sheldon and Miriam Adelson, who have contributed $10 million to the pro-Gingrich Winning Our Future super PAC. If it weren’t for the Supreme Court’s astonishingly wrongheaded Citizens United ruling, which among other things allows “independent” (hardly!) political committees to raise unlimited sums, the couple might have directed their millions to better use—like recapitalizing a casino or two.

headline: Just One Look | Givenchy
text: At Givenchy, Riccardo Tisci was inspired by the cool glamour of Fritz Lang’s “Metropolis” and by early techno culture. The results were 10 long lean looks, encrusted with bugle beads, sequins and croc paillettes, that said red-carpet rebel, especially when finished with a jeweled nose ring (seen earlier this week at Givenchy men’s) and massive chandelier earrings. One exquisite example of why his influences were so cleverly paired: an Erté-worthy silhouette, fully embroidered on the bias, worn over a ribbed muscle tank.

headline: Soros Promotes Crisis Plan for Europe
text: The billionaire investor George Soros said on Wednesday that it was possible Greece could be pushed out of the euro zone this year.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Tasting Table: It’s time to stop being a hater when it comes to iceberg lettuce. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Reflections on an Unfinished Revolution
text: A year after the first protests in Tahrir Square, young Egyptians look back at the promise of the Arab Spring as well as the reality many revolutionaries failed to foresee.

headline: Bout Time: Claressa Shields
text: The story of Claressa Shields, a 16-year-old female boxer living in Flint, Mich.

headline: HBO Bets on Two Thoroughbreds
text: A HORSE race is a just a contest where large animals are loosed from a pen at the sound of a bell to take a few lefts around an oval, first one home wins.

headline: ‘Real Housewife’ Bethenny Frankel Gets Talk-Show Tryout
text: MIAMI — Bethenny Frankel, made famous by Bravo as a member of the “Real Housewives of New York City,” is being given a talk-show tryout by Warner Brothers and Fox.

headline: Image of the Day: January 25
text: A sculpture by Australian artist Sam Jinks on display at the India Art Fair.

headline: Bout Time: Tiara Brown
text: The story of Tiara Brown, a 23-year old female boxer who spends six hours per day in the gym and doesn’t plan to stop until she makes the Olympics.

headline: Dissected Long Before Her Debut
text: IT’S already difficult to remember Lana Del Rey, but let’s try. She was a meme of 2011, a singer who emerged seemingly fully formed from the ether who was in short order revealed to be, get this, a singer who was not always fully formed. That moll with the dangerous tastes in men and pastimes and the puffed-out lips and hair? That songwriter who used words like “velvet” and “exotic” in the tiki-lounge way of overemphasizing noir culture? Yep, it was a pose, cut from existing, densely patterned cloth. Just like all the other poses. And all the other cloths.

headline: ‘Midnight in Paris’ Almost Didn’t Happen in Paris
text: When she got the script for “Midnight in Paris,” Letty Aronson, Woody Allen’s longtime producer, wasn’t buying it. “When I first read the script, honestly, my impression was, who’s going to come to this movie?” said Ms. Aronson, who also happens to be the director’s sister. “Nobody even knows Gertrude Stein anymore.”

headline: Romney Calls Obama ‘Detached From Reality’
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Mitt Romney called President Obama “detached from reality” on Wednesday, accusing him of saying one thing during his State of the Union speech and doing another during his presidency.

headline: Netflix to Issue Earnings Report, First Since Consumer Backlash Over Its Spin-Off Plan
text: Netflix on Wednesday afternoon will release its earnings for the fourth quarter of 2011, the first full quarter since a price increase and a bungled plan to spin off a DVD service hurt the company’s reputation and decimated its stock price.

headline: Ramones Jacket Is Off the Block, for Now
text: The online auction house offered a sweat-soaked gem from punk’s New York glory years — the black leather jacket worn by the Ramones drummer Marky Ramone during his first stint with the band. But the drummer cried foul, calling the jacket a fake.

headline: Spare a Hair Band? A Man Bun to Go
text: ON a recent night at Hotel Delmano, a stylish speakeasy in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the heavily tattooed head bartender, Sam Anderson, and his colleague, Michaelangelo Davis III, were shaking up cocktails with manly vigor.

headline: In the Company of Bears
text: There’s a vast gap between scary bears and teddy bears, but it’s one comfortably occupied by the bears who star in three new picture books. “My Bear Griz,” “Otto the Book Bear” and “Maudie and Bear” are all about real(ish) bears who greatly prefer the company of others to bearish solitude.

headline: The Chink in Illumina’s Defense
text: Roche Holding’s $5.7 billion hostile offer for Illumina is built on a loophole in Illumina’s takeover defenses.

headline: Activists Call for Breakup of Bank of America
text: Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group, is calling for the breakup of Bank of America.

headline: For a Veteran, Disability Payment Is Long in Coming
text: The year Leroy MacKlem lost his veterans disability compensation for a bad hip, gasoline cost 27 cents a gallon, a Yankee shortstop named Rizzuto was the American League’s most valuable player and President Harry S. Truman ordered production of the hydrogen bomb. It was 1950.

headline: Stewart, Colbert and Coldplay Lined Up for First Secret Policeman’s Ball in U.S.
text: 11:28 a.m. | Updated

headline: When the Sex Offender Is a Teenager in Love
text: For having sex with his freshman girlfriend when he was a senior in high school, Ken Thornsberry spent six years in a Michigan prison. Abigail Pesta of The Daily Beast reports on his story and on the growing number of parents outraged that older teenagers are being jailed, and added to sex offender registries, for having sex with younger teenagers.

headline: Gloomy Debate over Euro Darkens Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — For a usually optimistic crowd, there was a lot of gloom and doom being prophesied among the movers and shakers gathered here on the first day of the World Economic Forum. The subject of their angst: whether the euro zone will ever get out of its lingering troubles in one piece.

headline: Tip of the Week: Gmail’s Pop-out Feature
text: Composing and replaying to Gmail messages through the Web browser is a convenient way to keep all your mail in one online location. But keeping the message in the main window can be frustrating if you need to refer to a different message elsewhere in your account’s inbox.

headline: Behind Closed Doors at the Fed
text: You may have wondered what exactly happens when the Federal Open Market Committee meets every six weeks to make policy decisions for the Federal Reserve — like the two-day meeting that is wrapping up Wednesday. And you are in luck, because earlier this month, the Fed released transcripts of the committee’s meetings in 2006, Year One in the chairmanship of Ben S. Bernanke.

headline: Wheelies: The Skunkworks Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Take My Comedy Influences. Please.
text: If it wasn’t a trend before, it certainly will become one on Thursday night with the premiere of “Inside Comedy” on Showtime. The business of being funny has spawned a cottage industry of comedians talking about the business of being funny.

headline: States’ Drive to Collect Taxes on Internet Sales Is a Blow to Marketers
text: On a dreary day last April, Tim Storm, the founder of FatWallet, and his 54 employees formed a convoy of some 30 cars, three moving trucks and a trailer laden with two fiberglass cows (one purple, one black), and drove five miles north from their old corporate home in Rockton, Ill.. to the new FatWallet headquarters in Beloit, Wis.

headline: Anniversary of the Egyptian Uprising
text: Tens of thousands of Egyptians gathered in Tahrir Square, the crucible of their revolution, on Wednesday.

headline: A Staten Island School Blames Its Problems on Location
text: The announcements came year after year: Eight schools to shut down in Manhattan. Ten in the Bronx. Six in Brooklyn. Two in Queens. None on Staten Island. It was hard for Staten Islanders not to develop a degree of superiority when it came to school closings. But now a Staten Island school, P.S. 14, is on the list of 19 city schools to be closed. Some see it as a political decision to close a Staten Island school. And many say the school is facing daunting challenges in the poverty-related problems of its students.

headline: Is Affiliate Marketing a Useful Tool?
text: We’ve just published an article that looks at how the new nexus tax laws affect affiliate marketing companies and the retailers that use their services. The nexus laws say, in essence, that any company advertising through an affiliate marketer — usually an online deal site or blog that publishes ads or coupons and collects commissions on sales that come through them — has to collect and remit sales tax in the states and jurisdictions where the affiliate marketer is located.

headline: For India’s MBAs, Money Does Not Come First
text: If you were graduating from a topnotch business school, would you pick a great job profile or a tempting salary?

headline: On Our Radar: A Big Solar Storm
text: The solar storm of the last few days was the largest since 2003, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says. Some aircraft flying over the North Pole were rerouted in anticipation of potential communication problems linked to proton radiation. [Discovery News]

headline: Sports Club Switches to Annual Fee in Lieu of Monthly Increases
text: Many members who last year joined fitness clubs owned by Town Sports International saw a $29 fee on their bill this month. The fee represents an annual rate lock payment, assessed in lieu of an increase in the members’ monthly dues, the company says.

headline: Federer-Nadal Rivalry Adds Another Chapter
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The rivalry between Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer is now a fully formed, fully explored phenomenon, one that has put them on a first-name basis with much of the planet. They meet for the 27th time on Thursday (3:30 a.m. Eastern, ESPN2), in the semifinals of the Australian Open.

headline: New Books for the Old Internet
text: There have been many attempts to replicate the experience of reading a real, tangible book on a screen. There is Google Books, of course, and this somewhat unconvincing page-flipping simulation. There is also Project Gutenberg, the vast online archive of public domain e-books, and, you know, the Kindle.

headline: Marriage Equality: Demagoguery in New Jersey
text: To borrow an old Washington joke about another self-promoting politician, the most dangerous place in politics is between Chris Christie and a TV crew. Most weeks, he clamors for national attention with rhetoric about small government (for the poor, that is, not the rich). This week, he’s taken up gay marriage.

headline: A Few Tears on Oscar-Nod Morning
text: Like a producer of “Midnight in Paris,” the writer-director of the financial thriller “Margin Call,” J.C. Chandor, who received his first Oscar nomination on Tuesday for best original screenplay, also initially worried about finding an audience. “Our film has always suffered from the fact that it doesn’t sound that good on paper,” he said. “It’s not the most heartwarming, feel-good movie.”

headline: Luminaries Gather Virtually to Mark Global Fund’s 10th Anniversary
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — One place where Davos luminaries will be gathering this year — at least virtually — is on the silver screen. To mark the 10th anniversary of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, Fund supporters including Bill Gates, Bono, Tony Blair, Bill Clinton and Jeffrey Sachs will feature in a two-minute film that celebrates the Fund’s work, while calling for more efforts against the diseases that still kill millions of poor people.

headline: Bout Time: Alex Love
text: Alex Love, a self-taught boxer from Monroe, Wash., will compete in the U.S. Olympic Team Trials in February for a shot at the London Games.

headline: It’s Getting Routine: Top 4 Men Are Final 4
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — David Ferrer was subdued to begin with Wednesday as he took gulps from his water bottle after another defeat in the second week of a Grand Slam tournament, this one to Novak Djokovic.

headline: Fears Lurk in a Post-Transition Afghanistan
text: Over the mountains from frigid Kabul, Mihtarlam is one place where American-led forces have transferred authority to the Afghans.

headline: TiqIQ: The Kayak of Live-Event Tickets
text: When searching for airline tickets, many people are like quants at a hedge fund. They pore over data, using sites like Kayak, SeatGuru and Bing Travel to divine the best price, route and seat for their coming flight.

headline: Reflections on an Unfinished Revolution
text: A year after the first protests in Tahrir Square, young Egyptians look back at the promise of the Arab Spring as well as the reality many revolutionaries failed to foresee.

headline: Using Test Scores to Evaluate Teachers Is Based on the Wrong Values
text: In an opinion post, one of the organizers of the statewide letter from principals protesting New York's Annual Professional Performance Review system writes that for those reformers who believe student testing should weigh heavily in teacher evaluations, "test scores are the bottom line, and these 'bottom line' reformers believe that what gets measured gets done. Educators have a different belief. We believe that what is nurtured grows."

headline: As I.P.O. Looms, Facebook Halts Clearing of Trades
text: As Facebook readies for an initial public offering, its lawyers are pressing the pause button on the trading process for shares of the social networking giant.

headline: Rolle’s Super Bowl XLII Memories (From Brazil)
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – Antrel Rolle is not one of the 15 players on the Giants’ roster who played in the Super Bowl XLII victory over New England four years ago, but that does not mean Rolle – the Giants’ loquacious safety – does not have a good story from the game.

headline: Greenlight Capital to Pay $11 Million Fine in Insider Case
text: 8:43 p.m. | Updated

headline: An Emotional Farewell on the House Floor
text: WASHINGTON — The House bade a tearful farewell to Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona on Wednesday as she submitted her resignation and was praised by members of both parties as an inspiring symbol of courage in the aftermath of an assassination attempt against her last year.

headline: On a Futures Bet, Las Vegas Loses if the Giants Win
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It should come as no surprise that the Giants have fans rooting against them in the Super Bowl in places like New Hampshire, Massachusetts and even parts of Connecticut. After all, the New England Patriots have a dedicated following, and quarterback Tom Brady has mainstream appeal.

headline: In Reversal, Iran Allows Interest Rates to Increase
text: Facing a wave of panic selling by Iranians worried that international sanctions and inflation are destroying the value of the country’s currency, the rial, Iran’s president reversed himself on Wednesday and allowed bank interest rates to rise sharply in an effort to stop a slide that has depressed the rial to a relentless string of record lows.

headline: J.C. Penney to Revise Pricing Methods and Limit Promotions
text: J. C. Penney’s new leader has a vision for tomorrow’s shopping experience. But the retailer is still stuck with yesterday’s stores.

headline: Fed Signals That a Full Recovery Is Years Away
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, declaring that the economy would need help for years to come, said Wednesday it would extend by 18 months the period that it plans to hold down interest rates in an effort to spur growth.

headline: State of the Republicans
text: Gail Collins: David, I have to apologize. For the last few weeks I was somewhat snarky about my having more faith than you did in the Republican voters being too sane to nominate Newt Gingrich. My confidence in their rationality was, at best, premature.

headline: Does Technology Affect Happiness?
text: As young people spend more time on computers, smartphones and other devices, researchers are asking how all that screen time and multitasking affects children’s and teenagers’ ability to focus and learn — even drive cars.

headline: Newt Gingrich Gets a Grilling on Univision
text: MIAMI — Where was Jorge Ramos when John King and Juan Williams needed him?

headline: Paris Top 5 | Hermès
text: The Hermès collection, described as having a palette of “colorful blacks, dark harmonies,” was a quiet show that grew on me the more time I had to reflect on it. Luxurious materials, and leather — always a feature of the house and certainly a trend this show season — were beautifully represented in belted calfskin coats, slim serge trousers, and suits in colors like ebony, licorice, plum and black. Signature printed ties were noticeably absent, replaced with dark, solid neck wear and collared shirts buttoned all the way up. The look that stuck was simple but clever: a carbon-colored evening suit paired with a black crew-neck knit and a dark patterned scarf that came draped under the lapels (attached with a hidden zipper to keep it in place all evening long). It was a chic and sexy runway look — easy to envision on handsome young actors on red carpets everywhere.

headline: Gingrich Ad Faulting Romney on Immigration Stirs Furor
text: 2:17 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich faced a rising chorus of demands Wednesday that he pull a radio ad that calls Mitt Romney “anti-immigrant.” In a letter released by the Romney campaign, Hispanic leaders said the ad was “untrue, offensive and unbecoming a candidate for the Republican nomination for president.”

headline: Why I Don’t Rat Out My Son’s Friends
text: Let me say right off the bat: I have no interest in being the Narc Mom.

headline: TimesCast | January 25, 2012
text: Thousands gather on the Egyptian uprising’s first anniversary | President Obama begins a three-day tour that includes battleground states.

headline: Below the Line: Dressing the ‘Bridesmaids’
text: When it comes to costume designing, the Oscars tend to favor the past. In the same ways that dramas dominate the best picture category, period films are primarily the ones that get recognition in the costume design category. But costume design for contemporary films can present as many challenges as the ones involving corsets and long skirts.

headline: How Obama’s Tough Talk Plays in China
text: BEIJING — President Obama took a new swipe at China’s economic policies in his State of the Union speech on Tuesday, and leaders here are unlikely to be surprised. China’s rulers know that Mr. Obama faces a tough re-election battle, and they know that he must address his opponents’ repeated claims that he has failed to stand up to Beijing.

headline: He Has Two Legs. But What About His Name?
text: Update, Jan. 29 | We found him, or, more accurately, he responded to us. He’s an actor named Cleo Berry who is not thrilled with the fictionalization of his body. Read the story.

headline: With Split at Colorado College, Minnesota Takes Conference Lead
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Goodbye Rebecca, Hello Stella: ‘Streetcar’ Will Open on Broadway This Spring
text: The new multiracial production of Tennessee Williams’s “Streetcar Named Desire,” starring Blair Underwood, Nicole Ari Parker, Daphne Rubin-Vega and Wood Harris, will play the Broadhurst Theater this spring, according to a spokesman for the production. No performance dates were announced.

headline: The Essence of Obamanomics
text: Even the liberal Matt Yglesias was exhausted by the president’s paean to industrial policy in last night’s speech, calling it “a strikingly retrograde, self-contradictory, and confused agenda of reviving American prosperity through mercantilism.” He goes on:

headline: Just One Look | Elie Saab
text: Elie Saab’s haute couture show, presented in the Grand Palais to an audience of Bollywood stars (Sonam Kapoor, gorgeous in kohl-lined eyes and a pale pink jeweled sari), Oscar hopefuls (Berenice Bejo) and clients from all the global wealthy pockets, was as beaded and lacy as we have come to expect from this house. The effect, for spring, was sweet, not sultry. Pastel dresses were entirely covered in tulle flowers, metallic embroideries and crystal beading. Since Saab is so well known for his red-carpet columns, it was refreshing to think about how his shorter offerings, all indisputably for evening, could fare on a big night. Consider, for example, an elegant little frock in white lace and pearls, so ridiculously pretty it registers angelic and wicked clever all at once.

headline: Hornets’ Gordon Offered Contract Extension
text: It was a bit of a cliff-hanger, but the New Orleans Hornets, currently operated by the N.B.A., have arrived at a contract extension for guard Eric Gordon. According to Yahoo.com , the team is giving Gordon a four-year deal, after getting approval from the league.

headline: TV Ad Says Gingrich Exaggerates His Ties to Reagan
text: A new ad on behalf of Mitt Romney pokes fun at Newt Gingrich, and says he is exaggerating his relationship with Ronald Reagan.

headline: Court Keeps Hitler’s Work From German Newsstands
text: BERLIN — The German authorities on Wednesday won their most recent victory in a continuing battle to prevent circulation of Hitler’s seminal work in Germany when a Bavarian court ruled that a British publisher could not release annotated excerpts of“Mein Kampf.”

headline: Castro Calls Republican Field a ‘Competition of Idiocy’
text: With the Republican candidates courting Cubans in Miami today, Fidel Castro chimed in with an opinion piece in state-run media saying he was unimpressed, at the very least, with the field.

headline: European Banks Push to Meet Capital Goals
text: LONDON — European banks have been busy.

headline: Caucus Click: Changes Down the Road
text: Supporters of Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney waved signs outside of an early-voting station in The Villages, Fla., on Wednesday.

headline: Historic Buildings May Be Greener Than You Think
text: In New York City, a conflict has long been perceived between historic preservation and urban sustainability goals. Older buildings are often seen as outdated energy hogs that can’t pull their weight, efficiency-wise, in a city that is expected to add a million new residents by 2030. About 55 percent of the city’s 838,337 buildings were constructed before 1940, half a century before the notion of green LEED building certification was even dreamed up.

headline: Something Rare for Iowa Wrestling: A Losing Streak
text: Throughout the college wrestling season, The Quad will follow some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Runway in Review
text: The critics weigh in on Monday and Tuesday’s shows in Paris.

headline: M.T.A. Board Loses 2 Members and Star Power
text: Updated 2:59 p.m. | Two members of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority resigned on Wednesday. One will leave to spend more time running the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey; the other will have more time with her new spouse, Paul McCartney.

headline: IMAX Chief Envisions the Future of 3-D in Theaters
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — For the IMAX Corporation, the future is brighter, larger and in 3-D.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier: Spring 2012 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier Couture
text: Paris

headline: Andreessen Is Said to Seek $1.5 Billion in Fund-Raising
text: A name like Andreessen goes a long way in Silicon Valley.

headline: Obama Embarks on Five-State Tour
text: 10:19 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

headline: Penney’s New Approach Takes Target-Like Tack
text: Shoppers are about to find out what is changing at J.C. Penney in an advertising effort that, not coincidentally, evokes the Target way of marketing.

headline: Towers of Dreams: One Ended in Nightmare
text: Hortense Davis sat beside neat stacks of new magazines in the pristine administrative office at Penn South, the 1960s high-rise housing cooperative development for low- and moderate-income workers in Chelsea. She was asked to ponder life there across 20 years.

headline: Oil Supply as a Strategic Risk
text: Concerns about the climate have not inspired a lot of action lately on global energy policy. Now two professors are arguing that supply concerns and rising oil prices ought to be enough to get governments moving, even if the climate does not.

headline: Scientist Plays Down Danger of Flu Strain
text: A Wisconsin virology team that created a more contagious form of bird flu did not produce a highly lethal superflu, as a Dutch team famously and controversially did last year, according to the leader of the Wisconsin team.

headline: Showing a Little Restraint
text: IF you’re one of the guys who likes to chuckle over the penchant some gals have for crazy stilettos that can cost more than $1,000 — well, brother, don’t look down. Over the last decade, your fashion-forward comrades have developed a taste for similarly extravagant shoes, a predilection that has somehow escaped derision because of its origins in the untouchable cool of hip-hop culture.

headline: At Davos, Discussions of a Global Data Deluge
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Each year, a new theme reverberates through technology conferences around the world. A few years ago it was predictions of the coming wave of social media, location-based services and mobile, long before they became mainstream.

headline: Deep Crisis of Confidence Afflicts Democracies, Elsewhere Unease
text: Protesters in Moscow and Cairo fill public squares to demand representative government. Yet, on the streets of Madrid and New York — or of Athens, which gave us the very word for democracy — discontent is almost as rampant.

headline: Assange to Host Conversations on TV Show
text: In yet another twist to the pretzel-like Julian Assange story, stay tuned for Mr. Assange’s talk show, set to air in March.

headline: Using More Than Two In Vitro Embryos Adds to Risks
text: The United States is one of the few countries that still routinely transfer more than two embryos during an in vitro fertilization procedure. While that’s a practice that may be in keeping with our national “more is more” philosophy, and with the natural instinct of anxious parents to maximize the chances of success, The Times’s Vital Signs column just reported on a British study showing that transferring three or more embryos does not increase the number of live births. Instead, those larger transfers are associated with “a significantly higher risk of complications, including preterm birth and low birth weight.”

headline: Red Bulls, Klinsmann, College Soccer: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Q.

headline: Adele Racks Up Two No.1’s This Week
text: If anyone still doubted the commercial appeal of an old-fashioned soul singer who can channel raw emotion into song, Adele has put those doubts to rest. Not since 1993 has an album remained at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart for as long as  her album, “21” (XL/Columbia). That album finished its 17th week atop the sales chart since its release in the United States last February, selling 95,000 copies last week. That’s the best any album has done since “The Bodyguard” soundtrack, released in 1993, was on top for 20 weeks, Billboard reported.

headline: Obama Returns to Familiar Theme in Case for 2nd Term
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s election-year State of the Union address on Tuesday echoed a theme that has run through his career: Government and citizens are responsible together for the common good, even as they celebrate individualism and free markets.

headline: New Rules for School Meals Aim at Reducing Obesity
text: WASHINGTON — Hoping to combat the growing problem of childhood obesity, the Obama administration on Wednesday announced its long-awaited changes to government-subsidized school meals, a final round of rules that adds more fruits and green vegetables to breakfasts and lunches and reduces the amount of salt and fat.

headline: The Class Warfare Canard
text: Republicans roared onto the post-State-of-the-Union morning shows accusing President Obama of waging class warfare. Actually the class warrior in the field yesterday was in Florida, campaigning for the Republican nomination for president.

headline: TimesCast | Anniversary of the Uprising
text: January 25, 2012 — Thousands gather on the Egyptian uprising’s first anniversary.

headline: With Prevalence of Nanomaterials Rising, Panel Urges Review of Risks
text: Tiny substances called nanomaterials have moved into the marketplace over the last decade, in products as varied as cosmetics, clothing and paint. But not enough is known about their potential health and environmental risks, which should be studied further, an expert panel of the National Academy of Sciences said on Wednesday.

headline: Syrian Role at Unesco Under Fire
text: PARIS — At least 25 countries have joined to try to unseat Syria from two committees of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that deal with issues of human rights, Western diplomats and Unesco officials said Wednesday.

headline: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast
text: Jeff Z. Klein joins Christopher Botta in studio to discuss the latest Rangers, Devils and Islanders news in this edition of the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast. Pierre McGuire from NBC and Brian Compton of NHL.com also join in to discuss news from around the N.H.L.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Givenchy
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Time to Push for Tax ‘Fairness,’ Democrats Say
text: This time they’re really serious.

headline: TimesCast | President Obama's Tour
text: President Obama begins a three-day tour that includes battleground states.

headline: Bachmann to Run for Re-Election
text: WASHINGTON – Representative Michele Bachmann, whose White House quest fizzled after a poor showing in the Iowa caucuses, said Wednesday that she would seek re-election in Minnesota’s Sixth Congressional District.

headline: Caucus Video: President Obama’s Tour
text: President Obama begins a three-day tour that includes five battleground states. Jonathan Weisman reports.

headline: Knicks Over Bobcats: That Was Supposed to Happen
text: Before Tuesday night’s game against the Charlotte Bobcats, the Knicks had lost their previous six games. With the Knicks performing below expectations, this streak harkened to Micheal Ray Richardson’s famous quote “the ship be sinking.”

headline: ‘SundayArts’ Show on City Culture Moves to Prime Time
text: New York City’s arts and culture scene will get a high-profile spotlight and a more vibrant digital presence when WNET’s afternoon “SundayArts” show takes over a  prime-time slot, on Thursdays at 8 p.m. Along with the move, the half-hour program will take on a new name, NYC-ARTS, as its news, interviews and video archives are merged with the existing Web site and mobile platforms of NYC-ARTS.org, a  guide to arts and cultural events in the city. NYC-ARTS, developed with the help of city funds by the advocacy and research organization Alliance for the Arts, moved its operations to WNET last year.

headline: Uh-Oh, Peer-to-Peer Networks Discover 3-D Printing
text: As I wrote in a column in November, people will soon be able to download files of physical objects and print them out at home. Although being able to print out a new mug or toothbrush at home sounds magical, I said that there would surely be copyright problems that occur as a result of this technology’s going mainstream.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 26
text: Power blazers are back; a line of jewelry incorporates mechanical parts; and the return of the bodysuit.

headline: Valentino: Spring 2012 Couture
text: Paris

headline: Valentino Couture
text: Paris

headline: On Eve of Philharmonic Concert, Chinese Conductor Slugs It Out With Attacker
text: A man attacked the Chinese conductor Long Yu on Columbus Avenue a day before his Chinese New Year concert with the New York Philharmonic — punching him in the eye and running off — but not before Mr. Yu landed a few blows of his own.

headline: Patient Voices: Hemophilia
text: From weekly treatments to long-term joint pain to changing attitudes on the disease, hemophilia affects everyone slightly differently. Here, five people speak about living with hemophilia.

headline: The Voices of Hemophilia
text: Hemophilia is a rare genetic condition in which the blood doesn’t clot normally. The disease primarily affects men, and patients with hemophilia take injections of a clotting factor to prevent or reduce bleeding episodes.

headline: Is This the Last Year the Academy Votes by Mail?
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s official: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is going to electronic voting for next year’s Oscars, with a system that will be developed by Everyone Counts.

headline: Merrill Lynch Fined $1 Million for Bonus Clawbacks
text: The big bonuses doled out at Merrill Lynch during the height of the financial crisis have once again reared their ugly head.

headline: Activists Press for End to Military Rule on Anniversary of Egypt’s Revolution
text: Updated | 4:42 p.m. As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, there was a mixture of celebration and anger as Egyptians gathered in Tahrir Square on Wednesday on the first anniversary of the protest movement that forced President Hosni Mubarak from power.

headline: Apple and Verizon Earnings Underscore the Power of the iPhone
text: Apple and Verizon on Tuesday reported their quarterly earnings, and for both companies, much of their good news centered on one product: the iPhone. And the numbers tell the story of a device that seems to gain power each day.

headline: Avoiding Surgery in the Elderly
text: It may take members of our parents’ generation (and our own) a long time to get over thinking of hospitals as refuges of safety and operating rooms as harbingers of better days ahead. But it’s gradually becoming clearer that for the very old and frail, and for nursing home residents in particular, hospitals are places to avoid whenever possible, and surgery can become a source of danger in itself.

headline: The United States of Numeracy: The Math of a Presidential Campaign
text: A presidential race is a gift to American history and civics classes. But it’s also rife with learning opportunities for math students, too.

headline: A Toast to the Bard of Ayrshire
text: It’s entirely possible that, just a few weeks ago, you sang the fine old tune “Auld Lang Syne” to welcome the New Year. You might still puzzle over the lyrics, no matter how many times you’ve sung it, and you might not know that the man responsible for the song as we know it is Robert Burns, the Scottish poet who was born on this day in 1759. “Robert Burns and ‘Auld Lang Syne,’” a lovely little exhibition at the Morgan Library and Museum, can take care of explaining the lyrics; seeing it would be a great way to kick off your celebration of Burns Night, the Scottish holiday marking the birth of the Scottish poet behind the song.

headline: Citing Europe’s Progress, Merkel Urges Patience
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Wednesday that Europe had made more progress in dealing with the sovereign debt crisis than foreign investors acknowledged, as she toned down her usual calls for budgetary austerity.

headline: Cracking the Code in ‘Heeere’s Johnny!’
text: Burbank, Calif.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: An Urban Paradise Lost
text: Images from the documentary, “The Pruitt-Igoe Myth,” which examines the St. Louis housing project that became a symbol of urban disaster.

headline: New Rule Requires Fee Disclosure for Overseas Cash Transfers
text: People transferring money overseas must be informed of the exchange rate they are paying as well as any fees, under a new rule from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Wittman and the Wizards: Where to Begin?
text: The responsibility for getting the wayward Wizards on the same page no longer falls on Flip Saunders’s shoulders. Washington officially parted ways with Saunders on Tuesday, and though the former head coach was hardly blameless in the Wizards’ horrendous 2-15 start, his firing appears to be little more than a token. Something had to change in Washington, and as is often the case, the head coach turned out to be – in the eyes of the organization – the most disposable element.

headline: Cameron Calls for European Court to Limit Its Reach
text: BRUSSELS — Opening a new battle over the reach of Europe’s institutions, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain on Wednesday called for the European Court of Human Rights to restrict its power to overrule national judgments.

headline: A New Player on the Fashion Stage
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Executive Director of Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation to Step Down
text: After 16 years as executive director of the Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation, Sharon Gersten Luckman will step down next year, the organization announced on Wednesday.

headline: Romney Defends Stance on Immigration
text: MIAMI — Mitt Romney on Wednesday angrily rejected Newt Gingrich’s accusation that he is “anti-immigrant,” calling that a personal attack that is out of bounds.

headline: The Sons Also Rise
text: Here are the stages of inequality rationalization:

headline: Romney’s Tax Bill, European Style
text: 5:46 p.m. | Updated to correct income figure for Liliane Bettencourt.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 25
text: A view of the day in sports, from basketball in Moscow to Joe Paterno’s funeral.

headline: Is iMessage Starting to Take a Bite Out of Standard Texting?
text: When Apple introduced iMessage, a service that lets people with its mobile devices send each other free text messages over data networks, many analysts predicted that it would take a substantial bite out of the profits that text messages generate for wireless carriers in the United States.

headline: Despite Generic Rivals, Branded Drugs Still Sell Well
text: Though the loss of patent protection on a brand-name prescription drug tends to lead to a sharp drop in sales for that product in the United States, such older medicines have become a booming business for the pharmaceutical industry in emerging markets.

headline: Homes for $350,000
text: A two-bedroom in Utah, a 1920s bungalow in Atlanta and a three-bedroom in Kingston, N.Y.

headline: What You Get for ... $350,000
text: EMIGRATION CANYON, UTAH

headline: M.I.T. CityCar, Renamed Hiriko, Is Headed to Production
text: At European Union Commission headquarters in Brussels on Tuesday, the commission chief, José Manuel Barroso, inspected a small city-car prototype. It was the commercial version of the long-gestating CityCar from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab.

headline: Yuri Rasovsky, Dramatist for the Ear, Is Dead at 67
text: Yuri Rasovsky, whose boyhood revelation that radio drama transcends the stage — because listeners must make imaginative leaps to “see” the action — propelled his career as a leading creator of radio plays and audio books, died on Jan. 18 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 67.

headline: Finding the Truth
text: A commenter on my latest Politifact screed asks a good question: where do you go to check whether a politician’s statement is actually true?

headline: Contemporary Zeitgeist, in Design and Furnishings
text: The classic and the modern come together in a roomy, high-tech home not far from a large American military base.

headline: House Hunting in ... Germany
text: A FIVE-BEDROOM MOUNTAINSIDE HOME NEAR FRANKFURT

headline: Just One Look | Jean Paul Gaultier
text: Jean Paul Gaultier loves to flirt with bad taste. So was it at all surprising that his spring couture show was dedicated to the memory of Amy Winehouse? To a live doo-wop performance of “Rehab,” beehived models strutted the catwalk in an extraordinary variety of garments and looks — yes, Winehouse-inspired pencil skirts and boleros, but also an elegant draped evening gown in electric blue crepe and a fetishist’s corset dress in black and ivory satin. Here, a dress that proves that python, tulle, cabochon embroidery, roses and lace can — in the right mains — keep one from going back to black.

headline: Greenwich Village Country Club
text: WITH its adult kickball leagues and Craigslist roomies, New York could be regarded as a cradle for suspended adolescence. The argument is hard to deny at Greenwich Village Country Club, a monstrous shrine to frat culture and preppy nostalgia that opened last November above Bowlmor Lanes.

headline: A Rebirth on Fulton Street
text: The South Street Seaport Museum in New York City reopens to the public on Thursday after nearly a year of being closed.

headline: The Fine Line
text: PARIS

headline: Haute Couture: The Fine Line
text: Couture survived and nowadays, almost no one talks about its demise.

headline: Build Up Your Phone’s Defenses Against Hackers
text: Chuck Bokath would be terrifying if he were not such a nice guy. A jovial senior engineer at the Georgia Tech Research Institute in Atlanta, Mr. Bokath can hack into your cellphone just by dialing the number. He can remotely listen to your calls, read your text messages, snap pictures with your phone’s camera and track your movements around town — not to mention access the password to your online bank account.

headline: A Free Source of Information and Advice for New Parents
text: Everyone wants a piece of a new parent — or, at least, the wallet of a new parent.

headline: Sylvie Guillem to Make Rare New York Appearance
text: The French ballerina Sylvie Guillem will bring her production “6000 miles away” to the David H. Koch Theater this spring, in a rare New York appearance. She last performed here in 2006. The engagement, a co-production with Sadler’s Wells London, on April 4, 5 and 7, is the latest to fill empty nights at the theater, which lost New York City Opera this season because of the company’s financial problems. “6000 miles away,” a reference to Japan’s earthquake and tsunami last year, is being presented by the Joyce Theater Foundation. It consists of works by the choreographers Mats Ek, William Forsythe and Jiri Kylian.

headline: Polls: Before and After South Carolina
text: Two Florida polls released on Wednesday offer a clearer snapshot of how Newt Gingrich’s upset victory in South Carolina is swaying the state’s likely primary voters, as Mr. Gingrich pulls even with Mitt Romney.

headline: We’re Having Fun!
text: WHEN Amber Katz, who blogs at BeautyBloggingJunkie.com, speaks of her favorite cosmetics collections, high on the list is the “supersized” red lipglass shade from the Wonder Woman for MAC Cosmetics collection, inspired by what she called “the fierce superheroine.”

headline: Murray State Is Small but Accustomed to Winning
text: MURRAY, Ky. — The place to be on Monday nights in this Kentucky town is the wistfully named Big Apple Cafe. On a recent blustery evening, 71 people — a record, it was said — jammed into the back room to watch the Murray State radio play-by-play announcer Neal Bradley interview the university’s men’s basketball coach, Steve Prohm, for the weekly radio show “Hey Coach,” which can be heard across southwestern Kentucky.

headline: Shopping for Soup Tureens
text: The chef Dale Talde searched for versatile tureens for that “ta-da” moment.

headline: Soup Tureens
text: DALE TALDE might be known to many people as one of the more memorable contestants on the Bravo show “Top Chef.”

headline: Winter Wonders | Day Break
text: The casual end of the coat spectrum brings us woolens with hoodies and casual closures, like wooden toggles, zippers and snaps. Here, the singer Taylor Swift wears riding boots with a burgundy toggle coat in London; the television host Alexa Chung looks cozy in our favorite color combo, navy and black; and the actress Elizabeth Olsen sports a double-breasted schoolboy blazer, complete with gold buttons and crested pocket.

headline: Goal of the Year (So Far)?
text: As we write this, the match between Barcelona and Real Madrid at the Camp Nou, the second leg of their Copa del Rey series, is still in progress.

headline: New U.N. Envoy Urges Afghans to Take Part in Peace Process
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The new United Nations representative to Afghanistan urged Afghans on Wednesday to embrace an inclusive peace process in which all the elements of society would have a voice.

headline: Previewing Federer Vs. Nadal
text: Wednesday night’s Australian Open semifinal match from Melbourne between Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal has tennis fans across the globe giddy with anticipation. Their rivalry has elevated the level of play in men’s tennis, and it is a privilege to get to watch them play in such an important match. Federer has been playing sublime tennis, and, remarkably, has improved his game in the last year, especially his backhand and his net play. He knew that the book on how to play him involved attacking the Federer backhand until it broke down.

headline: SUNY Trustees Support Tuition Aid for Illegal Immigrants
text: State University of New York trustees unanimously approved on Wednesday a resolution supporting a plan to offer state-sponsored tuition assistance, grants and scholarships to college-bound illegal immigrants who want to enroll in state schools.

headline: A Generation’s Big Sister Pays a Visit to New York
text: Bright lights, big city. Youth and hope. A glittering wonderland of infinite possibility where “everything’s waiting for you.” That is a paradisiacal dream world of “Downtown,” held out like a bauble in Petula Clark’s signature hit that entered the charts in late 1964 and went to No. 1 early the next year.

headline: The Lyricism of Chinese New Year
text: That the New York Philharmonic would salute China with a glitzy affair like the Chinese New Year gala it hosted on Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall should come as no surprise. For years now China has been cast as the next great frontier for Western classical music: a place of crowded conservatories, hungry audiences and, possibly, bulging coffers. The Philharmonic saw the effects of this bloom firsthand during its concert tour there in 2008.

headline: A Tribute to an Artifact of ’60s Originality
text: The oddest and possibly slyest aspect of David Dorfman’s “Prophets of Funk,” his tribute to Sly and the Family Stone, which opened at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, is the role he plays himself. He’s the first dancer we meet: white, middle-aged, thick around the waist. Squatting and kicking to the groove in platform shoes, he’s more limber than you might expect, yet unavoidably comic. Mr. Dorfman knows this and makes the ridiculousness look intentional. The recorded applause isn’t for him, but he acts as if it were.

headline: Panama vs. U.S.: Pregame Notes and Quotes
text: PANAMA CITY — The road to the World Cup in Concacaf qualifying goes through Central America, and Wednesday night United States national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann got his first taste of what that means when the Yanks played Panama in Estadio Rommel Fernandez.

headline: Applied Neuroscience, the Six-String Method
text: At 13, an age when most boys want to learn the guitar, Gary Marcus, decided he wanted to be a scientist. Twenty-five years later he had become one of the country’s best known cognitive psychologists, with major papers and three general-interest books on the workings of the human mind and a position running New York University’s Center for Language and Music.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Video Game Rats and Groupon’s Snake Serum
text: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: All Sorts of Strange Stuff Happens When You Destroy the World
text: Near the end of Ryan Boudinot’s bracingly weird new novel a man asks his girlfriend, an editor, about the book that she’s working on.

headline: Retired Police Commander Could See Dismissal of Protest Charges
text: A retired Philadelphia police commander who was arrested at an Occupy Wall Street demonstration in November will have his case dismissed if he stays out of trouble for six months.

headline: The Catchy Voice of a Hundred TV Moments Shows a Blunter Edge
text: Hours before her album-release show at Joe’s Pub on Tuesday night, Ingrid Michaelson was in the back of an ambulance, speeding toward the emergency room. The incident — a false alarm, as she described it onstage — had involved heart palpitations, a mounting panic and some awkward embarrassment. But what if her “near-death experience,” as she wryly put it, had yielded a musical epiphany? “What if I came up here and started doing, like, freestyle jazz?” she asked, before delivering an impromptu-sounding gag song with her guitar. Then, laughing: “ ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ will not like that one.”

headline: Embracing the Mothers of Invention
text: I’ll admit it: I’m sometimes smugly entertained by the older generation’s reaction to the fads of the Web. “Facebook? Why on earth would I want other people to know about my private life?” “Twitter? Who’s got the time for that nonsense?”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Greece, France and Thailand.

headline: Independent Hair Salons in New York
text: A number of under-the-radar salons are thriving.

headline: Bout Time
text: America’s boxing women set their sights on an Olympic debut.

headline: For Hair That Isn’t Brand-Name
text: AMY SCHIAPPA’S first job in New York was as an assistant at John Barrett Salon in Bergdorf Goodman, which was famed for churning out the sort of platinum-coiffed society girls celebrated in Plum Sykes’s 2004 novel, “Bergdorf Blondes.”

headline: Antony Sees the Light
text: Critics like to describe Antony Hegarty, the silken-voiced leader of Antony and the Johnsons, as “otherworldly.” In recent years, the singer’s music has grown from pop, cabaret and soul signifiers to include characteristics of art song and sounds stranger still. Certainly, each of his acclaimed, prismatic albums seems to float in its own haunted universe.

headline: Moss, a Design Mecca, Is Closing
text: After 18 years in business, Moss, the SoHo design mecca, is shutting down its retail space on Greene Street, on Feb. 17.

headline: Frieze Art Fair New York Announces Commissioned Art Projects
text: The American version of London’s annual Frieze Art Fair, which makes its debut in New York in May, wants to be more than just another place to see and buy contemporary art. Using its unusual and remote location – the 256-acre Randall’s Island, in the East River between East Harlem, the South Bronx and Astoria, Queens – it has commissioned eight artists to construct what is calls “a temporary pop-up village.’’

headline: Seaport Museum Sets Sail, Again
text: Its historic ships still aren’t in any shape to hit the high seas.

headline: Greenhill Profit Jumps, and Firm Honors Its Fallen Bankers
text: Greenhill & Company had a lot of good earnings news to report on Wednesday — but it acknowledged its continued sadness over the deaths of two senior bankers last month.

headline: Barcelona Keeps Rival Real Madrid From Advancing
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Barcelona knocked out its archrival, Real Madrid, in the quarterfinals of the Copa del Rey on Wednesday, securing a tense 2-2 draw and delivering another blow to the ambitions of Madrid’s boisterous coach, José Mourinho.

headline: A Decline in Viewers for State of the Union Address
text: The State of the Union address Tuesday night was seen by 37.8 million television viewers, according to figures released by the Nielsen company, by far the fewest who have watched President Obama give the address.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: A Frosty Meeting for Obama and Arizona Governor
text: PHOENIX — President Obama’s visit to Phoenix got off to a rough start on Wednesday afternoon when Air Force One was met by  Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona — she of the book “Scorpions for Breakfast,” in which she accuses the Obama administration of turning a blind eye to illegal immigration because migrants will help Mr. Obama register more Democratic votes.

headline: Unlikely Routes Lead to Oscars
text: When she got the script for “Midnight in Paris,” Letty Aronson, Woody Allen’s longtime producer, wasn’t buying it. “When I first read the script, honestly, my impression was: Who’s going to come to this movie?” Ms. Aronson said. “Nobody even knows Gertrude Stein anymore.”

headline: A Town House Filled With Reimagined Vintage Pieces
text: In Brooklyn, the design firm Nightwood created a space that looks at once handmade and ethereal.

headline: What Vintage? Circa 2011
text: AYA YAMANOUCHI LLOYD met Nadia Yaron and Ry Scruggs, the Brooklyn designers who own Nightwood, in the spring of 2010.

headline: Polls Suggest Gingrich’s Support May Have Peaked
text: Polling released within the past 24 hours suggests that Mitt Romney has stopped and possibly reversed Newt Gingrich’s momentum before the Florida primary on Tuesday.

headline: Mourners Pay Tribute to Paterno During Funeral Procession
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The blue Cadillac hearse carrying Joe Paterno made its way through streets lined with thousands of mourners who tossed flowers, took photographs or simply waved goodbye as his funeral procession rolled through the Penn State campus and downtown along College Avenue on Wednesday.

headline: Attention, Class: Show-and-Tell Time With Carleton Varney
text: The interior designer Carleton Varney is a man of many talents. He has designed furniture, lighting, dinnerware and linens; he has two lines of fabrics, as well as a CD (“Carleton Varney, Music With Style”); his client roster includes luminaries like former President Jimmy Carter and the late Joan Crawford; and he can often be seen hawking his wares on HSN, where he is never without his signature scarf-worn-as-tie (the scarf designs are his as well).

headline: Amazon Aims Service at Cloud Novices
text: Amazon just made life a little harder for old-line computer companies, by making a play for their data storage backup business.

headline: Folk Art for Young Collectors
text: Susan Baerwald, a former Hollywood producer who now runs Just Folk, a gallery outside Santa Barbara, Calif., that she started with a fellow TV industry veteran, Marcy Carsey, said her first brush with American folk art was buying quilts. “They were a wonderful way to decorate an apartment in New York,” she said. “They took up a lot of wall space.”

headline: A Hand-Embroidered Flight of Fancy
text: Marie-France de Crécy, a 38-year-old Parisian textile designer who once worked as a fashion stylist, creates upholstery fabrics with many of the same qualities as those found in haute couture, including hand-embroidery, hand-beading and “the idea of placement,” she said, where a print appears “in a very specific place” on a piece of furniture.

headline: Stored for Decades, Hitler’s Silver Is to Go on Display
text: For 66 years, they lay unseen, first in a vault on the Upper West Side, more recently in a special cabinet. Now the New-York Historical Society plans to put them on public display alongside a silver cigar box, a silver ice cream dish and the silver controller handle that Mayor George B. McClellan Jr. used when he drove the first subway train, in 1904: A knife and fork with the initials A and H, for Adolf Hitler.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Valentino
text: For the Couture edition of The Daily Shoe, T picks the most exquisite made-to-measures.

headline: Design Perfectionists at Home
text: The minimalist spaces where design perfectionists live — some so fastidious that they have no furniture at all.

headline: Sales at Phaidon and Jensen-Lewis
text: Hundreds of art, architecture, design and photography titles from Phaidon are up to 80 percent off during January, or while supplies last (the three-volume “Phaidon Design Classics,” regularly $175, is about $87); 83 Wooster Street (Spring Street), (212) 925-1900, phaidon.com.

headline: One Foot Planted Firmly in the Nest
text: I LOVE Yorkville, the Manhattan neighborhood that my family has called home since 1896. During my childhood in the 1960s, it was my warren, and I burrowed joyously into and around it. There was Joe’s Candy Store, with the moodiest Italian bachelor in New York City, who served cold soda from his giant tub of frosty water. There was Parker’s Mom & Pop Grocery, starring sweet Murray Parker and his Elmer Fudd hat with earflaps that he wore year round on his bald head. And there was Prexy’s (“The hamburger with the college education”), Loftus Tavern (my father’s regular haunt) and the Cherokee Democratic Club (a double-wide brownstone on East 79th Street that I had the run of because my grandmother was Yorkville’s longtime district leader).

headline: No Room for Mistakes
text: TODD WATERBURY’S apartment is just perfect.

headline: Kris Humphries Redecorates for One
text: The 72-day marriage and subsequent divorce of Kim Kardashian and Kris Humphries set off a firestorm of tabloid coverage, he-said she-said bickering and angry cries that the whole thing was a publicity stunt. But for all the high-profile drama, the relationship may have been doomed by a mundane problem: the couple apparently couldn’t agree on where to live.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I have a built-in banquette in my kitchen. Should I reupholster it before trying to sell my home?

headline: A Highly Rated Body of Work
text: ALL around, there were construction workers, particle-board dust and the whine of drills. But as John Blair, arguably the longest-working gay nightlife promoter in New York, swaggered through what would soon be XL, the city’s first new gay megaclub in many years, you could almost hear the thump of the dance music, see the writhing throng of shirtless men and smell the heady mix of cologne, dry ice and sweat.

headline: EBay Seller Seeks a Cool $1 Million for President Obama’s Chrysler
text: Cars with presidential provenance have been known to command hefty premiums at auction. One eBay seller is hoping to sell a 2005 Chrysler 300C that reportedly belonged to Barack Obama for a downright princely sum.

headline: An Indian Student’s Guide to the SAT and ACT Admissions Exams
text: Robin Mamlet, the former dean of admissions at Stanford University in California, and Christine VanDeVelde, a journalist, are the authors of “College Admission: From Application to Acceptance, Step by Step.”

headline: When Skyscrapers Are Your Screen
text: THERE is a commercial building at the intersection of Canal Street and West Broadway with a whitewashed and windowless side that most people would consider an eyesore. But for J R Skola on a recent evening it was a six-story canvas for a traveling work called “Space Monkey.”

headline: Poll: Apple Products
text: Results from a telephone survey conducted by The New York Times in Nov. 2011.

headline: Poll Finds Consumer Confusion on Where Apple Devices Are Made
text: The outsourcing of manufacturing jobs remains a major sore point for most Americans. But owners of some of the nation’s most popular electronics — including iPhones and iPads — are less concerned than other Americans about where their purchases are made, according to a nationwide survey conducted by The New York Times.

headline: Parsing the State of the Union Address
text: To the Editor:

headline: In China, Human Costs Are Built Into an iPad
text: The explosion ripped through Building A5 on a Friday evening last May, an eruption of fire and noise that twisted metal pipes as if they were discarded straws.

headline: Colts Pick Ravens’ Pagano as Coach
text: The Indianapolis Colts hired Chuck Pagano, the defensive coordinator for the Baltimore Ravens, as their coach Wednesday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,868 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Chinese Readers on the ‘iEconomy’
text: On Sunday, The Times published “How the U.S. Lost Out on iPhoneWork,” the first article in “The iEconomy,” a new series examining the challenges posed by increasingly globalized high-tech industries.

headline: Deft Grand-Slam Bidding Wins a Pair Game
text: The District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., which started on Jan. 10, was carefully scheduled. Since it ended on Jan. 16, Martin Luther King’s Birthday, an extra day of play could be sneaked in.

headline: Facebook Chat About the ‘iEconomy’ Series
text: 5:31 p.m. | Updated  We’ve added highlights from the Facebook chat at the bottom of the post.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Jean Paul Gaultier
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Turnaround at Netflix, as Its Mail Sector Shrinks
text: After a haltingly poor performance in the middle of last year, Netflix reported fourth-quarter earnings on Wednesday that exceeded analysts’ expectations and a subscriber uptick that surpassed its own outlook.

headline: At Perelman Trial, an Assistant’s Work Is Scrutinized
text: Personal assistants on Wall Street inhabit a secretive world, with daily access to the private lives of the powerful.

headline: The Language of Flowers: Latin No More?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Campaign Contributions: ‘Speech at a Premium’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Antibiotics in Animals
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Year Later, Still Young, Still Fighting
text: “It’s been a year. Nothing happened.”

headline: Profits Rise, and Shares Follow, for US Airways and Delta
text: Shares of both Delta Air Lines and US Airways rose after the companies reported fourth-quarter profits that topped analysts’ estimates.

headline: Made in China
text: Workers assembling iPads, iPhones and other products often work in abusive, sometimes deadly conditions. Employees of Foxconn offered a glimpse inside their factory in Chengdu.

headline: Pattern of Intimidation Is Seen in Arrests of Iranian Journalists and Bloggers
text: The judicial authorities in Iran have arrested at least half a dozen journalists and bloggers over the past few weeks, according to their acquaintances, opposition Web sites and rights groups. The moves appear to be part of a pre-emptive campaign of intimidation to thwart protests surrounding the parliamentary elections that are scheduled to be held in early March.

headline: Grunting Is Loud, and So Is Response
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The sound of women’s tennis has not changed, but the fury it can cause has intensified.

headline: The New York (Mayor’s) Review of Books
text: He controls a global publishing empire, but few would call him bookish. His city is a hotbed of writers and critics, but when it comes to literature, he pleads ignorance.

headline: Recommend a Book to Mayor Bloomberg
text: During a visit to a high school English class in the Bronx, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg revealed his love for the John le Carré classic, “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.” His literary leaning even inspired a rare trip to the cinema to catch the new movie version of the book.

headline: Hedge Funds Scramble to Unload Greek Debt
text: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Judgeship With Prestige, and, Oh, What a Grand Room
text: Sure, being the top judge of the appeals court in Brooklyn is impressive. It is one of the most powerful judicial seats in the state.

headline: Candidates Scramble to Win Hispanic Votes in Florida
text: MIAMI — The leading Republican candidates spent Wednesday appealing for the votes of South Florida’s Hispanic voters, with the campaigns of Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich skirmishing over an advertisement that branded Mr. Romney as anti-immigration.

headline: Wesley E. Brown, Oldest Judge in Nation’s History, Dies at 104
text: Judge Wesley E. Brown, whose work ethic and a hale constitution kept him climbing the stairs to his fourth-floor courtroom past his 100th birthday, making him the oldest active federal judge in the nation’s history, died on Monday in Wichita, Kan. He was 104.

headline: Djibouti Outpost Behind Somalia Rescue Is Part of New Defense Strategy
