headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Slashes C.E.O.’s Bonus
text: LONDON — Royal Bank of Scotland announced on Thursday that it would pay its chief executive, Stephen Hester, an all-stock bonus of £963,000, or $1.5 million, less than half what he received last year.

headline: Parental Quandary Considered: The Sex Offender Next Door Is Not the Problem
text: C.’s quandary was simple, and read something like a nightmare (or the opening sequence of an episode of “Law and Order”). She’d received notice from the local sheriff that a registered sex offender was moving into the house next door to hers. This was no “Romeo and Juliet” misunderstood teen, but someone with a genuine history of preying on young men and boys, although not as young as C.’s toddler son.

headline: House Democrats Embrace Obama’s Newfound Combativeness
text: CAMBRIDGE, Md. – The on-again-off-again relationship between Barack Obama and House Democrats appears to be on again with the president’s turn toward a more populist, confrontational tone on the Republican Party.

headline: Look of the Moment | Léa Seydoux
text: The Look: Vroom Vroom. The classic American cars that speed across pieces from Prada’s latest collection give whole new meaning to the term “fast fashion.”

headline: As Evaluation Talks Resume, Some Teachers Press for a Resolution
text: Teachers at some of the 33 so-called struggling schools that are engaged in improvement efforts sent a letter last week to Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott and the teachers union president, Michael Mulgrew. The teachers petitioned the city and union to reach an agreement on a new teacher evaluation system that would fulfill the requirements of a federal grant and free up $58 million that the state has been withholding. Meanwhile, the city and union have resumed informal talks.

headline: Leaders in Euro Zone Shift Focus Beyond Gloom
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Is the “end of the euro” over?

headline: China's Factory Cities
text: Catherine Rampell, a business reporter, interviews David Barboza, a foreign correspondent, about working conditions in Chinese electronics factories and the role of U.S. companies.

headline: More Than Schnitzel
text: Frank Bruni tours some of Berlin’s newest restaurants.

headline: Get the Whistleblowers
text: There was an article on the front page of the Times on Wednesday that stopped me cold. It reported that the Justice Department has charged a former Central Intelligence Agency officer, John Kiriakou, with disclosing classified information to journalists—charges that could mean 30 years in prison.

headline: They’ve Done It Again: An Albatross Chick
text: To the delight of scientists, a pair of lovers returned to Hawaii this year for what might turn out to be an annual sojourn. The two birds are endangered short-tailed albatrosses, and for the second time in the species’ recorded history, they nested there, producing a chick on American soil.

headline: Milwaukee Gets Arty in the Third Ward
text: The city, known for its blue-collar roots, gets a bit of flair.

headline: Lawmakers Release Proposed Redistricting Maps
text: ALBANY – Lawmakers on Thursday unveiled their proposal to redraw state Senate and Assembly districts to comport with the most recent Census, setting in motion what is expected to be a bruising fight among legislators, government watchdogs and civil rights groups over how the state’s political map should look for the next decade.

headline: Madison Square, 1:18 p.m.
text: Carol Willis is, appropriately enough, the founder, director and curator of the Skyscraper Museum.

headline: With $25 Million Gift, Signature Theater Has a New Name
text: The Signature Theater is only going to unveil and move into its new home on 42nd Street next week, but it has already received one unusually generous housewarming gift: on Thursday the Pershing Square Foundation announced that it is donating $25 million to Signature, much of it to be used in a 20-year initiative to keep ticket prices affordable.

headline: TimesCast | Gingrich on Space Industry
text: Though the latest polls show Newt Gingrich’s momentum may have stalled, he has found strong backing in Brevard County, Fla., by proposing a bold initiative in space industry employment.

headline: Latinos on the Economy: Hard Hit but Hopeful
text: Latinos have been especially hard hit by the economic downturn, with nearly four in 10 — 38 percent — saying they have skipped meals because they did not have enough money for food, according to a national survey published on Thursday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Firms and Latvian Trader of Market Abuse
text: A Latvian trader is accused of hacking into the brokerage accounts of innocent investors in the United States, making hundreds of thousands of dollars for himself while costing the unwitting victims millions.

headline: Teaching the Volt to Charge Smarter and Cleaner
text: On Thursday, General Motors announced an alert system under development that would instruct the Chevy Volt to charge only when a relatively high percentage of renewable energy was available. Being plugged in at those times would further minimize the carbon footprint of the plug-in hybrid. Google plans to test the technology, facilitated by the subscription-based OnStar alert and navigation system, on its fleet of 17 Volts.

headline: Chinese Clusters and Me
text: I realized that if you wanted to know where I was coming from on the Apple-in-China story, the best reading is probably the paper I prepared for the Association of American Geographers (pdf), which offers both a nontechnical account of what the “new economic geography” was about and a discussion of how it applies to China.

headline: Caucus Video: Gingrich and the Space Industry
text: Though the latest polls show Newt Gingrich’s momentum may have stalled, he has found strong backing in Brevard County, Fla., by proposing a bold initiative in space industry employment. Trip Gabriel reports.

headline: A Russian Principal Sniffs Around Brooklyn
text: Cliff Levy’s article in the magazine about sending his non-Russian-speaking children to a Russian school received hundreds of comments when it ran in September — not a few of which expressed admiration for Vasiliy Bogin, the school’s charismatic principal. On Wednesday it was Bogin’s turn to observe the American educational system – or at least P.S. 321, a well-regarded school in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where as reported here on the Schoolbook site, he found some ideas worth taking home.

headline: Plunging Ahead to Poke the Bear
text: WE were camping in a dust pile at Chickenfoot Lake. Elevation: 11,000 feet. The landscape there is beautiful, sublimely so — diamond lakes, wildflowers, soaring mountains flecked with snow. Looking back at pictures, I can’t believe I didn’t want to be there.

headline: Suddenly, Debate No. 19 Means Everything
text: It’s the most important night of Mitt Romney’s political life.

headline: Carrefour Said to Seek Chief Executive
text: PARIS — Carrefour, the French retailer that ranks second in the world in revenue behind Wal-Mart Stores, was in advanced talks to replace its chief executive, people with direct knowledge of the situation said Thursday.

headline: In Man vs. Wolf Pack, Survival of the Flintiest
text: “The Grey” continues what has become a welcome seasonal movie tradition. For the past three winters, just when the Oscar nominees you’ve missed are trying to dazzle and guilt-trip you with visions of Importance, a lean and angry Liam Neeson shows up at the multiplex, out for righteous payback or at least the paycheck that no one would dare begrudge him. Buy a ticket, punk! Having paid his quality biopic dues as Oskar Schindler, Michael Collins and Alfred Kinsey, Mr. Neeson has, at least for now, turned to the rougher and perhaps more lucrative work of action heroism. It takes nothing away from his earlier achievements to note that he’s really good at it. He conveys a ferocious and absolute seriousness even when the going gets silly, and he finds the soul in each new angry-everyman cipher he is asked to play.

headline: A Bloody Roman Romp With a Dose of Debauch
text: “Spartacus,” the Starz channel’s costume-optional drama set in the waning years of the Roman Republic, returns for a second season on Friday night with the four B’s of its appeal intact: beefcake, blood, breasts and the Bard. (The fourth B refers to the show’s solemn, mock Elizabethan dialogue, light on definite articles — “When ritual is ended, see blood cleansed” — but studded with profanity.)

headline: 3M’s Profit Beats Analysts’ Estimates
text: The 3M Company, the maker of Post-it Notes and industrial products, reported higher fourth-quarter profit than analysts had estimated as demand increased for aerospace and auto products.

headline: Marco Rubio Won’t Be V.P.
text: Your parents came to Miami from Cuba in the 1950s. Your dad became a bartender, and your mom worked as a hotel maid, among other jobs. Was it always clear that you wouldn’t follow them into a service job? The service industry is hard, honorable work, but early on my parents drove it into us that a job is what you do to make a living; a career is when you get paid to do something that you love. They had jobs so I could have a career.

headline: Sarkozy’s Main Rival Offers Proposals for Lifting France’s Economy
text: PARIS — François Hollande, the Socialist Party candidate leading in the polls for the French presidency, appeared Thursday to try to address complaints that he had been too vague about his plans for France and its slowing economy, issuing a package of 60 measures that would increase taxes and government spending but aim to balance the budget by 2017.

headline: Before and After: Automat Under Wraps
text: An automat at 611 West 181st Street, designed in 1930 by Louis Allen Abramson, was converted to a bank in 1978 and today the space houses a Sleepy’s mattress store.

headline: Can the Blazers Keep All the Pieces?
text: The Portland Trail Blazers of today are deep, versatile and effective on both ends of the court. This particular Portland team certainly isn’t without its flaws, but it plays an eminently watchable brand of basketball with more than enough substance as its foundation.

headline: Expats Face Confusing New Law to Buy Insurance in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — Expatriates living in Turkey scrambled this week to try to fulfill a new requirement that foreign residents register and pay for national health insurance by Tuesday, January 31, or face a fine said to be 886.50 lira, or about $495.

headline: Boy, Did She Make It
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — In her office at her home here Mary Tyler Moore has one case that holds her Emmy statuettes (she has won seven) and Golden Globe awards (three). A second case has, among other honors, her People’s Choice awards (four). She’ll have another piece of hardware after this weekend. She will receive the Screen Actors Guild’s lifetime achievement award on Sunday during that organization’s annual ceremony in Los Angeles, which will be broadcast at 8 p.m. on TNT and TBS.

text: IT never fails. You go into Lee’s Art Shop, half a block from Carnegie Hall, as a customer — usually for something prosaic like a couple of Pilot Razor Points from their amazing 215-slot pen rack — and leave wishing you were an artist.

headline: Rituals Must Be Observed By Those Onstage and Off
text: There’s an overwhelming sense of ritual behind any solo piano concert by Keith Jarrett: a set of expectations and behaviors, often unspoken but widely understood. To the extent that it’s a code, it involves both the artist and his audience, and especially the transaction between the two. Since the 1970s, when Mr. Jarrett first earned a reputation for sustained, spontaneous rhapsody, he has trained his concertgoers to gather as congregants, complicit witnesses to his search for illumination. Also: no cameras. No coughing. No, seriously.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tales of Kim Dotcom and the iPhone Makers

headline: Parents Waging a Battle Against the Ultimate Foe
text: “Declaration of War” is a manic sprint whose style and momentum recall French New Wave films like “Jules and Jim” revved up to double-time. On paper, the story of Juliette (Valérie Donzelli) and Roméo (Jérémie Elkaïm), bohemian Parisians whose 18-month-old son develops a brain tumor, may sound depressing. But the emergency channels their energy into an exhilarating race against time. A crucial insight of the movie, directed by Ms. Donzelli, is that a crisis can infuse daily life with a surreal, zany urgency.

headline: Santorum Says He’s ‘Not Going Anywhere’
text: MIAMI — Rick Santorum, who has been all but shut out of news media coverage since Newt Gingrich won the South Carolina primary last week, said Thursday that he was staying in the race for the long haul.

headline: A Grotesque Stillness Flirts With Flamboyance
text: The tendency of commercial galleries to mount exhibitions of historical material is pushed to rewardingly crazed extremes by the latest offerings at Sperone Westwater. This blue-chip gallery, previously located in SoHo and then Chelsea, has crammed two lavish exhibitions into the four floors of available display space in the narrow, overly hygienic building on the Bowery — commissioned from the British starchitect Norman Foster — to which it moved in 2010.

headline: Antiques on Camera and Behind Every Door
text: Reality television about antiques is available practically around the clock now, and half a dozen new shows have appeared in the past few months. But the transactions shown these days little resemble how the trade actually works.

headline: A Life of Marital Bliss (Segregation Laws Aside)
text: What’s the difference between a political activist and a political hero? It’s often a matter of intention versus accident. Within the civil rights movement Rosa Parks is seen as an activist: She trained at the Highlander Folk School for social justice in Tennessee, and her refusal to give up her seat on a crowded bus was the catalyst for the 1955 Montgomery Bus Boycott. Richard and Mildred Loving, an interracial couple from Virginia whose marriage prompted a benchmark 1967 Supreme Court ruling overturning state miscegenation laws, are portrayed in “The Loving Story: Photographs by Grey Villet” as heroes who fell into history by accident.

headline: Off-Campus, With Elbow Room
text: BY the time he reached his third year of law school at New York University, Michael Igyarto had had enough of dorm living.

headline: Previewing the Debate in Jacksonville
text: This one could be the nastiest, most personal debate yet.

headline: Good Works Should Top Good Looks
text: I have three daughters, who are still quite young. The oldest is very striking, and people often tell me how beautiful she is — right in front of the other two girls, without saying a word about them. Even my family does this. It makes my heart ache for my younger daughters. I find it so insensitive, even though everyone is just trying to be nice. How should I handle this?J. S., Marina, Calif.

headline: Romney Paid More Than He Owed
text: Mitt Romney’s tax returns tell us some things about him. They tell us a lot more about the sad state of the tax laws in this country.

headline: At Yale, the Collapse of a Rhodes Scholar Candidacy
text: NEW HAVEN — On Nov. 13, Patrick J. Witt, Yale University’s star quarterback, announced that he had withdrawn his Rhodes scholarship application and would instead play against Harvard six days later, at the very time of the required Rhodes interview. His apparent choice of team fealty over individual honor capped weeks of admiring national attention on this accomplished student and his quandary.

headline: Joyce Pensato’s ‘Batman Returns’ at Friedrich Petzel
text: Friedrich Petzel Gallery

headline: Namath, an Estranged Jet
text: Joe Namath wishes he had a better connection to the Jets’ regime. He is their only true icon, but he has also turned critical of them at times, on Twitter, ESPN Radio and his BroadwayJoe.tv Web site.

headline: Doug Wheeler’s Futuristic Installation at David Zwirner
text: David Zwirner

headline: JAMES NARES: ‘1976: Movies, Photographs and Related Works on Paper’
text: Paul Kasmin Gallery

headline: Shrinking the Escrow
text: WHEN you choose a fixed-rate loan for a home purchase or refinancing — as more than 9 out of 10 people currently do — only one part of the monthly mortgage statement is ever likely to change: the escrow amount.

headline: Could Marco Rubio Solve Mitt Romney’s Hispanic Problem?
text: A lot has changed since I interviewed Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on the morning of Jan. 17. That evening Newt Gingrich unleashed theatrical opprobrium upon John King, and Mitt Romney went from presumed nominee to bloodied establishment candidate. Rubio’s home state of Florida, which votes Jan. 31, has become, pick your metaphor — ground zero, Armageddon, The Last Exit To Somewheresville — for both candidates.

headline: JORDAN WOLFSON
text: Alex Zachary Peter Currie

headline: Surfing on a Hardwood Floor
text: I DON’T really like the ocean. Let me clarify: I don’t really like the idea of the ocean. Who knows what’s down there? Not me. So you might not think of me as a prime candidate for a surfing class. Luckily, a surfing class on dry land is no longer a myth, for I have seen it.

headline: Dance on Camera Festival Opens, and ‘Pina’ Film Is Extended
text: Dance isn’t the most affordable art form to keep up with. Decent tickets to the ballet can range from $60 to $200. But Dance on Camera, a collaboration of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and Dance Films Association, helps keep the Miser rich in high culture, at movie theater prices.

headline: Q & A
text: Who Should Fix a Plumbing Problem?

headline: Manic Peter Pan Rules Dance Clubs
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: They’ll Strum From Day Into Night
text: If there is one instrument with a built-in passport for crossing genres, it is the guitar. Central to folk music of all kinds, the backbone of the blues and, in its amplified form, both a supple solo voice in jazz and the lifeblood of rock, the guitar also has a classical literature that (with some transcriptional tweaking) stretches back to the 16th century and includes a rich, complex contemporary repertory.

headline: Mayor Defends Kelly, but Says Anti-Muslim Film Caused Damage
text: As his administration faces a firestorm over a video  shown to hundreds of police officers that depicted Muslims as extremists, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg conceded on Thursday that the episode had damaged relations between the city’s Islamic community and the Police Department.

headline: Best Time to List a Home? Midweek
text: GLENN KELMAN, the chief executive of Redfin, an online real estate brokerage based in Seattle that has had a presence on the Island for two years, always thought that houses on the market in the dead of winter were like a “clearance rack.” He was convinced that winter was the worst time to sell.

headline: Cops and Robbers, and Vertigo
text: It is not just painful, but it is also infuriating to see Ed Harris humiliated by having to deliver his wretched dialogue in the thriller “Man on a Ledge.” His character, David Englander, is an evil real estate tycoon given to screaming things like, “There are two kinds of people in the world — people who will do anything to get what they want and everybody else.” That’s about as subtle as it gets.

headline: A Quick Roundup of the Pentagon’s Proposed Budget Cuts
text: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta outlined on Thursday the first major step — he called it a “down payment” — of shrinking the Pentagon after a decade of war. Included in the proposal: limit pay raises for troops, increase health insurance fees for military retirees and close bases in the United States. Of those proposals, our colleagues Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker write that pay-raise limits, though modest, “are certain to ignite a political fight in Congress, which since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has consistently raised military salaries beyond what the Pentagon has recommended.”

headline: ‘Historic Dirt’ Preserved
text: LONG VALLEY

headline: Canadian Legonaut Returns From the Stratosphere Bearing Remarkable Images
text: Even if he didn’t quite make it all the way to outer space, as some early reports claimed, a two-inch Lego man, with a fixed grin and a Canadian flag in his hand, did travel about 80,000 feet above the Earth’s surface to the upper stratosphere this month, and he has the stunning video to prove it.

headline: Searching for Love and the Second Book
text: Eric Schaeffer has said he intends his latest film, “After Fall, Winter,” to be the second of four he will make at 15-year intervals focused on the same character. Watch out, current holder of the World’s Longest Vanity Project title.

headline: Trackside Developments Catch On
text: MORE than a century ago, before the term “transit-oriented development” entered the urban-planning glossary, plenty of it was being built in Westchester: clusters of housing, shops and sometimes industrial buildings close to railroad stations.

headline: Twitter Announces Micro-Censorship Policy
text: 7:52 p.m. | Updated Within hours of the announcement, people had figured out ways to subvert Twitter’s blocking.

headline: AT&T: We Need Spectrum or Prices Are Going Up
text: Smartphones and tablets are squeezing data networks. And because of the limited amount of the frequency spectrum available to expand wireless services, the nation may face a data network shortage in the coming years. AT&T thinks the government is the problem.

headline: 14-Year-Old Texan, a Student of Science and Sex
text: “Five Time Champion,” written and directed by Berndt Mader, is a kind of indie Every Film. Quiet, mostly well observed, a bit quirky, regionally distinct (it takes place in Texas) and aware of human complexity, it’s also a little pat and a little dramatically underpowered.

headline: Fielder Comes Home
text: DETROIT — It was a happily eerie scene at Comerica Park on Thursday, as the new Detroit Tigers slugger Prince Fielder sat on the dais for a news conference, flanked by his cute, curly-haired 7-year-old son, Jadyn.

headline: Gingrich Insurgency Tests Party’s Old Guard
text: WASHINGTON — The Old Guard of the Republican Party has suddenly surfaced with some acid criticism of Newt Gingrich and warnings that he would be crushed in November, seeking to impose some discipline on an electorate that seems to be flirting seriously with nominating Mr. Gingrich for president.

headline: A Venerable Fresh Face Goes on Tour
text: The No. 1 question from visitors to the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, according to Emilie Gordenker, is “Where is ‘Girl With a Pearl Earring’?”

headline: Web Site’s Call Ends in Four Happily-Ever-Afters
text: “Oft expectation fails, and most oft there/Where it most promises,” says Helena, the heroine of Shakespeare’s “All’s Well That Ends Well,” as she pursues her man doggedly despite his brutish behavior. Not for nothing is this comedy characterized as a problem play.

headline: Visionaries, Charmers and Demons
text: The near death of the American Folk Art Museum was one of the more alarming events in the New York art world last year. So it is heartening to see this irreplaceable institution rising from the grave with “Jubilation/Rumination: Life, Real and Imagined,” a wonderful exhibition of works from the permanent collection.

headline: Conservatives Criticize Drudge for Anti-Gingrich Assault
text: Furious conservatives have taken to blogs and Twitter on Thursday to vent their ire against what they allege is a conspiratorial dumping of twisted and manipulated negative attacks on Newt Gingrich.

headline: Bolstering Staff, Yankees Complete Deal With Kuroda
text: The Yankees announced the signing of Hiroki Kuroda, a right-handed starter, on Thursday and also agreed to a one-year deal with reliever Boone Logan to avoid arbitration.

headline: History Unfolding on a Hand Scroll
text: The painter Fu Baoshi was born in China in 1904, seven years before the Chinese Revolution brought 2,100 years of dynastic rule to an end. He died in 1965, months before China’s Communist regime unleashed the Cultural Revolution, which aggressively persecuted the country’s writers, artists and other intelligentsia, sometimes unto death.

headline: A Rising Tide of Applications to Harvard Appears to Crest
Ruling Favors Owner of Rig in Gulf Spill
text: Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, which blew out in the Gulf of Mexico nearly two years ago, is not liable for some of the pollution claims arising from the fatal accident, a federal judge in Louisiana ruled on Thursday.

headline: Shot-Up Image of President Draws a Secret Service Inquiry
text: PHOENIX — The Secret Service said Thursday that it was looking into a photograph posted on the Internet that showed a group of young Arizona men posing in the desert with guns while holding up what appeared to be a bullet-riddled image of President Obama’s face.

headline: Life, Liberty and the Fact of Slavery
text: WASHINGTON — The astounding thing about American slavery is not that it existed — the enslavement of one people by another may be one of history’s universals — but that it persisted. It lasted into an era when its absence could be imagined and its presence could become an outrage.

headline: Patriots’ Gronkowski Does Not Practice
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — New England Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski did not practice Thursday, the only player missing from the team’s first official workout since Sunday’s victory over the Baltimore Ravens in the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Auto Retailer Heralds a Turnaround, Citing Demand to Replace Aging Cars
text: DETROIT — The nation’s biggest automotive retailer on Thursday reported strong financial results for 2011 and suggested the recovery of the American car market had reached a turning point.

headline: Long a Divisive Figure, but Still the Grocer’s Daughter Back Home
text: GRANTHAM, England — It is a poignant story, and the sparse audiences at the Reel Cinema, a few blocks from the handsome 18th-century facades of the town center, tell it as well as anything else.

headline: Apple in China: Has iOrwell Arrived?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spy Drone and Missile Sub Are on Military’s Budget-Cutting List
text: As the Pentagon Thursday announced changes in its programs, military contractors were bracing for cancellations or cutbacks of several programs.

headline: Senate to Take Up Bill to Ban Insider Trading by Lawmakers
text: The Senate next week will take up legislation seeking to ban lawmakers from profiting on inside information gleaned through their Congressional work, said Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Papua New Guinea: Mutiny Said to Fail
text: A mutiny by a group of soldiers loyal to Papua New Guinea’s ousted leader, Sir Michael Somare, has failed, the country’s prime minister told reporters late Thursday. The announcement comes amid escalating tensions between the current and former heads of government in the South Pacific island nation, each of whom claims legitimacy. Up to 20 soldiers stormed the barracks of the Papua New Guinea Defense Force in the capital, Port Moresby, early Thursday, detained the military chief and demanded that Prime Minister Peter O’Neill bow to a Supreme Court ruling ordering Sir Michael’s reinstatement as leader. But after a tense day, Mr. O’Neill said his military chief had been freed and the barracks had been returned to the control of his government.

headline: A Call Resounds Across Florida for an Overscheduled Candidate: ‘Is He Here Yet?’
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — It is one of the great unappreciated skills of a political campaign: running out the clock at rallies while waiting for a candidate who is behind schedule.

headline: Early Indicators Point to Stellar Season for 76ers
text: The first month of this abbreviated N.B.A. season has brought a number of unexpected twists and turns. One of the more surprising developments has been the stellar play of the Philadelphia 76ers.

headline: In Punishing Year for Hedge Funds, Biggest One Thrived
text: The world’s biggest hedge fund is also one of the best performers.

headline: With Every Big Drive, Watson Helps Fight Cancer
text: SAN DIEGO — On the two driving holes Thursday on Torrey Pines’ North Course — the 434-yard par-4 fourth and the 547-yard par-5 ninth — Bubba Watson’s shots off the tees traveled 314 and 370 yards. His booming drives are a boon for the “Bubba & Friends: Drive to a Million” charity campaign he started this week.

headline: Israel Senses Bluffing in Iran’s Threats of Retaliation
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli intelligence estimates, backed by academic studies, have cast doubt on the widespread assumption that a military strike on Iranian nuclear facilities would set off a catastrophic set of events like a regional conflagration, widespread acts of terrorism and sky-high oil prices.

headline: Getting Back to Basics After Brain Surgery
text: SAN DIEGO — After J. B. Holmes’s first competitive swing in more than five months, his shoulders slumped. His drive Thursday on the first hole of Torrey Pines’s South Course traveled 280 yards, coming to rest in the first cut of the right intermediate rough.

headline: Regional Cap-and-Trade Effort Seeks Greater Impact by Cutting Carbon Allowances
text: Adjusting to shifts in the economy, states in the cap-and-trade system known as the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative have slashed the number of allowances that electric power companies can buy to offset their emissions.

headline: South Carolina: Schools Agree to Halt Prayers
text: A school district that was sued for holding a prayer rally at a school assembly and prayers at official events has agreed to end its promotion of religion. A federal judge on Thursday made final a consent decree in which the Chesterfield County schools admitted to violating the separation of church and state. Under the decree, school officials may not encourage prayers at events or allow endorsement of religion in the classroom. The suit was brought by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of a middle-school student who objected to the evangelical assembly and other Christian activities at school.

headline: For Many in Pakistan, a Television Show Goes Too Far
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — One morning last week, television viewers in Pakistan were treated to a darkly comic sight: a posse of middle-class women roaming through a public park in Karachi, on the hunt for dating couples engaged in “immoral” behavior.

headline: Deconstructing Gingrich
text: In his weekly column, Timothy Egan writes:

headline: In Perelman Lawsuit, a Fight Over Files Not Deleted
text: When Ronald O. Perelman was looking to buy Deluxe Entertainment Services, he turned to Goldman Sachs for advice.

headline: Jobs, Jobs and Cars
text: Mitch Daniels, the former Bush budget director who is now Indiana’s governor, made the Republicans’ reply to President Obama’s State of the Union address. His performance was, well, boring. But he did say something thought-provoking — and I mean that in the worst way.

headline: Maine: Gay-Rights Backers Say Petition Goal Is Met
text: Gay-rights advocates say they have almost twice the 57,277 signatures required to put a same-sex marriage referendum on the ballot this November, which will most likely bring the issue before voters for the second time in three years. Same-sex marriage was legalized here in 2009, but voters overturned the law with a so-called people’s veto later that year. Six states and the District of Columbia allow same-sex marriage, but none have yet legalized it with a popular vote.

headline: TV Anchor Not Shy About Being Police Leader’s Son
text: For some New York journalists, being a son of one of the city’s most powerful public officials might require some professional distance.

headline: Republican Candidates Debate in Jacksonville, Fla.
text: The debate was a crucial face-off just five days before Florida’s presidential primary.

headline: Hope, but Not Much Change
text: The Simpson-Bowles report wasn’t just a policy document. For a few months, it expanded the national debate. Everybody seemed to realize that the country was beset by large challenges that could no longer be neglected: soaring debt, lagging growth, wage stagnation, family breakdown, political dysfunction.

headline: Indignation Over Immigration Marks Beginning of Debate
text: Interesting start to the debate, with a question from the audience about illegal immigration. Though it at first seemed likely to prompt a more civil debate — especially since Wolf Blitzer, the moderator, chose to direct the question to Rick Santorum — it ultimately yielded the kind of vitriol between Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney that some expected.

headline: Jacksonville Debate Live Blog
text: The candidates take the stage for the last debate before the Florida Primary on Tuesday. The two-hour debate, being broadcast on CNN, is co-sponsored by the Florida Republican Party.

headline: Debate Fact Check: ‘Self-Deportation’
text: Wolf Blitzer asked Newt Gingrich whether Mitt Romney is anti-immigrant; a Gingrich campaign Spanish-language radio ad called Mr. Romney “anti-immigrant.”

headline: At Davos, Debating Capitalism’s Future
text: Davos, Switzerland

headline: North Carolina Governor’s Decision May Aid Obama Bid
text: Bev Perdue, a Democrat who barely grabbed the governorship of North Carolina three years ago and never gained widespread popularity, said on Thursday that she would not run for re-election this fall.

headline: For $2 a Star, an Online Retailer Gets 5-Star Product Reviews
text: In the brutal world of online commerce, where a competing product is just a click away, retailers need all the juice they can get to close a sale.

headline: Massachusetts: Congressman Will Marry His Partner
text: Representative Barney Frank, left, one of the first openly gay members of Congress, will marry his partner of five years in a ceremony in Massachusetts, Mr. Frank’s spokesman said. Mr. Frank’s partner, Jim Ready, 42, is a photographer and handyman in Ogunquit, Me. Mr. Frank, 71, announced in November that he would retire at the end of this year after more than three decades in the House. Mr. Frank’s spokesman said the wedding date had not been determined. Same-sex marriage is legal in Massachusetts.

headline: In Britain, a Partial List of Those Who Declined to Be Called ‘Sir’
text: LONDON — Which is cooler: To accept a knighthood from the queen, or to turn one down?

headline: When the Police Say One Thing, the Facts Another
text: One evening in November 1990, at the end of a speech in a hotel on the East Side of Manhattan, a man stuck out his arm and squeezed off shots that killed a militant Israeli politician and rabbi named Meir Kahane. The assassin ran to Lexington Avenue and jumped in a cab, but was caught a few blocks away.

headline: With Trays of Tacos, Joining in Condemnation of a Mayor
text: In East Haven, Conn., the menu on Thursday, not surprisingly, was tacos, and perhaps crow, in an episode featuring both allegations of serious civil rights violations and goofy Twitter fodder.

headline: Fact Check: ‘Language of the Ghetto’
text: Newt Gingrich was asked if he had called Spanish “the language of the ghetto,” as a new ad from the Romney campaign suggests.

headline: Afghanistan: Suicide Bomber Kills 4
text: A suicide bomber exploded a car near a British reconstruction team traveling in a convoy through the center of Lashkar Gah in southern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing four Afghans, including a child, and wounding 31 others, the provincial governor’s office and the British government said. Three British citizens were hurt in the explosion, Britain’s Foreign Office said. It was unclear whether the convoy was the target of the attack. The reconstruction team is one of dozens across Afghanistan in which civilian and military personnel lead efforts to build roads and schools and to help local governments become more effective. Lashkar Gah was among the first cities where Afghan security forces assumed sole control last summer in the first stage of a transition from American security.

headline: Don’t Mind the Gap
text: Washington

headline: Mara Rides Whirlwind Clear Into Super Bowl
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Over the past 12 months, here are some things that have happened to the Giants co-owner John Mara:

headline: For Greece, the Outlook Is Still Grim
text: LONDON — Even as Greece tries to convince creditors that its debt-reduction efforts are on track, gloomy new International Monetary Fund forecasts about its long-term economy are threatening to derail talks meant to secure the nation’s next big installment of bailout funds.

headline: Mickelson in Unfamiliar Spot After First Round
text: SAN DIEGO — Watching Phil Mickelson’s first round at the Farmers Insurance Open was disorienting, like seeing the sun set in the East. Mickelson has 10 top-10 showings here, including three victories and two runner-up finishes, but he looked lost Thursday, posting a five-over 77 on the South Course.

headline: Fact Check: Profiting From the Housing Crisis
text: Seeking to exploit questions over Mitt Romney’s investments, Newt Gingrich attacked Mr. Romney on Thursday night for profiting from the housing woes of Florida residents.

headline: Soap Operas With a Social Message
text: Every Sunday evening, seven million Kenyans sit in front of their television sets to watch “Makutano Junction,” a soap opera set in a fictional village. In one episode, audiences watch as a woman, Mama Mboga, holds her crying infant. “I need some money to take Joni to hospital,” she tells her husband, Erasmus, after he wakes up and takes a swig from a bottle. “I think he has malaria.” Erasmus insists that his son is healthy, that she is overreacting and that he has no money to give her.

headline: New York City Tuition Higher and Rising
text: Charts showing the rising tuition at New York City private schools.

headline: Romney Stays on the Offense With Gingrich
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Mitt Romney, facing his greatest challenge of the campaign so far, relentlessly pressed Newt Gingrich on Thursday night in their final debate before the Florida primary, seeking to regain the offensive against an insurgent challenge that has shaken his claim to inevitability.

headline: Co-op Manager Accused of Theft in the Bowery
text: A property manager for a low-income co-op in the Bowery was charged on Thursday with stealing more than $260,000 from the building.

headline: Fair Is Fair
text: President Obama’s choice to emphasize fairness rather than equality in the State of the Union address makes good political sense. Although equality is the central concern of the Occupy Wall Street movement, focused as it is on income disparities, Americans are at least ambivalent toward equality as a primary value. They think emphasizing equality was O.K. in the context of the Civil War and segregation because inequality was institutionalized in those days and it is a good thing those days are over.

headline: Romney and Gingrich Clash on Immigration
text: The candidates begin the debate with a heated argument over immigration and attack ads.

headline: Energy Tax Breaks Proposed, Despite Waning Support for Subsidies
text: Assisted by technological innovation and years of subsidies, the cost of wind and solar power has fallen sharply — so much so that the two industries say that they can sometimes deliver cleaner electricity at prices competitive with power made from fossil fuels.

headline: With Rape Inquiry, District Attorney Again Finds Himself in a Tough Spot
text: Given the inherent potential for tension between police departments and prosecutors, any district attorney might be reluctant to investigate the son of a police commissioner.

headline: Strong Words Resound at Tribute to Paterno
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Penn State concluded its weeklong goodbye to the former football coach Joe Paterno with a memorial Thursday at a packed arena that featured remembrances from a player from each of the six decades in which he coached, videos of him with the team and an emotional closing eulogy from his son Jay.

headline: The Navy’s Stone Fleet
text: In November 1861, the whaling ship Leonidas sailed from New Bedford, Mass., for the last time. Five times before, the Leonidas had departed New Bedford Harbor bound for whaling voyages in the Pacific, Indian and Atlantic Oceans; each time, the ship returned home with a hold full of oil extracted from sperm whales. Whaling was one of America’s first global industries, and oil carried home in ships like the Leonidas lubricated machinery in booming factories and lit homes in the nation’s growing cities.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Big Victory on Internet Buoys Lobby
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The unlikely coalition of companies and consumer groups that last week helped quash antipiracy legislation on Capitol Hill is now weighing the future of what might be called lobbying 2.0. Can the Internet industry, along with legions of newly politicized Web users, be a new force in Washington? And if so, what else can they all agree upon?

headline: Winston Riley, Jamaican Music Producer, Dies at 68
text: Winston Riley, a record producer and singer whose diverse, influential work helped to popularize Jamaican music around the world, died on Jan. 19 in Kingston, Jamaica. He was 68.

headline: The Candidates on Housing
text: Mitt Romney brings up Newt Gingrich's connections with Freddie Mac.

headline: Obama and Fairness
text: In “Fair is Fair,” Stanley Fish writes today on our politics blog, Campaign Stops:

headline: A Touch During Recess, and Reaction Is Swift
text: It started as schoolyard roughhousing during recess, with one boy’s hand allegedly touching the upper thigh, or perhaps the groin, of another. There were no reported witnesses, and it remains unclear if anyone complained, but the principal immediately suspended the student, placing the incident on the boy’s record as a case of “sexual assault.” The children involved were first graders — the purported assailant just 6.

headline: Accused of Atrocities, Guatemala’s Ex-Dictator Chooses Silence
text: MEXICO CITY — Efraín Ríos Montt, Guatemala’s former military dictator, was ordered by a Guatemalan judge on Thursday to stand trial on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity leveled at him. He is accused of orchestrating the razing of Indian villages decades ago during the country’s long civil war.

headline: Trying to Escape a Path of Violence for the Sake of Her Daughters
text: Alyssa Marrero, 4, sat staring out a window as she waited with her mother for food vouchers they needed to buy milk, beans and bread.

headline: In Honduras, a Mess Made in the U.S.
text: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.

headline: Rudi van Dantzig, Provocative Dutch Choreographer, Dies at 78
text: Rudi van Dantzig, a provocative choreographer whose mix of idealism and social protest gave the Dutch National Ballet an international profile when he served as its artistic director until 1991, died on Jan. 19 at his home in Amsterdam. He was 78.

headline: Student Faces Town’s Wrath in Protest Against a Prayer
text: CRANSTON, R.I. — She is 16, the daughter of a firefighter and a nurse, a self-proclaimed nerd who loves Harry Potter and Facebook. But Jessica Ahlquist is also an outspoken atheist who has incensed this heavily Roman Catholic city with a successful lawsuit to get a prayer removed from the wall of her high school auditorium, where it has hung for 49 years.

headline: The Delusion of Equality in Triplicate
text: MIAMI

headline: Trade Tower Is Set to Add Prime Tenant, a Law Firm
text: Chadbourne & Parke, a 110-year-old law firm, is close to a deal to move to the 1,776-foot skyscraper under construction at ground zero, from its headquarters at Rockefeller Center.

headline: Senate Vote Approves Rise in Debt Limit
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Thursday to allow a further increase in the federal debt limit, permitting President Obama to borrow $1.2 trillion more to operate a government that spent about 55 percent more than it collected in revenue last year.

headline: Pandora’s Problem
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — So we’ve got this weird enclosure, this “navel” if you will, right in the middle of our grid. We’ve seen enclosures in grids before, like this one by Patrick Merrell (Across Lite, Solution), but now we’re told that the three letters that fit inside are (1) in alphabetical order and (2) don’t appear anywhere else in the grid.

headline: Artifice as Armor in a Duel With Death
text: Cynthia Nixon’s gaze has its own grammar. Playing a terminally ill English professor in the inescapably moving new revival of Margaret Edson’s “Wit,” the 1999 Pulitzer Prize winner for drama, Ms. Nixon seems to construct perfectly composed, illuminating and surprising thoughts with her sky-blue eyes — the kind of thoughts that if you saw them in print would make you stop and savor and reread.

headline: Tests on Pitcher Found Five Banned Substances
text: Since baseball introduced drug testing a decade ago, first in the minor leagues and then in the majors, a large majority of those who have tested positive for performance-enhancers and been suspended have not been familiar names.

headline: So Who’s a Lobbyist?
text: Under the federal lobbying law, Newt Gingrich can legitimately claim that he is not a lobbyist. That alone demonstrates how much the law needs to be changed.

headline: More in Mitt's Taxes
text: After criticizing Mitt Romney on his taxes, candidate Newt Gingrich offers a two-way truce.

headline: The Debate Heads to the Moon
text: The candidates debate Newt Gingrich's plan to spend on space.

headline: Executive at Oprah’s Cable Channel Departs Suddenly
text: Lisa Erspamer, a co-executive producer of “The Oprah Winfrey Show” who was sent to OWN to bring Ms. Winfrey’s personal touch to her cable channel, has unceremoniously exited the channel.

headline: Japan: Nuclear Contamination Cleanup Near Stricken Plant to Start in Spring
text: Japan said Thursday that it would begin a cleanup this spring of radioactive contamination near the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, with the goal of cutting radiation levels in half within two years. The Environment Ministry said the cleanup would cover about two-thirds of the 100-square-mile zone around the plant that was evacuated after last March’s accident. The ministry says radiation levels in these areas are low enough that the cleanup, along with the natural decay of radioactive materials, should make it possible for residents to return at an unspecified time after two years. However, the ministry said it had no plans to clean the remaining third of the evacuation zone, where it says radiation levels are too high to be brought to safe levels with current technology.

headline: School Improves With Help of U.S. Money It May Lose
text: The federal grant had ambitious purpose, few restrictions and a not-so-distant expiration date: three years. With almost $1 million to spend, Brian Rosenbloom, the principal at Chelsea Career and Technical Education High School in SoHo, once one of New York City’s worst schools, knew he had to be strategic.

headline: In Airport Run-In, Democrats See Help for Obama Among Hispanics
text: AURORA, Colo. — Democrats see the chance that President Obama’s heated exchange with Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona on the airport tarmac in Phoenix could help him with the Hispanic voters he came West to court this week.

headline: U.N. Sees an Unexpected Arrival: Bags of Drugs

headline: A Revival for Broadway Joe
text: Joe Namath was in the back of the auditorium, watching a documentary about himself. Ninety minutes of Joe Willie. It tickled him to watch, and he chuckled now and then as he sat beside his attentive older daughter, Jessica.

text: CAMBRIDGE, Md. — The on-again-off-again relationship between President Obama and House Democrats appears to be on again with the president’s turn toward a more populist, confrontational tone toward the Republican Party.

headline: An Outrage in East Haven
text: Hispanic residents and civil-rights advocates have raised alarms for years about the police in East Haven, Conn. Their claims gained chilling corroboration on Tuesday. The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a sergeant and three officers on charges of terrorizing the town’s Hispanic neighborhoods, stopping and detaining people, searching businesses without cause, beating people in handcuffs, smashing a man’s head into a wall.

headline: Gabby Giffords’s Farewell
text: House members were moved to tears on Wednesday when Representative Gabrielle Giffords handed in her resignation because, she said, she needed more time to heal from the grievous gunshot wound she suffered last year at the hands of a would-be assassin. The rarest of Congressional events — a display of genuinely bipartisan tributes — was the parting gift from her colleagues along with unanimous approval of Ms. Giffords’s bill to fight drug trafficking along the Mexican border.

headline: Life With Father, Who Also Runs the State of Israel
text: TEL AVIV — Noa Rothman bears an uncanny resemblance to her grandfather Yitzhak Rabin — so much so that when Rami Heuberger tried out for the prime minister’s role in Ms. Rothman’s television series, “The Prime Minister’s Children,” he had trouble looking at her.

headline: Deconstructing a Demagogue

headline: Number of Older Inmates Grows, Stressing Prisons
text: The number of Americans in prison older than 55 is growing at a faster rate than the group’s share of the population at large, and many prisons are unprepared to provide them with health care, which can cost as much as nine times more than for younger inmates, Human Rights Watch said in a report released Friday.

text: PARIS — Raised, if respectful voices at a private dinner party in Paris on Thursday. Among the guests — two Syrians, both anti-regime but with diametrically opposite analyses of what is going on in their home country.

headline: Seeking Out the Funny, Sketchfest Mines the Web

headline: Nursing Home Investigation Finds Errors by Druggists
text: A woman with a medical history of seizures was prescribed the antipsychotic drug Seroquel, despite research showing that elderly people who take antipsychotic drugs are more likely to experience seizures. She was also given the antidepressant Trazodone, which has been linked to an increase in seizures among older patients. And then, according to a recent investigation by the California Department of Public Health, the woman was given a second antipsychotic drug, Risperdal. The combination of the two antipsychotic medications, the investigators said, could cause “life-threatening arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats).”

headline: House Speaker Spreads Blame for State’s Mess

headline: Silencing Cheers, to Save Troubled School District

headline: Finnish Flight Attendants Go Bollywood for India’s Republic Day
text: The passengers had all boarded Finnair Flight AY201 from Helsinki to New Delhi on Jan. 17, when two dozen beaming flight attendants dressed in Indian attire came dancing through the aisles to “Deewangi Deewangi” from the Bollywood mega-blockbuster “Om Shanti Om.”The well-rehearsed and choreographed routine was in commemoration of India’s 63rd Republic Day, said Helena Kaartinen, the flight attendant who came up with the idea. “It was a good way to show respect,” she said, and to show Finnair’s Indian passengers “that we do know some things about them.”

headline: All-Sports Radio Matures Beyond Screamers
text: Sports talk radio was a phenomenon fairly new to Chicago the first time I heard it here. I was visiting from California, taking my daughter to college on a trip that included a two-hour drive from Chicago. I came upon WSCR — “the Score” — while punching the buttons in a rental car and heard a boisterous guy later identified as Mike North lambasting the hopeless Bears in a loud, indignant voice that was both unmistakably “Chicawgo” and scalded-cat screechy.

headline: With This Library System, Government Isn’t All Bad

Another underwhelming debate performance like the ones he delivered in South Carolina would open the door for a Newt Gingrich victory in the Florida primary. Losing Florida could begin the type of downward spiral for Romney that would lead to even less pleasant consequences.

headline: Wilco Goes Animated With Popeye
text: So it turns out that Jeff Tweedy, the frontman of the Chicago alternative-rock band Wilco, has a sense of humor after all. The group has just released its first video in more than 10 years, and the format is that of an old-fashioned cartoon, with Popeye, Olive Oyl, Bluto, Wimpy and Swee’Pea as the band’s fans and foils.

headline: Sating the Fiery Dragon, or That Fired-Up Pigskin Fan
text: I HAD the thought that chicken wings would be nice to make in honor of the Chinese New Year, so I pitched the idea to my editor. If wings are too banal or plebeian, it could always be thighs, I offered. The editor replied: wings absolutely, everyone loves wings! But, he said, why not something for the Super Bowl? Perhaps, I ventured, these wings could be multipurpose.

headline: Dragon Wings
text: I had fun playing with chicken wings for this week’s City Kitchen column. A lot of chicken wings. I set out to make Chinese-style wings, but the path from concept to realized dish can often be littered with somewhat less than stellar results. Trying to create a recipe sometimes takes several tries. Enlisting the (tasting) help of a few opinionated friends whose palates I trust, I experimented with a few versions until the balance of sweet and spicy rang true, with the right amount of five-spice, ginger and garlic.

headline: Words Gingrich Governed By
text: During his years in Congress, Newt Gingrich emerged as one of Washington’s most aggressive practitioners of slash-and-burn politics. He believed, and preached, that harsh language could win elections.

headline: Growth Accelerates, but U.S. Has Lots of Ground to Make Up
text: The American economy picked up a little steam last quarter, growing at its fastest pace in a year and a half. Whether it can sustain that momentum is critical to millions of Americans out of work — and perhaps President Obama’s re-election chances.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Questions for Drudge Report, and When Bowie Said No
text: The 19th Republican presidential debate represented a role reversal, as Newt Gingrich tried to dial down the conflict on stage and a well-prepared Mitt Romney went at Mr. Gingrich, at one point saying, “Wouldn’t it be nice if people didn’t make accusations somewhere else that they weren’t willing to defend here?” Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny noted that while Mr. Gingrich has usually won over debate audiences “with an assortment of one-liners aimed at the establishment and, frequently, the news media,” those techniques didn’t seem to have the same effect.

headline: Friday Reading: Teaching the Volt to Charge Smarter and Cleaner
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Death of a Poser
text: FAYETTEVILLE, North Carolina — The War on Terror hasn’t produced many clear signs of progress in the last decade. But here’s an unequivocal one: with each year, we’ve heard a little less about Jonathan “Jack” Idema, the self-styled mercenary who surfaced in Afghanistan in late 2001, fed credulous journalists lies about his work with the Northern Alliance, and later was convicted by an Afghan court of running his own private torture chamber in a Kabul cellar. (He claimed he was working for the U.S. government to hunt terrorists, but in fact he seems to have been kidnapping his “suspects” almost randomly off the street, and choosing them partly by beard length.) Hamid Karzai pardoned him in 2007 as part of a general amnesty.After his time in Afghanistan, he sank deeper and deeper into obscurity. Last weekend he died from AIDS complications in Mexico at the age of 55.

headline: A Question of Honor
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — In recent years, Pakistanis have been increasingly consumed by the concept of ghairat, or honor. An urge to defend the nation’s ghairat — a blend of intense patriotism and heightened religiosity — underpins the country’s soaring anti-Americanism and growing calls for the Islamization of society. It also drives the sanctimonious diatribes of politicians and talk show hosts who dominate Pakistan’s public sphere.

headline: Gingrich Campaign Seeks Reinforcement With Florida Ad Buy
text: TAMPA, Fla. — As his momentum shows signs of slowing, Newt Gingrich has poured about $1 million into advertising across Florida in recent days.

headline: Leading Off: The Circus Starts Early in Indianapolis

No, it’s the hometown Colts rushing to the top of the bizarre-o-meter, with owner Jim Irsay deciding to wage a public hissing war with Peyton Manning.

headline: Michael Jackson Honored at Grauman’s Chinese Theater
text: Hollywood celebrities have been leaving their handprints and footprints in wet cement in front of Grauman’s Chinese Theater in Los Angeles for decades. On Thursday at dawn Michael Jackson’s children stamped a pair of the late singer’s shoes and one of his sequined gloves into a wet slab on Hollywood Boulevard to honor him, according to Agence France-Presse.

headline: Draghi Points to Signs of Stress in Financial System
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said Friday that action by the central bank had averted a severe credit crunch, but he warned of a “short-term contraction” in the euro zone as governments cut spending and try to get debt under control.

headline: A Trio of Siblings With a Classical Sound
text: A basement bar and pool hall where a bright neon sign touts “$1 Massage” is the last place you’d expect to find a home-schooled classical string ensemble. But the JoSunJari String Trio is used to popping up in unexpected places – like parks and beaches – where their music is like a random gift bestowed upon you by strangers.

headline: Face Time | Gretchen Mol
text: As Gretchen Mol gets ready to attend the S.A.G. Awards in Los Angeles this weekend (she plays Gillian, a beautiful showgirl in “Boardwalk Empire,” which has been nominated for two awards), she reveals what she does when not shooting the show, as well as some of her nominations for Best Supporting Beauty Products.

headline: More Fines in Greenlight Insider Case in Britain
text: LONDON – Britain’s financial regulator said Friday that it had fined a former Greenlight Capital compliance officer and a JPMorgan Cazenove trader in connection with Greenlight’s sale of shares in a British pub operator more than two years ago.

headline: How to Manage U.S. Forests, Version 3.1
text: In the high-tech world, new versions of programs are released to fix new bugs. In the federal regulatory world, new versions of management blueprints are released to address legal problems. Each is generally judged by a simple metric: did the fixes work, or will they have to be redone?

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Specialty Food: Hot trends from last week’s Winter Fancy Food Show in San Francisco: heritage grain products (quinoa, amaranth, chia) proliferate in snacks and pastas; pickling of beets, carrots, peas, okra and fruits is increasing; oats and almonds are coming to juice drinks; coconut is in everything, and the gluten-free category is expanding rapidly (gluten-free granola, anyone?). — Glenn Collins

headline: The Art of the Doodle
text: English artist David Shrigley is a master of the incompetent line.

headline: The Scare
text: One day last summer I got an e-mail from one of my best friends, updating me on the last few months of his life: work developments; a vacation recap; a reply to a barbecue invitation; and “one other thing” that he would tell me about when we met. We had dinner a few weeks later, and at the end of our second beers, he casually said, “I’m H.I.V.-positive.”

headline: Judith Clark’s Radical Transformation
text: If Judy Clark is not a fit candidate for clemency, it is hard to imagine what argument could be made for giving clemency to anyone. The pain and anger of the Rockland families is completely understandable, but should the desire for endless retribution prevail over every other consideration? I hope that Governor Cuomo will choose the just and courageous course and release her.

headline: Preschool of Hard Knocks
text: My daughter loves her preschool. So do my wife and I: It’s affordable, it’s on our way to work and it teaches Mandarin, her second language. Recently, the school’s co-owner and director was indicted for stealing a ton of money meant to feed low-income children at her other business. I wouldn’t be shocked if the charges stick. How do my ethical obligations not to support a (supposed) crook square with my daughter’s love of the school and its teachers, especially given the lack of equivalent options? NAME WITHHELD, BROOKLYN

headline: The Dilemma of Being a Cyborg
text: This kind of thing happens all the time now, but three or four years ago it still seemed momentous and thrilling: a sudden argument at a dinner party (something about Tom Selleck and Burt Reynolds and iconic mustaches of the ’70s) was quickly put to rest when half the people present picked up their phones and started to Google. Observing this, a friend of mine made what struck me as a very clever remark about our “stegosaurus brains.” It didn’t occur to me that only a dinosaur would delight in a dinosaur analogy.

headline: Romney Goes on Offensive in Florida, Bolstered by Debate Performance
text: MIAMI — Mitt Romney might have felt on Friday that he had finally gotten his groove back.

headline: Reconsidering the Genius of Gertrude Stein
text: Approaching Gertrude Stein’s writing critically is tricky. Because she strove to reshape literary conventions — syntax, language usage, narrative order and the sense of making sense — any comment on her choices may already be rebuffed in her poetics and practice. Stein is a trickster. This may be why, as I read “Ida” and “Stanzas in Meditation,” both reissued in corrected, authoritative editions from Yale University Press, I remembered a Jonathan Richman lyric I’ll paraphrase as “Pablo Picasso never got called a jackass.”

headline: ‘The Anointed’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Something Big
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Rise of the Right
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Vigor of Middle Age
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paperback Row
text: INDIA CALLING: An Intimate Portrait of a Nation’s Remaking,  by Anand Giridharadas (St. Martin’s Griffin, $14.99.) Through the prism of his émigré family history, Giridharadas, a columnist for The International Herald Tribune, captures fundamental changes in the very idea of what it is to be Indian. Moving among entrepreneurs, radicals and religious seekers, he notes that the greatest upheaval is “in the mind, in how people conceived of their possibilities.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: BEN JONSON: A Life,  by Ian Donaldson (Oxford University, $39.95.) In his time, Jonson was as central to the development of British theater as Shakespeare was, if not more, Donaldson argues in this deeply researched but happily readable biography.

headline: At Sundance, One Star Bakes; Another Keeps the Party Going
text: PARK CITY, Utah – Sundance is drawing to a close just as the Bagger is emerging from our Academy foxhole, where (incoming!) we have been dodging snubs while hoping to see Michael Fassbender in a pirate hat.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Jeanette Winterson discusses the legacy of Henry Miller’s “Tropic of Cancer”; Charles McGrath on the deeply personal poetry of publisher Jonathan Galassi; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Fourth-Largest City in America in Mourning
text: And now, a moment of televised silence (if you turn the volume down) to mark the passing of Robert Hegyes, former portrayer of the small screen’s reigning 26-year-old Puerto Rican Jewish high school student and sideways role model.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II in Public and Private
text: As a British expat trying to keep in touch with the old sod, I’ve acquired the slightly eccentric habit of buying coffee mugs recording key moments in the public life of our royal family. Alas, those celebrating the weddings of Prince Charles and Prince Andrew broke soon after their marriages fell apart. Not so the mug I bought for Queen Elizabeth’s Golden Jubilee in 2002. In fine bone china, no less than in person, she just keeps on going.

headline: How the Jews Handled Prohibition
text: Even in New York Times headlines, they were known as “Izzy and Moe.” Their very presence could make bartenders faint. They possessed a keen sense of smell and a theatrical flair that included disguises as fruit peddlers and football players. Stumpy Izzy, who had rejected a career as a rabbi, and his partner were credited with 4,392 arrests in five years, including one in a Manhattan meatpacking district club where Izzy posed as a turkey salesman and found bottles of booze concealed in a huge stuffed bear.

headline: Islam and the West Through the Eyes of Two Women
text: Very few of the heroes and villains made famous in the wars of the past decade are women. Of the scant exceptions, two of the most fascinating are the subjects of Deborah Scroggins’s thoughtful double biography, “Wanted Women.”

headline: The Influence of the Inquisition
text: In the moral atlas of Cullen Murphy, the road to Abu Ghraib, Guantánamo Bay and the secret “black sites” of the war on terror begins in Montségur, a fortress in the foothills of the Pyrenees. There, in 1244, a French army assembled at the behest of the Roman Catholic Church besieged several hundred Cathars. Their sect’s heresy was dualism, a belief in both a beneficent God and an equivalent evil deity. Enticed into surrendering by the promise that their followers would be spared, the Cathars were burned alive on a pyre.

headline: The Dangers of Sharing
text: It may surprise anyone under 16, but even before the advent of social networking we faced threats to our privacy. A hospital accidentally releasing patient records or a shady marketing firm engaging in Stasi-like data collection — such violations were substantial enough and disturbing enough to make the evening news. Today, however, the “death of privacy” is more like death by a thousand cuts: information leaks out slowly and invisibly, and so routinely that we’re hardly shocked when it does. Internet companies, which use the word “sharing” almost as a euphemism for “oops,” like to pretend these lapses are normal, even natural. If Mark Zuckerberg’s private photos are up for grabs (as when a recent glitch exposed his Facebook account), what can the rest of us expect?

headline: Edmund White’s Body Language
text: Some novels plumb psyches, others draw social outlines and still others leave character pretty much out of it in favor of cerebral concepts or intricate plotlines. Over the course of his long career, Edmund White has written all of the above. But with his latest, “Jack Holmes and His Friend,” White delivers something rare: a novel that above all else leaves its readers intimately familiar with its characters’ bodies.

headline: Up Front
text: Sara Wheeler is no stranger to the rigors — and the literature — of polar exploration. The author of “The Magnetic North: Notes From the Arctic Circle” and “Terra Incognita: Travels in Antarctica,” she has also written a biography of Apsley Cherry-Garrard, whose classic account of the doomed Robert Falcon Scott expedition, “The Worst Journey in the World,” she first read “in a lonely tent on the West Antarctic ice sheet.” In a recent e-mail, Wheeler recalled that her travels have also taken her to Spitsbergen, Norway, the remote site from which S. A. Andrée began his aeronautical assault on the North Pole — yet another frigid failure and the subject of Alec Wilkinson’s “Ice Balloon,” which she reviews this week.

headline: Falling Short of the North Pole
text: The history of 19th-century Arctic exploration is gruesome. Ice floes throttle creaky ships, men vanish into the white silence, and the North Pole remains elusive. At that time, nobody even knew if that sacred spot lay on land or sea. Then a Swedish aeronaut had a new idea. Approaches by sledge and ship had failed, so why not fly to the pole?

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: BERLIN STORIES  By Robert Walser.  New York Review Books; paper, $14.

headline: The Reign of Venice
text: Medieval travelers were overwhelmed by Venice’s affluence — the sacks of spices! the bales of brocades! — and driven to distraction by its seeming paradoxes. The city was surrounded by sand and mud, yet its markets dazzled with variety. Since there was no land to speak of, it had no feudal system, yet its councils handed down orders like holy writ. Its people reveled in their republican freedom, yet bowed undemurringly to the collective good. Even the physical city defied logic: a wooden settlement perched on piles in a swampy lagoon had turned into the densest urban area in Europe, its brick bell towers jostling for airspace, its stone palaces squatting on reclaimed land.

headline: Our Favorite Weapon
text: You rarely pull a gun to start a conversation, but when I recently told an in-law that I was writing about Glock pistols, he improvised a research project. Reaching beneath his jacket, he quickly unholstered, unloaded and handed me his Glock 9 millimeter — this was in Kentucky, land of permissive ­concealed-carry laws. “I always carry this, and I always will,” he said before giving me a primer that could have been used in a promotional video for both the pistol and “Glock: The Rise of America’s Gun,” Paul M. Barrett’s engaging if uneven history of the most famous handgun in contemporary America.

headline: Chris Christie, Revisionist Historian
text: Some readers thought I was a little hard on Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey this week. On Wednesday I wrote about his decision to veto any law guaranteeing marriage rights to all state residents. He said he thought the issue should be left up to voters. And I said that civil rights don’t belong on a ballot. Besides, referendums are a bad way to govern a state. Check out California sometime.

headline: Memories of South Africa During and After Apartheid
text: Zakes MDA and J. M. Coetzee, the two most acclaimed South African novelists of the past 20 years, could be writing about different countries — and, in a way, they are. Coetzee excels at sparsely populated fictions of gnawing interiority. His socially uneasy and anguished solitaries, often academics like himself, wrestle with psychological dilemmas and metaphysical maladies. In contrast, Mda’s greatest gift is his Dickensian social range, his ability to generate characters from diverse backgrounds, colluding and colliding across the barriers erected to divide them. Where Coetzee is drawn to existential hinterlands, Mda takes us deep into his country’s literal interior, those rural regions that, in most South African writing, are pushed to the margins.

headline: The Will to Believe
text: Stella Morrison is an elegant woman: an accomplished hostess for her financier-turned-member-of-Parliament husband, a devoted but not doting mother, tastefully devout in her religious beliefs. She’s also beguiling to the opposite sex, one of whom regards her charm as “will-o’-the-wisp and indefinable, all strands and tendrils and impossible to pin down.” Yet Stella is unhappy, trapped in a loveless marriage, pining for her children, all of whom have left home. Getting ready for yet another dinner party, she thinks of herself as “a priestess in an Attic temple preparing for sacrifice.” This unsettling combination of magnificence and pathos suffuses Fran­cesca Kay’s second novel, “The Translation of the Bones.” (Her first, “An Equal Stillness,” won Britain’s Orange Award for New Writers.)

headline: Connecting the Lowly and Mighty in New York
text: Any beginning writer could find both instruction and inspiration in Elliot Perlman’s new novel, “The Street Sweeper.” If it were tricked out with commentary in the margins — in fact, now that I’ve finished marking it up, anyone’s welcome to take my copy — it could serve as a textbook on how not to write fiction. At the same time, it gives the lie to those killjoy teachers who tell you that no reputable publisher will touch your work if you don’t learn your craft. This 600-plus-page epic turns out to have only a novella’s worth of story and substance: the rest is repetition, over and over, of basic information about who the characters are, where they are and what’s going on, long expository and hortatory speeches that no real person would ever deliver and the padded, ping-ponging dialogue beloved of amateur writers. “ ‘And your family?’ ‘My family?’ ” “ ‘I’ve always felt kind of . . . fraudulent.’ ‘Fraudulent?’ ”

headline: Chinese Police Fire on Tibetan Protesters Again
text: HONG KONG — The police in the western Chinese province of Sichuan fired on Tibetan protesters for the third time this week, killing at least one and injuring several, overseas Tibetan activist groups said on Friday.

headline: Cultural Conflicts, Playing Out on the Football Field
text: After his team was routed by the New England Patriots this month, driving the Denver Broncos out of the N.F.L. playoffs, Tim Tebow jogged off the field. Camera crews and photographers surrounded him, waiting for Mr. Tebow, the quarterback, to drop to one knee and bow his head in prayer, his famous and controversial signature gesture.

headline: Final Reckonings, a Tuneful Fedora and Forgiveness
text: LEONARD COHEN generally takes his time. He sings, speaks, writes and records at his own measured pace. Concerts on his recent world tour have stretched to three hours. His new album, “Old Ideas,” is his first studio album since “Dear Heather” in 2004.

headline: Work Wear | Brook Klausing
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Market for Films Signals Good, Not Great, Year for Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah — “The buzz means nothing,” said Robert Redford as his Sundance Film Festival opened in this luxury ski town last week. “Wait until it’s over, and see what sticks.”

headline: Wheelies: The $2 Billion Addition Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: In Michigan, Obama Calls for Overhaul of Financial Aid
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — President Obama called on Congress to approve a financial-aid overhaul that for the first time would tie federal financing to colleges and universities to the success of these institutions in improving affordability and value for students.

headline: Winter Jam Canceled Due to Lack of Winter
text: Sorry, kids: The parks department has officially canceled winter.

headline: Pushed to Limit, Djokovic Defeats Murray to Set Up a Familiar Final
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — There were big hints of a power shift at this Australian Open. There were grueling, long-form semifinals bristling with uncertainty. But when Friday night had turned into Saturday morning in Melbourne and Novak Djokovic lay spread-eagled on his back with a fulfilled look on his stubbled face, the status quo had been preserved.

headline: Top Central Banker Urges No Delay to Basel III
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — A top central banker on Friday damped the hopes of some in the banking industry that they might get more time to comply with new regulations.

headline: ‘Wolf-gang! Wolf-gang!': Mozart Opera at Cowboys Stadium
text: It will be Sarastro’s host versus the Queen of the Night and her minions at Cowboys Stadium. The stadium, the home of the Dallas Cowboys, will open its gates for a free simulcast of Mozart’s “Magic Flute” on April 28, the Dallas Opera and the football team said on Thursday. In a statement, the Cowboys’ executive vice president for brand management, Charlotte Anderson, called it a “distinctive event.” Dallas Opera’s general director, Keith Cerny, called it a “game-changing” collaboration. The production comes from the Lyric Opera of Chicago. Officials said the opera would be shown on the “world’s largest high-definition video board structure,” which consists of four screens suspended over the field. The largest, according to the statement is 72 feet tall and 160 feet wide. There was no mention of cheerleaders or whether missed notes would be subject to instant-replay review.

headline: For Super Bowl, JoeDough and No. 7 Sub Go the Extra Yard
text: Eli Manning stands 6-foot-4. But for that game-time party, a hero that measures in at a mere six feet will probably do.

headline: The U.S. Military Cuts for the Cloud
text: Anyone who watches what is going on in tech should not be surprised by the turmoil at the Pentagon.

headline: Opera Ready, Even Offstage
text: The soprano Danielle de Niese, 32, is featured in “The Enchanted Island,” with Plácido Domingo, at the Metropolitan Opera. Born in Melbourne, Australia, and raised in Los Angeles, the singer now lives in East Sussex, England. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: Defense Budget Limits Reach of a Campaign Promise for the Navy
text: WASHINGTON — One of the most specific campaign promises Mitt Romney has made in the realm of defense policy is to increase the Navy’s shipbuilding program to 15 vessels each year from 9 or 10, enough to significantly increase the size of a fleet that has been straining to meet its global missions.

headline: How Readers Cut the Pentagon Budget
text: More than 12,000 readers completed The New York Times’s interactive calculator on the Pentagon budget. The results are not scientific, of course. But among those readers who filled out the calculator, a few patterns emerged:

headline: BNP Paribas Said to Be Selling $11 Billion of Loans
text: LONDON — The French bank BNP Paribas is looking to sell up to $11 billion of loans to oil and gas companies in an effort to reduce its loan book in the United States, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Reaping a Bonus From Cap-and-Trade
text: Criticism of cap-and-trade programs often centers on the costs they impose on electric power companies and their consumers. But as I report in Friday’s Times, New York and other Northeastern and mid-Atlantic states that are trying out such a system have found that those costs can be offset by energy efficiency measures paid for by the cap-and-trade program itself.

headline: City Limits Free Tutoring to the Poorest Students
text: An increase in the number of students who qualify for free tutoring this year has led New York City to narrow its eligibility requirements.

headline: Popular Criticism Cracks China’s Wall of Denial About Pollution
text: BEIJING — Weary of waiting for the authorities to alert residents to the city’s most pernicious air pollutant, citizen activists last May took matters here into their own hands: they bought their own $4,000 air-quality monitor and started posting its daily readings on the Internet.
