headline: ‘War Horse’ Film Turns Book Into Best Seller in Britain
text: Michael Morpurgo’s novel “War Horse” was published in 1982. Over the next 25 years, about 50,000 copies were sold. “It simply was not a book that anyone really knew about or cared about,” the author once noted in an interview. But since the release of Steven Spielberg’s Oscar-nominated film version in Britain two weeks ago, the book has sold more than 60,000 copies there, BBC News reported.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Small, interactive macaron-making classes will start on Saturday at Mille-Feuille Bakery, 552 LaGuardia Place (Bleecker Street), in Greenwich Village. The classes begin at 2 p.m., run for about four hours and cost $190 a person, with discounts for larger groups of up to six at $115 a person. Register online.

headline: Another View: Private Equity Creates Value
text: Bronwyn Bailey, Ph.D., is the vice president of research at the Private Equity Growth Capital Council.

headline: The Last Days of Newt
text: I had intended to write a longer post explaining why, the results in South Carolina notwithstanding, Newt Gingrich still cannot win the Republican nomination. But after the last few days of polling and then last night’s debate, it looks like that explanation would be superfluous.

headline: The Quiet Driver of Economic Growth: Exports
text: The estimates of the nation’s economic performance last year, released Friday, highlight a striking trend: Exports have never been more important.

headline: Davos Potpourri, Day 3: Masters of Creation
text: Every year, the world’s elites flock to the World Economic Forum to either solve the world’s economic problems, drink flights of 100-point Parker wines or both, simultaneously.

headline: Some State of the Union Viewers Tuned Out Fast
text: President Obama’s State of the Union address on Tuesday underwhelmed by one significant measure: with 37.8 million television viewers, it was the least watched of the three he has delivered since 2010.

headline: 10 Winter Getaways to Suit Every Age
text: SUDDENLY it’s the end of January and you realize the children will be off for Presidents’ Day next month — an ideal opportunity to squeeze in a short family vacation.

headline: Syrian Rebels Make Inroads With Help of Armed Fighters
text: SAQBA, Syria — If the scene here on Friday was anything to judge by, the armed opposition to the Syrian government was making inroads and had won control of this town at the doorstep of the capital, Damascus, and perhaps of several other neighborhoods, signaling an escalation of violence in this beleaguered country.

headline: Lost in Jerusalem
text: To the Editor: I read Travel to learn about appealing destinations and useful travel tips. I am completely uninterested in the psychological baggage and identity conflicts of Matt Gross (“Lost in Jerusalem,” Jan. 15). Furthermore, I found it offensive that he would rather visit any place on earth than Israel, because to him “Israel has always felt less like a country than a politically iffy burden.” I would expect a Travel article on Israel to report on experiences in the country unadulterated by biased personal opinion. I dare you to show me an article on any other country where your correspondent stated such an antagonism to, or disrespect for, the place he was visiting.

headline: Samurai Shopper | The Year of the Dragon
text: The Samurai Shopper hails from a tribe whose holidays are based on the moon’s orbit around the earth. This tribe gravitates toward other lunar-leaning people, especially when solar-centric Gregorians start putting fir trees in their living rooms in mid-December. So, Kung Hei Fat Choy! Happy 4,710, Year of the Black Water Dragon, to my firecracker-wielding kin who’ve provided such fulsome sustenance during our lunar year, 5,772. Eat, drink and ink yourself a dragon tattoo — unless you have Biblical issues or faint at the sight of needles.

headline: N.H.L. All-Star Game Rosters
text: The N.H.L. All-Star Game is 4 p.m. Sunday at Scotiabank Place, the home of the Ottawa Senators. The teams were selected via a draft Thursday night. Zdeno Chara of the Bruins and Daniel Alfredsson on the Senators were selected captains, with the Maple Leafs’ Joffrey Lupul serving as Chara’s assistant and the Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist serving as Alfredsson’s. (Players are listed in the order they were drafted, with the six rookies assigned to each team at the bottom.)

headline: Agency Upgrades Investigation of 387,000 Liberty S.U.V.’s for Inadvertent Air-Bag Deployments
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified its investigation into unwarranted air-bag deployments on nearly 387,000 Jeep Liberty S.U.V.’s from the 2002-3 model years.

headline: Q&A With Ross Halfin, Celebrity Photographer
text: ROSS HALFIN has traveled the world photographing rock stars like Jimmy Page and Mötley Crüe against backdrops as varied as Perth, Australia, and the South Dakota Badlands. Along the way he learned a few things about the best lens to travel with and where to find a stunning landscape. For a striking sunset, he said the window of an airplane as it takes off from the Los Angeles International Airport is the place to be. “You see the coast of California all in shadow and this amazing golden light. That’s Los Angeles at its best.”

headline: In Potsdam, Germany, a Time to Celebrate
text: IN the mid-1740s, Frederick the Great, king of Prussia, decided he needed a break from his bustling Berlin castle. Seventeen miles away in Potsdam, he built a one-story rococo castle atop a slope, eventually adding more than 700 acres of manicured parks and buildings to a place he would name Sanssouci, French for “carefree.”

headline: Admiral’s Row Site Is Transferred to the City
text: Admiral’s Row finally belongs to the city.

headline: A Bohemian Pocket in London’s East End
text: Touring the neighborhood around Olympic Park.

headline: An Olympic Preview in London’s East End
text: EVEN on uncharacteristically sunny days, it’s a lonely walk from the closest tube stop to London’s forthcoming 500-acre Olympic Park. But after reaching the 80,000-seat Olympic Stadium — skeleton in place and awaiting its exterior sheeting — I found hundreds of other construction-site rubberneckers clogging the sidewalk.

headline: Making ‘The Descendants’ Funny — and De-Funnying It, Too
text: If you were taken with the wry tone and occasionally absurd laugh lines of “The Descendants,” you can tip your hat to the co-writers, Nat Faxon and Jim Rash. The pair are comedians and performers: Mr. Rash plays Dean Pelton on the (we hope not canceled) NBC sitcom “Community,” and Mr. Faxon has appeared in “Bad Teacher” and “Zookeeper.” They met at the Groundlings, the storied Los Angeles comedy troupe, around 2000 and became writing partners, first producing a TV pilot based on Mr. Rash’s experiences as an adoptee (it was quickly canceled). “The Descendants,” based on Kaui Hart Hemmings’s novel of the same name, is their first produced screenplay, and it earned them an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay.

headline: Restaurant Review: Le Grand Pan, in Paris
text: It can take a bit of effort to get to Le Grand Pan, especially if you’re a Métro gal like me. You take the No. 12 line deep into the most boring part of the 15th Arrondissement, then walk for a good 10 to 15 minutes. The first time I took my husband, he asked, “Are you sure you know where we’re going?”

headline: Giants, Peyton Manning, Tom Coughlin: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers questions from readers.

headline: Pack and Go Lunch Recipes
text: Many people who have chimed in on the Recipes for Health page on Facebook have requested recipes for lunches they can take to work and eat at a desk, writes Martha Rose Shulman. Here she offers a week’s worth of light and simple ideas for dishes that travel well.

headline: Off Tanzania, Serene Mafia Island
text: WHEN seen on arrival by air, Mafia Island doesn’t appear to be much more than a crescent-shaped splash of green off the eastern coast of Africa. Slightly smaller than New York City, the verdant island, 20 miles from mainland Tanzania, is densely covered in coconut trees, with nothing but green flora visible in the interior and just a few intermittent stretches of white sand breaking up the coast.

headline: Off the Charts: Much of World Sees Need for More Regulation
text: Americans are more likely than people in any other country to believe that their government overregulates business, according to a survey of public attitudes in 25 countries around the world, conducted by the public relations firm Edelman. The question asked in October and November of last year was, “When it comes to government regulation of business, do you think that your government regulates business too much, not enough or the right amount?” The charts show the percentage of the public in each country who think their government gets it right, and then show the proportion of the remainder who believe there is too much or too little regulation.

headline: ‘A Wrinkle in Time’ and Its Sci-Fi Heroine
text: Bookish girls tend to mark phases of their lives by periods of intense literary character identification. Schoolgirls of the ’70s had their Deenie and Sally J. Freedman and Margaret moments, muddling through adolescence in the guise of one Judy Blume heroine or another. And for almost a century and a half, girls have fluctuated between seasons of Amy and Meg and Jo March, imagining themselves alternately with blond corkscrew curls, eldest sister wisdom or writerly ambitions.

headline: Inside the List
text: UNCLE ORSON: Science-fiction fans know Orson Scott Card best for his 1985 novel “Ender’s Game,” a cult classic about a boy training for space combat, and for the series of related novels (and comic books) that have followed in its wake. That includes “Shadows in Flight,” the latest entry in the Enderverse, which hits the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 8.

headline: ‘Big Bang Theory’ Is Now Bigger Than ‘American Idol’
text: Is “The Big Bang Theory” now more popular than “American Idol?”

headline: Tips for Putting a Price on Your Work
text: WHEN I first started as a freelance writer, I was eager to sell myself — but not eager to have to discuss money. So I more or less took whatever was offered.

headline: Sorry to Disappoint, but I Ate Well in Berlin
text: BAD reputations outlive the circumstances that gave rise to them. My recent meals in Berlin were a reminder of that.

headline: When Safe Bonds Don’t Yield Enough to Retire On
text: PLAYING safe with your investments doesn’t pay these days.

headline: On Our Radar: 6 More Coal Plants to Close
text: FirstEnergy says it will retire six older coal-fired power plants in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Maryland by Sept. 1 because of tighter federal rules on emissions. [The Akron Beacon Journal]

headline: How the Public Sees Business Rules
text: AMERICANS are split almost down the middle on the issue of whether there is too much regulation of business or too little. Residents of most other countries are more likely to think more regulation is needed.

headline: Changes in Kabul Classrooms
text: Eleven years ago, if you walked into a classroom in Kabul, this is what you might have seen: all boys; Korans resting on every desk; men leading prayers and study; only religious subjects being taught at every school and university in the country; students wearing uniforms of payraan tumbaan (long shirts over baggy pants) and turbans; empty chairs pushed to the back of the classrooms where girls once sat.

headline: Extreme Theater: Wake-Up Calls From the 1600s
text: THE 17th-century playwright John Ford never met a character he didn’t want to kill: gruesomely, ingeniously, poignantly. He liked them stabbed, starved, poisoned, burnt, bled and assaulted by roving packs of bandits. His two best plays — both having forthcoming New York revivals — boast body counts nearly as long as the cast lists.

headline: What Did You Buy at Bleecker Bob’s?
text: One of the more primitive features, historians and old people will recall, of the era before recorded music could be summoned on command from a tap like water or electricity, was this: not only was music physically engraved onto physical objects (made of plastic, though it might as well have been stone or walrus tusk), but these physical objects could be acquired only from specific physical locations — yard sales, mail-order houses or, more usually, those boxy fluorescent-lit places smelling of shrink-wrap and cardboard dust known as record stores.

headline: Out There | Encore Performances
text: Just about halfway through its marathon, six-month broad-based excavation of Southern California’s formative postwar art scene, Pacific Standard Time is now neck deep in its 11-day Performance and Public Art Festival. Though the menu includes plenty of new commissions, many events are re-creations of ephemeral works from the 1960s and ’70s, and some of these have been among the most evocative moments of the whole shebang.

headline: Pass the STOCK Act: It’s Beyond a No-Brainer
text: It looks like the STOCK Act, which would bar members of Congress and their staffs from insider trading, will actually come to the floor next week.

headline: Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain: Theo Walcott 2.0?
text: When Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain arrived at Arsenal in the summer, the comparisons were irresistible.

headline: Diverging Stories of a Rhodes Candidacy
text: It may have been the sharpest day of extremes in the young life of Patrick J. Witt, star student and athlete at Yale University.

headline: TimesCast | January 27, 2012
text: Syrian violence spreads to the Damascus suburbs | The Gingrich campaign loses momentum in Florida.

headline: Madison Avenue Art Dealer Faces Fraud Charges
text: A Madison Avenue art dealer, Robert Scott Cook, has been charged with defrauding a client of 16 artworks by Picasso, Manet, Matisse, Renoir and others worth more than $4.2 million, the United States Attorney’s Office in Manhattan announced on Thursday. Over a period of six years Mr. Cook, the principal of Cook Fine Art, secretly sold watercolors, drawings and photographs to galleries and auction houses behind the owner’s back, according to the attorney’s office. The F.B.I.’s assistant director in charge in New York, Janice K. Fedarcyk, said the charge “is that Mr. Cook is a crook.” If convicted he faces a maximum of 20 years in jail and a $250,000 fine.

headline: On Troubleshooting
text: THOSE who have issues with their mortgage lenders now have another place to take them: the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which began accepting such complaints and inquiries this month.

headline: Audrey Brand and Danny Brown
text: IN 2006, Danny Brown, a former drummer and guitarist, made good on a dream he once had, opening a restaurant and wine bar in Forest Hills, Queens, that in time would earn him a Michelin star.

headline: At Retreat, Biden Rallies House Democrats
text: CAMBRIDGE, Md. – Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., addressing a retreat for House Democrats on Friday, delivered an overtly political speech challenging the economic pronouncements of Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney while setting the bar high for his re-election as President Obama’s second in command.

headline: Paying Far More Than 13.9%: A Taxpayer’s Lament
text: In the many years I’ve been paying income taxes, I’ve never actually done the math to calculate my tax rate. Until now.

headline: Former Hostages Are Recovering at a U.S. Base
text: ROME — Two hostages rescued in Somalia by Special Operations Forces this week after three months of captivity were recovering at a military base in Sicily, an American military official said Friday.

headline: Parental Quandary: How to Choose Your Child’s Guardians
text: This week’s quandary is what I suspect is a common one — in fact, it’s one I share. Who do you ask to be your children’s guardian when there’s no obvious choice at hand?

headline: Jackson Asks to Meet Academy President Over Grammy Cuts
text: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson has demanded a meeting with the head of the Recording Academy to talk about deep cuts to Grammy Award categories this year that some musicians have complained discriminate against certain ethnic groups.

headline: And in Couture Is …
text: DURING the Armani couture show the other day, I kept glancing across the runway at Jessica Chastain. Probably many people were, and all with the same thought: Does she see a dress here she might like to wear to the Oscars? No doubt Mr. Armani will be happy to make her something. Ms. Chastain learned she had been nominated for “The Help” shortly before the show started. People around her applauded. Maybe in all the excitement everything looked blurry.

headline: Sleepwalking and Time-Traveling at Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah — There is a certain kind of movie you see over and over at Sundance, one that blends a bit of magical realism with astutely observed character humor – the leaps of logic that drove the family in “Little Miss Sunshine,” for example.

headline: Moving Into the Refrigerator for a Long Winter’s Stay
text: RESOLUTIONS to eat more vegetables may wilt in the cold of January, when heartier foods beckon and Greenmarket offerings dwindle. But don’t give up: quick winter pickles can satisfy the desire for crunch and put a new, fresh taste on your plate.

headline: When Marine Mammals Become Food
text: Dolphin for dinner? It may be more common than you think. The first global study on human consumption of marine mammals found that the practice is widespread and is becoming more prevalent in many tropical regions.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Life at a Paranormal Bureau
text: The second volume of “B.P.R.D. Hell on Earth, Vol. 2,” published by Dark Horse, enters our paperback graphic books best-seller list at No. 7 this week. The story, written by Mike Mignola and others, chronicles the strange events that the Bureau for Paranormal Research and Defense must cope with on a daily basis. The agency originally appeared in “Hellboy,” created by Mr. Mignola, about a demon fighting on the side of good.

headline: The Caucus | Gingrich Loses Momentum
text: Newt Gingrich's momentum from the South Carolina wanes days ahead of the Florida primary.

headline: Voices of Chinese Workers in the ‘iEconomy’
text: Two recent Times articles in a new series, “The iEconomy,” have addressed the challenges faced by high-tech industries, including the pressures of a globalized supply chain and questions about labor practices at manufacturing partners.

headline: Taking On Soccer Violence, One Derogatory Chant at a Time
text: GLASGOW — It was a normal Saturday game at Ibrox Stadium, home of the Rangers soccer team. A prematch fight broke out on the subway. The crowd lobbed trash onto the field. Fans of Rangers and their mutually despised opponents, Aberdeen, abused one another with traditional chants, songs and obscene gestures.

headline: The Get | Aesa Cuff
text: The Aesa designer Randi Mates was fantasizing about fantasies — Marie Antoinette’s, to be exact — when she designed this cuff. As part of a collection called “Antoinette’s Dream,” the bracelet is what Mates imagines her muse thinking of during her daily public dressings. Call it an escapist’s accessory. Made of hand-wrought bronze, it features one real, semi-spherical mabe pearl and a second hand-hewn brass one that “balances the overall form and calls even more attention to the undulations of the real pearl,” Mates says. “Both jewels look ancient, futuristic and contemporary all at once.” Imagine that.

headline: Costa Rica Blocking Path to London for U.S. Women
text: The United States women’s soccer team could provide a riveting story line at the 2012 London Olympics, given the household names of players like Hope Solo and Abby Wambach, and the galvanizing performance the Americans displayed last year at the World Cup. But first comes the urgent matter of qualifying for the Games. Jeré Longman previews Friday night’s win-or-else Concacaf qualifying tournament semifinal. Read the article, then come back to comment.

headline: Wolves, Snow and the Red Dragon
text: John Vucetich, a wildlife ecologist from Michigan Technological University, leads the wolf-moose Winter Study at Isle Royale National Park.

headline: Caffeine Alters Estrogen Levels in Younger Women
text: Your daily dose of caffeine may tinker with more than just your energy levels.

headline: A Horror Company Rises From the Grave
text: FEW names in horror command more respect than Hammer.

headline: TimesCast | Syrian Violence Spreads
text: January 27, 2012 — The United Nations Security Council discusses resolutions as violence continues to spread in Syria.

headline: Israelis Say Settlements Must Be Part of Israeli State
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli negotiators told their Palestinian counterparts this week that their guiding principle for drawing the borders of a future two-state solution would be for existing settlement blocks to become part of Israel, an approach that the Palestinians rejected as unacceptable.

headline: Before Closing Night, Snapshots of ‘Naked Boys Singing’
text: The Naked City will become a little more modest this weekend when “Naked Boys Singing!,” the all-male, all-nude musical revue, closes on Saturday night after an almost 13-year run in New York.

headline: People’s Diva Sets Her Course
text: DURING a stretch of several months in 2010 the soprano Renée Fleming made what looked to be some startling shifts in her lustrous career.

headline: Wanted: Banking App to Monitor Balances
text: You haven’t been able to turn around in recent months without hearing about one or another bank adding fees to its checking accounts or making new rules for people who want to keep their free checking.

headline: The Welsh Economy Slips, but London Cushions the Fall
text: BLAENAU FFESTINIOG, Wales — This could have been Britain’s Greece.

headline: Racing Up (and Down) the Performance Index
text: Watching the rankings of countries by environmental performance over the last six years has been an occasion for admiration, mingled with bursts of skepticism and even disbelief. It is seldom a surprise that Scandinavian countries occupy at least four spots in the top 15, given their lauded environmental sensibilities (excepting, perhaps, Norwegian whalers and Danish fishermen).

headline: TimesCast: Gingrich Loses Momentum
text: Newt Gingrich’s momentum from the South Carolina wanes days ahead of the Florida primary. Paul Volpe reports.

headline: Top Technology Official Leaving the White House
text: Aneesh Chopra, the White House’s first chief technology officer, will step down, the White House said Friday.

headline: Two Reasons The Patient Is Still Kicking
text: EVERY so often someone declares ballet dead. The theater critic Kenneth Tynan even did so in the 1960s, a decade that many of us assume must have been a golden age. (The choreographer Frederick Ashton said, “It’s having the biggest funeral in history.”) In 2010 it was the turn of Jennifer Homans, the dance critic of The New Republic, in the epilogue of her ballet history, “Apollo’s Angels.” In 1993 — I’d better come clean — it was me.

headline: Avoiding Monthly Balance Minimums on Checking Accounts
text: In this week’s Your Money column, which I wrote with the Bucks stalwart Ann Carrns, we look at the question of why banks don’t let you know the average monthly balance in your bank account, even when they’re using that number to figure out what fees to charge you.

headline: Twitter’s New Policy on Blocking Posts Is Attacked, and Defended
text: Twitter users around the world reacted with confusion and a sense of betrayal on Friday to the company’s announcement that it had developed the capability to “reactively withhold” certain posts in certain countries. To many, the language sounded like a euphemism for censorship.

headline: Darkly Spiritual Challenge to Injustice
text: “THE world turns on its dark side — it is winter,” the chorus sings near the start of “A Child of Our Time” (1939-41), an oratorio by the English composer Michael Tippett. Unlike Handel’s “Messiah” and Bach’s great Passions, the formal and spiritual models Tippett emulated, his oratorio fills no particular slot in the ecclesiastical calendar.

headline: Why Men Always Tell You to See Movies
text: WHAT gender is the voice of God?

headline: Checking In | Public Chicago
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: List of Pardons Included Many Tied to Power
text: JACKSON, Miss. — On a Saturday night in October 1995, a blue Toyota came hurtling down the wrong side of a county road in North Mississippi and crashed head-on into a pickup truck. Scotty Plunk, the driver of the truck, was killed. The driver of the Toyota, 19-year-old Joel Vann, had been drinking so much that he did not remember the accident.

headline: France, Breaking With NATO, Will Speed Afghan Exit
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy announced on Friday that France would break with its allies in NATO and accelerate the French withdrawal from Afghanistan, pulling back combat troops a year early, by the end of 2013. Mr. Sarkozy also said that he and Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai, would ask the NATO alliance for a similar speedup of the transfer of primary security responsibilities to Afghan troops.

headline: So You’re Priced Out. Now What?
text: It’s easy to fall in love with a neighborhood in New York. And given the high cost of housing, it’s common to realize that you can’t afford the home you want in the neighborhood you love.

headline: Anthony Takes a Seat as Knicks Bow to Miami
text: MIAMI — Reality caught up to Carmelo Anthony on Friday, chasing him into temporary exile and destabilizing an already unstable Knicks lineup at perhaps the worst possible time.

headline: Jan. 29 — Feb. 4
text: Theater

headline: With His Ring, Weatherford Says, It’s All About ‘Comfort’
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – Steve Weatherford is not the only player in the N.F.L. to wear a wedding ring while he plays – my colleague Ben Shpigel did a great piece earlier this season on Buffalo Bills quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick, who prefers to keep his band in place while slinging passes.

headline: A Word to the Wise Renter: Insurance
text: NEW YORKERS who have gone without renter’s insurance may want to reconsider that decision after a year of wild weather that brought down trees and damaged rooftops throughout the city.

headline: Townsend and Andrews Take Junior Girls Title
text: A pair of 15-year-olds from the United States, Taylor Townsend of Stockbridge, Ga., and Gabrielle Andrews of Pomona, Calif., captured the Australian Open junior girls’ doubles title on Friday by defeating Irina Khromacheva of Russia and Danka Kovinic of Montenegro, 5-7, 7-5, 10-6.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Legacy of Henry Miller’s ‘Tropic of Cancer’
text: In the New York Times Book Review Jeanette Winterson reviews Frederick Turner’s “Renegade: Henry Miller and the Making of ‘Tropic of Cancer,’ ” about this controversial novel, which was published in the United States in 1961. Ms. Winterson writes that Mr. Turner “cleverly places Miller in a line of American folklore heroes, real and invented, like Daniel Boone and Davy Crockett, Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn.” But she takes issue with the book when it comes to addressing Mr. Miller’s treatment of women. Ms. Winterson writes:

headline: Gingrich Unleashes Ad Attacking Romney
text: Newt Gingrich unleashed a new attack ad on Mitt Romney on Friday, accusing him of being dishonest and untrustworthy.

headline: Does Heavy Media Use Make Girls Less Happy?
text: Researchers at Stanford University examined an online survey taken by more than 3,400 8- to 12-year-old girls and found that “those who say they spend considerable amounts of time using multimedia describe themselves in ways that suggest they are less happy and less socially comfortable than peers who say they spend less time on screens.”

headline: Thanks for the Memories
text: Carina Chocano writes on the resurgence of “artisanal analog technology” for cataloging keepsakes in this week’s Riff. Below, six services that preserve your Facebook page on actual paper.

headline: Proposed Central Park Takeover, Back in ’76
text: Here’s an even stranger footnote to the history-is-stranger-than-satire factoid we noted Thursday regarding an Alaskan lawmaker’s modest proposal to have the federal government take over Central Park, which turns out to have been suggested with a straight face back in the dismal ’70s.

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 27
text: Subjects include the first snowfall in 2012, a great apartment deal in the West Village and a subway track that doubles as a wishing well.

headline: A Blog as Therapy for Teenagers
text: THE GIST Blogging is therapeutic for teenagers.

headline: Offering Plans to Read on Your PC
text: OFFERING plans, the bulky books that can run to hundreds of pages describing the ins and outs of a condominium or co-op, have long been an awkward reality of home-buying in New York City. The state has adjunct warehouse space upstate in the city of Troy to store these behemoths.

headline: Reader Ideas | Teaching the Civil Rights Movement
text: This month, we asked educators, How Do You Teach the Civil Rights Movement?

headline: It’s the 37th District. Or Is It a Squirrel?
text: On Thursday, New York State lawmakers released their redistricting proposals for 2012. Those oddly jagged shapes may suggest gerrymandering, but do they have a deeper psychological meaning?

headline: No Commuting Required
text: IT may be true that real New Yorkers know the easiest way to eat a slice of pizza while walking is to fold it. And it is probably true that real New Yorkers know the first syllable of “Houston Street” rhymes with “cow.” But if you think real New Yorkers avoid areas where tourists throng, you need to visit 57th Street.

headline: Yanks Abroad: Gyau Set for Hoffenheim Debut
text: 2:04 p.m. |Update

headline: Vegetable Oil Will Fuel Record Attempt at Bonneville
text: Dave Schenker enrolled at Boise State University three years ago after working in construction for 15 years. He is about halfway to a bachelor’s degree in mechanical engineering and would like to pursue a career exploring the use of alternative fuels in motorsports.

headline: Tim Cook: ‘We Care About Every Worker’
text: Timothy Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has sent an e-mail to the company’s 63,000 worldwide employees emphasizing Apple’s dedication to improving working conditions inside overseas factories that make products for Apple and other companies.

headline: Sunny Face and Sounds Don’t Hide Dark Reality
text: An air of ceremonial gravity infused the music of the Tierney Sutton Band on Wednesday evening at Birdland, where Ms. Sutton, a Los Angeles-based jazz singer, and her group performed most of its recent album, “American Road,” which has been nominated for two Grammys.

headline: Another Check on the Campaign’s Truthiness
text: When we last looked at how the Republican candidates for president were faring with the facts, there had been just a few debates. But Thursday night’s debate in Jacksonville, Fla., was the 25th time at least two of the candidates have gotten together to argue. A presidential debate, like the campaign trail in general, is often an unwelcoming environment for unadulterated truth. Indeed, our last post on PolitiFact, a venture of The St. Petersburg Times that grades political statements on their validity, came while the campaign was still just simmering. But it’s come to a full boil now, and most of the candidates’ PolitiFact report cards have deteriorated accordingly.

headline: F.B.I. Looks Into Adviser on Chinese Reverse Mergers
text: 8:41 p.m. | Updated

headline: Salad From the Soup Pot
text: In this week’s column, I give a recipe for a cheesy onion soup made from a stock rich with oxtails. So for the frugal cook, the question is: what to do with the oxtails after you’ve strained them from the broth? Surely gnawing on them warm and glistening isn’t the only option. (Though it’s a good one.)

headline: Faking It to Make It: A Beautiful Try
text: Fake reviews on the Internet are probably everywhere. We just don’t know exactly where. The Kindle Fire case on Amazon, which I wrote about today,  came to light only because an outraged customer contacted me, saying he felt he was being bribed for a positive notice. But if we don’t know the volume of counterfeits, one thing is clear: some companies will go to enormous efforts to throw a positive light on themselves.

headline: One-Pot French Onion Soup With Garlic-Gruyère Croutons
text: Adapted from Philippe Bertineau, Benoit, Manhattan

headline: A Snip of the Shears Tames a Cheesy Soup
text: THE gratinéed onion soup at Benoit, the French bistro in Midtown Manhattan, was everything you’d imagine it to be: golden crusted and bubbling, gooey and rich, beefy and fragrant.

headline: Polls Highlight Florida’s Diverse Electorate
text: It’s been fairly evident all week that the Republican primary campaign is no longer in South Carolina — just listen to the shout of “Hola!” by one candidate’s grandson to a crowd of supporters and hear many of the campaign advertisements and interviews in Spanish.

headline: Barnes & Noble Uses Apps to Lure Customers Into Stores
text: Will tablets and e-readers kill bookstores of the nonvirtual variety? Not if Barnes & Noble can help it. The company is using apps on its Nook devices to help drive store traffic and sell physical books, board games and toys.

headline: Homeless Science Whiz Goes to Washington
text: Samantha Garvey, the Long Island teenager who made headlines because her family was living in a homeless shelter when she was named a semifinalist in the Intel Science Search, was still homeless last Tuesday, when she went to Washington. Invited by her congressman, Steve Israel, she met with John P. Holdren, the president’s science adviser; John Boehner, the speaker of the House; and Nancy Pelosi, the minority leader. And she had dinner with Jane Lubchenco, administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Tony Bennett: Duets II’
text: Tony Bennett is known for his smooth, nontaxing sound, but there’s a jarring moment in “Tony Bennett: Duets II,” which documents the making of that hit album and is being broadcast Friday night on PBS’s “Great Performances” series. (Check local listings.)

headline: Consumers Leery of Online Shopping with Tablets and Phones
text: Even as Internet shopping becomes almost routine, consumers still worry about online fraud and are especially leery of shopping with tablets or smartphones, a survey finds.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $14 Million
text: A duplex penthouse at 181 East 65th Street that sold for $14 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to public records.

headline: The Comeback Gains Traction as Prices Soar for Rarest Cars
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

headline: A Strong Supporting Cast
text: It wasn’t just the top of the collector car market that did well at the 2012 Scottsdale auctions. Here are five mid- and entry-level examples, all of which brought handsome returns to their sellers.

headline: The Role of Austerity
text: The chart here offers one of the better recent snapshots of the American economy that you will find.

headline: Santorum’s Attacks on Romney Health Plan Could Help Democrats
text: If Democrats wants a step-by-step instruction manual for how they might try to neutralize Mitt Romney on the issue of health care, they might want to grab a transcript of Thursday’s debate.

headline: Stricken Cruise Ship’s Operator Offers Settlements to Passengers
text: ROME — The operator of the Costa Concordia luxury cruise liner, which crashed and partly sank two weeks ago with more than 4,200 people aboard, made its first attempt on Friday to limit the legal consequences of the shipwreck and chaotic evacuation, offering a settlement of about $14,400 to each uninjured passenger.

headline: Davos, in the Style of Occupy Wall Street
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — In the lofty atmosphere of Davos during the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, a spontaneous debate about the state of the world can break out anywhere — even in a snow-covered parking lot with ski slopes in the background.

headline: First Day for New Chief of Staff
text: At midday Friday, William M. Daley, a former commerce secretary and the son and brother of Chicago mayors, passed the baton as White House chief of staff to Jacob J. Lew, the former budget director.

headline: Buxom, Lustful and Thirsty for Blood
text: THE movies have their outsider artists too, filmmakers who work away from the established centers and financial structures, often laboring in blissful ignorance of academic technique. A disproportionate number of these directors work in horror films, for reasons that probably have to do with the genre’s openness to obsession and high tolerance for the incoherent. Most famous, there is Edward D. Wood Jr., whose endearing ineptitude in films like “Plan 9 From Outer Space” can run thin after a while. There are also genuine poets like Herk Harvey, the Midwestern maker of industrial and educational shorts who poured his heart and personal savings into his one feature-length film, the eerie and elusive “Carnival of Souls” (1962).

headline: Hamas Leader Abandons Longtime Base in Damascus
text: GAZA — Khaled Meshal, the leader of the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas, has effectively abandoned his longtime base in Syria, where a popular uprising has left thousands dead, and has no plans to return, Hamas sources in Gaza said Friday.

headline: Mitt and Newt Hate Fannie and Freddie
text: Which candidate is guiltier-by-association with the two obviously evil government mortgage companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac? Settling this question made for gripping theater at Thursday night’s debate.

headline: Welterweight Champ Steps Back in the Ring
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

headline: New Fraud Investigation Group Issues Subpoenas to Financial Companies
text: WASHINGTON — A new law enforcement group examining securities fraud from the housing bubble and financial crisis has already issued civil subpoenas to 11 financial companies for information related to their actions in the market for residential mortgage-backed securities, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Friday.

headline: A Score Card for Changing Schools
text: Some 62 low-performing public schools in the city have been designated to be closed or otherwise overhauled. Some will be phased out and gradually replaced by new schools, others will be shut at the end of this school year and reopened with a radical change in its staffing in the fall, and four will be left alone on their current improvement paths. Here is an explanation of which schools are affected, and how.

headline: Protesters Storm Syria’s Embassy in Cairo
text: As Egyptians calling for an end to military rule took to the streets again on Friday, protesters stormed the Syrian embassy in Cairo, smashing an official portrait and waving the flag adopted by opponents of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Lara Stone, Minus the Evil
text: Immediately after filming “Touch of Evil,” our videos featuring 13 Oscar-worthy actors channeling their inner villains, Alex Prager did this commercial for Mercedes. Her brilliant commercial is yet one more example of the wonderful blurring of the boundaries between the art, fashion and commercial spheres. This short with Lara Stone would be right at home in an art-film festival.

headline: Citigroup to Close Prop Trading Desk
text: Citigroup is giving in to the Volcker rule.

headline: Return of the Blockbuster
text: The 2012 Arizona auctions reflected the over all strength of the collector-car market, relative to recent years, from the top of the price ladder to the bottom rung.

headline: Should Knicks Look to Miami’s Model for Success?
text: Losers of seven out of their last eight games, the Knicks have undeniably hit one of the lowest points in Coach Mike D’Antoni’s tenure.

headline: Uncommon Trick in a Common Concerto
text: Some of the buzz around the New York Philharmonic residency of the German violinist Frank Peter Zimmermann this season has focused on the conservatism of his repertory. Mr. Zimmermann’s distinguished discography includes items by Weill, Szymanowski and Ligeti, after all, and a West Coast colleague in the audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night fondly recalled accounts of works by Busoni and Britten played elsewhere.

headline: Activists Crack China’s Wall of Denial About Air Pollution
text: BEIJING — Weary of waiting for the authorities to alert residents to the city’s most pernicious air pollutant, citizen activists last May took matters here into their own hands: they bought their own $4,000 air-quality monitor and posted its daily readings on the Internet.

headline: Union Membership Rate Fell Again in 2011
text: The nation’s union membership rate continued a decades-long slide last year, falling to 11.8 percent of the American work force in 2011, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced in a report on Friday.

headline: Congress To Hear From MF Global’s Former Risk Chiefs
text: The congressional inquiry into the collapse of MF Global and its misuse of customer money is set to intensify next week, when a House committee hears testimony from the top executives once responsible for monitoring risk at the brokerage firm.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Namath’
text: Sure, it’s an exercise in legend-burnishing and a bit hokey, but “Namath,” Saturday night on HBO, is fun to watch anyway, for comparison’s sake. Is there anyone on New York’s current Super Bowl team remotely as interesting as Joe Namath, the quarterback who led the Jets to victory in Super Bowl III in 1969? No, not even close. Is there anyone anywhere on the New York sports scene with his kind of gaudy charisma? Derek Jeter has the charisma but not the gaudiness. A-Rod? Nah, he has the hot women but doesn’t generate the love from fans.

headline: ‘The Auckland Project’
text: The Strand Book Store is a not-so-secret New York gem. During a recent jaunt to the photography section, I fell in love with “The Auckland Project,” two hardbound volumes showcasing a joint photography project by John Gossage and Alec Soth (who has contributed to our magazine). It is the culmination of a trip the two legendary photographers took to Auckland, New Zealand, in the spring of 2009.

headline: Hollywood Fixer Opens His Little Black Book
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: In Youth Pairs Event, 2 Girls Win a Big Game
text: On Jan. 16, the last day of the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., a nine-table youth pairs event included 20 players who arrived on a bus from New Jersey.

headline: Chic in Review | Taylor Swift’s Songs for Jake
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: 2012 Honda CR-V
text: With strong new competitors lining up, how long can the new CR-V stay on top of the compact crossover segment?

headline: Cure for a Terminal Condition
text: FORDS with transmission leaks and Mitsubishi transmissions stuck in the Park position are among the mechanical ailments covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Honda Begins Deliveries of Battery-Powered Fit
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Looking for Alternatives to Safe Bonds
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, discusses higher-yielding, but safe, alternatives to United States Treasuries and other high-grade bonds. Those bonds have long been the favorites of older investors because they were a safe way to guarantee income. At the moment, though, they’re barely generating income.

headline: Based in China? Why Not Commission One of These?
text: To trace the political and economic encounter between China and the West to its first mass flowering, read Souren Melikian’s latest column in the IHT. Reporting on two Christie’s auctions this week, Souren shows how the meeting of East and West centuries ago yielded decorative and representative art.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 27
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Three Stars Flaunting Their Styles: Flirty, Serene and Mysterious
text: New York City Ballet has its flaws, but a lack of vibrant female dancers isn’t one of them. In George Balanchine’s era dancers weren’t carbon copies in body type or personality; mercifully, the same holds true today. On Thursday evening at the David H. Koch Theater, three principal dancers evoked their assertive harmony or individuality in a program of ballets by Balanchine and Jerome Robbins.

headline: Getting Lessons in Acting, and Life
text: PEEKSKILL, N.Y.

headline: For a Moon Colony, Technology Is the Easy Part
text: Could the United States establish a moon colony and develop a new propulsion system for going to Mars? All within eight years of a Newt Gingrich presidency, as Mr. Gingrich promised this week?

headline: Thomas Faces Scrutiny Again at All-Star Media Day
text: OTTAWA — Tim Thomas, the embattled Bruins goalie confronted with the fallout from his politically motivated decision to boycott his team’s Monday visit to the White House, told reporters Thursday his actions and statements were made “as an individual, not as a representative of the Boston Bruins.”

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 27
text: More Photographs

headline: Diabetes Drug Injected Weekly Wins F.D.A. Approval
text: Amylin Pharmaceuticals won federal approval on Friday for its new, more convenient drug for Type 2 diabetes, ending years of setbacks.

headline: Should a Life Coach Have a Life First?
text: ON a recent winter evening, Jeannine Yoder, a life coach, was at her Upper West Side apartment, hosting a monthly MasterMind, an industry term for a group session done via conference call. Ms. Yoder began her coaching business, theRSVPrev.com — which is centered on the “life-empowerment” mantra Restore, Simplify, Verify, Power — last year to help finance an acting career, only to find coaching taking center stage. She quickly built a stable of 18 clients (including Amanda Perna, a contestant on “Project Runway”) who each pay her $125 for the weekly hourlong sessions.

headline: New York’s Fracking Deliberations Inch Along
text: In yet another sign that New York has slowed efforts to green-light fracking of natural gas, officials at the state Department of Environmental Conservation canceled a meeting of a drilling advisory panel this week for a second time.

headline: Chelsea Piers, 12:04 P.M.
text: The new Greenpeace Rainbow Warrior, the organization’s third flagship in its 40-year history, arrived in New York on its maiden voyage to the United States, en route to Baltimore and points south, including, eventually, Brazil. It will be open to the public on Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.

headline: When Is a Debt Not a Debt? When Republicans Need a Propaganda Tool
text: In his State of the Union address the other day, President Obama made a powerful point about the political nonsense that has been consuming Washington. “The greatest blow to confidence in our economy last year didn’t come from events beyond our control,” he said. “It came from a debate in Washington over whether the United States would pay its bills.”

headline: Cablevision Workers in Brooklyn Vote to Join Union
text: In a 180-to-86 vote on Thursday, Brooklyn’s Cablevision workers unionized and became members of Communications Workers of America Local 1109.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 27
text: The day in sports, including a World Cup skiing event in St. Moritz, Switzerland, and tennis action from the Australian Open.

headline: Buzz on a Facebook I.P.O. Grows Louder
text: The drumbeat on Facebook’s initial public offering is getting louder.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, Egypt, Bahrain and France.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom 1928 Tudor in Hempstead, N.Y., and a four-bedroom colonial in Bridgeport, Conn.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Lincoln Square maisonette, a Greenwich Village one-bedroom and a Prospect Heights co-op.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The First Password and Cool Data Centers
text: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: The Lam Family of Ludlow Street
text: When the life of the Lam family was documented by Thomas Holton, a photographer, from 2003 to 2005, their compact existence within a tiny downtown apartment seemed brimming with optimism and hope.

headline: A Girl’s Got to Work: From Lingerie to Glocks
text: “One for the Money,” the latest Katherine Heigl vehicle to park itself in the multiplexes, is also the title of a best-selling novel by Janet Evanovich. It is worth stating this fact at the outset to avoid the mistaken but entirely plausible assumption that the phrase somehow made its way onto the lobby posters from the subject line of an e-mail from Ms. Heigl’s agent.

headline: The New Merseyside Beat
text: Everton may never allow Landon Donovan to leave.

headline: N.Y. Airports Account for Half of All Flight Delays
text: Delays are a fact of life at New York’s three main airports.

headline: Oh, Look, It’s Time Again for the Village Orgy
text: It’s easy to see why the British writer-director Robin Hardy would want to reimagine his 1973 cult horror classic “The Wicker Man.” Take one glimpse at Neil LaBute’s remake from 2006, starring Nicolas Cage — now enshrined in the pantheon of high-camp turkeys — and Mr. Hardy’s need to set matters aright makes sense. “The Wicker Tree,” based on Mr. Hardy’s novel “Cowboys for Christ,” and a companion piece to the 1973 film, infinitely surpasses the LaBute fiasco, but can’t beat the raw, earthy and mythic (and far more low-budget) power of the first.

headline: Violence Continues in Syria
text: Violence in Syria has escalated sharply in the past two days, with heavy bloodshed reported Friday in at least three flash points as Arab League monitors expressed exasperation.

headline: One Man, Three Flying Fiancées: A Bumpy Ride
text: Bernard is a quirky kind of fiancé. He has an obsessive interest in his girlfriend’s work schedule. Although they share an apartment in Paris, he has never introduced her to his friends. And he doesn’t actually plan to marry her.

headline: Friday Night Music: Damn Love Song
text: Sorry about the lack of posts — hard to blog when you’re coughing your lungs out. Here’s something I’ve been listening to lately:

headline: S.&P. Lowers Outlook on Jefferies and Cantor
text: Standard & Poor’s lowered its outlook on the Jefferies Group and Cantor Fitzgerald to negative from stable on Friday, expressing concern that the European debt crisis could weigh on profits at the brokerage firms and cause a decline in market activity.

headline: Narrowing the Definition of Autism
text: To the Editor:

headline: On City Hall Steps, Harsh Words for Bloomberg
text: During a week in which the Bloomberg administration has embraced an independent, landmark study that linked its hallmark policy of small schools to increased student success, a group of parents and elected officials took to the steps of City Hall on Friday to denounce the administration’s education agenda, particularly its decisions to close or phase out city schools and its policies to address low college preparedness rates for minority students.

headline: Thwarting Scalpers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Academics vs. Athletics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Alternate-Side Stickers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Charter School Releases an Ad Supporting Cuomo
text: ALBANY – As he girds for confrontation with what he calls the state’s educational bureaucracy, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has found an unexpected ally singing his praises on cable television: a group of high school students in East Harlem.

headline: Nature and Death Have a Family Shivering and Bickering
text: The snowy woods of the Sierra Nevada are not easy to simulate inside a small Off Broadway theater, but Raul Abrego, the designer of the new drama “Yosemite,” gives it a shot. Several impressively large, ridged trees, speckled in dirty white, stand near a mound of genuine-looking dirt inside the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.

headline: Some in Egypt Turn Their Anger on Islamists, and the Syrian Embassy Is Attacked
text: CAIRO — The resentments of many young political activists toward the Muslim Brotherhood spilled into a public spat on Friday as some demonstrators who came out to mark the first anniversary of the country’s revolution turned on the group.

headline: Technology and Philanthropy Merge at Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Saying there are a lot of rich people in attendance at the World Economic Forum is like noting that there is a lot of water in the ocean. So where there are millionaires and billionaires, there is also talk of philanthropy.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Groundswell
text: The signature high-fashion look for this winter is now clearly established: narrow trousers and ankle-high boots with chunky heels.

headline: Banks Taketh, but Don’t Giveth
text: BANKS are eating up all the real estate in my neighborhood. I live on a basically residential street, and within three and a half short blocks of my house are eight banks: two Chase, one Wells Fargo, one Citi, one HSBC, one Bank of America, one Sovereign and one Capital One. Go two more blocks and there are 10 banks (one more Chase and one more Citi).

headline: A Symphony’s Leader Takes Seattle by Storm
text: SEATTLE — At a cocktail party on Wednesday evening in an art-filled home in the fashionable Capitol Hill neighborhood here, Andrew Russell, the 28-year-old artistic director of the Intiman Theater, addressed a small crowd in front of a picture window and unexpectedly mentioned Ludovic Morlot.

headline: Judge Moves Congressional Primary Date to June
text: A federal judge ordered New York State on Friday to move its primary elections for Congressional races to June from September, creating a major complication for the state’s election calendar.

headline: Amazing Child, Typical Grown-Ups
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Now in its 28th edition, the Sundance Film Festival has eased into a mellower groove, hallelujah and pass the parka. Despite the predictable hazards and hassles, like slip-sliding on black ice and waiting for shuttles in the frigid cold, it no longer is the nightmare it had become back when Paris Hilton and frat types descended. The economic downturn plays a part — there are fewer self-important industry players crowding the scene — as does the affable presence of the festival’s director, John Cooper, who took over in 2009.

headline: Songs, Some Coded, of Liberation
text: WHEN Nkeiru Okoye, a composer who lives in Massapequa, decided to move beyond the mostly orchestral works she had written, she set out to create some vocal music.

headline: Bloomberg Executive Is Said to Be in Talks to Lead Dow Jones
text: News Corporation is said to be in advanced talks to hire Lex Fenwick as the chief executive of Dow Jones, filling a six-month vacancy created when the publisher’s top executive resigned amid the phone-hacking scandal in Britain.

headline: In a Grueling Match, Djokovic Dominates Murray’s Second Serve
text: A more aggressive Andy Murray battled world No. 1 Novak Djokovic for five sets but could not quite will himself over the finish line to score the upset. It was a physically brutal match, with both men going through patches in the match where fatigue and pain lowered their level of play. The match lasted nearly five hours, with each player committed to playing long, grinding baseline points that featured clean hitting, pinpoint accuracy, and breathtaking pace.

headline: Delta Explores Possible Bid for US Airways
text: 8:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: California Board Votes Unanimously to Toughen Zero-Emission Vehicle Mandate
text: In a unanimous vote on Friday, the California Air Resources Board, known as CARB, affirmed a major expansion of its Advanced Clean Car rules. According to CARB’s projection, the program would result in an additional 1.4 million zero- and near-zero-emission vehicles on the state’s roads by 2025.

headline: The Mississippi River Delta Must Be Restored
text: New Orleans

headline: Creating Artworks Without a Net
text: Let’s all agree that “outsider artist” is a term of convenience, encompassing the self-taught, the visionary, the geographically isolated, the mentally ill or developmentally disabled, and (in one memorable episode) Homer Simpson. And in that spirit, we must judge the Outsider Art Fair, now celebrating its 20th anniversary, not by its title but by the vitality and variety of works on offer.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 27
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the first snowfall in 2012, a great apartment deal in the West Village and a subway track that doubles as a wishing well.

headline: What’s a Cad to Do With Three Fiancées?
text: The word “stewardess” is never spoken in the Paper Mill Playhouse’s bubbly new production of “Boeing-Boeing.” But neither are the words “flight attendant,” because the play is set long, long ago in the 1960s. Instead the three young, sexy, female airline employees who all live in the same apartment in Paris (but don’t realize it) are referred to as “air hostesses.”

headline: New Routes May Speed New York Air Traffic
text: New routes for some flights from Kennedy Airport

headline: New Music Opens a New Hall
text: It has been a long time coming — about four years of raising money and renovating — but on Wednesday evening the Issue Project Room settled into its new digs in the former Board of Education building at 110 Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn. For anyone who spent time in Issue Project’s former home, a tiny space at the Old American Can Factory, also in Brooklyn, this is a new world: the room is spacious (5,000 square feet) and rich in retro grandeur, with marble floors, columns and arches, and a high, ornate ceiling.

headline: Paratroopers’ Anti-Putin Song Stirs the Opposition
text: A video of a musical group, apparently featuring former Russian paratroopers, performing a song with lyrics sharply critical of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, quickly became an Internet sensation after it was posted to YouTube on Thursday. By Friday evening, the band had performed the song on a private television channel, TV Dozhd (Russian for TV Rain).

headline: Congressman Voices Doubt on Oversight of D.E.A.
text: WASHINGTON — The powerful chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform increased his pressure on the Justice Department on Friday, raising new questions about how the Drug Enforcement Administration conducts its undercover money-laundering investigations and whether those operations cross the line between fighting and facilitating crime.

headline: Teaching Tibetan Ways, a School in China Is an Unlikely Wonder
text: ZHANDETAN, China — There are many marvels at the end of the punishing dirt road that skirts the edge of this stark white glacier high on the Tibetan plateau: thousands of fluttering crimson prayer flags, planted on the slopes by the religious faithful; wild goats scrambling across impossibly steep cliffs; and Buddhist monks meditating as they have for centuries in a place where newcomers find themselves gasping for air.

headline: Reviewing the 2012 Honda CR-V
text: In his first vehicle evaluation for The Times, Csaba Csere (pronounced CHUB-uh CHED-uh) reviews the 2012 Honda CR-V in Sunday’s Automobiles Section. Mr. Csere, an M.I.T.-trained automotive engineer, was on the staff of Car and Driver magazine for 28 years and served as editor in chief from 1993 to 2008. He previously wrote for the Automobiles section about the search for a fast-charger plug that would be compatible with all of the existing electric cars.

headline: Perelman Loses Court Battle Over $16 Million Suit
text: 8:58 p.m. | Updated

headline: Cries From the Heart, Crashing Like Waves
text: Wonderment and sorrow course through the songs of Antony Hegarty, who leads Antony and the Johnsons. Those are immense emotions, and on Thursday night he performed in a place to match their scale: Radio City Music Hall. A towering backdrop was often illuminated by lasers; his band members were supplemented by a 60-piece orchestra. He had chosen his most contemplative songs, with sustained melodies like lullabies grown operatic, carrying lyrics to proclaim and repeat revelations: “I need another world/This one’s nearly gone.”

headline: Gingrich Releases Two Attack Ads
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — A pair of vitriolic anti-Romney ads were released on Friday, one from Newt Gingrich’s campaign and another from the “super PAC” supporting him.

headline: Medicare Seen as Battleground Issue in Congressional Races
text: WASHINGTON — A Republican plan to remake Medicare, set forth in a budget blueprint devised by Representative Paul D. Ryan, has largely faded from public view. But it is about to come back in a big way as Democrats try to win control of the House by battering Republicans over Medicare in Congressional races around the country.

headline: Iran Says It Could Terminate European Oil Sales Next Week
text: Escalating retaliatory threats over the West’s nuclear sanctions, Iran warned on Friday that it could terminate oil sales to Europe as early as next week, and it bluntly advised Arab oil producers that any attempt by them to replace Iranian exports would be considered unfriendly.

headline: F.T.C. Sues to Block Omnicare’s Bid for PharMerica
text: The Federal Trade Commission sued Omnicare on Friday, seeking to block the pharmacy service provider’s hostile $441 million bid for PharMerica.

headline: Mickelson Misses Cut at Torrey Pines
text: SAN DIEGO — After his work week was unexpectedly cut short, Phil Mickelson emerged from the scoring trailer to a welcome sight. “Hi, Love,” he said as he scooped wife, Amy, into his arms.

headline: Senegal Court Says President Can Run Again
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Senegal’s elderly president can run for a third term next month, according to a ruling Friday night by the nation’s constitutional court, which also threw out the candidacy of the popular music star Youssou N’Dour, who vowed to appeal.

headline: A Goalkeeper Should Never Dance With a Moose
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — You know that women’s soccer in the United States has begun to reach a broad audience when the goalkeeper becomes a star in cleats and in heels.

headline: Cuomo Defends Closed Session With Executives and Lobbyists
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo defended his decision to participate in a closed-door discussion of infrastructure policy on Friday before an audience of deep-pocketed donors, some of whom paid $50,000 or more to attend, at the same time that his administration is preparing to accelerate billions of dollars of public works projects across New York State.

headline: A Familiar Menu for Red-Sauce Fans
text: WHEN Enzo’s, on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx, finally opened its much-awaited sibling on East Main Street in Mount Kisco last spring, pulses quickened in anticipation of the kinds of solid red-sauce dishes that first made Americans love Italian food.

headline: An Iraqi Massacre, a Light Sentence and a Question of Military Justice
text: WASHINGTON — The collapse this week of the prosecution of a Marine for a civilian massacre in Haditha, Iraq — a striking outcome, even in a military justice system with a mixed record of charging soldiers for war crimes — has not only outraged Iraqis but also stunned some American military law specialists.

headline: As Nations Line Up Against Syrian Government, Russia Sides Firmly With Assad
text: MOSCOW — There are not many world capitals today where President Bashar al-Assad of Syria can count on unstinting support. But diplomats who passed through Moscow this week hoping to secure Russia’s help in forcing him from power were met with cold refusal.

headline: The Tastes, and Ingredients, of New England
text: A WALL painted with Brobdingnagian-size, Georgia O’Keeffe-style magnolias is the focal point of the main dining area at Artisan — until the food arrives. The menu at this stylish restaurant in the new Delamar Southport Hotel is even more creative than the décor. The chef, Frederic Kieffer, formerly of the much-missed Gaia in Greenwich, has created a modern version of New England cookery that makes use of many local and regional ingredients, like chilled oysters from the Thimble Islands and Cape Cod hard-shell clams.

headline: ‘Barefoot Bandit’ Receives a Federal Prison Sentence
text: SEATTLE — Colton Harris-Moore, the former fugitive known as the Barefoot Bandit, was sentenced in federal court here on Friday to six and a half years in prison, completing a legal odyssey that mirrored his two-year, cross-country crime spree.

headline: Comfort Food With a Wide Provenance
text: IF you find yourself in Hopewell and hungry for gumbo, Bell & Whistle is the place to go. Deeply flavored and very reasonably priced at $4, this mildly spicy stew offers the essence of the so-called holy trinity — celery, bell pepper, onions — along with chicken, andouille and crawfish in every bite.

headline: For Blues’ Elliott, Bumps Part of Route to Top
text: OTTAWA — Sidney Crosby and Alex Ovechkin may not be playing, yet the N.H.L. All-Star Game is still a showcase for established stars like Pavel Datsyuk, Patrick Kane and Zdeno Chara.

headline: Pursuing iPhone Thief, Officer Knew Right Buttons to Push
text: As crime-solving tools go, it may not have the same pedigree as, say, the oversize magnifying glass. But with apologies to Sherlock Holmes, an iPhone — specifically, the iPhone 4 — proved quite useful in helping police officers track down a robber on Thursday in Manhattan.

headline: If You Didn’t Catch It the First Time
text: Through more than 20 Republican presidential debates, candidates have returned to some themes and phrases over and over and over again.

headline: A Crime Apparently in Progress, and a Man Who Had Seen Enough
text: The white van parked on East Houston Street as it does most mornings. The sign on the back read, “Follow This Truck for the Best Chopped Liver in New York.” The driver, Pablo Allende, a muscular 44-year-old, stepped out carrying a box of lunches from the Second Avenue Deli and approached an unmarked door.

headline: Lincoln Tells a Story
text: On Tuesday, Jan. 28, 1862, George Templeton Strong, New York lawyer and philanthropist, and Henry Ward Bellows, Unitarian minister and president of the United States Sanitary Commission, called on the president to discuss reform of the Army medical bureau. The next day, Strong, an inveterate diarist, wrote at length about the meeting, and included a Lincoln story in dialect so as to capture the president’s diction. The elitist Strong described the backwoods president as “a barbarian, Scythian, yahoo, or gorilla, in respect to outside polish (for example, he uses “humans” as English for homines), but a most sensible, straightforward, honest old codger.”

headline: Censoring of Tweets Sets Off #Outrage
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It started five years ago after a young engineer in San Francisco sketched out a quirky little Web tool for telling your friends what you were up to. It became a bullhorn for millions of people worldwide, especially vital in nations that tend to muzzle their own people.

headline: Obama Buttresses Case for U.S. Resilience With Book From Unlikely Source
text: WASHINGTON — When Senator Barack Obama was photographed clutching a copy of “The Post-American World” as he left his campaign plane during the Democratic primaries in May 2008, some critics viewed it as a telling sign that he embraced a view of the United States as a waning world power.

headline: In Defense of Clean Energy
text: After months of standing by as Republicans tried to gut environmental laws and discredit his clean energy initiatives, President Obama took the offensive in his State of the Union address. He blasted Republicans for their single-minded commitment to fossil fuels, argued the case for a diversified energy strategy and dared to talk about climate change, a topic he has been silent on for months.

headline: A Team’s Ragtag Roots
text: The New England Patriots play in a $325 million palatial stadium complex, their star quarterback appears on fashion billboards nationwide and the team has won three Super Bowls. They are one of the N.F.L.’s glamour franchises and a model for the prosperous professional sports operation.

headline: A Veto for the Voters
text: This week, New York State lawmakers unveiled proposed legislative district maps, based on the 2010 census and required in time for this year’s elections. The maps, as expected, are entirely designed to protect party interests for Republicans who control the State Senate districts and Democrats who run the Assembly.

headline: Mixed Reviews of Obama Plan to Keep Down College Costs
text: In a campus visit Friday morning, President Obama outlined his plans to keep college tuition costs in check, getting a wildly enthusiastic response at the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor.

headline: Like an Avocado in a Glass
text: The food-friendly whites made at Waters Crest in Cutchogue and sold in its adjacent tasting room, in the North Road Commons industrial park, are noteworthy for their texture.

headline: Diverse Asian Cuisines, Together on the Menu
text: THE popularity of Asian fusion restaurants on Long Island shows no sign of abating. Shortly after one such place, Dao, closed last fall in Huntington, it was replaced by Legacy Asian Fusion, which opened in mid-December.

headline: Jacobs May Be the Key to Short-Yardage Plays
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The value of Brandon Jacobs to the Giants was reinforced during the championship game last Sunday. Not in San Francisco, where the Giants outlasted the 49ers to reach the Super Bowl, but in Foxborough, Mass.

headline: Egypt’s Assault on Civil Society
text: Post-Mubarak Egypt is facing profound challenges with its unfinished revolution and looming economic crisis. The last thing it needs is to pick a fight with the United States. Yet the military rulers have done just that, demonstrating contempt for civil society and an old ally.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: European leaders continued to pressure Greece and address the debt crisis, Apple released blockbuster earnings lifted by the iPhone 4S, global financial leaders met in Davos and the American economy was seen as gaining strength.

headline: Donovan Powers Everton
text: Landon Donovan provided two pinpoint crosses for assists as host Everton ousted Fulham, 2-1, in a fourth-round match of England’s F.A. Cup. The game included perhaps the top three American soccer players: Donovan, goalkeeper Tim Howard and Fulham striker Clint Dempsey.

headline: Kelly Says Anti-Muslim Film Shouldn’t Have Been Screened
text: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Friday that “The Third Jihad,” a film depicting many American Muslim leaders as extremists, “should not have been shown” to New York City officers.

headline: Promoting a New Album, and Often Going Off Script
text: Here’s what working with Steve Albini can do for your band, as evinced by “Attack on Memory” (Carpark), the strong new album by the Cleveland outfit Cloud Nothings. Like a preset mode in ProTools or other recording programs, there is an Albini sound: the drums hit with a certain crispness, and there’s a mild claustrophobia to the proceedings. Mr Albini, who engineered the new album, can only give the Albini.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: THE New York Giants are going to the Super Bowl. And New Jersey’s governor would like you to remember where their stadium is.

headline: Obama on the Road
text: Fresh from a State of the Union speech he used to make his case for re-election, President Obama took to the road this week to build support for his economic message of fairness.

headline: A Long Island Teenager Studies Species Survival and Saves Herself in the Process
text: If you recognize Samantha Garvey’s name, it’s probably not for the details of her research, a study of the effect of invasive crabs on native mussels in Long Island Sound. It’s for the poignancy of her life in the last few months.

headline: No More Nice Guys: Fans Love ‘Nuclear Newt’
text: MOUNT DORA, Fla. — Newt Gingrich is happy to talk about Reaganomics or his plan for an “environmental solutions agency” and almost any other issue under the sun, or moon for that matter. But that is not really what his supporters come to hear.

headline: Russia: Liberal Candidate Is Barred From Election
text: The Central Election Commission on Friday barred Grigory A. Yavlinsky, founder of the liberal opposition party Yabloko, from competing in the March 4 presidential election. Mr. Yavlinsky, left, submitted the 2 million signatures required to qualify for the ballot, but the commission ruled that over a quarter of the 600,000 signatures randomly selected for verification were invalid. Mr. Yavlinsky promised to challenge the ruling, which he said was politically motivated. Without a candidate, Yabloko will not be able to send thousands of observers to polling stations in March, as it did for parliamentary elections in December. Another independent candidate, Dmitry Mezentsev, was also disqualified.

headline: Et Tu, Harvard?
text: If the worst thing that ever happens to Temi Fagbenle is that she gets to play college basketball for only three seasons instead of four, she’ll have lived a blessed life. No question, the wrong being perpetrated on this 6-foot-4 Harvard freshman pales compared with some of the injustices in college sports that I’ve been recounting lately.

headline: Times and Tides Weigh on Hudson River Park
text: It is supposed to be the model for New York City parks to come — built from dilapidated industrial structures, self-sustaining and financed by commercial ventures operating on parkland. And Hudson River Park, which stretches five miles along the Manhattan waterfront from Battery Place to 59th Street, has succeeded in drawing millions of visitors and billions of dollars in development to the West Side. But it now finds its future in doubt.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: A Dangerous Rarity

headline: Lottery Numbers
Expert Witnesses Faulted in Suit Against Mets’ Owners
text: Lawyers for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff have accused the Mets’ owners of enriching themselves with illegitimate profits from his Ponzi scheme. The owners, in turn, have called the lawyers shakedown artists bent on ruining their good reputations to extort money.

headline: Robert Hegyes, a Sweathog on ‘Kotter,’ Dies at 60
text: Robert Hegyes, who played Juan Epstein, the Sweathog voted Most Likely to Take a Life, on the 1970s sitcom “Welcome Back, Kotter,” died on Thursday in Edison, N.J. He was 60.

headline: Cat Food, Sports and, Yes, Brew
text: As chairman and president of the Brooklyn Brewery, Steve Hindy enjoys the privilege of having one of his favorite brews, Brooklyn Brown Ale, on tap in his kitchen. Mr. Hindy, 62, became intrigued with beer-making in the 1980s while a Beirut-based Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He and a neighbor, Tom Potter, then a lawyer, went into the brewery business in 1988. Mr. Hindy lives in an 1840s clapboard house in Gowanus with his wife, Ellen Foote, 61, the principal of Intermediate School 89 in TriBeCa, and their cat, Pinsky. Their daughter, Lily, 28, lives nearby in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens and is a frequent Sunday visitor.

headline: Profit Slips for Chevron, Disappointing Analysts
text: Chevron’s fourth-quarter profit declined to $5.1 billion, or $2.58 a share, from $5.3 billion, or $2.64, a year earlier. Its earnings per share were 32 cents below the average of five analysts’ estimates compiled by Bloomberg. Sales rose 11 percent to nearly $60 billion during the quarter. Chevron’s American refineries lost an average $2.2 million a day during the final three months of 2011 as crude-processing margins shrank and maintenance work at a California plant curbed fuel output, the company said in a statement. Chevron added the equivalent of 1.67 billion barrels in reserves last year, enough to replace 171 percent of the oil and gas the company pumped last year.

headline: What Cuts Power in Half
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — If you ever want to look at your daily crossword puzzle in an entirely different way, take a gander at the “Analyze” feature on Xword Info. Just go to any puzzle on the site, scroll down and click the “Analyze this puzzle” button.

headline: Five Years Later, a New Reality
text: When Thomas Holton began visiting the Lam family in 2003, he was struck by how much life they fit inside their 350-square-foot apartment on Ludlow Street in Manhattan. Three small children, their parents, relatives and friends, a bathtub in the kitchen, with clothes racks above the table. It was a jumble that fascinated him for its grit, warmth and can-do optimism.

headline: Back to Classroom for Skills Not Taught in High School
text: On a recent morning in a small classroom in the Bronx, Ivette Gongón-Volmar asked a group of students to list their needs.

headline: Tending the Soul, and Earthly Gardens
text: FOUR years ago, the Rev. Forrest Church informed members of his congregation, the Unitarian Church of All Souls, on the Upper East Side, that he had terminal cancer. Less than 20 months later, he was dead at 61. In “Being Alive and Having to Die: The Spiritual Odyssey of Forrest Church” (St. Martin’s Press, $27.99), the book critic Dan Cryer ably captures the theologian who was the son of a United States senator and became a champion of liberal political causes in religion.

headline: Newt’s Real Legacy
text: DO you think that after all is said and done, Newt Gingrich will just go down in history as the politician who conclusively proved that voters don’t care about a candidate’s sexual misbehavior?

headline: Corrections: January 28
text: SPORTS

headline: A Slimmer Curry Aims to Regain Relevance
text: MIAMI — As he attempts to revive a lost career, Eddy Curry is focusing firmly on the road ahead and shunning any discussion of the jagged path behind him.

headline: Lunar Colonies, Lunacy and Losses
text: Newt Gingrich is spaced-out. Literally.

headline: Rabbi’s Followers Cast Doubts on Congressman’s Fund-Raising
text: Soon after he began running for Congress in 2009, Michael G. Grimm, a Staten Island Republican, needed to convince party leaders in Washington that he could raise enough money to become a viable candidate. Seeking help, he turned to an unlikely source: followers of an Orthodox rabbi and mystic from Israel.

headline: Cathedral Expects New Revenue, and Controversy, in Residential Tower Deal
