headline: Take Blood Pressure in Both Arms, Study Says
text: Doctors who make a habit of measuring blood pressure in only one arm may be doing their patients a disservice.

headline: Health Costs, Regardless of Your Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Mattek-Sands, a Loss Turns Into a Win
text: MELBOURNE — Few players win their first Grand Slam title because they lost on the first day of the tournament, but that’s exactly what happened to the Minnesota-born Arizona resident Bethanie Mattek-Sands.

headline: ABB to Buy Thomas & Betts for $3.9 Billion
text: 6:52 a.m. | Updated ABB of Switzerland agreed on Monday to buy Thomas & Betts, an American maker of electrical connectors, for about $3.9 billion in cash.

headline: Egypt’s Military Seeks Advice on Early Handing of Power to Civilians
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers have asked a panel of advisers for suggestions about handing over power to civilians earlier than the scheduled deadline at the end of June, state news media reported Sunday.

headline: In Florida, Romney and Gingrich Go for New Lows in Pandering on Cuba
text: TAMPA – At a Cuban restaurant in Hialeah today, two days ahead of the Florida primary, Mitt Romney carved up some pork and denounced Fidel Castro, a ritual as old and formalized as politicians putting on plastic yarmulkes and consulting with wizened rabbis in Brooklyn. Well, except maybe for the pork part.

headline: With Focus on Income Inequality, Albany Bill Will Seek $8.50 Minimum Wage
text: The Occupy Wall Street encampment at Zuccotti Park is no more, but the focus it brought to income inequality is having an impact in Albany and beyond.

headline: Kiwanuka Goes Home, but His Heart Is Far Away
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Mathias Kiwanuka says he does not remember how old he was when he first found out his grandfather had been assassinated. He struggles to remember the point at which he realized the true meaning of his own last name. He is not certain when he became aware of his family’s importance in African history.

headline: Jonathan Idema, Con Man and Afghan Bounty Hunter, Dies at 55
text: Jonathan K. Idema, a convicted con man who gained notoriety in post-invasion Afghanistan as a swaggering hunter of terrorists, then ignominy when he was imprisoned for taking Afghans hostage and torturing them, died Jan. 21 at his home in Bacalar, Mexico. He was 55.

headline: U.S. Banks Tally Their Exposure to Europe’s Debt Maelstrom
text: After a hurricane, homeowners check nervously to see if their insurance will cover all of the damage. With the European financial crisis still threatening a trail of defaults, United States banks are betting that their insurance is going to pay out.

headline: English Is Global, So Why Learn Arabic?
text: Lawrence Summers says the emergence of English as the lingua franca makes learning other languages less vital. Does he have a point?

headline: New Playbook for Post-Career Success
text: In the moments before kickoff in an early-season game between the Tennessee Titans and the Baltimore Ravens, two linebackers engaged in some good-natured trash talking. The banter had nothing to do with who would win; it was about who was further behind on his homework.

headline: Mulberry Street May Fade, but ‘Mulberry Street’ Shines On
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. — “I’ll take you to see Mulberry Street,” said Guy McLain, the director of the Museum of Springfield History.

headline: Coaching Can Be Older Man’s Game, if Wins Keep Coming
text: If the Giants win the N.F.L. championship on Sunday, 65-year-old Tom Coughlin will become the oldest winning coach in Super Bowl history.

headline: To Mend Ties After Clash, Kazakhstan Makes an Offer
text: ZHANAOZEN, Kazakhstan — Despite the vast wealth of nearby oil fields, this industrial settlement in the desert of western Kazakhstan is a picture of rural poverty. Sheep meander through the town. The streets, mostly unpaved, are so deeply rutted that cars must slow to a crawl.

headline: Imagine His Shock. His Leg Had Vanished.
text: Having played a singing elephant on stages across the country, Cleo Berry is well acquainted with the vagaries of show business. But he still was stunned to learn that he had unwittingly become an amputee in advertisements that New York City is posting to warn of the dangers of diabetes.

headline: Bridge’s Partial Fencing Points to a Bigger Divide
text: The footbridge is, at first glance, unremarkable. It connects two sections of the Ingersoll public housing project in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and its dull red walkway matches the brick apartment houses on either side. Underneath it are the roadway and bike lanes of Navy Street.

headline: Private Equity Trade Group to Name Permanent Chief
text: The Private Equity Growth Capital Council plans to formally appoint Steve Judge as its chief executive on Monday, making him the official leader of the private equity industry trade group.

headline: A Glimpse of Murdoch Unbound
text: As American business has become more and more media savvy, its leaders have appeared in media less and less. Business reporters have to work their way past background conversations with underlings, written statements that state nothing, and that increasingly hardy perennial: the “no comment.” The modern chief executive lives behind a wall of communications operatives, many of whom ladle out slop meant to obscure rather than reveal.

headline: U.S. Drones Patrolling Its Skies Provoke Outrage in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — A month after the last American troops left Iraq, the State Department is operating a small fleet of surveillance drones here to help protect the United States Embassy and consulates, as well as American personnel. Some senior Iraqi officials expressed outrage at the program, saying the unarmed aircraft are an affront to Iraqi sovereignty.

headline: Rural Land Grabs
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Mixtape of the Revolution
text: DEF JAM will probably never sign them, but Cheikh Oumar Cyrille Touré, from a small town about 100 miles southeast of Dakar, Senegal, and Hamada Ben Amor, a 22-year-old man from a port city 170 miles southeast of Tunis, may be two of the most influential rappers in the history of hip-hop.

headline: It’s Time to Police the N.Y.P.D.
text: THE Police Department has the formidable responsibility of keeping New Yorkers safe from a terrorist attack. It is entrusted with significant powers and broad discretion in how to use them. It has done an admirable job in preventing violence. But last week, we were reminded that no government entity with such powers should operate free from independent oversight.

headline: Santorum to Return to Campaigning on Monday, in the Midwest
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., — Rick Santorum will return to the campaign trail on Monday afternoon, but instead of coming back to Florida before Tuesday’s primary, he will head to the Midwest.

headline: Not Diseases, but Categories of Suffering
text: Scotland, Conn.

headline: For Family of Burned Woman, an Offer, but No Help
text: For the family of a woman burned to death inside an elevator in Brooklyn, the apparent act of generosity could not have come at a better time.

headline: Facebook Users to Put Political Views Up in Lights on Times Square
text: As the country prepares for this year’s presidential election, political devotees have been following the nuances of every debate, caucus, straw poll and primary. A new application for Facebook users, however, is intended to encourage those who are not as engaged to talk about the election issues that are most important to them.

headline: Birth Control and Reproductive Rights
text: It was good news that the Obama administration withstood pressure from Roman Catholic bishops and social conservatives to deny contraceptive coverage for millions of American women who work for religiously affiliated employers. Kathleen Sebelius, the Health and Human Services secretary, rejected broad exemptions from a new rule requiring all health plans to cover birth control, without a deductible or co-payment.

headline: Back With Patriots, Branch Returns to Familiar Stage
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — As Deion Branch prepares to play in his third Super Bowl, he has a very specific to-do list that has nothing to do with the Giants.

headline: Online Ambitions, and a Dash of Real Estate, Drive Newspaper Deals
text: IF the future of media is digital, who would want to buy a newspaper? Many people, it turns out.

headline: BlackBerry Under Siege in Europe
text: The iPhone has taken a big bite out of the BlackBerry in a market where the older phone once dominated: business customers in North America.

headline: After Florida, a New Tenor for the G.O.P. Campaign
text: As polls showedMitt Romney pulling far ahead ofNewt Gingrich in Florida, both campaigns have begun looking ahead to a period of campaigning that is likely to look and feel very different.

headline: Justice Department Official to Join Davis Polk Law Firm
text: Greg D. Andres, a senior Justice Department official, is leaving the government to join the law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell, according to two people with direct knowledge of his move.

headline: A Reform for Fair Courts
text: With rising special-interest spending in state judicial elections, there is an urgent need to protect judicial integrity from the flood of campaign cash. Tennessee is leading the way with a new rule prohibiting judges from hearing cases when campaign spending by lawyers or litigants raises a reasonable question of their impartiality.

headline: Djokovic Prevails in Australia
text: Novak Djokovic won the Australian Open title by outlasting Rafael Nadal, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2, 6-7 (5), 7-5.

headline: Moving Ahead on Marriage Equality
text: Gov. Chris Christie’s announcement last week that he would veto a measure to legalize same-sex marriage in New Jersey is maddening, but sadly predictable. He vowed to block marriage equality when he ran for office in 2009 and is now calling for a statewide referendum.

headline: Trampoline’s New Frontier
text: Professional trampolinist Julien Roberge is hoping to make the wall trampoline an extreme sport.

headline: New Strategy, Old Pentagon Budget
text: The $259 billion in budget cuts over the next five years announced by the Pentagon may sound like a lot. But they are mainly a scaling back of previously projected spending — the delights of the Washington budget games.

headline: The Austerity Debacle
text: Last week the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, a British think tank, released a startling chart comparing the current slump with past recessions and recoveries. It turns out that by one important measure — changes in real G.D.P. since the recession began — Britain is doing worse this time than it did during the Great Depression. Four years into the Depression, British G.D.P. had regained its previous peak; four years after the Great Recession began, Britain is nowhere close to regaining its lost ground.

headline: Defying Gravity With Creativity
text: QUEBEC — One by one, five athletes hurl themselves off a wall beneath the sweeping arches of what once was the St.-Esprit church. Sixteen feet below, they land on a trampoline, snap back toward the wall and send themselves outward again.

headline: A Tearful Response to a Final-Hole Collapse
text: SAN DIEGO – After building a five-stroke lead through 54 holes of the Farmers Insurance Open, Kyle Stanley described himself as “kind of an internal guy.” And it was true. For 71 holes, Stanley betrayed no emotion, his body language a study in stoicism.

headline: Search for Aliens Is on Again, but Next Quest Is Finding Money
text: HAT CREEK, Calif. — E.T. might be phoning, but do we care enough to take the call?

headline: For Young Wizards, a Difficult Season and a Shaky Future
text: WASHINGTON — On Jan. 10, when the Washington Wizards won their first game of this truncated N.B.A. season after eight losses, the talk in the locker room was of relief, but also of candy and coins.

headline: Insider Jury May Hear From a Top Aide at Berkshire
text: Ajit Jain, a top lieutenant at Berkshire Hathaway, is on the short list of candidates to succeed Warren E. Buffett, Berkshire’s chief executive.

headline: Flourishing Without Packers as a Shadow
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The connection between the University of Wisconsin-Green Bay and the iconic N.F.L. franchise it shares a city with goes back to the 1960s. As the story goes, Vince Lombardi, the legendary Packers coach, advised the university’s first chancellor, Edward W. Weidner, to make men’s soccer the signature athletic program rather than football, in part to avoid competing with the Packers for community attention.

headline: Afghan Family, Led by Father Who Called Girls a Disgrace, Is Guilty of Murder
text: OTTAWA — It began with a puzzling and grisly discovery in 2009: a car submerged in a 19th-century canal lock with the bodies of three teenage girls and a middle-aged woman inside. On Sunday, the father, the mother and a brother of the girls were each convicted of four counts of first-degree murder.

headline: Romney and Gingrich Scrap Amid Shifting Fortunes
text: HIALEAH, Fla. — His fortunes turned upside down in the span of a week, Newt Gingrich sought on Sunday to rally his grass-roots coalition against the heavy campaign machinery of Mitt Romney, whose resurgence was punctuated by new polls showing his lead in Florida widening two days ahead of the Republican presidential primary here.

headline: Young Golfers Emerge as Woods Fades From View
text: SAN DIEGO

headline: Food Network Executive to Run YouTube Channel
text: Bruce Seidel, who oversaw shows for the Food Network and the Cooking Channel on cable, is moving online to a forthcoming food channel for YouTube.

headline: In Later Years, Rediscovering Love but Finding the Rent Too Much to Pay
text: Norma Zevallos does not speak much English, having lived in the United States for only eight months. But she knows the words to one of her favorite American songs, a classic by the Platters that she likes to sing for her husband.

headline: Fishing Rules, a Different Sort of Nun and Other New York Tales

headline: A Florida Bush Stays Silent, and to Many, That Says a Lot
text: MIAMI — A steady stream of endorsements has been flowing to Mitt Romney, with his campaign promoting Republicans who are giving their blessing to his presidential candidacy. Yet on the eve of the Florida primary, he has been unable to land the biggest catch of all: Jeb Bush.

headline: Playing Against Type, Belichick Is in Jovial Mood as Team Arrives
text: INDIANAPOLIS — When Bill Belichick coached the Giants’ defense in the 1980s, he spoke in such a monotone that the players branded him Captain Sominex. Even now, at his fifth Super Bowl as the coach of the New England Patriots, when Belichick arrives in a room, he is not expected to bring levity with him.

text: NYT Front Page for 01/30/2012

headline: For ProPublica, More E-Books
text: ProPublica, the nonprofit news organization known for its investigative journalism, is about to expand its e-book efforts.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for December (Monday); the S.& P./Case-Shiller home price index for November, the Chicago purchasing managers index for January, and consumer confidence for January (Tuesday); ADP employment for January, the I.S.M. manufacturing index for January and construction spending for December (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and productivity for the fourth quarter (Thursday); and unemployment for January, the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for January and factory orders for December (Friday).

headline: Iraq’s Sunni Leaders End Their Boycott
text: In a development in Iraq’s political crisis, the country’s Sunni leaders said on Sunday that they would end their boycott of Parliament. In an article in Monday’s Times, Tim Arango reports on the decision by members of the Iraqiya coalition, a largely Sunni-backed group of lawmakers.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Critics of SoHo Proposal Ask, You Call This Improvement?
text: Living in SoHo for decades has taught Sean Sweeney how to urge people to hurry up in several languages, though not without his blood pressure shooting up.

headline: Hamas Leader Takes Rare Trip to Jordan
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Khaled Meshal, the leader of Hamas, made a rare and pointedly low-key visit to Jordan on Sunday, days after Hamas officials signaled that he had effectively abandoned the group’s base in Damascus, the Syrian capital.

headline: Gaborik Touches Off a Typical Goalfest
text: OTTAWA — The N.H.L.’s two biggest stars were missing from the All-Star Game, but that did not seem to matter. The event was its usual just-for-laughs exhibition, the climax of a happy weekend for a league that continues to prosper but may be only months from a labor impasse.

headline: Bound for London, U.S. Keeps Foot on Gas
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Pia Sundhage, the coach of the United States women’s soccer team, wanted an honest answer.

headline: Sarkozy Unveils Tax Raises but Not a Re-election Bid
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy, insisting that he was acting as a head of state — not a presidential candidate — announced Sunday that he would raise consumer taxes to make French companies more competitive and reduce the national budget deficit.

headline: Florida’s Diverse Electorate and Economic Climate
text: A look at Florida’s electorate and electoral climate ahead of Tuesday’s Republican primary.

headline: The Caucus | Voters on the I-4 Corridor
text: Susan Saulny talks to voters along Interstate 4 - which runs through the center of Florida and is a crucial swing region - ahead of the state's primary on Tuesday.

headline: Sour Mood for Voters in Florida
text: A journey along Interstate 4, through central Florida, reveals despair about the economy.

headline: Years of Despair Add to Uncertainty in Florida Race
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — Only four years ago, life certainly seemed on the upswing for Kate and Marcus Freeman, young professionals who had recently moved from Worcester, Mass., into a new house here in sun-splashed central Florida, where they hoped to enjoy the warmer weather and new jobs. He was an accountant. She would be teaching preschool.

headline: ‘The Help’ Tops the S.A.G. Awards
text: “The Help” led the Screen Actors Guild awards on Sunday night, taking home three honors: best cast performance (the S.A.G. equivalent of best picture), best actress for Viola Davis and best supporting actress for Octavia Spencer. Among the men, Jean Dujardin of “The Artist” was named best actor, and Christopher Plummer from “Beginners,” best supporting actor.

headline: Brees Is No Flutie, Blowing  Drop Kick in Pro Bowl
text: There isn’t much to say about the Pro Bowl, as usual, but at least we have this:

headline: Ruling on Contraception Draws Battle Lines at Catholic Colleges
text: Bridgette Dunlap, a Fordham University law student, knew that the school’s health plan had to pay for birth control pills, in keeping with New York state law. What she did not find out until she was in an examining room, “in the paper dress,” was that the student health service — in keeping with Roman Catholic tenets — would simply refuse to prescribe them.

headline: Corrections: January 30
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Excerpts From a Report on Women’s Health
text: When the Obama administration wanted a list of preventive services that women needed to stay healthy and that should be insured with no co-pay, it commissioned a report by the Institute of Medicine, an independent group of doctors and researchers. Increased access to contraception made the list. The institute’s report found the following:

headline: Proposal to Cut Some Felonies From Records
text: The New York State Bar Association is proposing a change to state law that would allow more types of criminal records to be sealed, saying the shift would give offenders who stay out of trouble a better chance to rebuild their lives.

headline: Newt Gingrich and the Future of the Right
text: In 1999, shortly after the Senate voted to acquit President Clinton on two charges of impeachment stemming from his affair with the intern Monica Lewinsky, Paul Weyrich — mastermind of the union of the Republican Party and the Christian right, a founder of the Heritage Foundation, the Moral Majority and the Free Congress Foundation — threw up his hands in despair.

headline: Brett Kimmel: Create a 'To-Die-For' Place
text: Brett Kimmel was interested in school reform and decided the best way to change schools was to become a teacher. Then he was interested in creating a place where teachers would crave to work, and he created his own school, the  Washington Heights Expeditionary Learning School, also known as WHEELS. As its first senior class is about to graduate, and every student has applied to college, he thinks there are lessons here for others who want to make systemic change.

headline: One-Room School Also One-Student School
text: GREENOUGH, Mont. — At a time when many schools are concerned about overcrowded classrooms, the Sunset school in this ranching community has a different problem — keeping its lone student at her desk so it can remain open.

headline: Rangers’ Gaborik Is M.V.P. of All-Star Game
text: OTTAWA — The Rangers just keep rolling, through win after win in the first half of the regular season and victory in the Winter Classic, to first place in the Eastern Conference.

headline: State Department’s Drones in Iraq Stir Outrage
text: With American troops gone, the State Department is using unarmed aerial drones in Iraq to help protect the United States Embassy, consulates and personnel, and senior Iraqi officials are calling the program an affront to the country’s sovereignty. In an article in Monday’s Times, Eric Schmitt and Michael S. Schmidt report on the program and a possible expansion of drone operations by the American government into its diplomatic arm.

headline: In a Gang-Ridden City, New Efforts to Fight Crime While Cutting Costs
text: SALINAS, Calif. — People in California generally know two things about this agricultural city nestled among lettuce fields east of Monterey’s beaches and hotels: John Steinbeck was born here, and it has a big problem with gangs.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 29
text: A look at the day in sports, from the United States Figure Skating Championships to the N.H.L. All-Star Game.

headline: Word of the Day | nirvana
text: nirvana •\nir-ˈvä-nə, (ˌ)nər-\• noun

headline: Drive Time in Myanmar
text: HONG KONG — There might have been a deep sense of foreboding — along with renewed hopes and trills of excitement — as Aung San Suu Kyi traveled from her home in Yangon to the rural southern coast of Myanmar this past weekend.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Moments Savored, Loose Ends Tied Up
text: Sunday night’s chapter of “The Good Wife,” titled “Another Ham Sandwich,” was like a highlight reel — an agglomeration of the sort of too-good-to-be-true moments that are usually rationed, two or three to an episode. Alicia saying to Will, as the grand jury considered indicting him, “So use me.” The ever smug David Lee telling Will: “That’s how a pro does it. You’re welcome.” The final, reassuring reveal that Kalinda was working a long con on the prosecutors rather than selling out Will, followed by Dana slapping an impassive Kalinda in the courthouse. A classic David Lee-Eli Gold confrontation. Peter finally snapping and admitting to Alicia that this entire plot line was driven by his anger over her affair.

headline: Riddles In The Dark: Is a Temple’s Treasure Worth Billions?
text: A committee appointed by the Supreme Court of India will return to the vaults of the Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Thiruvananthapuram on the southern tip of India in the second week of February. Their task: try to put a value on what is believed to be the largest temple treasure in the world.

headline: Punjab, Bread Basket of India, Hungers for Change
text: Punjab State goes to polls Monday to elect representatives to its legislature. Once considered the pioneer of green revolution in India, the state is now struggling with slow industrial growth, Reuters reports.

headline: Homai Vyarawalla, Pioneering Indian Photojournalist, Dies at 98
text: Homai Vyarawalla, India’s first female photojournalist who chronicled the country’s march toward independence and captured enduring images of leaders like Mohandas K. Gandhi, Ho Chi Minh and various American presidents of the mid-20th century, died on Jan. 15 in Vadodara, in west India, Haresh Pandya wrote in an obituary for The New York Times.

headline: A Conversation With: Akhtarul Wasey
text: Following the controversy over author Salman Rushdie’s appearance at the Jaipur Literature Festival, which ultimately ended with even a video conference with Mr. Rushdie being cancelled, India Ink is speaking with Muslim leaders about the situation, their feelings about his book “The Satanic Verses” and what role politics played in the affair.

headline: News Quiz | Jan. 30, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: 12 Arrested at Manhattan March for Oakland Protesters
text: Twelve protesters were arrested Sunday night on a march through Lower Manhattan to show support for Occupy protesters in Oakland, where a violent confrontation erupted on Saturday night between the police and demonstrators who tried to take over an empty convention center.

headline: China Denies Sudan Freed Workers Held by Rebels
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The Sudanese military said Monday that it had rescued 14 of the 29 Chinese road workers kidnapped by rebels in southern Sudan, but China denied early Tuesday that any workers had been freed.

headline: Jan. 30, 1948 | Mahatma Gandhi Assassinated
text: On Jan. 30, 1948, Indian political and spiritual leader Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi was murdered by the Hindu nationalist Nathuram Godse, who fired three shots at close range as the 78-year-old Gandhi entered a prayer meeting.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 30, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Joe Paterno, Longtime Penn State Coach, Dies at 85.”

text: WHO is Danah Boyd?WHO are the subjects of her research?

headline: Odd Shadows in a Sunny Land

headline: Bedsheet Revolution
text: VALPARAÍSO, Chile —On a Valparaíso street choked solid with traffic not long ago, I looked up as Chilean students on a balcony unfurled a bedsheet banner. “Please pardon the bother,” it read, “but we’re having a revolution.”

headline: Angry Over Austerity Measures, Belgian Workers Go on Strike
text: BRUSSELS — Belgium was paralyzed by a national strike Monday as unions, angry over austerity measures, timed the protest to coincide with a one-day meeting of European Union leaders here in the capital.

headline: Fables and Fantasy Infuse 40th Hong Kong Arts Festival
text: Fables, fantasy and spirituality inspire many of the performances in the 40th annual Hong Kong Arts Festival, which runs through March 8. This year’s festival features over 160 productions, staged at 17 venues.

headline: Fear and Trembling on the Post-Application Roller Coaster
text: A couple of weeks ago, I started teaching Saturday morning tot ice skating classes at an arena near my house. These children scramble through the door and pile onto the ice. Some are barely 3 years old. Some can’t stand up in skates without being hoisted under the armpits. These are the students our program director calls “Very-Beginners.”

headline: Traffic Jam Economics
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: How Should You Handle the End of a Friendship?
text: Sometimes, good friends simply “grow apart.” Interests change, social circles shift, a family moves away–these are just a few reasons a friendship might fail apart. What is the best way to handle a friendship’s end? What have you learned from your experiences or from witnessing other friends grow apart?

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Chief Waives Bonus
text: LONDON — The chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland, which was effectively nationalized during the financial crisis, has decided to turn down his bonus after coming under heavy pressure from British politicians.

headline: Iran Offers to Extend Inspection by U.N. Team
text: LONDON — Iran’s foreign minister offered on Monday to extend a three-day visit to his country by United Nations inspectors in what seemed to be a further attempt to lower the strident tone of a crisis with the West over Tehran’s nuclear program after the imposition of new economic sanctions.

headline: Q. & A.: Mobile Phones on the New York City Subway

headline: Super Bowl Arrival: Bill Belichick Transcript
text: “I never had too much hospitality here until I went for it on fourth and 2, and since then, I’ve been greeted in a lot more friendly manner than I have in the past.” — Bill Belichick, Patriots coach, after being asked about Indiana’s hospitality

headline: In Australia, Djokovic Was Unbeatable, but Not Untouchable
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The leading men played overtime in Rod Laver Arena in the homestretch of the Australian Open this year, and they often exchanged pleasantries with Laver.

headline: Gary Marcus, Cognitive Psychologist, Answers Readers’ Questions
text: At 13, an age when most boys want to learn the guitar, Gary Marcus, decided he wanted to be a scientist. Twenty-five years later he had become one of the country’s best known cognitive psychologists, with major papers and three general-interest books on the workings of the human mind and a position running New York University’s Center for Language and Music. And he wanted to play the guitar. He said he had no rhythm, but spent his sabbatical finding a way to learn to play the guitar and wrote a book about his effort, discussed in this New York Times article last week. Dr. Marcus agreed to answer readers’ questions about the fears and challenges of learning new skills as an adult. Here are his responses.

headline: This Week in Small Business: A Twitter Lesson
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Starbucks Comes to India
text: Starbucks Coffee, the world’s largest coffee company, became the first foreign retailer to enter India Monday, after the government loosened rules about how single brand companies can invest here.

headline: Former UBS Trader Pleads Not Guilty to Fraud
text: 4:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Plea for Southern Treasures
text: The Southern Environmental Law Center, a Virginia-based nonprofit legal advocacy group, has released its 2012 list of the Top 10 endangered places in the Southeast, environmentally speaking. While the list changes from year to year, certain places like the Chesapeake Bay remain a top concern — and issues like pollution from coal-fired power plants and the protection of public lands and old-growth forests are recurring themes. While the list only considers six states, the issues raised by each site resonate nationally, and even globally.

headline: British Regulator Appoints Senior Investment Banking Adviser
text: LONDON — The Financial Services Authority, Britain’s financial regulator, said on Monday that Will Samuel had been appointed a senior adviser in its investment banking supervisory unit.

text: For the largest venture capital firms, there is no shortage of capital.

text: From the editorial page

headline: Pro Bowl Is Missing a Skills Competition
text: The N.F.L. has been called the No Fun League by some because of its strict rules on touchdown celebrations.

headline: Pairings: Party Picadillo
text: With some Douros as cheap as a pizza, and just as bold, I’d think of them as party wines, to serve to a crowd fortified with big sandwiches, wings and meaty casseroles. Even at the high end, most are not wines to contemplate but to quaff with slabs of seared red meat.

headline: One Sip Says Portugal
text: THE Douro Valley region of Portugal has so much going in its favor, it’s almost ridiculous.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: 5 U.S. Banks Tally Exposure to Europe’s Debt Maelstrom  |  Five large American banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, have more than $80 billion of exposure to Italy, Spain, Portugal, Ireland and Greece, the most economically stressed nations in the euro currency zone, according to a New York Times analysis of the banks’ financial disclosures.

headline: Bank Organization to Buy Stake in Russian Stock Market
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire a stake in a Russian stock exchange as part of an effort to encourage transparent capital markets in the country.

headline: Remembering Gandhi on Martyrs’ Day
text: Carved stone footprints dot the path that Mahatma Gandhi took toward a prayer meeting in New Delhi 64 years ago, ending where his frail body was torn by an assassin’s bullets.

headline: Portugal Suffers as Loss of Confidence in Bonds Sends Yields Higher
text: Investors fled out of bonds of weaker European countries on Monday, sending yields on Portuguese government bonds to a record high over concerns that the euro zone debt troubles were spreading beyond Greece.

headline: China Says It Curbed Spill of Toxic Metal in River
text: BEIJING — Officials in southern China appear to have averted environmental calamity by halting the spread of a toxic metal that had threatened to foul drinking water for tens of millions of people, the state media reported Monday.

headline: Sundance Documentaries Transform Data Into Stories
text: Over the weekend, “The House I Live In,” Eugene Jarecki’s heart-heavy investigation into the American war on drugs, nabbed the grand jury prize for documentary at the Sundance Film Festival. Mr. Jarecki’s other movies include “The Trials of Henry Kissinger,” about you know who, and a 2005 grand jury prize winner, “Why We Fight,” about the American military industrial complex. Notably, one of this year’s jury members was Charles Ferguson, whose documentaries include “No End in Sight” and “Inside Job,” and who, like Mr. Jarecki, has a methodological gift for transforming boatloads of information into both political arguments and eminently watchable narratives.

headline: Bocuse d’Or USA Winner Is a Veteran Competitor
text: Richard Rosendale, executive chef of the Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., won the gold medal at the Bocuse d’Or USA  competition on Sunday at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y. He and his commis, Corey Siegel, a 21-year-old senior apprentice at the Greenbrier, will compete at the international Bocuse d’Or in France, next Jan. 29 and 30.

headline: Monday Reading: Winter Getaways for Every Age
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Bank of America Taps Meissner as Head of Investment Banking
text: The management shuffle at Bank of America continues.

headline: The Florida Primary
text: Republican candidates campaigned hard in Florida, but Mitt Romney won a decisive victory.

headline: Private School Tuition in New York City 'Higher Than Harvard's'
text: Private school tuition rates have been on the rise in the city -- so much so that the annual tuition is hovering on the brink of $40,000 a year, even for the lowest grades. That means that some parents pay more for their child's private school tuition than they would if the child were attending Harvard, The New York Times reported this weekend.

headline: Pep Boys to Be Sold in $791 Million Buyout
text: Pep Boys is prepped for a tuneup.

headline: On a Day Full of Go Daddy Girls, There Will Be Beckham in His Underwear
text: When word got out that the soccer star David Beckham would appear in a Super Bowl commercial for the H&M retail chain, selling a new line of underwear named after him, the speculation began: just how revealing would the spot be, given that it is to appear on a broadcast network (NBC) in prime time?

headline: Here Come the Cloud Cartels
text: What kind of cartels will deliver business computing, and how should businesses respond?

headline: U.S. Embassy in Cairo Shields 3 Americans
text: CAIRO — The United States Embassy in Cairo is giving shelter to three American citizens to protect them from potential arrest by the Egyptian authorities in a politically charged investigation of four American-backed nongovernmental organizations operating here, colleagues said Monday.

headline: Morning T | Pierre Hardy
text: In this installment, T’s Online Editor Jane Herman talks to the designer about his work for Hermés, his store in New York and how he can love two very different pairs of shoes at the same time.

headline: Technology Companies Confront a Scourge of the Internet

headline: In Million-Dollar Theft Case, Church Worker With a Secret Past
text: For eight years, the woman worked in accounts payable for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, gaining the trust of her superiors.

headline: We’re Not So Bad. Really.
text: Over the last few days City Hall has noted that more people came to New York in 2011 than it had previously thought. The mayor made the point again on Sunday in his weekly radio talk. It seems that 50.5 million masochists from foreign countries and other parts of the United States journeyed to our city last year and spent $32 billion.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Wall Street Journal: Eric Ripert discusses his favorite airport food in New York and around the world. He doesn’t mention World Bean coffee in the Delta terminal at La Guardia, one of the best pour-overs in the city. Are they still there? — Nick Fox

headline: Welcome
text: Whenever I bump into my friend Felix Salmon, the ridiculously prolific business blogger at Reuters, he starts pestering me about getting back to blogging again. I point out to him that blogging is what he gets paid for, whereas for someone like me, blogging is something I’m supposed to be doing “in between” the things I get paid for, like writing Op-Ed columns as well as articles for the Times Magazine.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Reading Rupert’s Tweets, and B.&N. Wears a White Hat
text: At 80, Rupert Murdoch has jumped into Twitter with both feet, among a rare number of moguls who share their thoughts as soon as they pop up. David Carr assesses his corpus of writing – 107 Tweets and counting. They are “devoid of nuance, partisan in the extreme and prone to crankiness,” he writes; in other words, vintage Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Commerzbank Chief Defends Not Paying Past Bonuses
text: LONDON — Martin Blessing, the chief executive of Commerzbank, said on Monday that he thought he had acted “honorably” when the bank decided not to pay 2008 bonuses to 104 investment bankers.

headline: Grand Old Stage at Ryman Auditorium Is Being Replaced
text: Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, home of the scuffed oak stage most associated with the Grand Ole Opry, is getting an overhaul, The Associated Press reported.

headline: In Final Florida Push, Romney Takes Aim at Gingrich
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Mitt Romney may have set a new personal record here Monday morning.

headline: Europe Zeroes In on Shipping Emissions
text: New rules to limit pollution from ships are set to start moving through the European Parliament on Tuesday, with the specter of potential environmental contamination from a stricken cruise ship lending momentum to the debate.

headline: On Eve of Florida Primary, Romney and Gingrich Travel State in Appeal to Voters
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — With just one day to go before Florida’s primary, Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich hopscotched around the state by bus and chartered jet on Monday, mostly along the vote-rich Interstate 4 corridor, as they sought to appear on as many television screens in major media markets as possible, hoping to give voters a last glimpse of their images and messages.

headline: Talbots Reconsiders Sycamore’s Lifeline
text: Talbots may find a home with Sycamore Partners after all.

headline: Polls Give Romney Commanding Lead
text: TAMPA, Fla. — What a difference a week makes, in a primary state like none before it.

headline: Victory, Elusive in Nascar, Finds A.J. Allmendinger in Rolex 24 at Daytona
text: Having signed recently with Roger Penske Racing for the 2012 Nascar Sprint Cup season, A.J. Allmendinger might have been expected to pass the weeks before the Daytona 500, on Feb. 26, by visualizing races, holding conference calls with his pit crew and familiarizing himself with his new racecar. Instead, he’s busy winning races in anything but a stock car.

headline: The Rise of the Toilet Texter
text: We know where some of you are reading this.

headline: ‘Summertime,’ Rendered 25,000 Ways
text: Two Sunday Reviews ago, I wrote about the long history of “Porgy and Bess” as a prism through which African-Americans have viewed their own history. I am a relatively recent devotee of what I like to think of as the “real” “Porgy and Bess,” the full-length opera. (So far as I can tell, there is only one performance of the opera ever recorded on DVD — a 1993 Trevor Nunn production with Simon Rattle conducting, released in 2001.) Like most people, I came to “Porgy and Bess” through some of the many popular recordings of its famous songs. Indeed, I received several e-mails questioning my sanity for writing about the opera without mentioning two of the most famous recordings: the Ella Fitzgerald-Louis Armstrong version, and the equally sublime Miles Davis recording.

headline: In Indianapolis, the Cute Won’t Quit
text: INDIANAPOLIS – In a great article examining how this city landed (and then prepared to host) Super Bowl XLVI, my colleague John Branch described how local eighth-graders were involved in delivering bids to the N.F.L. owners. It was innovative, thoughtful and downright cute, and surely enhanced the city’s proposal.

headline: Really? The Claim: Never Go to Bed Angry
text: THE FACTS

headline: Study Finds 50-Year Burst of Tropical Eruptions Spawned Enduring ‘Little Ice Age’
text: A remarkable paper coming in the Jan. 31 issue of Geophysical Research Letters has a title that says it all: “Abrupt onset of the Little Ice Age triggered by volcanism and sustained by sea-ice/ocean feedbacks.”

headline: At Sundance, Kickstarter Resembled a Movie Studio, but Without the Egos
text: One night last week there was a late-night party at Sundance — one of many — this one hosted by an outfit that had helped finance 10 percent of the festival’s slate, 17 movies in all, including four that were in competition.

headline: Off-Duty Detective Fatally Shoots Robber, Police Say
text: Updated, 3:00 p.m. | An off-duty police detective fatally shot a teenager who tried to rob him Sunday night in Bushwick, Brooklyn, according to the police, who offered the following account:

headline: Fewer Beds for Men Entering Nursing Homes
text: Searching for a nursing home for his hospitalized father in semirural Massachusetts, a friend of mine recently came up against an unexpected barrier. It’s harder to find a bed for a man than for a woman.

headline: Mother, Accused of Abandoning Children, Is Arrested
text: A woman who abandoned her 3-year-old and 5-year-old daughters in front of a Brooklyn housing project on Sunday afternoon has been arrested, the police said.

headline: The Get | Dolce & Gabbana Bag
text: “Often the attention to details makes all the difference,” says the Dolce & Gabbana co-designer Stefano Gabbana, referring to the design of his and Domenico Dolce’s newest spring bag, which hits stores this week. Structured and clean, with a handle made for elbow-hooking and a padlock made of gold metal (speaking of details), the style comes in three sizes and is available in a variety of materials, from aluminum foil to straw and python, and in a range of gorgeous colors (pastels, primaries) and finishes (metallic and matte). For the minimalist, the classic leather style suits best. For the quirky carrier, a metallic picnic purse version is perfect. And, for the vintage-inspired, a dainty woven version like this one in dusty rose does the trick. Pick your poison.

headline: Russia Says Syria Has Agreed to Talks
text: MOSCOW—Russia announced on Monday that it had convinced Bashar al-Assad’s government in Syria to start informal negotiations in Moscow with representatives of the opposition in an effort to end a bloody uprising that has left thousands dead.

headline: An Update on Sahar Gul
text: Some readers might remember the last time I visited Sahar Gul, when I managed to get past the bureaucracy of the hospital in Kabul where she was being treated and her relatives, doctors and supporters welcomed me to her bedside.

headline: A Certified Grand Slam Classic
text: Normally, the weekend before the Super Bowl is a quiet one, the landscape cleared of meaningful football — the Pro Bowl not counting as meaningful or football — aided by the N.H.L. taking its season siesta at the same time for its All-Star game, but the Australian Open had other plans this year. Usually, it’s the Grand Slam that few in this hemisphere realizes is going on because A) it’s played in the American Insomniac Time Zone and B) doesn’t tennis have an offseason and isn’t it now? (Answer: it lasted three minutes and no).

headline: Street Style: Houndstooth
text: The best of readers’ street style for the week of Jan. 23.

headline: In a Departure, USA Network Plans a Washington Political Drama
text: This summer the cable network known for its sunny, feel-good shows is heading to a town famous for its shortage of good feelings: USA Network will take on Washington.

headline: Honda Releases Super Bowl Ad for CR-V, Ferris Bueller Included
text: A 10-second teaser video for a Honda Super Bowl ad featuring Matthew Broderick, in a reprise of his fondly remembered title-character turn in 1986’s “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off,” appeared on Jan. 26 and amassed more than 4 million views on YouTube by Monday.

headline: Musical About Charlie Chaplin Heading to Broadway
text: A musical about the silent screen star Charlie Chaplin might seem like an oxymoron. But such a show is nevertheless Broadway bound, courtesy, in part, of the producers behind this season’s coming Broadway production of “Jesus Christ Superstar” — Bob and Mindy Rich and John and Claire Caudwell — along with the producer Roy Gabay.

headline: Accepted at Vassar, for About Three Hours
text: For those of you who missed Matt Flegenheimer’s piece in The Times on Sunday about 122 early-decision applicants to Vassar College who viewed an errant test letter that led them to believe they had been accepted,  Mr. Flegenheimer details the heartbreak that ensued:

headline: If Ritalin Has ‘Gone Wrong,’ What’s the Right Way to Cope?
text: Perhaps the most easily drawn conclusion about L. Alan Sroufe, who wrote Ritalin Gone Wrong for the Jan. 29 Week in Review, is that he does not have a child who suffers from what he calls “problems in focusing” — or what most call attention deficit hyperactivity disorder — and who has benefited from Ritalin or one of the many other drug therapies available.

headline: A Texan in Maine
text: Rep. Ron Paul of Texas has largely passed on the sunny campaigning in Florida in favor of spending time in Maine, which holds its Republican presidential caucus on Feb. 4.

headline: Fighting Escalates in Syria as Opposition Rejects Russian Plan
text: UNITED NATIONS — As Syrian forces pushed rebels back from strongholds near Damascus on Monday, some of the world’s top diplomats converged on the United Nations to try to press President Bashar al-Assad to leave office through a Security Council resolution.

headline: After a Year of Delays, the First Starbucks Is to Open in Tea-Loving India This Fall
text: MUMBAI, India — After years of studying the Indian market, Starbucks Coffee said Monday that it would open its first store here by September through a 50-50 joint venture with Tata Global Beverages, a unit of the largest business group in India.

headline: Romney on the Campaign Trail in Florida
text: After the unexpected loss to Newt Gingrich in South Carolina, Mitt Romney and his team shifted focus to a state where he is gaining ground in the polls.

headline: A Fresh Take on the World Food Problem
text: The global food crisis has dragged on so long now that is beginning to seem less like a crisis and more like a permanent state of affairs. Prices did take a dip late last year, owing to bumper harvests. But reserves remain tight, and the Food and Agriculture Organization reports that prices are still at some of the highest levels seen in decades.

headline: Guns N’ Roses Plans Minitour, With Three Shows in New York
text: Guns N’ Roses will play three concerts at relatively small clubs in New York City in February as part of the run-up to its induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in April, a publicist announced on Monday morning.

headline: Merger of Actors Unions Keeps Up the Momentum
text: LOS ANGELES — A planned merger between the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists, which has been clearing hurdles of one sort or another for many months, cleared another on Saturday when the Aftra board gave its approval. The SAG board had already done so.

headline: What the S.A.G. Awards May Portend for the Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES — “Now it’s actually a race; now it’s actually going to be fun,” one Oscar-watcher whispered after the Screen Actors Guild awards on Sunday, which scrambled predictions by picking “The Help” as the best movie of the year. The actors guild also chose the star of “The Artist,” Jean Dujardin, over the leading hopeful George Clooney (and others) for best actor, and Viola Davis of “The Help” for best actress. Octavia Spencer and Christopher Plummer continued their lockstep toward Oscar in the supporting categories.

headline: Look of The Moment | Emma Stone
text: The Look: Black Rose. A glamorous tea-length dress with a hip-defining waistline and embroidered bustier needs only a heel with the skinniest ankle strap and a lip with the rosiest tint to make it feel finished.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Ronen Bergman on Whether Israel Will Attack Iran
text: Ronen Bergman is a political and military analyst for the Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth and is currently at work on a history of the Mossad. He wrote this week’s cover story on the possibility of an Israeli attack on Iran in 2012 to prevent Iran from becoming a nuclear power.

headline: Artists’ Development in Harlem Gets Final Financing
text: The construction of El Barrio’s Artspace (P.S. 109), a development of housing and work spaces for artists planned for East Harlem, will be aided by low-income housing tax credits from the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, Artspace Projects has announced.

headline: Segregation Curtailed in U.S. Cities, Study Finds
text: More than 40 years after the federal government enacted fair-housing legislation and the Great Migration of blacks from the South began to ebb, residential segregation in metropolitan America has been significantly curtailed, according to a study released Monday.

headline: W.P.S. Suspends Operations
text: 5:26 p.m. | Updated Less than a day after the United States women’s national team won the regional qualifying tournament for this summer’s London Olympics, the top professional soccer league for women in the United States, the five-team Women’s Professional Soccer, announced that it has suspended operations for the 2012 season and hoped to return to the field with eight teams in 2013.

headline: New Sex Education Mandate Taking Effect
text: A new sex education mandate is taking effect in New York City public schools, starting Tuesday in the high schools. All public middle schools and high schools are required to include sex education lessons in existing health classes. Many schools already provide sex ed, but New York City is now mandating those lessons for the first time. Here is a primer on how the new program will work.

headline: The 2012 Presidential Campaign, Week by Week
text: Every week during the 2012 presidential campaign, The Times posted a slide show recapping the events of the past seven days.

headline: Bill to Prohibit Insider Trading by Members of Congress Advances in Senate
text: WASHINGTON — In an effort to regain public trust, the Senate voted Monday to take up a bill that would prohibit members of Congress from trading stocks and other securities on the basis of confidential information they receive as lawmakers.

headline: Lower-Income Families May Pay More for Auto Insurance
text: Updated | Jan. 31 Added information from industry trade groups.

headline: Helen Gurley Brown Gives $30 Million for Media Innovation at Columbia and Stanford
text: With the backing of a $30 million donation from Helen Gurley Brown, the former editor of Cosmopolitan, the graduate school of journalism at Columbia University and the school of engineering at Stanford University on Monday said that they would create a center for media innovation.

headline: Does Google+ Offer Businesses an Edge?
text: There was a lot of excitement last year when Google+ — Google’s answer to Facebook — was introduced, because, well, it’s Google. But according to everything I’ve heard and can observe, the great majority of small businesses haven’t flocked to the service.

headline: Applying for Scholarships, Designing a Prom Dress and Waiting

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry

headline: Travelers Say They Were Denied Entry to U.S. for Twitter Jokes
text: 3:55 p.m. | Updated  As American security agencies increasingly take to Twitter, Facebook and other social networking sites in search of potential threats, two European travelers say the system lacks one important quality: a sense of humor.

headline: Scientists Challenging Climate Science Appear to Flunk Climate Economics
text: An op-ed article signed by 16 scientists rejecting the need for “drastic action to decarbonize the world’s economy,” published Friday by the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, has been widely and thoroughly fact-checked and challenged elsewhere.

text: At the Screen Actors Guild awards, Viola Davis discusses her role in “The Help”

headline: After Rejection, Rutgers Taps Interim Coach
text: Kyle Flood, the interim coach at Rutgers, agreed Monday to permanently replace Greg Schiano as football coach after hours of discussions with Mario Cristobal of Florida International ended with him declining the job, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Will Curve Appeal Demonstrate Appeal?
text: A popular fragrance is being joined by a new variety that seeks to freshen the appeal of the brand franchise to younger consumers.

headline: The Cast of ‘The Artist’ at SAG Awards
text: James Cromwell, Beth Grant and Malcom McDowell discuss their supporting roles in “The Artist” at the Screen Actors Guild awards.

headline: Art-Sales Web Site Announces New Financing and Partnerships
text: Artspace.com, one of a wave of online art dealers that is starting to change the way contemporary art is bought and sold, said on Monday that it had raised $2.5 million from a group of investors. Additionally, it said, it had signed up several prominent museums and galleries – among them the New Museum, the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia and the Mexico City gallery kurimanzutto – as partners that will offer works to buyers through the Web site.

headline: Afghan Kin Are Accused of Killing Woman for Not Bearing a Son
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The young Afghan woman gave birth to a third girl three months ago — to a husband, the authorities say, who had been demanding a boy.

headline: Michel Hazanavicius and Bérénice Bejo
text: Michel Hazanavicius, the director of “The Artist” and Bérénice Bejo, one of its stars, discuss the film.

headline: Will President Obama’s Blueprint Cut College Costs?
text: Mark Kantrowitz is the founder of the Web sites finaid.org, and fastweb.com. He regularly answers reader questions on The Choice. Readers can post comments of their own at the end of this essay.

headline: East Haven Police Chief Retiring After Charges for Officers
text: The chief of the embattled Police Department in East Haven, Conn., announced on Monday that he was retiring after the arrest of four officers last week on federal charges of harassing and intimidating members of minority groups.

headline: Ear Doctors Performing Face-Lifts? It Happens
text: After moving from New York to Los Angeles in 2010 to take a job with a financial services firm, Joan, now 59, believed she needed to freshen her look. So she got a face-lift and tummy tuck from a board-certified doctor in Beverly Hills.
