headline: Emptying the Pacific Ocean With a Thimble
text: I always like starting off the week with a good laugh. So I was delighted to learn that the Obama campaign is returning donations from five registered federal lobbyists because of its oh-so-high standards.

headline: In Search of the Elusive Definition of Heterosexuality
text: Science generally succeeds in bringing some order to human existence — except when it does just the reverse, imposing a structure that never quite fits properly no matter how much it is tweaked. Then it just accentuates the underlying chaos.

headline: Kenneth Branagh and the Red-Carpet Bazaar
text: Noting that fame has changed tremendously (and, also, not at all) in the past few decades, the Bagger’s pals at New York magazine have done an exhaustive study of the celebrity economy, from freebies to the cost of appearing wrinkle-free. It’s worth a look.

headline: NBC Pulls ‘Fear Factor’ Episode Featuring Drinking of Donkey Semen
text: Back in December, when NBC was promoting the return of “Fear Factor,” the stunt and gross-out reality competition, there was one event that the producers and the host, Joe Rogan, would not discuss. It was extreme even by the standards of “Fear Factor,” they said at the time, and they didn’t know if it would ever be broadcast.

headline: Celebrate Digital Learning Day With 40 Years of Times EdTech Reporting
text: The New York Times has been covering technology’s role in education since the paper first began publishing — from an 1872 editorial questioning whether to teach science or the classics to boys of “ordinary abilities,” (PDF) to Sputnik-era pieces demanding more technical education for American schoolchildren (PDF) to today, when you can hardly open, or click on, the paper without finding an article that references the impact of technology on schools, learning or thinking.

headline: Image of the Day: January 30
text: A voter in Punjab, India.

headline: Everything Indy: The Invasion of the Roman Numerals
text: Throughout the week, Mike Tanier will be out and about and filing dispatches from the Super Bowl city.

headline: Envisioning a Perpetual Look for a Memorial AIDS Park
text: Updated, 6:11 p.m. | The winning design for a proposed AIDS memorial park opposite the former St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village was announced on Monday after a worldwide design competition.

headline: Caucus Click: Romney the Flight Attendant
text: Mitt Romney brought snacks and a birthday cake to his traveling press on Monday.

headline: Long Wharf Cancels Stage Version of ‘Sophie’s Choice’
text: The Long Wharf Theater in New Haven has replaced what it had billed as the “world premiere” of the play “Sophie’s Choice” with an adaption of Chaim Potok’s 1972 novel “My Name Is Asher Lev” for the final slot of its 2011-12 season, the theater announced.

headline: In Victory for the West, W.T.O. Orders China to Stop Export Taxes on Minerals
text: HONG KONG — The appeals panel of the World Trade Organization ruled on Monday that China must dismantle its system of export taxes and quotas for nine widely used industrial materials.

headline: News Corp. Is Replacing Its Head of Communications
text: News Corporation will lose its head of communications next month, the company said Monday, as Teri Everett becomes the latest senior executive to depart the media conglomerate.

headline: Home Court Advantage or Burden for the Underachieving Knicks?
text: Even in the leanest of years for the Knicks -– an era in which they’re still arguably mired -– they have enjoyed an impressive home-court advantage at Madison Square Garden. Whatever their on-court fortunes, the Knicks can count in their favor a fan base as knowledgeable, and as loud, as any in professional sports.

headline: The Changing Meaning of Heterosexuality
text: In today’s Science Times, Dr. Abigail Zuger takes a look at “Straight: The Surprisingly Short History of Heterosexuality,” a book by Hanne Blank, an expert on the history of sexuality. In “Straight,” Ms. Blank delves into the history of heterosexuality – a history that in at least one sense is surprisingly short. She notes, for example, that the word “heterosexual” didn’t come into use until a little over a century ago. As Dr. Zuger writes:

headline: Warm and Furry, but They Pack a Toxic Punch
text: What’s black and white, with a skunkish look to its cover,

headline: The 2012 Republican Primaries in Pictures
text: The primary season of a presidential campaign offers a unique glance into the character of a state. Take a look back at key moments and scenes from the 2012 campaign, state by state.

headline: More Middle-Income Borrowers Seek Debt Help
text: More middle-income consumers are seeking help through formal debt-reduction plans, according to an Atlanta-based credit counseling outfit.

headline: All Kinds of Kale
text: On a recent Thursday at my neighborhood farmers’ market, one farmer had three different varieties of kale on offer – black kale (also known as cavolo nero, dinosaur kale, dragon tongue, lacinato or Tuscan kale), curly gray-green kale and red Russian kale, another ruffled variety that has red veins and a purplish color. I bought all three and had a lot of fun turning them into dinners over the next 6 days.

headline: The Pro’s Tip Sheet: Adam Smith on Florida’s Political Environment
text: “We’re not just The Villages,” opined reporters for The Tampa Bay Times in a list of unconventional campaign stops for Republican candidates. Florida is so much more than retirees and snowbirds (though they are a big part of the equation, to be sure). It’s the most populous primary state yet, mired in a housing bust after a population boom that drove the latest rotation of its exaggerated economic cycles. Its political campaigns are primarily waged over the air, while developers, farmers and corporations wage constant battles over the water, be they the Everglades or Florida’s 1,197 miles of coastline.

headline: Petula Clark: ‘Downtown’ Uptown
text: Petula Clark’s cloud-breaking voice first entered my life when, as a nursery schooler, I begged my parents to buy me her big new hit single, “Downtown.” So it seemed appropriate that I spent Friday night, the 47th anniversary of the song’s run at No. 1, hearing her sing it at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, during her first extended New York engagement in decades. Appropriate, but also odd. As much of a pop milestone as “Downtown” was, who in 1965 would have imagined that Clark would still be singing it, at a swank Park Avenue cabaret no less, almost 50 years later? Probably not even Clark herself.

headline: Lessons From ZocDoc, a Health Tech Start-Up That Works
text: ZocDoc, an oddly named Web service for scheduling appointments with doctors, started in New York in 2007 and has been growing at a torrid pace. Last week the company added Seattle, its 14th metropolitan market in the United States.

headline: Britax Recalls 14,220 Child Restraints for Harness Flaw
text: Britax Child Safety is recalling 14,220 child restraints because the shoulder harness may not hold the child, according to a document posted Saturday on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. A further 3,600 seats are being recalled in Canada.

headline: Occupy D.C. Protesters Stay Put as Evacuation Deadline Passes
text: WASHINGTON — Demonstrators affiliated with the Occupy movement maintained a wary vigil here on Monday as a deadline from the National Park Service for campers to remove their gear or depart from two downtown parks came and went.

headline: Stanford Fraud Case Puts Old Friends at Odds
text: HOUSTON — R. Allen Stanford and James M. Davis were roommates at Baylor University and trusted friends over three decades who together built an international financial empire. But this week they are scheduled to confront each other in federal court as indicted swindlers ready to cross swords.

headline: Religious Giving and Its Critics
text: Since I used my Sunday column to write about the ways that government can crowd out — sometimes gently and subtly, and sometimes much more directly — private efforts to serve the common good, I was struck by the way that The New Republic’s Alec MacGillis reacted to conservative praise for the millions of dollars that Mitt Romney has given away to private charity:

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 30
text: A view of the day in sports, from the Giants’ trip to Indianapolis for the Super Bowl to action from the African Cup of Nations.

headline: In Honda Ad, Matthew Broderick Takes a Day Off
text: One of the most talked about commercials in the coming Super Bowl — on the basis of a 10-second teaser — features Matthew Broderick in a tribute to his long-remembered role in “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off” in an advertisement for the Honda CR-V. That clip has now been superseded by a nearly two-and-a-half-minute version, our friends at the Wheels blog reported. Unlike most viewers, perhaps, Jonathan Schultz was struck “by the level of suspension compression that Honda would allow the cameras to capture in the jump sequence.” Read more at the Wheels blog »

headline: New Jersey Symphony to Mark Jazz Age and Wagner Next Season
text: Jazz Age American music and a celebration of the 200th anniversary of Wagner’s birth will be among the highlights of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra’s 2012–13 season. Jacques Lacombe, in his third year as music director, will lead 16 weeks of traditional classical programs, four pops programs in Newark and New Brunswick and three family concerts. Opening night, on Sept. 28, will feature the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and include Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue.” The program also features “Remembering Gatsby: Foxtrot for Orchestra,” by John Harbison, a New Jersey native, that is part of the orchestra’s New Jersey Roots Project. During the season the orchestra will also perform music from Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde,” “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg” and “Parsifal.” More information about the season is available here.

headline: Polls Diverge, but All Point to a Romney Win
text: There has been a diversity of polling results in Florida — more so than in the three earlier nominating contests — even among surveys conducted at the same time.

headline: The Super Ad Bowl: Two Decades of Players
text: Compare commercials from year to year and watch some of the most memorable spots.

headline: Communities Learn the Good Life Can Be a Killer
text: Developers in the last half-century called it progress when they built homes and shopping malls far from city centers throughout the country, sounding the death knell for many downtowns. But now an alarmed cadre of public health experts say these expanded metropolitan areas have had a far more serious impact on the people who live there by creating vehicle-dependent environments that foster obesity, poor health, social isolation, excessive stress and depression.

headline: For Do-It-Yourself Nail Artists
text: WITH the rising popularity of salon nail art, companies have started to introduce affordable do-it-yourself versions. Impress Press-On Manicure by Broadway Nails is like an updated version of Lee Press-On Nails. More substantial than polish strips, the hard, nail-like adhesives are long and come in 18 trendy colors ($5.99 at drugstores, including Walgreens), and 18 patterns ($7.99). Once applied, there seemed to be too much space between the real and fake nails toward the cuticle, which made an irritating gathering spot for stray fibers. The adhesives looked decent and survived a multitude of weekend chores. But after 24 hours they were officially annoying me, so I pulled them off, which felt odd but not painful.

headline: New Museum Lowers Entry Fee After Raising It
text: Museums often make news by raising their admission prices. (The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s recommended admission went to $25 from $20 last year; the Museum of Modern Art, whose fee is not recommended but mandatory, also rose to $25 from $20.) It’s much rarer – in fact, almost unheard of – for a museum to get attention by reducing its prices. But the New Museum for Contemporary Art – which raised its admission fee recently to cover higher operating costs for the highly participatory show of the work of Carsten Höller – has decided to lower it. Before the show the fee for adults was $12, which was raised to $16 for the Höller show. It has now been set at $14. The museum continues to offer free admission every Thursday evening from 7 to 9 p.m. and to anyone under 18 at all times. The museum’s next exhibition, its second Triennial, titled “The Ungovernables,” opens Feb. 15.

headline: The Limits of Gingrich’s Debate Skills
text: WASHINGTON — For months, Newt Gingrich has been making the case that he should be the Republican presidential nominee in part because he would destroy President Obama in one-on-one debates.

headline: Restored Edison Records Revive Giants of 19th-Century Germany
text: Tucked away for decades in a cabinet in Thomas Edison’s laboratory, just behind the cot in which the great inventor napped, a trove of wax cylinder phonograph records has been brought back to life after more than a century of silence.

headline: Changed, but Not Defined, by Hemophilia
text: Hemophilia, which affects 20,000 Americans, is a genetic disorder in which the body lacks a clotting factor needed for blood to coagulate. Depending on severity, it can lead to life-threatening, seemingly unprovoked bleeding episodes — or it can go undetected for years, until a serious injury or a routine medical procedure suddenly touches off uncontrolled bleeding.

headline: European Leaders Agree to New Budget Discipline Measures
text: BRUSSELS — All but two European Union countries agreed Monday to new and tougher measures to enforce budget discipline in the euro zone, but the bloc still showed few signs of producing a comprehensive solution for the sovereign debt crisis or a credible plan to revive fragile economies across Europe’s weakened Mediterranean tier.

headline: What’s Not to Love About Acting in Silents?
text: There are a lot of theories about why “The Artist” has struck such a chord with critics and prize-givers (movie theater audiences are still just getting the message).

headline: A New Honor for the Hatchet Job
text: 10:00 a.m. | Updated

headline: O Say: How Fast Can Kelly Clarkson Sing the Anthem?
text: INDIANAPOLIS – While betting on the actual result of the Super Bowl is, obviously, a popular activity for many fans, the unusual “prop,” or proposition wagers, can often be more intriguing.

headline: AIDS Prevention Inspires Ways to Make Circumcisions Easier
text: The day of the assembly-line circumcision is drawing closer.

headline: Sizing Up the Top 25
text: Each week The Quad will analyze the top 25 N.C.A.A. teams (rankings and results are from The Associated Press).

headline: The Most Expensive Colleges
text: Higher-ed affordability, or lack thereof, has been in the news, what with President Obama’s proposed financial aid overhaul, and with the Occupy movement drawing attention to student-loan debt (now outpacing credit-card debt).

headline: Helping Unlicensed Chinese Contractors by Bridging the Language Gap
text: If New York City’s licensing test for home improvement contractors were given in Chinese and included the finer points of bamboo scaffolding, contractors like Gary Lin, 42, of Queens would breathe much easier taking it.

headline: Now Serving | Smile to Go
text: “For a long time I have wanted to do takeaway food. Other cities have great takeaway, but I haven’t found it in Manhattan,” explains Matt Kliegman, who with co-owner Carlos Quirarte and head chef Melia Marden, open their long-awaited Smile to Go today.

headline: Pro Bowl Helps NBC in Ratings
text: NBC’s coverage of the 2012 N.F.L. Pro Bowl drew a decent number of fans on Sunday as the American Football Conference defeated the National Football Conference 59-41, though not nearly enough to dominate the overall broadcast network ratings. NBC was No. 1 in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates, and it finished second in total viewers with 10.7 million, just behind CBS (11.4 million). Those two networks were close enough in total viewers that NBC might yet squeak by when the final numbers are released. “Undercover Boss” had the largest audience for CBS, at 13.1 million total viewers. On ABC, “Once Upon a Time” continued to perform well – especially for a freshman drama – with its highest audience total since November (10.8 million).

headline: To Sell Home, Attaching Fame to Find Fortune
text: For more than 15 years, Michael A. Gales has lived in a cozy but serviceable studio apartment on 66th Street just off First Avenue in Manhattan. There is not a lot of glamour about the place — just enough room for a queen-sized bed, a puffy green sofa and a small, separate kitchen to the right of the front door.

headline: Dudamel, Gergiev, Salonen and More Coming to ‘Great Performers’
text: Gustavo Dudamel and his orchestra, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, will give the first New York performance of the oratorio “The Gospel According to the Other Mary” composed by John Adams next season, Lincoln Center said on Monday. The concert was announced as part of the Great Performers 2012-13 lineup, which will include two concerts devoted to Brahms by Valery Gergiev and the London Symphony Orchestra.

headline: The Caucus | The Florida Primary
text: January 30, 2012 - Nate Silver discusses the Florida primary and the race in February.

headline: A Renewed Focus on a Financial Crisis Crackdown
text: In his State of the Union address, President Obama promoted the creation of a new unit to investigate “the abusive lending and packaging of risky mortgages that led to the housing crisis” in order to “hold accountable those who broke the law, speed assistance to homeowners, and help turn the page on an era of recklessness that hurt so many Americans.” On Friday, Eric H. Holder Jr., the attorney general, announced the formation of the Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities Working Group, which will be staffed by 55 lawyers, agents and analysts, to implement the president’s program.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug for an Advanced Skin Cancer
text: The first drug for an advanced form of the most common type of skin cancer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Monday.

headline: Like Son, Like Father: Kyle and Ken Williams Face the Critics
text: CHICAGO — Ken Williams, the general manager of the Chicago White Sox, was at Candlestick Park in San Francisco for the N.F.C. championship game to watch his son, Kyle, a 49ers receiver, play in the biggest football game of his life.

headline: Financial Improprieties Alleged at All-Girls Charter School Network
text: Public Prep, a charter school network in New York City, said a senior member of the finance and operations staff used the organization's credit card to spend tens of thousands of dollars on personal items. The staff member has resigned, and the network said all but $1,000 should be recouped through insurance.

headline: Injured Dancer Out for the Rest of City Ballet Season
text: Jennie Somogyi, a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, tore the Achilles’ tendon in her right foot during a performance Saturday night and will be out for the rest of the season, the company said on Monday. It was the second major injury for Ms. Somogyi since early 2004, when she tore a tendon in her left foot during a show. She battled back then, undergoing reconstructive surgery and extensive physical therapy before returning to the stage after 18 months. Rob Daniels, a City Ballet spokesman, said Ms. Somogyi would have surgery on Tuesday.

headline: In the Best of Times, Despairing the Giants
text: On Thursday nights from tiny WHDD-AM and FM in Sharon, Conn., David Kamp and Peter Richmond’s love for the Giants battles their sense of inevitable doom. And love loses.

headline: An Oil Minister, Plugging Renewables?
text: When you think of proponents of green energy, the Saudi oil minister may not be the first person who comes to mind. But in a speech on Monday in London, Ali al-Naimi, the minister from OPEC’s leading member nation, had a lot to say about renewable energy and global warming.

headline: N.F.L. Super Bowl Ad Will Stress Safety
text: To the usual lineup of beer and car commercials on Super Bowl Sunday, add this: one about player safety.

headline: Links for January’s End
text: January 2010 was the warmest January ever. If you live in the Northeast you’d have trouble believing that that record will not have been broken by Wednesday. I’m going to ask Andy Revkin.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:   F.D.A.’s Lack of Privacy and Facebook Ticker Symbols
text: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: Eurozone Problems
text: I’m giving a talk in Paris tomorrow. Here are some slides; they won’t come as a shock to regular readers, but it may be useful to see them all in one place.

headline: Joint Effort Announced Against Tropical Diseases
text: Thirteen drug companies, the governments of the United States, Britain and the United Arab Emirates, the World Bank, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the Lions Club and other smaller charitable organizations on Monday announced a joint effort to tackle 10 neglected tropical diseases in a coordinated fashion.

headline: Feeling Strain When Violent Patients Need Care
text: I didn’t know much about the patient — just that he’d showed up on my floor the previous evening after some confusion about whether his room was ready. When I went into his room that morning, he was still asleep. I gently roused him while his doctor, who had followed me in, explained that he needed to do a physical exam.

headline: Beverly Sills Artist Award Is Announced
text: The soprano Angela Meade won the Beverly Sills Artist Award, a $50,000 prize for singers from ages 25 to 40 who have already appeared in featured roles at the Metropolitan Opera, the company said on Monday. Ms. Meade, 34, made her Met debut as Elvira in Verdi’s “Ernani” four years ago and will appear again in the role on Thursday in a new run of the opera. The award was endowed by Agnes Varis, a Met managing director, and her husband, Karl Leichtman. Ms. Sills died in 2007. Previous winners include Nathan Gunn, Joyce DiDonato, Matthew Polenzani, John Relyea, Susanna Phillips and Isabel Leonard.

headline: Access Hollywood | Inside the Directors Guild Awards
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Vote for African Union’s Leader Hits Stalemate
text: JOHANNESBURG — A high-profile and bitterly fought race for the top post in the African Union ended inconclusively on Monday, with neither the incumbent, Jean Ping of Gabon, nor his main challenger, South Africa’s home minister, Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma, securing enough votes to win.

headline: Watch Out Dowager Countess, Shirley MacLaine to Join ‘Downton Abbey’ Cast
text: Attention all “Downton” fans: Shirley MacLaine is joining the popular Masterpiece Classic series for its coming third season, ITV and Carnival Films said on Monday.

headline: TimesCast | Embassy Shields Americans
text: January 30, 2012 — The American Embassy in Cairo is protecting at least two Americans from potential arrest by Egyptian authorities.

headline: Super Bowl Playbook: The Patriots’ First-Down Edge
text: Throughout the week, Mike Tanier will be looking at the New York Giants and the New England Patriots by the numbers.

headline: More City Principals Sign Letter Protesting Evaluation System
text: All of the political talk in the last week about negotiations over a state teacher evaluation system seems to be having some impact: more principals are putting their name to a letter that protests the state's system. The latest tally is 1,318 signatures. New York lists 4,511 principals in the state.

headline: Plotting to Make Their Audience Laugh
text: In a recent sketch by Harvard Sailing Team, a family stages a teary intervention to inform its patriarch that he has a problem — with his sense of humor.

headline: Viola Davis on How an Ensemble Helped ‘The Help’
text: LOS ANGELES — The Screen Actors Guild award for best actress is not the only prize Viola Davis picked up over the weekend. Ms. Davis, a star of “The Help,” was also honored by the Santa Barbara International Film Festival, which gave her its performer of the year award on Friday.

headline: Japanese Auto Suppliers Are Fined, and Executives Agree to Prison, in a Price-Fixing Case
text: DETROIT — A Japanese auto supplier, the Yazaki Corporation, agreed to pay one of the largest ever antitrust fines, and four of its executives will serve up to two years in prison for price-fixing and bid-rigging, the Justice Department said Monday.

headline: That Wide-Eyed Look
text: Q. Why do doctors dilate your eyes for an exam, and are there any drops to reverse the dilation?

headline: London Ensemble Raises a Flute to Frederick the Great
text: “On Playing the Flute,” the manual written in 1752 by Johann Joachim Quantz, has long been a benchmark for flute players. But much of Quantz’s vast collection of concertos and sonatas languished in the Berlin State Library until recently, when Rachel Brown, the Baroque flutist, sifted through the manuscripts, then edited and published a few, including the delightful Flute Sonata in B flat (No. 275).

headline: What Should Vassar College Do About Its Admissions Mistake?
text: Electronic college admissions decisions make me nostalgic for the old slim letter/fat letter days. Waiting for a piece of paper in a stamped envelope was a rite of passage. Plus, sending word the old-fashioned way provided more opportunities to catch an error like the one that happened at Vassar College over the weekend.

headline: A Tribute to Moon: The Man, the Machines and Those Eyes
text: POMONA, Calif. — Dean Moon, who died in 1987 at age 60, established a small production shop behind his father’s restaurant in the Los Angeles suburb of Norwalk in 1952. Moon Equipment would become one of the most recognized and respected names in the hot-rod and drag-racing cultures, in part for its unmistakable logo: two goggling eyes casting a sidelong glance, a design Mr. Moon first toyed with in his high school typing class.

headline: The Art of Contrasts, as Small Strokes Unravel a Fierce, Complex Symmetry
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — In the past two years the young British choreographer Liam Scarlett has achieved the status of an important classical-ballet choreographer. The images, constructions and textures of “Viscera,” his new creation for Miami City Ballet, show why. I watched it with three different casts over the weekend at the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts here. Each time the audience proclaimed its excitement the moment it ended. That’s a natural response to the terrific control of physical energy in its elaborate finale; but in terms of architectural organization too, this is an impressive piece.

headline: In the Spurs, a Model of How to Play
text: When Gregg Popovich is referred to as an exceptional coach, it refers as much to his coaching style as it does his overall effectiveness.

headline: Romney Keeps the Heat on Gingrich
text: DUNEDIN, Fla. — Mitt Romney kept up the attack on Newt Gingrich at his second stop of the day Monday, even as he seemed a bit more subdued and tired than in recent days, offering a more muted criticism of the former speaker of the House to the large crowd that had gathered here for an outdoor, afternoon rally.

headline: Jumping Spiders Focus Like a Camera to Hunt
text: Jumping spiders do not weave webs. Instead, they jump about and then pounce on their prey. For this reason, depth perception is very important to their survival.

headline: Looking for That Midnight Train to Jamaica?
text: Riders who find themselves on the New York City subways late at night know, or learn quickly, that their journeys might not follow the routes on the maps posted in stations or handed out at booths.

headline: After 18 Albums, Rapper Gets a New York Stage
text: With Too Short, the numbers count. He is 45, and next month he will release “No Trespassing” (Dangerous/EMI), which by his count will be his 19th album in a career that has spanned 29 years.

headline: Even With a Jonas, a Box-Office Drop for ‘How to Succeed’
text: After 11 months of strong ticket sales, the box-office receipts for the Broadway revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying” fell sharply last week as the actor and musician Nick Jonas took over the starring role of the corporate schemer J. Pierrepont Finch, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League. The gross of $682,879 for the standard eight performances was the lowest amount for “How to Succeed” since early preview performances last March.

headline: Black Feather May Have Helped Archaeopteryx Fly
text: The winged dinosaur Archaeopteryx is often proposed as an intermediate creature between reptiles and birds, but large uncertainties surround it. Could it even fly? Scientists are still unsure.

headline: Apple Becomes World’s Biggest Maker of Computers, Thanks to iPad
text: The company that proclaimed the “post-PC era” — Apple — is now the biggest maker of PCs in the world.

headline: Marine Turtles Make Up for an Early Gender Gap
text: The sex of a baby marine turtle is determined by the egg’s temperature at incubation. The warmer the weather, the more female baby turtles there are. (The phenomenon is called temperature-dependent sex determination.)

headline: From Biden, a Vivid Account of Bin Laden Decision
text: In the anguished White House debates over the war in Afghanistan, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. argued consistently to stress counterterrorism over the more costly strategy of nation-building. It turns out, though, that Mr. Biden warned against the most sensational counterterrorism operation of the Obama presidency: the commando raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

headline: How Riverdale Country School Spends Its Tuition Dollars
text: David N. Roberts, chairman of Riverdale Country School's board of trustees, and Dominic A.A. Randolph, Riverdale's head of school, sent an e-mail in response to an article about the high cost of private school tuition. Riverdale charges $40,450 for 12th grade, but spends $1.10 for every $1 charged, they say.

headline: Gingrich’s Five Stop Tour
text: Newt Gingrich flew to five different campaign stops in Florida on the day before voting began.

headline: All They Hope for Is Survival
text: “Zehrunisa Husain was a tear-factory even on good days; it was one of her chief ways of starting conversations,” Katherine Boo writes in “Behind the Beautiful Forevers,” her exquisitely accomplished first book. Novelists dream of defining characters this swiftly and beautifully, but Ms. Boo is not a novelist. She is one of those rare, deep-digging journalists who can make truth surpass fiction, a documentarian with a superb sense of human drama. She makes it very easy to forget that this book is the work of a reporter.

headline: A Long Journey to Immune System Insights
text: Ruslan M. Medzhitov loves scientific puzzles. And this penchant has led him to tackle some of the big questions of modern biology.

headline: The Real Artists of Marfa | Adam Bork
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Teacher’s Learning Curve in Kabul
text: A few weeks ago, as I was sitting in the English department office at a university in Kabul, sipping coffee and talking to other professors about the end of my time in Afghanistan, I realized that Kabul had taught me patience. But it took a while to get here.

headline: For Scientists, Hope Diamond’s Blue May Offer Geology Lesson
text: The Hope Diamond’s 45.52 sparkling, steely blue carats make it the most famous diamond in the world — shrouded in mystery and intrigue since it was pulled out of the ground in 17th-century India.

headline: Santorum Daughter’s Illness a Test for Candidate
text: TAMPA — Isabella Santorum, the fragile 3-year-old daughter of Rick Santorum, has pulled through again.

headline: A Prolific Composer Pauses, Briefly, for His Birthday
text: Philip Glass’s friends had a reasonable excuse for jumping the gun and throwing him a 75th-birthday party two days early at Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday evening. On the actual day, Tuesday, Mr. Glass will be at Carnegie Hall to hear the American premiere of his Ninth Symphony.

headline: The sound of the 1880s; wolves versus moose in northern Michigan; and watch where you get that nose job.
text: The sound of the 1880s; wolves versus moose in northern Michigan; and watch where you get that nose job.

headline: Blue Jackets Awarded All-Star Game as Fans’ Frustration Grows
text: From the hometown fans cheering wildly for the Senators’ representatives (and heartily booing the Maple Leafs’) to the awestruck players videotaping the performance of the Toronto-born rapper Drake, Canada’s capital city of Ottawa provided a nearly perfect backdrop for this past weekend’s All-Star festivities.

headline: Royals Seeking Romance, Disguised (but Not as Frogs)
text: “Undercover Princes”: If the title makes you think of dashing Hohenzollerns trading secrets in romantic locales, think again.

headline: A War on Religion?
text: TAMPA – Mitt Romney is comfortably ahead in Florida, according to several polls, and has begun to taunt Newt Gingrich about it, as he did this afternoon standing in the warm sun of Dunedin, a nearby Gulf town.

headline: Text and Video From Nine State-of-the-State Addresses
text: Speeches from a coterie of new Republican governors show that they are adopting a decidedly more moderate tone the year after implementing aggressive agendas.

headline: Weighing Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
text: The Commerce Department is scheduled to decide in a month whether Chinese solar panels should be subject to an import tariff, after fielding a complaint from domestic manufacturers that the Chinese are illegally subsidizing their solar export market. The department has not said how it will rule.

headline: Second Year In, Republican Governors Moderate Tone
text: A year after a coterie of new Republican governors swept into the statehouses and put in place aggressive agendas to cut spending and curb union powers, sparking strong backlashes in many places, many of them are adopting decidedly more moderate tones as they begin their sophomore year in office.

headline: A One-Man Studio Band and the Strength of Smooth Jazz
text: GOTYE

headline: Theater Complex Raises Its Curtain
text: During the depths of the recession in 2009, leaders of Signature Theater Company had a showy selling point in their pitch to raise $38.5 million to build a new home: models of the 70,000-square-foot complex by a star architect, Frank Gehry. Yet Signature, a respected but frills-free Off Broadway nonprofit, lacked a grand space in which to show the models and to entertain prospective donors.

headline: Fluoridation Pro and Con (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Marred Portrait of Disgust (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Signature Home
text: A look at the $66 million Signature Center, home of the Signature Theater Company.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington, D.C., and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Washington, D.C., Nepal, Brazil and India.

headline: Federal Pay vs. Private Sector Compensation
text: Are federal workers really overpaid?

headline: Folklorist’s Global Jukebox Goes Digital
text: The folklorist and ethnomusicologist Alan Lomax was a prodigious collector of traditional music from all over the world and a tireless missionary for that cause. Long before the Internet existed, he envisioned a “global jukebox” to disseminate and analyze the material he had gathered during decades of fieldwork.

headline: Listening to the Globe
text: Songs from the archive of the ethnomusicologist Alan Lomax to be included in the Global Jukebox project.

headline: If Twitter Is Any Clue, Axelrod Thinks a Lot About Romney
text: David Axelrod has found his id. On Twitter.

headline: DNA Turning Human Story Into a Tell-All
text: The tip of a girl’s 40,000-year-old pinky finger found in a cold Siberian cave, paired with faster and cheaper genetic sequencing technology, is helping scientists draw a surprisingly complex new picture of human origins.

headline: Numberplay: Ordering in Circles
text: Take a look at the numbers in the inner black circle above. This clockwise arrangement of 1, 2, 3, 1, 3, and 4 has an interesting property. With it you can count all the numbers from one to seven in order in the following way. You go around the circle reading each number and if it is in counting sequence starting from one, you count it and move on. If it is not in counting sequence, you are allowed to add as many consecutive numbers as needed to make it so.

headline: Unusual Problem: Rangers Have Too Many Forwards
text: Unlike the Devils, whom they visit at Prudential Center on Tuesday night for the first of five remaining games this season, the Rangers have a problem unique to N.H.L. teams as the calendar turns to February: a roster logjam.

headline: Corzine Is Seeking $2.9 Million for Hoboken Penthouse
text: Nearly three months after MF Global filed for bankruptcy protection, many questions still surround the failed brokerage firm. Not among them, however, is what it will cost to live in the penthouse of its former chief executive.

headline: App Smart Extra: Parenting Apps
text: Last week’s App Smart column highlighted a pair of apps for new parents, WebMD Baby (free on Apple) and Baby Connect ($5 on Apple and Android). Given WebMD Baby’s pedigree, it’s little surprise that the app offers a deep well of medically related information.

headline: Massachusetts: Kennedys Transfer Hyannis Home
text: The Kennedy family transferred ownership of the main home in their compound in Hyannis Port, Mass., to the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate on Monday. The institute will use the 9,055-square-foot waterfront home for educational seminars and will create a plan to allow limited visits by the public, according to a statement. The Kennedy family, which still owns other homes in the compound, will continue to use the property on a limited basis. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who died in 2009, arranged for the home to be donated to the institute.

headline: A Flying House of Fun, Ever Ready for Takeoff
text: If Italo Calvino, Douglas Adams and William Gibson had gotten together, maybe become a little drunk and decided to pull a literary all-nighter, the resulting collaboration might have had something of the flavor of John Jesurun’s “Stopped Bridge of Dreams.”

headline: New Fund Hopes to Prove Outspoken Analyst’s Thesis
text: R. Christopher Whalen doesn’t mince words about the big banks.

headline: A Travel Start-Up Raises Money for Planning Tourism Activities
text: For many travelers, planning the trip is almost as fun as taking it. Yet using the Web to plan a vacation can be frustrating because there are still few helpful resources online.

headline: A Power Outlet With USB Ports Built In
text: There are a lot of approaches to getting rid of wall-warts, those blocky power transformers that let you plug your low-voltage, battery-powered USB products into the wall to charge.

headline: General Withdraws From West Point Talk
text: Plans for a talk at West Point by a retired general known for his harshly anti-Muslim remarks were abruptly canceled on Monday after a growing list of liberal veterans’ groups, civil liberties advocates and Muslim organizations called on the Military Academy to rescind the invitation.

headline: Super Bowl on a Whim? That Trip Will Cost You
text: AS of last Friday, you could still find a scarce hotel room for this weekend in Indianapolis, at the budget Best Inn — for $898.99 a night, according to Travelocity.com. That would put you in town for the Super Bowl on Sunday between the New York Giants and New England Patriots.

headline: Colorado Lawsuit Challenges Wisdom of Ballot Box
text: DENVER — Few elected officials would ever dare say, at least within earshot of a microphone, that voters making public policy decisions through ballot-box referendums are less capable or wise than legislators deliberating under a capitol dome.

headline: Obama and Romney Campaigns Adopt Square for Funding
text: Social media was a game-changing technology that helped alter the course of the 2008 presidential election. In 2012, mobile payments could be the transformational technology, as millions of political supporters are given the ability to collect money on smartphones for candidates.

headline: Albany Redistricting Plan Faulted as Unfair to Minorities
text: ALBANY — A proposed redrawing of New York State’s political districts came under intense criticism on Monday, as civil rights leaders said the maps did not fairly represent blacks and Hispanics in an increasingly diverse state, and Democrats said they would file a lawsuit asking a judge to intervene.

headline: A Police Training Film About Muslims: 2 Views
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brodeur Remains Devils’ Gatekeeper
text: NEWARK — As if the Devils always need to be reminded of their glory days, replicas of their three Stanley Cup banners hang above their practice rink. It seems hard to believe the first of those Cups came nearly 17 years ago, the last almost nine years ago.

headline: The Democrats’ Agenda
text: To the Editor:

headline: Joseph Brooks, Who Refined Lord & Taylor, Dies at 84
text: Joseph E. Brooks, a retail executive who doubled the size of the Lord & Taylor chain and made its flagship New York store a showplace of spectacle, including elaborate retail stagecraft and a daily morning rendition of “The Star-Spangled Banner,” died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Technology and Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ritalin and the Hyperactive Child
text: To the Editor:

headline: Burmese Civil War Turns Grimmer for a Guerrilla
text: DUMHPAWNG KAWNG, Myanmar — When the Burmese soldiers dumped the body of a young ethnic Kachin guerrilla fighter outside a jungle hut in front of his commander, he was still in his uniform. His right hand had been shredded with a knife. There was a large gunshot wound in his stomach.

headline: Free Speech vs. Infringement in Suit on Alabama Artwork
text: In the specialized field of sports art, Daniel Moore is well known for his paintings of the University of Alabama football team in action. But he soon may become similarly recognizable in legal circles as his fight against the university’s charge of trademark infringement heads to the United States Court of Appeals.

headline: F.T.C. Fines a Collector of Debt $2.5 Million
text: The Federal Trade Commission signaled on Monday that it would continue to crack down on debt collectors who harass consumers for money they may not even be legally obligated to pay.

headline: Treasury Investigates Freddie Mac Investment
text: The Treasury Department is investigating a report that Freddie Mac, the mortgage giant, bet against homeowners’ ability to refinance their loans even as it was making it more difficult for them to do so, Jay Carney, a White House spokesman, said on Monday.

headline: Volcker Rule Stirs Up Opposition Overseas
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — Usually, it is the banks that are fighting efforts to impose new regulations on the industry. Now, it is foreign governments fighting against bank regulations in the United States.

headline: The End of Health Insurance Companies
text: Here’s a bold prediction for the new year. By 2020, the American health insurance industry will be extinct. Insurance companies will be replaced by accountable care organizations — groups of doctors, hospitals and other health care providers who come together to provide the full range of medical care for patients.

headline: At the Century Mark, It’s Not Just About the Cookies
text: “I’D like to drop out of high school and get a meaningless job that makes me feel bad about myself,” says a young girl in a new public service announcement. “I’d like to fall victim to the old boys’ network,” says another.

headline: Trade Protest Is Planned on Eve of a Chinese Leader’s Visit
text: HONG KONG — As the White House prepares for a Washington visit by the man who is expected to run China for the coming decade, trade tensions between the United States and Beijing are on the rise.

headline: On Day Before Primary, Gingrich Hits Five Florida Cities
text: With Florida’s Republican primary just a day away, Newt Gingrich plans a five-city rush on Monday — with stops in Jacksonville, Pensacola, Tampa, Fort Myers and Orlando. Here, reporters follow him on his hectic journey.

headline: Gatekeepers Under Scrutiny
text: Lawmakers dissatisfied with the performance of the Transportation Security Administration are pushing to revive a proposal the agency has resisted — allowing airports to use screeners hired by private contractors — so the agency can focus more on its role as overseer, rather than operator, of airport security.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Pregnant, and Pushed Out of a Job
text: FEW people realize that getting pregnant can mean losing your job. Imagine a woman who, seven months into her pregnancy, is fired from her position as a cashier because she needed a few extra bathroom breaks. Or imagine another pregnant employee who was fired from her retail job after giving her supervisors a doctor’s note requesting she be allowed to refrain from heavy lifting and climbing ladders during the month and a half before her maternity leave: that’s what happened to Patricia Leahy. In 2008 a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that her firing was fair because her employers were not obligated to accommodate her needs.

headline: Tunisia Faces a Balancing Act of Democracy and Religion
text: TUNIS — The insults were furious. “Infidel!” and “Apostate!” the religious protesters shouted at the two men who had come to the courthouse to show their support for a television director on trial on charges of blasphemy. Fists, then a head butt followed.

headline: Drones for Human Rights
text: Washington

headline: Giants Leave the Injured Back at Home, for Now
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The Giants’ charter landed at Indianapolis International Airport at 2:49 p.m. Monday, according to flight records, and the requisite team flag was hung out the window as the plane taxied in from the runway. When the door opened, numerous coaches, assorted staff members and players stepped out, and the Giants had officially arrived at Super Bowl XLVI.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Primary Bounce
text: One of the maxims of past nomination campaigns is that a candidate should expect to receive a bounce in the polls after winning a major primary or caucus — particularly if he or she beat the expectations established by the polls and the news media while doing so.

headline: Above Africa and Alaska, Awe Replaces Anxiety
text: CONSIDERING the fact that I’m an author and I’m telling people about places they need to see, it’s crazy that I’m actually a nervous flier. Maybe people who don’t like to fly can take some solace in that.

headline: A Cheesebox on a Raft
text: A month before the first shots were fired at Fort Sumter, the Philadelphia Examiner editorialized, “If we intend to have a national naval force worthy of our power and pretensions, we shall have to … build iron-cased vessels. … Before the end of the year, France will have eight and England six. … How many are we to have?” At that moment, most of the country’s ranking naval officers would have answered “none,” for they were uniformly skeptical of both the need for and the practicality of “ironclads.” To John Lenthall, the Navy’s chief of construction, equipment and repair, the very idea was a “humbug.”

headline: Can a Town Divided Against Itself Stand?
text: Abraham Lincoln, what does he know? A house divided against itself can stand, and will do so for decades, no sweat. Berlin, Nicosia, Jerusalem — heck, even Kansas City: all are cities that have been split in two by borders. All are still around. But if being split down the middle doesn’t mean the end of the world, it ain’t fun either. A house divided is a house of pain, with degrees of inconvenience varying from administrative annoyance to frequent lethality.

headline: After Mistake, a Mea Culpa From Vassar
text: After 76 applicants were mistakenly told they had been accepted to Vassar College, its president has apologized for the “considerable confusion and hurt” caused by the “terribly upsetting event,” and said the college would reimburse the students’ $65 application fees.

headline: For Patriots and Giants, a Shared Priority
text: INDIANAPOLIS — From studying videotape of the Giants’ defense this season, the New England Patriots know they must protect Tom Brady on Sunday. This revelation was disclosed Monday by their center, Dan Connolly, who concluded that it will take “work and effort” to shield Brady from a pass rush from the team that pummeled him four years ago in Super Bowl XLII but, in what must be a relief to New England fans everywhere, “yes, I think we can do it.”

headline: Buoyant Romney Speaks of Victory in Florida
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney swept through a final day of campaigning here on Monday, energized by more polls showing him with a commanding lead in the Florida primary. He even allowed himself to break superstition and proclaim, “I’m beginning to feel we might win.”

headline: The Great Divorce
text: I’ll be shocked if there’s another book this year as important as Charles Murray’s “Coming Apart.” I’ll be shocked if there’s another book that so compellingly describes the most important trends in American society.

headline: With Muslims, Using a Brush Far Too Broad
text: I stood last week on City Hall’s plaza, as a gray wet January day pressed in, and thought: How completely isolated they look.

headline: Knicks, Short on Players and Time, Feel Urgency
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Ten men in blue and white jerseys ran full court in an early-afternoon scrimmage Monday, revealing a vivid, woeful picture of the Knicks.

headline: Don’t Stop the Debates
text: Senator John McCain spoke for many nervous Republicans on Sunday when he said it’s time to “stop the debates.” They’ve turned into mud-wrestling contests, he said on “Meet the Press” on NBC, and are driving up negative impressions of the party’s presidential candidates.

headline: Food Crisis as Drought and Cold Hit Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — A drought that a government official called the most severe Mexico had ever faced has left two million people without access to water and, coupled with a cold snap, has devastated cropland in nearly half of the country.

headline: Celebrity Guest Solver Alan Zweibel
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the nice things about the Celebrity Guest Solver feature, other than giving me the opportunity to work with some truly brilliant minds, is that it gives me a bit of a break. A chance to put my feet up, if you will, and let someone else do the heavy crossword lifting for a change. It’s asking a lot, because these are busy people who obligingly take the time out of their busy schedules to solve and write about the puzzle for your entertainment. And because they usually have a book to plug.

headline: A Family Reunion, With a Chaser
text: The standup comic and sometime actress Janeane Garofalo drops the shtick, more or less, to play a stern Russian Jewish mother in Brooklyn in “Russian Transport,” by Erika Sheffer, a new play from the New Group that opened on Monday night at the Acorn Theater.

headline: The Shortfall in Cancer Screening
text: A new federal study found that Americans are getting screened for three major cancers — breast, cervical and colorectal — at rates far below national targets. The shortfall is especially high among adults who lack insurance or regular access to a doctor, partly because the recession drove employers to lay off workers or cut health benefits.

headline: Tom Coughlin
text: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin spoke on Monday about the leadership qualities of his quarterback Eli Manning.

headline: College Says It Exaggerated SAT Figures for Ratings
text: Claremont McKenna College, a small, prestigious California school, said Monday that for the past six years, it has submitted false SAT scores to publications like U.S. News & World Report that use the data in widely followed college rankings.

headline: In Studios and Grand Halls, Feeling a Pinch From Italy
text: As Italy’s new government scrambles to stave off economic disaster, the budget cuts it has imposed are rippling through Italian institutions in New York City, slicing into paychecks and prompting plans to shut down a venerable state-owned television operation.

headline: Deconstructing the Boatright Decision
text: In my column, I try to make sense of the decision on Ryan Boatright, the University of Connecticut freshman, who, until last Saturday, had been suspended from the men’s basketball team. In handing down its ruling to reinstate him, the N.C.A.A. issued a press release so malicious in its intent that I could not let it pass. Longtime watchers of the N.C.A.A. tell me that they have never seen an athlete and his mother thrown under the bus the way Ryan and Tanesha Boatright were on Saturday. Below, I’ve annotated the press release. Click here to see an enlarged version.

headline: Hollywood Copyright Dispute: The Skirmishing Resumes
text: LOS ANGELES — Save the date: Monday, July 9, 2013.

headline: UConn Wins on Road but Isn’t There Yet
text: DURHAM, N.C. — In the post-Maya Moore era at Connecticut, the Huskies are no longer the alpha females of women’s college basketball. Baylor and Notre Dame share that place now.

headline: John F. Baker Jr., Who Saved 8 G.I.’s in 1966, Dies at 66
text: John F. Baker Jr., who joined the Army after being deemed too short for the Marines and went on to receive the Medal of Honor for saving eight fellow soldiers during the Vietnam War while under heavy fire, died on Jan. 20 in Columbia, S.C. He was 66.

headline: Afghan Officials Consider Own Talks With Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Concerned that it is being left out of potential peace talks between the United States and the Taliban, the Afghan government is pushing to open its own direct negotiations with the insurgent group in Saudi Arabia, Afghan officials said on Monday.

headline: Saving Freshman Ryan
text: My plan had been to give the N.C.A.A. a rest this week; there are, after all, other problems in the world. But then, at 6:15 on Saturday evening, the N.C.A.A. announced that it was reinstating Ryan Boatright, the University of Connecticut freshman who had been suspended from the men’s basketball team, and whose mother, Tanesha, had been the subject of a horrific investigation that I had previously written about.

headline: Steve Jones and Nicole Scherzinger Won’t Return to ‘The X Factor’
text: Steve Jones and Nicole Scherzinger, two of the people who helped start “The X Factor” in the United States, will not be sticking around for season two of the singing competition, the Fox network said Monday.

headline: A Companion for the Journey
text: Tori Stitt, a former Navy officer who did a tour in Iraq, relies on the companionship of her golden retriever to aid her recovery.

headline: Coughlin Not Worried About His Legacy
text: INDIANAPOLIS – One of the more popular story lines of the pre-Super Bowl XLVI coverage has been what a Giants victory would mean for the legacies of quarterback Eli Manning and Coach Tom Coughlin. Bill Pennington of The Times wrote recently about how Coughlin would compare to some of the more successful coaches in N.F.L. history if the Giants were to defeat the New England Patriots in the Super Bowl for the second time in four years.

headline: Amid Ailments and Loss, a Mother Forges Ahead
text: Above Nelsy Peralta’s bed is a photograph of a birthday cake amid baby pictures pasted together in a large collage. The cake has vanilla frosting with a bright blue trim. A message reads, “Happy Birthday to Pedro and Nelson.” They are Ms. Peralta’s fraternal twin sons, born in 2007.

headline: The Shock of Recognition
text: After nearly 30 operations, Joey Paulk began to resign himself to his appearance. But with help from a program that aids burned veterans, he received surgery that revived his self-confidence.

headline: A Harder Squeeze on the Poor
text: House Republicans have hit upon a noxious scheme to help pay for an extension of the payroll tax cut: a tax increase on millions of poor working families. A bill passed by the House and now in conference seeks to deny cash refunds under the child tax credit to those who file tax returns using “individual taxpayer identification numbers” issued by the Internal Revenue Service. Only those using Social Security numbers would be eligible.

headline: The Hard Road Back
text: A series of articles and videos chronicling the experiences of military veterans who have returned from Iraq and Afghanistan but continue to confront the medical and psychological scars of battle.

headline: For Soldier Disfigured in War, a Way to Return to the World
text: Specialist Joey Paulk awoke from a coma in a Texas hospital three weeks after he was burned nearly to death in Afghanistan. Wrapped in bandages from head almost to toe, he immediately saw his girlfriend and mother, and felt comforted. Then he glanced at his hands, two balls of white gauze, and realized that he had no fingers.

headline: Free Opinions at Firehouses
text: Some firefighters in the New York City Fire Department are actively opposing a federal judge’s order to reform the department’s long history of bad employment practices. They have started a misguided campaign called Merit Matters to stop the judge and the city from creating new exams for potential applicants and have distributed materials to various stationhouses. Last month, the Fire Department, in what seems like a misguided response, tried to ban “material presenting opinions or viewpoints” anywhere in the city’s firehouses.

headline: What Is It About Mormons?
text: If Mormons are such responsible people, why are voters turned off?

headline: In Berlin, a Festival Focuses on the Contemporary Arts
text: This year is the 25th anniversary of Berlin’s alternative media arts festival, Transmediale. This five-day event, which starts on Tuesday at the Haus der Kulturen der Welt contemporary arts center, has a rich international program of artworks, installations, video screenings, workshops, performances and an interdisciplinary symposiums, all organized by various guest curators.

headline: In a Political Ritual, Candidates Tour France in a Race for 500 Signatures
text: PARIS — In 1965, Marcel Barbu, a jeweler and philanthropist, ran for the French presidency as “the candidate of battered dogs.” In 2002, Pierre Rabhi, a farmer and philosopher of Algerian descent, built himself as the candidate of “peaceful insurrection.” Coluche, a well-known comedian, called for “the lazy, the filthy, the drug addicts, the alcoholics, the pedophiles” and other nonmainstream voters to elect him in 1981.

headline: Money Can’t Buy Him Love
text: Most polls predict a sizable victory for Mitt Romney in Florida. How did this happen? How did Newt Gingrich lose his grip on the state? Money, that’s how.

headline: Claremont McKenna in California Admits Exaggerating Students’ SAT Scores
text: Pamela B. Gann, the president of Claremont McKenna College, a small, selective liberal arts college in California, admitted on Monday that a “senior administrator” had been submitting inflated SAT data to ratings agencies since 2005, in an apparent effort to increase the college’s standing. My colleague Richard Pérez-Peña and I report in Tuesday’s Times that Richard C. Vos, vice president and dean of admissions, is believed to be the source of the false information, and the only individual involved.

headline: Civilian Deaths Due to Drones Are Not Many, Obama Says
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday defended the use of drones to strike suspected terrorists in Pakistan and elsewhere, saying the clandestine program was “kept on a very tight leash” and enabled the United States to use “pinpoint” targeting to avoid more intrusive military action.

headline: Gingrich Makes a Last-Minute Push in Florida
text: On the last day of campaigning, the candidate went on a five-city “Florida Fly-Around” tour to woo voters before the primary Tuesday.

headline: Corrections: January 31
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Cart Hurled at Bronx Mall Injures 2 Men
text: Two men were injured, one critically, on Monday after someone hurled a shopping cart off the third story of a parking garage at a Bronx megamall, slamming into both men, the police said.

headline: After Rescinding Mistaken Acceptances, Vassar Delivers an Apology
text: Vassar College’s president, Catharine Hill, apologized on Sunday night to 76 students who were mistakenly informed they had been accepted to the college. The apology came after Matt Flegenheimer reported that Vassar accidentally posted a test letter that led 122 early-decision students to think they had been admitted when only 46 of them had. Mr. Flegenheimer details the apology here:

headline: Katherine Boo’s ‘Behind the Beautiful Forevers’
text: “Half an acre. 335 huts. 3,000 people. And a concrete wall that is supposed to hide them from view: this is Annawadi, the Mumbai slum that comes vibrantly to life” in “Behind the Beautiful Forevers,” Janet Maslin writes in this book review in The New York Times.

headline: Clear Channel to Invest in Company Run by TV’s ‘Idol’ Host
text: Ryan Seacrest, who already is a host, producer and spokesman for Clear Channel, will soon be an investment partner as well.

headline: Word of the Day | wince
text: wince •\ˈwin(t)s\• noun and verb

headline: Report by House Democrats Absolves Administration in Gun Trafficking Case
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee on Tuesday are expected to publish a report on the disputed gun trafficking investigation called Operation Fast and Furious, concluding that agents in Arizona — not Obama administration officials — were responsible for the tactics used in the inquiry and for providing misleading information relayed to Congress.

headline: Fatally Flawed: Five Years of Gun-walking in Arizona
text: Democrats on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee released a report on the disputed gun trafficking investigation called Operation Fast and Furious.

headline: India’s Chai Drinkers Embrace Coffee
text: For coffee-shop regulars across India, Starbucks’ plans to enter the Indian market will be hailed as a pleasant development.

headline: Pakistan: Crusading TV Host Is Fired
text: A major television station fired a prominent journalist on Monday after she led a self-styled moral crusade against dating couples that set off a furious public outcry. Maya Khan, 31, the host of a breakfast show, led a group of women that chased young couples through a Karachi park on Jan. 17, accusing them of bad behavior and, in one case, demanding to see their wedding certificate. To many Pakistanis, the images evoked comparisons with the Taliban. The chairman of Samaa TV, Zafar Siddiqui, said Monday that he could not “absolve such behavior irrespective of ratings the show was getting.”

headline: One Country, Two Systems? Not Lately
text: HONG KONG — It pretty much started with a little girl from mainland China spilling some noodles onto the floor of a Hong Kong subway car.

headline: Fighting Intensifies in Syria
text: An anti-Assad group known as the Free Syrian Army, composed partly of army defectors, has attacked and violently resisted loyalist forces.

headline: NYT Front Page for 01/31/2012
text: NYT Front Page for 01/31/2012

headline: Colbert’s Super PAC Raises More Than $1 Million
text: Stephen Colbert’s quasi-satirical presidential bid has raised serious cash — over $1 million, as of Tuesday morning, the comedian announced.

headline: News Quiz | Jan. 31, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in today’s paper.

headline: Jan. 31, 1865 | House Passes 13th Amendment, Abolishing Slavery
text: On Jan. 31, 1865, the House of Representatives passed a constitutional amendment to abolish slavery. The amendment, which would become the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, read, “Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction.”

headline: Banking on the Future of Print

headline: Daily Report: A Global Jukebox Goes Digital
text: Technology has caught up to the imagination of Alan Lomax, the folklorist and ethnomusicologist whose life’s work was collecting traditional music from cultures across the world, Larry Rohter reports in Tuesday’s New York Times. Long before the Internet existed, Lomax wanted to create a “global jukebox” for the material he had found. Now, 10 years after his death, his archive — amounting to about 5,000 hours of sound recordings, 400,000 feet of film, 3,000 videotapes, 5,000 photographs and piles of manuscripts — is being digitized so that it can be accessed online. About 17,000 music tracks will be available for free streaming by the end of February, and later some of that music may be for sale as CDs or digital downloads.

headline: The Giants History Countdown: Running Back Tandems
text: Throughout the week, we will be ranking the Giants’ 1934, 1938, 1956, 1986, 1990 and 2007 N.F.L. championship teams in various categories. The 1920s teams are not included because of severe differences in the game and the league. In this installment, we rank the running back tandems, whether they are rotations, committees, or old-fashioned three-back attacks. For the teams of yesteryear, “tailbacks” who acted as de facto quarterbacks are counted in the mix.6. 1934 Giants: Harry Newman had a short, modestly distinguished career as a 179-pound A-formation tailback (by today’s standards, a Tebow). He led the league in nearly every passing category in 1933, but in 1934 he threw just one touchdown and 12 interceptions, statistics that were almost as bad then as they are today. Ken Strong was an All-Pro fullback/defensive back for both the Giants and the Staten Island Stapletons, then an N.F.L. team, and Strong rushed for 431 yards and 6 touchdowns. His best years were behind him by 1934, though he stayed with the Giants as a placekicker until after World War II. The third member of the backfield was Wee Willie Smith, who played just one season in the N.F.L. (He is not to be confused with the legendary basketball player of the same name.) You do not have to be an expert in 1930s football to realize that a backfield with one player who played just one season and another who played just three seasons belongs low on any all-time list.

headline: Risotto With Red Kale and Red Beans

The first time I made it, without the red beans, the finished product reminded me of the way the rice looks when I make red beans with rice. So I decided to add red beans to the mix, which provide a healthy dose of protein and fiber, as well as color.
