headline: Who’s Financing the ‘Super PACs’
text: The Times is tracking donors to “super PACs” as they filed regular reports with the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Howard Strikes Wrong Note in Magic Slide
text: It’s getting late early in Orlando, as the Magic continue to disappoint and the sign-and-trade rumors swirl around center Dwight Howard. The Magic stand third in the Southeast Division at 12-9 and are sliding backward on a four-game losing streak and five losses out of their past six games.

headline: Stanley Is Back on Course, and at Peace
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. – “Another day, another week,” Kyle Stanley said softly as he sat down for the second time in 40 hours to talk about his worst moment in golf.

headline: Rust Is His Palette: The Automotive Art of Bo Lundvang
text: Long the scourge of car collectors in the Salt Belt states, rust has become a subject of aesthetic interest in recent years, with various concours adding juried categories with euphemistic names like Preservation Class. A Swedish artist, Bo Lundvang, is channeling the trend into an oxidized form of pop art, projecting desirable automobiles against a backdrop of rusted steel.

headline: Letterman Anniversary Is Like a Low-Key Guest
text: 5:12 p.m. | Updated David Letterman will celebrate 30 years as a late-night television host on Wednesday, though without much fanfare.

headline: Cuomo Bets Heapings of Fermented Milk on the Giants
text: Certain foods are emblematic of New York: a thin pizza slice with grease enough to soak through a paper plate, a hot dog bursting with condiments, and the impossible-to-recreate New York bagel.

headline: Caucus Video: The Florida Primary
text: Florida Republicans cast ballots as Newt Gingrich tries to hold off Mitt Romney’s march to the party’s presidential nomination. Jim Rutenberg reports.

headline: In Talks on Greek Bailout, Eyes Turn to Central Bank
text: BRUSSELS — The European Central Bank may forgo future profits on its Greek bonds as efforts remain under way to fill a financial hole that has been obstructing a second bailout for Greece.

headline: Worms, Roots and Anxiety Lead Three Young Scientists to the Intel Finals
text: UPDATED | Mimi Yen's father thought she was just playing with worms. But Ms. Yen’s countless hours spent in New York University’s Center for Genomics and Systems Biology lab was far from play. Her experiments with worms shed light on how genes control behavior. And her work earned her a place as a finalist in the Intel Science Talent Search, along with HuiHui Fan of Stuyvesant and Danielle Goldman of Bronx Science. Here are their stories.

headline: Look of The Moment | Keira Knightley
text: The Look: Natural Glow. A fresh face and simple upsweep echo the quiet elegance of this crimson keyhole dress.

headline: Accommodating Pregnant Women at Work
text: Depending on your circumstances, being pregnant and needing just that little bit of extra accommodation at work — more bathroom breaks, a stool at the counter, a break from the requirement that all retail employees share in the lifting of boxes and climbing of ladders — could mean you’re out of a job. Laws that ban discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace don’t require that any special needs be accommodated, and the Americans With Disabilities Act, which would, doesn’t apply to most pregnant women.

headline: A Conservative Report Card, With Facts Disputed
text: In a last-minute effort to derail Mitt Romney, conservative evangelical groups say they e-mailed a “report card” on the candidates’ “real positions” on marriage and moral standards on Monday to 1.6 million Florida residents, mainly self-identified Christians and pastors. The message is signed by the American Family Association, which strongly opposes same-sex marriage and equal rights for homosexuals, and claims to list the candidates’ positions on 10 issues.

headline: Is Your Building Gobbling Energy?
text: Want to know who’s an energy hog?

headline: Crown
text: Crown opened just after Labor Day, and already everyone looks as if they have been coming here forever.

headline: Government Unions and Layoffs
text: As my colleague Steven Greenhouse wrote in Saturday’s paper, the share of workers who are unionized fell again last year, to 11.8 percent.

headline: The Comforts of Millionaires
text: IT looked as if fireflies had been released into the dining room.

headline: Iowa G.O.P. Chairman Resigns in Wake of Caucus Controversy
text: DES MOINES – The chairman of the Republican Party of Iowa announced his resignation on Tuesday after mounting pressure over his handling of the results of the caucuses that kicked off the presidential nominating process this month.

headline: HBO Renews ‘Luck’ for Another Season
text: In what looked like a sure thing given the creative pedigree involved, HBO announced on Tuesday that it had renewed its new horse racing drama “Luck,” starring Dustin Hoffman and produced by Michael Mann and David Milch, for a 10-episode second season with a premiere date set for January 2013. The first episode has drawn 3.3 million total viewers over multiple airings including the 1.1 million viewers who tuned in on Sunday. The quick turnaround has become standard operating procedure for HBO; “Game of Thrones,” “Boardwalk Empire” and “Treme” were also renewed two days after their debuts.

headline: Einhorn Case Highlights Britain’s Broader Definition of Insider Trading
text: The settlement of charges filed by the Financial Services Authority, Britain’s financial regulator, against David Einhorn and his hedge fund, Greenlight Capital, for trading on confidential information highlights how malleable the term “insider trading” can be.

headline: HBO Renews ‘Luck,’ Stronger in Reviews, So Far, Than Ratings
text: HBO, citing many favorable reviews, moved quickly to renew for a second season the new racetrack-based drama “Luck.”

headline: And Now, Here’s Ocho
text: INDIANAPOLIS – When the Patriots advanced to the Super Bowl, a scheduling conflict emerged for Chad Ochocinco. Instead of asking questions at Media Day, as he has done the last two years as the lead reporter for the Ochocinco News Network, he would be answering them.

headline: Connecting the Dots: Mapping Apple’s Development and Manufacturing Process
text: March 19, 2012 | Updated

headline: Giants’ Williams Says Foot Injury Not an Issue
text: INDIANAPOLIS – Actual news can be hard to come by on Media Day at the Super Bowl and this year’s version was, for the most part, no exception. There were people in costumes, a variety of folks using props as they conducted interviews and a slew of offbeat questions including one, which was posed to several players, about which famous actor would best portray Coach Tom Coughlin in a movie (my first thought: Jon Voight).

headline: Time Warner Cable Campaign Focuses on Brand More Than Services
text: Time Warner Cable is continuing to promote services beyond conventional cable television with a new brand-image campaign that urges customers to “Enjoy better.”

headline: At U.N., Pressure Is on Russia for Refusal to Condemn Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — The battle over Syria moved to the United Nations on Tuesday with Western powers and much of the Arab world confronting Russia and its allies in the Security Council over their refusal to condemn the Syrian government for its violent suppression of popular protests.

headline: The Caucus | The Retiree Vote
text: Ashley Parker reports from the Romney event in The Villages, Fla., where many residents remained undecided in today’s primary.

headline: A Debt Market’s Slow Recovery Is Burdened by New Regulation
text: Collateralized loan obligations may seem at first to be nothing but a throwback to private equity’s “golden era” of enormous leveraged buyouts.

headline: A Start-Up Rewards Savers, Not Spenders
text: We are accustomed to earning credit card points for spending money. A start-up called SaveUp wants to flip that idea on its head and give prizes for saving money instead.

headline: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast
text: In this edition of the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast, Christopher Botta looks ahead to the second half of the season with Adam Rotter of SNYRangersBlog and John Forslund, the play-by-play announcer for the Hurricanes.

headline: Caucus Video: The Retiree Vote
text: Ashley Parker reports from the Romney event in The Villages, Fla., where many residents remained undecided in today’s primary.

headline: Four N.F.L. Concussion Lawsuits Consolidated
text: A federal judicial panel has consolidated four lawsuits started by hundreds of former N.F.L. players who have sued the league and helmet makers, alleging that they deliberately hid critical information about the dangers of concussions and hits to the head. The combined case will be tried in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia before Judge Anita B. Brody.

headline: Home Economics
text: Catherine Rampell, a business reporter, interviews Motoko Rich, a reporter, about how the continuing decline of housing prices weighs on the economy.

headline: Indiana Legislation Could Create Awkward Situation for N.F.L. Players
text: INDIANAPOLIS — With the Indiana Senate poised to vote – and almost certainly pass – a “right to work” bill on Wednesday, the N.F.L. players’ union could find itself in an awkward position.

headline: Eli Manning Talks About Peyton, but Not His Future
text: INDIANAPOLIS – Can you name all 12 schools in the SEC? Could you have done it when you were six years old and had your big brother rapping his knuckles on your chest?

headline: Confident Rolle Is Out of the Prediction Game
text: It was a kinder, gentler Antrel Rolle at the Super Bowl media day, no matter how hard the contingent of reporters tried to push for something bolder.

headline: Islanders to Play Devils in Preseason Game at New Arena in Brooklyn
text: Perhaps hinting that they are seriously considering alternatives to Nassau County, the Islanders will be the home team in the first N.H.L. game at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Officer Accused of Stealing iPads
text: A New York City police officer was arrested on Monday and accused by prosecutors of committing a crime while he was arresting a suspect.

headline: The Insider | Tricia Donegan
text: Tricia Donegan, 41, met Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta when Germanotta was a New York University student taking classes at Donegan’s Bikram yoga studio on Allen Street. Germanotta became Lady Gaga, and Donegan became her private teacher. As part of the Yoga Freedom Project, Donegan will teach at a yoga class tonight in New York City that benefits the Somaly Mam Foundation, an organization dedicated to fighting human trafficking. She told The Moment how she fell for Bikram, how yoga can change the world and what makes Lady Gaga a successful yogini.

headline: Singapore, Point of Departure
text: CHILI crab may be the world’s messiest national dish. Dismantling a massive crustacean slathered in spicy sauce at one of Singapore’s street-food stalls can require more napkins than you have fingers. It’s thrilling, as is much of the dining in Singapore, where dozens of vendors share a clamorous stage at one of the country’s government-run hawker centers.

headline: In a First, a Woman Will Be Senate Parliamentarian
text: For the first time, a woman is going to be the parliamentarian for the Senate.

headline: Faulk Has Fans in High Places
text: On the occasion of his fifth Super Bowl appearance, Patriots running back Kevin Faulk was awarded one of the fourteen main booths on the field of Lucas Oil Stadium for Media Day.

headline: Charles Grassley’s Curious Obsession
text: As the highest-ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Charles Grassley of Iowa should be obsessing over the Constitution, the rule of law, and other weighty matters. Instead, he’s obsessing over Virginia Seitz, the assistant attorney general for the Office of Legal Counsel.

headline: As Florida Votes, Paul Campaigns Elsewhere
text: LAS VEGAS — The only contest Representative Ron Paul is likely to win in Florida on Tuesday is this: highest ratio of votes to time spent campaigning there.

headline: Breast Cancer Surgery Rules Are Called Unclear
text: Nearly half of women who had lumpectomies for breast cancer had second operations they may not have needed because surgeons have been unable to agree on guidelines for the most common operation for breast cancer, a new study finds. It also hints that some women who might benefit from further surgery may be missing out on it.

headline: A Sign Law Spurs Investment in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — An influx of new residents, stores, restaurants and hotels in Center City has largely bypassed Market East, the blocks of Market Street east of City Hall to Independence Mall.

headline: Five Dishes at Crown
text: Crown, an Upper East Side townhouse that has become a local joint for well-off neighbors, is the subject of my restaurant review this week. John DeLucie’s menu is all fairly familiar, which can lead to a bit of dullness around the edges, but a number of the dishes come together in ways that make you understand how classics get to be classics. Here are five that are worth ordering if you find yourself on East 81st Street with a spare hundred or two in your pocket.

headline: It Starts With Lip Gloss
text: THE other day at Kimara Ahnert’s makeup and skin care studio on Madison Avenue, Sloane Kratzman, 12, was sitting in a chair, having blush applied to her cheeks, her legs dangling above the floor. She had been driven in after school from Greenwich, Conn., by her mother, Teresa Kratzman, a longtime friend of Ms. Ahnert’s, for her first makeup application lesson.

headline: French Court to Review Genocide Bill
text: PARIS — France’s Constitutional Council said Tuesday that it would rule on the constitutionality of criminalizing the denial of a genocide of Armenians during World War I, after receiving appeals signed by dozens of lawmakers from across the political spectrum.

headline: Assembly Investigating Transportation Group
text: ALBANY — The State Assembly has begun an investigation of a little-known government body that plays a major role in setting transportation policy in New York City and its suburbs.

headline: Barnes & Noble Won’t Sell Books From Amazon Publishing
text: In a sharp answer to Amazon and its expanding publishing efforts, Barnes & Noble said on Tuesday that it would not sell books released by Amazon Publishing in its bookstores.

headline: Scene City: Famous Faces Who Posed for Sandro Kopp
text: Tilda Swinton, Frances McDormand, Michael Stipe and others celebrate artist’s gallery show.

headline: Frankies vs. Deen
text: AFTER the hue and cry following Paula Deen’s announcement that she has Type 2 diabetes and would become a paid spokeswoman for a drug company, a question nags: Is the food that emerges from her kitchen really less healthy than the cuisine from other restaurants?

headline: Party Is in New York; a Host Is on Skype
text: For an artist who lives in remote northern Scotland, Sandro Kopp is very well connected. But then, you would be, too, if Tilda Swinton was your girlfriend and you had a score of famous faces willing to pose for you.

headline: To the Police, an Embezzler; to a Shop Owner, a ‘Lovely Person’
text: The woman first entered Mary-Anne’s Irish Gift Shop, in the Bronx, sometime in the 1990s, thrilled at having happened upon the boutique and its scarves and sweaters, pewter and pottery and Celtic photography.

headline: Dan Burton to Leave House After 30 Years
text: Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, announced Tuesday that he would retire at the end of the year after three decades in the House.

headline: A $1 Billion ‘Model’ Employee Education Program
text: Big companies often seem to be conflicted — if not two-faced — when it comes to their workers. They pay lip service to their employees as their most cherished corporate assets, yet they routinely shed workers.

headline: Will AT&T Get Rid of the Yellow Pages?
text: AT&T has hinted that it may sell off parts of its business that are performing poorly. Perhaps the most obvious candidate is the good old-fashioned Yellow Pages. Yes, the fat phone book that you probably toss into the recycling bin after it has been out on the porch for a few weeks.

headline: Quakes and U.S. Reactors: An Analytic Tool
text: With the release of a computer model of all known geologic faults east of Denver, nearly all of the nuclear power plants in the United States are about to embark on a broad re-evaluation of their vulnerability to earthquakes. The new mapping is the first major update of the fault situation for plants since 1989.

headline: Reviewing Masak
text: Some Singaporean food shouts for attention, some speaks more softly. Masak in the East Village, the subject of this week’s $25 and Under column, serves the latter. The small dining room is modestly decorated, free of gewgaws and garish bottles of hot sauce, and the spiciest and most pungent flavors of Singapore’s wildly diverse cuisine have been tempered. The bright open kitchen, however, offers an excitement all its own.

headline: My Oscar Picks: Jeffrey Eugenides
text: Our Oscar ballot is online and more than 15,000 of you have filled it out so far. The Carpetbagger is asking a few notable names — authors, television and Broadway stars, newscasters — to join you and then talk to us about their Oscar picks.

headline: Q&A: Getting the Gray Out of iPhoto
text: Q.

headline: After the Lunar New Year, Schools in Chinatown May See More Students
text: Principals of public schools in Chinatown say they see an influx of new students in the weeks and months after the Lunar New Year holiday, which took place last week.

headline: Amazon’s Revenues Disappoint
text: Amazon.com’s plans for world domination hit a slight bump on Tuesday.

headline: Modern Love à la Shaw, From His Life
text: In a Victorian London galvanized by “A Doll’s House,” a rake is caught between the woman he loves and the woman who loves him. All are members of the Ibsen Club, where men and women may socialize, provided they are committed to more “advanced,” modern relationships. Eventually, though, all learn that each alternative — marriage or an idealized, unrealized courtship of equals — carries its own disappointments.

headline: Federal Donuts
text: Doughnuts and fried chicken under one roof in Philadelphia.

headline: Obama Campaign Releases Names of Bundlers
text: In keeping with his practice — and unlike any of the Republican candidates for president — President Obama on Tuesday volunteered an updated list of his “bundlers,” wealthy donors who gather checks from their networks of friends, family members and business associates.

text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Facebook Said to Be Planning for I.P.O. Filing on Wednesday
text: 6:02 p.m. | Updated Facebook plans to file the prospectus for its initial public offering on Wednesday, according to people briefed on the matter, finally kicking off one of the most anticipated stock sales of the social networking era.

headline: Gronkowski Greets News Media Without a Boot
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski was wearing a sneaker and not a boot on his injured left ankle Tuesday when he met with the news media. Gronkowski, who was injured during the A.F.C. championship game against the Ravens, said it was not a gamesmanship ploy.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Humor and Rethinking the Car
text: Here are the interesting things that the tech reporters and editors for The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. Find more Scuttlebot items here.

headline: Model in Anti-Obesity Ad Criticizes the Campaign
text: Another of the overweight models appearing in ads from New York City’s health department — one who did not have a limb edited off — criticized the campaign, saying that the ads will not have the desired effect.

headline: For Top-Ranked Wisconsin Women, a Big Victory and a Big Crowd
text: Throughout the college hockey season, Slap Shot will feature reports about some of the country’s top-ranked teams.

headline: Chips, Translated From the Spanish
text: Dare we suggest elitist chips to go with workaday beer and dips? From Spain come uncommonly flavorful but light potato chips fried in olive oil. Their producer grows its own potatoes at high altitude east of Madrid and offers the chips in organic and conventional varieties, seasoned with sea salt. After tasting a third version, dusted with Spanish paprika, you may forswear barbecue-flavor chips.

headline: New Condiments With Kick
text: Every Super Bowl spread needs a kick, and that’s where the spreads and sauces come in. Saucy by Nature, a new line of condiments, makes some that can transform the usual fare.

headline: A Rare Public Lament for Lost Earmarks
text: One of the things House Republicans are most proud of is banishing earmarks from their bills, including, notably, the current version of an infrastructure and transportation bill, which has traditionally been a veritable stew pot of pork for member’s districts.

headline: The Ground Where Brady Sat
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Tom Brady’s podium stood on hallowed ground Tuesday at Media Day — at least for Colts fans.

headline: Students at Claremont McKenna More Worried About Reputation Than Rankings
text: CLAREMONT, Calif. — Students at Claremont McKenna College acknowledged on Tuesday that revelations that a senior administrator had inflated SAT scores submitted to college ranking guides was not the best way to make headlines. But they also defended their school, which has climbed to No. 9 among liberal arts colleges in the U.S. News & World Report.

headline: In Last Quarter of 2011, Gingrich Rakes In Nearly $10 Million
text: Newt Gingrich raised nearly $10 million in the final three months of 2011, according to reports his campaign filed with the Federal Election Commission on Tuesday. That is roughly triple what he raised in the first six months of his campaign, and his spokesman, R.C. Hammond, said Mr. Gingrich had raised an additional $5 million in January.

headline: The Hottest Item at the Super Bowl Is Hand Knit
text: INDIANAPOLIS – The must-have souvenir from the first few days of Super Bowl week is not a team jersey or a miniature helmet. And it is not for sale, although one person has offered $200 for one and players and team executives have clamored to get them for themselves and their wives.

headline: A Gathering for Both Conversing and Playing
text: Among opportunities to hear music by the composer David Lang performed live, the best are those in which he is invited to talk about his works. Genial, droll and articulate, Mr. Lang has a knack for making the disparate impulses and methods that mingle in his music seem not just appropriate but also inevitable.

headline: A Firing Offense
text: Last Friday, we ran an editorial about East Haven, Conn., a charming New England town where the police force harasses Latinos and the mayor is an incompetent fellow who makes racist jokes. The Federal Bureau of Investigation had arrested four police officers on charges of terrorizing the town’s Hispanic neighborhoods, stopping and detaining people, searching businesses without cause, beating people in handcuffs, smashing a man’s head into a wall.

headline: Heroism and Hell: War as Told by Hollywood and by Soldiers
text: Whether you prefer your war stories low key or over the top, hesitant or harrowing, “Gonna See a Movie Called Gunga Din” has you covered.

headline: Italian Marathon, Pretty and Challenging
text: The title of the marathon of guitar music presented by the New York Guitar Festival at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday was “Bell’Italia,” and there was not a moment in the three-and-a-half-hour evening session that was less than beautiful.

headline: Chrysler Readies New Mopar Mods for Chicago Auto Show
text: CENTER LINE, Mich. — On Tuesday, the Chrysler Group commemorated the 75th anniversary of its Mopar performance parts division by showing four vehicles here at the division’s headquarters, to be introduced officially at the Chicago auto show next month.

headline: Fox News Marks a Decade at No. 1 in Cable News
text: Fox News Channel has long surpassed its rivals in the cable news business and now it has an official round number to point to: Fox News has been No. 1 for a full decade.

headline: Florida Benchmarks From 2008
text: As we did with South Carolina, here — courtesy of Matthew Bloch, a New York Times graphics editor — are county-by-county results from the 2008 Republican primary in Florida for you to follow along with as results are reported tonight.

headline: Republican Chided Over Blog Says He Won’t Run for Senate
text: Marc Cenedella, a wealthy Republican businessman who was laying the groundwork for a United States Senate campaign in New York, announced on Tuesday that he had decided not to run.

headline: Hulu Returns to Super Bowl, as Ad Lineup Firms Up
text: 11:34 a.m. | Updated Five days before Super Bowl XLVI, the lineup of advertisers is being firmed up with the news on Tuesday that the video-streaming site Hulu will be buying commercial time.

headline: Live Coverage of the Florida Primary
text: Welcome to FiveThirtyEight’s live blog of Florida’s Republican primary. Polls in the state are closed, and we’ll be bringing you the results, data-driven observations, exit poll information and some historical perspective.

headline: Draft of Security Council Resolution on Syria
text: Following is a draft of the proposed United Nations Security Council resolution concerning Syria, as it was circulated among diplomats on Tuesday afternoon and provided to The New York Times.

headline: Physical Flickers of Light and Motion Animate Film Pioneers
text: It is probably impossible to recreate in modern audiences the wonder that the very earliest films must have incited. For us the poetry and pathos of those rudimentary artifacts — brief slices of life — come mainly from their mere survival, while the people in them, and the people who made them, are long gone.

text: The last polls in Florida do not close until 8 p.m. ET, but we’re learning what we can about the Republican electorate from the early exit polls.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Spring Secrets | Finding the Season’s Staples
text: The subtext for the arrival of a new season of clothes in stores and online — brace yourself, it’ll happen any day now — is one riddled with tough decisions like cost-per-wear calculations and heart-wrenching explorations of need versus want. The pieces you’ve earmarked in all of your favorite magazines — the bandeau tops and hot-shorts as suit separates, perhaps? — aren’t always the most practical investments. Sure, they’re perfect on glossy paper, but watch what happens when applied to plastic.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Allen West to Switch Districts
text: Representative Allen West, Republican of Florida, will switch Congressional districts to greatly increase his chances of winning re-election.

headline: The Hashtag Dresses Up
text: THE suit sections at most of New York’s major department stores remind me of funeral homes. The dark wood. The austerity. The hands-offness of the sales clerks, who will assist when asked, but who otherwise consider respectful distance to be an effective marketing technique. If you can afford these suits, the theory seems to go, then you must understand them. And if you understand them, then you want to be left to your wandering, your fingering, your discerning.

headline: Gupta Faces New Charges in Insider Trading Case
text: 7:55 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Warm, Hopeful Breeze Wafting From Juilliard
text: A couple of planets in the small cosmos of early music seemed out of alignment last week when an obscure French Baroque opera passed through New York, and the great French Baroque specialist William Christie was here to conduct. For they appeared on competing stages.

headline: A Crime of Genocide Denial
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting for Gender Equality on the Battlefield
text: Suspended from her position in December, the commandant of the United States Army’s drill sergeant school is currently under investigation for an undisclosed personnel issue. Command Sgt. Maj. Teresa L. King was the first female commandant of the school, a somewhat high-profile position that is the source for the Army‘s pool of drill sergeants. These soldiers, who are typically men, are responsible for training thousands of new recruits each year. Sergeant Major King, known for her keen attention to detail and dogmatic demand for discipline, was named commandant in 2009. Since then, she has enjoyed some well-deserved popularity, including being named to Oprah Winfrey’s O Power List, as well as an appearance in the October 2010 issue of O, The Oprah Magazine.

headline: Your Film of Films: A Sweeping History of an Art
text: A glance at the nominees for best picture at this year’s Oscars will confirm that the movies, a forward-looking medium tumbling headlong into a digital future, find themselves in a moment of retrospection. It is not just that a majority of the nominees take place in lovingly imagined and carefully costumed versions of the past — that in itself is hardly new — but also that several look back with affection at earlier phases in the history of cinema.

headline: Disney Adds to Its India Investment With Takeover of UTV Software
text: LOS ANGELES – It’s full steam ahead for Mickey Mouse in India.

headline: Trailer: 'The Story of Film'
text: A preview of “The Story of Film: An Odyssey.”

headline: On Godly Grounds, a Prideful Flock
text: On the 13 acres surrounding the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine are a biblical garden, a fountain depicting the struggle between good and evil, and three longtime residents who spend their days wandering where they please: Jim, Phil and Harry.

headline: On ‘X Factor,’ 2 Judges and Host Get the Ax
text: Before he starts the second season of “The X Factor,” Simon Cowell is pressing the reset button.

headline: A Rapper Reborn Into a Whole New Status
text: Tall and gangly and with arms that seem impossibly long, the Atlanta rapper 2 Chainz is an endearing galoot, never menacing even when talking tough. Once upon a time, he was Tity Boi, of the rap duo Playaz Circle, but about a year ago, he switched his name, and with the change came new life.

headline: In Atlanta, Housing Woes Reflect Nation’s Pain
text: MARIETTA, Ga. — Housing prices continue to fall nationwide, despite a few modest signs of improvement. But not all markets are equal.

headline: Footnote
text: The soprano Angela Meade, above, has won the Beverly Sills Artist Award, a $50,000 prize for singers 25 to 40 who have appeared in featured roles at the Metropolitan Opera, the company said on Monday. Ms. Meade, 34, made her Met debut as Elvira in Verdi’s “Ernani” four years ago and will appear again in the role on Thursday in a new run of the opera.

headline: Gaining Power in Parliament, Islamists Block a Cairo Protest
text: CAIRO — The Muslim Brotherhood flexed its muscles here on Tuesday as hundreds of its young members linked arms to block a protest march from reaching Parliament while its lawmakers inside dominated the selection of leaders for legislative committees.

headline: The House That George Romney Built
text: Ithaca, N.Y.

headline: ‘A Wrinkle in Time’ Turns 50
text: “A Wrinkle in Time” turns 50 years old this year. That would make its heroine, Meg Murry, 63 years old, and her daughter, Polly O’Keefe (heroine of “An Acceptable Time”) probably near 40, since Meg had her first child young (in the style of many fictional heroines, whose romantic fate was often decided in their first book appearance).
